title: Richard Tufts to Wed Miss Lynda J. Farrar
description: CRAFTSBURY COMMON, Vt., Sept. 30Mr. and Mrs. William P. Farrar have an nounced the engagement of their adopted daughter, Miss Lynda Joyce Farrar, to Air man 1st Cl. Richard Edward Tufts, U.S.A.F., the adopted son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Burns Tufts of Scarborough, N. Y.

title: On the McGovern Endorsement
description: To the Editor:

title: Illinois Denied Accounting Of Dead Official's Estate
description: ELDORADO, Ill., Sept. 30 (AP)Judge Jack C. Morris of Circuit Court has dismissed a suit by the State of Illinois asking a full accounting of $3,5million estate of the late Secretary of State Paul Powell.

title: Bowling Green Tied, 1313
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Sept. 30 (AP)  Western Michigan scored twice in the final quar ter today to earn a 1313 tie with Bowling Green.

title: PATH OF BIG RIVER UNDER SEA TRACED
description: There is a great, deep river in the sea, probably the most voluminous on earth, and the United States has embarked on an ambitious, effort to trace its path and extent of flow through fall three of the major oceans.

title: Photography
description: ACOURSE in color slides will be taught by Hel en Mainzer at the Penn Sylvania Railroad YMCA in Penn Station (on first floor below LIAR infor mation booth, between tracks 5 and 6). The course will start the evening of Oct. 13, with registration the sane night between 6:30 and 7. Tuition will be $35 for the 10 sessions (Friday evenings) with Miss Manzei studying individual student's slides from 6 to 7 each evening, followed by group sessions from 7 to 9 For more infor mation write Miss Romayrie Chapman, 136 East 36th Street, New York, N. Y. 10016.

title: More I.B.M. Employes Sent To Teach Minority Students
description: Colleges serving Appalachia, MexicanAmericans and Ameri can Indians have been added to the faculty loan program sponsored by the International Business Machines Corporation, the company said.

title: MRS. KING GAINS FINAL AT PHOENIX
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 30 (AP)Mrs. Billie Jean King of Palmaire, Fla., and Mrs. Mar garet Court of Australia scored semifinal victories today in the Virginia SlimsPhoenix Thun derbirds women's tennis tour nament.

title: WALL STREET
description: One of the most controver sial issues to confront Wall Street in recent years in volves who should be al lowed to buy seats on stock exchanges. Now it appears that the matter is about to be resolved.

title: DutyFree Airport Shops Trouble Ahead
description: AMSTERDAM  A Swiss banker who specializes in currency arbitrage and car ries the latest price of the Turkish lira and the Indian rupee at his fingertips bought a bottle of Chanel No.5 at the Schiphol Airport shopping center here the other day while waiting for a flight to London.

title: Manhattan Harriers Win 28th Straight Dual Meet
description: Mike Keogh, Joe Savage, Pete Squires and Tony Colon led Manhattan to its 28th con secutive dual crosscountry victory yesterday as the Jaspers defeated Fairleigh Dickinson, 1549, at rainy Van Cortlandt Park.

title: SENATE GETS BILL TO CUT DRUG COSTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 Charging that the public and the Federal Government have been forced to pay inflated and dis criminatory prices for drugs, Senator Gaylord Nelson intro duced a bill this week to make chug patents available to all applicants under certain market conditions.

title: MISSISSIPPI DOWNS SOUTHERN MISS., 139
description: OXFORD, Miss., Sept. 30 (UPI)Greg Ainsworth scored on a 2yard run with 2 minutes 54 seconds left in the game today to salvage a 13.9 victory for Mississippi against surpris ingly, tough Southern Missis sippi.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  By giving the American people full access to the facts, of political financing, President Nixon declared last February as he signed the bill, this legislation will guard against campaign abuses and will work to build public confidence in the integrity of the electoral process.

title: COLUMBIA ROUTS FORHAM, 44 TO 0
description: New York collegiate football came back yesterday as Colum bia defeated Fordham, 440, at Baker Field.

title: Preps
description: KENT, Conn., Sept. 30Brett Whitcomb scored three times on passes of 35, 25 and 22 yards from three different quarter backs to pace Kent to a 40.0 victory over Canterbury. Joe Fernold added sixpointers on a. 15yard run and a 25yard pass.

title: New & Novel
description: The Australian outback pic tured in The Last Station has points of similarity with our own vanished frontier. The plains Down Under are as thick with kangaroo as the West was with buffalo, the aborigines are harshly treated, and life on a remote cattle station is hard and precarious. Bob and Troy are a pair of cowhands on a ranch 300 miles from the near est settlement, a onestreet town called Alice Springs. Their boss is a brute with a mailorder wife, and an insane mother kept chained in a back room. Life and death are seen through the eyes of Bob, an American vagabond who is as signed an admirably spare, lean prose.

title: SHOP TALK
description: PATERSONOf the three largest cities in the state Newark, Jersey City and Pat erson  only Paterson has shown an increase in popula tion during the last decade.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Newsboys' Captain, 52, Saluted by Asbury Park
description: ASBURY PARKThis city observed Captain Johnny Richardson Day Friday, honoring a 52yearold news boy who has been a popular figure here for decades; he started selling papers at the age of 5.

title: Wagner Halts Drexel, 97, On Schaefer's Field Goal
description: Wagner College stopped a Drexel University scoring drive in the final minute of the game to post a 97 victory yesterday at Fischer Memorial Field.

title: Series at Rutgers Signs 6 Foreign Music Groups
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  The 197273 concert series at Rutgers University here has an international air this year, with six music ensembles from as many foreign coun tries represented in two of the major series.

title: The Guest Word
description: Giorgio Bassani was walking down a street in the East Fifties, a fish out of Ferrara waters, when suddenly he spotted a lifesize blowup of Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers twirling cardboard mem ories for a dance studio one flight up, and he began to sing in English, Top hat, putting on my top hat, tying up my white tie, brushing off my tails. He pointed to Astaire and said in Italian, What elegance!, and the window re flected his own, his finely drawn features and carefully tailored jacket and un crinkled manners, something like his sentences, casual and yet thoughtout.

title: PILOTS ARE POLLED ON A NEW PROTEST
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)The Air Line Pilots As sociation is surveying pilot at titudes toward another broad scale shutdown of air service to protect the threat of hijack ing.

title: Mrs. Wiberg Has Son
description: A son was born Sept. 12 to Mr. and Mrs. Anders Wi berg of New York and Nas sau, the Bahamas, at the Harkness Pavilion. Mrs. Wi berg is the former Jane Dil lon McDermid of Scarsdale, N.Y. Her husband is Swedish vice consul to the Bahamas. The child has been named James McDermid.

title: Negus, a 16to1 Shot, Triumphs in the Cambridgeshire Stake a Newmarket
description: NEWMARKET, England, Sept. 30Negus, urged on by Philip Waldron, scored a photo finish victory today over Roy Bridge to win the Cambridge shire, returning $122,500 each to 14 Irish sweepstakes ticket holders.

title: City Fringe Costs Doubled in 5 Years
description: Fringe benefits for munici pal employestheir pensions, health plans and the likehave climbed to 28 per cent of the city's total labor costs, and went above $952million for the year ended June 30.

title: The nationalist vs. the integrationist
description: In the nineteenfifties, when there was growing talk about racial integration and officials at all levels were beginning to feel the impact of a rapidly developing civilrights movement, black people led by Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. boycotted the buses of Montgomery, Ala. The protest, which was ultimately won in the Federal courts, was aimed at ending segregated seating on the city buses.by the N.A.A.C.P. Fund in the Federal District Court, re versed by the Court of Ap peals, and is being appealed to the Supreme Court), as jeopardizing the eventual con trol by blacks of the city school system. Swinton says, This includes the power to make the major decisions about curriculum, personnel and general educational policy. Perhaps of almost equal im portance is control over the economic power represented by the budget of a large school district. This includes the ability to hire and to fill top salary positions, as well as the ability to make pur chases and to let construc tion contracts. The potential importance of these things for Black development is ex tremely great. Swinton con cludes: The movement to gain control over a number of significant American cities and the strategy of demand ing community control are much sounder strategies.

title: RHODE ISLAND RALLY BEATS BROWN, 2117
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 30 (AP)Buddy Denniston ran 82 yards with a punt return in the fourth quarter today to cap a strong Rhode Island comeback as the Rams handed Brown its 11th straight defeat 2117.

title: Poor Crop of Champagne
description: PARIS, Sept. 30 (Agence PrancePresse)This was a bad year for grapes in the cham pagne country with a harvest expected to be 25 per cent less than last year's, the champagne growers announced this week. The interprofessional commit tee of the champagne district said that the poor crop had forced authorities to increase the price of the grape used to make champagne by 22.9 per cent.

title: Roy Alciatore, Host of Antoine's, New Orleans Restaurant, Dead
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 30 Roy L. Alciatore, proprietor of Antoine's, the famous restau rant in the French Quarter, died yesterday. His age was 69.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  The Presidential race seems to be the only one in doubt at this stage, advised an other wise upbeat state campaign analysis distributed the other night when Sen ator George McGovern paid a visit to Sioux Falls, S. D.

title: WILLIAM C. OLSEN
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Sept., 30William C. Olsen, a State, Assemblyman in the late 1920's and a former Bronxville police justice, died last night at his home, 94 Warwick Road.

title: IN THE NATION
description: One day this year, eight inmates made nine suicide attempts in the mental observation ward on the tenth floor of the Tombs, New York City's jail for men awaiting trial. One day last week, another tenthfloor inmate passed up the opportunity to go up to the roof of the building to get some fresh air and recreation.

title: Unbeaten Iowa State Wins From New Mexico by 310
description: AMES, Iowa, Sept. 30 (UPI) Iowa State combined a stingy defense with flashy running by a sophomore back, Mike Stra chan, to defeat New Mexico, 310, today.

title: Diminished people
description: The life people live in the fiction of Joyce Carol Oates is both drab and electric, full of melodrama and yet curiously dull. Life is mysterious, a character thinks in her novel Them (1969), and then wonders why the mystery is cast in the forms of such diminished people. The suggestion is that melodrama is not nearly as un usual as we think, is hardly extraor dinary at all. It is all too often merely a familiar instance of life's heavy hand as a scenarist. We live with it, lose our friends and children by it, but we acquire none of the glamour that seems our due, we are as diminished as ever.

title: New Chamber Orchestra Is Set for New Season
description: JERICHO, L.I.A cham ber orchestra that was started here by a housewife is tuning up in preparation for its fourth season.

title: Music: Jazz Ensemble Loses Its Leader
description: AMITYVILLE, L.L.  The John Wilson Jazz Ensemble, a ninepiece jazz group made up primarily of Long Island music teachers who once played in, big bands, Is going through its first major crisis in the II years of its exist ence.

title: Notes: Carryon Searching
description: PASSENGERS on American Air lines and Trans World Airlines flights find it takes a little longer to get aboard these days due to scrutiny of their hand luggage, but the delay does not seem to prompt them to write angry letters to airline executives. In fact, officials of both carriers insist, the majority of travelers remain unruffled about the extra time needed to pass through the boarding gates. As one salesman said while a T.W.A. employe was rummaging through his briefcase, I'd sooner be held up down here than face a real holdup while we're in the air.

title: Balloonist's Widow, 77, Joins Seminary to Pursue, Long AmbitionPriesthood
description: When the former Jeannette Ridlon entered Bryn Mawr in 1914 she indulged a wild hope that, somehow, by the time she had earned her degree in philosophy, the Episcopal church would have decided to let women become priests and she would be able to enter the General Theological Seminary here.

title: Smoky Fire in Jersey Hotel
description: LAKEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 30 (UPI)Fourteen persons were treated for smoke inhalation in a fire late last night in a four story hotel here. A Fire Depart ment spokesman said the fire had been contained in the first floor manager's room of the Light Hotel, at First Street and Madison Avenue, but that thick black smoke had engulfed the entire building.

title: Richard Scarry's Funniest Storybook Ever By Richard Scarry. Illustrated. Unpaged. New York: Random House. $3.95. (Ages 3 to 6)
description: Much as water seeks its own level, each new Richard Scarry picture andword compendium unerringly finds its audiencealmost any child between the ages of 3 and 6. The ideal Scarry viewer can be counted on to devote from 15 to 30 rapt minutes poring over one or another of the illustratorauthor's bright and busy outsized volumes. It matters little which. Like Volkswagens, this year's model looks a good deal like last year'sor next year's.

title: Mary De Witt Diebold Is Wed To Richard Sutton, a Solicitor
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 30Miss Mary De Witt Diebold, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Robert Diebold, was married here this evening to Rich ard Manners Sutton, son of John Charles Ludlow Man ners Sutton of Scarborough, Yorkshire, England, and the late Mrs. Daphne Agnes Sut ton. The ceremony was per formed in St. Paul's Epis copal Cathedral by the Very Rev. Elton O. Smith, the dean.

title: Recordings
description: THIS past summer I de rived a great deal of pleasure from the is suing of two vocal surveysone, a single disk devoted to Ljuba Welitsch that included, among other novelties, a hitherto unfa miliar, preReinerinAmerica performance of the Final Scene from Salome, and the other, a tworecord pack age of arias by Lauritz Mel chior put on shellac in Eu rope during the late 1920's and early 1930's. The com pany responsible for these treats is the German label Dacapo, and it has now fol lowed up with three very worthwhile releases whose subjects are Maria Cebotarl, Lotte Lehmann and Marcel Wittrisch.

title: BLAST ON U.S. SNIP NEAR DMZ KILLS 19
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sun day, Oct. 1  An explosion ripped through a gun turret early today on the heavy cruis er Newport News, killing 19 sailors and injuring 10, the United States Navy announced.

title: Elizabeth Britton Bride in Hartford
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 30 Miss Elizabeth Wood. Pritton, daughter of Charles P. Brit ton 2d and the late Mrs. Britton, and Dr. Frederick H. Lovejoy Jr. of Boston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lovejoy. of Concord, Mass., were married here this afternoon in the Asylum Hill Congregational. Church by the Rev. Bernard T. Drew.

title: 5 MALE TEACHERS CHARGE SEX BIAS
description: The State Division of Human Rights is investigating charges of five parttime physicaledu cation instructors In Queens that they were discriminated against for reasons of sex when the local school board decided to hire women instructors in their place.

title: Views of the Review
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Are Today's Composers Adrift In a Void?
description: As always at the start of each season, the perennial debate about the plight of contemporary music has come flowing turgidly across these pages, clogged with soggy chunks of familiar polemic, invective, casuistry, harangue and prophecy. It would foolish to presume that I or anyone else could clean out the well  worn channel it courses through by single handedly dipping out so much detritus we could see the bottom of this subject. Any discussion of modern music is doomed to be rather muddy since modern ma sic is a cloudy term nowadays and covers a turbulent variety of shifting, roiling styles. Still, someone must begin somewhere for the sake of what I really think we should call esthetic ecology.

title: South Carolina Triumphs Over Memphis State, 347
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 30 (AP)Dobby Grossman, play ing in his first collegiate varsity football game, threw three touchdown passes to Mike Haggard to spark South Caro lina to a 347 rout of Memphis State tonight.

title: NOTRE DAME TOPS PURDUE BY 3514
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 30 (AP)A sophomore, Tom Clem ents, punctured Purdue with his passing and the young Notre Dame, defense continued to im prove today as the 10thranked Irish smashed the Boilermakers, 3514.

title: GUERRILLAS UPSET BY SADAT'S OFFER
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 30 The offer by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt to recognize a Palestinian government in exile, if one is formed, has sown confusion and divisions in the ranks of the Palestinian guerrilla groups.

title: To Minn, illumination is nonexistent
description: Great stories and novels have been written about no bodies, solitaries, fantasts, the disappointed and the trapped. Why not about women at home alone with their kids, when every one of those categories is populous with housewives? Is there something about this subject that makes small novels, when fiction of cosmic, diabolical scope can take off from one room? It can't be that women don't dream; maybe it's that many of us dream so hesi tantly that even our failures lack grandeur and absurdity. To someone like Marian Engel's nonheroine (antiheroine is too strong), disappointment comes not as an adversary but as a sour, helpful mother who was expected all along. It might still be possible to write a really good novel about a Minn Burge, but it would take per spective, a certain caustic com passion and distance from the character which this Canadian author lacks. Without it, her novel suffers from its protag onist's limitations instead of illuminating them.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Grambling Wins, 360
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI) Matthew Reed passed for 221 yards and three touchdowns to day as Grambling routed Prairie View, 360. A crowd of 20,101 watched the game in Robert F. Kennedy stadium.

title: A TwoPlane Family Flies What It Builds
description: PITTSTOWN  When Ed and Valerie Mahler want to visit Mrs. Mahler's brother in Oneonta, N.Y., they pack a picnic lunch, deck out their two daughters in their visit ing best, walk a couple of hundred feet from their home here in this rural Hun terdon County community to their private hangar, get in their homemade monoplane and fly across the border. Time: Less than an hour. In an auto: Over five hours.

title: SOVIET ADVANCE ON MISSILE SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 Wellplaced Administration of ficials have reported that, the Soviet Union has tested an ad vanced guidance system for its new longerrange submarine launched missile that should substantially improve its accu racy.

title: About Pro Football
description: The big game today is In Minnesota, the big doubt in Atlanta. The Minnesota Vik ings and the Miami Dolphins, both as likely a pair of play off candidates as one can find, meet at Bloomington in a nationally televised game that will be seen here over Channel 4, start ing at 4 P. M.

title: Local
description: Ron Porcello put on a scor ing exhibition to pace Gorton to a 2614 victory over Ford ham Prep. The halfback scored on a 19yard run, a 40yard touchdown pass play, and 75yard kickoff return. He also ran for Gorton's only conver sion.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market finally showed some snap last week; thanks to a midweek rally blossoming out of rumored Vietnam peace developments. Later, these rumors fell to earth, with both sides denying that a ceasefire was at hand.

title: Drysdale Eliminates Ashe In Coast Semifinal, 75, 62
description: ALAMO, Calif., Sept. 30 (AP) Australia's John Newcombe and South Africa's Cliff Drys dale will meet tomorrow in the $10,000 Redwood Bank ten nis tournament final.

title: Poverty Fund Drive Called Failure on L.I.
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I.The failure of a recent fund drive by the Economic Opportu nity Commission of Nassau County has been attributed by John Kearse, executive director of the commission, to a serious apathy.

title: A logical maze of levels
description: Walls have been disappearing in the design of houses for several decades. The first disappearance was when the dining area moved into the living room in the open plan. Then, kitchen walls became low counters and the kitchen, too, joined the major living complex. Now walls are tumbling down all through the house. Cutouts and interior win dows open rooms to each other as well as to levels above and below. Paradoxically, this openness can render interior spaces so complex that new owners need time to find their way around. In this glasspierced house on Martha's Vineyard, the main living area is crisscrossed by a network of bridges and levels. The living room (top, left) is half a flight up from the dining room (below). The bridge over the living room links the twin staircases that serve the two wings.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: George Lois, a Greek kid in an Irish neighborhood who would fight at the drop of greaseball, becomes the boy wonder at Doyle Dane Bern bach and one of the top art directors on Mad Ave. In racy, sometimes excruciating prose (although it improves as it goes along) he details a string of successes (Volkswagen's Think Small) and, all told, takes one long ego trip for himself. Only, unlike advertis ing, it's true.

title: COURT BACKS H.U.D. ON GRIEVANCE RULES
description: OMAHA, Sept. 30The lease and grievance procedure regu lations of the Department of Housing and Urban Develop ment have been ruled valid in a reversal of a lower court decision.

title: Housing Unit to Test Private Guards
description: The city's Housing Authority will begin an experiment soon to see if its own police force can be replaced by or supple mented with cheaper private guards.

title: Nassau South
description: Maybe it was the rain, may be it was the earlyseason jit ters, but whatever the case, 11 teams failed to score a touch down in the 15 football games that took place on the south shore of Nassau County yester day. Nine of the shutouts came in interleague competition.

title: DUKE VANQUISHES VIRGINIA, 3713
description: DURHAM, N. C., Sept. 30 (AP)Steve Jones scored three touchdowns and Hal Spears, a freshman quarterback passed for two other's today as thrice beaten Duke defeated Virginia, 3713, in an Atlantic Coast Con ference football game.

title: P.E. Guernsey Jr. Plans to Marry Barbara Hunter
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 30  Miss Barbara Spring. Hunter and Peter E. Guernsey Jr., graduates of Lake. Forest College, plan to be married Dec. 9.

title: CONRAD GAINS EDGE IN LARCHMONT SAIL
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 30 Peter Conrad of Killingworth, Conn., won both Finn Class races on Long Island Sound to day at the opening of the Larchmont Yacht Club linvita tion small boat regatta.

title: Crooks: The American McCormack
description: An Appraisal

title: Functional plus . . .
description: The major direction in furniture design today is toward greater simplicity, combining more pieces of freestanding furniture in one functional form. The sofa, above (shown both front and back), links several loosecushion settees in a polystyrene frame. The frame wraps around the seating units to form end tables; the back has niches for books and storage. The end tables telescope so that the sofa units can be arranged in wide or shorter curves. Swing one of the units around to face its partner and you've gained a double bed. The unit, was designed by Italian Cini Boeri. Prices vary with components; as shown, $1,920 at Knoll Associates.* The undulating sofa, below, does away with the need for individual chairs and ottomans. They're all included in a selfcontained conversation area. The stretch velour cover hugs the curves of the polyurethane units in a glovetight fit. $3,514 at Stendig.*

title: Law
description: For centuries the man In the black robes has fixed the defendant's sen tencewhat else, after all, is a judge for? And who else could do it? Rhetor ical questions: In America, at least, a man has a right to have his fate de cided by a judge.

title: Suffolk's Income Level Is Rated 5th in the State
description: One third of Suffolk Coun ty's 266,000 families had an annual income exceeding $15,000 in 1970, a level of prosperity exceeded by only four other counties in the state.

title: Miss Wallace Bride of W. S. Browne Jr.
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 30Miss Margaret Elizabeth Wallace, daughter of Edward Corbett Wallace of New York and Greenwich, was married here this afternoon to William Schenck Browne Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Browne of Flemington, N. J. The Rev. Vincent J. O'Connor per formed the ceremony at the St. Timothy Roman Catholic Chapel.

title: Karen Kaufteil Engaged
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 30Mr. and Mrs. Theodore R. Kaufteil have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Karen Kauf teil, to Robert Brilliant, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Brilliant of Newton Centre, Mass, The prospective bride is a senior at the University of Hartford, and her fianc, a University of Virginia grad uate, is completing studies for a master's degree in ac counting at Bentley College.

title: Williams Quits Rangers
description: Ted Williams, who was lured back into baseball four years ago in an attempt to work wonders with one of the major leagues' weakest franchises, quit yesterday as manager of the Texas Rang ers. Details on Page 4.

title: Scene of Asbury's '70 Riot Still Festers
description: ASBURY PARKViolence and death are common fare along Springwood Avenue, halfmile mosaic of gutted buildings, boardedup store fronts and empty strewn lots all of it a reminder of the ghetto rage that erupted three summers ago.

title: Jaycees and State Medical Unit Set joint V.D. Fight
description: LAKE SUCCESS, L. I., Sept. 30The Medial Society of the State of New York and the New York State Jaycees announced here this week that they would work together to expand edu cation on venereal disease pre vention for the two million junior and senior high school students in the state.

title: On the McGovern Endorsement
description: To the Editor:

title: Preps
description: BELMONT, Mass., Sept. 30 Milton scored in every period to spoil Belmont Hill's opening game of the season today, 266. Ed Giandomencio pounded out consistent yardage, including touchdowns from 2 and yards, to pace the visitors.

title: Polite Campaign of Lord of the Island
description: SHELTER ISLAND, L. I. It was not exactly a political fundraising party. The invi tations merely asked guests to come and meet Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. L. Gardiner at a reception the Andrew Fiskes were holding in honor of the Gardiners at Sylvester Manor, the 17th Century, 385acre baronial estate that dominates Shelter Island.

title: Gardens
description: GOOD things happen when good people get together. Rocke feller Center, The Parks Council and five con tainer manufacturers teamed up to show the city how it can make itself greener.

title: Carmona to Defend Title
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 (AP) Chango Carmona of Mexico City has signed to defend his World Boxing Council light weight championship against Rodolfo Gonzales of Long Beach, Calif., on Nov, 18. The title bout will be held at the Los Angeles Sports Arena.

title: Less clash and clatter
description: The interest in antiques shows no signs of diminishing as we enter the autumn of 1972. But pattern is being used judiciously with less clash and clatter. Designer Mario Buatta pairs a Chesterfield loveseat in a traditional chintz with a Victorian lounge chair in a squiggly print. The painted Italian armchair brings lightness and delicacy to the all upholstered scheme. Accessories account for the room's finished appearance. On the table (covered in a windowpane plaid) are a con temporary crystal lamp, plants in ceramic cachepots, tiny paintings on stands and small exotica. The antique country genre painting hangs from the ceiling molding on a silk satin ribbon against lacquered plaid walls.

title: Dumont Home Is Clock and Doll House
description: DUMONT  When a cou ple of inveterate collectors add up their finds and their visitors, and when the total comes to more than 200 clocks, more than 800 dolls and 300 visitors in a single 24hour period, what do they do? They open a museum.

title: V.D. Tests Rise in Bergen
description: RIDGEWOOD  In the first eight months of this year, Valley Center, an an nex of Valley Hospital serv ing 15 towns in affluent Northwest Bergen, examined nearly twice as many people, most of them teenagers, for venereal disease as in the whole of 1971.

title: Erving Plays, Excels As Hawks Triumph
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Sept. 30 (AP)Julius Erving, defying a National Basketball Associ ation directive not to play for the Atlanta Hawks, scored 42 points tonight to spark a 120 106 exhibitiongame victory over the Carolina Cougars.

title: Japanese Medicine Burned
description: TAIPEI, Sept. 30 (UPI)  More than 50 physicians and nurses at Keelung, a port city in northern Taiwan, burned about $5,000 worth of Japanese medicine today and vowed never to buy any Japanese goods again.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Music: Folk at Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICKTwo and a half years ago, two Rutgers University students started a folkmusic series with two basic ideas in mind: to have it lowpriced and to give concerts regularly.

title: A.B.A. Determined Not to Go Nameless
description: Activity in the American Basketball Association has been almost endless since the Indiana Pacers beat the New York Nets for the champion ship last May, but nothing contributed more to the league's well being than the acquisition of Billy Cunning ham and Charles O. Finley. They are the names the A.B.A., which opens its sixth season on Oct. 12, needs to offset the loss of its to players and scorers, Rick Barry, Charlie Scott, John Brisker, Jim McDaniels and possibly Julius, Erving.

title: On the McGovern Endorsement
description: To the Editor:

title: William and Mary Crushes Citadel, 3112
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 30 (AP)Bill Deery threw for two touchdowns, ran for a third and engineered two other scor ing drives as William and Mary's Indians today routed The Citadel's Bulldogs, 3112, in a raindrenched Southern Conference football game.

title: Cambodians Report Gains
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 30 (AP)Cambodian paratroop ers lifted the siege Of the small town of Samrong Yong on Highway 2 today. About three quarters of the 100man gar rison were killed or wounded in eight days of fighting which destroyed about half of the town, which is 20 miles south of Pnompenh.

description: For the bluejean crowd

title: Alexandra McAllister Is a Bride
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., Sept. 30  Miss Alexandra Joan McAllister, who is de scended from James McAl lister, a founder in 1864 of the marine towing firm of McAl lister Brothers, was married here this afternoon to Lieut. Gary Alan Woodfield, U.S.A. The Rev. John P. Callahan performed the ceremony in the Infant Jesus Roman Cath olic Church.

title: Preps
description: EAST HAMPTON, Mass., Sept. 30Mark McQuie and Ed Watts led Vermont Acad emy to a 3414 victory over Williston in the first game for both schools. McQuie threw a 67yard touchdown pass play to Gil Bennett and one of 52 yards to Watts, one of four touchdowns he scored.

title: Local
description: New Dorp, led by Jim Garcia, the tailback, and Pat Brande fine, the fullback turned back Susan Wagner, 13.0, Friday night. It was the first victory for New Dorp in two starts and the second loss for Wagner, playing its first varsity season.

title: The Screen: 'Where Does It Hurt?':Sellers Administrator in Hospital Farce Closet Capers Enliven Lackluster Lampoon
description: Peter Sellers and a staff of assorted comics doggedly try to make a laughing matter out of bloated hospital costs and medical monkeyshines in "Where Does It Hurt?" the farce exposed at the Cinerama and other theaters Friday. But most of the time they manage to be only frenetic, rather than funny.Rod Amateau, who was co-author of the book from which this picture was made, and served as the film's director, proceeded on the theory that speed, gags, explicit cracks and sex were sufficient to make life at "Vista Vue Hospital" hilarious. Unfortunately, the basically thin story line is overcomplicated by a plethora of plotting. And the film is not enhanced by the merely athletic performances.As the conniving hospital administrator. Peter Sellers blackmails his doctors and technicians into robbing patients blind, keeps a step ahead of a suspicious, hospital commissioner, dallies with willing nurses in linen closets and even steals from the Pepsi machine. But despite all the activity, Sellers gives the bland impression of simply walking through a pedestrian role.Rick Lenz is pleasantly confused as a young construction worker suddenly caught in this expensive, sterile trap. Jo Ann Pflug and Eve Bruce raucously compete for Sellers's favors, while Pat Morita, Paul Lambert and Harold Gould are among the men in white laboring for laughs.In one of the rare, inventive bits in an otherwise lackluster lampoon, Kathleen Freeman plays a no-nonsense-type dowager dickering to pay for a prospective hysterectomy with a valise full of green Stamps. Frustrated by Sellers's machinations, she decides, instead, to get a color TV set with those supermarket dividends. All things considered in "Where Does It Hurt?" it's a wise choice.

title: Reinventing The Wheel
description: Someone has finally done the only thing left to do in the credit card busi ness: issued a card that brings you a discount if you pay cash. For $20 the first year and $10 an nually after that, the United Interna tional Club, Inc. (P. O. Box 3485, Bev erly Hills, Calif. 90212) will issue a credit card that discourages the use of credit. In the four years since it was founded by Mike M. Yemano, United International, or UNIC (pro nounced unique), has attracted nearly 60,000 members in the Los Angeles area; they get discounts as high as 40 per cent from some 1,000 member stores and restaurants when they pay in cash or by check.

title: The World
description: TOKYO  The Chinese girls at the Peking Airport on Friday were dressed in blazing reds, deep blues and gleaming whites, with ribbons in their pigtailed hair and bright streamers flowing from their wrists. They danced and twirled their tam bourines to the lively tunes of a brass band while Chinese and Japanese flags curled under a brilliant sky.

title: GARELIK LEANING TO MAYORAL BID
description: City Council President San ford D. Garelik, in a virtual declaration of his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, says his major issue will be crime in the streets, terms Mayor Lindsay more ar rogant than Tammany Hall and predicts that no flaming lib eral can win next year against either a moderate or a mod erateconservative.

title: Marianas Likely to Join U.S.; Talks Planned for December
description: APIA, Samoa, Sept. 28  It is now considered certain that the strategic Marianas Islands in the western Pacific will be come American territory in the near future, strengthening United States defenses on the threshold of Asia.

title: SCHOOL FOOTBALL
description: DEERFIELD, Mass., Sept. 30 Bob Underhill's passing and running sparked Deerfield on thirdquarter touchdown drive and the conversion gave beer field a 1414 tie with Lawrence ville. It was the first game for Deerfield. The Larries have won one and tied one.

title: A COLLEGE PAPER STILL IN DISPUTE
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Sept. 28 The University of Florida student newspaper, The Flori da Alligator, has resumed pub lication in the hands of student editors but is still a subject of dispute after the university president, Stephen C. O'Con nell, failed in an attempt to as sume editorial control.

title: UTTER BORE
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: ARMY CONQUERS TEXAS A. AND M.
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Sept, 30  Army got its first taste of the Wishbone offense tonight and found it a lot more palatable than what they swal lowed last week against Ne braska, defeating Texas A and M., 2414, at Kyle Field.

title: ELIS' JAURON NETS 194 YARDS RUSHING
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 30 Yale's new Wishbone offense had plenty of muscle today as the Elis beat Connecticut, 287. Dick. Jauron scored touchdowns on runs of 80, 64 and 18 yards, breaking his singlegame rush ing record and setting a uni versity career standard.

title: Rustling the strays from the Big D Ranch
description: WASHINGTON: A Roosevelt for Nixon? Three Roosevelts for Nixon? Democrats for Nixon!!? Why, shore. New Deal chillen' and Depression babies, y'all come.

title: Celtics Trounce Nets At Coliseum, 118 to 94
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Sept. 30 The New York Nets, making their first home appearance since their sparkling efforts in last season's American Basket ball Association playoffs, pro vided little but gloom for their supporters in tonight's crowd of 4,627, as they were crushed by the Boston Celtics, 11894, at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: From African artisans
description: Contemporary wares from Africa are signs of the Dark Continent's rich culturenow reaching our country. The handcrafted baskets, above, of plaited Makalani palms, bear the stamp of the Vambo artisans in their diverse shapes and designs. Prices range from $5 to $50, depending on size. Largest basket shown is $50. African artisans also crafted the superb rug, above, of thick, stubby Karakul wool in natural tones. Rug, $100, and baskets at African Artcraft America Ltd.* The redandblue oriental rug is in for competition from the Tunisian carpet, below. It is in the beautifully soft tones of beige, brown and white well suited to today's love of naturals. $1,280 at Phoenix Carpet Co.*

title: Paterson Family Health Center Opens To Serve Ghetto Residents Profitably
description: PATERSON  The Family Health Center, a private or ganization offering compre hensive medical and dental care opened its doors last week in the heart of one of the poorest sections of this old industrial city, to be greeted enthusiastically by the residents.

title: Democrats Name 2
description: The appointment of Patrick J. Delaney as executive direc tor and Florence Shientag as treasurer of New York State Democrats for Nixon was an nounced yesterday by John B. Connally, former Secretary of the Treasury and national chairman of Democrats for Nixon. Mr. Delaney is the son of Representative James J. De laney, Democrat of Queens. Mrs. Shientag, a lawyer, is a former assistant United States attorney and judge.

title: Environment
description: The Battle of the Sexes is rarely fought more vigorously or won more convincingly than among the wrasse, a type of small, iridescent blue fish that lives in the waters of Australia's Great Barrier Reef.

title: Wilson Wins Opening Race For Thistle Class Series
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 30 Tom Wilson of Cedar Point Yacht Club won the opening race of the annual invitation regatta for Thistle Class sloops on Long Island Sound off Cedar Point Y.C. today.

title: Soviet Politburo Shuffle Is Due After Georgian Shift
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 30  The Soviet Union announced today a change in the political lead ership of the independentmind ed Georgian Republic, fore shadowing a shuffle in the Communist party's Politburo, the top ruling group of the Soviet Union.

title: FLORIDA CONQUERS MISS. STATE, 2813
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Sept. 30 (AP)The Florida Gators found the key to their running attack today in a speedy sophomore, Nat Moore, and whipped Mis sissippi State, 2813, in Southeastern Conference game.

title: Guaranteed Income for All In Nation Urged by Spook
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI) Dr. Benjamin Spock called to day for a guaranteed income for all citizens, with a level of $6,500 for a family of four.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThere is little dis agreement among the expertseco nomic or politicalthat the Federal budget deficit that looms ahead for the current fiscal year is simply too largepossibly something on the order of $35billion, The argument is over what to do about it.

title: Views of the Review
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: A Window On Russia For the Use of Foreign Readers. By Edmund Wilson. 280 pp New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $7.95.
description: This collection is a welcome record of Edmund Wilson's en counters with Russian litera ture over the last three decades. It includes, to quote the fore word, all the pieces on Rus sian subjects . . . not collected in other volumes. The essays vary widely in subject matter, in relative weight and genre. They range from the 19th century Russian classics to re cent Soviet memoirs and fic tion, from extended literary analyses to random notes on the peculiarities of the Russian language. Some of the items are, frankly, rather thin, but the best are vintage Wilson.

title: Preps
description: WINDSOR, Conn., Sept. 30 Mike Aroney ran for three touchdowns to lead Wilbraham Monson to a 3628 triumph over Loomis. Ted Berry led a fourth quarter rally for Loomis that fell short. Berry scored two touchdowns and ran for two conversions.

title: A NEWSMAN FINDS RED TAPE IN HANOI
description: The writer of the following article, a special correspondent of The Associated Press, re turned to New York Friday night after spending 10 days in Hanoi covering the release of the three American prisoners of war.

title: Library's Black Collection Is Saluted in Day of Its Own
description: Schomburg Collection Day was observed yesterday with a series of events saluting one of the world's largest and most comprehensive collections of black history, literature and art.

title: Commuter Had Dream In 1865: Teaneck
description: TEANECK  The 43,000 people who live in Teaneck are surrounded by reminders of the Dutch settlers who moved into the tranquil Hackensack Valley more than 200 years agostreet names like Brinkerhoff, Vandelinda, Blauvelt and Bogert.

title: Trenton Is LowIncome Spot in Mercer
description: In New Jersey, where the old central city is generally the poor relation of a rap idly expanding suburban area, Trenton, the state cap ital, is a case in point.

title: Key Focus of Campaign Shifts To the Courts Over Financing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30In the closing weeks of the Presi dential struggle, much of the drama left in what is seen by many as an issueless and list less campaign is shifting to the courts. The issue there is cam paign money.

title: City to Check IncomeTax Records of Its MitchellLama Tenants
description: Tenants in cityaided Mitch ellLlama projects will have their local incometax records examined to determine if they have to pay surcharges, Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton an nounced yesterday.

title: New & Novel
description: Here is an investigative novel, to coin a genre, hold ing up to scrutiny the 1968 Troubles at Columbia. Of course the university is called something else and Columbia's Professor Frankel (philosophy and social theory) has tossed in a number of composite char acters and juxtaposed a hap pening or two. But A Stub born Case distills brilliantly the quintessential madness that swept Morningside Heights that spring like ergot poisoning.

title: TV Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: GREENWICH SEEKS AIRPORT CURFEW
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 30Declining property values, rising citizen unrest, environ mental decay. This Connecticut suburb, not often associated with any of those urban ills, claims that the Westchester County Airport, just over the state line, is responsible for all three and is preparing to take Westchester to court to force a change in airport op erations.

title: Zoning Plan Is Disputed By Group In Freeport
description: FREEPORT, L. I.White the Village Board here awaits applications from developers to construct apartments and commercial buildings in the controversial rezoning area on North Main Street, oppo nents are planning further legal action in an attempt to overturn the board's deci sion.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  There is an im pression afloat that President Nixon wishes to remain above the political battle this year. It is a myth. There was a rumor that he wished to con duct only a Presidential campaign. It turned out to be false.

title: Ready or Not, 155,000 in Connecticut Join Adults
description: HARTFORD, Sept, 30Start ing tomorrow, Connecticut's 155,000 residents from 18 to 20 years old will be, by law, adults and there is concern among legislators and others that for some of the youths adulthood has been thrust upon them too soon.

title: Child to the Alexanders
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. George F. Alexander on Sept. 19 at Roosevelt Hos pital. The child has been named Meghan, Mr. Alex ander is science editor of Newsweek magazine. His wife is the former Miss Daryl Orians of Toledo, Ohio.

title: The World
description: KAMPALAThere is a young Asian girl in the hospital here today recov ering from selfinflicted wounds re ceived when she plunged a kitchen knife into her midriff. She did it, she told her boy friend, because she couldn't face the turmoil of leaving Uganda.

title: Andretti in U.S. Grand Prix
description: MODENA, Italy, Sept. 30 (Reuters)Mario Andretli of Nazareth, Pa., will drive a Formula One Ferrari in the United States Grand Prix at Watkins Glen, N.Y., on Sunday, Oct. 8, Ferrari sources con firmed today.

title: A sort of memoir, a sort of novel
description: Hortense Calisherwho has a splendid habit of getting carried away by her own metaphorssays in Herself: An Autobiographical Work that art is a church without communicants, presided over by a parish of the respectable. . . An artist is born kneeling; he fights to stand. A critic, by nature of the judg ment seat, is born sitting. You can do with that what you like. Hortense Calisher probably won't care if it prompts you to build a Spanish cloister in the air or a private Little Gidding on a welltrimmed lawn at the end of time. She's likely to be come annoyed, though, if you start explaining to other readers (or to her) what it means. She won't catch me doing that. Not that I'm afraid. It's just that I haven't the faintest idea what she means. Reading and writing about booksespecially books like hersdoes not feel to me like figurative sitting.

title: Indiana Edges Kentucky
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 30 (UPI)  Glen Scolnik's third touchdown reception of the game with a little over four minutes remaining gave Indiana a 3534 victory over Kentucky today.

title: What's Up At the Film Festival?
description: THE following is in tended to be an infor mal guide to some of the filmmakers whose works are being shown at the 10th New York Film Festival, which opened Friday night at Alice Tully Hall in Lincoln Center. The remarks are per sonal, biased and, in some cases, totally irrelevant. Not having seen any of the films at this writing, I'd say that the French directors (eight of them) will dominate the festival, at least numerically. Eight American filmmakers are represented by six, pro grams, including The Assas sination of Trotsky, directed by Joseph Losey, who is an American living in England but whose film is described as ItalianFrench, and Robert Altman's Images, which competed at Cannes as an Irish entry although the di rector is American.

title: Supermanager to the Rescue
description: When a big company has to go shopping for a new chief, executive, the price comes high. Once be, starts on the job, the pressure is on the new man to prove that he's worth the tag.

title: MRS. RANKIN'S 142 LEADS OREGON GOLF
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept, 30 (AP)Mrs. Judy Rankin of Midland, Tex., shot into a two stroke lead in the $25,000 Port land women's golf classic with a secondround twounderpar 71 today that put her four un der par for the tournament at 142.

title: K. J. Bender Marries Nancy Schoenfield
description: PALOS VERDES, Calif., Sept. 30  Miss Nancy Schoenfield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Schoenfield of North Hollywood, was married here this afternoon in the La Venta Inn, to Ken neth Jay Bender, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Bender, also of North Hollywood.

title: Fall Brings Rich Harvest Of Cultural Events to Area
description: For devotees of music, art, dance and theater in this area, autumn, 1972, promises much more than the howl of wind, the changing hues of leaves and the shimmy of bared branches.

title: Freehold Sight: Ponytail on Backstretch
description: Mrs. Kathy Martin, at 29, has embarked on what she hopes will be a permanent career as an ownertrainer driver of standardbreds by working as a stable assistant td Mike Pisko on the Free hold Raceway backstretch.

title: BRONX MOTHER OF 5 HELD IN A HOMICIDE
description: A 30yearold South Bronx mother of five children was arrested yesterday and charged with fatally shooting, then dis membering the body of a man who she said had been harass ing her and the children.

title: Student Not Guilty of Rioting
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 30A Cornell University senior ac cused of leading a window smashing melee last spring was found not guilty yesterday by a Tompkins County Court jury. The defendant, 20yearold James R. Bean of Anchorage Alaska, had faced firstdegrer riot charges for allegedly hurt ing a rock at a Cornell building during a violent antiwar protes, on May 11.

title: Two views of evilatlarge
description: What, after all, was really wrong with the Nazis? Accord ing to Hans Hellmut Kirst those that were not insane were sim ply good businessmen. In Hero in the Tower we have both: the mad captain Hein, lover of Siegfried, death and clean young men; and a com pany run by entrepreneurs who could have gone high in the upper echelons of Krupp, I.T.T. or United Fruit.

title: The Issues
description: For 1.1 million city pupils, the 197273 school year is three weeks old. For 90 black seventhgraders who live in the Samuel J. Tilden Houses in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, the new school year has yet to begin  not one of them has set foot in side a classroom this fall.

title: Driving in Africa Needn't Be Beastly
description: One nice thing about a Land Cruiser is that it has 4wheel drive and nineinch clearance and is meant for crosscountry bush busting. This means that you can drive it off a road and over the veldt to get close to a lion.

title: STANFORD BEATS WEST VA., 4135
description: STANFORD, Calif., Sept. 30 (AP)John Winesberry ran for 136 yards and three touch downs and Mike Boryla threw for 228 yards and two touch downs for unbeaten Stanford in a 4135 victory over West Vir ginia today.

title: Republican Blocks Attempts by Democratic Leaders to Rush $74.6Billion Defense Bill Through the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The Senate Democratic leader ship was thwarted today by a Republican Senator  Charles McC. Mathias Jr. of Maryland in an attempt to rush a $74.6 billion defense appropriations bill through the Senate with only a few hours of debate.

title: Cocker Spaniel Runs BestinShow Awards to 33, Drawing Praise of Judge
Trial Looms on Use of Zoning To Block LowIncome Housing
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30A court case that could have a wide impact on the use of federally subsidized housing to force in tegration in suburbs is ex pected to go to trial here soon.

title: KINGS POINT DOWNS GETTYSBURG, 276
description: KINGS POINT, L.I., Sept. 30 Bob Young sparked the United States Merchant Marine Acad emy with his excellent running as Kings Point defeated Gettys burg College, 276, before raindrenched homecoming day crowd of 3,572 today.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: PRESS IS WORRIED BY SRILANKA BILL
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka (Sept. 30 (UPI)Journalists here fear that an independent and free press may soon be extinct in Sri Lanka because of a new press council bill expected to be introduced soon in Parina ment.

title: GEORGIA SUBDUES N.C. STATE, 2822
description: ATHENS, Ga., Sept. 30 (AP) A Georgia sophomore, Horace King, scored one touchdown and keyed another secondhalf scoring drive with a crucial pass reception, leading the Bull dogs to a 2822 victory over North Carolina State today.

title: The Squiggles and Scrawls of a Master
description: IN the work of Pierre Bon nard we encounter a pic torial world so enchant ing in its delicacy of ob servation, so pleasurable in its careful evocation of time, place, atmosphere, and the feelings they engender, that we are sometimes in danger of overlooking one of the es sential constituents of his art its extraordinary rigor. Vis ual felicities abound in such profusion, gratifying the eye's appetite with such a surfeit of retinal delectation, that we hardly feel called upon to search out the source of our pleasure. There is a tempta tion to succumb to the para dise of sensation that is so abundant in Bonnard with out ever bothering to consid er what it is that makes his art at once so appealing and so strong. Bonnard's The Cat (circa 1920), at the Finch College Museum of Art He never goes beyond his own sensibility

title: Military Construction Bill Opposed by Mrs. Abzug
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Be cause of an error in transmis sion, the votes of Representa tive Bella S. Abzug, Democrat of Manhattan, were omitted from the tabulation in today's New York Times of the votes cast this week by New York area members of Congress.

title: Family Doctors, Meeting Here, Say New Morality Makes Their Role More Psychiatric Than Fatherly
description: Most of them still make house calls, deliver babies and reveal an oldfashioned en thusiasm for the solo practice of medicine and for treating the whole patient.

title: Gloria Chen Married to A. D. Wahl
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 30  Miss Gloria Chen and Andrew Delveaux Wahl, who received M.B.A. degrees last year from Rutgers Uni versity, were married here this morning in the Roman Catholic Chapel of the Im maculate Conception at Seton Hall University.

title: New York to Montreal Trains Are Running Again After 18 Months
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 30  Passenger trains are running again between New York and Montreal after 18 months, and the hundreds of railroad buffs who stayed awake last night to cheer the maiden voyage would have you believe it's the only way to travel.

title: State Asked to Check Commune In Hunt for Missing Queens Girl
description: A Queens Criminal Court judge, in a case involving a missing 15yearold girl, has asked the State Attorney Gen eral's office to investigate the commune of the Children of God, a radical religious group, near Ellenvile, N. Y.

title: AFRICANS PROPOSE A NEW TRADE BODY
description: LIBREVILLE, Gabon, Sept. 30, The creation of a commission to promote trade between Afri can countries was urged today by representatives of 33 black and Arab African nations here.

title: Neil Rocks Broadway
description: NEIL DIAMOND? On Broadway?

title: the traveler's world
description: WEST MILFORD, N. J.Any manufactured tourist attrac tion that gets $3.75 a head for adults and $2 for children and attracts half a million paying cus tomers in its first three months war rants a close inspection. Jungle Habitat, the Warner Brothers tourist trap that opened July 15 in the beautiful blue greeerolling hills of the Ramapo Moun tains, clocked its 500,000th visitor the other day and is already a profitmaking private enterprise. It did so well in midsummer that many days they had to close the gates for long stretches. At these peak periods, 8,000 cars were crawling bumper to bumper between the freely roving animals.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Here's a Blessing On Both Their Houses
description: THERE are two kinds of people that go to the theater. One kind doesn't in the least mind killing half the evening waiting for a 10 o'clock starting time, making its way past what is left of the Bow ery, climbing a narrow stair case to inch along a still nar rower ledge to a seat perched directly over a pit, attending quietly while five nearnaked bodies first suspend them selves from a kind of mobile junglegym and then slither crablike on their backs sup porting the metal structure on their stomachs while long tangled ropes tug at their necks and loins.

title: Local
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Sept. 30Leroy Shaw proved too much for Mount Vernon to handle as he led the Kangaroos to a 14.6 victory at Memorial Field. Shaw, a sophomore half back, amassed 214 yards rush ing and scored both Kangaroo touchdowns on runs of 85 and 51 yards. Boys is now 11 while Mount Vernon is 02.

title: Miles Davis and Group Play Philharmonic Hall
description: Miles Davis, who refused to appear at Carnegie Hall as part of the Newport Jazz Festival in July, gave a con cert of his own Friday eve ning at Philharmonic Hall. In general, it was very much like Mr. Davis's other ap pearances in the last year or twoa continuous, unbroken stream of what is essentially moodsetting music.

title: What's Opened At the Movies?
description: THE EMIGRANTS, directed by Jan Troell from a screen play by Troell and Bengt Forslund, got 16 favorable reviews (Kathleen Carroll, News; Archer Winsten, Post; Howard Kissel, Wom en's Wear; Gene Shalit, NBC; Judith Crist, New York; Pauline Kael, NeW Yorker; William Wolf, Cue; Stanley Kauffman, New Republic; John Simon, New Leader; Jay Cocks, Time; Paul D. Zimmerman, News week; Arthur Knight, Sat urday Review; Richard Schickel, Life; Rex Reed, News; Frances Taylor, New house Newspapers; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Serv ice) and 2 mixed reviews (Vincent Canby, Times; Jo Gelmis, Newsday).

title: On the McGovern Endorsement
description: To the Editor:

title: AIR. FORCE MAULS DAVIDSON BY 686
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Sept. 30 (AP)Davidson pen alties, fumbles and intercep tions opened the door for the Air Force today as the unbeat en Falcons whipped the North 1Carolina visitors, 686.

title: Coach Takes a Busman's Holiday
description: Passing up a ticket for the bullfights and a spot on a sunny beach, Arnold Ram irez spent his entire six week visit to Spain last summer on the soccer field.

title: Sexy Spanish women and good Greek colonels
description: David Holden is chief for eign correspondent of The Lon don Sunday Times, and he has visited Greece many times as a journalist during the past two decades. Judging from the opin ions on Greeks, Greece and things Greek expressed in his book, he must count those visits among the more unpleasant experiences of his life.

title: James Meredith and Ole Miss: Decade After a Bloody Insurrection
description: OXFORD, Miss., Sept. 30 The pool air of autumn is slow to come to the University of Mississippi, and the musky heat of summer lingers late over the campus as the students saunter past the stately buildings and great gray oaks.

title: Two Cheers for Villerest, the Capital of Packaged Joy
description: VILLEREST, France  Each year thousands of tourists set off to follow the Loire in its majestic aimlessness through a valley of ancient religious fervor and modern gourmandise. Most make pilgrimages to the chateaux; many cater to different spiritual needs, tasting their way through the vineyards and wine cellars along the great river.

title: Local
description: Canarsie combined a bal anced offense with an unyield ing defense and routed Eras mus Hall, 360, yesterday for its second consecutive shut out in Public Schools Athletic League Division II play. Ra made Boys High Field slippery and forced Canarsie to stay on the ground. The Chiefs gained 279 yards, 244 rushing.

title: Foes Stili Quiet On Road Bonds
description: TRENTONWhen Governor Cahill's proposal for a $650million transportation bond issue cleared the Legis lature last May, a number of conservationist and environ mentalist organizations, and other groups demanding higher priorities for mass transit promised to campaign against the proposal this fall.

title: County Committeemen Were Elected in June
description: The county committeemen who will choose a new Demo cratic nominee for the House in the 20th Congressional District at the Commodore Hotel tonight were elected for twoyear terms in the pri mary last June, when district leaders were also chosen.

title: An entertaining pad
description: This typical highrise apartment in Manhattan was drastically altered as architect Christopher Owen attacked its Lshaped layout, tailoring the space to personal needs. A request for a table to seat six to eight people comfortably turned out to be the key to the archi tectural grace of this bachelor apart ment. Businessman Byron Sugaraha who owned the coop had a pen chant for cards and not only did he want the large table but it had to be close to the kitchen so snacks and refreshments could be easily served. The architect and, interior designer Sylvia Owen streamlined the space, built in the sofa and end tables and countered the com fortable banquette with twin leather covered chairs. The compact kitchen is exposed to the room; its cabinets and divider bring warm wood accents to the allwhite scheme. The cylinder over the diningcumgame table casts light on the scene.

title: Columbia to Award a Prize To a Professor at Harvard
description: Dr, Stephen W. Kuffler, the Robert Winthrop Professor at Harvard Medical School, will receive Columbia University's 1972 Louisa Gross Horwitz Prize on Oct. 4 for outstand ing research in biology.

title: 40% of Newark Pupils Found to Need Extra Help
description: NEWARKAs much as 40 per cent of the city's 80,000 pupil school population is in need of some special educa tional service, according to report prepared by the Essex County Mental Health Asso ciation.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Senator George McGovern, in a threestate sweep up the East Coast yesterday, used some of the harshest language of his campaign in accusing the Nixon Administration of being scan dalridden and corrupt.

title: Hufnagel Rallies Penn State To 1410 Victory Over Iowa in Waning Seconds
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Sept. 30John Hufnagel, whom Joe Paterno has called the best quarterback in Penn State his tory, waited until the fourth quarter today to substantiate his coach's contention.

title: Preps
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 30 St. George's had a bad case of the fumbles as they dropped 26.6 decision to Providence Country Day bath school had 262 yards total offense, but St. George's blew several scoring opportunities with goalline fumbles. John Bellows and. John Jones both scored two touch downs for Providence.

title: ADVERTISING POINT OF VIEW
description: TORONTO  Like the United States, Canada has a consumer movement that is generally critical of business and particularly vocal when it uncovers advertising faults. Its champion in the Federal Government is a Cabinet Minister and his Department of Consumer and Corporate Affairs. In each of Canada's provincial governments there are ministructures similarly geared to protecting the con sumer public from over zealous marketers.

title: Local
description: Nathaniel Jackson, a 5foot 10inch, 180pound sophomore transfer from Charleston, S. C., was impressive as he led John Adams to a 340 triumph over James Monroe on the loser's field yesterday.

title: Antiwar Activist Learns a Lesson From Son
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I.  Mrs. Irma Zigas, a longtime activist in Women's Strike for Peace, thought she was as devoted to the cause as any American  until her adopted son announced he was joining a ship planning to run the blockade of Hai phong Harbor.

title: Study Says Subways Are Noisy How's That?
description: It should not come as any surprise to the thousands of riders of New York's sub way system that the noise level on the cars is one of the two or three loudest in the world.

title: OHIO STATE HALTS N. CAROLINA, 2914
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 30 (AP)Archie Griffin, a home town freshman tailback carry ing ball for the first time in college, broke loose for a school record 239 rushing yards today, leading Ohio State to a 2914 victory over North Carolina.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Who is this Crumb?
description: SAN FRANCISCO: His clothes are almost period pieces: flatbrim hat, small red bow tie and gray Hush Puppies. Somehow they make him appear at once older and younger than his 29 years. His face is pale and oval, marked by a thin pencilline mustache. He sits hunched over his sketchpad, his left hand doodling in ink to the sounds of rag time. Looking up, he smiles shyly from behind transparent hornrims, thick round lenses that com ically enlarge his eyes. The look is that of honkytonk piano playerwhich is not inappro priate, since he's an avid collector of old 78's, and wellpracticed on piano, kazoo, banjouke and har monica. And when he begins to speak of old music, as he often does, it's as if he has suddenly come unstuck in time.

title: GROWTH POLICIES OF CITIES SCORED
description: A federally funded study cri ticizes local government offi cials around the nation for con centrating their economic poli cies solely on growth, which the study says perpetuates their cities as unattractive places to live in.

title: Montclair State Triumphs Over C. W. Post, 21 to 14

description: CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP) Our Pappa Joe, ridden by Tom my Barrow, came from far back Saturday to win the $34,200 Thomas D. Nash Memorial Handicap before 16,579 at Sportsman's Park.

description: DARIEN, Sept. 30  Repre sentatives of 10 Connecticut shoreline towns and cities grappled this week with laws regulating Use of their beaches under the threat that one town might be taken to court soon for excluding nonresidents.

title: CATHERINE RUTLEDGE
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 30 Catherine Arm Rutledge, for mer president of the Flemming Rutledge Oil Company, died Thursday at St. Joseph's Hos pital. She was 70 years old and lived at 65 Glenbrook Road.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: Now that aircraft are so large, comfortable and smoothflying, it should be possible to introduce one of the luxuries that was for merly offered on express pas senger trains. On longer flights it would be a good idea to have a barbershop so that men could spend their time more usefully than per haps otherwise. Appoint ments could be booked on the ground at the time of ticket purchase.

title: Less TV but More Births
description: COLCHESTER, England, Sept. 30 (UPI)The birth rate in the Lexden and Winstree district of Essex is 5 per cent above the national average for the 10th year running. County officials said fewer people in the area have television sets than in most parts of the country.

title: MorrisSomerset
description: Bound Brook, unbeaten in nine games last season, swept to its second victory Of the new season yesterday, 386, over Kenilworth, behind the running of Sam Jones in Kenilworth.

title: The Leadership Issue
description: The overriding consideration in this Presidential cam paign is what may be called the leadership issue. As we noted Thursday in our editorial endorsement of Senator George McGovern for the Presidency, The Times believes that President Nixon has failed to lead the American people with any sense of moral purpose toward the broad social, economic and political goals of this Ameri can democracy. Despite some major accomplishments, this Administration has appeared to govern during most of the past four years not with any evidence of inner conviction and outward vision but rather with a mixture of opportunism, insensitivity and confusion of aim.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: NEW IBERIA, La., Sept. 30 The Vice President campaigned today at the Sugar Cane Festi val in Louisiana's Cajun coun try before returning to Wash ington. He said in his speech at the festival that Senator George McGovern, the Demo cratic Presidential nominee, would have us become a nation that in some AliceinWonder land fashion would successfully negotiate with superpowers from a position of weakness.

title: VA. TECH WINS, 1310; THE STROCKS EXCEL
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., Sept. 30 (UPI)Don Strock passed 42 yards for a touchdown and his older brother, Dave, kicked two field goals and an extra point to account for all of Vir ginia Tech's scoring today as the Gobblers defeated South ern Methodist, 1310.

title: Airliner Skids Off Runway
description: BUFFALO, Sept 30 (UPI) An American Airlines Boeing 707 skidded off the runway at Greater Buffalo International Airport last night, authorities said. All 86 persons aboard escaped injury. An airlines spokesman said the front land ing gear had turned to one side, causing the plane to slide. The planeFlight 193 from Kennedy International Airport was pulled back on the run way after the passengers were taken off.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Designs for tomorrow
description: Urbanites have become accustomed to huge concrete blocks as the only solution to highrise housing. The future could hold other living structures in store that needn't be all sharp angles and rectangles. Two prototype designs for housing of the future forsee a radically different urban environment. Both projects, not yet built, explore the technology of our time and make use of products and materials already at hand. The Apartapak system, shown above, is a versatile building made up entirely of standardized components. Interior and exterior partitions are stacked and rearranged to provide outdoor terraces with privacy from neighbors; curved windows of glass give light, airy interiors; the setback steps of each floor eliminate the dark tunnellike rooms of lower levels so they, too, are as desirable a living space as apartments up top. Apartapak was designed by architect Richard Aldiedge of Los Angeles who talks in terms of people ordering their apartment or house from a mail order catalog of components to create their own design. The partial list of components includes interior and exterior wall panels, premolded or prefabricated kitchen and bath room units, sun protection shields, and storage units. Kitchen and bath room units would slip into the structural utility core with the plumbing, mechanical and electrical hookups sandwiched in floor panels.

title: Ethnic outsider
description: This welltranslated short novel by the author of The Garden of the FinziContinis is a complex and sub tle yet highly dramatic work which fully deserves to rank with such clas sic explorations of identity as Joseph Conrad's Secret Sharer and Thom as Mann's Tonio Kroeger. Like Conrad and Mann, Giorgio Bassani comes to such a theme with an appro priate personal background.

title: YUGOSLAVS ASSAIL CROAT DISSIDENTS;Denunciations of the Ustashi Resumed After Long Lull
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 25Amid the dismal swamp lands at Jasenovac, a small tiwn southeast of the Croatian city of Zagreb, a graceful con crete monument suggestive of hands raised in an appeal for mercy looks out over grass covered mounds that neatly cinceal the remains of one of the death camps of World War II.

title: 3D TRIAL DENIED IN COCAINE CASE
description: A Federal District Court judge in Brooklyn dismissed an indictment against a narcotics defendant whose two trials ended in hung juries on the ground that a third trial would violate his constitutional rights.

title: Suffolk
description: Brentwood's defensive unit set up two firsthalf touch downs and the streaking Indians made them stand up for a 148 triumph over stubborn Smithtown eleven yesterday. The victory extend ed Brentwood's undefeated streak to 19 games.

title: Class to Hail High School's Half Century
description: RUTHERFORDWhen the class of 1950 was graduated from the high school here, the commencement program involved a history of the community's previous 50 years, told through the activ ities of the graduates' rela tiveswho had been mayors and doctors and athletes and various sorts of civic activ ists.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 30 (UPI) The health of Lieut (jg) Norris Charles of the Navy, the third prisoner released by the North Vietnamese, was reported with in normal limits yesterday by a Defense Department spokesman.

title: Jews Mark the Start of Simhath Torah
description: The celebration of Simhath Torah, the most joyous day in the Hebrew calendar, began in synagogues at sundown yes terday.

title: No place to go but up
description: A long and narrow room in a London flat would seem to offer few possibilities for housing two growing boys. Luckily the ceilings were high and the logical move to designer Barnie Broad bent was to look up for sleep and play areas. First he got the beds up off the floor in shipstyle berths and used the space beneath for the long counter that runs the length of the room. The counter faces a wall of cork where the boys display their latest fancies. The round portholes in the lower partitions are partly playful and partly functional; they serve as ladders to the bunks. The entire floor area is left free for play.

title: NEBRASKA ROUTS MINNESOTA, 490
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 30 (AP)Johnny Rodgers ran for two touchdowns and Gary Dix on scored three times on short runs today as seventhranked Nebraska crushed Minnesota, 490.

title: Interceptions, Fumble Help Utah Top Washington State
description: PULLMAN, Wash., Sept. 30 (AP)The University of Utah defeated the Washington State Cougars, 4425, today, capital izing on a halfdozen errors.

title: Bridge
description: In the 45year history of the game one might suppose that every angle of bidding theory has been thoroughly explored. But there are sev eral common situations in which standard practice is open to objection in theory.

description: Three Roman Catholic priests and a social action worker from a Brownsville periah have charged that poor people tin Brooklyn are being victimized by new city policies aimed at wel farecheats.

title: New & Novel
description: Faith Farrell is a golden girl who blooms in the 1930's, wilts in a drought of love and self esteem, tries to nourish her in sufficiences with drink, winds up a nearsuicide  and is resurrected by AA and psy chiatry. Mrs. Crowe follows Faith through a childhood filled with nightmares and a disas trous marriage, to the realiza tion that her past may not have been responsible for her present. No profound probing into character here, but the pro file of alcoholism is drawn with dramatic effect.

With 32 cars lined up, it equals Monza in 1961 as the largest grid in the history of Formula One racing and there is plenty of sil ver, or gold, or coin of the realm for the partici pating drivers.

Williamson is 11. Trade, 269, Greg Leighton, a kicker, was inserted at half back for only one play from scrimmage and ran 76 yards for a touchdown. Williamson is 11.

title: A Surprising Race Finally Ends For a RainedOut Yankee Team
description: Rained out of their game with Cleveland more than an hour before it was scheduled to start, the New York Yankees left Yankee Stadium yesterday not knowing whether or not the two games they must play today will mean anything.

title: Poor Crop of Champagne
description: PARIS, Sept. 30 (Agence PrancePresse)This was a bad year for grapes in the cham pagne country with a harvest expected to be 25 per cent less than last year's, the champagne growers announced this week. The interprofessional commit tee of the champagne district said that the poor crop had forced authorities to increase the price of the grape used to make champagne by 22.9 per cent.

title: Cost of Attendance At Public Colleges Rises More Slowly
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)The cost of attending a state university rose again this fall but much more slowly than in the previous eight years when tuition jumped 75 per cent for residents and 115 per cent for nonresidents.

title: Idaho Nominee Withdraws
description: MOSCOW, Idaho, Sept. 30 (UPI)Patrick Monaghan, who won this year's primary nomi nation for prosecuting attorney of Latah County, has with drawn from the race. He with drew Tuesday after learning that he failed to pass the Idaho state bar examination.

title: U.S. Witness Against 4 in Theft of M16 Rifles Is Killed by Bomb
description: STERLING, Conn., Sept. 30 A Government witness sched uled to testify next month in a Federal case involving stolen military rifles was killed here yesterday in an explosion that ripped his home apart. The state police said today that the blast had been deliberately set.

title: The Politics of Textiles
description: It's been a year now since the Nixon Administra tion extracted voluntary agreements on textile quotas from four: Far. Eastern na tions.
