description: HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 30 Williams, backed by an alert and tenacious defense, defeated Trinity College, 210 today in the opener for both teams.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article Illegal Threes Flourishing in City (Sept. 10] overlooked one essential element that should end the argument for making them legal: the moderate rent Il legal tenants now pay be cause of the illegality will rise immediately and precipi tously as the property's in comeproducing value (and therefore its price) jumps. This effort by the City Plan ning Commission to ease rents is therefore selfdefeat ing.

title: Football Injury Is Fatal
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan., Sept. 30 (AP)Mark Tindle, 17 years old, a starting fullback for Independence (Kan.) High's football team, died today at the University of Kansas Medi cal Center. He suffered a head injury in last night's game with Parsons High.

title: House warming
description: Many city dwellers crave the comfort and warmth of country houses. That expains the preponderance of chintz and prints, of antiques and fullsize trees in their city apartments. Designer David Easton of EastonLaRocca captured the cozy atmosphere high in the Manhattan sky for a widowed client who moved to the city from a huge house on Long Island. The rooms were large and airy, well suited to her superstuffed sofas and oriental rugs. In the living room, left, seating is clustered around the fireplace. A subsidiary seating area, right, is off the foyer in the Lshaped alcove of the living room. Eighteenthcentury tea tables, Regency chairs and floors bleached to a parchment shade add to the comfortable country feeling. The larger pieces are slipcovered in colorful chintz. The same chintz is repeated at the windows.

title: KNICKS VANQUISH PISTONS BY 10384
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 30 Minor injuries continued to pile up for the New York Knicks to night, but the fact that Jerry Lucas, Dean Meminger and Dave DeBusschere were side lined could not stop the Knicks from posting an easy 10384 victory over the Detroit Pistons at Westchester County Center.

Haley. The Rev. James T. McGuire performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.

description: DETROIT, Sept. 30Swing ing hot bats in the chilly weather, the Detroit Tigers crushed Milwaukee, 134, today, kept the heat on Boston and knocked the Yankees cold.

title: BERDENA MINTOSH

She was believed to have been in her eighties, and was a 1908 gradyate of Wellesley College.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 Nuclear safety experts from around the nation have been meeting in secret with the Atomic Energy Commission regulatory staff members this week to iron out a public posi tion on the highly controversial subject of nuclear reactor safety.

title: Education
description: The boarding schools  prep schools, as they are popularly knownhave long been considered the Rolls Royce of American sec ondary education: expensive, ex clusive, prestigious. Largely for children of the upper class, boys' schools like Andover, Exeter, Gro ton, St. Paul's, Hotchkiss and Law renceville have served as jumping off places for Harvard, Yale, Prince ton and other top universities. Boarding schools for girls have played a similar role.

title: New & Novel
description: Nobody actually gets drunk in Madrid, but there's quite bit of drinking in New York, Paris, Acapulco and Mexico City. The drinkers include brace of Joyce Elbert's patent ed crazy ladies, who take part in four separate sequences, un connected except by occasion al sexual intercourse. Susan is running around with Mike who used to go with Leslie. Leslie is having it off with Bruce who was once married to Claire, about whom the less said the better. Noreen and Neil are friends of Bruce and Claire and come to a bad end in Mex ico.

title: TANAKA CAUTIOUS ON CHINESE TIES
description: TOKYO, Sept. 30Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan, back from his successful journey to Peking, cautioned his country today that there would be problems between Japan and China in the future even though the two nations have begun diplomatic relations.

title: Child Play Is Taught to Mothers in Ghetto
description: PATERSONFive mornings a week, 19yearold Mrs. Gwendolyn Breaker, and Mrs. Antonia Lugo and Mrs. Zaida Ramoz, both 23, waved good bye to their own babies and marched off to play with others.

title: Slight Overcharge for Phone
description: JOHNSON CITY, Tenn., Sept. 30 (AP)I believe I've been overcharged, said P. E. Broyles as he handed his monthly tele phone bill to a United Inter mountain Telephone Company pay clerk. Evidently something went wrong, said the clerk, staring at the $2,359.62 bill. Just an honest mistake, said Allan Frith, manager of John son City's telephone exchange. He explained that because of equipment malfunction, hun dreds of long distance calls made by others had been charged to Mr. Broyles.

title: Dance
description: TO be perfectly honest, and at times in a somewhat disconcert ing fashion I do at tempt to be perfectly honest, I do not like ethnic dance. often find myself wishing that it would keep to its ethnic area and leave me alone. I am guiltily aware that there are enormous au diences only waiting to be thrilled deathless by the Patagonian National Dance Company, which has been ex ported from Patagonia at enormous cost to the hard pressed Patagonian Govern ment and enormous profit to the lowpressed American im presario who is giving them the chance to wave high the Patagonian flag on Broadway. But the financial problems of both parties do not really get to me.

title: The Nation
description: Visions of sugar plums danced in the heads of American travelers last week as the Civil Aeronautics Board took on all the trappings of an early Santa. The board's ruling: Virtu ally anyonenot just Moose, Elks and other joiners of organized, groupswill henceforth be permitted to hop aboard lowcost charter flights. One possible effect: Roundtrip charter flights, New York to Europe, as low as $140; to the West Coast, $300 or less.

title: The Human Side of Textiles
description: BELMONT, N. C.The Bible says to work and earn thy breadyou're supposed to earn it by the sweat of your brow, Betty Smiley says. And so Mrs. Smiley works 48 hours a weekand someimes 56 hoursas a texturizingmachine operator at the Pharr Yarns plant in nearby McAdenville.

title: Rowe Stands Out as Dartmouth Downs New Hampshire, 2414
description: HANOVER, N.H., Sept: 30 Ellis Rowe, a junior fullback from Miami, gained 153 yards in 12 carries before spraining his ankle early in the third pe riod today, but his spark was enough to push Dartmouth to a 2414 victory over New Hampshire at Memorial Field.

title: Bridgeport Wins, 1612, Stretching Streak to 13
description: BOSTON, Sept. 30 (AP) Bridgeport, building an early 14point lead, held on to beat Northeastern, 1612, and ex tend its winning streak to 13 games, the longest in the nation.

title: PRIEST IS RUNNING FOR STATE SENATE
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 30A lowkey, thus far friendly, con test between a Roman Catholic priest and the president of the Rochester school board is under way here In the 53d Senatorial District with but one certainty to date: Whoever wins will add one more vote in the Legislature next year for repeal of the state's liberal ized abortion law.

title: Williams Quits After Four Seasons as Manager of Texas Rangers
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Sept. 30 (AP)Ted Williams has de cided not to manage the Texas Rangers after the current sea son, Robert E. Short, president of the club, announced today.

title: PAKISTAN REPORTS AN ATTACK BY INDIA
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 30 (UPI)A Pakistani military spokesman said that Indian military forces today fired heavy artillery and mortars deep into the Pakistani side of disputed Kashmir.

title: New & Novel
description: This updated version of Un der Two Flags finds two white mercenaries employed by dif ferent factions of the recent civil war in Nigeria. (O tem pora!) John Gibson, personal pilot to an oil baron, is dra gooned into taking up a fighter plane for the Government. Imagine his surprise when he discovers that the ace at the controls of a Biafran bomber is none other than Tubby San ders, an old buddy. Mr. Kearey, who has clocked plenty of exotic air time in Asia and Africa, puts his background to good use in some hairy flying interludes.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE.
description: THE one strain that continues to pervade the eco nomic assessments pouring out of economic, business and Government circles these days unbridled optimism, despite some legitimate question marks, on a number of issues and in the face of a strange, highly pessimistic mood in the investment world.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 30 (UPI)Maj, Edward K. Elias, of the Air Force, who returned to the United States with Lieu tenant Gartley Thursday, was reported today to be spending a happy, relaxed weekend with his family at Maxwell Air Force Base here.

title: Horse Show News
description: The indoor fall horse show circuit opens Tuesday when the second annual Philadel phia event gets under way for six days at the Spectrum.

title: ARKANSAS VICTOR OVER TULSA, 2120
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Sept. 30 (AF)Joe Ferguson guided Arkansas 80 yards to a fourth quarter touchdown as the Razorbacks rallied to defeat the University of Tulsa, 2120, today.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOS ANGELESTo citizens interested in the environment: I need your help tomorrow, said a newspaper advertise ment on the eve of South Carolina's recent primary.

title: Vast Oriental Library Is Opened to the Public
description: PRINCETON  A recent ly completed renovation program at Princeton Uni versity will open thousands of rare documentscompris ing the internationallyknown Gest Oriental Libraryto public examination.

title: Virginia A. Rynne Engaged to Marry
description: TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept. 30Mr. and Mrs. William A. Rynne have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Virginia Ann Rynne, to Peter Lanman Richard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Van Buren Richard of Glen Head, L.I., and York Harbor, Me.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Although Josephine Hendin's highly regarded study, The World of Flannery O'Connor, published two years ago, coun tered the general view of Miss O'Connor as essentially a Cath olic writer, Gilbert H. Muller's new book makes an interesting case for her as a nonorthodox but nonetheless religious writer who made artistic use of the Catholic grotesque. Quoting from her letters and her lec tures, he shows how her stories are all grounded in a belief in original sin, mercy and reve lation and how they are in volved with death, judgment and grace. But because she knew how divisive grace is and because she knew how to make the external world in her stories vivid and concrete, there was no conventional Christian piety in her work. In acknowledging the spiritual core of her fiction, Mr. Muller does not overlook her literary excellence. His book adds a new dimension to a complex and invidualistic writer.

title: Health Dean Named on Coast
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 30 (AP)Dr. Warren Winkelstein Jr. this week was appointed dean of the University of Cali fornia's School of Public Health in Berkeley. Dr. Winkelstein, 50 years old, has headed the school's epidemiology program since 1968 and previously held a similar position studying epi demics and epidemic diseases with the School of Medicine at the State University of New York at Buffalo.

title: Mall Playhouse, Mold for Others
description: PARAMUS  The first, and for many years the only, legitimate theater in a New Jersey shopping center, the Playhouse on the Mallnow celebrating its 10th annivers ary  has proved so suc cessful that it has become the model for other such theaters.

title: Canada Ties Czechoslovak Six, 33, on Parise's Goal With 4 Seconds to Play
description: PRAGUE, Sept. 30 (UPI)A goal by JeanPaul Parise with four seconds remaining saved Team Canada from a defeat in a 33 tie with the world ice hockey champion, Czechoslo vakia, tonight.

title: Diminished people
description: As the last fragments are gathered up from the loaves and fishes of all Colette wrote, it is natural to look for clues to what kept such bounty coming so long. The present volumessome unpublished mater ial, some only now collected, all of it translated into English for the first timetogether render such a clue, even though The Other Woman is composed of short stories and a novelette, and the other two collections, of short nonfiction.

title: Construction Union at Airport Starts Training Blacks
description: NEWARKA specially de signed training program for the six black men who were refused work by a construc tion union and triggered a work stoppage at the con struction of the $400million terminal at Newark Airport began last Wednesday.

title: Best of Both Worlds: Living in Washington, Working in New York
description: Intercity commuters  a type dis tinct from daily suburban straphangers or weekend transoceanic jetsetters are proliferating between New York and Washington, D. C. They spend two to five days in their offices in New York (where they find it more profitable to work), while their families remain in the Washington area (which they con sider more pleasant to live in).

title: Home Improvement
description: To eliminate the prob lem of accidentally flooding a basement or laundry room if the hoses on an automatic wash ing machine should develop a leak when no one is watch ing, homeowners can now buy a special shutoff valve that will shut the water off automatically if either hose should develop a leak while the water valve is on (most people leave these valves on all the time). They are in stalled by merely threading onto the end of the faucet, then attaching the hoses to them (one on each faucet). If a slow leak develops, the wa ter will be shut off in from 2 to 5 minutes; if the hose breaks completely, the water will be shut off in a little more than 5 minutes. Flood Stop Automatic ShutOff Valves, $19.95 per pair, post paid. (Ausco, Inc., 820 Port Washington Boulevard, Port Washington, N.Y. 11050).

title: On the East African Railway: Going to the Nile's Source...
description: MOMBASA, Kenya  The great snake uncoils under the humid, Indian Ocean sun of this strange Sinbad city of open vowels and Arab dhows plying the monsoon. All afternoon the evening train for Nairobi is assembled while the Arab Old City blinks in the heat. On the open station platform, uncrated armchairs and bare iron bedsteads are loaded into the baggage car while a steam engine huffs on a siding.

title: America as a dialectic without a synthesis
description: It might seem as easy as falling off a log to produce yet another book about American national char acter. The guidelines have already been set out by a multitude of previ ous interpreters, American and for eign. You can take the inheritance tack, once popular among historians as the germ theory. According to this genetic approach institutions are best explained by tracing back where they came from. The emphasis here is on origins and continuity.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  One of the most prominent and re spected European central bankers was talking here last week at a party about prob lems of intervention curren cies and other technical is sues involved in international monetary reform. The occa sion, of course, was the an nual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

title: The Nation
description: For the American over 65the middle income worker in particular there was the promise of a brighter day: The Senate last week voted to allow him to earn up to $3,000 a year without losing any of his Social Security benefits.

title: Illinois Poll Puts Nixon Ahead of McGovern 3 to 1
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP) The Chicago Tribune reported tonight that a survey it took of Illinois voters showed that they preferred President Nixon to Senator George McGovern by almost 2to3 margin.

title: Sanitationmen Gain A Tentative Accord With Valley Stream
description: VALLEY STREAM, L. I., Sept. 30 Agreement was reached early today on a three year contract between sanita tion workers and the Village of Valley Stream.

title: SYRACUSE AWAITS. BIG TAX REDUCTION
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 30Real estate taxpayers in this city will receive a reduction of $1.46 per $1,000 assessed valu ation, the biggest tax cut in 22 years, if the Common Council approves a budget adopted by the city's Board of Estimate this week.

title: The Home
description: Transitional times lack the electric charge of excitement that crackles through the air when trends are in the making. For design and architec ture 1972 was a transitional year, devoid of the dynamic activity of previous ones, of the splashy use of pattern on pattern, of the Italian designers noisy insistence on new shapes and materials of the emphasis on silver and glitter. But things are happening  a consolidation of established trends, a playing down of faddish exuberance and a return to classic values. A change of attitude is underway that is more portentous (though less exciting) than a revolution in furniture design or a scoop on next year's hot color news.

title: Richmond Wins, 3415, From Virginia Military
description: RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 30 (UPI)  Billy Meyers scored three times from inside the 3 yardline today to lead Rich mond to a 3415 victory over Virginia Military Institute. V.M.I. has lost 14 straight games.

title: Numbers Game vs. Lottery
description: TRENTON  When Gov ernor Cahill announced re cently that New Jersey would become the first state to offer a daily lottery, he expressed the hope that it could deliver a crushing blow to the illegal numbers racket.

title: CLEVELAND MAYOR WARNS STRIKERS
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 30 Striking city employes have been given an ultimatum by Mayor Ralph J. Perkeither re turn to work next Monday or he will use the full power of my office to end the strike that began last Monday.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 After a month on the road, Sargent Shriver's campaign as the No. 2 man on the Demo cratic ticket has begun to develop a significance unusual for a VicePresidential nominee.

title: MonmouthOcean
description: Two touchdowns in the fourth quarter broke open a close battle and sent Mon mouth Regional to a 200 vic tory over Lakewood yesterday in New Shrewsbury.

title: On the McGovern Endorsement
description: To the Editor:

title: Oregon State Wins, 29.3, With a 22Point First Half
description: CORVALLIS, Ore., Sept. 30 (AP)Oregon State converted three Brigham Young rrors into touchdowns in the first half to day and recorded a 293 victory in a looselyplayed football game.

title: Wall St.No Place for Jokes
description: Wall Street, like other arenas of mystery, sometimes best reveals its mood by in direction. By what is left un said. By what is left un rented.

title: Bicyclists Happy With CarFree Path
description: SOUTH ORANGE  Early each Sunday morning, rain or shine, about 20 very seri als bicycle riders pace them selves along the rolling trails of South Mountain Reserva tion, here, free from the in terference of that nemesis of bikesthe automobile.

title: Caroline Savage Ray Is Bride Of Clyde Calvin Gunsaulus 3d
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Sept. 30The chapel of the First Presbyterian Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Caroline Savage Ray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Edwin Ray 3d of New York and Virginia Beach, to Clyde Calvin Gun saulus 3d, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Gunsaulus Jr. of Chicago.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Local
description: Mark Caizza continued as the leading man for Evander as the Tigers won their first game, 98, in a Manhattan Bronx division P.S.A.L. game. Evander lost to Far Rockaway last week in a nonleague game. Brandeis has won one and lost one in two league games.

title: Music
description: HE was a man of eclectic tempera ment, just mind, indefatigable imag ination, and an open soul, endowed with a rare facility of assimilation. Thus An toineFrangois Marmontel, the teacher of Georges Bizet (and also the teacher of D'Indy, Guiraud and Debus sy, among many others) wrote of his pupil a few years after the composer of Carmen died in 1875. It used to be an article of faith that Bizet died of a broken heart after the poor success of his great opera. Marmon tel was one of the sentimen talists who was responsible for that myth. Bizet, he wrote, succumbed to acute heart disease, accelerated by the emotions he had gone through during the few pre ceding months. As a matter of fact, modem research has established the fact that Carmen was respectfully received and was not a fail ure at all.

title: Gardens
description: A BOUT a hundred years ago, black gold bounced out of the Amazon jungle and, started the world rolling in comfort on rubber. Over 165 plants will produce a rubber like substance, but only the latex of Hevea brasiliensis, a tree that weeps white, sticky tears has proved commercially valuable, supplying 2.6 million tons of rubber annually.

title: LEHIGH TURNS BACK VERMONT, 26 TO 20
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 30 Lehigh fought off a desperate Vermont threat in the final sec onds today to preserve a 2620 victory before 5,000 spectators. It was the Engineers' second triumph against two losses and the second defeat for Vermont in two games.

title: PROGRAM OF DANCE IS GIVEN AT CHURCH
description: Even as unremittingly dull a dance performance as that of fered at St. Clement's Church Thursday evening has some limited function. In this case it was to establish a negative standard of creativity. The cho reographers were Ben Dolphin, Diane. Germaine, Jacques Pata rozzi and a collaborative trio of Harriet Berg, Katya Biesanz and Christopher Pilafian. After this program, there's nowhere to go but up.

title: Rangers Lose 15th Straight
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Sept. 30 (AP)Pat Kelly's bad hop, pinchhit double started a five run Chicago uprising in the seventh inning tonight as the White Sox downed the Texas Rangers, 53.

title: LINK OF SCLEROSIS TO VIRUS IS HINTED
description: Three teams of medical re searchers have independently reported the first isolations of a virus from the brains of pa tients with multiple sclerosis, a nervous system disease that is common in temperate areas of the world.

title: The Human Side of Textiles
description: NAGOYA, JapanFor 19yearold Mikiko Ura, working at the Teijin, Ltd., spinning mill here is an unusual mixture of feudalism, individual enter prise and Japanese tradition. She was recruited on another Japanese island and brought here 15. Her whole life is involved in her job, but she has saved almost $1,300 in her four years here and is acquiring the high school diploma she might never have received had she stayed home.

title: Islanders Set to Open on Defensive
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Sept. 30The New York Islanders officially bring the Na tional Hockey League to the suburbs next Saturday when they help open the season against the other new expansion team, the Atlanta Flames.

title: The Key: Getting Rid of That Dump
description: LYNDHURSTAs envisioned, the 21,000 acres the Hackensack Meadowlands will be a planned commercialresidentialrecreational complex in 30 years with clean water and preserved estuarial enclaves.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The monetary system, we are apt to forget, is one of the key instruments of inter national relations and not, as it is sometimes treated, an exotic set of technical ar rangements simply affecting trade and payments. The dif ference among countries, therefore, reflect hard politi cal and economic realities and are rooted in the total context of their foreign pol icies.

title: The cult of Kim
description: PYONGYANG: On a country highway, east of here, I see about a hundred men and women work ing in the paddy fields. I ask my two official guides to stop the car so that I can talk to the peasants, and perhaps photograph them. Instead, my senior escort, an editor named Pak, tells the driver to go on. I protest, but he says, This is not a typical scene. Our beloved and respected leader, Comrade Kim II Sung, has announced that our agriculture fully mechanized. These men and women working in the fields do not represent the true state of our farming.

title: Davis Cup Team Finds It Is Behind the Times
description: PARIS, Sept. 30  In a search for lost time, the United States Davis Cup team is making a oneweek stopover in Paris before it goes looking for its fifth straight Davis Cup title.

title: For stirfry enthusiasts
description: The craze for Chinese cooking has spawned new interest in Oriental cookware and utensils. Some of today's imports are authentic, traditional items, others are being crafted of modern materials. The traditional Chinese cooking pot, the wok, opposite, is given a long wooden handle. Both the wok and its domed cover are stainless steel for easier upkeep. Wok and cover, $36. Bamboo steamer baskets include the woven top and individual trays that stack atop the wok. Vegetables can be steamed in tiers. Cover with two steaming trays, $20. Utensils include the wire strainers in small to tiny sizes, plus long handled spoons and ladles. Large wire steel strainer, $16. Spoon and ladle, $5 each. Cleavers from Mainland China are the real articles with wide blades and wooden handles. Large size, $7.50; medium, $7. All of the items from The Kitchen Shop, Altman's.

title: SCHOOL FOOTBALL
description: Cornwall's Chick Jurgens joined a rather select group of quarterbacks who have man aged to defeat Riverdale teams when he led Cornwall to a 32 14 victory that snapped a Ri erdale winning streak of nine.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: One woman's bout with breast cancer. Ms. Campion happens to be a writer and a good one, so this is more than a clinical account. The drama here revolves around the author's stubborn decision, in the face of youareachild authoritarian advice from her surgeon, not to undergo a masectomy. A lesser operation is performed at the Cleveland Clinic under a physician who believes that each case is uni que, calling for unique treat ment. The author's operation has apparently been successful, and although her tumor was a small one, this story reflects the increasing rebellion of wo men against allornothing breast surgery.

title: GREEKS RECRUIT VILLAGE PRIESTS
description: ATHENS, Sept. 30 (Reuters) The Greek Orthodox Church says that a program to allow young poorly educated Greeks into the priesthood to fill vacancies in small villages is meeting success.

title: Japan's Taipei Embassy Continues Normal Duties
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 30  The Rising Sun flag was not flying atop the Japanese Em bassy in Taipei today.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: G. O. P. Backs L. I. Judicial Area
description: MINEOLA, L. I.  Nassau Republican candidates are going to call upon voters to vote yes for Amendment No. 3 on this year's Novem ber ballot; according to As semblyman Joseph M. Mar giotta, the Nassau County Republican chairman.

title: Sam Snead Cards 69
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 30 (AP)  Sam Snead shot a threeunderpar 69 today to take a fourshot lead after two rounds in the 20th Homestead 36hole proamateur invitation golf tournament.

title: Shinnecocks Keep Old Ties in Modern World
description: PATCHOGUE, L. I.Once long ago, the young brave Poggatatuck set out in his canoe to court Ashwa, a fair maiden who lived on man hansett aha quash awanuck, an island sheltered by islands. He was to become the last sachem of the Shinnecocks, whose dissolu tion as a tribe had been fore told in legend.

title: N.R. Papanicolaou Weds Miss Alexandra Gardner
description: BOSTON, Sept. 30  Miss Alexandra Gardner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Pea body Gardner Jr., was mar ried here at noon today to Nicholas Frederic Papani colaou, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sophocies Papanicolaou of Athens and London.

title: American U. Picks Coach
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  Tom Crouse, former track and crosscountry coach at Vir ginia's T.C. Williams High School, has been named Ameri can University's crosscountry coach. Crouse, who will also coach track, inherits the team that won the Middle Atlantic Conference championship.

title: PANEL WOULD END JAIL FOR THE ILL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30A special panel studying the na tion's criminal justice system will recommend to the Presi dent in November major changes in determining who ends up in prison.

title: Newark State Tops F.D.U. In Club Football by 127
description: UNION, N. J., Sept. 30 James Wilder's 60yard punt re turn with 33 seconds to play gave Newark State College 127 club football victory over Fairleigh Dickinson University, today. It was the opening game for both schools.

title: EssexHudson
description: Montclair and Seton Hall, two of the top teams in Essex County, won for the second straight weekend yesterday. Montclair blanked Irvington; 60, at Irvington, and Seton Hall stopped Newark East Side, 166, at Ironbound Stadium in Newark.

title: MRS. NE WIN
description: LONDON, Sept. 30 (AP) Mrs. Ne Win, wife of Burma's Prime Minister, died today in a hospital here, the Burmese Em bassy announced. She flew to London Thursday for treatment of a kidney illness. The em bassy did not disclose her age.

title: Bleached blonds
description: Blond, bleached woods are sweeping the design scene, part of the movement to get back to nature. Stacking chairs, above, designed by Bruno Rey, have upholstered seats and oak frames in a natural finish. Three are stacked. $125 each at Stendig.* The bleached wood frame of the chair, above, folds slim as a rail. Seat is cane; back is shaped for seating comfort. $50 at Gimbels.

title: Elly Rides a Crazy Carousel
description: AT 4 P.M., three hours before the recent Broadway premiere of Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris, Elly Stone entered a wellknown midtown the atercrowd restaurant. She was alone. In fact, she was the only customer in the res taurant except for a few boozers at the bar. Elly wanted a nice quiet vitamin packed dinner, a leisurely prelude to the evening ahead. She asked the waiter if he'd turn off the muzak. Canned music is to Elly what TV dinners are to Julia Child.

title: Rockland
description: The unbeaten preseason fa vorite, Nyack, got stuck in the mud and streaking North Rock land had its ego badly bruised yesterday in Rockland County P.S.A.L. football. Nyack was trounced by Nanuet, 267, but North Rockland rallied in the second half to run its winning streak to 18 with a 164 victory, over Clarkstown South.

title: WYOMING SURPRISES ARIZONA STATE, 4543
description: (AP)A junior quarterback, Steve Cockreham, ran for three touchdowns, passed for another and Wyoming held off a late rally to defeat 11thranked Arizona State, 4543, in a West ern Athletic Conference foot ball game here today.

title: PLANE CRASH KILLS OKLAHOMA STUDENTS
description: GOLDSBY, Okla., Sept. 30 (UPI)Six young men, includ ing the head cheerleader and three other University of Okla homa students returning to campus from Texas for today's football game with Clemson, were killed early today in the crash of their airplane at a small, fogshrouded airport.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Ohba, Chionoi to Fight
description: BANGKOK, Sept. 30 (Agence France Presse)  The World Boxing Association flyweight boxing champion, Masao Ohba of Japan, has agreed to meet Charchai Chionoi of Thailand, a former champion, over 15 rounds in Japan on Jan. 2, 1973.

title: Skull Found in South Africa Put at 2 Million Years Old
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 30 (Reuters) Workers digging in the Sterk fontein caves have uncovered the fossilized skull of an ape woman possibly two and a half million years old, it was an nounced by Prof. Phillip To bias, an expert in man's origin.

title: Sheriffs Suit Brings $5,000 Oilspill Fine
description: WOODBRIDGEThe Coast Guard, acting on an antipol lution complaint filed by a sheriff in New Jersey, has fined the Amerada Hess Cor poration $5,000 for an oil spill in the Arthur Kill last June.

title: New & Novel
description: I'm not certain about the se quence in Saw when I was halfway through, my unbound review copy selfdestructed, dribbling its pages all over the floor. Reassembling them as best I could, I concluded that Steve Katz (his previous books were The Exaggerations of Peter Prince and Creamy & Delicious) is a witty fantasist who can homogenize pop de tritus, campy slang and hallu cination to achieve inspired chaos.

title: Where the Whole Town Gathers, Or So It Seems
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt.  Whitehaired women, nursing mothers, suited profes sionals and barefoot freaks share tables and inside information on what's good today at The Common Ground restaurant here.

title: On the McGovern Endorsement
description: To the Editor:

title: Two More Boat Shows Get Under Way Friday
description: If you think you've been see ing fewer boats on the Sound and along the coast lately, you are probably right. With five inthewater boat shows vying for attention in the East, there's hardly a new vessel that has not been comman deered by an overanxious boat show producer. In any case, there are too few boats to go around, and promoters are turning to other attractions to lure a satiated audience.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: LANDER, Wyo.  Dawn was cold 7,500 feet high in the foothills of Wyoming's Wind River Mountains, But the sky was clear and when the Indian Summer sun rose its warmth touched the cot tonwoods in the valleys and gleamed on the yellowing leaves of the aspens on the hillsides as we looked down into South Pass, a portion of the Oregon Trail that cuts through the mountains at this point.

title: Preps
description: HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Sept. 30 Connie Pensavalle returned the opening kickoff 84 yards for a touchdown and. Tabor Academy went on for a 176 victory over Peddie. John Zac chile, who scored on a 54yard touchdown run, gained 103 yards in five carries.

title: Grandmother's Path to Pulpit Is Long
description: SUMMITWorry over not being able to believe the Bible stories she was teach ing as a Sundayschool teach er started Mrs. Marguerite Beissert on the long spiritual journey that culminated in her ordination as a minister of the United Church of Christ.

title: Old Foes, New Friends
description: Japan has now leapfrogged ahead of the United States in the world rush to tie new links with the onetime international pariah, mainland China. This is as expected; in fact, the mission of Japanese Premier Tanaka to Peking proceeded with such precision that the most grievous upset of the whole visit was Mr. Tanaka's absentminded ness in starting to drink Premier Chou Enlai's toast his own sake instead of the Chinese mao tai wine.

title: Amherst Beats Springfield In Season Opener, 27 to 3
description: AMHERST, Mass., Sept. 30 On a slippery field under rainy skies, Amherst College opened its 1972 football season with a 273 victory over Springfield today.

title: Rutgers to Offer Courses To Comuters on Trains
description: NEW BRUNSWICK Rut gers University will convert some ErieLackawanna Rail road cars into classrooms for commuters beginning Oct. 16.

title: U.S PLANES RAID 4 BASES IN NORTH AND CLAIM 5 MIG'S
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sun day, Oct. 1  United States fighterbombers have attacked four North Vietnamese air bases, an American spokesman said yesterday, dealing what he described as the heaviest blow to date against enemy aircraft on the ground.

title: The Nation
description: Normally unsung and unknown, 950 Democratic county committeemen are suddenly Big Men on the West Side political campus.

title: A Hint of McGovern's Latin Program
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 30  Theodore C. Sorenson has is sued a sharp attack on Presi dent Nixon's Latin  American policies and then outlined what may constitute a preview of Senator George McGovern's po sition on the subject.

title: Pull yourself together
description: Suitable is the word, all right, for suits are suitable to this utumn's way of life. They have a puttogether elegance nat's a refreshing change from the hodgepodge fashions e've been seeing for too long. They make words like sleek and soign and wellgroomed sound respect ble again. Fall '72 is a season when no smart woman ants to look messy. So it's into hats and higher heels and uits, suits, suits. Leave the blue jeans to history!

title: State Unit Is Flooded By Gripes Of Buyers
description: NEWARKIn the case of the New Jersey Division of Consumer Affairs, familiari ty breeds complaint: as many as 1,500 a month from oftn ira te consumers with real or imagined grievances.

title: The Nation
description: Senate hearings into the unauthor ized air strikes ordered against North Vietnam by Air Force Gqn. John S. Lavelle ended on something of a quizzi cal note last week. Echoes of Catch22.

title: Retarded Children's Unit Is Now 25
description: TEANECK  Back in 1946, when Mrs. Alfred Blossford realized she could not care for her braindamaged son alone, she turned to outside help, but found that the few state institutions for the re tarded were overcrowded, and that the few private fa cilities were too expensive and too far from her Tea neck home.

title: Two books depressing by their excellence
description: Any reporter who has prac ticed the craft for 30 years or more knows much that he has never written, and one who has spent many of those years as a White House correspond ent knows vastly more than he has ever committed to print. Merriman Smith and Bill Law rence not only were assigned to the White House for many years, but both were stars of the first magnitude in that galaxy. Now that the service of both has been ended by death, it is not surprising to learn that each had material for a tale that holdeth chil dren from play and old men from the chimney corner.

title: On the McGovern Endorsement
description: To the Editor:

title: FUNDS CAMPAIGN BEGUN BY COLLEGE
description: Marymount Manhattan Col lege announced yesterday the beginning of a twoyear cam paign to raise nearly $2mil lion to complete construction of a $5million annex to its quarters at 221 East 71st Street and an additional $500,000 for scholarships and faculty sabbaticals and professional study.

title: 6 Students Fighting Eviction By Village
description: BELLE TERRE, L. I.The house they live in is rented, but they keep it as neatly as if it were their own. Their furnishings, paid for out of their own pockets, are as modest as themselves. They appear to a visitor to be quiet, studious, almost diffident young people.

title: Letter to the Editor 2  No Title
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: The knitfabric industry, with more than $1billion in annual sales, has achieved technological breakthroughs that will give its product higher priorities than ever in fashion apparel.

title: Prison Hole Closed
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 30 (AP)The hole, a feared soli taryconfinement facility at the state prison in McAlester since the early days of statehood, has been closed by Gov. David Hall.

title: SCHOOL FOOTBALL
description: Dalton defeated Fieldston, 80, on a 6yard touchdown run by Orlando Wright, a halfback, early in the fourth period. Turnovers on intercepted pass es; fumbles and penalties were prominent In Fieldston's third straight loss.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Television
description: IN the world of television, few things are more standardized than tele vision criticism. The general pat tern, has been firmly established: Watch the program and, in several paragraphs or less, attempt to explain what is good or bad about it. The re sult is, of course, highly subjective but it can provide, especially in the form of prereviews, a service of some value to the reader.

title: Local
description: Pete Pakvorian's 3  yard touchdown run in the final quarter led Stuyvesant to 156 ManhattanBronx P.S.A.L. victory over Washington on the loser's field. Lt was the second straight triumph for the Peg legs and the second league de feat for Washington, compet ing in its first season of var sity competition.

title: Isaac Gets Iona Post
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 30  Warren Isaac, who still holds seven individual records at Iona College, will return to his alma mater as assistant varsity basketball coach this season. The second greatest scorer in Iona history, trailing only Richie Guerin, Isaac graduated from Iona in 1965 and has played profes sional basketball in Italy since.

title: French Chef Gets Grant
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 30 (AP)  Julia Child's French Chef cooking show on the Public Broadcasting Systenl has gotten a second life with an $80,000 grant from the Polaroid Corp. Polaroid, which has sup ported the television program for the last five years, had de cided to withdraw its support from the show but reconsidered after receiving mail backing it. P.B.S. made the announcement yeseterday.

title: Movies
description: SELDOM have I had to revise my opinion of a film upward on seeing it a second time only a few days later. But The Ruling Class, which is well worth seeing once, seems to me wickedly persuasive the second time around. The jokes, amusing the first time, become more clearly purpos ive the second; even the seemingly deficient discipline and overabundant length re veal a perverse cogency and insidious logic. That second time, as the lights went up, I looked everywhere for my objections  under my seat and all the neighboring onesbut I could not find them.

title: Thomas Flynn Weds
description: Miss Mary Elnora Engle, daughter of Mr; and Mrs. Francis Engle of Bayside, Queens, was married there yesterday morning to Thomas J. Flynn, son of Mrs. Martin Flynn of Jamaica, Queens, and the late Mr. Flynn.

title: Michigan Routs Tulane As Shuttlesworth Stars
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 30 (AP)Ed Shuttlesworth bull dozed for 150 yards in 21 car ries, scoring three touchdowns, to lead Michigan to a 417 vic tory over Tulane today.

title: Law
description: Being in the Mafia has its disad vantages. You have to be careful about what you say on the phone in case it's bugged. You have to watch your move ments in case you're followed. And you may find your meal interrupted by gunfire when you're at your favorite restaurant.

title: Awarding of a West German Peace Prize Stirs Memories of a Wartime Martyr of the Warsaw saw Ghetto
description: WARSAW, Sept. 30  A cloudy morning, apparently an ordinary beginning to the day, wrote Janusz Korczak from the office of his Warsaw orphan age. It was Aug. 4, 1942, and it was to be no ordinary day.

title: The People
description: Everyone is a little shunned about it. That was 14yearold Mitchell Rosen's explanation of the reluctance of his East Flatbush neigh bors to discuss the tense confrontation with racial overtones that has enveloped his school, the stolid red brick Meyer Levin Junior High School 285 at Ralph Avenue and Beverley Road. What the ninthgrader meant quickly became clear despite the garbled word.

title: On the McGovern Endorsement
description: To the Editor:

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Virginia Knauer, Special As sistant for Consumer Affairs, said, Of the thousands of con sumer complaints I receive monthly, the largest single cat egory concerns automobile service and repairs. Senate hearings have been held on the problem (at one point, Sen ator Hruska joked that the subject might better be under the ju??isdiction of the com mittee on organized crime). The authors point out that no states license auto repairmen, require adequate equipment of them, or with the exception of California and Connecticut pro vide punishment for cheat ing. The authors describe the use of flatrate manuals, go into the great warranty head ache and the auto manufac turers interest in selling cars and parts rather than prevent ing breakdowns. The book offers valuable tips to con sumers to prevent these and other abuses.

title: Rutgers Rule Due On Guns for Police
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  Rut gers University is near a de cision on whether the cam pus police should be allowed to carry pistols under limited conditions.

title: Twice Over Lightly
description: Twice Over Lightly by Helen Hayes (the first lady of the American theater) and Anita Loos (author of Gentle men Prefer Blondes and over 200 movie scenarios) is precise ly titledselected presentday views of New York places and personalities set in a counter point of the authors' reminis cences.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  To the scores of newsmen assembled at New York's Kennedy Airport, it was a joyous scenethree freed American pilots le turning home from a prison camp in North Vietnam.

title: M. I. Saltzman to Wed. Sandra Gabrilove
description: Dr. and Mrs. J. Lester Gabrilove have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Leslie Gabrilove, to Michael I. Saltzman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Saltzman of Paterson, N. J. The wedding is planned for January.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: An attempt to theorize about the antidemocratic character of public education in this country. Mr. Spring's analysis is historical. Nineteenthcentury thinkers, he says, were im pressed by the corporation as a model for society. Education became a way of adapting youth to social demandsmak ing them good organization men, capable of functioning in a corporate society. Even though lip service was paid to freedom and permissive ness the real goal of educa tion was to manipulate the student as a thing, a unit of production and consumption, rather than to allow him to adapt to his own needs. There are portraits of such leading educational theorists as George W. Perkins, Herbert Croly, G. R. Taylor, John Dewey and Wilson Gill. Another shot fired in the battle to deschool society, with a predictably appreciative foreword by Ivan Illich.

title: Black Exposition Marked by Politics
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 30  The theme was Save the children and economics was the over all goal, but Presidential poli tics dominated this year's Black Expo.

title: MIDDLEBURY DOWNS WESLEYAN BY 186
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Sept. 30 (AP)Phil Pope, New Eng land's 1971 smallcollege scor ing leader, scored all of Middle bury's 18 points today, while rushing for 114 yards in 11 carries as the Panthers scored an 186 victory over Wesleyan.

title: The New York Times Guide To Business and Finance By Albert L. Kraus. Illustrated. 280 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $8.95.
description: The uncertainties and the complexities of finance and business are examined from different viewpoints by the au thors of four recent books. Three are toilers, at descend ing levels, in the monetary mines; and the fourth is an ob server, a business journalist. All agree that dazzling oppor tunities as well as unpredict able difficulties are the na ture of modern commerce and finance.

title: The Human Side of Textiles
description: HONG KONGBy American standards the $107 a month Mrs. Chan Kamchuen receives for tending a spinning machine in the South Seas textile mill here is not much, but considering the company extras that go with it and the modest costs of the way she is able to live, the attracive 28yearold Mrs. Chan says she is doing pretty well.

title: Preps
description: Locust Valley Friends, led by Vince Mazzeo, a quarterback, downed McBurney, 280, at the Horace Mann field. Mazzeo scored twice on runs and passed 45 yards to Mike O'Brien to account for three touch downs.

title: BOSTON COLLEGE BEATEN BY NAVY
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 30 (AP)Dan Howard raced 41 yards for a fourthperiod touchdown and slipped over from six inches for another to day to power Navy to a 2720 football victory over Boston College.

title: Headliners
description: Black Comedy

title: Religion
description: Pope Paul VI is a man who under stands the value of symbolic acts, and a few years ago, on the way to his summer residence at Castelgandolfo, he stopped briefly to pray at the last living quarters of Pope Celestine V. Pope Celestine, in case you don't re call, was a 13th century. Pontiff whose principal achievement was that he re signed after only five months on the job.

title: L.S.U. Beats Wisconsin, 277, As Dantin Outrushes Ferguson
description: BATON ROUGE, Sept. 30 (AP)Louisiana State's tail back, Chris Dantin, stole the glory from WiEconsins Rufus (Roadrunner) Ferguson tonight by gaining 115 yards on 27 car ries and miring a touchdown in a 277 Tigers' victory.

title: Ecology Expert In New Job
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I.Dr. Ian W. Marceau, Huntington's environmental expert, is leaving this town in two weeks to begin new battles for nature on Long Island's South Fork.

title: JETS SEEKING NO. 3 AT HOUSTON TODAY
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 30One of the things Weeb Ewbank, the New York Jets coach, likes about Texas is the great foot ball players that come out of the state, and proof of that fact is that the Jets brought nine Texans with them to face the Houston Oilers in the As trodome tomorrow.

title: Bay State Disaster Area
description: BOSTON, Sept. 30 (AP) Plymouth County, damaged by a tropical storm during the La bor Day weekend, has been de clared a disaster area, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said yester day. The action makes home owners and businessmen eligi ble for longterm, lowinterest Federal loans to make repairs.

title: LINDSAY STUMPS IN THE MIDWEST
description: WINONA, Minn., Sept. 30 Mayor Lindsay of New York this weekend went on the national campaign trail for Senator George McGovern for the first time. The message he carried to Iowa, Minnesota and Michigan was that the Demo cratic Presidential nominee was no radical, and both the mes sage and the New York Mayor were well received.

title: Clemente Notches No. 3,000, Officially
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 30 Roberto Clemente, who com plained bitterly when he felt the official scorer deprived him of his 3,000th hit last night, finally achieved his cherished goal today when he stroked a long double to leftcenter field off the Mets' J. Matlack in the fourth inning to become the 11th man in major league his tory to reach the 3,000hit plateau.

title: Refugee from the Holocaust
description: It's a tribute to the power of tradition that after all these years of printing (rather than declaiming or chanting or sing ing) we still haven't fully rec ognized that poetry and fiction are arts for the eye, like paint ing, rather than for the ear, like music. This is an exaggera tionbut it's worth thinking about. True, the relation of language to speech is always crucial. True, we can't ignore the importance of the mind's ear. True, there are fine poets who work in a bardic style, like Ginsberg.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Commodity Controversy
description: LONDONWhen the next round of world trade negotia tions gets underway, some of the hottest controversy is ex pected to center on some of the least known International agreementsthe worldwide commodity agreements that regulate the price and supply of such primary products as wheat, sugar, tin and coffee.

title: FIRE AIDE DEFENDS NEW BROOKLYN PLAN
description: Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery yesterday defended his department's plan to cut fire equipment and manpower in the Brownsville, BedfordStuy vesant and Bushwick sections of Brooklyn through a system of adaptive response.

title: The Nation
description: A couple of weeks ago, officials of the Nixon Administration and of sev eral large American graindealing cor porations were basking in the glory of the largest grain deal in history. In the transaction the Russians, thanks to a $500million credit agreed to by the Nixon Administration, were able to purchase $1billion worth of Amer ican wheat, feed grains and soybeans.

title: Richard Crooks, Tenor at the Met, Dies
description: Richard Crooks, the tenor who was for many years a star of the Metropolitan Opera in New York and for 14 years the featured singer on the Voice of Firestone, died today of cancer at his home. He was 72 years old and lived in Portola Valley, Calif.

title: Charles Victor on 285
description: TURNBERRY, Scotland, Sept. 30. (AP)  Lefthander Bob Charles of New Zealand, bat tling the windswept Ailsa championship course and the challenge of Gay Brewer, shot a 76 today for a 72hole total of 285 to win the $134,750 John Player golf tournament.

title: The Nixon Men
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Any list of the most lively, interesting persons to serve in the Nixon Administration would probably be headed by Dr. Henry Kissinger, a Rockefeller Re publican; John B. Connally, a Johnson Democrat, and Daniel P. Moynihan, a Kennedy Democrat.

title: News of Dogs
description: The Westbury Kennel As sociation takes pride in call ing its annual fixture the Show of Distinction. Today's event, on the grounds of C. W. Post College, in Brook ville, L. I., has the distinction of being the 50th staged by the club. Mrs. John Marshall Jones, its able president, has gone all out to make the show, which has drawn 1,795 dogs, a real ly distinctive one. There will be flags flying from every tent, flowers on the tables in each ring, and posts garnered with vines. More than $5,000 in cash prizes will be dis tributed and the trophy table will be lush, with silver bow els, trays and figurines.

title: Harvard Names Official
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 30 (AP)  Raymond Vernon has been named director of the Center for International Affairs at Harvard University, effective Jan. 1, to succeed Robert R. Bowie, who is resigning.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: About 15 years ago a friend took me, a small realestate investor, to a neighborhood in Queens where a contractor was putting up a double row of illegal threes. She urged me to buy one as an invest ment. I was pretty fed up with my rentcontrolled brownstone in Manhattan and was looking around for something easier to run.

title: GA. TECH'S SURGE TIES RICE, 3636
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 30 (UPI) Eddie McCashan, a quarterback, passed for five touchdowns and a 2point conversion today that helped Georgia Tech gain a 3636 tie with the unbeaten Rice Owls. The tying point came with 17 seconds left to play.

title: Consumer Bill Closure Bid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) A second petition to cut off debate on a bill to establish a Consumer Protection Agency was filed in the Senate today to be voted on Tuesday. An initial move to invoke the Sen ate's antifilibusted rule failed yesterday.

title: Syracuse Downs Maryland
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 30 (AP) Syracuse scored two touch downs and a safety in less than three minutes of the second pe riod today and went on to de feat Maryland, 1612.

title: Transplant Worth Risk? 500 Who Know Yes
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30 The main ballroom of the San Francisco Hilton was crowded today, with living testimony to the importance of medical transplantation about 500 men, women and children who would have died had they not received transplanted organs.

title: Ronan Named Man of Year
description: Dr. William J. Ronan, chair man of the Metropolitan. Trans portation Administration, has been named man of the year by the American Transit Associa tion for revitalizing urban mass transportation in the New York metropolitan area and for his leadership role nationally.

title: Cahill, at Women's Conference, Defends Record
description: TRENTON, Sept. 30 (AP) Governor Cahill defended his record on, the women's issue today before the first New Jersey Conference on Women. But the audience that was polite to the Governor was openly hostile to the State Commission on Women.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: LONDON, Sept. 30  How to meet growing public and governmental pressures for lower airline fares without going bankrupt was the ma jor topic of discussion at the 28th annual meeting of the International Air Transport Association in London this week.

title: RYANABZUG RACE IS RATED A TOSSUP
description: Mrs. William F. Ryan and Representative Bella S. Abzug pressed, their campaigns for the Democratic nomination in the 20th Congressional District yes terday, with the outcome, scheduled for a vote today, still uncertain.

title: Local
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 30Stony Brook used an alert defense and the running of Randy Ellison and Wayne Pierce to take an 186 victory from Horace Mann. Pierce, the quar terback, scored twice on short runs and Ellison ran for 97 yards and one score. The Stony Brook defense recovered five fumbles and intercepted two passes. Each school is 11.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: M'GOVERN MAKES SLIM GAIN IN POLL
description: Senator George McGovern has slightly improved his stand ing among the voters, particu larly outside the South, ac cording to a new Gallup Poll.

title: Not quite a mother but more than a friend
description: The birthday of my niece Lizzie the other dayshe was 7felt like a landmark, whatever that is, or maybe I mean a slight pain in the throat. (What, 7 already?) I didn't ask my brother and his wife how they felt, but I was shaken. Lizzie has two brothers, Tom, 14, and Peter, 16. I am their only aunt on our side of the family. They have other aunts, but I have no other children. They are what posterity I have. Genetically, there are ties, faint perhaps, but luminous.

title: Mrs. Deanne Hansen Remarried
description: In the chapel at the Brick Presbyterian Church yester day afternoon, Mrs. Deanne Houghton Hansen was mar ried to Charles. Spencer Bis sell Jr. by the Bev. Thomas Seth Stewart. Members of the immediate families at the ceremony included the cou ple's children from previous marriages, which ended in divorce. They were Miss Caroline Bissell, Charles Bis sell, 3d, Henry Bissell, John Bissell and Lee Hansen.

title: Breezy Point Awaits Action on Park
description: The orange and black butterfly flitted across the al most deserted beach near the tip of. Breezy Point, Queens, passing over seashells and seaweed before coining to rest momentarily on a rusted beer can.

title: The World
description: OSLOHow, asked a Conserva tive member of Norway's parliament, can we explain to the world why this country has committed economic suicide?

title: SENATE VOTES CUT IN AGE TO RECEIVE PENSION BENEFITS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  The Senate voted today to lower the ages at which work ers and widows can begin re ceiving reduced Social Security benefits.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Dr. Howard Rusk, a pioneer in physical rehabilitation, is now one of its leading au thorities. He became interested in the subject during service with the Air Force in World War IL Up to that time, para plegics were expected to lie immobile and wait for death. Rusk worked with thousands of G.I.'s who had lost arms and legs or suffered paralysis. A modest and sympathetic man, Rusk gives final credit for the remarkable success stories to the patients themselves.

title: Rule Changes in A.B.A.
description: These new rules will be in effect for the coming American Basketball Association season.

title: Health
description: Another methadone victim, ob served an aide to New York City Ad diction Services Commissioner Gra ham Finney. The sardonic comment was not about another death from methadone overdosethere have been 100 such in the city this yearbut about Mr. Finney himself, who sudden ly resigned last week, in part because of what he sees as an overemphasis on the use of methadone in City and Federal drug programs. They have slighted, he believes, the growing prob lem of polydrug users who are not on heroinand therefore cannot be helped by methadone.

title: FailSafe Education
description: Not long ago Federal agencies were instructed substitute lowincome for poverty in official docu mentsan ingenious effort to rid the country of poverty. Now Yale has joined several other universities in elimi nating failure in any course by the simple expedient of not entering failure on student records.

title: Bookshelf
description: THE CATALOGUE OF CATA LOGUES, The Complete Guide to WorldWide Shopping by Mail, by Maria Elena de La Iglesia, Random House, $4.95 paperback. Anyone who has traveled abroad is struck by the seemingly fabu lous buys that he encounters. But travelers are almost always too low on funds for the big expendi tures like antiques, silver and crystal, furniture or furs. Here are names and addresses (and prices) of foreign firms who issue catalogs of their wares for buy ing by mail. Many sources for tantalizing buys are listed along with details about ordering, ship ping, customs duty and the po tenial hazards of returns.

title: So. Connecticut Triumphs
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 30 (AP) Southern Connecticut State crushed Maine Maritime Acad emy, 4110, today at Bowen Field.

title: On the McGovern Endorsement
description: To the Editor:

title: Balladeer Starts Cultural Invasion
description: SYOSSET, L. I.  If this area has suddenly become a hotbed of junior folksingers, attribute it to Oscar Brand. The popular balladeer start ed a cultural invasion last week that took him through all 10 elementary schools in the district, singing ballads, telling stories, answering questions, swapping songs, and making new friends for America's oldest form of mu sic.

title: BISHOPS' AUDIENCES WITH POPE LIMITED
description: ROME, Sept. 30The Vati can has indicated that it would be harder from now on for bishops to see the Pope privately.

title: MOON SHOT DELAY BY SOVIET LIKELY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 United States intelligence sources say that the Soviet Un ion is dismantling a mammoth booster rocket at the Tyuratam launching site near the Aral Sea, thus apparently ending any attempt at a landing on the moon for at least six months.

title: Jean Barber Bride Of Nicocles Michas
description: SEWICKLEY, Pa., Sept. 30  Miss Jean Elizabeth Bar ber, a sales representative for Greeff Fabrics in New York, was married here this afternoon to Nicocles L. Michas of New York, Wain scott, L. I. and Andros, Greece. The Rev. Dr. Jack M. Maxwell, a Presbyterian minister, performed the cere mony in the garden at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Orndorff, friends of the bride.

title: Thursday By Catherine Storr. 274 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $5.95. (Ages 12 to 16)
description: Catherine Storr's Thursday is the story of a changeling. The setting British, contemporary and urban, but the echoes are from A Midsummer Night's Dream and from even older incantations. At first, what could be homelier, cosier, brighter? Bee Earn shaw, a teenage schoolgirl convales cing in her loving home, hears that her schoolfriend (boyfriend is going a little too far, as yet) has vanished. This is Thursday: a boy of intelli gence and sensitivity, but a boy with out a proper Christian name, be cause he has never had a proper family. Almost, because he has never had a proper identity. . . .

title: Please, Isn't There Anyone for Tennis?
description: CONSIDER the Continental break fast. It contains precisely the num ber of calories necessary to pro pel the vacationing Continental from his villa or hotel to the beach. By the time he has inflated his Sevylor Rec reonics air mattress and angled it tow ard the sun, he is fit for nothing more strenuous than the contemplation of lunch, Those who consume the brioche and the croissant may be able to sum mon enough vitality to lift their heads at a particularly taut bikini. However, the classic petit dejeuner was never in tended to sustain anyone through three sets of singles in the Mediterranean sun.

title: Carol Alberti Married
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Sept. 30Miss Carol Ann Alberti, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph V. Alberti, was mar ried here this afternoon to Frank J. Crudele, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Crudele of Brooklyn, by the Rev. Bren dan Riordan in St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church.

title: Stamps
description: CATALOGUE time is now. Both the Scott Stand ard Postage Stamp Cat alogue and the Minkus New WorldWide Catalog are now available at stamp stores.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: The ground is very dry. Unless there is abundant rainfall soon, watering will be essential for all valuable woody plants, perennials, bulbs and lawns. . . . Wait until frost to dig and store dahlias, gladiolus, cannas, etc. . . . Last call to seed lawns.

title: Kennedy to Aid Nominee
description: BANGOR, Me., Sept. 30 Sena tor Edward M. Kennedy, Dem ocrat of Massachusetts, will will visit Maine Oct. 18 to cam paign for Democratic Senate nominee Wiliam D. Hathaway, a campaign aide reported today.

title: A heady blend
description: Natural textures and primitive, handcrafted accents continue to be dominant forces. When mixed with bronzetinted mirror and shiny steel, the effect is both contemporary and exotic. Designers Bebe Winkler and Bob Patino drew. upon these influences to give character to this typical onebedroom high rise apartment in Manhattan for executive Charles Glueck. The windows of the living room, top right, are covered by tortoise patterned rollup blinds set in mirrored frames. The sofa is a plush Lshaped banquette, punctuated by removable round bolsters. But it is the preColumbian art and oriental ceramic jars on tabletops and pedestals that contribute the strangely heady amosphere. The mood starts at the foyer, below right, with the shell encrusted mirror and twin bronze tinted mirrored screens. By contrast the bedroom, far right, is a cool and serene retreat. The bed, upholstered in the same burgundy velvet, rests on a redandbeige geometric carpet flanked by black lacquered night tables. Metallic blinds and black ceramic lamps are foils for the vibrancy of the res bed.

title: Two views of evilatlarge
description: Love Songs By Lawrence Sanders. 320 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $6.95.

title: The Visconti Hours
description: In the very beatitiful reproduction of The Visconti Hours, a manu script of the late Middle Ages, Mil lard Meiss, Director of the Institute for Advanced Studies at Princeton University, presents and discusses an unfamiliar and important work of Italian art. The technique of deco rating and illustrating manuscripts was the basic art of the Middle Ages. Its lavish use of gold and bright colors won for it in modern times the name of illumination. For several centuries it was the only medium in which art forms could pass readily from one country to another, and during this period man uscript illumination supplied the themes and iconography for sculp ture and stained glass. Hence the interest of illuminated manuscripts for the historian of art as well as for the connoisseur.

title: Local
description: With Eric Kipperman scoring two touchdowns in his first varsity game, Poly Prep downed Tottenville, 140, at the win ners' field. Poly, which tied its opener last week, used Joe La Fauci's running to set up both touchdowns.

title: Atlanta Fears Chicago Gangs Are Organizing City's Rackets
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 30  Resi dents of Atlanta this week re examined a question that has troubled the city since it be came the established leader of the South's new prosperity:

title: 5 Die as Ulster Toll Reaches 18 in Week
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 30Five more persons died today, victims of one of the worst weeks in Northern Ireland's violent history since the current crisis began in August, 1969.

title: Home Improvement
description: LAMINATED window shadesthat is, shades which have wallpaper or fabric laminated (glued) to the face sidehave long been popular with home decorators, but their high price (anywhere from $25 to 00 per shade for a window of average size) has Put them nut of the reach of many homeowners and apartment dwellers. However, a new material recently introduced now permits anyone who can use a ruler, a pair of scissors and an iron to easily make their own.

title: Cave Painting Found in Peru
description: LIMA, Peru, Sept. 30 (Reu ters)A British expedition has discovered cave paintings esti mated to be at least 10,000 years old about 150 miles east of in eastern Peru, its mem bers reported here this week. The paintings are 450 feet un derground, said Julian Coward, one of the sixman expedition's members.

title: 122 Army Deserters Seized In Sweep, Saigon Police Say
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 30Saigon police report ed today that during the week ended last Monday they had arrested 122 army deserters and 202 draft evaders in the capital as part of a new campaign. The police also were said to have rounded up 510 curfew violators, 98 military men with out proper papers, 146 civilians without proper papers or with false identification, 296 illegal residents, and three suspected Communists.

title: Missouri Stifles 2dHalf Rally To Defeat California, 34 to 27
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., Sept. 30 (AP)Two secondstring run ning backs, Chuck Link and Ray Bybee, led Missouri to a 20point firstquarter, outburst and a 3427 victory over Cali fornia today.

title: Son to the Warhaftigs
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Sept. 30A son was born Sept. 18 at the Klingenstein Pavillion of Mount Sinai Hospital in New York to Mr. and Mrs. Solomon L. Warhaftig.

title: Mating patterns
description: Getting it all together

title: Drivers and Police in Chicago Irked by TicketWriting Blitz
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 30A traf ficticket writing spree this week by many of the city's 13,500 policemen, in support of demands for collective bar gaining and other changes, left city officials, many drivers and police militants in angry moods today.

title: Says poet Brodsky, ex of the Soviet Union: A writer is a lonely traveler, and no one is his helper
description: When Lot's wife looked back at the walls of her native Sodom, she turned into a pillar of salt. And among the feelings I have as I begin writing there is some fear, intensified by the absolute mystery about what I will see if I look ahead. One might even conjecture that it was not so much home sickness as fear of the unknown future that made Lot's wife do what had been forbidden.

title: New Tree Injection Technique May Curb Dutch Elm Disease
description: A new technique is raising strong hopes for saving Ameri can elm trees, which are being killed at the rate of 400,000 a year by Dutch elm disease.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Eileen Shanahan's article made refreshing reading, with its suggestion that the eco nomids profession enter the fray and provide some facts and analysis on economic issues in the current election campaign. It is too bad that she did not practice what she preached. Her article asked good questions, but looked in vain for some an swers.

title: The World's People
description: In recent days two milestones of sorts were passed the long campaign to reduce the runaway rate of world population growth. Both are encouraging; neither implies solution of any of the basic problems.

title: Barndoor dividers
description: As playful a scene as Old MacDonald's barnyard is the bedandplayroom that Design Coalition devised for what must be their youngest client, Winifred, an active 4yearold. Winifred's room adjoined the nursery of her baby brother so the architects separated the two rooms with large barnlike doors. When opened, the rooms are one big unrestricted playground. Behind the doors is a schoolsized blackboard where Winifred doodles, below right. The yellow scheme relates the two rooms and the border of oversized circles just below the ceiling line seems to lower the ceiling to kid's size. Twin beds are hidden in a cabinet that repeats the barn door motif, below. Bookshelves on either side of the cabinet are easytoreach toy organizers. Bright flowersplashed bedspreads with ruffle skirts cover the tuckaway beds. The print is also laminated to the vertical blinds at the windows that rim a butcher block desk and counter (not shown).

title: What Do You Say After You Say Hello? The Psychology of Human Destiny. By Eric Berne, M.D. 457 pp. New York: Grove Press. $10.
description: Eric Berne's last book, What Do You Say After You Say Hello?, published two years after his death, is more inter esting and ambitious than his bestselling Games People Play, and it reveals, as that book did not, both the modest value and the profound limita tions of Berne's creation, Trans actional Analysis. A psychia trist trained in psychoanalysis, Berne viewed Transactional Analysis as a system of psy chotherapy, a theory of per sonality and a theory of so cial action.

title: Preps
description: LENOX, Mass., Sept 30 Cranwell rallied for two fourth quarter touchdowns to edge Berkshire, 2012. All three Cranwell touchdowns came on short runs, with a conversion run by Keith Lange providing the winning points.

title: Connecticut

The design for the sterling silver, piece, which will be 39 mil, limeters in diameter, is also unknown. The Franklin Mint will strike the commemora tives for the office of Base ball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn and a certificate of authenticity, signed by Com missioner Kuhn will accom pany each medal.

Russo of Little Falls, N. J. The ceremony was performed by State Supreme Court Jus tice Alexander Berman.

title: Richard T. Thierot Marries Mrs. Augie Reynal Withers
description: HILLSBOROUGH, Calif., Sept. 30Mrs. Angelica Rey nal Withers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Juan Reynal of Buenos Aires, was married here this evening to Richard Tobin Thieriot, son of Charles de Young Thieriot, editor and publisher of The San Fran cisco Chronicle, and Mrs. Thieriot. title: 100,000 Are Due to March In Pulaski Parade Today
description: The 36th annual Pulaski Pa rade is expected to have up to 100,000. PolishAmericans in the line of march when it begins at 1 P.M. today at 26th Street and moves up Fifth Avenue to 52d Street and then east to Third Avenue.

title: Take Wheels and Feathers and Fishing Lines ...
description: COLLAGE and assem blage  the techniques of making art works out of all sorts of dis parate and often readymade objects and materialshave been basic, recurrent motifs in modern art for 60 years. Variously exploited by any number of major artists and art movements, they have on occasion been taken as the foundation of one or another critical theory that sought to explain their potency and rationalize their use. But there has always been some thing anarchic about them, a quality of unpredictableness, sometimes bordering on per versity, that one suspects is at the root of their modern appeal. They have often seemed the perfect mediums for willful, idiosyncratic ge nius of the sort that regularly makes a hash of tidy theoties.

title: Surgery for Pearl Buck
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 30 Pearl S. Buck, the 80yearold author, has undergone surgery for removal of her gall bladder at Medical Center Hospital here. Miss Buck was admitted to the hospital last Sunday, suf fering abdominal discomfort. She had been hospitalized in July at Rutland for pleurisy. Her condition, a hospital spokesman said today, contin ues to be very satisfactory.

title: Nuptials Nov. 1. Set in Michigan By Miss Schlaff
description: GROSSE POINTE, Mich., Sept. 30  Miss Frederica Price Schlaff plans to be mar ried here to George A. Rent schler Jr. on Nov. 11, the wedding anniversary of his parents, Mrs. Rentschler of New York and the late Mr. Rentschler.

description: Only Asians Holding Kenyan Passports Are Allowed To Travel By Train To Kenya Until Further Notice.Sign in the railroad sta tion in Kampala, Uganda, Aug. 24, 1972.

title: New & Novel
description: Gentle is the heroine's name in this early 20thcentury bibelot, and gentle is the tone. But not without the heartache we know was once concealed behind whaleboned facades.

title: Interpol's Restrictions Limit Resolutions Adopted at Its Frankfurt Conference
description: FRANKFURT, West Ger many, Sept. 26Cops are cops, said the operator of a night club on Frankfurt's sinful Kaiserstrasse. Wheth er they are from Britain or France, Germany or Ghana, they're all stingy.

title: Bright lights and stage effects forecast the future
description: Changing lifestyles have left their impact on the design of interiors. And there will be more surprises in store. Not only are designers concerned about function and esthetics, but many are exploring the psychological effects that lights, form and space have on all of us. This apartment, which many people might consider an abstract concept hardly a place for real live peopleis the home of a young pop singer in Milan. At home with the theatrics and stage effects of pop performances, singer Caterina Caselli wanted digs that reflected the excitement and vitality of her highvoltage career. Architect Carla Venosta, a pacesetter in futuristic design, brought it all about. The apartment is situated in an old district of the city in a 19th century building. Venosta retained the facade, but inside she severed all links with the past.

title: Brazilians Find Skeleton Of a Dinosaur Ancestor
description: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, Sept. 30 (Reuters)The skel eton of a giant 180million yearold carnivorous reptile was discovered in a rock formation near this southern state capital, the local uni versity has announced here.

title: JOBSON INCREASES HIS SAILING LEAD
description: BARRINGTON, R.I., Sept. 30 Gary Jobson, a 22yearold senior at the NeW York Mari time Academy, won four straight races today on Narra gansett Bay and took a com manding lead after the first two days in the North Ameri can InterClass solo champion ship.

title: ONE 'N ONLY TAKES GREEN HUNTER TITLE
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Sept. 30One 'N Only, who won $34,000 on the track under the name of Nix Pix before his an kles gave out, breezed to the green working hunter cham pionship today at the Cooper Hospital horse show.

title: Peking Banquet Opens National Day Festivity
description: PEKING, Sept. 30 (Agence FrancePresse)Celebrations of the Chinese national day holiday, which falls tomor row, began this evening in a Peking sparkling with light. A banquet held by the Chinese leaders contrasted with the lowerkey cere monies of a year ago, which were dulled by what has since been officially called the Lin Piao plot.

title: Some Prefer a Road Jam
description: MANTOLOKING  Among the stopped cars, an ice cream vendor darts, happily pursuing his weekend beat. Perhaps the only man in the area with a smile on his face, he exhorts motorists to take their tongues for a sleighride.

title: Health
description: LOS ANGELES  The germs of environmental can cer in the year 2,000 are in our environment right now. My concern is, will we sit here in the year 2,000 and say, Why didn't we do what we should have done to prevent this in 1972?

title: The World
description: WASHINGTON  Very little of what is done in these negotiations will be widely understood or generally ap preciated, President Nixon told the world's finance ministers as they as sembled here last week to discuss monetary reform.

description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Sept. 30 (AP)Alan Lowry rallied hard pressed Texas with two second half touchdown runs following Texas Tech mistakes and the defending Southwest Confer ence champions rolled to a 25 20 victory tonight.
