description: WENDOVER, Utah, Sept. 30 (AP)Dave Anderson Of Minneapolis set two world landspeed records today be for a faulty tire forced him to retire his jetpowered drag racer, Pollution Packer, from the Bonneville Salt Flats.

title: Environments for heroes
description: Apartments that I design are not for everyone, says archi tect Carnal el Zoghby. People who live in them are heroes. Heroes because they agree to live without art, plants, furniture and all extraneous objects. What they gain in return is an organized environ ment that strikes its admirers as deeply spiritual. This apartment in an older brown stone on Manhattan's West Side, started out as a studio, 16by16 feet square with ceilings nearly 12 feet high. The client, a young press agent for rock groups, demanded three beds, an excellent sound system, dining space and a large work area to write and sew. The incredible order was actually fulfilled. Beds serve as sofas by day; carpeted platforms are additional seating. One platform, above right, extends beneath the window as a work counter, the ledge beneath it acts as the chair, The dining alcove is behind the bed. The speakers? Hidden behind a soffit at the ceiling; the wall plane slanted to project sound into the room. Two staircases lead to a bridge that connects with a sleeping balcony where the owner perches, opposite. Other cutout niches are mirrored so that the tiny room actually appears to go on and on. (continued)

title: Defense Excels as Cheyney Defeats St. John's, 31 to 0
description: St. John's University's club football team made too many errors in its first home game yesterday on the Jamaica cam pus, losing to the unbeaten var sity from Cheyney State, 310. A linebacker, Art Henry, was the big man for Cheyney. He tackled the Redman quarter back, Pete Qualshie, in the end zone for a safety, then inter cepted four passes in the second half, all of them setting up Cheyney touchdowns.

title: PATH OF BIG RIVER UNDER SEA TRACED
description: There is a great, deep river in the sea, probably the most voluminous on earth, and the United States has embarked on an ambitious effort to trace its path and extent of flow through all three of the major oceans.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Little things that bother you ... For instance, in John Rossiter's A ROPE FOR GEN ERAL DIETZ (Walker, $4.95) the hero, a British agent in Spain trying to prevent two Englishmen from killing a Nazi war criminal, gets his collar bone broken. Somebody tries to help him. Then he pulled my handkerchief from my pocket and contrived a sling with it. Try that sometime. Most handkerchiefs are about 16 inches square. It is possible to loop it around neck and arm, just possible. But what will happen to the broken collar bone when it is pushed up at an impossible angle?

title: PHILIPPINES JAILS EXCHIEF OF HUB
description: MANILA, Sept. 30President Ferdinand E. Marcos had Luis Tame, the aged onetime mill ary leader of the Communist Hukbalahaps, put back behind bars today in the Government drive to detain individuals con sidered subversive to the exist ing political and social order.

title: 2 Alleged Robbers Are Shot to Death By Brooklyn Grocer
description: A 36yearold Brooklyn grocer shot and killed two alleged holdup men minutes after they robbed him of $70, the police of the Ralph Avenue station re ported last night.

title: All Together Now, Let's Identify
description: IN its September issue, The Atlantic Monthly published a short piece of fiction by Donald Barthelme, a letter in which a man explains to his lov er's analyst why he ap proves of her decision to quit analysis and buy a piano. In considering The Family Game, a weekly halfhour of psychodrama which was pro duced in Pittsburgh and has its premiere on Channel 13 Wednesday night at 7, it might be helpful to bear in mind this business about the piano as alternative.

description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 30 (AP)  District Attorney Jim Garrison was defeated today in his bid for a seat on the Louisi ana Supreme Court, while a political novice and a former aide to Gov. Edwin Edwards won nominations to seats in Congress.

title: Maple Month
description: October is the maple month. Now the maples assert themselves, particularly here in the Northeast. Within another couple of weeks they will have painted the whole landscape with red and gold and all the tints, tones and shades between. The maples are the particular glory of our vivid October woodlands.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30One of the joys of owning hooks flows from the opportunity afforded from time to time to prune and reorganize the bookshelves.

title: Education
description: School boards generally have not considered pregnancy a medical problem. Not only has it been the custom of school boards to compel a pregnant teacher to surrender her job as soon, as possible, but the teacher usually has been denied a paid leave during the period im mediately following childbirth. And often she has had no guarantee that there would be a job to which to return.

title: An invaluable biography for some future biographer
description: Luce and His Empire is one of those dinosaur biographies, more bulk than brains, we factobsessed Americans go in for, W. A. Swan berg has already given us old tomes on Hearst, Pulitzer, Dreiser (a con genial subject, stylistically) and oth ers. (0 that this too solid data would melt, thaw, and resolve itself into a form!) His life of the late Henry Robinson Luce is not definitive definition isn't his thingbut it is undeniably big. His energy and scope as a researcher are either awesome or awful, depending on one's appetite for Facts, Unlimited. His seems to be insatiable, like some people's in ability to resist just one more peanut.

title: America as a dialectic without a synthesis
description: Defeated candidates for the Presi dency of the United States ordinarily do not stay very long within the reach of history. Adlai Stevenson probably will. In a confusing time he was a clarifying agent making use ful connections between our first principles and our latterday obliga tions, giving substance and distinc tion to our arguments and always, by wit and grace, stimulating our better selves. One of his great re sources was the way he used words to give precise shape to his thoughts and feelings. Nothing slick; no po dium hokum. It is therefore good to know that we will soon have eight volumes of words that he spoke or wrote on every kind of occasion. This book, covering what the editors call the beginnings of his education in the years from 1900 to 1941, is the first of the series.

title: CORNELL DEFEATS COLGATE, 37 TO 7
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 30 Cornell unveiled a diversified offense to complement a solid defense today and defeat Col gate, 377, in the season opener for Cornell.

title: Movies
description: FOR 10 years she had been regarded as talented newcomer, a Great Black Hope. You know, the kind of performer The Times would identify in its news columns as Cicely Tyson, actress, rather than Cicely Tyson, the actress. But now, judging from her posh Plaza suite, her huge bouquet of welcoming roses from 20th CenturyFox, her incessant tel ephone calls, her press clippings predicting an Oscar nomination for Sounder, aria her very obvious joy, Cicely Tyson is on the verge of becoming a Great Black (scratch the Hope) well the actress.

title: Son for Mrs. Hollander
description: STOCKTON SPRINGS, Me., Sept. 30A son was born Sept. 14 in St. Joseph's Hos pital in Bangor to Mr. and Mrs. Lorin Hollander. The child has been named Joshua Neill. Mr. Hollander is the concert pianist. The child's mother is the former Miss Margo Scheer of Brooklyn, N. Y.

title: The Trial of Joseph Brodsky
description: Here are excerpts from the two court hearings in the Brodsky case, in March and February, 1964, as recorded by Frieda Vigdorova, a mem ber of the Leningrad Writers Union who was so shocked by the proceeding that she permitted her notes to be taken out of the country. The translation was done by Coll yer Bowen for The New Leader and appeared in the Aug. 31, 1964, issue of the magazine.

title: How Callas Inspired an Opera for Dalis
description: AT one point in his early twenties, Alva Henderson heard a recording of Maria Callas singing the Sleepwalk ing Scene from Verdi's Macbeth. With some theatrical but little musical background, he knew he must become a composer. A few years later, he heard an other recording by the same soprano, this time of Cherubini's Medea, and he de cided he had to write an opera about the sorceress who slew her two children when her husband, Jason, deserted her. He got permission to use as a libretto the Robin son Jeffers version, in which Judith Ander son had been so successful. About the same time, he saw a performance by the San Francisco Opera of Janacek's Jenufa, and was much impressed with the portrayal by Irene Delis of Kostelnicka. (She kills baby, too, although it is her stepdaugh ter's.) Henderson wrote his opera with the in mind for the title role.

title: BAETJER SCORES WITH 0:56 TO GO
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 30 It took Princeton's football team nearly a whole game to day to solve the riddle of Rut gers, but that was enough, the Tigers coming out on top, 76, before 22,000 fans at Palmer Stadium.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 30  Patrick Dwyer, the suburbs, stockbroker walked briskly along this city's fashionable, windswept Michigan Avenue the other afternoon, then sud denly disappeared down a winding stair way toward the Chicago River.

description: Several hundred Chinese, wearing white smocks em blazoned with antiCommunist slogans and waving Chinese Nationalist flags, held a demon stratiton yesterday outside Chi na's mission to the United Na tions, at 166 West 66th Street.

description: Queens College will cele brate its 35th anniversary next weekend and the whole community will be involved.

title: GREENWICH SEEKS AIRPORT CURFEW
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 30Declining property values, rising citizen unrest, environ mental decay. This Connecticut suburb, not often associated with any of those urban ills, claims that the Westchester County Airport, just over the state line, is responsible for all three and is preparing to take Westchester to court to force a change in airport op erations.

title: Nadjari and D. A.'s Agree On Handling Graft Cases
description: The city's five District At torneys and the newly named special state prosecutor, Mau rice H. Nadjari, announced an agreement yesterday specifying that many corruption cases would continue to be carried out by the District Attorneys themselves and in their names.

description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 30 Don Massengale of Elmwood Country Club, who made up eight strokes on the final round yesterday to tie Ron Letellier of North Hills in the 57th Metro politan open golf championship, won the title today by three strokes in an 18hole playoff, played mostly in rain, at the Stanwich Club.

description: Larry Williams and Jim Tea torn took turns treating Farm ingdale followers to touchdowns yesterday as Farmingdale rout ed MacArthur, 40.0, to open defense of the North Shore title it won last season. It was the 12th victory in a row for the Nassau County champions.

title: FREED PILOT CALLED HEALTHY BY NAVY
description: Lieut. (jg.) Mark L. Gartley, who returned to the United States Thursday after spending more than four years in a North Vietnamese prison camp, was reported yesterday to be medi cally, quite healthy.

title: Bay State Disaster Area

Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said yester day. The action makes home owners and businessmen eligi ble for longterm, lowinterest Federal loans to make repairs.

title: Canadiens At Garden Tomorrow
description: The New York Rangers, start ing their final five days of training, will oppose the Mon treal Canadiens in a preseason game tomorrow night at Madi son Square Garden. Gaine time is 7:35.

He starts out 20,000 in hock, sets up a trust to keep the thing going, gulps tranquilizers to get over the fiscal crises, has adventures and misadventures with his wardsmostly odd, exotic, endangered species. All quite entertaining; kids should love it.

title: J. C. Ferrer Weds. Miss Franklin
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 30Miss Jeanne Kerr Franklin and James Christian Ferrer, son of Dr., and Mrs: Jos M. Ferrer of New York and Southampton, were mar ried here this afternoon in St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal, Church. The Rev. Howard M. Lowell, the rector, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Hilary Martin, a Roman Catholic priest and a member of the faculty of Portsmouth Abbey in Rhode island. A reception was held at the Duck Pond Road home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Philip A. S. Franklin.

title: Mrs. Wilson Married

Carroll, a partner in the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling, were married here at noon today at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John de Roos. The Rev. Fred erick Jenkins of the Irvington Presbyterian Church perform ed the ceremony.

title: Marguerite E. Dorrnent Is Wed to William Glover 3d
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 30  Miss Marguerite Ellen Dorment and William Harvey Glover 3d were married here this afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of the Im maculate Conception. Msgr. Thomas Cunningham per formed the ceremony, as sisted by the Rev. Bernard Reilly.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: The author was chief mete orologist for the DDay invas ion and reported directly to General Eisenhower or his deputies. Weather, of course, played a key role in the ac tion; and now Mr. Stagg, who kept a diary, recounts his story .7the acute tension he was under; his relationships with other weathermen, who often differed with him; the difficul ties of collating conflicting data; the particular unpredictability of the weather that June and indeed at most times in that area. The invasion was begun on June 4 but had to be re called. Prognosis was dark, but suddenly a clear period ap peared on the horizon for Tues day, June 6. Mr. Stagg advised accordingly, and Eisenhower made his momentous decision. The forecast held. It turned out that if Eisenhower had postponed for two weeks (the next low tides) he would have been frustrated again: the next good weather didn't come until August. A red  lined footnote to history.

title: Mrs. Marcia H. Ince Married to Francis Branin Jr.
description: In the Chanel of the Be loved Disciple at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest here yesterday afternoon, Mrs. Marcia Herz Ince was married to Francis Sunfield Branin Jr., a secu rities analyst and registered representative with J. & W. Seligman & Co. The cere mony was performed by the Rev. Lawrence R. Prast, and was followed by a reception at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard W. Ford.

title: DIVORCE DEAL LAID TO ITALIAN REDS
description: ROME, Sept. 30Anticleri cal politicians and newspapers here are accusing the Italian Communist party of harboring Machiavellian designs to strike a deal with the Roman Catholic Church on the divorce issue.

title: Women's Editor. Salesman Found Slain in Raleigh, N.C.
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Sept. 30 (AP)  The women's editor of The Raleigh Times and a local real estate man were found shot to death at a fishing and picnic resort on the Neuse River near here today.

title: Miss Anne L. Sprole
description: DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 30 The engagement of Miss Anne Louise Sprole to Richard W. Jacobs has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Frank A Sprole, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred O. Jacobs of Goiden, Coto.

title: Art
description: THE overwhelming size and complexity of Lon don's mammoth multi museum exhibition, The Age of Neoclassicism, make it all but Impossible to describe, much less to evalu ate, except in such general terms as wonderful. One entire section, a brilliant col lection of architectural draw ings, models, paintings, and photographs assembled under the direction of Sir Anthony Blunt, is likely to be lost, tucked away as it is in the Royal Academy's diploma galleries, which must be reached by going down one flight from the rest of the exhibition and searching out a rickety elevator to take to the floor.

title: Sexy Spanish women and good Greek colonels
description: During the past two decades a book on Spanish affairs by New York Times correspon dents after serving in Madrid has become almost de rigueur. Herbert Matthews, correspon dent in Republican Spain dur ing the Civil War, returned briefly in the mid1950's and published The Yoke and the Arrows in 1957. Benjamin Welles, the son of Sumner Welles, was Times correspon dent in Madrid during the late fifties, and early sixties, and subsequently wrote a book called Spain, the Gentle An archy. Both these volumes con stituted highlevel contempor ary political analyses. Welles's book also provided an indepth chronicle of politics during his period and so made a contribu tion to modern Spanish his well.

title: Danes Say Undecided Voters Hold the Key to Tomorrow's Vote on Market Entry
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 30On the eve of the referendum that will determine whether Denmark becomes a member of the European Eco nomic Community, leaders of both sides are making major efforts to win over the large number of undecided voters.

title: Orioles'. 21 Victory Cuts Boston Lead to Half Game
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 1  The Boston Red Sox took a costly stumble on their collision course with the Detroit Tigers today when they lost a 21 deci sion to the Baltimore Orioles on the eve of their fateful series in Detroit.

title: They Seek Help for Anything From the School Ombudsman
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y.  A car struck Tommy Fowler's dog, Jingo, the other day. Tommy was racing for the school bus stop when he heard the brakes screech and Jingo's yelp. The dog  his tawny fur spotted with blood  fled into the brush. A minute later, the bus pulled up and the driver waved Tommy aboard.

description: PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 30  Astronomers at the Hale Observatories are conducting an elaborate postmortem on a grant star that died violently 10 million years ago.

Farrell has won 22 straight at home since it opened its field in 1968.

It concerns the casualties and refu gees  practically none of whom are white caused by present bombing policies over allied, enemy and neu tral countries in Indochina.

title: Aid for Ugandan Asians

If the U.N. were helpless to respond in this kind of human tragedy it would be almost as irrelevant as its diehard critics contend.

Whether it will equal the run of The Threepenny Opera is diffi cult to predict, but I think it will be around for quite a time. For one thing it is stuffed with some of the greatest theater music over written. With that kind of musical richness what can go wrong? A little.

Dr. Grand is a psychiatrist, and his wife, known as Mrs. Helen Grand, is a psycholo gist.

title: Miklos Jansco's 'Red Psalm' Screened
description: Miklos Jansco's "Red Psalm" takes place at an indeterminate time on an open field where a group of peasants confront and, in the long run, symbolically conquer a group of soldiers and landed aristocrats. Thus there are political issues at stakethough for Hungary of the 1970's, I should think, exceptionally safe onesbut I'm not sure they matter much. In "Red Psalm," as in Jansco's movies generally ("The Round-up," "The Red and the White," etc.), the point is not what things are, but what they look like.On one level things look pretty good. The cast is made up mostly of handsome young men and beautiful young women, and some of the young women undress from time to time in a kind of solemn masque of eroticism. The color is lush, the movements are graceful and the camera work  a Jansco trademarkis spectacular.According to the current issue of the film magazine, Sight and Sound, "Red Psalm" contains only 26 shots. An ordinary movie of this length (88 minutes) would contain several hundred shots. To make up the difference, the camera moves and people move back and forth and in large or small circles, and I suppose it is right to sayas everybody saysthat a Jansco film is not so much directed as choreographed. Actually, it looks to me less like choreography than a cross between eurythmics and close-order drill.It is difficult to pinpoint the reasons for the incredible monotony of so much vigorous activity, but surely one reason is that nothing happens in "Red Psalm" except for the benefit of the camera. That may sound like any movie, but actually it is like no movie (except another Jansco movie) and is virtually a negation of the whole, necessary relation of cinema to life.Nothing could be further, say, from the great fluid camera movements of a Max Ophuls than the elaborate cycles and epicycles of the Jansco world, where everybody  open fields notwithstandingis imprisoned within rigid limits of the director's rage for abstract patterns."Red Psalm" was the late Sunday evening offering of the New York Film Festival.

More than twenty years ago, growth of farm animals was found to be improved when small amounts of the common antibioticstetracyclines, penicillin, streptomycinwere added to their food. title: Focus on the Economy
description: The pocketbook issue in this Presidential campaign extends far beyond the persistence of unacceptably high levels of unemployment and inflation, great as is the hardship caused by both. Crucial also in assessing the health of the economy are the still lengthening welfare rolls and the stubborn survival of widespread poverty in a rich country, yawning deficits in the Federal budget, the level and fairness of taxes, the priorities of public expenditures whether for military or social purposes and the power and responsibilities of those who control great corporations and great wealth.

Moore called sensible and brilliant, informative and exciting.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: In Richard Nixon's Washington, Henry Kissinger stands out like Kili manjaro on an arid plain. He is a man of broad intellect in a narrow and antiintellectual world, a selfconfident man with a sense of humor among the defensive and the humorless.It has always been unlikely that the Communists would believe another unsupported promise to keep hands off Vietnam, least of all from a Presi dent whose rhetoric seems constantly to escalate the American interest in a nonCommunist Saigon. That Is why Hanoi has sought formal agreement with the U.S. on the political future of Vietnamas an assurance against renewed intervention.

It could, of course, drag out a prolonged existence as an ordinary twentieth century metropolis, replete with snarled traffic, high prices, noise and juvenile delin quency. But without its fabulous art and its revered antiquities, the grandeur that was Rome would at last be no more than the grandeur that is Indianapolis.

title: ' Summer Soldiers' Studies War-Weary G.I. in Japan
description: "The summer soldier," wrote Tom Paine in 1776, and the sunshine patriot will, in this crisis, shrink from the service of their country."The hero of "Summer Soldiers," Hiroshi Teshigahara's new Japanese film, is an American G.I. named Jim, a dark-haired, sad-eyed, exhausted, young Vietnam veteran who, while on leave in Japan, tries to desert from the Army and winds up, weeks later, back where he started in a state of controlled despair."Summer Soldiers" is an intelligent, level-headed movie that refusesbravely, I thinkto deal in the sort of hysteria that denies the intention of other antiwar films. Mr. Teshigahara, the director whose "Woman in the Dunes" was seen here eight years ago, and John Nathan, the American who wrote the screenplay, have made an antiwar film thousands of miles from any battlefront, in terms of culture shocks, the psychology of loneliness and people working at cross-purposes with the best of intentions. Which may be why "Summer Soldiers" is more witty than moving, and less tragic than Jim's eventual fate would lead you to believe.The soldier is first taken in by a good-hearted, not particularly bright B-girl. "You gonna give me a hard time?" she says to cheer him up. He smiles, and she says it again and again and again, which are a few times too many. She, in turn, puts Jim in touch with the Deserters' Aid Committee, a group of liberal-to-radical Japanese do-gooders who ask Jim why he's deserted, then argue passionately among themselves about whether or not Jim's lack of ideology is important."Summer Soldiers" describes no special dramatic parabola. It moves horizontally, as Jim does, in one-night stands, from family to family, most of whom treat the soldier as an exotic object. Jim, played by Keith Sykes, remains almost as mysterious to us, essentially decent and mostly inarticulate, Mr. Teshigahara, however, has a lovely time studying the attitudes of what a Japanese radical manual ("How to Resist Arrest") calls the "host families."The director has as much sympathy for these people when they are being silly or smug or insensitive as when they are being selfless and understanding. One of Jim's hosts attempts to teach him Japanese and is shocked when the American prefers to spend the night with the bar girl. The G.I. spends another night planted in front of the TV set watching a Japanese-dubbed Lucille Ball show. He can't understand a word, but the faces are as familiar as the intensity of the canned laughter.On still another night in another middle-class household, he plays a guitar and sings some songs he has written. Says the father: "You could go on television as 'The Singing Deserter,' wearing dark glasses. You could give the money to The Movement." "Yes," says Jim, though he realizes he has no real interest in any movements.From time to time, Mr. Teshigahara cuts from the narrative to an interview with a Spanish-American deserter, Miguel (Greg Antonacci), who, unlike Jim, knows exactly what he's doing, which is preparing for revolution. Miguel jogs, he studies, he disciplines himself. "Life is beautiful," he says in that glum way of someone trying to convince himself.These interludes are out of keeping with the rest of the film, which actually has less to do with specific issues than with loneliness of such desperate degree that it becomes a type of humiliation. Toward the end of the film, two Japanese school girls, members of The Movement, try to pick up the soldier in a bar in order to help him. He turns on them: "What if I were just an ordinary guy? Would you be interested then?" They wouldn't. It is not, perhaps, a fair question, but it makes one of the film's most sorrowful, even Buuelian points: to recognize charity is to accept insult."Summer Soldiers" was shown last night at the New York Film Festival.

title: U.S. Chess Team Bows to Yugoslavia
description: SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 1 (AP)  Firstplace Yugo slavia defeated the United States 31 in the fifth round of the men's Olympic chess finals today. The single United States point resulted from two draws.

The Houston Oilers finally allowed the other team to make all the mistakes and came up with a 26.20 upset victory over the New York Jets today before a standingroomonly crowd of 51,423, the second highest at tendance figure in the Astro dome for a National Football League game.

description: PARIS, Oct. 1 (Reuters)Ed Dibbs, a 21yearold Miamian, won his second match today in a weekend exhibition tennis series between the United States and France. His suc cess gave him a good chance to be selected for a singles assign ment when the United States meets Rumania in the final round for the Davis Cup in Bucharest, Oct. 13 to 15.

description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 1 Theoretically, at least, Bridge port should be George McGov ern's type of city.

title: Harvard Aide Electrocuted
description: BOSTON, Oct. 1 (AP)Frede rick K. Sullivan, 56 years old, of Belmont, an electrician for the Harvard Medical School, was electrocuted yesterday while working on power lines near the school. Investigators said there had been an explosion and Mr. Sullivan was appar ently electrocuted.

title: Film Festival: 'We Won't Grow Old'
description: Since its emotions are exposed nakedly and honestly, "We Won't Grow Old Together" (translated simplistically by the producers as "Break-Up" from the original, "Nous Ne Viellierons Pas Ensemble") cleaves to memory like a fond embrace of long ago or an unpaid debt. The writer-director, Maurice Pialat, in the French import that was screened Saturday night at the New York Film Festival, projects starkly beautiful truths but his devotion to details of an affair on its last legs finally becomes redundant and painfully obvious.Pialat, who was represented at the 1968 festival by his first feature, "Naked Childhood" (shown here commercially in 1970 as "Me"), is concerned with the final months of the disintegrating, six-year liaison between a fortyish, married movie cameraman and his 25-year-old mistress. If he has developed a story line that could be summarized in a simple sentence, Pialat nevertheless delves deeply and sensitively into nuances of his principals' feelings and actions to make them strikingly three-dimensional human beings.A compassionate viewer may not be entirely certain as to the compulsions that drive Pialat's often choleric hero, or his anguished mistress, or their parents and friends, or his estranged wife, who hasn't left his bed and board but who is devoted enough to try to help him out of his romantic mess. But the over-all effect of an essentially tragic triangle is made incisively real and tender.Marlene Jobert, chic and comely in bikini, blue jeans or miniskirts, is confused and terrified as the abused mistress. Although she finally opts for marriage to another man, she's completely convincing when she says, wistfully, "after all we've had, I can't believe it's over."As the equally ill-used wife, Macha Meril, who also sadly reminds her husband of his selfishness, elicits compassion in a somewhat vaguely written role. And wisps of character emanate from Christine Fabrega, Jacques Galland and Muse Dalbray, as Miss Jobert's sullenly, protective parents and grandmother.But Jean Yanne (remembered here for portrayals in Chabrol's "Le Boucher" and Godard's "Weekend"), as the burly, domineering antihero who discovers love too late, gives a naturalistic, forceful performance. Before winning the best actor's award for his portrayal in the recent Cannes Festival, Mr. Yanne castigated the film. "I think it's a lousy story," he said, in part, noting also, "If I'm any good in the part, believe me, it was completely involuntary."From this vantage point, Mr. Yanne protests too much. "We Won't Grow Old Together" does have some repetitious, soap opera-like faults but more often it poignantly touches the heart and mind.

title: Plotters Held, Haiti Says
description: PORTAUPRICE, Haiti Oct. 1 (UPI)Defense Minister Luck ner Cambronne announced yes terday the arrest of an undis closed number of persons for plotting to overthrow the Gov ernment of President Jean Claude Duvalier. He said the leader of the alleged plot was a former mmeber of the Haitian Congress, Leon Jean, who was among those arrested.

title: Moscow Attacks Mao
description: MOSCOW, Oct, 1 (AP)The Soviet Union congratulated the Chinese people today on the 23d anniversary of Communist China, but attacked Chairman Mao Tsetung for theoretical incompetence and antiSoviet policies.

title: Advertising:
description: You get the impression at Dancer Fitzgerald Sample that the agency feels it helped save the life of Life Savers. And doesn't it de serve at least a kind word for that? Maybe the beloved hard candy is not a historic landmark, but it's certainly been part of the American scene long enough to deserve preservation.

About 100 students gathered in front of the city hall waving placards that said Down With the Tanaka Cabinet. They called for a boycott of Japanese goods and burned empty cartons that had con tained Japanese products.

Leakey, the archeologist and anthropolo gist who pushed back the date of man's presence on earth by more than a million years and placed man's origins in Africa rather than Asia, died today in St. Stephen's Hospital follow ing a heart attack. description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 Yields on United States Treasury bills fell In the Government's weekly com petitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Socialist Workers Official Backs Black Political Unit
description: Andrew Pulley, Vice  Presi dential candidate of the Sodial ist Workers party, said here yesterday that the nation's blacks must form an indepen dent party to achieve libera tion because their goal can not be reached through the capitalist  controlled major parties.

title: Raid on Election Reform
description: President Lyndon B. Johnson once said that Federal statutes regulating the collection and expenditure of political money were more loophole than law. The new Federal Election Campaign Act which went into effect only five months ago was a major corrective effort.

title: Bluegrass
description: The extent to which blue grass music has spread from its Southern origins was un derlined by the program that the Blue Grass Club of New York presented Sunday eve ning in the auditorium of New York University Law School, 40 Washington Square, South.

title: Federal Court Enjoins Meany On Colorado Unit's TakeOver
description: DENVER, Oct. 2The United States District Court in Denver issued a preliminary injunction today to prevent George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., from taking over the national labor organization's state feder ation in Colorado.

title: Rinfret, Nixon Adviser, Attacks the Move 5% Kept on Coast
description: Most of the nation's largest banks increased their minimum charges on loans to the most creditworthy corporations yes terday to 5 per cent from 5 per cent.

title: Stoneman of Expos Pitches NoHitter as Mets Lose 70
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 2  Bill Stoneman of the Montreal Expos pitched the second nohit game of his career tonight, and the first nohitter in major league history outside, the con tinental limits of the United States when he paralyzed the Mets, 70.

title: Court Opens Term; Marshall Uses Cane
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) The Supreme Court opened its 197273 tern today witfi a fourminute ceremonial session attended by the nine Justices.

title: Turkish Farmers See Poverty in Ban on the Poppy
description: ATLIHISAR, Turkey, Oct. 1 The lovely poppy with the white or purple blossoms is their staff of life, as the vil lagers of this impoverished region of the central Anato lian highlands tell it, and every bit of it is put to good use.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: GREENSBURG, Pa., Oct. 2 (AP)State police said that they issued warrants today for the arrest of two jockeys on charges of attempting to fix a horse race at The Mead ows track, southwest of Pittsburgh, two weeks ago.

title: Polo at Westchester C.C.
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Oct. 2 Polo will return to the West chester Country Club for the first time in 35 years on Satur day when Meadowbrook of Long Island meets Aiken of South Carolina.

title: Wagner Sees Politics By Nixon on Pensions
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner charged yesterday that President Nixon was playing a political game with Social Security recipi ents, who he said are to re ceive a special message from the President fradu lently claiming credit for the new Social Security benefit increase.

title: Curbs on Banking Denied
description: MANILA, Oct. 2 (UPI) Secretary Tatad said today that Philippine National Bank offi cials had assured all depositors that there was no plan to limit bank withdrawals, con trary to rumors spread by economic saboteurs.

title: State Tax Receipts Reported Higher in First 6 Months
description: ALBANY, Oct. 2State tax collections in the first six months of the current fiscal year were $782.4million ahead of the same period last year, the State Tax Commissioner, Norman Gallman, reported to day

title: TONE OF MARKET TURNS TENTATIVE
description: Two of the stock market's 1972 spectacularsLevitz Fur niture and Curtiss Wright  were hit by selling yesterday as Wall Street began its final quarter of the year.

title: Woman Picket Halts Work
description: SMITHERS, W. Va., Oct. 2 (AP)Naomi Fields, 48 years old, upset over being discharged because her job was taken over by a machine, set up her own picket line today and halted op erations of the Marathon Coal Bit Company here.

title: Ed Adamson, TV Writer, 57; Creator Of Banyon Series
description: HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 2  Ed Adamson, a television writer producer for Warner Bros and creator of the current Banyon series, died Sunday of a heart attack at Cedars of Lebanon Hospital. He was 57 years old and had lived here since 1955.

title: Upsurge of Shelling
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Oct. 3 (AP)A sud den upsurge in North Viet namese and Vietcong rocket and mortar attacks and sabotage was reported yesterday by the Saigon command.

title: EAST BERLIN TRIPS FROM WEST EASED
description: BERLIN, Oct. 2  East Ger many agreed today to ease pro cedures for West Berliners to cross the, East German wall dividing this city.

title: MISS NETTUM HEARD IN SOPRANO RECITAL
description: For her New York debut recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night, Mary Nettum chose a sophisticated program of songs that too often were beyond her technical scope.

title: SENATE IS BACKED ON COASTZONE BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) A Presidential advisory com mittee, disagreeing with the Nixon Administration, has urged that coastalzone management be entrusted to the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Agency, instead of the Interior Department, where offshore oil interests want it.

title: Meskill Vetoes Bus Company Subsidies
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 2  Gov, Thomas J. Meskill vetoed a part of a bill today that would have provided subsidies to Connecticut's debt  ridden bus companies.

title: F111 Lost on Raid Over North Vietnam; Jets Reported Withdrawn From Combat
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Oct. 3The United States command here an nounced today that one of the swingwing F111 fighters that returned to the Indochina con flict last week has been lost over North Vietnam.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Oct. 2 The Rutgers University senate approved a controversial policy today giving campus patrolmen a limited right to carry guns.

title: The Strange Structure Called Environ A
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn.For years, Laurel Road, a pleas ant treeshaded street a cou ple of miles from The Green and Yale's campus, was lined with unbroken rows of at tractive, conservative looking homes. But no more.

title: HENRY P. CLARK
description: RADFORD, Va., Oct. 2  Henry P. Clark, vice president in charge of the international branch of the McCannErickson advertising agency until his re tirement, in 1959, died here yesterday while on a camping trip. He was 73 years old and lived at 60 Cottage Place. Allen dale, N.J.

title: COMMANDOS REJECT EXILE REGIME OFFER
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 2 The Palestinian commando leadership issued an indirect rejection today of the proposal by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt offering recognition of a Palestinian government in exile.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City Plans Flowers for Main Streets

title: 2 UNIONS VOTE TO END STRIKE IN CLEVELAND
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 2 (UPI) Two unions accepted the city's wage offer tonight and said that in all likelihood the strike of city workers was over.

title: Yugoslav Call for Curbs on Rich Raises Fear of a Run on Banks
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 2  Demands have been raised in Yugoslavia this month for curbs on socalled socialist multimillionaires and billion aires and are now reported to have created risks of a run on savings accounts ??y worried depositors.

title: Southern Yemen Truce Is Rejected
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 2 (AP)Yemen announced to day rejection of a proposal from Southern Yemen for ceasefire in the fighting that has continued since last Tuesday along the border be tween the two Red Sea coun tries.

title: Manila Decrees Death Penalty For Slayings With Illegal Guns
description: MANILA, Oct. 2 (Reuters) The Phillippine Government to day decreed the death penalty for persons who kill with fire arms that they are not author ized to possess under martial law.

title: Driver Killed First Day on Jab
description: A 22yearold. United Parcel Service driver was killed on his first day at work yesterday when another truck struck the one he was driving, throwing him out and pinning him under his own truck. The dead driver, Elias Maldonado, who was re cently discharged from the Air Force after duty in Vietnam, lived at 405 Claremont Park way in the Bronx with his wife and two children. The accident occurred on 168th Street near 10th Avenue.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: For years, this writer has regarded the eastern chain pickerel as little more than passing entertainment, some thing to be caught and re leased when other more sporty and edible fish were unavailable.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELI'S ASSAILANT IS TERMED EXSPY
description: The Arab gunman who shot and wounded an Israeli Em bassy official in a cafe in Brus sels last month was not, as supposed, an Arab terrorist but was instead a disgruntled for mer spy for Israel, Newsweek magazine says in its current issue.

title: IN THE NATION
description: If Senator George McGovern is go ing to put forward a specific Vietnam peace plan, as Mrs. McGovern has promised, he will have the opportunity to draw a sharp distinction between himself and President Nixon on this issue.. And perhaps that is what Mr. McGovern needs to give himself some thing like Presidential stature and thereby to turn his campaign around.

title: Market Place:
description: Take another peek at those stock tables. Maybe you did not notice that beginning to day, they carry priceearn ings ratios for stocks on the New York and American Stock Exchange.

title: U.S. Judge Tells Squires And Erving: Get a Referee
description: Julius Erving is a Virginia Squire againmaybe.

title: 76ers Trade Wohl
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 2 (UPI)  The Portland Trail Blazers traded Dale Schlueter, one of the team's four centers, to the Philadelphia 76ers today for Dave Wohl, a guard. The 6 foot2inch Wohl was the 76ers' thirdround draft choice in 1971.

title: U.S. Court Bans State Aid To PrivateSchool Parents
description: A threejudge Federal Court yesterday, struck down as unconstitutional a newly enacted New York statute that would have provided state tuition grants to parents of privateschool students.

title: Boston Democrat Leads Poll
description: BOSTON, Oct. 2 (AP)Rep resentative Robert F. Drinan, Democrat of Massachusetts, holds a 43to33 per cent lead over his Republican opponent, Martin A. Linsky, in the Fourth Congressional District race, ac cording to a poll published yes terday by The Boston Globe.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 2The United States Department of Labor has begun an investigation of the city's $6.5million Public Employment Project to follow up evidence of abuses in the administration of the program uncovered in routine audits.

title: 5 H.E.W. Awards to Help Disadvantaged Veterans
description: The Department of Health, Education and Welfare yester day announced awards to four city and state colleges and the city Y.M.C.A. totaling $375,000 for programs to recruit and train disadvantaged veterans for college admission or voca tional programs.

title: KARL M. LE COMPTE OF IOWA DIES AT 85
description: CENTERVILLE, Iowa, Oct. 2 (UPI)Former Representative Karl M. Le Compte of Iowa, who served in the House from 1939 until his retirement in 1959, died here Saturday, ap parently of a heart attack. He was 85 years old and was attending the annual pancake day festival.

title: VOLKSWAGEN TOLD TO REDUCE PRICES
description: The Price Commission yester day ordered Volkswagen of America, Inc., and its South Central Distributor, Inc., sub sidiary in San Antonio to re duce prices and make refunds on certain vehicles sold in the first quarter of 1972.

title: A CITY LAW CLERK SEIZED AS PUSHER
description: A law clerk for the city's Corporation Counsel was linked yesterday by District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn to a narcotics ring that specialized in selling drugs to students at Sheepshead Bay High School.

title: Tigers in First Place
description: The Detroit Tigers defeated the Boston Red Sox, 41, last night in Detroit and took first place in the Eastern Division of the American League. In Montreal, Bill Stoneman of the Expos pitch ed a nohit game in beating the Mets, 70. Details, Page 55.

title: Death Penalty Voted By House, 3542, For Air Hijackers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) Stiff legislation to permit death penalties against plane hijackings and terrorists and to suspended United States air service to countries that harbor them passed the House today, 354 to 2.

title: U.S. AGREES TO ADMIT 1,000 UGANDA ASIANS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The State Department announced today that the United States would admit up to 1,000 state less Asians who have been ordered to leave Uganda by Nov. 8.

title: SUSPECT IS SEIZED IN RALEIGH KILLINGS
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Oct. 2 (UPI) Wake County authorities ar rested a 24yearold suspect today in the weekend slayings of a Raleigh newswoman and a real estate salesman.

title: SENATE VOTES TODAY ON JOB SAFETY PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  Senate leaders set the stage today for a showdown vote tomorrow on a Houseapproved provision exempting employers of 15 or fewer workers from the requirements of the Occu pational Safety and Health Act.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TURIN, Italy, Oct. 2 (UPI) Officials of the Torino Soccer club said today someone slipped reflexslowing drugs into the food or drinks of several Torino players before an international game the team lost.

title: WOMEN PROS SET NEW TENNIS TOUR
description: In a move aimed at complete independence, a group of top women tennis professionals im nounced plans yesterday to form their own international federation.

title: Tigers Win, 41
description: DETROIT, Oct. 2Luis Apa ricio and Carl Yastzemski ran into trouble in the third inning and the Red Sox ran into Mickey Lolich, Aurelio Rodri guez and Al Kaline for the rest of the game as Detroit defeated Boston, 41, tonight and, moved to within one victory of win ning the Eastern Division championship of the American League.

title: Internes and Residents Demand Pay Raises at 5 Hospitals Here
description: Municipal hospital internes and residents have demanded salary increases ranging from $2,200 a year for internes to $5,900 for sixthyear residents.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The Knights of Columbus Track Meet will be resumed on Saturday night, Jan. 13, at the Nassau Coliseum, it was announced today.

title: Hart of Islanders' Defense Is Out for at Least a Month
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Oct. 2 The New York Islanders learned today that their only defense man with any significant big league experience, Gerry Hart, had a broken bone in his left leg and would miss at least a month of National Hockey League play.

title: Calhoun Named Coach
description: BOSTON, Oct. 2 (AP)James A. Calhoun, a former little all American at American Interna tional College, today was named as the basketball coach at Northeastern University, the school's athletic director, Her bert Gallagher, announced.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Sept. 26:

title: Advertising:
description: According to Stanley L. Goodman, president of EGR Communications, a seven year  old sales promotion company, dozens and doz ens of new companies are entering the field.

title: Durocher Dismisses 2, Hires 2 ExManagers
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 2 (AP) Leo Durocher, manager of Houston Astros, dismissed two of his coaches today and named two former major league managers to replace them for the 1973 season.

title: A.E.C. Staff Urges FiveYear Test Use For Indian Point 2
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Atomic Energy Commission's staff has recommended that the Indian Point No. 2 nuclear power plant on the Hudson River be allowed to operate for five years, although the staff said the present cooling system might kill up to five million, or more, young fish a year.

title: Nonstop Flights to Liberia
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) Pan American World Airways said today that it would inau gurate some nonstop service between New York and Mon rovia, Liberia, Oct. 29. Pan American said that five weekly flights would be offeredthose on Saturdays and Sundays, nonstop. The three others will go by way of Dakar, Senegal.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The new Federal law controlling po litical fund raising and expen ditures suffered a potential set back in Congress today and came under renewed attack in the courts.

title: Chess: Training for Future Stars Student Tournament Offers
description: The biennial Students Team Tournament is an excellent testing ground. Future stars receive valuable experience and those with real ability have an excellent opportu nity to win international rec ognition. Many great players including Boris Spassky, the recently dethroned chain pionhave come out of this event.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 30 On the northern edge of Co lumbus, where the village of Minerva Park is being nudged by urban growth, the national effort to open the prospering suburbs to blacks and other minorities appears to have sur vived a major battle.

title: 145 From France Are Teaching Louisiana's Children a Tongue That Was Nearly Stilled
description: PAULINA, La., Sept. 22 JeanPaul Chapelon picked up a picture of a mouse and held it high so the children could see. He lifted his eye brows into Gallic question marks and demanded of the class: Qu'estce que c'est?

title: Inquiry Delay Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) The Justice Department told the House Banking Committee today that a committee investi gation of the Watergate bug ging incident at this time would jeopardize criminal prosecution of those indicted in the case.

title: REV. ROBERT APPLETON
description: The Rev. Robert Floyd Apple ton, a former Episcopal mis sionary in China and Japan, and; more recently administra tor of psychological services at Fairleigh Dickinson Univer sity, died here Saturday. He was 51 years old and lived at 38 Brookside Avenue, Allen dale, N. J.

title: Yankees Lose to Brewers, 61, Sink to 4th Place By a  Game
description: The Yankees spent a cool October evening last night, los ing to the Milwaukee Brewers, 61, and dropping into fourth place in the American League's Eastern Division. Ken Brett pitched all the way for the Brewers for his seventh victory. Steve Kline, who was the Yankee pitching leader through August, lost for the ninth time in 25 decisions.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 2 (AP)An attorney for Dr. Robert M. Liv ingston of Englewobd Cliffs asked a Federal District Court judge today to convene a three judge court to hear his suit for an injunction against state en forcement of abortion laws.

title: U.S. Studying Saudi Plan For Oil Investments Here
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  Saudi Arabia has proposed that the United States give her an exemption from the oilimport quota in exchange for large Saudi investments in oil re fining and marketing in this country.

title: Bridge: Borderline Game Contract Hinges on the Opening Lead,
description: The team that will repre sent the United States in the 1973 world team champion ship will be determined by a playoff match in Lancaster, Pa., at the end of this month. Whatever the result, the in ternational team will have a veteran quality.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A baby pygmy sperm whale that washed ashore at Far Rockaway a week ago was reported very much better. A spokesman at the New York Aquarium, where attendants have been feeding the whale since its mother died last Tuesday, said the 40pound calf was eating more, giving it each day a better chance for survival.

title: Cahill Supported on Plan To Reduce Tocks Project
description: TRENTON, Oct. 2Governor Cahill received important Con gressional support today for his demand that the proposed Tocks Island Dam and Recrea tion Area be drastically modi fied and reduced in scope.

title: FINAL COUNT IS DUE OF PUERTO RICANS
description: The Census Bureau, answer ing charges that it had under counted New York City's Puerto Rican population in 1970, emphasized yesterday that, final figures from that census were still to be an nounced.

title: DANES VOTE YES ON MARKET ENTRY BY A WIDE MARGIN
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 2The people of Denmark gave a resounding yes today to membership in the Common Market.

title: Eban Cites Achievements Of Israel in Her 25 Years
description: Abba Eban, Israel's Foreign Minister, last night told Brooklyn congregation of his nation's economic, educational and scientific achievements as it enters the 25th year of its existence as a state.

title: Books of The Times
description: MY PRISON. By the Duchess of Medina Sidonia. 169 pages. Harper and Row. $6.95.

title: TAX VOW IS TIED TO DEBT CEILING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  Key officials linked today the Nixon Administration's, pledge not to increase taxes with Con gressional enactment of the $250billion ceiling on Federal spending this year.

title: TV Review
description: The Public Broadcasting Service's new television sea son begins this week and, for most part, the name of the game is culture, which seems to make politicianskeepers of the inadequate budget less nervous than investiga tive documentaries and pub licaffairs programming.

title: Metropolitan Museum Sells 2 More Masters
description: The Metropolitan Museum has disposed of paintings by two 20thcentury masters, Amedeo Modigliani and Juan Gris, and has plans for dis posing of objects from all of the museum's 17 depart ments, it was learned yester day. The news followed last Saturday's disclosure that the Metropolitan had quietly sold major paintings by Douanjer Rousseau and Vin cent van Gogh five months ago.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (Reuters)The Defense De partment defended today the use of taxpayers' dollars to transport Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird and other Pentagon officials on military planes to speaking engage ments where they have as sailed the Democratic Presi dential candidate, Senator George McGovern.

title: The U.N. in Namibia
description: The appointment of a United Nations representative for Namibia (SouthWest Africa) with the consent of the South African Government is an interesting experiment well worth trying. In selecting a veteran diplomat from Switzerland, a country that is not a member of the U.N., Secretary General Waldheim was clearly going out of his way to avoid giving offense to Pretoria.

title: Texas Rangers to Take Time Finding Manager
description: ARLINGTON, Tex. Oct. 2 (AP)  The Texas Ranger gen eral manager, Joe Burke, said today the club would wait about 10 days before talking seriously to any possible suc cessor to Ted Williams.

title: EDWIN A. HOLDEN, 54, A FORMER REPORTER
description: Edwin Arthur Holden, a for mer reporter for The Daily News and The Herald Tribune, died at Lenox Hill Hospital, on Sunday after a long illness. He was 54 years old and lived at 57 East 78th Street and Quogue, L. I.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: United Hospital Fund Campaign For $3Million Gets Under Way
description: The United Hospital Fund opened its 94th fundraising campaign last night with a speech by Dr. John H. Knowles, who said that improved health care lay in better health edu cation, in the redistribution of manpower and in greater con cern generally for the quality of life.

title: Sheepshead Bay Arrests Don't Shock Students
description: Students at Sheepshead Bay High School were hardly shocked yesterday at the ar rests that the Brooklyn District Attorney, Eugene Gold, said broke up a narcotics ring spe cializing in peddling drugs to students.

title: Professor to Be Honored
description: Dr. Stephen W. Kuffler, the Robert Winthrop Professor at Harvard Medical School, has been named to receive Colum bia University's Louisa Gross Horwitz Prize for outstanding research in biology, it was an nounced yesterday. The $25, 000 award will be presented at a dinner on Wednesday at the university's Low Memorial Library.

title: NIXON UNIT BEGINS BIG DRIVE BY MAIL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  A massive national campaign to influence the Presidential elec tion by political letters mailed to individual voters is being quietly started this week by the Committee for the Re election of the President.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: For years, this writer has regarded the eastern chain pickerel as little more than passing entertainment, some thing to be caught and re leased when other more sporty and edible fish were unavailable.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  President Nixon's two most vis ible spokesmenVice President Agnew and Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secre tarydefended Mr. Nixon to day against complaints that he, has been hiding himself and his views from the electorate.

title: BALTIC PIECES GIVEN BY PHOENIX QUINTET
description: Tne Phoenix woodwind Quin tet offered a diverting program at CAMI Hall late Sunday after noon that avoided all the obvi ous repertory choices. The mu sic was almost all lightweight but charming, and the perform ances were infectiously musical if, not always the ultimate in ensemble polish.

title: Social Security Rise Becomes A Nightmare for Many Elderly
description: Like millions of other aged Americans; Marie Nashif of Denver will receive a 20 per cent increase in her Social Se curity check this month. But unlike most, she will not wel come the extra cash.

title: Virginia Paper for Nixon
description: NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 2 (AP) The Norfolk LedgerStar to day endorsed President Nixon for reelection.

title: Mitchum to Buy Own Shares
description: Mitchum, Jones & Templeton Inc., a publicly owned member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that it intends to purchase shares of its own common stock from time to time prior to next June 30. The concern Indi cated that the shares might be used for acquisitions and for stockoption commitments. The concern is a large regional house with headquarters in Los Angeles. Its shares are listed on the Pacific Coast Stock Ex change.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 2 (UPI)The State Health Department an nounced today that Terry Prod ucts, Inc., of Elizabeth had de stroyed 8,000 pounds of em bargoed chocolate and 2,000 pounds of embargoed fruit slices and gum fruit candy. The materials had been embargoed by the department when an in spection showed that they had not been kept in a sanitary manner, a spokesman said.

title: 3 Killed in Train Crash
description: BELCHERTOWN, Mass., Oct. 2 (AP)At least three men were killed in the headon colli sion of two freight trains today, the police said. The collision occurred between Palmer and Amherst and involved trains of the Central Vermont and Boston and Albany Railroads.

title: Film Fete: Scarred Land
description: The sights and sounds of Marcel Ophuls's new docu mentary about Northern Ire land, A Sense of Loss, do not easily wash away. They stick like salty sand:

title: IndiaU.S. Amity Praised At Commemoration Here
description: Closer diplomatic, commercial and financial ties between the United States and India were forecast last night by the Indian Ambassador, Lakshmi K. Jha, at a dinner in the St. RegisShera ton Hotel commemorating both the 25th anniversari of Indian, independence and the birthday of Mahatma Gandhi.

title: CAPITAL TEACHERS END 2WEEKSTRIKE
description: Accepting a compromise pay increase with a promise of no reprisals, the Washington teach ers union yesterday ended a strike that had kept 141,000 District of Columbia pupils out of school for two weeks.

title: MARINER 10 FLIGHT TO HAVE 3 GOALS
description: PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 2 (UPI)  The first twoplanet space shot will set two other first?: An unmanned probe of Mercury, closest planet to the sun, and a photographic, look at Venus.

title: Social Security Rise Becomes A Nightmare for Many Elderly
description: Like millions of other aged Americans, Marie Nashif of Denver will receive a 20 per ccnt increase in her. Social Se curity check this month. But unlike most, she will not wel come the extra cash.

title: CloseUp of North Vietnam at War: Everything Moves by Night
description: If you have wondered why the North Vietnamese can con tinue to fight on despite the biggest bombing campagin in the history of war, then ride with three American pilots and me down the roads south of Hanoi and find out.

title: McGovern Impugns Nixon, Defends His Own Veracity
description: Senator George McGovern grappled openly yesterday with questions of his own credibility. It was the first time he had dealt with an issue that, according to a variety of national polls, now makes' President Nixon seem more sincere and trustworthy any comparison with Mr. Mc Govern, even among young voters and Demociets.

title: 6 Tours to View Foliage
description: To see New York State foliage at its best in mid October; here are soine sug gested automobile tours Most of which can he completed from the city in one day:

title: S.E.C. TO TIGHTEN ACCOUNTING REIN
description: DENVER, Oct. 2The Secu rities and Exchange Commission plans to supervise the account ing profession more vigorously, William J. Casey, chairman of the commission, said today at the 85th annual convention of the American Institute of Cer tified Public Accountants being held here this week.

title: ROBERT K. PLUMB, 50, WRITER, DIES IN FALL
description: Robert K. Plumb, a former science reporter and an infor mation specialist in the medi cal field, died last night in fall from the seventh floor of the George Washington Hotel, Lexington Avenue and 23d Street. He was 50 years old and lived at 161 Henry Street, Brooklyn.

title: Pennsylvania Said to Weigh A Special Prosecutor Plan
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 (AP) Pennsylvania may start a special state office to oversee investigations of alleged police corruption patterned after the Special Prosecutor's Office created in New York City.

title: Moment of Truth
description: No legislative body could be more compassionate than the Senate when dealing with the financial needs of the 3.2 million aged, blind and permanently disabled people on the nation's welfare rolls.

title: Personalities: Blass Is Ready
description: Steve Blass of the Pitts burgh Pirates, who was hit on the elbow of his right arm by a line drive on Sunday against the New York Mets, tested his pitching arm yes terday and said it was in good shape. After Xrays proved negative, the injury was diagnosed as a bruise. Blass said, after trying a few warmup pitches, that he was ready to pitch for the Pirates against the Cincinnati Reds in the opening game, of the National League playoffs series on Saturday at Pitts burgh, if Manager Bill Virdon gave him the call.

title: 9 Die in 2 Vermont Fires
description: SOUTH BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 2 (UPI)Nine persons, seven children and two moth ers, died today in separate fires that occurred just an hour apart. The State Fire Marshal's office is investigating the blaze that killed Mrs. Jenny Leduc, 40 years old, and her four chil dren in South Burlington. Meanwhile in Randolph Village, a preliminary investigation said the death of Mrs. Karen Rhoades, 29, and her three chil dren was caused by an oil stove explosion.

title: ALL JETS& FEARS WERE REALIZED
description: At the beginning of the sea son, almost everyone agreed that the success of the New York Jets this year would be contingent on their ability to survive without key injuries, but almost everything the Jets feared might happen, did on Sunday in their 2620 defeat at the hands of the Houston Oilers.

title: Kissinger's Deputy Confers With Thieu
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 2Maj. Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., who is Henry A. Kissinger's deputy, met with President Nguyen Van Thieu today for two and a half hours, according to United States Embassy sources, who did not disclose the substance of the meeting.

title: Zeckendorf Jr. Is Buyer
description: A syndicate headed by Wil liam Zeckendorf Jr., the son of the realestate promoter, has bought the Kips Bay Plaza housing project on the East Side from the Aluminum Company of America.

title: South Korea Force In Vietnam Is Said To Top U.S. Level
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 2 (AP)South Korea now has more troops in South Viet nam than the United States does, according to figures made public today by the United States command.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP)The Federal Reserve Board gave preliminary approval today for 23 bank holding com panies to keep control of any nonbanking business activi ties they acquired before June 30, 1968. Although it was the first time the board had Made a ruling in behalf individual banks under a grandfather clause in the 1970 Bank Holding Company Act, a spokesman said the decision should not be regarded as a precedent.

title: OWNERSHIP WIDENED AT BROWN BROS. UNIT
description: Brown Harriman Interna tional, Ltd., the Londonbased merchant banking affiliate of Brown Brothers Harriman & Co., announced yesterday that it had substantially broadened its base of ownership by bring ing in a number of new stock holders. These include the Pittsburgh National Bank, the First National Bank of Min neapolis and the Prudential As surance Company, Ltd., of London, as well as a group of six powerful European banks. The expanded group, typical of many similar international banking consortiums, is ex pected to become substantially more active in European money markets.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 2Low tui tion and a high commitment to community health problems have attracted a record number of applicants to the New Jersey Medical School, where this year's freshman class of 110 students include 12 black wom en.

title: 40 on a Chartered Yacht Held on Narcotics Charges
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2 (AP)Some 40 persons on a chartered motor yacht were booked on narcotics charges after attempting to dump the drugs over the side before ar resting officers came aboard, the authorities say.

title: $76BILLION FUND FOR ARMS VOTED BY SENATE, 705
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Senate passed a $76billion de fense appropriations bill today after decisively rejecting a pro posal to cut off funds for fur ther bombing in Indochina.

title: Course on Graft Hazards Being Offered by P.B.A.
description: In what appears to be a major policy change, the Pa trolmen's Benevolent Associa tion yesterday began conduct ing a training course in which its members were told about the benefits they stand to lose if they are convicted of taking bribes.

title: Reduced Beef Prices Are Held Remote
description: Reduced beef prices seem remote for some time, speak ers suggested yesterday at the 67th annual meeting of the American Meat Institute in the Americana Hotel.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rail Gain Is Sharp
description: The Chesapeake & Ohio Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Sys tem reported yesterday a net income of $13million, or $1.49 a share, for the third quarter of this year, up from $2million, or 21 cents a share, in the 1971 period.

title: Preliminary Approval Won
description: The City Planning Commis sion gave preliminary approval, yesterday to a plan to erect a stateaided, 1,700unit apart ment development in two 40 story towers on West 42d Street.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 2 In the crowded Bloomfield Avenue storefront of the New Jersey ItalianAmerican Association in this city's predominantly Ital ian North Ward Friday night, Representative Peter W. Ro dino Jr. stood modestly, head bowed, surrounded by scores of his supporters, and listened to George Haney, chairman of Citizens for Rodino.

title: Secret Indictment Cites Apparel Concern Officer
description: A secret indictment involving Garson P. Reiner, president of the Summit Organization, Inc., came to light yesterday with the disclosure that Mr. Reiner had been freed on $250,000 bail following a brief arraign ment Saturday.

title: DouglasHome to Visit China
description: LONDON, Oct. 2 (UPI)The Foreign Office said today that the Foreign Secretary, Sir Alec DouglasHome, would visit China Oct. 20 to Nov. 2.

title: Professor Held in Murder
description: An associate professor of eco nomics at Staten Island Commu nity College was held without bail for a hearing Thursday when he was arraigned yester day in Criminal Court on charge of murdering his wife. The defendant, Rao Bobba, 37 years old, called the police Sun day morning to tell them his wife, Dharathi, 27, was lying dead in their apartment at 382 Central Park West. The police said she had been bludgeoned to death with a crutch.

title: CommuterSchool M.B.A. Given
description: Under the exposed steel ceil ing braces of Pennsylvania Sta tion's lower level and amid the announcements of coming and going trains, Adelphi Univer sity yesterday conferred its first Master of Business Ad ministration degree to a stu dent who took his courses on a commuter train.

title: 5 on Bay Area Train Hurt As Automated Brakes Fail
description: FREMONT, Calif., Oct. 2 Computerized braking controls failed on one of the new Bay Area Rapid Transit trains to day and a car went off the end of the track here, injuring five persons.

title: Nixon Accused of Backing Israel to Woo Jewish Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI)  Three Democratic Senators accused President Nixon today of reversing course and be coming a stanch defender of Israel to woo the Jewish vote.

title: F.B.I. Chief Denies Nixon Uses Deceit In BreakIn Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2It would be hard to believe that President Nixon Was attempt ing to deceive the nation re garding the Watergate scandal, L. Patrick Gray 3d, acting direc tor of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today.

title: House Defeats Bill to Bar Unauthorized Hanoi Visits
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) A bill to bar unauthorized visits by Americans to North Vietnam was rejected by the House of Representatives today amid charges that it would have permitted the President to block trips by journalists and families of prisonersofwar.

title: Financial Follies Set
description: The Financial Follies of 1972, an annual spoof of business, labor and government present ed by the New York Financial Writers' Association, will be held on Friday, Nov. 17, at the Americana Hotel. Tickets are available from the association at Box 4306, New York, N. Y. 10017.

title: 25 at Card Game Held Up
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Oct. 2 (UPI)Three gunmen held up a card game in a private home last night and escaped with $2,500. The police said the men, wielding sawedoff shot guns, made the 25 persons in the house lie on the floor and rifled their wallets and pocket books. Early today, James Hodge, 30 years old, turned himself in, to the police and was charged with firstdegree robbery and reckless endanger ment.

title: 4 Held in Alleged Attempts To Bring Cocaine Into U.S.
description: Four persons were arrested over the weekend at Kennedy International Airport while al legedly attempting to smuggle about $750,000 worth of co caine into the country from South America, the Bureau of Customs announced yesterday.

title: Harvard Doctor Gets Award
description: Dr. Stephen W. Kuffler, Rob ert Winthrop Professor at the Harvard Medical School, will re ceive the $25,000 Louisa Gross Horwitz Prize for 1972, Colum bia University announced yes terday. The award, given an nually since 1967, cites Dr. Kuffler's outstanding experi ments as having provided information of fundamental im portance to the understanding of the nature of neuromuscular and synaptic transmission, the mechanisms responsible for in hibition in the nervous system, the functional organization of the retina and the visual sys tem, and the role of neuroglia in the central nervous system.

title: People and Business
description: The retirement of William M. Allen as chairman of the Boeing Company at the age of 73 has just been an nounced, thus ending an era at the giant corporation. Now two younger men are step ping upT. A. Wilson, 51, from president to chairman, and Malcolm T. Stamper, 47, from senior vice president operations to president. Mr. Wilson will continue as chief executive officer.

title: Egypt Ends Arbitrary Seizures of Citizens' Property
description: CAIRO, Oct. 2The Govern ment of President Anwar el Sadat today announced aboli tion of the longstanding prac tice under which powerful Gov ernment officials could order the seizure of a citizen's prop erty by a simple administrative measure.

title: Stage: Musical Soldiers
description: From Israel With Love, starring members of the Israeli Army Entertainment Groups (in other words, soldiers), produced by Col. Saul Biber, began a 10 performance engagement last night at the Palace. Because of the auspices, one antici pated that the show would be at least nationalistic if not militaristic.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 3Judge Panels to Weigh State Sentences in Bronx
description: Presiding Justice Harold A. Stevens of the Appellate Divi sion yesterday ordered the immediate creation of three judge sentencing panels in State Supreme Court in the Bronx to review every case before sentence is imposed.

title: $100.5Million Contracts Awarded Lockheed Unit
description: The Lockheed Missiles & Space Company, a subsidiary of the Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration, announced yesterday it had been awarded $100.5 million in military contracts from the Department of De fense.

title: McGovern Impugns Nixon, Defends His Own Veracity
description: Senator George McGovern grappled openly yesterday with questions of his own credibility. It was the first time he had dealt with an issue that, according to a variety of national polls, now makes President Nixon seem more sincere and trustworthy in any comparison with Mr. Mc Govern, even among young voters and Democrats.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nixon Signs Disease Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) President Nixon signed today a $322million bill extending for three years Federal programs to combat communicable diseases, including $2.5million annually for new programs to check ve nereal disease. The act in creases from $90million to $111.5million the authorization for birth control services.

title: $3 Sweepstakes Ends
description: CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 2 (UPI) The New Hampshire Sweep stakes Commission voted today to end its $3 sweepstakes pro gram, the first staterun betting system in the nation. The 50 cent lottery program will con tinue.

title: SHRIVER PROPOSES PORTABLE PENSION
description: ROCK ISLAND, Ill., Oct. 2 (AP)  Sargent Shriver pro posed today a portable pen sion plan for the nation's work ers.

title: Confident Rodino Campaigns in Newark
description: NEWARK, Oct. 2  In the crowded Bloomfield Avenue storefront of the New Jersey ItalianAmerican Association in this city's predominantly Italian North Ward Friday night, Rep resentative Peter W. Rodino Jr. stood modestly, head bowed, surrounded by scores of his supporters, and listened to George Haney, chairman of Citizens for Rodino.

title: Chance Remark Is Linked To Clearing of Black G.I.'s
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Sept. 29  John D. Weaver is an au thor known to his friends as a fanatical stickler for accurate details. Because of this, 167 black soldiers today stand exonerated of a crime that had tarnished their names for 66 years.

title: Balanchine, City Ballet Acclaimed in Leningrad
description: LENINGRAD, Sept. 30It is a certain sign of theatrical success in the Soviet Union when the only way to get tickets is for theatergoers to submit to the demands of offi cial ticketsellers that they buy unwanted tickets to unpopular shows as the price of landing tickets to the hit they want to see.

title: U.S. Team joining Fight to Stem Rare Fatal Fever in Africa
description: The United States Public Health Service, responding to a request from the Government of Sierra Leone, Is sending a team of six experts to fight a new outbreak of Lassa fever, a mysterious, lethal viral disease.

title: GIANTS VANQUISH EAGLES, 27 TO 12
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2Ron Johnson set a club record by scoring four touchdowns, three on passes from Norm Snead, as the New York Giants finally performed completely accord ing to form in a 2712 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles tonight.

title: JAPANESE GIVE U.S. A REPORT ON TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  Japan has informed the United States that the question of their defense agreements was never raised by China during last week's talks in Peking between Premier Chou Enlai and Pre mier Kakuei Tanaka.

title: Retailers Strike in Belgium
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 2 (AP)Re tail business in Belgium slowed to a crawl today as the coun try's 700,000 smallbusiness men began a twoday strike in protest against taxes, red tape and competition from super markets.

title: Steel Output Rises In the Latest Week And Year to Date
description: Steel production for the week ended Sept. 30 rose to 2,557, 000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This compared, with 2,536,000 tons a year ago.

title: Shellfish Ban Lifted
description: CONCORD, N. H., Oct. 2 (AP) The New Hampshire Division of Public Health said today it had lifted all restrictions on the sale and consumption of shell fish in the state. A spokesman said harvesting of clams and oysters by sport fishermen in New Hampshire was still re stricted because of danger from the effects, of red tide. There is no commercial harvesting in New Hampshire.

title: Mortars Bit Cambodian Airport
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 2 (AP)  Two mortar rounds struck the airport at the city of Kompot, 84 miles southwest of Pnompenh, today, killing nine civilian air passengers and wounding 20 others, the Cam bodian command reported.

title: New Commuter Flights Start
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 (AP) Altair Airlines started direct service today to Islip, L. I., and Bridgeport, Conn. The Phila delphiabased commuter carrier will handle five flights every business day between here and the two cities, using 17seat twinengine aircraft.

title: PORTUGUESE AIDE IS CRITICAL OF U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 2  The Portuguese For eign Minister said in a speech to the General Assembly today that the United Nations was an organization without law and without regulations.

title: Dance: Marathon '72
description: Twenty dance companies In six weeks, that is the pros pect and the promise of the City Center American Dance Marathon '72, which moved into action at the ANTA Theater last night with per formances by the companies Of Jose Limn and Lotte Goslar.

title: TAX VOW IS TIED TO DEBT CEILING
