description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  Key officials linked today the Nixon Administration's pledge not to increase taxes with Con gressional enactment of the $250billion ceiling on Federal spending this year.

title: Texas Rangers to Take Time Finding Manager
description: ARLINGTON, Tex. Oct. 2 (AP)  The Texas Ranger gen eral manager, Joe Burke, said today the club would wait about 10 days before talking seriously to any possible suc cessor to Ted Williams.

title: Library Adds to Whitman Collection
description: Twentyfive previously un known letters and postcards by Walt Whitman, shedding additional light on, his rela tions with an influential cir cle of British friends and ad mirers, are part of a large cache of manuscript and printed material about the American poet recently ac quired for the Berg Collection of the New York Public Li brary.

title: Luis Tiant, From Minnesota to Boston
description: Sports of The Times

title: Agnew's '76 Campaign
description: News Analysis

title: SEVEN FOOD PLACES FAIL 2D INSPECTION
description: Seven more foodprocessing establishments were cited yes terday by the Health Services Administration for failing, af ter a second inspection, to cor rect violations of the city's Health Code.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: A twoday strike of 170 bus drivers on four routes con netting New York City and 20 northern New Jersey points ended yesterday and service was resumed. The routes, over which 15,000 passengers ride each day, had been taken over last weekend from the InterCity Transporta tion Company by Transport of New Jersey.

title: U.S. to Press for Treaty On Harboring of Hijackers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2, (Reu ters)The United States is to make a new attempt to get an international treaty that will impose sanctions on nations harboring aircraft hijackers, the State Department said today.

title: Offensive Dialogue on Children's TV
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 Look at Connie run. I'll bet she's the best racist in the school.

title: Up North the Leaves Are Already Ablaze
description: HUDSON, N. Y., Oct. 2  The annual spectacle of fall, foliage is beginning to unfold in upstate New York and New England; drawing thousands of tourists to see and photograph the bril liance of leaves turning Yellow, gold, red and purple.

title: NANCY ROODENBURG, PRENTICEHALL AIDE
description: Mrs. Nancy McKee Rooden burg, senior book editor at PrenticeHall, Inc., died Thurs day in Lenox Hill Hospital, after having been injured in a fall several weeks ago. She was 63 years old and lived here.

title: Advertising:
description: The first issue of the Jour nal of Advertising, sponsored by the American Academy of Advertising, has just gone to the printers. It will be, ac cording to its circulation di rector, Dr. Donald W. Jugen heimer of the University of Kansas in Lawrence, a forum for the exchange of philo sophical ideas and criticisms, and an examination of ad vertising role in society.

title: Turkish Farmers See Poverty in Ban on the Poppy
description: ATLIHISAR, Turkey, Oct. 1 The lovely poppy with the white or purple blossoms is their staff of life, as the vil lagers of this impoverished region of the central Anato lian highlands tell it, and every bit of it is put to good use.

title: Cahill Wins Support On Plan to Reduce Tocks Island Project
description: TRENTON, Oct. 2Governor Cahill received important Con gressional support today for his demand that the proposed Tocks Island Dam and Recrea tion Area be drastically modi fied and reduced in scope.

title: Hoofs and Bullets Echo In Chase on West Side
description: A mounted patrolman gal loped a dozen blocks through the canyons of midtown Manhattan yesterday after noon in a bulletpunctuated chase after a motorist who had sideswiped his horse. But the fugitive, who alleged ly brandished a gun when the patrolman caught up, sped away and escaped in cloud of exhaust fumes on 10th Avenue.

title: Lausche Backs Nixon
description: CINCINNATI, Oct, 2 (AP) Prank J. Lausche, fivetime Democratic governor of Ohio and former United States Sen ator, said in an interview to day that he believes the secur ity of our nation and the wel fare of our people will be best served by the reelection of President Nixon. Mr. LauSehe said that the record of Senator George McGovern shows that he is indecisive and inconsist ent practically from day to day with the courses he will fol low.

title: BLACK UNIONISTS FORM COALITION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Black trade unionists, reacting to the decision of the American Fed eration of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations to remain neutral in the Presiden tial campaign, are forming a permanent national organiza tion.

title: GROMYKO INVITED TO NIXON RETREAT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  President Nixon conferred at the White House this morning with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko and, in an unusual, friendly gesture, invited the So viet official to continue the talks and spend the night at Camp David, the Presidential retreat in nearby Maryland.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: WASHINGTONNo public figure, no matter what his party, can be happy when charges of political dishonesty, and the evidence of it, are in the air.

title: Indicted Policeman Loses Plea to Speed Retirement
description: A 37yearold Queens patrol man lost in State Supreme Court yesterday his suit to bar the Police Department from taking disciplinary proceed ings against him because he was indicted Aug, :Al with seven other policemen on charges of stealing $10,000 from arrested suspects over the last two and a half years.

title: SALE OF GULF STOCK IS SET BY MELLONS
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation an nounced yesterday that mem bers of the families of the late Richard K. Mellon and Sarah Mellon Scaife and foundations and trusts established by them and their families are planning to sell about 9 million shares of Gulf stock through a registered secondary offering later this year.

title: Notes on People
description: Scheduled talks on the situation in Uganda col lapsed into a diplomatic flap of indeterminate import in London yesterday when N'guza IBond, the Foreign Minister of Zaire left the Carlton Tower Hotel in a huff.

title: Big Companies Accused Of Tax Fraud Schemes
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 2 (AP) Commissioner Johnnie M. Walters of the Internal Rev enue Service said today that the agency had discovered what he termed shocking instances of fraud and tax evasion schemes by giant corporations.

title: Emery to Expand Plants
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 2 (UPI) Emery Industries, Inc., said to day it expected to spend $12 million to $15million to ex pand its fatty acids products plants in Cincinnati and Los Angeles over the next three years.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The New York Public Service Commission yesterday author ized Orange and Rockland Utili ties, Inc., to issue and sell 1.5 million shares of $5 par value common stock. The proceeds of the sale, which will be managed through a negotiated offering, with Merrill Lynch as repre sentative of several underwrit ers, will be used by the utility to repay short term bank loans. It is expected that the selling date will be around Oct. 18. The company's stock was down  at 16 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Bay State Welfare Rises
description: BOSTON, Oct. 2Massachu setts welfare rolls have nearly doubled since 1968, rising from 7 per cent of the population to more than 13 per cent in 1972, according to a report issued yesterday by the Massachusetts Public Welfare Council.

title: NIXON UNIT BEGINS BIG DRIVE BY MAIL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  A massive national campaign to influence the Presidential elec tion by political letters mailed to individual voters is being quietly started this week by the Committee for the Re election of the President.

title: FRANK JOHNSON, 65, SET FISHING RECORDS
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Oct. 2 J. Frank Johnson, a saltwater sports fisherman, died today in Community Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 80 Fair View Road, Post Wash ington.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 2 (AP)The United States Auto Club has canceled the 300mile national championship race in Rafaela, Argentina, scheduled on Dec. 3.

title: Allen Snubs Tie....Redskins Bow
description: About Pro Football

title: State and City Report July WelfareRoll Declines
description: For the first time in many years, New York State has had four consecutive months of de cline in statewide welfare rolls. Abe Lavine, State Commissioner of Social Sehrices, reported yes terday a decline of 5,796 re cipients in Julycounter to historical experience.

title: A Most Wanted Gives Up
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) Byron J. Rice, wanted for killing an armored car guard in Mountain View, Calif., surren dered to Federal Bureau of In vestigation agents in Chicago today, Attorney General Rich ard G. Kleindienst announced. Rice had been on the F.B.I.'s most webted list since July, 1968.

title: Violence Erupts as Gypsies Protest Order on Cab Meters
description: Protests against new rules for gypsy taxicabs boiled over into violence in the South Bronx yesterday afternoon and last night.

title: RANGERS BEATEN BY CANADIENS, 65
description: The New York Rangers' mediocre exhibition season con tinued last night against the Montreal Canadiens, who came back from 40 and 51 deficits to post a 65 victory that counted only in their minds.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: WASHINGTON  Earlier this year, parallels were drawn between the pre convention campaigns of George Mc Govern and Barry Goldwater. The comparisons were neither invidious nor invalid. Both menone of the left, the other of the rightwere movement politicians. Unlike a John F. Kennedy or a Richard M. Nixon, who relent lessly pursued and won their party's nomination, Senators Goldwater and McGovern had their nominations cap tured on their behalfcaptured by an army of volunteers, motivated by ide ology, hungrier, better disciplined and better organized than the Establish ment they sought to displace.

title: Buffalo Bill Guns Sold
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 2 (AP) A firearms collection that in cluded a pair of derringers said to have been owned by frontiers man Buffalo Bill Cody brought $159,060 at an auction yester day. The auctioneers, Sotheby, ParkeBernet, said that $8,500 had been paid for the percussion cap derringers, part of the col lection of the late William Goodwin Renwick of Tucson, Ariz. The bid was entered on behalf of Antique Weapons of Long Beach, Calif.

title: Liberals Nominate Wks. Ryan to Run In Husband's Spot
description: Mrs. William R. Ryan last night sought and won the Lib eral party nomination for the 20th Congressional District seat held by her late husbandde spite the pleas of some close Democratic political associates to drop out and avert another bitter battle on the West Side.

title: Calhoun Named Coach
description: BOSTON, Oct. 2 (AP)James A. Calhoun, a former little all American at American Interna tional College, today was named as the basketball coach at Northeastern University, the school's athletic director, Her bert Gallagher, announced.

title: WOMAN ELECTED TO G.M.'S BOARD
description: General Motors, the nation's largest industrial corporation, elected a woman to its board of directors for the first time yesterday. She is Catherine B. Cleary, who is also the first and only woman on the board of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the na tion's largest utility and the world's largest private corpora tion.

title: Registration Questions Answered Over Phone
description: The city started a special telephone service yesterday to advise voters of registra Con procedures, dates, times and eligibility requirements for the Nov. 7 general elec tion. The telephone number is 4721003, and the service will operate daily from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Everything at the House of Barbazan, on Madison Ave nue at 83d Street, comes from Spain. There isn't a sign in the window saying Aqui se habla castellano, but there might well be. The shop's owner, Miss Gloria Barbazan, born in the United States of Spanish parents, is as fluent in Castilian Spanish as she is in Eng lish, as much at home in Madrid as in New York.

title: SOME OF KNICKS ARE IN FOR A TRIM
description: With only three more exhi bition games and one week left before the Knicks open their National Basketball. Association season, Coach Red Holzman has some rostertrimming prob lems to iron out.

title: $76BILLION FUND FOR ARMS VOTED BY SENATE 705
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Senate passed a $76billion de fense appropriations bill today after decisively rejecting a pro posal to cut off funds for fur ther bombing in Indochina.

title: GROMYKO INVITED TO NIXON RETREAT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 President Nixon conferred at the White House this mottling with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko and, in an unusual, friendly gesture, invited the So viet official to continue the talks and spend the night at Camp David, the Presidential retreat in nearby Maryland.

title: RoadsOr Rail?
description: Revival of decent mass transit in America's cities hangs on the action of the House of Representatives this week. The Senateapproved bill would break new ground by allowing $800 million to be diverted to rail transit from the hitherto pacred Highway Trust Fund; but as it now stands, the House bill allows no diversion whatever for mass transit out of the $7.5 billion available in money for highwaybuilding.

title: Liberals Nominate Mrs. Ryan to Run for Husband's House Seat
description: Despite the pleadings of some close Democratic political associates to drop out and avert another bitter battle on the West Side, Mrs. William F. Ryan last night sought and won the Liberal party's nomin ation for the 20th Congression: al District seat held by her late husband.

title: Efforts Pressed for Settlement Of Strike in Construction Trade
description: Negotiators in the three monthold construction strike were reported yesterday to be intensifying their efforts to settle the two remaining dis putes involving teamsters and elevator constructors.

title: Ineffectual Assembly
description: News Analysis

title: DANES VOTE YES ON MARKET ENTRY BY A WIDE MARGIN
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 2The people of Denmark gave a resounding yes today to membership in the Common Market.

title: Zeckendorf Is Buyer
description: A syndicate headed by Wil liam Zeckendorf Jr., the son of the realestate promoter, has, bought the Kips Bay Plaza, housing project on the East Side from the Aluminum Company of America.

title: U.S. Hires ExRep. Watson
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) Former Representative Albert W. Watson, a Democratturned Republican from Columbia, S.C., has been hired as a $33,260a yearspecial assistant in the So cial Security Administration. He was engaged for not More than one year to study the Social Security appeals process.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  Construction spending in August reached a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $121.7billion, the Commerce Department reported today. New building for the month was up 1 per cent from July's revised total of $120.1 billion.

title: AIRLINES SEEKING PACT EXTENSION
description: Merger News

title: Sports News Briefs
description: COMMERCE, Tex., Oct. 2 (UPI)Sam Houston State University today was placed on probation and ruled in eligible to compete in basketball in The Lone Star Confer ence this season.

title: Judith Harriss Wed to Broker
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Oct. 2Miss Judith C. Harriss was married this afternoon to Gerald Maxwell Geddes of Palm Beach and East Hampton, L. I., a wid ower, Judge Paul Douglas, a senior member of the Palm Beach County Judges Court, performed the ceremony in his chambers here.

title: 3Judge Panels to Weigh State Sentences in Bronx
description: Presiding Justice Harold A. Stevens of the Appellate Divi sion yesterday ordered the immediate creation of three judge sentencing panels in State Supreme Court in the Bronx to review every case before sentence is imposed.

title: Stoneman's NoHitter
description: Bill Stoneman of the Mont real Expos pitched a nohit game in defeating the Mets, 70, in the first game of a doubleheader last night in Montreal. He pitched a no hitter against Philadelphia in 1969. Details, Page 55.

title: Preliminary Approval Won
description: The City Planning Commis sion gave preliminary approval yesterday to a plan to erect a slateaided, 1,700unit apart ment development that would include two 40story towers on West 42d Street.

title: Trainer With a Special Touch Is King at Belmont Racetrack
description: What happened, King? a stunned horseplayer called out to W. Preston King yesterday at Belmont Park after the meet ing's leading trainer failed to saddle a winner in the first race.

title: MRS. JEAN M. CHIESA OF HARPER'S BAZAAR
description: Mrs. Jean Murray Chiesa, ex ecutive editor of Harper's Ba zaar from 1941 to 1969, died Saturday in Doctors Hosi She was 69 years old and lived at 529 East 85th Street.

title: Connecticut Stops 77 For Evading 25c Toll
description: A state police crackdown on Connecticut Turnpike toll evaders snared '77 motorists over the weekend at the West Haven, Stratford and Greenwich toll stations, the Connecticut Transportation Department reported yester day.

title: TaxExempt Securities Advance Moderately Corporates Slide
description: Credit Markets

title: DEALER SENTENCED ON FALSE EGG STORY
description: A Manhattan food dealer who admitted planting a false market report on the importa tion of 153 million eggs from Spain was sentenced in Federal District Court here yesterday to two months in jail.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Oct. 2Archie Niles Jr., one of the trainerdrivers competing at Freehold Raceway, has a onehorse stable and a $1 horse in it. That is, Niles gave up $1 for him when he acquired the colt as a 2yearold five years ago. But Butler Time is far from a $1 horse now. At the moment, his career earnings total $38,000.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Northwest Pilots End 95Day Strike by Accepting 29% Wage Increase
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 2 (UPI) Northwest Airlines and its 1,619 striking pilots reached a new contract agreement today, ending a 95day strike that crippled the airline's service across the Eastern, Midwestern and Northwestern United States.

title: Soviet Lofts 3d Satellite In Communications Series
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 2The Soviet Union announced today that it had launched the third of its se ries of Molniya 2 television satellites, which are part of a potential world communica tions system.

title: U.S. Court Bans State Aid To PrivateSchool Parents
description: A threejudge Federal Court yesterday struck down as unconstitutional a newly enacted New York statute that would have provided state tuition grants to parents of privateschool students.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Whenever life has settled Into a sixday rain and the cats have infested the house with fleas, and the shower stall over the diningroom sideboard is leaking into the mashed potatoes, and there is a recurring dream about graveyards and politicians keep reminding you of the existence of the Govesnmentthen it is time to turn your back on reality and slip away for a quiet restorative visit with the wonderful folks of tele visionland.

title: N.M.U. Head Urges Two Big Unions
description: The National Maritime Union was told by its president yester day that the time had come to bring about the merger of all maritime labor into two unions  one for officers and one for unlicensed seamen.

title: Two New Works Planned by City Opera
description: The New York City Opera's 10week spring season, open ing Feb. 21, will include two works previously unstaged in the city, Ginastera's Bea trix Cenci, Henze's The Young Lord, as well as Monteverdi's L'Incoronazi one di Poppea.

title: GROUP ORGANIZED FOR DOCTOR AIDES
description: The directors of training pro grams for physician assistants are forming an organization to work out the problems that are developing in this rapidly growing controversial new profession.

title: Respect Life Week Stresses the Unborn
description: The nationwlde Roman Cath olic observance of Respect Life Week, inaugurated in the New York Archdiocese on Sunday by Cardinal Cooke, focused yesterday, oh respect for the unborn and today will emphasize respect for the aged.

title: Thai Air Base Shelled
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 2 (AP)Thirtysix mortar shells were reported fired last night at the Ubon air base, one of the eight Thai airfields from which American planes strike at North Vietnam.

title: Civilians to Free 1,000 More Police for Patrols
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the Police De partment would begin hiring 150 civilians a month from Civil Service lists to replace 1,000 uniformed patrolmen now as signed to clerical and adminis trative duties in Police Head quarters and technicalservice units; The uniformed men would be sent out on patrol.

title: Hall Named Tampa Coach
description: TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 2 (UPI) George L. Hall, 68 years old, who retired Sept. 1 as golf coach at Cornell University, was named today to coach golf at the University of Tampa.

title: PRICES ARE LOWER ON AMEX AND OTC
description: After three consecutive ses sions of advances, prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthe  counter market closed lower yesterday in slow trading.

title: PRICES FOR CORN DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Dry, sunny weather over the weekend brought a sharp drop in corn and soybean prices yes terday, as the harvest gained momentum again.

title: Business Briefs
description: A second major contract for the construction of three large liquefied natural gas tankers has been approved over the weekend by the Maritime Administration in Wash ington.

title: Swiss Parliament Goes To Rescue of Cavalry
description: GENEVA, Oct. 2  The horse won a reprieve in, the Swiss Army today when the lower house of Parliament rejected by an overwhelming vote a Government proposal to disband the remaining 18 cavalry squadrons.

title: A.E.C. Staff Urges FiveYear Test Use For Indian Point 2
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Atomic Energy Commission's staff has recommended that the Indian Point No. 2 nuclear power plant on the Hudson River be allowed to operate for five years, although the staff said the present cooling system might kill up to five million, or more, young fish a year.

title: Inaction by States May Strengthen a New Drive for Federal NoFault Insurance Law
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Amid intensive lobbying and much animosity, 37 state legislatures considered the issue of nofault automobile insurance this but only two new laws emerged. The result may strengthen a renewed Congres sional drive next year for Federal nofault law.

title: Boston Gets Police Leader
description: BOSTON, Oct. 2 (UPI)Ro bert Digrazia, 44 years old, who headed the St. Louis Police Department since 1969, arrived yesterday to accept his appoint ment as Boston Police Commis sioner. He was named to the $35,000ayear post Saturday by Mayor Kevin H. White. He suc ceeds Edmund McNamara, who quit in May after his second fiveyear term ended.

title: Penrzsy Trustees Update Plan for Reorganization
description: Although the Penn Central Transportation Company con tinues to report huge deficits from operations, its trustees still are basing their reorgan ization planning on a system that by 1976 could produce some $243million of income available for meeting fixed charges  rentals, taxes and interest charges.

title: BOSTON ELDERLY TELL OF TERROR
description: BOSTON, Oct. 3When 70 yearold Mary Bellthat is not her real namereturned one evening to her small apartment in one of the public housing projects here following dinner with friends she was not sur prised to find that the hall way lights were out again and the elevator was broken.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 3  Opposi tion to Governor Cahill's pro posed $650million transporta tion bond issue surfaced here today when the New Jersey Taxpayers Association an nounced that it could not sup port it until the state aban doned crisis financing and in stead adopted tax reform.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: United States Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Mar shall refused a request by Connecticut officials for a ruling that would have kept the strict 1972 antiabortion law in effect until the high court can decide on its con stitutionality. The state, how ever, immediately sent a tele gram to Chief Justice Warren E. Burger asking him to con sider the matter.

title: Yonkers Cancels The Gotham Trot; 3 Horses Entered
description: YONKERS, Oct. 3  For the second straight year, Yonkers Raceway's oldest trotting fix ture, the Gotham Trot, will not be staged. Last season it was canceled because of a dearth of trotters. This year the invita tion event did not fill.

title: SCHOOLS IN CAPITAL RETURN TO NORMAL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 3 (AP) The 140,000pupil school sys tem here, struck for two weeks by teachers, returned to nor mal today as the Senate Dis trict Committee opened hear ings on a 12 per cent teacher pay increase.

title: ORVIS EXPARTNERS WIN A COURT CASE
description: A Federal Court judge ruled yesterday that three former partners in a New York Stock Exchange brokerage firm, which was liquidated after severe fi nancial losses, were entitled to inspect all documents relating to their case. The documents could be used by the exchange in hearings on the firm's col lapse.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Oct. 3 (AP) Britain's gold and foreign currency reserves backing the pound fell by $2million in September to $6.09bil lion at the end of the month, the Treasury an nounced today. It gave no explanation for the drop, but financial sources called the change relatively small. The pound held steady on foreignexchange markets here immediately after the Announcement.

title: ITALIAN HORSE DIES AT SPECTRUM SHOW
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3Just eight hours after the Philadel phia horse showthe first major event of the indoor fall circuitopened in the Spec trum today, a horse dropped dead of a heart attack.

title: Manna From Big Daddy
description: When 28 million persons get checks increasing their Social Security payments by 20 per cent five weeks before Election Day, some are bound to suspect just a trace of politics in the accompanying notice that they owe the extra money to a new law enacted by the Congress and signed into law by President Richard Nixon.

title: HOUSE BARS MOVE ON MINIMUM WAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The House of Representatives, re fused today to allow legislation increasing the Federal mini mum wage to go to conference with the Senate.

title: House Backs Civic Center
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) The House voted 210 to 169 today to authorize construction of a $65million civic center in the capital to be named in honor of President Eisenhower. The bill also authorized the naming of any Federal building in honor of civic leaders and present or former members of Congress. It specifically ap proved the naming of the new F.B.I. building under construc tion in memory of the late J. Edgar Hoover.

title: HOUSE BARS MOVE ON MINIMUM WAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The House of Representatives re fused today to allow legislation increasing the Federal mini mum wage to go to conference with the Senate.

title: The Danes Say Yes
description: Denmark's voters have given a sorely needed lift the flagging cause of Western European unity in decid ingby a nearly twotoone majorityto join the Com mon Market. This is a dramatic boost for the whole idea of European cooperation and integration, which will be strengthened in January by formal expansion the European Economic Community from six to nine nations. At that time, Britain and Ireland as well Denmark will join Europe.

title: 2 IN CAPITAL WIN SUITS ON ARREST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 A Federal district judge awarded $4,500 today to each of two persons he found had been falsely arrested during the May Day protests here last year.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: STEVEN AND IRWIN ARE ??

title: GRAY PUNISHES THIRD F.B.I. AGENT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) Richard, D. Rogge, an F.B.I. agent for 20 years, has become the third agent disciplined and transferred since L. Patrick Gray 3d took over in May as acting head of the Federal Bu reau of Investigation.

title: TV BLACKOUT BAN BACKED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI)With the nation's No. 1 fan, President Nixon, making the decision himself, the Ad ministration threw its support today behind legislation that would prohibit professional sports leagues from imposing television blackouts of home games.

title: Market Place:
description: Can the stock market sur vive ad we know if today if a stock's price can drop 20 per cent or more in a, single day's reaction to bad news?

title: Inmates at Jersey Jail Register to Vote In Presidential Election as Absentees
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 3In mates at the Hudson County Jail shuffled into the small thirdfloor gymnasium today in groups of five and 10, not to play the usual games of volley ball or shuffleboard, but to register to vote in the Nov. 7 Presidential election.

title: Tigers Win, 31, and Take Title
description: DETROIT, Oct. 3Al Kaline, the grand old master of the De troit Tigers, broke up a 11 stalemate with a runscoring single off Luis Tiant in the sev enth inning tonight and sent Detroit into the American League pennant playoff against Oakland.

title: Notes on People
description: Republican Senators Jacob K. Javits of New York and Norris Cotton of New Hamp shire engaged in an angry confrontation last night on the floor of the Senate.

title: The Store Is 100 Years Old, And, Oh, the Styles It's Seen
description: Bloomingdale's was lit up like an oldfashioned Holly wood premiere last night, but the celebrities in the klieg lights weren't movie stars. They were mostly fashion designers and manufacturers from Seventh Avenue and home furnishings suppliers who had come to celebrate the store's 100th anniversary.

title: New Community Trust Aide
description: The appointment of William J. Trent Jr., former executive director of United Negro Col lege Fund and now president of the board of trustees of St. Luke's Hospital, as a member of the New York Community Trust's distribution committee was announced yesterday. The trust is a public charitable or ganization that administers nearly 300 individual funds and foundations.

title: Nixon and Brezhnev Put 2 Arms Accords Into Effect
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Pres ident Nixon and the Soviet Foreign. Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, called today for fur ther steps to halt the arms race as they signed documents putting into effect the two agreements on limiting strategic arms reached in Moscow in May.

title: Rockefeller Rules Out Possibility of a Tax Cut
description: ALBANY, Oct. 3 (UPI) Governor Rockefeller said to day that there was no possi bility of a state tax cut next year and that the state faced another year with a very tight budget.

title: Accountant Says. S.E.C. Will Ask Profit Forecast
description: DENVER, Oct. 3  The Se curities and Exchange Commis sion will soon require corpora tions to make forecasts of earn ings in prospectuses describing stocks and bonds for sale, leading accountant predicted to day.

title: House Panel Criticizes Pentagon On Political Killings in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) A House of Representatives subcommittee has criticized the Pentagon for not investigating possible war crimes by United States soldiers taking part in a program of political assassina tion in South Vietnam.

title: The View From the Playground
description: Sports of The Times

title: Clinic Shut; Ph.D. Lack Is at Issue
description: A State Supreme Court judge yesterday ordered the closing of an unlicensed psychotherapy clink in Suffolk County following charges by the Attorney General's office that the man behind the clinic had misled his clients into believing that he was a licensed psy chologist.

title: Prisoners in Jersey City Register for U.S. Election
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 3In mates at the Hudson County Jail shuffled into the small thirdfloor gymnasium today in groups of five and 10, not to play the usual games of volley ball or shuffleboard, but to register to vote in the Nov. Presidential election.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Martial Law in Manila
description: The United States Governnent continues to maintain a discreet silence about developments in the Philippines, where President Marcos' martial law crackdown is now in its second week. This does not mean, however, that Americans are indifferent to the fate of their former Pacific colony.

title: Building Industry Assailed on Contract Bargaining
description: One of the major builders in the city criticized the construc tion industry here yesterday for being hapless and ineffec tive in collective bargaining, pitting amateur management negotiators against skilled union negotiators.

title: 9 Chosen for Commission To Revise Charter for City
description: Governor Rockefeller's of fice yesterday announced the names of nine members ap pointed to a special bipartisan state commission to revise New York City's Charter.

title: Rules Panel Blocks House on Nixon Plan to Let Urban Areas Use Highway Funds for Mass Transit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 The House Rules Committee refused today to permit a vote by the full House on the Nixon Administration's plan to let urban areas spend their share of Federal highway money to build mass transit systems.

title: Festival Jurors Discuss Film Choices
description: Behind the New York Film Festival, now playing to ca pacity audiences in Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center, lies a yearlong process of plan ning and selectionor, as its severest critics would have it, of misplanning and mis selection.

title: Labor and H.E.W. Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) The Senate passed today $30.5  billion appropriation bill for the Department of Labor and Health, Education and Wel fare that is nearly the same as the one that President Nixon vetoed on Aug. 16 as reckless Federal spending.

title: Exchange Sets Unit to Study Members' NewIssue Role
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced the appoint ment yesterday of a committee to study whether the exchange should have guidelines for its members regarding the sale of new issues. The Securities and Exchange Commission had asked the exchange to consider the matter.

title: SELLOFFS TOPPLE 2 GLAMOUR ISSUES
description: Two stocks with large insti tutional followings  American Air Filter and ARA Services plummeted yesterday on news developments, while a number of bluechip issues posted gains.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 3The Feder al Government today ordered Joseph Moriarty, a top Jersey City numbersgame operator, to pay more than $1.5 million in unpaid Federal income taxes.

title: Candidate Scores Kissinger
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Oct. 3 (UPI)Representative John G. Schmitz, Republican of Cali fornia, the American party Presidential candidate, warned today of a totalitarian govern ment if President Nixon was reelected and called Henry A. Kissinger, Presidential adviser on national security affairs, the unelected de facto Presi dent. He charged that Mr. Kissinger is the true Presi dent of the United States right now and said the Presidential adviser is from the Council of Foreign Relations, which is dedicated to a oneworld so cialist system.

title: McGovern Rates Crime And Drugs as Top Issues
description: Senator George McGovern promised yesterday to make eradication of crime and drug abuse the No. 1 domestic pri ority of my administration.

title: Denmark's Premier Quits After Victory On Joining Market
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 3  Premier Jens Otto Krag resigned today only a few hours after his countrymen had given him a decisive political victory by overwhelmingly endorsing Danish membership in the European Common Market.

title: Lithuanian Youths Sentenced for Role In Riots Last May
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 3The Lith uanian Supreme Court today sentenced seven youths to jai] terms ranging from 18 months to three years after a trial arising from rioting in May aft er a young man had burned himself to death.

title: Music Hall Faces Strike Tomorrow by Orchestra
description: Negotiators for the Radio City Music Hall and members of its orchestra continued efforts yesterday to settle, their contract dispute and avert a shutdown tomorrow.

title: Most of Nation's Largest Banks Join in Raising Prime to 5%
description: Almost all of the nation's largest banks joined yesterday in increasing their prime lend ing rates to 5 per cent from 5 per cent. This completed for all practical purposes the most recent round of increases in the minimum interest charge on highly rated business loans.

title: Parsley, Sage, Rosemary and ThymePlus 66 Other Herbs
description: AMITYVILLE, L. I.  It's the easiest kind of garden to grow, Virginia Colby said as she led the way out of her house to a big backyard shaded by old trees, and stopped at her herb garden.

title: Lemon Dismissed; McKeon of Omaha To Manage Royals
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 3 (UPI) Ewing Kauffman, the owner of the Kansas City Royals, dis missed Manager Bob Lemon today and replaced him with a minor league manager, Jack McKeon.

title: AMERICAN MARINE INDICTED IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Oct. 3An Ameri can marine was indicted by the Japanese prosecutor's office today, charged with the mur der of a Japanese citizen in a case that has developed diplo matic and racial overtones.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rome Moves to Prevent Decline of Colosseum
description: ROMEThere is a saying In Rome that When the Colos seuin falls Rollie will fall. Ever since 50pound chunks of travertine marble began crashing to the ground a few months ago from the 150foot high structure, superstitious Romans have had cause for alarm. The crumbling arena became not only an inauspi cious omen for the future of Rome but also a potential danger for anyone who ven tured near it.

title: WRIGHT, COLLINS SHARE GOLF LEAD
description: INWOOD, L. L, Oct. 3  Jimmy Wright, playing on his home course, and Bill Collins, a stranger to the layout, shared the lead at 72 in the Metro politan Professional Golfers Association championship to day.

title: Explosion in Pnompenh
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Wednesday, Oct. 4 (UPI)The explosion of an M113 armored personnel carrier set off sev eral thousand rounds of small arms ammunition stored in a Pnompenh sports stadium this morning and spread panic in this already tense capital.

title: LINDSAY CHARGES MACHINE RULE OF STATE BENCH
description: In some of the strongest Ian guage he has used about the courts since becoming Mayor, John V. Lindsay charged in an interview that the State Su preme Court was highly ineffi cient and strongly susceptible to corruption because it was controlled by political bosses.

title: OutofCity CabRide Rule Is Upheld by State Court
description: A rule requiring taxi drivers to take passengers to destina tions outside the city was up held in State Supreme Court yesterday.

title: Environmentalists Hail A.B.C. Ruling on Con Ed
description: Environmentalists, who gen erally have been critical of the Atomic Energy Commis sion, were openly praising it yesterday for the decision to ask Consolidated Edison to add an expensive cooling system to its nuclear plant to protect fish life in the Hudson River.

title: BREWERS DEFEAT YANKEES, 3 TO 2
description: The Milwaukee Brewers beat the Yankees for the fourth straight time last night, using homers by John Briggs and Joe Lahoud to take a 3.2 vic tory. Bobby Murcer and Roy White matched the Brewer homers, but Mel Stottlemyre, the Yankee starter, gave up a firstinning run that proved to be the winning margin.

title: Graft, Confusion Peril Bengalis
description: DACCA, BangladeshWhen the Prime Minister of Bangla desh, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, returned from Europe recently after a gall bladder operation, a local newspaper headline pro claimed, Days of Anxiety Over.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ARAB AT MUNICH LINKED TO FATAH
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 3 One of the surviving Palestinian commandos involved in the kill ing of Israeli Olympic athletes at Munich was identified here today as a close collaborator of a slain military hero of Al Fatah, a guerrilla movement.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: STEIN SONG Five short operas with librettos by Ger trude Steinthree of them getting their first airing in New Yorkwill be performed by the After Dinner Opera, a touring company that has headquarters in town but that rarely raises the curtain locally.

title: City to Put Bright Lighting On 1,200 Miles of Streets
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday a rapid expansion of the anticrime streetlighting program so that about a fifth of the city's streets will have new, brighter, sodium lamps by the end of next year.

title: Excerpts From Policy Talk by China's Representative at U.N. Assembly
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3  Following are ex cerpts front the speech in the General Assembly today by China's Deputy Foreign Min ister Chiao Kuanhua. The English translation was pro vided by the Chinese Mis sion:

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 The television phase of the Re publican Presidential campaign is beginning to get tough, and some concerned Democrats are wondering if they should not turn to the same tactics them selves.

title: Few Days Left to Register
description: New Yorkers who wish to vote in the Nov. 7 election may register at their local polling places tomorrow, Fri day, Saturday and next Tuesday. The polls will be open from 5:30 P.M. to 10:30 P.M. tomorrow, Friday and Tues day and from 7 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. on Saturday.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE GREAT BRIDGE. By David McCullough. 636 pages. Illustrated. Simon & Schuster. $10.95.

title: Curtin Scientific, Unit of Foremost, Bought by SCIMed
description: Merger News

title: Democrats Offer Spending Curb That Keeps Power in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 3Dem ocratic leaders in the House presented their own version today of a spending control billone that Administration lobbyists found so, weak that they were encouraged about their prospects for defeating it.

title: Three Senators, Courtesy and $11Million
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  In a Senate given to mutual ac commodation when it comes to dispensing Federal largesse, the two Senators from Washington are finding themselves unex pectedly challenged by Senator J. W. Fulbright in an attempt to get a $11.5million contribu tion for a fair in their home state.

title: Bethlehem Denies Charge
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 3 (UPI)  The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has denied a charge that it spent more than $500,000 unlawfully to support the reelection campaign of President Nixon. A Bethlehem spokesman said yesterday that the company would defend it self vigorously against a suit filed in United States Dis strict Court lash Thursday by Richard A. Ash, who holds 50 shares of Bethlehem stock.

title: Gas Stations Lead List of Complaints In Repairs of Cars
description: Independent repair shops in general and gasoline stations in particular are the most fre quent targets of complaints by car owners, who say the shops often overcharge them and fail to make necessary re pairs.

title: Transplant Successes
description: An impressive record of successes has been reported at the international transplantation conference in San Francisco. There are now people leading normal lives whose kidneys were transplanted into their bodies al most a decade ago. Two recipients of heart transplants more than four years ago are still alive, while the record shows that about one heart transplant recipient out of five has survived more than two years after surgery. Organ transplantation is, as one physician put it, one the greatest, although as yet incompletely exploited, therapeutic achievements of modern medicine.

title: CRIME TOP ISSUE, MURPHY ASSERTS
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy told an East Side seminar yesterday that crime was still the nation's No. 1 problem, domestic or foreign, and that it was destroying, the inner cities and spreading to the suburbs.

title: '72 Bomb Tonnage in Asia Already Tops Last Year's
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Pen tagon statistics showed today that bombs dropped by the United States in Southeast Asia in the first nine months of 1972 exceeded in tonnage the bombs dropped in all of 1971.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Leo C. Zeferetti, president of the 2,800member Correction Officers Benevolent Association, said yesterday that his union had rejected a tentative contract by a 4to1 margin.

title: Third Biggest Diamond Bought by Dealer Here
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, Oct. 3 (Agence FrancePresse) The third largest diamond ever found, the Star of Sierra Leone, has been sold, Presi dent Siaka Stevens an nounced here today.

title: McGovern as President
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  Senator George McGovern may be the most underrated figure in American politics.

title: Mollie Parnis Sees CiVic Pride Paying Off
description: Mollie Parnis, the designer, and Mrs. John V. Lindsay yesterday toured some vest pocket parks and sprucedup slum streets that had won cash awards' in a contest funded, by the New York born couturier.

title: 9 Canadiens Are Fined For Curfew Violations
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 3 (AP) Coach Scotty Bowman of The Montreal Canadiens has fined nine members of the National Hockey League club for break ing curfew.

title: $681 Million Jump for August Held Expansion Sign
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Man ufacturers' inventories climbed by $681million in August, a strong onemonth gain, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: INJUNCTION IS ISSUED AGAINST TIMES UNION
description: State Supreme Court Justice Joseph DiFede issued a prelimi nary injunction yesterday bar ring a strike against The New York Times by the New York Mailers Union No. 6.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Fanny May Yields Increase On 4Month Commitments
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (Reu ters)The average yield of four month commitments for Federal Homeowner Associa tion and Veterans Association mortgages at the auction yes terday by the Federal Nation Mortgage Association was 7.698 per cent, compared to 7.658 per cent at the previous auction on Sept. 18, the Federal National Mortgage Association said to day.

title: SENATE VOTES BILL TO AID THE ELDERLY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) The Senate passed today, 90 to 0, a bill to strengthen and expand Government programs to aid the elderly.

title: House Contests
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 3  There are no bandwagons in Connec ticut for the Congressional can didates to ride.

title: Celtics Conquer Knicks, 111 to 97
description: Because the game was a pre season exhibition, it didn't mean anything in the standings of the National Basketball As sociation. But the Boston Cel tics gave the Knicks an indi cation that dethroning them as the regularseason leaders of the Atlantic Division may be a difficult task.

title: HOUSE PANEL BARS PRENOV.7 INQUIRY INTO BUGGING CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The House Banking and Currency Committee rejected today, 20 to 15, a proposal to hold public hearings on certain aspects of the alleged bugging of the Dem ocratic party's Watergate head luarters.

title: Departing Danish Chief Jens Otto Krag
description: Man in the News

title: Judge Says Nursery Rhymes Advocate Crime
description: An Erie County judge has asked a Buffalo grand jury to investigate the use of The In ner City Mother Goose, satirical book based upon the familiar nursery rhymes, in public school libraries there.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Congress Contests
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 2 Yesterday was Dee Day in the Commonwealth of Ken tucky, the day when the 5 per cent food tax officially went off the books.

title: TV BLACKOUT BAN BACKED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI)With the nation's No. 1 fan, President Nixon, making the decision himself, the Ad ministration threw its support today behind legislation that would prohibit professional sports leagues from imposing television blackouts of home games.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Grain Price Rise Called Signal for Higher Output
description: The recent rises in the price of major grains and of soybeans resulting from huge exports are giving some valuable signals to the nation's farmers, Car roll G. Brunthaver, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, said yesterday.

title: GALLUP SAYS NATION IS LOW IN PRESTIGE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) George Gallup, the pollster, said today that American pres tige was at a low point in the world, partly because United States press services, in con centrating so heavily on our problems, may have given a distorted picture.

title: CATHOLICS SCORE SCHOOLAID RULING
description: Roman Catholic educators in, the city reacted with dismay and a touch of anger yesterday to the Federal Court ruling striking down as unconstitu tional two key provisions of a state law providing aid to private schools.

title: 64% SAID TO FAVOR U.S. RAIL SUBSIDY
description: A sizable majority of the American public favors con tinuing intercity passenger trains even if it means Federal subsidies, according to a na tionwide poll made public yes terday.

title: Personalities: Namath a Probable
description: A number of New York Jets nursed slight injuries yester day during a light practice for their game next Sunday against the Miami Dolphins, the National Football Lea gue's only unbeaten team. Joe Namath headed the list of probables, which means the stiffness and soreness from last Sunday's defeat by the Houston Oilers should not prevent him from playing. Namath complained of a sore left leg, caused by the pounding and setting up on the hard surface of the Astro dome. Other Jet probables are John Riggins (charley horse), Eddie Bell (sore right shoul der), John Elliott (hamstring muscle pull) and Rich Sowells sore leg).

title: Graft, Confusion Peril Bengalis
description: DACCA, BangladeshWhen the Prime Minister of Bangla desh, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, returned from Europe recently after a gall bladder operation, local newspaper headline pro claimed, Days of Anxiety Over.

title: Nonfatal Traffic Day Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) The National Association of Women Highway Safety Lead ers asked today for the estab lishment of a national day with out traffic deaths. Mrs. Paul J. Gnau, president of the associa tion concluding a threeday meeting here, urged that the day be set aside in recognition of the two millionth American road highway fatality in the 75year history of the automo bile, expected to occur later this year.

title: Fiat Head Denies Art Deal but Italian Labor Paints Another Picture
description: ROME, Oct. 3 Two paint ings sold recently by the Met ropolitan Museum of Art today enlivened the fight of 1.5 mil lion Italian metal workers for a new contract.

title: LINDSAY PUTS OFF CHOICE FOR HOUSE
description: Mayor Lindsay, said yester day that at the moment he was not taking a position on whether to support Representa tive Bella S. Abzug or Mrs. Pris cilia Ryan in their contest for the West Side Congressional spat left vacant by the death of Representative William F. Ryan.

title: Tigers Take Title.
description: The Detroit Tigers took the Eastern Division title in the American League last night by beating the Boston Red Sox, 31. Details on Page 55.

title: Aaron's 34th Home Ran Gives Hint 673 Total
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 3 (AP) Hank Aaron smashed a two out, tworun homer tonight, his 34th of the season and 673d of his career, but it wasn't enough to keep the Atlanta Braves from a 65 loss to the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: F.D.R. campaigning in Wheeling, W. Va., in 1932
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  How can one who believed in the principles and leadership of the Democratic party under Franklin D. Roosevelt support Richard Nixon for reelection as Presi dent of the United States?

title: Ivy League Roundup
description: The Ivy League unveiled Its 1972 football teams in non league competition last week end and came away with a collective 62 wonlost mark. As expected Columbia, Dart mouth, Penn and Yale dem onstrated superior talents in beating Fordham, New Hamp shire, Lafayette and Connec ticut, respective ly. But Cornell's victory over what had appeared to be a solid Col gate team had to be regarded with raised eye brows, and Princeton's close call over a rugged Rutgers team had to be considered an upset. The two losers, Har vard to Massachusetts and Brown to Rhode Island, were disappointments to coaches Joe Restic and Len Jardine.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  The United States Supreme Court today refused an appeal by a former Newark Evening News reporter who is sched uled to go to jail tomorrow for refusing to answer questions before an Essex County grand jury.

title: A BOOK ON CONGRESS RELEASED BY NADER
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 3 (AP) Ralph Nader released today the first volume of what he promised would be an ency clopedic study of Congress. He called that body the Great American Default.

title: State Report Finds Few Women Hold Top School Posts
description: ALBANY, Oct. 3 (AP)More than half the professional educators in New York State's public schools are women, but less than 3 per cent of them hold administrative positions.

title: 2 Held in Extortion Plot To Blow Up Power Building
description: BILLINGS, Mont., Oct. 3 (UPI)Two men accused of try ing to extort $100,000 from the Montana Power Company by threatening to blow up one of the company's buildings were ordered held on $50,000 bond yesterday.

title: U.S. and Spanish Chess Teams Tied in 7th Round of Olympics
description: SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 3  The United States scored 1 to 1, with one game ad journed, in its match against Spain in the seventh round of the Chess Olympics here.

title: Air Strikes in North Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Oct. 4 (AP)Thai based United States aircraft were reported yesterday to have flown air strikes aimed at heading off an enemy buildup in Laos.

title: Arms Accords Signed
description: President Nixon and the Soviet Foreign Minister, An drei A. Gromyko, signed documents yesterday in Washington putting into ef fect the two agreements, limiting the use of nuclear arms that were reached in Moscow in May. Details on Page 3.

title: Theater: Life of a Man
description: A massed chorus of more than 60 marches triumphant ly down the aisles and into Al Carmines's latest opus, The Life of a Man. Exult ant sound reverberates through Judson Memorial Church, where the show is playing (Fridays through Mondays) until Oct. 23. In the center at the piano (the entire or chestra) is Carmines himself  minister, playwright, di rector and composer of songs for all occasions, those occa sions being Carmines's musi cals.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 3For Ed ward Plaza, 29 years old, lately of Manhattan District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office, Here is where the action is.

title: Soviet Marking Sputnik Anniversary
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 3  Russians love anniversaries, and on the eve of Sputnik's 15th anniver sary, medals are being handed out to unidentified scien tists and technicians, the re sults of the Soviet space pro gram are being reviewed and assessed, and the newly devel oping collaboration with the United States is being hailed.

title: Mobutu Says Amin Agrees To Extend Asians' Deadline
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Oct. 3 (AP)President Sese Seko Mo butu of Zaire said today that President Idi Amin of Uganda would extend the Nov. 8 dead line for the expulsion of Asians Who do not hold Uganda citi zenship and would allow. the Asians to transfer their posses sions abroad.

title: Police Ask $36.4Million for Crime Weapons Ranging From a Copter to Stables
description: The Police Department yes terday detailed some of its needs for the paraphernalia of modern crime fighting  1,000 ultrahighfrequency walkie talkies, a twinengine helicop ter and new stables for its 210 horses.

title: About Pro Football
description: Ben Hawkins, the slack jawed wide receiver of the Philadelphia Eagles who lets, his unattached white chin strap dangle, and Rich Hous ton, the unsung and unap preciated Giants' wide re ceiver from Newark, were running from the bottom to the top and out of about 30 million television receivers on Mon day night. They were what is called the man inmotion. B u t what good do they do? The conclusion here would be not much, one substantiated by a tactical expert with credits, Fran Tarkenton.

title: CHINA, AT THE U.N., BACKS JUST WARS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3China told the General Assembly today that the people of the world must not be deluded by certain temporary and superficial phenomena of dtente at the present time and develop a false sense of secu rity.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Edward W. Blair, a pro fessional fundraiser, has, been named executive direc tor of the financially trou bled New Jersey Symphony Orchestra.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP)The Communications satellite Corporation, the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and the MCI Communications Corporation signed an agree tent today for a jointly owned company to provide nation wide satellite communications. Each of the three corporations will have onethird ownership of the company under the agreement filed with the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ISLANDERS DOWN PENGUINS, 3 TO 2
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 3 With 129 seconds remaining in their final exhibition game before they join the National Hockey League for real, the Islanders defeated the Pitts burgh Penguins tonight on a short shot by Billy Harris.

title: Business Briefs
description: Some progress was reported last night in the negotia tions under way in New York since Sunday between the five Persian Gulf oilproducing areas and international oil companies over the producers' demand for participation and eventual control of concessions held by the companies. A spokesman for the companies said that, after three sep arate fourhour negotiating sessions since Sunday, the two sides have moved closer together.

title: Denmark's Premier Quits After Victory On Joining Market
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 3  Premier Jens Otto Krag resigned today only a few hours after his countrymen had given him a decisive political victory by overwhelmingly endorsing Danish membership in the European Common Market.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BOSTON, Oct. 3A huge and spirited crowd welcomed Sena tor George McGovern here to day to cheer his denunciation of President Nixon as a fraud and give the Democratic Presi dential campaign a boost in morale.

title: City to Put Bright Lighting On 1,200 Miles of Streets
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday a rapid expansion of the anticrime streetlighting program so that about a fifth of the city's streets will have new, brighter sodium lamps by the end of next year.

title: Rockefeller Bids Congress Act on Welfare and Medicaid
description: Governor Rockefeller called on Congress yesterday to pass legislation that would, prevent the 20 per cent Social Security increase from disqualifying any one from welfare or Medicaid benefits.

title: The Stage: Lady Audley
description: At the end of the new musical Lady Audley's Se cret, which opened at the Eastside Playhouse last night, the cast is singing: Forgive Us, Forgive! Well yes, why not? But it will take until next week to forget.

title: Carrier Home From Asia
description: ALAMEDA, Calif., Oct. 3 (UPI)  The carrier Hancock returned today to her home port after a tour of duty off Vietnam. The Hancock, launched 28 years ago, will re main here for several months for repairs and retraining of her 3,000 crew members.

title: California Bonds Meet Resistance
description: Credit Markets

title: Music: A Weak Shostakovich's 15th
description: Dmitri Shostakovich, the most famous composer in Russia, got into a bit of trou ble with his Symphony No. 13, a setting of Yevtushenko poems. Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev did not like the text, especially the reference to the Jews murdered at Babi Yar. Then, in his Symphony No. 14, Shostakovich wrote what in effect was a song cycle. It Was a symphony only because he called it so.

title: SENATE REJECTS A WELFARE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The Senate killed today a compro mise welfare reform plan that President Nixon had earlier re fused to endorse.

title: SOYBEANS SHOW A GAIN OF 2 CENTS
description: Soybean prices rose about 2 cents a bushel yesterday for most delivery months, prices for corn held relatively steady and wheat showed rises of less than a cent a bushel.

title: A BOOK, ON CONGRESS RELEASED BY NADER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) Ralph Nader released today the first volume of what he promised would be an ency clopedic study of Congress. He called that body the Great American Default.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 3Judge U.S. Court to Get CampaignLaw Challenge
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 United States District Judge Barrington D. Parker said today that he would convene a spe cial threejudge Federal court to hear a constitutional chal lenge filed by the American Civil Liberties Union against the new Federal Election Campaign Act.

title: McGovern's SelfAnalysis
description: BOSTON, Oct 3In his latest swing through the East, George McGovern has been giving three reasons for his poor showing against President Nixon in the popularity polls.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Joseph Conrad reportedly is the authority for the statement that the schooner rig is the most beautiful afloat.

title: Guerrilla Attack Reported on a U.S. Base in Thailand, 2d in 24 Hours
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 3 (AP)Guerrillas attacked the United States air base at Udon in northeastern Thailand last night in the second assault on an American installation in this country in 24 hours, American officials reported to day.

title: Kerry Favored in Poll
description: BOSTON, Oct. 3 (AP)John F. Kerry, the antiwar Demo crat, holds a 2to1 lead over Paul W.Cronin, Republican, in the Fifth Congressional District race, according to a poll con ducted for The Boston Globe.

title: JOB SAFETY CURB EASED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The Senate voted 47 to 33 today to kill a Houseapproved pro vision exempting employers ofl 15 or fewer workers from the labor protective standards of the Occupational Safety and Health Act.

title: RALSTON NAMES 4 TO PACE RUMANIA
description: PARIS, Oct. 3 (AP)Dennis Ralston, captain of the United States Davis Cup team, named today, the four players who will compete in the International tennis tournament final against Rumania, Oct. 1315.

title: Military Bill Clears Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) A $2.3billion appropriations bill for military construction activities in the next fiscal year cleared the Senate today on an 87.0 vote. The bill now goes to a SenateHouse conference to draft a compromise with, the $2.2billion House version. The Administration had sought $2.6billion.

title: 2 Million Blacks Are Found Unregistered in the South
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 3 (AP)More than two and a half million blacks of voting age were un registered in 11 Southern states at the beginning of 1972, the Voter Education Project, Inc., said today.

title: Senate Again Refuses to Limit Debate on a Consumer Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  Managers of a bill to create an independent consumer protec tion agency failed today for the second time to limit Senate de bate on the measure.

title: Quadriplegic Loses Suit In Colgate Football Injury
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 3 State Supreme Court jury to night decided in favor of Col gate University in a $3million suit involving a football injury brought by a 25yearold quad riplegic from Hartsdale.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind., Oct. 3  Vice President Agnew abandoned his restrained reci tations today for a snappy, offthecuff debate with youth ful hecklers.

title: Economic Analysis
description: Anyone who has ever had a toothache disappear when he reached the dentist's office knows how easy it is for the dislike of a treatment to mask or color the perception of an ailment. The same phenomenon often occurs in national eco nomic policymaking: Policy de termines analysis, rather than vice versa. Is the United States dol lar still a sick cur rency  or is it already well on the way back to strength? The answers to that question are biased by the policy actions Governments favor or oppose.

title: House Committee Clears Securities Paperwork Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. (AP) A securities industry paper work reform bill, including eventual elimination of stock certificates, was approved by the House Commerce Commit tee today.

title: Gladys Schmitt, Novelist, Dies; Teacher at CarnegieMellon, 63
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3 Gladys Schmitt, a widelyread novelist whose David the King (1946) sold over 900,000 copies, died today of a heart attack at Shadyside Hospital in the same neighborhood where she was born 63 years ago.

title: Three Senators, Courtesy and $11Million
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  In a Senate given to mutual ac commodation when it comes to dispensing Federal largesse, the two Senators from Washington are finding themselves unex pectedly challenged, by Senator J. W. Fulbright in an attempt to get a $11.5million contribu tion for a fair in their home state.

title: About Pro Football
description: Ben Hawkins, the slack jawed wide receiver of the Philadelphia Eagles who lets his unattached white chin strap dangle, and Rich Hous ton, the unsung and unap preciated Giants' wide re ceiver from Newark, were running from the bottom to the top and out of about 30 million television receivers on Mon day night. They were what is called the man inmotion. But what good do they do? The conclusion here would be not much, one substantiated by a tactical expert with credits, Fran Tarkenton.

title: McGovern Rates Crime And Drugs as Top Issues
description: Senator George McGovern promised yesterday to make eradication of crime and drug abuse the No. 1 domestic pri ority of my administration.

title: Eight Basque Nationalists Arrested by Spanish Police
description: BILBAO, Spain, Oct. 3 (AP) The police said today that they had arrested eight Basque na tionalists, including Jose Luis Arteche Orejn, described as the political leader of the E.T.A. guerrilla organization in Viz caya and Alava provinces.

title: WAR RAINMAKING SUBJECT OF SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  In a largely unnoticed lawsuit filed here more than three weeks ago, a manufacturer of cloud seeding equipment charges that the United States is making rain in Indochina with a device he invented, in violation of his patent rights.

title: HOUSE PANEL BARS PRENOV. 7 INQUIRY INTO BUGGING CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The House Banking and Currency Committee rejected today, 20 to 15, a proposal to hold public hearings on certain aspects of the alleged bugging of the Dem ocratic party's Watergate head quarters.

title: Arms Accords Signed
description: President Nixon and the Soviet Foreign Minister, An drei A. Gromyko, signed documents yesterday in Washington putting into ef fect the two agreements limiting the use of nuclear arms that were reached in Moscow in May Details on Page 3.

title: Landlords Cautioned on Heat
description: The city's Rent and Housing Maintenance Commissioner, Nathan Leventhal, reminded landlord4 yesterday that they must maintain heat at certain levels now that chilly weather has arived. If the outdoor tem perature falls below 55, degrees Fahrenheit at any time from 6 A.M. to 10 P.M., the tempera ture indoors must be kept at 68. If the outside temperature falls below 40 after 10 P.M., the in door temperature must be at least 55.

title: AUBREY STARKE, 67, AUTHOR, HISTORIAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 Aubrey Harrison Starke, an au thor, historian and collector of Americana, died yesterday while on a visit to Cleveland. He was 67 years old.

title: RUNOFFS FOR HOUSE ARE HELD IN FLORIDA
description: MIAMI, Oct. 3 (UPI)Bill Sikes and William Lehman, former Dade County, school board chairman, won DeMo cratic Congressional nomina tions today.

title: Mark Set in August for Construction, 16% Above 1971
description: The construction industry set a new high in August, accord ing to the monthly report of the F. W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company. The Dodge index, which uses 1967 as its base of 100, reached 180, against 155 in July. The previ ous high was 167 in April.

title: Few Days Left to Register
description: New Yorkers who wish to vote in the Nov. 7 election may register at their local polling places tomorrow, Fri day, Saturday and next Tuesday. The polls will be open from 5:30 P.M. to 10:30 P.M. tomorrow, Friday and Tues day and from 7 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. on Saturday.

title: F111 IS KEPT OUT OF ACTION BRIEFLY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 American F111 tactical bomb ers were withheld from com bat missions for a few days, Pentagon sources said today, following the loss last Thurs day of one of the advanced planes during its first mission over North Vietnam.

title: Shriver Attempts to Allay Suspicions of the Regulars
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 3 Chasing a hastily drawn sched ule through northern industrial centers, Sargent Shriver is at tempting to break through a wall of suspicion that seem's to stand between Senator George McGovern, the Democratic Presidential candidate, and many traditionally Democratic voters.

title: GYPSYCAB OWNER TO IGNORE RULING
description: One of the largest nonmedal lion cab operators in the city said yesterday that he would ignore the new rulings by the Taxi and Limousine Commis sion and would not remove taxi meters from the 271 cars in his organization, the Black Pearl Car Service.

title: R. CLYDE ALLEN, 74, MARKETING EXPERT
description: NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 3 R. Clyde Allen, for many years an authority on product dis tribution and market research and since 1959 a director of the Bulova Watch Company, died at a nursing home today. He was 74 years old and lived on Butternut Lane.

title: Corona's Lawyer Says a Homosexual Committed the 25 Killings
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., Oct. 3 The defense in the trial of Juan Corona, the Mexican national accused of murdering 25 itiner ant farm workers, said today that the killings had been com mitted by a homosexual.

title: FIVE AREAS ADDED TO CITY PROGRAM
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the expansion of the city's neighborhood government program to two more commu nitiesthe Bay Ridge area of Brooklyn and the Queens area composed of Ridgewood, Glen dale, Liberty Park, Middle Vil lage and Maspeth. The program already is under way in six other areas of the city.

title: Carlton Captures No. 27 As Phils Rout Cubs, 111
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (UPI)  Steve Carlton Boasted to his 27th victory today, to tie one of Sandy Koufax's records as the Philadelphia Phillies backed him with six home runs, the most in the National League this season, to wallop the Chicago Cubs, 111.

title: House Panel Favors Tax Credit For Tuition in Private Schools
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  Legislation providing a special tax credit to parents and others who are paying tuition to pri vate, primary and secondary schools was approved today by the House. Ways and Means Committee.

title: LINDSAY CHARGES MACHINE RUE OF STATE BENCH
description: In some of the strongest guage he has used about the courts since becoming Mayor, John V. Lindsay; charged in an interview that the State Su preme Court was highly ineffi cient and strongly susceptible to corruption because it was controlled by political bosses.

title: CHINA, AT THE U.N., BACKS JUST WARS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3China told the General Assembly today that the people of the world must not be deluded by certain temporary and superficial phenomena of detente at the present time and develop a false sense of secu rity.

title: Bridge: Bill Keohane's Recent Death Dealt a Major Loss to Game
description: Organized bridge in New England suffered a major loss last month when Bill Keohane of Wellesley Hills, Mass., died at the age of 76. For many years he had had been the mainstay of tournament efforts in the Northeast, acting as chair man for a long string of suc cessful events of which the 1970 Summer Nationals in Boston was perhaps the most important.

title: Columbus Day Proclaimed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) President Nixon today pro claimed next Monday as Columbus Day and paid tribute to the navigator and explorer who helped to open a new chapter in history of mankind.

title: Trade and Aid Troubles of Small Nations, and Selfishness of Large, Are Emphasized in the U.N. Assembly
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3Economic difficulties have, become a growing pre occupation with the smaller countries.

title: MARCOS SEEKING OIL EXPLORATION
description: MANILA, Oct. 3President Ferdinand E. Marcos has em barked on a program of en couraging foreign investments, particularly in oil exploration and mining.

title: 9 Injured in L.I. Collision
description: NORTH BABYLON, L. I., Oct. 2A car and a nursery school bus collided here today, injur ing the bus driver and two of her charges and two women and four children in the car. The police charged the opera tor of the car, Andrew Galietta, 44 years old, of Lindenhurst, with driving while intoxicated. The accident occurred at Deer Park Avenue and August Road.

title: STOCKHOLDER SUIT ACCUSES GENESCO
description: A $35million classaction suit was filed yesterday against Genesco, Inc., by a stockholder, charging the producerretailer of apparel and footwear, 21 of its officers and directors and the accounting concern of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co. with deceptive business and account ing procedures to inflate the company's net worth.

title: CLEVELAND WORKERS RATIFY A. WAGE PACT
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 3 (UPI) Nine days of labor turmoil that curtailed vital city services came to an end tonight when members of the biggest union representing city workers rat ified a new wage agreement for the next 15 months.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: 2 Union City Aides Plead Not Guilty

title: People and Business
description: Horn & Hardartyes, Horn & Hardarthas hired a crea tive director, a position usu ally found in advertising agencies and, lately, in some manufacturing and retailing concerns heavily involved in sales promotion.

title: Gen. Haig Sees Thieu Again
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Oct. 4 (Reuters) Maj. Gen. Alexander M, Haig today held his second meeting with President Nguyen Van Thieu, an embassy spokesman reported. General Haig, who arrived Sunday, is deputy to Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's nationalsecurity ad viser.

title: U.S. Orders Moriarty To Pay $1.5Million
description: NEWARK, Oct. 3The Fed eral Government today or dered Joseph Moriarty, a for mer top figure in Hudson County gambling circles, to pay more than $1.5million in Federal income taxes.

title: Film Fete: Woes of Womanas Wednesday's Child
description: Janice gets pregnant and she wants to have the baby, but her parents tell her that they know best, and so Janice has an abortion instead. Janice likes a fellow, but he hates the Establish ment and drives around at night on a noisy motorbike, and so her parents decide: exit the boyfriend and enter Janiceinto a hospital for mental patients. Janice is a voluntary patient, and, think ing that means something, she walks out one day. But her parents, having done all they can, throw in the sponge and sign the papers that will forci bly commit Janice, I should imagine, for life.

title: SCHOOL PROTEST SNARES TRAFFIC
description: More than 100 parents from several West Side public schools blocked traffic on Co lumbus Avenue for 45 minutes yesterday morning in a demon stration aimed at obtaining more funds for education.

title: REPORTER LOSES HIGHCOURT PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  The United States Supreme Court today refused an appeal by a former. Newark Evening News reporter who Is sched uled to go to jail tomorrow for refusing to answer questions before an Essex County grand jury.

title: Tax Agency May Close Campaign Gift Loophole
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) The Internal Revenue Serv ice said today that it was considering closing tax loop holes whereby heavy con tributors to political cam paigns and both major na tional parties had avoided paying taxes on gifts of stock.

title: Mets Sweep Expos, 52 and 43, As Seaver Wins 21st in Opener
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 3Tom Seaver won his 21st game, 52, in the opener, but the Mets had to go 12 innings in the second game for 43 victory to sweep the Montreal Expos in their doubleheader tonight.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BURLINGTON, Mass., Oct. 3 (AP)Teachers voted today to accept a twostep pay increase, ending a twoweek old strike that had closed the town's pub lic schools. The new contract calls for a minimum salary of $7,900 effective Jan. 1, 1973, and a minimum of $8,150 ef fective Sept. 1, 1973, with pro portionate raises up the scale. The previous scale was from $7,550 to $11,300.

title: Railroad Deaths Decline
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) The Federal Railroad Admin istration said yesterday that 908 persons had been killed and 8,744 injured in railroad train accidents in the first six months of this year. In addition, 625 were killed and 1,698 injured in highway gradecrossing acci dents. All the totals were less than for the corresponding six months of 1971.

title: Casey Outlines Plan on Fuller Disclosure
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Wil liam J. Casey, Chairman of the Securities and Exchange Com mission, announced today two steps that the commission is taking to enable investors to get significant information more quickly about corpora tions in which they invest.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: City Center Reports A $1.3Million Deficit
description: The City Center of Music and Drama yesterday reported the first failure in its 29year history to cover operating casts by revenues and contributions a deficit of $1.3million being carried over from the year end ed last June 30.

title: U.S. Court Bids State Ease Rules on Voting Residency
description: A threejudge Federal Court in Brooklyn called on New York State yesterday to liber eralize its voter residency re quirements to enable many col lege students to vote from their campus addresses.

title: The Tudor City Parks
