description: In an unusual public hearing today, the City Planning Commission will offer a set of alternative options to the destruction of the Tudor City parks, two quiet green islands suspended above the compacted chaos of East 42d Street in the privately owned Tudor City development.

title: INCENTIVE URGED FOR CHILDREN'S TV
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3Tele vision people, citizens' groups and the Government ap proached agreement today that there should be some kind of incentive for broadcasters who present quality programing for children. But when faced with the task of agreeing on qual ity standards, the discussion promptly broke down.

title: Advertising: On Making Inroads
description: Lifestyle and Country Mu sic magazines appear to have little in common outside of the slick paper they're printed on. The former is aimed at the affluent with a $35,000 median income and the latter at the bluecollar type music lover with a me dian income of $12,000.

title: A PUTNAM HOSPITAL STARTING EXPANSION
description: CARMEL, N. Y., Oct. 3 (UPI) The Putnam Community Hos pital will begin construction on a $4.7million expansion this fall to increase its beds to 156 from 111. Construction will be gin next month, with comple tion expected in about 18 months.

title: West Side Story (Cont.)
description: When the death of Representative William F. Ryan two weeks ago deprived the Twentieth Congressional District of the able lawmaker it had just redesignated in a hard fought Democratic primary, this newspaper felt that the most appropriate way to choose a successor would be to run a special primary in this overwhelmingly Demo cratic district on Manhattan's West Side.

title: Earthquake Hits California
description: SAN JUAN BAUTISTA, Calif., Oct. 3 (UPI)An earthquake described by seismologists as strong rattled the San Juan Bautista area yesterday but there were no injuries and no reports of serious damage.

title: Ford Assails Protectionist Bill
description: Henry Ford 2d cautioned here yesterday that passage of protectionist legislation now before Congress, would help neither the American worker nor the consumer and would eliminate the American mul tinational corporation as a con tributor to economic growth.

title: jazz: Newest Big Band
description: New York's newest big Jazz band, a 20person en semble (including two wom en playing French horns) grandly billed as the New York Neophonic Orchestra, went through a trial run over the weekend at the Village Gate. The orchestra has been organized by Joel Kaye, a saxophonist who once played in Stan Kenton's band and was a student and close as sociate of the late Johnny Richards, a composer and an arranger who wrote for the Kenton band and led a big band of his own.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: 1972 N.Y.U. Law Grad with M.B.A. desired tax/SEC position 9295692Advt.

title: F.D.R. Jr. Is for McGovern
description: POUGHQUAG, N. Y.On Nov. 7, I will vote for George McGovern for President, Sargent Shriver for Vice President and for the entire Demo cratic ticket, even though some well known Democrats, whose political ca reers have been made possible through their affiliation and membership in the Democratic party, have decided they'd rather switch than fight.

title: Tokyo Dollar Sales Heavy On Yen Revaluation Fear
description: TOKYO, Oct. 3Unusually heavy selling of dollars contin ued today into the fourth consecutive day in the Tokyo foreignechange market, mainly on fears of another upward revaluation of the yen.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) Senator George McGovern will announce next Tuesday a true plan to end the Indochina war, Lawrence F. O'Brien, the Democratic Pres idential nominee's national campaign chairman, said to day.

title: Abortion Law Is Upheld
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Oct. 3 (UPI)The Missouri Supreme Court upheld today a state law that allows abortions only to save the life of the mother. In writing the majority opinion, Justice Robert T. Donnelly said the state court agreed with the United States Supreme Court, which had expressed its disap proval of the practice of put ting to death persons who had forefeited their right to live. We believe we must anticipate at least equal solicitude for the lives of innocents, he said.

title: AMEX AND QTC DECLINE, FURTHER
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthe counter market dipped yes terday for the second consecu tive session. Trading was dull.

title: Central Park Mall May Be Refurbished With Performance Pit and New Lights
description: The Central Park Mall may get a $300,000 refurbishing next year, with half the amount to be a sort of reverse birthday, pres ent from Bloomingdale's honor ing the department store's cur rent centennial anniversary.

title: Equity Financing
description: A nonregistered secondary offering of 237,500 shares of Mohasco Industries at $32 a share was announced yesterday by Morgan Stanley & Co. and Shields & Co. as managers. The company's stock closed at 32, down 7/8 on the New York Stock Ex change.

title: U.S. Court Bids State Ease Rules on Voting Residency
description: A threejudge Federal Court in Brooklyn called on New York State yesterday to lib eralize its voter residency re quirements to enable many col lege students to vote from their campus addresses.

title: JUDGES URGE DEFEAT ON JUDICIARY IN L.I.
description: The Administrative Board' of the state's Judicial Conference yesterday unanimously recom mended that voters reject. in November an amendment to the State Constitution that calls for a new Appellate Division Judi. cial Department in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: U.S. SEEKS CURBS ON LUMBER PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The Nixon Administration, acknowl edging that its wageprice con trols program had failed to check inflation in the lumber industry, announced today a multipronged drive against ris ing lumber prices, including an antitrust investigation.

title: Rubinstein Concert Delayed
description: The concert by Artur Rubin stein, which was to have opened the Recital Stage Series at Union High School on Saturday, will be held there instead on Jan. 13 at 8 P.M. The concert was canceled because of the pianist's illness. Tickets for the original date will be honored on Jan. 13, or if purchasers prefer, they may get a refund, accord ing to Recital Stage.

title: House Panel Favors Tax Credit For Tuition in Private Schools
ROCKLAND SPURNS COUNTY SALES TAX
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., Oct. 3 The Rockland County Legisla ture today turned down a pro posed 2 per cent county sales tax that would have reduced property taxes despite a pro posed increase in the 1973 operating budget.

title: 9 Chosen for Commission To Revise Charter for City
description: Governor Rockefeller's of fice yesterday announced the names of nine members ap pointed to a special bipartisan state commission to revise New York City's Charter.

title: Panel Upholds Long Hair
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 4 (AP) The Minneapolis Housing and Redevelopment Authority has been ordered to pay $100 in punitive damages to a summer intern whom it discharged in 1971 because of his shoulder length hair. In an order re leased yesterday, a committee of the Minneapolis Commission on Human Relations found that Jonathan Cain, 22 years old, had been discriminated against because of his sex. Many fe males in the agency wore their hair at the same or longer length the committee found.

title: Movement for Housing Reform Is Starting to Grow in Congress
description: News Analysis

title: Gambino Hospitalized Here In Very Serious Condition
description: Carlo Gambino, reputed to be the most powerful figure in or ganized crime, was reported in very serious condition yester day at Columbus Hospital, where he was admitted Satur day for treatment of a heart ailment.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 4  Senator George McGovern restated his plan for the proportional shar ing of jobs and power today, hinting that Polish, Italian and Greek Americans could expect high Government posts if he won, the Presidential election.

title: WELFARE REFORM KILLED IN SENATE; TEST PLAN VOTED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The hopelessly deadlocked Senate killed welfare reform legisla tion today, voting instead to test rival reform plans over the next few years.

title: AMIN REITERATES ASIANS' DEADLINE
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 4 President Idi Amin was quoted by the Uganda radio today as saying that his deadline for the expulsion of thousands of Asian aliens still stood and that he has no intention whatsoever of extending it.

title: An Increase in B52 Raids Around Saigon Is Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 5 (AP)  The United States command has re portedly ordered an increase in the number of B52 bomb ing raids in the Saigon re gion.

title: Sports Boycott Is Cited In Fight on Apartheid
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4The chairman of the United Nations Special Com mittee on Apartheid said to day that the most effective action against South Africa's discriminatory racial policies had been the worldwide sports boycott.

title: Foreign Ministers Meet
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Oct. 4 (Reuters)The Foreign Min isters of Tanzania and Uganda opened their longawaited peace talks here today on the crisis that arose over last month's unsuccessful invasion of Ugan da from Tanzania.

title: ALABAMA INMATES WIN HEALTH EDICT
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 4 A Federal judge, finding bar barous and shocking neglect of the medical needs of Ala bama prison inmates, ordered today a drastic reform of prison health care services.

title: Business Briefs
description: Merger announcements in the third quarter fell 7 per cent to 1,139 from 1,230 in the yearbefore period, W. Grimm & Co., specialists in mergers and acquisitions, announced yesterday. The last quarter represented the first downward trend in mergers since the fourth quarter of 1971.

title: Bridge: Defenders Who Grab Tricks Can Serve as Declarer's Ally
description: Declarers who like to make their contract, as most do, should pray for defenders who snatch their tricks at the earliest possible moment. Premature tricksnatching usually simplifies the declar er's problems, and would have done on the diagramed deal.

title: RED SOX, PATTIN DOWN TIGERS, 41
description: DETROIT, Oct. 4 (AP) Marty Pattin fired a fourhitter, and the Boston Red Sox de prived Detroit's Joe Coleman of a 20th victory today with a 41 triumph over the Tigers in the regularseason finale for both teams.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)Sales of United States Savings Bonds exceeded redemptions by $114million in September, the 24th straight month that the value of sales have topped the amount cashed in, the Treasury Department said today.

title: OBSERVER
description: Belcher spotted the average Ameri can voter at a drive in hamburger dis pensary. He had just eaten $1.37 worth of gastric distress.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) President Nixon returned to the White House tonight from Camp David, Md.

title: Kimbell Museum Opens in Ft. Worth
description: FORT WORTH, Oct. 4 The opening of the new Kimbell Art Museum, which this week has brought a large number of critics, col lectori, dealers and museum directors to a city that has held little professional inter est for them in the past, is an unusual event in two respects.

title: Chief of City Charter Revision Panel
description: Man in the News

title: Seymour Seeking Power to Oversee Local Draft Efforts
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 4 (AP)  United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr. called today for broad new power to step in and counter corruption where state or local officials fail to enforce the law.

title: Western Union Gets Permission to Shut 21 Offices in City
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission today approved Western Union's plan to con solidate 21 public telegraph offices in lower Manhattan into a single public message center.

title: Peru's Military, in 4th Year of Power, Presses Social Reforms
description: LIMA, Peru, Sept. 30It is one thing to try to remake a society with decrees issued and enforced by concentrated power, which the Peruvian mili tary Government has been do ing for the last four years.

title: Jailing for PriceFixing Urged by Antitrust Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4  Thomas E. Kauper, the new head of the Justice Depart ment's antitrust division, said today he believed that stiff jail sentences should be given to corporation officials who en gage in pricefixing.

title: Agnew Asserts Dakotan Uses Smear and Offers Philosophy of Defeat
description: RAPID CITY, S. D., Oct. 4 Vice President Agnew brought the Republican campaign to Senator George McGovern's home state today and accused him of using smear and in nuendo as the basic tools in his Presidential pursuit.

title: House Passes a Bill Aimed At Improving Auto Bumpers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) A bill to improve automobile bumpers calling or Federal standards intended to save American motorists billions of dollars in autorepair costs, was passed by the House today.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The socalled red tide in vasion that has seriously hurt Massachusettss shell fish Industry has also caused the yostponement of the opening of the states duck hunting season.

title: Jane Fonda Denied a Hall
description: OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 4, (AP)  The school board here voted last night to deny the use of a school auditorium to a group that had invited the actress Jane Fonda and a radical activist, Tom Hayden, here for an antiwar meeting Oct. 14.

title: EXREP. H. B. COFFEE OF NEBRASKA DEAD
description: OMAHA, Oct. 4Harry Buf fington Coffee, United States Representative from Nebraska from 1934 to 1942, died last night in a hospital here. He was 82 years old.

title: PRUDENTIAL STAFF
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America, which employs 8,000 people at its world headquarters in Newark, is planning to move 2,100 of them out of that city in 1974, company officials confirmed yesterday.

title: Soviet Malaysian Accord
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 4 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Soviet Union and Malaysia today signed an agreement on eco nomic and technical coopera tion and cultural exchanges, the visiting Malaysian Prime Minis ter, Abdul Razak, announced here.

title: Cultures of the World Depicted in Ounces, Cups and Spoonfuls
description: Good, cookbooks are rare. The best are more than collections of recipes. They are good anthropology. They set down, in clear language, specific ways in which cultures define themselves, deal with the natural world around them, and survive. Until the last 10 years there were almost no good, au thentic cookbooks in this sense. Few people bothered to attempt the very hard work of seriously translating the kitchen of one culture into the kitchen of another.

title: WELFARE REFORM KILLED IN SENATE; TEST PLAN VOTED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The hopelessly deadlocked Senate killed welfare reform legisla tion today, voting instead to test rival reform plans over the next few years.

title: Wider Link to Cancer Found in Asbestos Workers
description: A team of cancer researchers reported yesterday that asbes tos, already implicated as a cause of lung cancer in work ers repeatedly exposed to the material, might also have mused a threfold increase in the incidence of cancer of the stomach, colon and rectum in the same workers.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The New York and American Stock Exchange yesterday is sued reports on changes in share ownership of major stockholders, directors and of ficers of their listed companies. They included the following:

title: Nixon Environment Aide Ends 10Day Tour of Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 4Russell, E. Train, President Nixon's prin cipal aide on environmental problems, met today with Pres ident Nikolai V. Podgorny after a 10day tour of the Soviet Union that included an inspec tion of Lake Baikal, the sym bolic testing ground of Soviet ecological concerns.

title: Elias Feels Governments, Not Groups, Should Arrange P.O.W. Releases
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 4 Maj. Edward K. Elias of the Air Force, one of the three United States prisoners of war recently returned from North Vietnam, said today that he had 7a strong feeling that prison errelease negotiations should be conducted from government to government and not between a diverse bunch of individuals.

title: MRS. SIMON G. KRAMER
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 4  Mrs. Tirza Nelson Kramer, widow of Rabbi Simon Gad Kramer, for mer head of the New York Board of Rabbis, died today of a heart condition at the Jew ish Convalescent Hospital here. She was 58 years old.

title: 2 Blacks Returning to Alabama Take Office as Mayors
description: PRICHARD, Ala., Oct. 4  Southern politics reached an important new stage this week when two black native sons, both former national campaign aides of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy, assumed political control of two Ala bama cities.

title: Rockefeller Backs McKay Stand on Attica Data
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he was in full agreement with the view taken by the head of the Attica Com mission that the panel's records were confidential and should not be subpoenaed.

title: Park Ranger Finds An Oakland Boy, 4, Believed Kidnapped
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 4 Fouryearold Raymond Luce, who was apparently kidnapped near his home here Monday, by a man who ordered him to get into his car, was found aban doned but not seriously injured tonight by a park ranger in the Oakland hills.

title: MRS. ADAIR HICKMAN
description: BOSTON, Oct. 4Mrs. Gene vieve King Hickman, widow of Adair Hickman, who was a member of the Christian Science Board of Lectureship, died here yesterday at the age of 90, She lived at East End Avenue in New York City.

title: Columbia's East Asian Unit Gets a $650,000 Ford Grant
description: Columbia University an nounced yesterday, that its East Asian Institute had received a $650,000 Ford Foun dation grant to support gradu ate study and research in the modern and contemporary so cieties of China, Japan and Korea over the next three years.

title: ARABS' EXTREMISM ANALYZED BY JEWS
description: The killing of 11 members of the Israeli Olympic team at Munich and of civilians at the Tel Aviv airport are neither isolated nor surprising phe nomena but rather are part of an Arab history and tradi tion of extremism and violence which has contributed the word assassin to international lexi cons, according to a report made public yesterday by the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith.

title: National Chains Gain
description: Strong consumer buying in many areas of the country during September was re flected yesterday in reports of big sales advances by a number of the largest retail chains.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 George Meany, undeterred by an adverse court order, is plan ning to take disciplinary action against additional state labor federations that have defied his demand for neutrality in the Presidential campaign.

title: L.I. DRIVE TO URGE G.O.P. DEFECTIONS
description: What is described by its sponsors as grassroots cam paign to get registered Repub licans to work and vote for Sen ator George McGovern will be started tonight at a dinner in Oyster Bay, L. I.

title: $60Million Worth of Heroin Reported Seized in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 4 (UPI)Federal police confirmed tonight the capture of the larg est quantity of pure heroin ever seized in South America.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct 4A three judge Federal court today up held the controversial new wel fare eligibility requirements in volved in a state financed pro gram to aid the working poor.

title: Arab Store in Paris Bombed; Note Warns of Jewish Action
description: PARIS, Oct. 4 (UPI)An ex plosion badly damaged a Pales tinian bookstore today in what appeared to be Jewish violence against Arabs.

title: Notes on People
description: Duke Ellington plans to give his collection of original compositions and arrange ments to Yale University for its James Weldon Johnson Collection of Negro Arts and Letters. Announcement of the gift was made in New Haven by Willie Ruff, an associate professor of music. The El lington collection includes letters and manuscripts from black writers and composers of the 19th and 20th cen turies.

title: Indians to Drive to Capital
description: DENVER, Oct. 4 (UPI)  Indian leaders disclosed today plans for a series of automobile caravans to the nation's capital to remind elected officials of the common mistreatment and neglect of the American Indi an. Vernon Bellecourt, national codirector of the American Indian Movement, said that seven separate caravans would start this month from Seattle, San Francisco, Los Angeles and several Canadian cities, hoping to reach Washington on Nov. 1.

title: 2 Blacks Returning to Alabama Take Office as Mayors
description: PRICHARD, Ala., Oct. 4  Southern politics reached an important new stage this week when two black native sons, both former national campaign, aides of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, assumed political con trol of two Alabama cities.

title: Grant to Aid Queens Elderly
description: The Community Service So ciety of New York announced yesterday that it had received a $133,000 grant from the State Office of the Aging for a serv ice program to aid the elderly in Jamaica, Queens. The society said the Jamaica service pro gram would include health service, individual and group counseling, personal care and home service, information and referral services, recreational and educational programs, con sumer programs and safety pro grams.

title: SHRIVER ADVOCATES MINISTRY OF PEACE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4Ac cusing the Nixon Administra tion of an obsession with power, Sargent Shriver called today for a revitalized State Department that would func tion as a ministry of peace.

title: A's Vote 35 Full Shares
description: ANAHEIM, Oct. 4 (AP)The Oakland A's have voted to split their postseason earnings from the American League playoffs, or possibly the World Series, 152 ways. They voted 35 full shares and 17 partial shares or leash grants.

title: House Contest
description: NORWICH, Conn., Oct. 4 The Congressional race in eastern Connecticut pits a young, upandcorning Repub lican incumbent who has helped dramatize the extent of inter national narcotics traffic into this country against a former Kennedy appointee who re signed from the Johnson Admin istration over its Vietnam war policy.

title: MRS. NIXON FETED BY IRISH SOCIETY
description: Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, who was, born on the eve of St. Patrick's Day and whose father was the son of Irish immigrants, was awarded the gold medal of the American Irish Histori cal Society last night for her humanitarianism and service to her country.

title: Prudential to Move 2,100 in Newark To 3 Satellite Offices in jersey in '74
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America, which employs 8,000 people at its world headquarters in Newark, is planning to move 2,100 of them out of that city in 1974, company officials confirmed yesterday.

title: Endorsement of McGovern
description: To the Editor:

title: Greek Student, on Trial, Says He Was Tortured
description: ATHENS, Oct. 4A Greek student facing a military court on bomb charges, identified a prosecution witness today as the security officer who had personally totured me to ob tain a confession.

title: Stage: Oh Coward! Offers CabaretStyle Tribute to Sir Noel
description: Before Oh Coward! be gins, there is a curtain with a caricature of a double headed Sir Noel. Facing stage right, he is slightly sour. Fac ing left, he is faintly smiling. Sad or happyit is a calcu lated attitude, one measured step removed from the gau cherie around him. The pose is very Cowardy, and it sets the stylish tone of this production.

title: Business Briefs
description: The dollar retreated on a broad front yesterday in relation to leading foreign currencies, but traders attributed the weakness to temporary profit taking rather than a reversal of the dollar's recent strength. The volume of trading, both on European exchanges and in New York, was described as light.

title: Results Lag in City
description: September retail sales in New York City continued at disappointing level for the sec ond consecutive month despite the fact that several big stores stayed open on Labor Day for the first time. The city's retail sales gain also trailed that of other major cities.

title: Gunman in a French Store Kills Four and Wounds Six
description: ANGOULEME, France, Oct. 4 (Reuter)  A 32yearold watchmaker with a history of mental illness today drew a rifle from under his jacket and fired shots around a depart ment store here, killing four people and wounding six.

title: SENATE PLAN BARS CREDITS IF SOVIET RETAINS EXIT FEES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Senate served notice today that it would block passage of a SovietAmerican trade agree ment now reportedly near com pletion unless Moscow re scinded heavy eicit visa fees lev ied on Jews and others seeking to emigrate.

title: Advertising: Marketing Ecology
description: After all of the heat the industry has been taking for air and water pollution, the last thing you'd think a paper company would want to do is stimulate the establishment of environmentalist groups.

title: Endorsement of McGovern
description: To the Editor:

title: BEISSINGER GOAL: BACK IN HARNESS
description: YONKERS, Oct. 4Howard Beissinger, the 49yearold Ham ilton (Ohio) rancher and har ness horseman who has been confined to Good Samaritan Hospital here since suffering a mild heart attack Sept. 19, has hopes of being allowed to leave the hospital Saturday morning to watch Billy Haughton train Speedy Crown four separate miles at Liberty Bell Park in Philadelphia.

title: Personalities: A Columbia Aide
description: Emette Bryant, who par layed his finesse and smart play into an eightyear career in the National Basketball Association with New Yoric, Boston and Buffalo, was named yesterday an assistant coach at Columbia Univer sity. Jack Rohan, the var sity coach, said, Em is the type of player who was ad mired not only for his phys ical skills, but also for his attitude. We feel he will be able to help our boys in both areas.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: WHAT DOES QUALITY LIFE INSURANCE COST? $100.000 Yearly Renewable & Convertible Term, annual premium, age 40, $383.00. Full details, rates your age, call or have your agent call North Atlantic Life, Jericho. N. Y. (516) 6056900.ADVT.

title: Bonn Aide Confers With Laird
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (Reu ters)West German Defense Minister, Georg Leber, con ferred today with Secretary of Defense, Melvin Laird and other military officials.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
The President Fumbles the Ball
description: Sports of The Times

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 4Gover nor Cahill, the chairman of President Nixon's reelection campaign in New Jersey, said today that Senator George McGovern had indulged in the lowest form of cam paigning in charging the Nixon Administration with corruption.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Repeater Squad Cuts Crime

title: 4DAY BOAT SHOW OPENS TOMORROW
description: ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Oct. 4With two shows down and three to go, the first International InWater Boat Show geared Itself yesterday for a fourday run, starting Friday.

title: Bonn Bans 2 Palestinian Organizations
description: BONN, Oct. 4West Ger many announced today that, it had banned two Palestinian or ganizations because they had threatened Violence here.

title: London Seeking to End School Boycott
description: LONDON, Oct. 4  School busing, angry parents and dis gruntled teachers have Involved London's education system in a series of turbulent disputes.

title: FIRST SUBPOENAS ISSUED ON PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Price Commission disclosed today that it had used its sub poena power for the first time.

title: Tigers Living It Up in Old Folks' Home
description: DETROIT, Oct. 4While sobering up today from the euphoria and the champagne that engulfed them the night before, the Detroit Tigers en joyed exceptional status in the American League's East ern Division: They were the first team other than the oncefeared Baltimore Orioles to win the Eastern cham pionship.

title: Credit Markets
description: Underwriters of taxexempts, bidding cautiously on $156mil lion of New York State bonds, raised yields substantially yes terday and attracted strong de mand from a broad range of institutional and individual in vestors.

title: U.S. URGED TO CURB USE OF RESOURCES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)  A scientific panel under government contract urged to day that the United States be gin limiting its population and its consumption of resources.

title: Tuesday Night Fight
description: Tokyo Koichi Wajima, 150 pounds, Japan, knocked out Matt Donovan, 151 Trinidad, 3 rounds; Wajima retained world Junior mid dleweight title.

title: Acquisitions Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commis sion issued proposed com plaints today charging ARA Services, Inc., the nation's largest vending company, with anticompetitive practices in its acquisition of 98 vending com antes and 12 magazine and aperback distributors.

title: BOREK, WRIGHT TIE FOR LEAD ON 145'S
description: INWOOD, L. I., Oct. 4Gene Borek scored a 70, the tourna ment's low round, to share the 36hole lead today at 145 with Jimmy Wright in the Metropol itan Professional Golfers' Asso ciation championship.

title: GOVERNOR, MAYOR AGREE TO STRIVE FOR COURT REFORM
description: Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay agreed yester day to work on court reform through the development of program to submit to the Leg islature next year.

title: Johnson One Up on Jim Brown in N.F.L. Record Book
description: Football statistics, usually the driest part of what can be a dry subject anyhow, took a little life for the New York Giants yesterday. They dis covered that Ron Johnson on Monday night had set a Na tional Football League record no one had ever heard of, and they found that their upcoming opponent, New Orleans, had compiled some rather remark able numbers of another sort.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TEANECK, N. J., Oct. 4The message being carried to college campuses by Bill Russell at $1,500 a throw as basic as the fast break he used to trigger on the basket ball court for the world champion Boston Celtics. It consists of two pieces of advice: (1) think, (2) participate.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: CLARK BRYSON, 77, OF PEASE & ELLIMAN
description: ORRS ISLAND, Me., Oct. 4 Clark Bryson, retired vice presi dent and treasurer of the real estate firm of Pease & Elliman, Inc, of New York and a water color artist, died yesterday in Parkview Hospital, Brunswick. He was 77 years old.

title: Vote Yes
description: At least one spot on the November ballot should pose no problem for New York voters. Anyone who wants the public waterways to be made cleaner and the air he breathes to be rendered less toxic should have no qualms about voting Yes on the bond issue for environ mental improvements. The money to be raised would be earmarked to build urgently needed sewage treatment facilities and help solve the solid waste problem.

title: KENNECOTT ACTS ON CHILE COPPER
description: The Kennecott Copper Com pany took its first action yes terday to prevent Chile from selling copper from the com pany's expropriated mines lo cated in that country.

title: U.S. and Soviet Will Lead A 12 Nation Think Tank
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Led by the United States and the Soviet Union, scientific academies of a dozen nations today set up a joint think tank to seek solutions to problems created by the in creasing industrialization of societies.

title: Lindsay Said to Consider Race In '73 on BeattheBosses Issue
description: Mayor Lindsay is thinking of running for reelection on a beat  the  bosses platform, sources close to him said yes terday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BOSTON, Oct. 4As Sen ator George McGovern's mo torcade crawled along Wash ington Street yesterday to ward the biggest rally crowd so far in his campaign, the narrow passage was sudden ly blocked by slow traffic ahead and by spectators spilling over from the side walks.

title: Endorsement of McGovern
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR PERU INDIANS, CHANGE IS SLOW
description: CHACAPALPA, Peru, Sept. 25 The heavy thumps made by men pounding dirt into build ing blocks for a wall did not carry far in the thin, high mountain air. The men worked in silence, breathing hard around lumps of halfchewed coca leaves bulging in their cheeks.

title: Chess:
description: Twentyyearold Henrique Mecking of Brazil won the recent South American Zonal Tournament scoring 17 points out of 20. He thus qualified for the Internation al Tournament to be held next year, the next step in the eliminations that lead eventually to the world championship.

title: Jordanian, in U. N., Says Israel is Showing Internal Weakness
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4  The Foreign Minister of Jordan told the General As sembly today that there were signs of internal weakness in Israel that offered hope for peace in the Middle East.

title: HEALTH VIOLATIONS LAID TO FOOD SHOPS
description: The Health Department yes terday announced the names of 11 restaurants and other food establishments charged with violations of the city's health code.

title: Martin, Kasko, Quilici Retained as Managers
description: Four American League man agers received new contracts as the regular baseball season closed yesterday, including Billy Martin of the Detroit Tigers and Eddie Kasko of the Boston Red Sox, who fought each other for the Eastern championship.

title: Cosmos 522 Launched
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 4The So viet Union marked the 15th an niversary of the first sputnik today by launching the 522d in its Cosmos series of unmanned satellites.

title: IN THE NATION
description: In its last term, the United States Supreme Court held in the Earl Cald well case that a newspaper reporter may not refuse to appear before a grand jury to answer questions about the sources of his information.

title: Butz Now Doubts Advisability Of Aide's Role in Soviet Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Agri culture Secretary Earl L. Butz said today that he would prob ably have advised a former assistant not to participate in grain negotiations with the Soviet Union last spring if he had known of the assistant's plans to join a private com pany that ultimately sold wheat to the Russians.

title: N.U.D. Suspects Corruption In 10 Cities, Romney Says
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) George Romney, the Secretary of Housing and Urban. Develop ment said today that Federal grand juries were investigating possible criminal activity in the housing programs in 10 of the nation's major cities.

title: Baron von Guttenberg, 51, Christian Socialist Leader
description: GUTTENBERG, West Ger many, Oct. 4 (UPI)Baron Karl Theodor von and zu Gutten berg, a founder of the Christian Socialist Union in 1946 and an outspoken critic of Chancellor Willy Brandt's Eastern policy, died today. He was 51 years old.

title: Endorsement of McGovern
description: To the Editor:

title: LONBORG 3HITTER TOPS YANKS, 1 TO 0
description: The Yankees closed out their 1972 American League season last night by losing, 10, to the Milwaukee Brewers. The Yankee bats, which combined with Sparky Lyle for a run at the American League East Division championship remained silent, as they had throughout the three straight losses to the Brewers.

title: Dance: Program Sharing
description: Variety is what we are certainly getting in the City Center's American Dance Marathon at the ANTA Thea ter. Tuesday night, the lyri cism of Yuriko and the dra matic strength of Jose Limon provided the contrast for the second program in the six week moderndance series that has just opened.

title: Jets' Little Is a Big Devil on Defense
description: If he is at all related to Larry Little, the Miami Dol phins guard, John Little, de fensive tackle of the New York Jets, knows nothing about it.

title: Schooner Race Marks the Opening of InWater Boat, Show at Highlands
description: ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N. J., Oct. 4Six schooners started and five finished an 11mile race today from the VerrazanoN arrows Bridge to Atlantic Highlands to mark the opening of the Interna tional InWater Boat Show. Agamemnon, a 40foot gaff rigged vessel owned by Mi chael Daniels of the Bahamas, was first, both on elapsed and corrected time, and won the Atlantic Cup. Rebel, a threemaster owned by Dean A. Worcester of Crownsville, Md., was the first staysail schooner across the finish line. The South Street Sea port Museum's Pioneer was second in the staysail class, while A.E. McCarthy's Pis ces finished second among gaff  rigged boats. One schooner, Gerry B., went aground on a shoal off Hoff man Island, near Staten Is land, and withdrew.

title: FIRST SUBPOENAS ISSUED ON PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Price Commission disclosed today that it had used its sub poena power for the first time.

title: Congress Overrides Veto, Raises Rail Pensions 20%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Congress today overrode Presi dent Nikon's veto of a bill to increase railroad retirement benefits by 20 per cent. The White House had announced the veto only five hours be fore the House acted.

title: Newspaper Strike Backed
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 4 (UPI) Members of Local 1 of the Cleveland Newspaper Guild voted yesterday to authorize a strike against The Cleveland Plain Dealer if a new contract is not reached this week. The Guild and the Cleveland Pub lishers Association scheduled bargaining meetings today and Friday. We called for the strike vote because the negotia tions are at an impasse and we have been working without a contract since June 1, a Guild spokesman said.

title: Marcos Slackens Censorship, But Only for Foreign Newsmen
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 4The martiallaw regime of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines has somewhat loos ened its censorship of news dispatches sent abroad but con tinues to exercise stringent con trol over public information and comment inside the country.

title: PERON PROGRAM ASKS STATERUN ECONOMY
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 4 (Reuters)  Former President Juan Perlin today urged Argen tina's military rulers to free the nation from what he describes as the dictates of hemisphere imperialism and to veer to ward a staterun and national iststyle economy.

title: A's and Pirates Favored
description: STATELINE, Nev., (UPI) The Harrah's Tahoe race book today named the Oakland A's and Pittsburgh Pirates 65 fav orites towin their playoff con tests against Detroit and Cin cinnati.

title: Jewish Congress Supports Early Move to Aid Elderly
description: Congress was called upon yesterday by the American Jewish. Congress to enact emer gency legislation that would protect the nation's elderly by requiring state officials to dis regard the new Social Security increase in computing eligibil ity for other federally funded health and welfare benefits.

title: British Labor's Fantasy
description: When the British Labor party is out of power, its annual conference  probably the most undemocratic assembly of its kind in the Westoften becomes an emo tional outburst of unreality and irresponsibility. It is useful to keep this thought in mind in scanning the havoc wrought at Blackpool this week by a bizarre com bination of union bosses, fellow travelers, Little England ers, Commonwealth Firsters and sordid opportunists.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: CAMDEN, Oct. 4 (UPI)  A 26yearold mother of seven, whose children were once taken from her by the State Children's Bureau, was held without bail today on charges she tortured one daughter to death and beat another.

title: NEWBURGH DISORDER QUELLED BY POLICE
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., Thurs day, Oct. 5A fourblock area here was sealed off by the po lice last night after bands of youths roamed through the vi cinity, tossing rocks and bot tles and smashing windows, the police reported. There were a few minor injuries reported.

title: Cornell Professor Report Meeting 7 P.O.W.'S in Hanoi
description: A professor of government at Cornell University, just back from a trip to Hanoi, reported yesterday that he had met with seven captured American pilots and that all had told him they Were in good health.

title: Coin, Once in Orbit, Sells for $15,000
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 4 (AP)A 179yearold United States coin, which was secreted on board the Gemini 7 spacecraft in 1965, was sold recently for $15,000, and the man who sold it said it could now be worth as much as $100,000.

title: People and Business
description: Glenn W. Turner was sen tenced yesterday to 150 days in jail for contempt of court by a Florida judge after 600 banner  waving women showed up at a Clearwater, Fla., courthouse to protest his trial. The 38yearold sharecropper's son, who par layed scopes of pyramidsales companies into a multimil liondollar operation, was or dered booked into the Pinel las County jail.

title: Senate RollCall Vote To Shelve Relief Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)Following is the roll call vote by which the Sen ate adopted today an amend ment by Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Dela ware, to shelve welfare re form in favor of testing rival proposals:

title: Planning Unit Approves Forest Hills Compromise
description: With expressions of reluc tance, the City Planning Com mission voted 4 to 2 yester day to accept the Forest Hills public housing compromise that would halve the controversial project's scope to three 12 story buildings.

title: G.I.'s Held in Marijuana Case
description: PALMDALE, Calif., Oct. 4 (Reuters)The Army Criminal Investigation Division has dis closed that 19 enlisted men were arrested at a Nike Hercu les antimissile site near here for allege'd smoking and possession of marijuana.

title: Ballet: Joffrey Opens at City Center
description: The City Center Joffrey Ballet waltzed expansively into its fall season at the New York City Center last night to music by the family Strauss and a little rock. It proved a breezy and cheer ful homecoming.

title: NYQUIST TO WEIGH THE FUENTES CASE
description: The counsel to the State Edu cation Department said yester day that the State Ethication Commissioner, Ewald B. Ny quist would act on a request; which is expected to be sub mitted shortly, that he look into Luis Fuentes's fitness to hold a state certificate as a school superintendent.

title: F.D.A. and Bay State Official Split Over Safety of Shellfish
description: BOSTON, Oct. 4 (UPI)The Federal Food and Drug Ad ministration today declared an end to the poisonous red tide emergency that forced a ban on most shellfish harvesting in Maine, New Hampshire and Massachusetts.

title: Nytronics Bid Extended
description: Nytronics, Inc., an electronics concern offering to exchange its stock for present debt, said yesterday that a total of $5.6 million in debt had been tend ered for exchange. Bernard Goldsmith, chairman, said the total included $312,000 from trade creditors, with the bal ance in notes, bonds and de bentures. He said the offer had been extended to Oct. 31.

title: U.S. and Soviet Will Lead A 12Nation Think Tank
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Led by the United States and the Soviet Union, scientific academies of a dozen nations today set up a joint think tank to seek solutions to problems created by the in creasing industrialization of societies.

title: Renata Scotto Sings a Polished Lucia
description: Given a competent mad woman, Lucia di Lammer moor is the nearest thing opera knows to a surefire audiencepleaser. When there are important singers on hand and they are singing well, as they were at the first Lucia of the Metropol itan Opera's season Tuesday night, a certain irreducible minimum or excitement can be anticipated.

title: Bartender Convicted in Slaying Of Witness in Crime Inquiry
description: Robert Grimaldi was found guilty of murder last night in the death of Conrad Greaves, a witness in a rackets inquiry, who was shot to death outside his nightclub lest. March 30.

title: I.C.C. ALLOWS RISE IN FREIGHT RATES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)  The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today its approval of an increase in some interstate freight rates for the nation's railroads, but less than that requested by the car riers.

title: U.S. CHESS TEAM DRAWS 3 GAMES
description: SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 4 The United States team drew three games against Argentina in the eighth round of the chess Olympics here, and is expected to win the fourth game, be tween Pal Benko and Jaime Emma, which was adjourned. Benko is two pawns ahead. The game is to be played off this morning. A victory by Benko would give the American team the match, 21.

title: AMATEUR JUMP TITLE TO SPACE CITATION
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5 Fox Brook Farm's Space Cita tion won only one class but piled up three thirdplace rib bons and captured the amateur owner jumper championship to day at the Philadelphia Indoor Horse Show at the Spectrum.

title: MATLACK WINS 15TH AS METS TOP EXPOS
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 4  The Mete ended an otherwise dis appointing season on a success ful note tonight when Jon Mat lack and Tug McGraw com bined to beat the Montreal Expos, 31, It was the Mets' 83d triumph and it marked the third straight year they fin ished with that number of vic tories. This year's schedule for the Mets was cut short by six games because of the players' strike in April.

title: ' Night of Lepus' Shows Peter Rabbit's Other Side
description: It is a plague of giant man-killing bunny rabbits that Dr. Bennett has to deal with. Roy Bennett (Stuart Whitman) and his lovely wife, Gerry (Janet Leigh), and especially his little daughter Amanda (Melanie Fullerton), have only themselves to blame, having messed around with nature and produced a horrible hungry mutation that is breeding beyond all sense of decency, threatening to overrun Arizona and filling up the screen in William Claxton's "Night of the Lepus," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters.The plan had been to discourage rabbits, not encourage them. But it backfired somehow. And finally it takes the police, the Army, the railroad and the power company (but not the Air Force or the Marines) to vanquish the big-eared monsters who neigh like horses, stampede like cattle, roar like lions and breathe very heavilyespecially when they are going to do something awful, like chew up the keeper of the general store, so as to get at the lettuce in the back room.Several friends have asked how you can make a rabbit seem scary, and I must confess that "Night of the Lepus" in no way answers their question. It doesn't even reasonably try.Except for a few tired clichs of monsterdom (rabbits rearing up on their hind legs, blood dripping from their two front teeth), the film relies almost entirely on slow-motion shots of ordinary rabbits running through miniaturized settings or in front of scaled-down back projections.It is this technical laziness as much as the stupid story or the dumb direction that leaves the film in limbo and places it in neither one camp nor the other  neither with "Attack of the 50-Foot Woman" nor with Flopsy, Mopsy and Cottontail.

title: Let Them Eat Cake
description: Marie Antoinette seems to have taken over as dictator of policy on Capitol Hill. The 92d Congress, rushing toward adjournment, is busily slamming doors on the needs of the nation's poorest citizens, both those on welfare and those working for sweatshop wages.

title: City Charges G.M. With Bus Monopoly
description: New York City charged in Federal Court here yesterday that the General Motors Cor portation had illegally monopo lized the manufacture and sale of buses for local public trans portation.

title: Sutton Challenges F.B.I. Arrest Of Democrat Over Registration
description: Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan has ques tioned the motives of the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation in arresting Esta Washington, a clerk at the City Board of Elec tions and a Democratic co leader in Harlem with Hulan E. Jack on a charge of con spiracy to violate voter regis tration laws.

title: Justices' Response to Lindsay's Views on Courts
description: Following is a statement by Presiding Justices Harold A. Stevens and Samuel Rabin of the Appellate Divisions, First and Second Depart ments, respectively, in re sponse to statements made about courts by Mayor Lind say in an interview published in The New York Times yes terday:

title: House Contest
description: UNION TOWNSHIP, N. J., Oct. 4Union County's seat in the House of Representa tives is up for grabs amid a host of factors that are blur ring party allegiance to such an extent that oldtime po litical watchers in this coun ty refuse to predict an out come.

title: Endorsement of McGovern
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Briefs
description: The International Business Machines Corporation in troduced yesterday a new computer in its System 370 line. The new data processing machine, the Model 125, will be the lowestcosting device in the System 370 line.

title: Stanton Hits Proposed Curb on TV Satellite Use
description: Dr. Frank Stanton, vice chair man of the Columbia Broad casting System, Inc., last night called on the State Department to take a firm stand against what he described as a devel oping international campaign to censor satellite television broadcasts of the future.

title: AntiOlympic Drive Pressed
description: DENVER, Oct. 4 (UPI)An organization opposed to holding the 1976 Winter Olympics in Colorado announced yesterday plans for a campaign to get out the vote Nov. 7 to halt further tax expenditures for the games. Officials of citizens for Colorado's future said a poll showed that a majority of per sons were opposed to the games but were uncertain about how to vote on the ques tion on the general election ballot.

title: IVAN GIVEN, 70, DEAD; EDITOR OF COAL AGE
description: Ivan A. Given, chief editor of Coal Age magazine for 23 years until his retirement in 1967, died of a heart attack Monday at Sun City, Ariz., where he lived for the last two years. He was 70 years old and a former resident of Massape qua, L. I.

title: Newark Reporter Goes to Jail To Serve Contempt Sentence
description: NEWARK, Oct. 4Peter J. Bridge, a reporter who worked for the defunct Evening News here, surrendered this morning to begin serving an indetermi nate sentence for contempt of court for his refusal to answer five questions before an Essex County grand jury investigat ing possible corruption in the Newark Housing Authority.

title: One Wishbone Seems Sure to Snap This Weekend
description: Eastern College Football

title: At Liberals' Dinner, He Intensifies Criticism Backs Mrs. Abzug
description: Intensifying his attack on the Nixon Administration as cor rupt, Senator George McGov ern said last night that not in my memory has an adminis tration handled the truth more cynically than has this admin istration.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BOSTON, Oct. 4 (AP)The Massachusetts State Labor Council overwhelmingly ap proved today a resolution calling for the defeat of Presi dent Nixon, and in an informal show of hands delegates to the state convention expressed strong support for the candi dacy of Senator George McGov ern.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 President Nixon met today with advisers at Camp David to discuss plans for the final month of the campaign.

title: COUNCIL UNIT ACTS TO END NEPOTISM
description: Members of the City Coun cil committee that is inves tigating charges of Civil Serv ices abuses in the Lindsay ad ministration have introduced legislation aimed at curbing the appointment of city officials' relatives to provisional posts.

description: The New York phase of the current negotiations between five Persian Gulf oil producing countries and the international oil companies over the issue of participation in existing con cessions is expected to end to day.

title: Lindsay Signs Noise. Code; Acts to Allow Night Work
description: The city's new noise code, which seeks to muffle most major noise sources, was signed into law yesterday, and Mayor Lindsay announced immediate ly that he would submit an amendment next week to permit emergency night con struction work.

description: Some of the best juvenile colts on the continent came from such distant posts as Ar lington Park, Detroit, Calder Park, in Florida and Woodbine in Canada yesterday to take part in the 50th running of the Cowdin Stakes at Belmont Park.

description: State Supreme Court Justice Bernard S. Meyer received la bor backing yesterday, in his campaign for election to the State Court of Appeals.

title: Airport Grants Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) The Federal Aviation Admin istration said today that it had approved grants totaling $110, 000 for preparation of master plans at four airports. They in cluded Greater Rockford, Ill., airport, $40,000; Nantucket Memorial, Nantucket Island, Mass., $29,000; Torrance, Calif., Municipal, $27,000; and Mont rose County, Colo., $14,000.

title: U.S. Bans Pork Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) The Agriculture Department announced today that imports of live pigs and uncooked pork, mostly from Mexico, had been banned in an effort to curb hog cholera. The ban was an nounced in a routine news re lease two days after it became effective.

title: Congress Votes $24Billion Bill to End Water Pollution by 1985
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Senate, by a vote of 74 to 0, gave final Congressional ap proval tonight to a farreach ing bill designed to eliminate over the next decade the pol lution of the nation's water ways. The House adopted the measure earlier today.

title: Rangers Tie Bruins at 33 On Tkaczuk's Late Goal
description: BOSTON, Oct. 4 (AP)Walt Tkaczuk's powerplay goal with 4 minutes 55 seconds remain ing lifted the New York Rang ers to a 33 tie with the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League exhibition tonight.

title: LetterBomb in Rome
description: ROME, Oct, 4The police announced tonight that a letter bomb had been delivered today to the local office of the United Hias Service, a worldwide Jew ish immigration organization, and had been made harmless by explosives experts. The en velope, mailed from Malaysia, contained inscriptions in Eng lish and Arabic that said Black September, which is the name of an Arab guerrilla group.

title: Israelis Disclaim Knowledge
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 9Israeli officials disclaimed knowledge today of the socalled Masada organization. The officials said privately that it was not an arm of the Israeli security Es tablishment. There was no offi cial comment on the blast in Paris.

title: An Increase in B52 Raids Around Saigon Is Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 5 (AP)  The United States command has re portedly ordered an increase in the number of B52 bomb ing raids in the Saigon re gion.

title: A's Vote 35 Full Shares
description: ANAHEIM, Oct. 4 (AP)The Oakland A's have voted to split their postseason earnings from the American League playoffs, or possibly the World Series, 52 ways. They voted 35 full shares and 17 partial shares or cash grants.

title: Making Food Cans the Same in St. Paul and So Paulo
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 Ten years ago tomorrow rep resentatives of 43 nations meeting in Geneva proposed creation of an international code of food standards so a consumer in New York could regard a can of corn as much the same whether it were packed in St. Paul, Minn., So Paulo, Brazil, or San Pablo, the Philippines.

title: The Decade of Short Cuts
description: NEW HAVENIt is said that there is a new quiet settling upon the colleges and universities. Maybe, but I do not think it runs very deep.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 4 (PI)Rider College officials agreed today to allow distributors of ready made term papers to advertise in the college newspaperwith one concession, The advertise ment must carry the warning that any student who turns in a used term paper will be thrown out of school.

title: City Seeks a Study For a New Hospital In Brooklyn Area

title: INSTITUTION RULE CRITICIZED BY U.S.

title: TV: Review
description: Premiere week continues on the Public Broadcasting Service with the debut to night, on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock, of a new series en titled International Per formance, another contribu tion to publicTV's enlarged accent on Culture. Or per haps in this case that should read Rultur.

title: Earl Scruggs Strums In
description: Earl Scruggs, the five stringbanjo virtuoso, is heard so rarely in New York that you would think his ap pearance here would bring the, banjo enthusiasts of the metropolitan area flocking to hear him. But he opened a fiveday engagement at the Village Gate on Tuesday night under such a cover of promotional silence that only a handful of listeners was rattling around in that cavernous room to greet him at his first show. And a scheduled second show that night was canceled for lack of audience.

title: HAIG HEADS HOME AFTER SEEING THIEU
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 4Maj. Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., deputy to Henry A. Kissin ger, met with President Nguyen Van Thieu and top members of his Cabinet for three hours and 40 minutes this morning.

title: Flood Damage Reported For Brazil's Coffee Crop
description: CURITIBA, Brazil, Oct. 4 (AP) At least 30 per cent of this season's coffee crop in the southern State of Parana may have been damaged by floods that followed recent intense rainstorms, according to re ports today.

title: Market Place: Orderly Market System Pressed
description: It's happening, it seems, every week. Some bad news gets in the newspaper about a company's prospects, and the next day a drama unfolds in Wall Street that spells losses for shareholdersbig losses.

title: Congress Overrides Veto, Raises Rail Pensions 20%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Congress today overrode Presi dent Nixon's veto of a bill to increase railroad retirement benefits by 20 per cent. The White House had announced the veto only five hours be fore the House acted.

title: Outsiders and Insiders
description: Following the example of the New York Stock Ex change, the American Stock Exchange is restructuring its board of governors to include ten representatives the public and ten representatives of the securities indus try, with its own chief executive as the board's full time, salaried chairman.

title: Books of The Times
description: Mr. Trevanian, is not only a better writer than most of those who turn out suspense novels, he hag also made a computerlike analysis of the various elements readers look for in such novels and included one of each. His hero, for example, is a master piece of conflicting qualitiessomething for everybodybut he is still within the limits of the willing suspension of dis belief. Jonathan Hemlock is an immensely popular professor of art history; an ardent collector of modern paintings, illicitly ac quired; a man who can kill without com punction, not out of patriotism, but simply to support his expensive lifestyle. Yet, with all this he is also capable of true friendship and loyalty. In the best James Bond tradition, he is an irresistible seducer of womenbut with a difference. His sexual virtuosity is appealingly penalized by the fact that he feels almost nothing in bed, except for a negative athletic release.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 4Officials of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People are trying to revive a stalled housing rehabilitation project before some 40 families who have already moved in face a winter without heat.

description: Mayor Lindsay is thinking of running for reelection on beat  the  bosses platform, Entrees close to him said yes terday.

title: Saga of a Homecoming:Mekas Brothers View Lithuanian Journey
description: In his open-ended, autobiographical film, "Diaries, Notebooks and Sketches," Jonas Mekas says at one point: "They tell me that I should always be searching, but I celebrate what I see." Although the photographed diaries are indeed a celebrationof friends, of enemies, of fine meals eaten, of beautiful weather enjoyed, of streets walked, downthey also document a search for an unhackneyed use of the autobiographical motion-picture camera as an instrument of self-understanding. "Diaries" is the "War and Peace" of a type of home movie that is more familiar when it's called "Daddy's New Car," "Susan's Wedding" or "Our Summer Vacation, 1971."Mr. Mekas's newest film, "Reminiscences of a Journey to Lithuania," is the 88-minute record of the trip he took last summer with his younger brother, Adolfas, and Adolfas's wife, Pola Chapelle, to the home in Lithuania the Mekases left during World War II, thinking they were going to the University of Vienna, although, instead, they landed in a slave-labor camp outside Hamburg. It was shown last night at the New York Film Festival on a program with "Going Home," Adolfas Mekas's 61-minute record of the same trip.The program makes for an evening rather more brimful of Mekases than one might ordinarily seek out, yet it's also successively moving, indulgent, beautiful, poetic, banal, repetitious and bravely, heedlessly personal. Although "Reminiscences" can stand by itself well enough, it is a continuation of the "Diaries" in style and mood.The action is speeded up, as if to extract the essence of an event. There are parenthetical inserts referring to other places and times. And over all of it there is the same feeling of passion, affection and wonder that marks Jonas Mekas as a film critic and a champion of underground filmmakers, even when he is being most rude and outrageous about the idiocies of nonbelievers. Although I'm told that neither brother was allowed to see the other's film until it was completed, Adolfas's "Going Home" serves as a rather homey (a little too homey, I'm afraid) curtain-raiser to Jonas's film. It is Adolfas and Pola putting on the home movie, but not quite far enough: saying good-by to their cats, sitting in the plane, buying a poncho in Dublin for Pola and mugging the way people do in home movies. Turn a camera on Pola, even in Moscow, and she's likely to do a "Shuffle Off to Buffalo" routine."Going Home," for all that, does supply a lot of straight information that makes "Reminiscences" more easily comprehensible. The brothers, however, seem to disagree on whether it was 27 or 25 years since they'd seen their birthplace."Reminiscences" is an especially appealing film, and a good deal more than a record of Jonas Mekas's summer vacation. It is a testament to all persons displaced, geographically, as the Mekas brothers were, and spiritually. Without sentimentality, Jonas recalls meetings in the early 1950's of displaced persons at Stony Brook, L. I., and "somewhere at the end of Atlantic Avenue." They were cheerful gatherings of people who seemed doomed, sentenced forever to be out of touch.There is something of this same feeling about his treatment of the family's reunion in Lithuania. The great familial love is still there. The joy of reconciliation is real. Yet the years have created a gulf that no amount of touching and eating and drinking and singing together will ever quite bridge. "Reminiscences" is about growingaway as well as up.

title: COLLEGES GIVEN ANTIBIAS GUIDES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4  Avoiding racial quotas and re lying on genuine good faith effert, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare issued a pet of guidelines today for college presidents to follow in complying with Federal nondiscrimination orders on employment.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Out standing consumer installment credit rose by more than $1 billion in August for the sixth consecutive month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Big Three Claiming Record for Their New Model Week
description: DETROIT, Oct. 4The 1973 model year opened with the automobile makers claiming record sales for their new model introduction week.

title: Toll Now 20 in Cruiser Blast
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) The death toll from the turret explosion aboard the cruiser Newport News last week has risen to 20 with the death from injuries of a 21yearold sailor, the Navy announced today. Seaman Apprentice Joseph Grisafi of Springfield, Va., died aboard the helicopter carrier New Orleans in the Pacific where he was being treated for his injuries, the Navy an nounced today. Seaman Ap prentice Joseph Grisafi of Springfield, Va., died aboard the helicopter carrier New Or leans in the Pacific where he was being treated for his in juries, the announcement said.

title: Man Pleads Guilty To Heroin Charge Just Before Retrial
description: The owner of a children's clothing store In Brooklyn, whose prior conviction on a heroin possession charge had been reversed by an appeals court, was sentenced yester day to 10 years In prison on his plea of guilty to the same charge.

title: F111 Back in Combat
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) American F111 fighterbom bers are flying combat missions again in Vietnam after being limited to noncombat flying for more than five days when one of the $15million planes was lost on its first such flight, the Pentagon said today.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The LTV Aaerospace Corpora tion has received $42.2million in Army and Navy contracts, it was announced yesterday. The company obtained a $25.1mil lion Army contract for Lance surfacetosurface bombard ment missiles, and a $17.1mil lion addition to a Navy contract for A7E aircraft.

title: RICHARD L. BOLSTER
description: BOSTON, Oct. 4 (AP)Rich ard L. Bolster, a member of the faculty at American Interna tional College and Western New England College in Spring field, died on Sunday in Chel sea Naval Hospital. He was 58 years Old.

title: Pope Paul and Heath Confer on Ulster
description: ROME, Oct. 4  Pope Paul VI and Prime Minister Heath discussed ways to end violence in Northern Ireland today.

title: For Elderly Psychiatric Patients, a Chance to Trade Hospital for an Apartment
description: Once, they would have ended their days in the faded walls of a mental hospital. Today, nine chronically hos pitalized elderly patients at Bronx State Hospital look forward to a new home and a new way of life in their own apartment.

title: STEPHEN R. MORRIS
description: Stephen R. Morris, partner and senior vice president of Liberty Travel, one of the city's largest travel agencies, died yesterday of cancer at his home at 1016 Fifth Avenue. He was 51 years old.

title: Southern Yemen Charges An Air Attack by Yemenis
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 4 (UPI)The Southern Yemeni Embassy said today that war planes of Yemen had made their first bombing attack against two villages in Southern Yemen, killing seven persons and wounding several others.

title: BUSH TELLS U.N. OF BUDGET STAND
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4  George Bush, the United States representative, today tried to clear up what he characterized as some misunderstanding of an Amer ican effort to have its United Nations budgetary assessment reduced.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Toll cheating on the nine facilities of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority has soared to almost $1million a year, it was asserted yesterday by Anthony M. Mauro, president of the Uniformed Bridge and Tunnel Officers.

title: Mansfield Discerns Validity In Nader Study of Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) The Senate Democratic lead er, Mike Mansfield of Montana, said today there was a good deal of meat and validity in Ralph Nader's criticism of Con gressional operations.

title: 26 ARE HURT HERE IN BLAST AND FIRE
description: An explosion and a fivealarm firepossibly caused by a com bination of arson and a gas leakburned out of control for two hours in Brooklyn yester day, destroying part of an abandoned threestory commer cial laundry and a tenement with streetfloor shops.

title: Patrick Fogarty Is Dead at 80; Former Justice of Family Court
description: Patrick J. Fogarty, a former justice of the Family Court and a slate Assemblyman, died yesterday at Memorial Hospi tal. He was 80 years old and lived at 446 East 140th Street in the Bronx.

title: The Opera: Hoffmann
description: Tricky as the City Opera's new production of Offen bach's Contes d'Hoffmann it nevertheless is an imaginative conception, hand somely executed. It came to the stage of the State Thea ter last night.

title: Stephen Rowland Sings at Town Hall
description: It stands to reason that an artist presented by the New York Singing Teachers' As sociation would possess the basic virtues of good vocal ism. This was certainly true of Stephen Rowland, a 24 yearold baritone who pre sented a program in Town Hall on Tuesday night as a result of winning the asso ciation's 10th Recital Award.

title: Militant Protestant a Target
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 4William Craig, leader of the Ulster Vanguard, a mili tant Protestant movement, was unhurt today when three bul lets struck his car near Belfast. One lodged in the rear seat and others hit the car's body work.

title: Personal Finance: Investing Payouts
description: An increasing number of companies are taking an in terest in what their share holders are doing with quar terly cash dividend payments.

title: NUN AND 8 PRIESTS FREED BY MANILA
description: MANILA, Oct. 4A nun and elght priests detained under the martiallaw proclamation of Sept. 23 were released today and Information Secretary Fran cisco S. Tatad said that they hap all pledged to cooperate with the administration of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Yanks' Coaches Rehired
description: The Yankees rehired Jim Turner, Dick Howser, Elston Howard and Jim Hegan yester day as coaches for 1973. The night's paid attendance was 5,210, making the season total 967,715, the first time since 1945 that home attendance fell below the million mark.

title: Mayor Will Return to TV Sunday Nights at 10:30
description: With Mayor Lindsay, the weekly television program that station WNEW dropped this year after Mr. Lindsay became an active candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomi nation, will return to TV on Oct. 15 on station WPIX.

title: One City Tree
description: RYE, N. Y.They cut down our maple tree, It was a handsome tree, 30 or even 40 feet tallI cannot tell precisely because it's gone and I never thought to measure it while there was time. All that's left now is a stump.

title: Benjamin Rowland Jr., 67, Dies; Fine Arts Professor at Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 4 Benjamin Rowland Jr., the Gleason Professor of Fine Arts at Harvard University, died yesterday in Mount Auburn Hospital after a long illness. He was 67 years old.

title: U.S. CHECKS ARABS TO BLOCK TERROR
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Nixon Administration, acting on a promise by the President to protect Israeli citizens in the United States from terrorist at tacks, has begun a major effort to identify Arabs residing in this country who are suspected of planning terrorism and to screen travelers from Arab na tions more carefully.

title: Saks Appoints Officer
description: Kalman Ruttenstein has been appointed a vice president and merchandise manager of Saks Fifth Avenue. He was previ ously a merchandise manager at Lord & Taylor.

title: Berlinger Charges Deceit In City Report on Welfare
description: The State Welfare Inspector General, George F. Berlinger, declared yesterday that city re ports had deliberately under represented the number of in eligible people receiving wel fare either to deceive the state and Federal Governments or even the city's own welfare chief.

title: SENATE PLAN BARS CREDITS IF SOVIET RETAINS EXIT FEES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Senate served notice today that it would block passage of a SovietAmerican trade agree ment now reportedly near com pletion unless Moscow re scinded heavy exit visa fees lev ied on Jews and others seeking to emigrate.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Restaurants are rated for food (tour stars to none) and for atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: 2 Boys, 16 and 15, Charged With Rape of 6 Women Here
description: A 16yearold rape suspect, who the police said always apologized to the victims, is charged with attacks on six women, the Queens District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Connecticut Cites High Costs
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 4 The Connecticut State Treasurer has told the Securities and Ex change Commission that the state is seeking a seat on the BPW Stock Exchange because the high cost of dealing through brokers leaves no alternative.

title: FREDERICK FRANKLIN
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., Oct. 4 Frederick Franklin, who re tired in 1957 as technical editor of Bell Telephone Laboratories publications in Whippany, died yesterday in Morristown Memo rial Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 24 Franklin Street.

title: LABORITES BACK SHIFT ON MARKET
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 4  The British Labor party committed itself today to try to renegotiate the terms of Britain's membership in the Common Market when it next comes to power, but it refused to adopt a pledge to pull out of the market altogether.

title: A. T. & T. SHARES REACH 1972 HIGH
description: American Telephone sold yesterday at its highest price in 1972, but several fallen glamour issues were pounded anew in a market that saw a rally blossom and then wither.

title: City Block: Where Fear Is a Part of Life
description: Everyone who lives on 85th Street between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue knows about street crime. It is a fact of life, something that is there. Some fear it terribly and a few not at all. For everyone else, however, it is a burden they live with because they must.

title: Equity Financing
description: An offering of 2.2million shares of Consumers Power Company common at $28 a share was made yesterday by a group of underwriters headed by Morgan Stanley. The utility will use the proceeds to finance a portion of its construction program. The company's stock closed at 28, up  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Walsh Reported to Be Resigning Housing Post
description: Albert A. Walsh, head of the city's Housing and Develop ment Administration, was re ported early today to be plan ning to resign his post soon.

title: Ruling Aids Student Voters
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 4 (UPI)A Federal District Judge William R. Collinson issued to day a restraining order allow outofstate students at Mis souri colleges to vote in state races in November. He for bade county clerks to demand more evidence of voter qualifi cation from students than was required from other persons. The ruling affects all county clerks and election boards, Judge Collinson said.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 Without public hearings and with no advance notice, the Senate Rules Committee voted today to exempt corporations and labor unions from certain provisions of the 1971 cam paign reform law.

title: 2 Soviet Jews, in Israel, Tell of Harsh Jail Treatment
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 4 (AP)Two Soviet Jews who arrived in Israel today after serving two year sentences in a Soviet la bor camp said that the situa tion of Jewish prisoners in Russia was becoming worse every day.

title: Notes on People
description: If there is a better way to stir up support for the Rocke feller administration's $1.5 billion environmentalbond issue than pedaling a 10 speed bicycle 533 miles across the state, Henry L. Diamond, state Commissioner of Environmental Conserva tion, will entertain sugges tions. Mr. Diamond said he would peddle the bond issue, which will be on the ballot Election Day, on a trip be ginning Oct. 12 at. Niagara Falls and going through Buf falo Rochester, Syracuse, Albany and New York, and finally to his home in Port Washington, L.I., on Oct. 23.

title: Notes on People
description: If there is a better way to stir up support for the Rocke feller administration's $1.5 billion environmentalbond, issue than pedaling a 10 speed bicycle 533 miles across the state, Henry L. Diamond, state Commissioner of Environmental Conserva tion, will entertain sugges tions. M1. Diamond said he would peddle the bond issue, which will be on the ballot, Election Day, on a trip be ginning Oct. 12 at Niagara Falls and going through Buf falo, Rochester, Syracuse; Albany and New York, and finally to his home in Port Washington, L.I., on Oct. 23.

title: Paul Morrissey's Heat Shown at Film Festival
LegalFee Plan to Be Aired
description: The Insurance Company of North America announced plans yesterday for a pilot prepaid legal services program to be tested in the Philadelphia area for the next year. Insurance policies, to cost about $75 to $150 a year, would be offered on a group basis to cover legal expenses of any lawyer.

title: The Sullen Emperor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5Ten years ago in a state of nervous collapse after his defeat for the California governorship, Richard Nixon vented his deep hostility toward the press.

title: Drop Is for Fiscal Year
description: Sluggish securities markets caused Salomon Brothers, one of Wall Street's most profit able investment houses, to in cur an earnings decline in its most recent fiscal year, the firm disclosed yesterday.

title: Rose Reported to Advise Lindsay To Enter Race for Governor in '74
description: Alex Rose, leader of the Liberal party, which played a key role in Mayor Lindsay's two successful races for City Hall, has advised the Mayor not to run for reelection next year, according to close as sociates.

title: Interfaith Meeting At Vatican Draws No NonCatholics
description: ROME, Oct. 5  A Cardinal told Pope Paul VI during a group audience today that rep resentatives of nonChristian religions whom the Vatican had invited to an interfaith meeting here had failed to show up.

title: Human Cannonballs and Humanities
description: Sports of The Times

title: Personalities: A Culpable Coach
description: The latest postmortem analysis of the disappointing showing by the American team in the Olympic Games at Munich came yesterday from Hobie Billingsley, the coach of the men's diving team, who holds the same job at Indiana University. To be brutally honest, I have to say I did my worst job of coaching ever, and a very large share of the blame for our poor showing was my fault, he said. I just didn't get the divers ready, either mentally or physically. I didn't push them hard enough and instead I let them do their own thing about train ing and curfew. As a result, we lost the springboard com petition for the first time in 40 years.

title: Amin Writes to Waldheim
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 5General Amin has informed Secretary General Waldheim that Asians being expelled from Uganda would be allowed to take out their possessions.

title: Jailing of a Reporter in Jersey Spurring Action in Legislature;
