description: Prices of Japanese prints soared yesterday and Thursday at Sotheby Parke Bernet as buyers from Japan sparked bid ding on the Hans Popper col lection, one of the most not able of its kind in the world. Receipts, about twice presale estimates, came to approxi mately $650,000.

title: Yugoslav Enterprise Prospers
description: SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia  Emerik Blum, the founder and director of Energoinvest, one of the most dynamic enter prises in socialist Yugoslavia, has a reputation for capitalist style emphasis on efficiency and results.

title: Ecologists Battle for Idyllic Florida River
description: BRISTOL, Fla.  It was about a mile out of town here that God breathed life into Adam and Eve and set them up in housekeeping in the Garden of Eden.

title: Lindsay Visits Brooklyn For Look at Its Problems
description: Mayor Lindsay left City Hall yesterday for a trip into Brook lyn from downtown to Grave send Bay to cut red tape, heap praise upon civic workers, build goodwill between his own task forces and locality groups and, in general, make Brooklynites put aside the feel ing they are considered some what alien stepchildren.

title: 42D ST. RESTAURANT IS SITE OF A SLAYING
description: A 25yearold man was stabbed to death last night in Grant's restaurant on West 42d Street, just off Times Square.

title: McGovern and the World
description: In his first comprehensive foreign policy speech of the campaign, Senator George McGovern has emphatically rejected isolationism and summoned the nation to new internationalism, rooted in historic American ideals and fueled less by military might and a narrow nationalism than by economic strength and a willingness to share it with the less fortunate world. The speech Cleveland was clearly in reply to the Nixon campaign charges that Mr. McGovern's proposals for withdrawal from Vietnam, cutting American forces in Europe and slashing the defense budget portended a retreat to pre World War II isolationism.

title: Grand Jury Said to Reconsider Jailing of Silent Jersey Reporter
description: TRENTON, Oct. 6The Essex County grand jury that had requested the contempt cita tion and subsequent jailing of a reporter for refusing to an swer some of its questions was reported tonight ready to reexamine its action.

title: Ballet: A Joffrey Evening of 3 Works
description: The City Center Joffrey Ballet excels at offering a good evening at the theater. For its second program of the season Thursday night at the City Center, it presented the high art of George Balanchine in Square Dance, a successful dance drama in Alvin Ailey's Feast of Ashes and some entertaining corn in Ruthan na Boris's Cakewalk.

title: Basketball's Leading PloyMaker
description: Man In the News

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuts Likely in Senate's Pension Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) Some of the major Social Security and Medicare benefits in the $18.5million bill passed early today by the Senate seem certain to be dropped In the conference with the House.

title: Guam a Center of U.S. BuildUp As Vietnam Pullout Progresses
description: AGANA, Guam, Oct. 4  The United States military buildup in the Pacific, proceeding at the same time as the disman tling of the American machine in South Vietnam, has trans formed Andersen Air Force Base here into the biggest and busiest center for B52 opera tions over Indochina.

title: ... and Buckseeking
description: Congressmen of both parties are anxious to get cam paign contributions from anybody who will give them, and if the law stands In the way, so much the worse for the law. That is the implicit lesson of the extraordi nary moves that have taken place in both the House and the Senate this past week to weaken existing bar riera against campaign contributions by corporations sand unions.

title: Credit Markets
description: Bond prices leaped ahead again yesterday afternoon fol lowing news agency reports of a plan that was said to repre sent the latest allied proposals for ending the war in Vietnam.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. SAMUEL DOLBEAR, A MINING ENGINEER
description: Dr. Samuel Hood Dolbear, a leading mining engineer and an organizer of Behre Dolbear & Co., Inc., 299 Park Avenue, min ing, geological and metallurgi cal consultants, died Thursday in Tucson, Ariz. His age was 85.

title: SALES ARE MIXED AT 3 RETAIL CHAINS
description: Three leading retail chains yesterday reported mixed sales results for September.

title: 2 DANCERS PRESENT OWN CHOREOGRAPHY
description: Sara Shelton and Raymond Johnson are marvelously trained dancers who pooled their talents for a joint con cert at the Cubiculo Thursday evening. Each contributed two, works, the more successful of which drew mainly on the dancers' resources of techni cal accomplishment and per forming skill.

title: Arabs Vow to Punish Bonn
description: CAIRO, Oct. 6The Presi dents of Egypt, Libya and Syria announced today that the three countries would retaliate against West German citizens for the arbitrary and inhuman measures taken against Arab nationals by West German au thorities.

title: Business Briefs
description: DETROIT, Oct. 6 (AP)  The General Motors Corpo ration will spend some $10million to reopen Fisher Body Plant No. 23 as a van assembly plant as part of G.M.'s commitment to the city of Detroit, G.M.'s, chairman, Richard C. Gerstenberg, said today.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6Clark MacGregor, the President's campaign manager, took his turn today at defending the Nixon Administration against Senator George McGovern's charges of corruption.

title: Cabaret: Gisela May Singing Brecht
description: Only five days after Berlin to Broadway, a show that draws heavily on the songs of Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill, opened at the Theater de Lys, the songs turned up again as a major part of the program sung by Gisela May, who opened at the Village Gate on Thursday.

title: TB VACCINE FOCUS OF CANCER PARLEY
description: BETHESDA, Md., Oct. 6At a twoday meeting on use of immune mechanisms to bolster cancer patients' defenses, some glimmers of hope were raised along with the disappointment registered in this extremely dif ficult field.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Black Wed To B. J. Lasker
description: Bernard J. Lasker, senior partner in the stock ex change firm or Lasker, Stone & Stern and former chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Ex change, was married here yesterday evening to Mrs. Christiana Black of Rye, N.Y. The ceremony was per formed in the bridegroom's apartment at the Carlyle by the Rev. Dr. David Seligson, senior rabbi of the Central Synagogue.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Sports of The Times

title: A 10Year Treaty of Friendship Is Signed by France and Poland
description: PARIS, Oct. 6France and Poland signed a 10year friendship and cooperation agreement today, the climax of the fiveday visit here of Edward Gierek, the Polish Communist leader.

title: Violence Reported in Teamster Drive at Kennedy
description: The head of an airfreight company said last night that fire bombs, threats and vandal ized vehicles had accompanied an effort by a teamsters' union local to unionize the employes of his branch at Kennedy Inter national Airport.

title: A Nuclear Submarine And Freighter Collide
description: NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 6 (AP) The nuclear attack sub marine Tullibee, cruising just below the surface, and a West German freighter collided in the Atlantic today 150 miles off the North Carolina coast, the Navy said.

title: Buckpassing ...

That bipartisan characteristic has now produced a situa tion which threatens a serious abnegation of Con gressional responsibility.

title: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn
description: There is one other invaluable way in which literature com municates irrefutable and condensed human experience  from generation to generation. Thus, it becomes the living memory of nations. Thus, it keeps warm and preserves within itself its lost historyin a way not subject to distortion or falsification. Thus, literature itself together with language preserves the national soul.

title: PHILIP LIEBER
description: Philip Lieber, deputy auditor of the Greater New York Sav ings Bank, died Monday evening after a brief illness. He was 61 years old and lived at 9144 82d Street, Woodhaven, Queens.

title: New Jersey Sports

Dawn was breaking when three men trudged over the farmlands of Edward Simonson and C. S. Stults. They were John Trzepac of Calumet City, Ill,; Bob Willow, from Spottswood, N. J., and Arthur Sampson, whose property adjoins the Stults' farm.

title: Bundesbank Lifts Discount Rate

title: Mideast Tensions Afflicting the Arab Communities Here

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rose at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  Yields on United States Treas ury bills rose in the Govern ment's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities. The sale was held today because of observance of Columbus Day Monday.

Ger stenberg, said yesterday. This year's plant closingdue to de emphasis of yearly model style changes and transfer of tool and die work to other plants resulted in layoffs of nearly 1,000 persons.

title: AMNESTY ORDERED BY EAST GERMANY
description: BERLIN, Oct. 6East Ger many announced today a sweep ing amnesty that was expected to bring the release, of thou sands of criminals and political prisoners from jail.

description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6 (AP) The nation's black community is in the midst not of a reces sion but a depression of major proportion, Sargent Shriver said today.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP)  The Pentagon's manpower chief reported today that armed services recruiting set a four year record of more than 50, 000 men last month.

title: Art:
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Oct. 6Another new art mu seum opened in Texas this weekthe Art Museum of South Texas, designed by Philip Johnson of New York. The museum, at the water's edge in this scenic Gulf Coast city, is a boldly designed, all white cubist structure rem iniscent of both Russian constructivism and Le Cor busier's celebrated chapel at Ronchamp.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecti cut, was on the Senate floor early Wednesday morning de livering a speech denouncing the Democratic Presidential candidate, Senator George McGovern, for advocating general amnesty for all draft dodgers. Yes terday morning it was the turn of Senator James L. Buckley, Con servativeRepub lican of New York to de liver a speech assailing Mr. McGovern for proposing foolhardy cuts in defense spending.

title: HUGH E. WHITE

Bob Charles, the New Zealand lefthander, was second. Bobby Mitchell of Danville, Va., took 74 and dropped into a tie for 12th place on 214. Lee Elder Washington, with a 70, had a total of 222.

title: Big Arms Cache Seized In Illinois by U.S. Agents

description: RICHMOND, Oct. 6 (UPI) Flood waters caused by heavy rains swept through central Virginia for the second time in four months today, taking at least three lives and cutting off some major traffic routes.

title: 'Nathalie':French Work by Duras Proves Minimal
description: The most insidious thing about the nouveau movie, which is a polite way of describing Marguerite Duras's newest, most minimal film, "Nathalie Granger," is that it traps you in its own time, unlike the nouveau roman, which can be skipped through or read at leisure in an afternoon or a year.You can't skip through "Nathalie Granger." To see it you are forced to watch it for as long as it lasts, while, in turn, it watches its characters, rather as if the camera were a Siamese cat whose feelings had been hurt.Without betraying the slightest interest, the camera records the physical appearance of two expressionless women who look a lot like Jeanne Moreau and Lucia Bose. They share a house with their two children, one of whom, Nathalie, is apparently a problem. "She wants to kill everyone," says one of the women, who seem to be interchangeable. "She wants to be an orphan, or a Portuguese maid."Nathalie, however, remains docilethis being a minimal movie.The camera paces through the house, looking into mirrors, down hallways, through windows. There is a report on the radio about a murder and a police manhunt. The telephone rings. Wrong number. "There is no telephone here, madame," Miss Moreau says into the receiver." Funny? Not really. It's too pretty and solemn. A salesman calls. He tries desperately to sell a Vedetta Tambour OO8 washing machine that comes in three colors. For a brief moment, the ghost of Pinter's wit walks over the grave of the film. Miss Bose goes into the garden, again. Miss Moreau falls asleep. A cat saunters through. The camera just stares. When a person or a cat leaves a room, Miss Duras seems to say, that room is empty. Such are the discoveries of "Nathalie Granger," a dead-end movie that, I confidently hope, few of us are ready for."Nathalie Granger" was shown last night at the New York Film Festival and is a dismal follow-up to "La Musica" and "Destroy, She Said," the two earlier directorial efforts by the novelist turned filmmaker.

title: KAHANE SAYS HE GOT VOTES IN ISRAELI JAIL
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 6Rabbi Meir Kahane, who by his own count has been jailed 18 times in the United States for his measures in support of Jewish causes, emerged from his first stay in an Israeli prison today. He was fully confident, he said, that he had lined up voters for the Jewish Defense League among his jailers. Rabbi Kahane announced on Sept. 27 that the league would enter parliamen tary elections next year.

title: Dance: Joffrey Ballet Stages Robbins's Interplay
description: Second ballets are always dangerous, often fatal and better left alone. Way back in 1945, Jerome Robbins at tempted his own second ballet, Interplay. Indeed, everyone who ever has aspira tions to a third ballet, has to. Mr. Robbins's second ballet was set to Morton Gould's suburbanly yet suavely jazzy Concertette, and it was very sensibly devised for a revue by Billy Rose. After all, had it fallen flat on its flip per, Mr. Robbins could al ways have said: But I was only teasingyou weren't meant to take that seriously. But we did, and we do.

There, he is ex pected to help his party pre pare a rally to recapture the governorship and legislative posts now held by the New Progressive party, which fa vors union with the United States for the island. Mr. Mufioz Marin, who is 74 years old, was once a champion of Puerto Rico's semiautono mous relationship with the United States.

title: 'Inner Scar' by Talented Young Frenchman Shown
description: Among the very few new talents in the New York Film Festival, the young Frenchman Phillipe Garrel is on several counts the newest. An avant-garde filmmaker who began directing movies while still in his teens, he was only 22 in 1970, when he made "Inner Scar," which played last night in Alice Tully Hall."Inner Scar" features Pierre Clementi (nude) and the Andy Warhol superstar Nico (dressed in a loose robe) and a few others, including Phillippe Garrel. Clementi speaks French; Nico sometimes complains in English and sometimes declaims in German verse, and sometimes sings for musical background on the soundtrack. There are no subtitles.The people, never more than two at a time, move through a variety of landscapes from glacial to nearly tropicalbut that are always, in some manner, desert. The people may walk or run or ride a horse, or drive a flock of sheep or even sail a little boatbut almost always they are in movement. At some level I suspect there is a story in which Clementi, carrying bow and arrows and wielding a sword, comes as king or savior or avenging angel to Nico in the wilderness, and then disappears without satisfying her complaint. But the story is very obscure.Much of the time the landscape seems reducedeven self-consciously reducedto the four elements of earth, air, fire and water. It conveys the feeling of a space unreal in the way, say, that the landscape of the Krazy Kat comic strip was unreal. And as if it were in a comic strip or cartoon, the landscape supports images and gestures of great stylishness and wit."Inner Scar" is sometimes very funny, and it is a humorusually concerning the indignities suffered by an unhappy Nico spurned  that grows out of, and depends upon, the incongruity of human finiteness seen against the vast perspectives of the film's natural world.In such stark, unyielding simplicity there is surely a good deal of pretension. But I think there is also some achievement, and irony, and an implicit appreciation of the ridiculousness of sticking a couple of people out in the middle of nowhere (in fact, several strange locations, including Iceland) to perform symbolic drama.Compared with the desert journeys of Alexandro Jodorowsky"Fando and Lis," "El Topo"  "Inner Scar" seems downright civilized. Not a movie you can exactly warm up to, and no startling breakthrough in screen art eitherbut a very interesting and restrained experiment in visual rhetoric, in minimal gesture, in setting some highly abstract patterns of human behavior in the midst of a curiously agreeable wilderness.

title: SHOP TALK
description: What may well be the first major collection of period Chinese rugs to reach this country from mainland China in two decades is now on view at Lord & Taylor. Most of the 600 designs are temple hangings, those woven pic tures that tell human and spiritual tales or document symbols of worship. Because they were probably never walked on, the colors and patterns in these picturesque weavings appear to be in mint condition.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The unemployment rate remained essentially unchanged in Sep tember at 5.5 per cent of the labor force, the Labor Depart ment reported today.

This is the last of the 12race series on four continents for the world driving championship in For mula One cars and the only one in this country.

description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6  Rain swept over the area today, threatening to disrupt the open ing game of the National League playoff tomorrow be tween the Pittsburgh Pirates and the Cincinnati Reds.

title: PNOMPENH RAIDED BY ENEMY FORCE
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sat urday, Oct. 7 (UPI)Commu fist commandos stormed across a bridge over the Tonle Sap River early today and engaged Government forces in battle in the heart of the Cambodian capital.

title: A Mental Unit Is Planned For Inmates on Rikers I.
description: Benjamin J. Malcolm, the Commissioner of the Depart ment of Correction, announced plans yesterday for the con struction of a 248bed unit on Rikers Island to house city prisoners requiring mental ob servation.

title: Bridge:
description: How deep a finesse should be is of course a matter of circumstance, but in general the deeper, the better. The nine is the right card to finesse more often than most players think, and was on the diagramed deal played in a Regional Swiss Team cham pionship last month.

title: Noise Levels Monitored
description: Patents of the Week

title: Dr. Solomon Leischetz Dead; Princeton Mathematician, 88
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 6 Dr. Solomon Lefschetz, one of the world's most eminent mathematicians and the Henry Burchard Fine Profes sor of Mathematics emeritus at Princeton University, died yesterday at the Princeton Medical Center. He was 88 years old and lived at 11 Lake Lane.

title: City Signs a Lease to Redevelop Downtown Bropklyn
description: Mayor Lindsay signed a 39 year lease yesterday for 17 acres of commercial property in downtown Brooklyn in what the city calls its first privately financed urbanrenewal project.

title: U.S., HANOI DENY PEACE PROGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6New reports of movement in the Vietnam peace talks originated today in London and Saigon, but they were quickly denied by both the United States and North Vietnam.

title: Raid on Leper Colony By Vietcong Reported
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, Oct. 6 (AP)A small band of Vietcong guerrillas reported ly attacked an isolated seaside leper colony and or phanage near here early today, blowing up houses, hospital wards and part of school.

title: A Patrolman Is Suspended In Purchase of Marijuana
description: A patrolman with the Police Department's Public Morals Di vision was arrested and sus pended from the force last night after he was spotted al legedly buying a bag marijuana on an Upper Manhattan street corner.

title: Palestinian Rebuke
description: The cool reception that Palestinian guerrilla leaders have given to President Sadat's suggestion that they form a government In exile is not surprising. The militant Palestinian leadership has always eschewed the respon sibilities that such a step would thrust upon them.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI)  Senator Warren G. Mag nuson, Democrat of Washing ton, sought today to link $94, 580 in gifts from a carpet com pany executive to Republican campaign committees with a White House decision to post pone tough safety standards for the carpet industry.

title: Campaign Spreads to Asia
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) Senator Marlow W. Cook, Republican of Kentucky, an nounced today that he was embarking on a twoweek trip to campaign for President Nixon's reelection among Americans living in Asia. He said 500,000 Americans were living in the areas he will visit, 85 per cent of whom are eligi ble to vote.

title: ELLIOTT IS ACHING TO PLAY Al HOME
description: Jim Kiick and Larry Csonka, Miami's running backs, have expressed desires to get their feet on the real grass of Shea Stadium, and John Elliott of the New York Jets also longs to play a game at Shea.

title: MARTIN J. SIRLIN
description: Martin J. Sirlin, an interior designer, died Thursday, appar ently of a heart attack, at his home, 405 East 54th Street. He was 64 years old.

title: Clinton Defeats Brandeis On SecondHalf Rally, 2814
description: Clinton won its third straight Public Schools Athletic League ManhattanBronx Division foot ball game yesterday, rallying for a 2814 victory over Bran deis. Buzzy Broughton, a senior running back, scored two touch downs, giving him six for Clin ton this season. After falling behind 140. Clinton scored touchdowns in the second and third quarter, finally taking the lead when Greg Taylor scored on a 1yard run.

description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. Capital Post Filled
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) John J. McDermott, special agent in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Alex andria, Va., field office, has been put in charge of the Washington, D.C., field office to succeed Robert K. Kunkel, was transferred to St. Louis in a dispute with Acting Direc tor L. Patrick Gray 3d, it was announced today.

title: WEEK'S AUTO OUTPUT SETS A 4YEAR HIGH
description: Detroit, Oct. 6 (AP)Over time at 20 plants spurred domestic auto production this week to its highest level in four years, the trade paper Automotive News reported yes terday.

title: WINE TALK
description: Some good news from FranceBordeaux, actually and some bad news, pretty much in that order. The good news is about the weather and the bad news, of course, is about prices.

title: UNEMPLOYED RATE REMAINS Al 5,5%; JOBS UP BY 250,000
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The unemployment rate remained essentially unchanged in Sep tember at 5.5 per cent of the labor force, the Labor Depart ment reported today.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6 (UPI)  A judge has ruled that the police made illegal use of a search warrant to look for photographs in a campus news paper office at Stanford Univer sity.

title: Watergate Judge Relaxes Ban on Comment on Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The Federal judge who issued an order Wednesday prohibiting extrajudicial statements by all parties to the Watergate bugging indictments said today that he had never in tended his order to restrict Congressional activity, politi cal debate or news reports concerning the case.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 6The presi dent of the Columbian Founda tion announced plans today to build a multimilliondollar cul tural and recreation center in the Essex County suburbs.

title: Clamp to Bar Driving Is Asked for Scofflaws
description: Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. moved yesterday to put the French boot on scofflaws. He introduced a bill in the City Council to permit the police to clamp an 18pound steel device on an automobile wheel to make the vehicle inoperable.

title: 21 HEED IN RAIDS ON DRUG CHARGES
description: In early morning raids yes terday in four states, 21 per sons were arrested on charges of conspiring to smuggle 8.5 kilos of heroin Into the coun try from Lebanon.

title: The Eagleton Impact
description: News Analysis

title: Scores on WQXR
description: Scores of leading football games will be given at the end of the WQXR 6 P.M. news broadcast and in other news reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times or WQXR for scores; the calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper and the radio station.

title: For Meadows, Balance and Openness
description: LYNDHURST  The Hack ensack Meadowlands will be a neatly balanced amalgam of development, redlamation and preservation, with an emphasis on open space and with a low construction pro file in keeping with the char acter of the, tidal marshes that are its heart.

title: Conservationists Fight for Blue Herons
description: LAFAYETTE  Two con servation groups have begun a campaign to fight what they see as serious threats by min ing and real estate interests to Crooked Swamp, one of the Northeast's biggest nest ing sites of the blue heron.

title: California Faces 22 Ballot Issues, Including Chavez and Busing
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7 California's voters must make up their minds next month about 22 ballot measures, some of which touch on the most controversial social and polit ical questions of the time.

title: TOUGH TALKS DUE, EGYPTIANS TOLD
description: CAIRO, Oct. 7  Egyptians were told in strong terms to day that there has been no im provement in SovietEgyptian relations since President Anwar el Sadat demanded the with drawal of Soviet pilots, missile crews and advisers in July.

title: MISSISSIPPI URGED TO REVAMP PRISON
description: JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 7A blueribbon committee named by Gov. William L. Waller to study Parchman Penitentiary has called for abandoning the prison's farmforprofit system and hiring a professional pe nologist to head the institution.

title: GROSS RESIGNS JOB ASCITY YOUTH AIDE
description: Ted Gross, the Commissioner of Youth Services, resigned yesterday after being. Sum irioned to City Hall to answer charges of improper and questionable expense proce Idures at his agency.

title: Ohio State, Down at Half, Defeats California, 3518
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 7 (AP)Thirdranked Ohio State, frustrated in the first half, got a threetouchdown performance from a sophomore fullback, Harold Henson, in the third period today and rallied for 3518 victory over California.

title: DOCTORS WARNED OF RARE EPILEPSY
description: Two California physicians have called their colleagues' at tention to abdominal epilepsy, A rare condition in which a few children experience recurrent episodes of abdominal pain without the seizures or convul sions that usually characterize epilepsy.

title: Hasidim Flexing Political Muscle
description: On last Yom Kippur the most solemn day of the Jewish yearthe sexton of the synagogue of the Satmar Hasidim in Williamsburg rose to the pulpit and told 4,000 worshipers that they should vote for Representative John J. Rooney.

title: Heath's Policies Assailed By Powell at Rightist Rally
description: ILKLEY, England, Oct. 7 (AP)Enoch Powell, a right wing leader in the Conservative party, delivered his most direct and sweeping attack today on Prime Minister Heath, accusing him of demolishing party pol icies and cheating the electorate.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: A collection of articles on heroin edited by two doctors who have worked for five years at the HaightAshbury Free Clinic, treating over 3,000 ad dicts. Pieces on the history of heroin legislation, the pharma cology of heroin, drug use in Vietnam, various forms of treatment from methadone to therapeutic communities like Synanon. No easy answers emerge, of course, and the con tributors occasionally tend to politicalize the problem, but this is a good collectionit re flects advanced thinking about heroin and provides some his torical perspective.

title: MANHATTAN ELEVEN DOWNS SIENA, 210
description: Steve Holmes ran for two touchdowns and gained 136 yards yesterday as he led Man hattan College to a 210 vic tory over Siena College at Gaelic Park.

title: Depression during the Depression
description: Paula Fox has fashioned her sec ond novel out of desperate realities. The Western Coast is a fine, strong book whose idiomatic rendering of the blind passage of life through loss and confusion onto the cliff edge of experience and awareness is pro foundly American. It is a record of an unmistakably American life dur ing a period that forced to the sur face of our lives some of the most distinctive characteristics of Ameri can culture. The time is the end of the Depression and the years of World War II. The place is Los Angeles. The life is that of Annie Gianfala, daughter of Elizabeth, a beautiful woman unfitted for life, who dies before Annie is two years old, and of Tony, a frightened, pas sionate man who drinks, paints, mar ries numerous women, and aban dons his wondering, unformed daugh ter repeatedly in his lost, reckless pursuit of feeling.

title: ERIK ERIKSEN DIES; DANISH LEADER, 70
description: COPENHAGEN., Denmark, Oct. 7 (Agence FrancePresse) Erik Eriksen, former Premier, regarded as the father of the present Danish Constitution, died in an Esbjerg hospital to day at the age of 70.

title: What made Tony run?
description: When I was growing up on (I almost said with) movies, Anthony Quinn was my favor ite halfbreed, which was a term scriptwriters used to toss around in those neolithic times. Halfbreed, half anything, Quinn played them allthe tainted ones, the partIndians, the partMexicans, the visibly partforeign ones with disquali fying blond Quinn, born into poverty of MexicanIrish heri tage, the Mexican side winning out, was too darktoo Latin was Hollywood's rationaleto pass for anything but an Out sider.

title: Booster Club for Jets Cards First Luncheon
description: First & Ten, the booster club of The New York Jets, Will hold the first of seven lunches tomorrow, in the penthouse of the New York Playboy Club.

title: Tibetans Take Root, But Yearn To Go Home
description: FANWOODMost of the 85,000 Tibetans who fled their country after the Chinese Communist takeover in 1959 have remained in India, but a few others went abroad 700 to Switzerland, and about 100 to the United States.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  This was to have been the year of the issues. Only 10 weeks ago President Nixon told a news conference: The is sues that divide the opposite side and this Administration are so wide in fact the clearest choice in this centurythat we must campaign on the issues. George McGovern already had a track record in the primaries as an issueoriented can didate.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Oct. 7Lawrenceville defeated Wil Iiamson Trade, 217. Dave Lecher, working as a winghack, threw three passes for Law renceville and completed each one, two for touchdowns. Glenn Williard caught both scoring passes for Lawrenceville, now 201.

title: The World
description: When Israeli armor moved against Palestinian commandos in southern Lebanon on Sept. 16, in retaliation for the murder of 11 Israelis by Palestinian terrorists at the Olympic games in Munich, the question in Arab capitals was whether any of the protesting Arab nations would take military action against Israel. None didand the fail ure of the large Egyptian armed force to move reduced Cairo's influence in the Arab world, in the view of many Arab commentators, to the lowest point since the death of President Gamal Abdel Nasser.

title: Montclair College Aiding Prisoners
description: MONTCLAIR  To one segment of New Jersey's stu dent population, the new aca demic year may be a turn ing point; they are student inmates of penal institutions.

title: 2 British Members Named To Common Market Body
description: LONDON, Oct. 7Prime Min ister Heath today named Sir Christopher Soames, now Am bassador to Paris, and George Thomson, a labor party mem ber of Parliament, as Britain's members on the Common Mar ket's commission.

title: Art
description: THE search for a distinctly native tradition in American art has led some writersnotably John W. McCoubrey, in his interesting book, American Tradition in Painting to suggest that landscape is the great protagonist of our art. The argu ment, stated very roughly, is that the characteristic wildernessthe raw, un settled landscapeof the American continent, as distinct from the cen turiesold cultivated landscapes of Eu rope, allowed American painters, even as late s the 19th century when the wilderness was fast disappearing, to push American art beyond the limits of its borrowed European styles. It is an attractive argument  that the native land is a shaping force of the native art but one that relies more on sensibility than on specific visual proofs. One's response to an American landscape painting is more likely to be a question of mood ether than photographic ac curacy.

title: P. F. Cowie Jr. Weds Lisa Whitbeck
description: WESTON, Conn., Oct. 7In Emmanuel Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Lisa Whitbeck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin P. Whit beck, was married to Paul Frederick Cowie Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cowie of Wil ton. The Rev. George R. Laedlein performed the cere mony, which was followed by a reception at the Fairfield County Hunt Club in West port.

title: Much of Area Sports Schedule Is Postponed Because of Rains
description: High winds and heavy rain forced the postponement yes terday of many sports events and disrupted several others.

title: A COLLEGE OPENS CONSUMER CENTER
description: Are you a victim of con sumer fraud? asks a bold sign on a door of a Bronx Com munity College building at Jerome Avenue and 143d Street.

title: ROBERT STEPHENSON, COURT REFEREE, DIES
description: Robert P. Stephenson, an of ficial referee in bankruptcy in the Federal Court of the South ern District of New York from 1929 to 1963, died here Wednes day. He was 91 years old and lived at 176 Sullivan Street.

title: Civic Group in Hamptons Wins Without Fighting
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I.It is not always necessary to fight City Hall. Members of East Hampton's Village Im provement Society, long the watchdogs of civic affairs in this resort community, have learned this the easy way.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: A charming beginner's na ture book for adults, with one chapter entitled Howto Lure Kids. Mr. Davids reels out un ending encyclopedic lore about birds, plants, insects, animals and their habitats, gathered, apparently, from a lifetime of observation. His aim is to se duce likeminded but less knowl edgeable amateurs into an ap preciation of nature's variety. He succeeds.

title: Views of the Camera World
description: THE Photographic His torical Society of New York, Inc., 244 Fifth Avenue, New York, N. Y. 10001, will hold a weekend symposium, Photo graphica '72 at the Penn Garden Hotel here, the week end of Oct. 2123. To start with hospitality suite activi ties at 7:30 P.M. on Friday, Oct. 20, the symposium will include many speakers and panel discussions of interest to camera collectors, as well as to those interested in our photographic heritage and equipment. There will also be three planned programs in which registrants may par ticipate, a swapshot session on Sunday, a museum slide andtape show, a film on the life of Daguerre, and a ban quet in the Grand ballroom that Saturday at which Peter Bunnell will be the keynote speaker. Advance registra tion by mail (before Oct. 15) is $15 per person or $20 per couple; after that it will be $18 and $23, respectively. The Saturday night dinner will be $10 per person.

title: New York
description: New York City's chaotic taxi situ ation is always at or near the critical flash point. It exploded again last week. On Monday, about 500 gypsy cab driverswho drive the nonmedal lion taxispoured out of Hunts Point Palace, a garish meeting hall in the South Bronx, after a wild, noisy meet ing. Within hours, they, had halted rushhour traffic on the Triborough Bridge, set fire to several yellow, me dallion taxis, smashed the windows of three others and injured five police men.

title: Big Slate Entered On Wisconsin Ballot By American Party
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 7The American party has fielded the widest selection of third party candidates for the Wiscornin Legislature since the old Pro gressive party three decades ago.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WELCH, W. Va., Oct. 7 Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts stumped across the West Virginia coal fields today by car and helicopter on a nostalgic tour for John D. Rockefeller 4th, the young Democratic gubernatorial can didate, whose, race here is stirring more excitement in the fallcolored Appalachian Moun tains than the Presidential cam paign.

title: The World
description: Not long ago, perhaps five years back, a story went the rounds in New York about the Arab potentate who had to call the oil company president every time he wanted to buy a new Cadillac.

title: PACIFIC LEADERS CRITICAL OF U. S.
description: APIA, Western Samoa, Sept. 28  Leaders of emerging Pa cific island peoples, gathered in this steamy little South Seas port for the 12th annual South Pacific Conference, have sev erely criticized the United States and France for the slow pace of their economic aid to the area.

title: Court Allows 102 Verdicts
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 7 (UPI) The Texas Supreme Court has adopted new rules allowing civil cases to be decided by verdicts of 10 to 2 rather than by unanimous agreement of the jurors. Chief Justice Robert W. Calvert said they were the greatest reform measure during my term on the court.

description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey to Finance BlackBuilt Housing
description: NEWARK, Oct. 7A corpo ration formed by Imamu Amiri Baraka, the black nationalist, and his followers has won state support for construction of a 16story lowandmoder ateincome housing project in the predominantly white North Ward.

title: Larchmont Races Deferred
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 7 The start of the HerreshoffS Class interfleet team sailing match between Western Long Island Sound and Narragansett Bay was postponed today until tomorrow because of gale warn ings and heavy seas off Larch mont Yacht Club.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Newspaper readers casually familiar with the exchange of Col. Rudolf Abel for Francis Gary Powers, or, in Great Brit ain, Peter and Helen Kroger for Gordon Lonsdale probably think of the cases as no more than two EastWest spy trades. But E. H. Cookridge, a prolific writer on espionage, has dis cerned a pattern. The Soviets, he says, in order to encourage spy recruitment, guarantee their agents that, if captured, they will be bartered for. Since more Eastern than Western spies are caught, the Soviets are not above arresting in nocent travelers or using for eigners who have fallen afoul of the law as bargaining chips. Mr. Cookridge has drawn to gether numerous examples of this flourishing trade and con tributed a small but significant chapter to the story of the es pionage game.

title: The Price Was Right and the Party Fun
description: It was a Salute to Presi dent Nixon ball, complete with flags that had, and no one knew why, only 48 tstars; swags of plastic bunting, and red, white and blue balloons that read Nixon Now.

description: WARSAW, Oct. 7  The visit to Poland of Cardinal Krol opens the way to a long awaited trip to the United States by the Polish primate, Cardinal Wyszynski, in the view of diplomats here.

title: 250 Police Officials Get Corruption Questionnaire
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy has ordered every commander in the department to fill out a lengthy question naire detailing the kinds and extent of corruption he believes may exist among his men and what he is doing to reduce it.

title: FORFEIT IS AWARDED TO SLEEPY HOLLOW

description: Foundation money! Encounter maga zine! Angry intellectuals! It's the socio literary late show, a rerun of the anxious 1960's in the disconsolate 1970's  com plete with hot and cold running warriors athwart their mimeograph machines.

title: This Week Gets Twin Billing

He announced two designations for the week beginning tomor row, proclaiming it as both National Legal Secretaries' court Observance Week and National School Lunch Week.

title: Art Gets a New Showcase
description: PRINCETON  A wel come contribution from in dustry to the arts is the new Squibb Gallery at the world wide headquarters of E. R. Squibb & Sons, Inc.

title: Briton Says His Nation Leads U.S. in Fight for Environment
description: Britain is solving her environ mental problems at a faster rate than the United States, but the reasons for this are not a reflection of American foot dragging or incompetence, Peter Walker, Britain's Minister for the Environment, said here last week.

description: PLYMOUTH MEETING, Pa., Oct. 7Mr. and Mrs. Elkins. Wetherill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alexandra Wetherill, to John Cole Tu ten Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Tuten of Bowmansdale,
