description: FOR SALE: ANTINIXONITES FOR NIX ON BUTTONS. 10$2.50; 25$5.50; 30$8 100$10. Chk/M.O to: Rande Mart, Inc. (att: Randers Heimer), 240 E. 76 St., N.Y., N.Y. 10021  Advt.

title: Salisbury Routs Gunnery
description: WASHINGTON, Conn., Oct. 7Salisbury spoiled homecom ing day for Gunnery with a 200 rout of the host school. Tim Henkan scored twice for the winners, now 20. Gunnery, which has dropped two straight, lost three fumbles and had two passes intercepted.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Wagner's LastPeriod Rally Turns Back Upsala, 136
description: Scott Spratford, a lineback er, intercepted a pass on the final play of the game and ran it back 34 yards for a touch down to give Wagner College a 13.6 victory over Upsala yesterday at Fischer Memorial Field.

title: Fast Start for the Pirates
description: Sports of The Times

title: Hutcherson Gains Pole
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Oct. 7 (AP)Ron Hutcherson of Keokuk, Iowa, won the pole position for tomorrow's Royal Triton ARC 300 at the Texas World Speedway. He averaged 165.864 miles an hour for his first time on the superspeed way.

title: Yale Downs Colgate, 277, Scoring All Points in 2d Halt
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 7  A sparse crowd of 6,074 sat through a bone chilling rain storm today to watch Yale's wishbone offense against Col gate's wishbone offense and saw the Elis come up with a 277 victory in the Bowl.

title: Young Adults Puzzle Business
description: Remember the baby boom of the nineteenfifties and the unforeseen growth enter prises it spawned, such as blue jeans, rock records and marijuana?

title: Article 2  No Title
description: DALLAS, Oct. 7 (AP)  Southern Methodist, led by Chris Silverthorn's 77yard punt return and freshman Wayne Morris's 82yard scoring run, exploded for five third quarter touchdowns today to route New Mexico State, 556.

title: New Help for Handicapped
description: WOODRIDGE  Dr. Rus sell G. Layden, who began work last week as super intendent of a new school district for emotionally dis turbed and handicapped chil dren in Bergen County, is man who believes in parental involvement.

title: Mrs. Adams Has Child
description: BOSTON, Oct. 7A daugh ter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Donald J. Adams on Sept. 20 at the Boston LyingIn Hos pital. Mrs. Adams is the former Miss Audrey Stier of Mount Vernon, N. Y. Her hus band is completing his resi dency at the Massachusetts Mental Hospital. The child, who has been named Sarah, is a granddaughter of David C. Adams, board chairman of the National Broadcasting Company, Inc., in New York.

title: Foreign Banks Flowering on U. S. Soil
description: In Garden City, L. I., these days, the cry could well be The Redcoats are coming!

title: Powerboats to Take Over in Annapolis
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 7 Some time during the 60 hours after the United States sailboat show closes Mon day evening and the United States yacht show opens Thursday morning, a feat of magic will take place at the city docks: all the sailboats will turn into powerboats.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: A society reporter and col umnist for The Washington Post chatters away cheerfully about. White House weddings, diplomatic functions (the Rus sians always seclude their vaunted caviar behind the deviled eggs), the overuse of sex as a beauty aid, etc. It's all rather madcap and free as sociationjust as she's making some point about Washington society, she veers off into fan tasy. More giddy than funny.

title: The reeducation of John Lindsay
description: New York City politics could be said to have come full circle one night last spring. At the Wal dorfAstoria Hotel, the captains and soldiers of Bronx County's regular Democratic organization were gathered for their annual testimonial to one another and the virtues of party regularity. There on the dais sat Patrick J. Cunningham, the latest of a long string of Irish bosses who have held party power, seemingly unperturbed, while the Bronx has coasted downhill. There too, along with a squad top municipal officeholders, sat John V. Lindsay, who it now seems has been running almost forever as the candidate of unbossed reform.

title: A Patisserie in Ridgewood
description: RIDGEWOOD,The Paris Pastry Shop is on treelined main shopping street of this Bergen County community, but inside the wares on dis play look like those in any patisserie on the Boulevard Hausmann.

title: BLACK ACADEMY HONORS 5 HERE
description: Blacks are no longer needed in the nation's economy and facing genocide, must fight for their survival or accept extinc tion quietly, according to a black authorone of five win ners of the 1972 Letters Awards of the Black Academy of Arts And Letters.

title: Miss Galiani Bride In Pelham Manor
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Oct. 7Miss Virginia Galiani, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joshua L. Galiani of Pelham Manor, was married here this afternoon to John M. Manga niello, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Manganiello of New Rochelle.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: COLOGNE, West Ger many, Sept. 30Putting air mail postage on a domestic letter has become a rarity in West Germany and this is not only because of the coun try's relatively small size and its speedy surface carriers.

title: RAIL COMMUTERS REBELLING IN ITALY
description: ROME, Oct. 7Italy, which has no shortage of social troubles, is suddenly facing new one  a commuter re bellion.

title: Solomon Schechter School Takes New Step
description: A new structure opened in Flushing, Queens, this term, marking the first Solomon Schechter school in the city with a separate highschool building.

title: Miss Adelia Moore Wed Upstate to Tom Gerety
description: TUPPER LAKE, N. Y., Oct. 7Miss Adelia Moore, a June graduate of Radcliffe, was married at her family's Adirondack camp here this afternoon to Tom Gerety, a graduate student in philoso phy at Yale.

title: Miami (Ohio) Wins, 210; 3 Touchdowns for Hitchens
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Oct. 7 (AP)Bob Hitchens gained 184 yards in a schoolrecord 44 carries today, pacing Miami of Ohio to a 227 victory over Marshall University.

title: Miss Hawley Has Nuptials
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Oct. 7 Miss Alexandra Hawley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Hawley of Fair field, and Landgrove, Vt., was married here this after noon to Peter W. Oldershaw. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. Oldershaw of Holyoke, Mass., and Bidde ford Pool, Me.

title: Quangtri in Ruins After Battles
description: QUANGTRI, South Viet nam, Sept. 29  What the South Vietnamese marines captured here more than two weeks ago was not Quangtri city, nor the Quangtri Citadel. It was an unrecognizable wasteland of smashed build ings and craters.

title: Anne O'Callaghan Wed
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., Oct. 7  Miss Anne O'Callaghan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James K. O'Callaghan of Great Neck, was married here this afternoon to Gary Dennison Gilbert, a vessels manager of the Alcoa Steam ship Company in New York. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack D. Gilbert of Kailua, Hawaii. The Rev. Brendan Riordan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the cere mony in the Mariners Chapel of the United States Mer chant Marine Academy.

title: Brewer, on 205, Leads Japan Golf By One Stroke
description: INZAI, Japan, Oct. 7 (UPI) Gay Brewer of the United States shot a fourunderpart 67 to day for a onestroke lead over Australian David Graham in the third round of the $300,000 Pa cific Masters golf tournament.

title: CHARLES CAPTURES BRITISH GOLF ON 277
description: NEWCASTLEONTYNE, Eng land, Oct. 7 (AP)  Bob Charles the New Zealand left hander, shot a finalround 68, four under par today and over took Tony Jacklin of Britain to win the Dunlop Masters golf tournament. Charles had a 72 hole total of 277, 11 under par, and won $4,900.

title: Greenwich Races Canceled
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 7 A northeast wind of Up to 40 knots and big waves off the Riverside Yacht Club caused cancellation today of the sched uled fall series regatta for Yacht Racing Association fleets based eastofRye on Long Island Sound.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 7 (UPI) Jack Egers scored on a 45foot shot in the third period tonight to give the St. Louis Blues a 44 tie with the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: There Really Was a Super Suicide Society
description: Exeter tempered me and brought out in my nature a very strong compe titive and ambitious streak. It tuned me up for life. I suppose if I hadn't gone to Exeter I would be quite a different person today.John Knowles, Exeter '45, author of A Separate Peace.

title: Television
description: THE WALTONS, CBS's gift to viewers who were hoping for one, just one different show this season, seems strangely out of place until you realize what makes it different: you're being asked to care. Caring is an motional muscle that Seldom gets flexed in prime time, thanks to the cutouts that pass for people on the tube. The wonderful and unusual thing about the Waltons is that they, come across as real people.

title: The World
description: BLACKPOOLIn the confusion there was something for everyone. On the climactic issue of the Common Market the one that had badly split the Labor party and all but driven out such prominent figures as Roy Jenkins last week's party conference man aged to mount a horse and ride off in all directions.

title: Summing Up: What Travel Abroad Meant to 5 Young Americans
description: The European year has been the goal of young Americans since the days of steamer trunks and let ters of credit; never have so many attained the goal as in these days of credit cards and camper vans. Five young AmericansMary Cun nane, Candido A. DeJesus, Linda Brown, Philip Dine and Phoebe A. Erb, all between 22 and 26 years of age  shared their experiences with Travel Section staff members Stanley Carr and Jonathan Segal. Here is an edited transcript of their conversations.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Many of the nation's bet ter specialty stores, which are constantly trying to capi talize on what they do have, are for the first time finding that they have to take a se rious look at what they do not have. And what they do not have are, many shipments of expected fall merchandise.

title: Photography
description: IT is more instructive to deal separately with the successes and failures of Hans Levi's Street Jesus (Hans Levi/Scrimshaw Press, $4.95 softbound) than to praise it with faint damns or vice versa.

title: Quotas in business
description: To the Editor:

title: SPASSKY ASSESSES ERRORS IN HIS LOSS
description: In a Moscow interview in which he analyzed some of the mistakes he made in losing the world chess championship to Bobby Fischer, Boris Spas sky said that he was willing to meet the American grand master again.

title: The Old Entertainer at his best
description: Not so fast; not so fast, Talley rand once told his coachman; We are in a hurry.

title: Miss Nora von Meister Bride of Neil Macdonald
description: PEAPACK, N. J., Oct. 7 Miss Eleanora Marie Ann von Meister, daughter of Fred erick William von Meister and the late Mrs. von Meister, former Countess Eleanora ColloredoMansfeld of Siern dorf, Lower Austria, was married here this afternoon to Neil Matheson Macdonald. He is a son of Patrick Donald Macdonald of Suva, Fiji, and Mrs. Delia Travers Macdonald of Hove, England.

title: MICHIGAN ROUTS NAVY SQUAD, 357
description: ANN HARBOR, Mich., Oct. 7 (AP)An 83yard punt return by Dave Brown sparked a 28 point Michigan third quarter to day and the Wolverines breezed to a 357 victory over Navy.

title: In 1945, George Orwell wrote an introduction to Animal Farm. It was not printed, and remained unknown till now. It appears here under Orwell's title:
description: This book was first thought of, so far as the central idea goes, in 1937, but was not written down until about the end of 1943. By the time when it came to be written it was obvious that there would be great difficulty in getting it pub lished (in spite of the present book shortage, which ensures that anything describable as a book will sell), and in the event it was refused by four publishers. Only one of these had any ideological motive. Two had been publishing antiRussian books for years, and the other had no noticeable political color. One publisher actually started by accepting the book, but after making the prelim inary arrangements he decided to consult the Ministry of Information, who appear to have warned him, or at any rate strongly advised him, against publishing it. Here is an extract from his letter:

title: A woman possessed of furies
description: There is nothing I would rather read this season than biographies of women written by women. I need to know how the historic famous and nearfamous of my sex managed to construct their triumphswhat en abled them, what stopped them; and I need to learn these truths directly, without the filter of a male mind, although I am willing now and then to make grateful exception for a Joseph Lash. But the women have things to discuss. We must utilize our own shorthand, speak to our own questions. Eleanor Flexner's Mary Wollstonecraft approaches this kind of exciting function.

title: W. 77th St. Residents, Protesting Noise and Crowds Seek to Close a Cabaret
description: Their sleepless nights began in April, residents of West 77th Street say, when the Forbidden Fruit cabaret opened on the block between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue.

title: New York
description: Aristotlein the guise of Metropolitan Museum director Thomas P. F. Hovingseems to be contemplating the sale of the bust Homer. In reality the Rembrandt masterpiece is securely on display in the museum but the security of some other great works at the institution is not so sure.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Negotiations on reform of the monetary system having got under way at the Inter national Monetary Fund meeting in Washington, the attention of governments will soon turn to the prac ticalities of trade negotia tions.

title: Gardens
description: A HILL of daffodils is a wondrous sight but busy gardeners can bring joyous color to a prim foundation planting with a handful of golden daffodils. I often pass an eastfacing house with a severely hand some planting of closely clipped yews. Every summer it is ornamented by an edging of begonias laden with rosy blossoms, but in spring there is nary a flower to relieve the dark austerity. Not enough sun for tulips? but why not daffodils?

title: Center for Mentally Retarded
description: A corporation has been organized to pave the way for the development of a $3.6million education and training facility it Brooklyn for the mentally retarded, braininjured and emotionally disturbed. The faculty would be under the aegis of the Brooklyn School for Special Children.

title: Georgia Pacific Is Struck
description: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 7 (AP)Union workers struck the, Georgia Pacific Company paper mill here this morning, after a week of contract talks at which union officials said little progress had been made. Union officials said the 650 Members of two locals of the Pulp and Sulfide Paper Makers at the plant voted unanimously last night to begin the walkout at midnight. The morkers have been without a contract since Oct. 1. Negotiations were sched uled to resume on Tuesday.

title: Widener Defeats Fordham As Johnson Stars, 21 to 7
description: Billy Johnson, a halfback, scored two touchdowns yester day in leading Widener College to a 217 victory over Fordham at rainswept Jack Coffey Field.

title: Agnew Will Inspect Center For Indians That Is Closing
description: ROSEWELL, N. M., Oct. 7 The controversial decision by the Department of the Interior to close the educational and job training program for In dians here will receive a top echelon review when Vice Pres ident Agnew visits this city next week.

title: WASHINGTON TOPS OREGON, 23 TO 17
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 7 (AP) Washington's Sonny Sixkiller threw three touchdown passes today to lead the Huskies to a 2317 victory over the Ore gon Ducks in a Pacific8 Con ference College football game.

title: Fish Tests in Iowa Show Perilous Pesticide Residue
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 7 (UPI)Iowa's Agriculture Sec retary L. B. Liddy, said yester day that tests on buffalo fish and carp at the Coralville Res ervoir near Iowa City indicated dangerously high levels of diel drin, a pesticide residue.

title: Tax Break on Land Urged
description: BOSTON, Oct. 7 (AP)Legis lation to exempt a homeowner's land from property taxes has been filed for the 1973 session by State Senator Irving Fish man, Democrat of Newton.

title: Mary Frothingham Wed to David Cook
description: NEW LONDON, N. H., Oct. 7  Miss Mary Robinson Frothingham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Frothingham of Sherborn, Mass., was married here this afternoon to David Mac Strong Cook, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lyman Baldwin Conk of New London. The Right Rev. Charles P. Gilson, Suf fragan Bishop of Hawaii, per formed the ceremony in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: Screen: Phantom India
description: Louis Malle's sixhour col or documentary Phantom India is a towering, memo rable film that engulfs the viewer: Filmed in 1968, set ing off a storm on British televisidn, and shown theat rically in separate segments here, last spring, the work is now being presented com mercially in toto for the first tune at the New Yorker. The ater. The six hours of hard Sitting are worth every minute.

title: Miss Clarke Has Wedding
description: KENT, Conn., Oct. 7Miss Christina McCullough Clarke, daughter of Mrs. Thaddeus Eugene Alwyn of East Hamp ton, L. I., and Sarasota, Fla., was married here this after noon in the Kent School Chapel to John Bamford Wat kins. The Rev. Peter Wood ward, the school chaplain, performed the Episcopal cere mony.

title: Federal Agency Joins Fight on Pollution of a River an Wisconsin
description: APPLETON, Wis., Oct. 7 Wisconsin's paper industry faces a crackdown by Federal and state agencies because of pollu tion of the once clean Fox River in east central Wisconsin.

title: Don't Pen Us Up in Chinatown
description: A LOT of white racist ink's been coming dirty out of New York, trashing AsianAmerica, turning black against yellow, ridiculing American Indians to trivialize us yellow folk, and finally coming all the way hope to me, by name, turning me against my own people, my, own work to mark me as the white theater's yellow token.

title: Selfservice
description: The number of gas stations in the Soviet Union is being expanded; it is said, with inexpensive Indianmade pumps and other equipment, acquired in return for Soviet foreign aid. In 1970, the latest year for which statistics are available, there were estimated to be nearly 2,000 (compared with 220,000 in the U.S.).

title: Chess: How Larsen, the Favorite, Blew It in the U.S. Open
description: The 1972 United States Open Championship Tourna ment, played in August at Atlantic City, drew 350 play ers, including two grand masters  Bent Larsen of Denmark and Walter Browne of Australia  four senior masters and a host of mas ters and experts. Browne topped the field with 10 points and Larsen, Larry Kaufman; Larry Gilden, Nor man Weinstein and. Ed Cele rio followed with 9 each.

title: Northern Illinois Victor
description: DEKALB, Ill., Oct. 7 (AP) Mark Keller raced for three touchdowns today, powering Northern Illinois to a 207 vie tory over Xavier.

title: McGOVERN PROPOSAL ON MILITARY SCORED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI) A group of Democrats sup porting President Nixon issued today a study concluding that Senator George McGovern's proposed $30billion cut in mili tary spending was irresponsi ble and dangerous.

title: LOOMIS CURTAILS KINGSWOOD SKEIN
description: WINDSOR, Conn., Oct. 7 Loomis played Kingswood to day for the first time in 15 years, and Kingswood may be wishing that the two never met. Loomis won, 76, snap ping Kingswood's 13game win ning streak. A fight following a 1957 game between the two schools had caused the long interruption in the rivalry.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7With exactly one month left until Election Day, President Nixon appears within striking distance of one of the great electoral sweeps in American Presiden tial history.

title: HiFi: TimeTripping with the Sound of Tomorrow
description: THE Sound of Tomor row is what the New York High Fi delity Show was called this year, and there were enough flashing lights, space age gadgetry and tech nological jargon to more than justify the title. Running for four days at the Statler Hilton Hotel, it was the first consumer high fidelity pres entation in the metropolitan area in the last four years; its significance to the city was acknowledged when Mayor John V. Lindsay pro claimed the week of Septem ber 25 High Fidelity Week in New York City.

title: Judges May Wield the Tape at Shows
description: News of Dogs

title: New Square, Once a Farm, Now Supports 250 Families
description: NEW SQUARE, N. Y. Business isn't booming in this Rockland County community, but it is showing steady growth.

title: Eleanor McKnight Bride of E. I. Haupt
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., Oct. 7 Miss Eleanor S. McKnight and Edward I. Haupt, both of Wayne, were married here this afternoon in the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Chapel by the Rev. Dr. David B. Water mulder.

title: How the essay came to be written
description: George Orwell in his As I Please column in the left wing Tribune for Feb. 16, 1945, wrote:

title: Rangers Beaten, 53, By Wings in Opener
description: DETROIT, Oct. 7  The Detroit Red Wings scored four goals in the first period and held on for a 53 victory over the New York Rangers tonight in a National Hockey League opener.

title: TITO FOR CUTBACK IN YUGOSLAV PARTY
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 7President Tito declared to day that Yugoslavia's million member Communist organiza tion was too large and said that several hundred thousand members could he ousted to make it a disciplined, vanguard party.

title: Journalism Group Assails Curb on Publicity in Trial
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7 (UPI) An attorney for the national journalism society, Sigma Delta Chi, told an appellate court yes terday that any restraint on publicity in a trial would lead to a secret administration of jus tice.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Cheers for Rabbi Krantz [Rabbi Tries the Landlord's Role, Sept. 24] and land lords like him everywhere.

title: New & Novel
description: Athmani is a young entrepre neur living in a British colony in East Africa, presumably in the present day (?), whose ad ventures are recounted in the picaresque tradition of Hajji Baba. If you can accept the antique flavor of Mr. Browne's narrative, its anecdotal prog ress offers some lowkeyed di version.

title: Aide to Lindsay Is Landlord of Yankee Stadium
description: Don Evans, an aide to Mayor Lindsay who has served in various oddjob capacities, in cluding as an advance man in the city and as a political work er in the defunct Lindsay Presi dential campaign, has been quietly named as the city's landlord representative at Yan kee Stadium.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: If by his title the author means to imply that the history of the Pacific Northwest is ob scure, he has a pointand he does something about it. In this wideranging history, with an approach more evocative than chronological, he conveys the brooding, rainsoaked beauty of the region. A number of forgotten characters are revived, and especially inter esting is a chapter on North west writers which masterfully describes how the land was refracted through their imagi nations. There is some very good writing on salmon desper ately trying to spawn in too warm waters, also on the great storms that provide such a dramatic backdrop to the peo ple who have made the North west what it is.

title: The Man Who Struck It Rich With Bonanza
description: THE deep, gutsy, Vitamin E voice comes over loud and clear on the telephone from Cali fornia. It is the patriarch of the Ponderosa, the father's fatherLorne Greeneand he is setting the record straight about his recent hos pitalization. Some news reports had labeled his ill ness a heart attack. Others said it was gastric distress. But no matter what it was, it had the NBC brass trembling about their 14yearold, highly rated gold mine, Bonanza, which is now down to only two of the original Cartwright family since Dan (Hoss) Blocker died last May of a blood clot in the lung.

title: Soviet Replying Vigorously on Emigration Tax
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 7It was the turn of the next speaker at a meeting of Moscow citizens convened to denounce Western critics of the Soviet Union's education tax on emigrants.

title: Season Underway For Bow Hunters
description: LINDENIn a onetime bowling alley here, 45 peo ple watched intently the oth er night as Richard Gage fired four arrows into the chest of a cardboard deer.

title: Susan Swords, C. H. Stevens 3d Have Nuptials
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 7In Trinity Episcopal Church this afternoon, Miss Susan Swords became the bride of Carle ton Hickox Steven 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stevens Jr. of Branford. The bride's parents ate Mr. and Mrs. Gerard S. Swords of New Haven.

title: The Nation
description: When Juan Corona was arrested in May, 1971, in the slaying of 25 itin erant farm workersthe largest mass murder in the nation's history the authorities offered no motive. And at the opening of the trial last week in Fairfield, Calif., the prosecutor, Bartley Williams, said that the state had no re sponsibility to establish motive. Mo tive is not part of the crime, he said. If you have it, fine; if not, fine.

title: Clouds Over This Year's Apple Harvest
description: CLAVERACK, N. Y.  The summer of 1972 has been the worst growing season I ever saw.

title: Favorecidian Captures $21,575 Walter Haight Handicap by Nose at Laure
description: LAUREL, Md., Oct. 7Fa vored Favorecidian defeated Laplander in a torrid stretch today, but had to withstand both a stewards' inquiry and jockey's objection before he was officially declared the winner of the $21,575 Walter Haight Handicap at Laurel Race Course.

title: With raisins and nuts and hobgoblins
description: Halloween, almost upon us, is a children's holiday. And this ginger bread can be made by youngsters, with a little parental coaching. The decora tions shown here were executed in butter cream by two grownup artists, Jennifer Bartlett and Robert Israel, but the technique is simplejust mix and squeeze. The result is less lasting though more edible than Crayolas.

title: World News Briefs
description: OSLO, Norway, Oct. 7De feated in a referendum on the Common Market issue the La hor Government of Premier Trygve Bratelli stepped down today, and tile small Christian People's party said it would try to replace it in an antimar ket coalition with the Liberals and the Center party.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Nancy E. Meisenhelter Married to Thomas F. Leddy
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., Oct. 7 Miss Nancy Elizabeth Mel senhelter and Thomas Francis Leddy were married here this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer by the Rev. Timothy Pickering. The Rev. Joseph Maher as sisted.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 7The only question left on con struction of a deepwater ter minal off the Texas coast is who is going to operate it.

title: Press
description: NEWARK  When Superior Court Judge H. Curtis Meanor sent reporter Peter J. Bridge to Essex County jail last week for refusing to answer ques tions for a grand jury, he told the newsman, The keys to the jail are in your pocket. All Mr. Bridge had to do to regain his freedom was to cooper ate with the grand jury investigating allegations of corruption in the Newark Housing Authority.

title: SMEAR CAMPAIGN CHARGED BY G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7A formal complaint alleging that the Democratic Presidential and VicePresidential candidates are conducting a defamatory cam paign against President Nin has been filed with the Fair Campaign Practices Commit tee by the Republican Congres leadership.

title: It a World Away And Yet Quite Close
description: FOR those with passes or permis sion, the trim little ferryboat Pvt. Nicholas Minue makes the crossing from the more populous neighboring island every quarter hour, and though the trip takes only seven minutes, the ferry, docks in a distant world.

title: Education
description: Equal opportunity just does not exist on the campus currently. In a curious way, the college and uni versity seem less enthusiastic than almost any other major component of society in doing something about the inequities.

title: Marriage Planned
description: LLOYD HARBOR, L. I, Oct. 7Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Malone have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Teresa Malone, to David Williams Tilney, son of Dr,. and Mrs. Robert Wallace Tilney Jr. of Far Hills, N. J., and Northeast Harbor, Me.

title: POLL FINDS ISSUES NOT AT ISSUE IN '72
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The issues, political polls strongly suggest, are not at issue in the 1972 Presidential campaign.

title: U.S.C. VANQUISHES STANFORD, 3021
description: STANFORD, Calif., Oct. 7 (AP)  Southern California, helped by a bad center snap, cracketva tie at the end of the first half, and then Pat Haden, the sophomore quarterback, ran and passed the Trojans to a 3021 victory over its Pacific 8 Conference nemesis, Stan ford, today.

title: Miss Cochran Wed To David S. Larkin
description: COTUIT, Mass., Oct. 7 Miss Susan Evarts Cochran, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William D. Cochran of Wes ton, was married at her fam ily's summer home here this afternoon to David Seymour Larkin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles L. Larkin Jr. of Mid dlebury, Conn. The Rev. Har ry Hoehier of the Unitarian Church of Weston and his wife, also an ordained min ister officiated at the cere moy, which they and the bridal couple wrote.

title: Boston College Wins, 2120, As Villanova Rally Fails
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., Oct. 7 (AP)  Boston College scored in each of the first three quarters and held off a lastquarter Vil lanova rally today to beat the Wildcats, 2120.

title: Pirates, A's Win Playoff Openers
description: Al Oliver drove in three runs with a home run and a triple to lead the Pirates to a 51 triumph over the Cin cinnati Reds at Pittsburgh yesterday in the first game of the National League base ball playoff.

title: Federal Funds Helping Princeton TeenAgers to Run Club
description: PRINCETONA group of Princeton High School teen agers are planning organiz ing and conducting their own activities with the aid of an $8,000 grant from the Depart ment of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: YUGOSLAVIA LOSES TO HUNGARY IN CHESS
description: SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 7 Hungary today defeated Yu goslavia 2 to 1 in one of the crucial matches of the chess Olympics here.

title: Mrs. Hall Married To James Snedecor
description: Mrs. Virginia Mary Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Hall of Montclair, N. J., was married here yes terday afternoon to James Young Snedecor, son of Mrs. Helen Y. Snedecor of Toledo and the late Kenneth Snede cor. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read performed the ceremo ny in the Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Her Budget Cut, Teacher Shifts Gears
description: PRINCETON  When the Littlebrook School here was forced to cut its budget four years ago, field trips for kindergarten and firstgrade children were eliminated. Evelyn Saldick, a petite but determined teacher who be lieves in field trips and a very direct approach to teaching, found a way to beat the budget after three years of frustration; she learned to drive a bus.

title: Religion
description: Since the earliest days of the Christian Church, Christians have periodically speculated that the Second Coming of Christ was imminent. Some sects, like the Millerites, have even gone to the extent of selling their worldly goods and taking to the moun tains to await the end. Now, despite the record of past prophets, the idea is having a major revival.

title: ATLANTA ORDERED TO DESEGREGATE
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 7 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, declaring Atlanta's school system vir tually totally segregated, or dered the city yesterday to put a desegregation plan into operation in seven weeks.

title: The Week That Was
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7It was a bad week in Washington for the public interest.

title: AUBURN CONQUERS MISSISSIPPI, 1913
description: JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 9 (UPI) Randy Walls, a sophomore quarterback, ran for one third quarter touchdown and passed for another today to lead Au burn to a 1913 upset over Mississippi.

title: CALIFORNIA COAST IS ELECTION ISSUE
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7 Thirtyone bicyclists led by a topranking state legislator have just finished a 600mile trip over half the length of California, not for exercise but to rally support in the latest of the nation's battles over state land use control.

title: Ellen C. Mayer Married Here
description: Miss Ellen Cecile Mayer, daughter of Mrs. James H. Durgin of New York and the late Frank J. Mayer, was mar ried here yesterday morning to Harold James Diamond, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stan ley Diamond of Bellerose, Queens, and Sandisfield, Mass.

title: Exeter Triumphs, 2913
description: EXETER, N. H., Oct. 7With Randy Lombardo rushing for more han 100 yards for the second consecutive game, Ex eter won for the second time, 2913, today from the Bowdoin freshmen. Lombardo ran 14 and 34 yards for scores and caught a pass from Doug Brothers for a 25yard scoring play.

title: Keystone Pat Scores
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 7 (AP) Keystone Pat won the $10,000 Lafayette Pace at Freehold Raceway by half a length to day, covering the mile in 2:08 25 and returning $6.40 straight.

title: East GermanIndian Ties
description: BERLIN, Sunday, Oct. 8 (Agence FrancePresse)East Germany and India have estab lished diplomatic relations at the ambassadorial level effect ive today, an official commu niqu announced early today. The existing missions in East Berlin and New Delhi will be come embassies, the announce ment said.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CORNELL DEFEATS RUTGERS, 36 TO 22
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 7 Speedy John McKeown blocked two punts and a field goal to propel Cornell to a 3622 vice tory over Rutgers today.

title: AMHERST IS VICTOR OVER A.I.C. BY 217
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 7 (AP)Rick Murphy hit on 10 of 17 passes for 111 yards and one touchdown today and carried the ball in for another score as Amherst defeated American International College, 217.

title: MORMONS UPHOLD CHOICE OF LEADER
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 7 A solemn assembly unanimous ly upheld the appointment of Harold B. Lee as 11th prophet and president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latterday Saints this weekend as church members crowded this city for their 142d semiannual general conference.

title: Heels Lift Men's Shoe Sales
description: High heels, platform soles and multicolored leathers and synthetics are the biggest hit in the men's shoe business these days. That's right, men'snot women'sshoes.

title: Art
description: WHEN first encount ered, the art of alien cultures  especially if it bears some visual affinity to our own art is always a doubleedged experience. We are at once surprised and comforted by the obvious parallels, and all the more so if the culture in question is regarded as primitive. For we like to have our own cultural as sumptions confirmed by a sense of ontological neces sity. It gives our timebound, historyhaunted preoccupa tions an added dimension. It allows us to feel that we, too, are participants in a uni versal enterprise, and have not lost touch with the pri mordial impulse.

title: Law
description: In 1846 New York State changed its method of selecting judges. Up to that time, they had been appointed by the Governor with the approval of the Senate; now they were to be elected along with all other state of ficers.

title: Sexual discrimination?
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut's Kick at Finish Tops New Hampshire, 107
description: DURHAM, N. H., Oct. 7 (AP) Bob Innis kicked a 22yard field goal with 2 minutes 41 seconds left to give Connecticut a 107 victory over New Hamp shire today.

title: U.S.E.T. Coach Continues to Work Horses Daily
description: Horse Show News

title: STOLLE IN FINAL OF TOKYO TENNIS
description: TOKYO, Oct. 7 (AP)Fred Stolle upset John Newcombe, 16, 63, 63, today on the eve of Stolle's 34th birthday and advanced to the final of the $33,222 World Championship Tennis Tokyo tournament against 37yearold Ken Rose wall, who eliminated Cliff Richey, 60, 76.

title: L.I. Is Hurt by Shellfish Scare
description: NORTHPORT, L.I.  Fear of the red tide, a poisonous algae affecting soft clams and mussels in limited areas off Massachusetts and Maine, is severely hurting sales of fish from Long Island wa ters which are not affected.

title: New & Novel
description: The Dear Ruin is an oc cult joke played on a wealthy widow of 50, who consults a witch on the Riviera for her geriatric problem. Poor Hebe Morrison fares no better than Dr. Faustus, or Aldous Hux ley's immortalityhunter in Af ter Many a Summer Dies the Swan, who met a similar des tiny under more complicated circumstances. Entertaining.

title: Vicky Clarke Wed to James C. Linville
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 7 Miss Doris White Clarke, was married here this afternoon to James Coker Linville, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Edwin Linville of Scars dale, N. Y. The Rev. Brad ford Hastings performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: A Test of a Motorist's Mettle
description: MANHASSET, L. I.  A workman stood in front of thte corner gas station, gaz ing across Plandome Road in disbelief. An elderly woman and her even more elderly mother wandered, perplexed, back and forth on the other side. An elegant gent strode by them to No. 519, halted, backed off and stared.

title: OBSERVER
description: One vice of newspaper columns is their refusal to keep quiet for a few minutes and let somebody else get a word in. Yet the world has always been filled with people other than journalists who are far more literate than trenchant. Unfortunately, many of them are printed only in books and, therefore, have little access to the American public. In the cause of par ticipatory journalism, therefore, we relinquish this space today to a few of these interesting men to comment on contemporary American issues,

title: The foodgathering life
description: The following account of a day with the Tasaday was included in a report to the Pancunin Foundation entitled The Tasa day: Cavedwelling Food Gatherers of South Cotabato, Mindanao. It was pre pared by Carlos A. Fernandez 2d and Frank Lynch, S. J.

title: WASTE DISPOSAL TIED TO MARKETS
description: The top Federal official for solidwaste programs has said that stimulating new markets for waste through revised tax laws, freight rates and even subsidies for reused materials is more important now than just looking for new disposal technology.

title: Coast Guard Sinks Norwich
description: NORTHFIELD, Vt, Oct. 7 (AP)Coast Guard built a 13 point lead in the first quarter today and then held off a late rally by Norwich to post a 206 victory In the 38th re newal of the little ArmyNavy game.

title: Art
description: WASHINGTON, D. C.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: It was a meaningful mo ment and the some 100 neat and trim businessmen gath ered for lunch at the Prince ton Club knew it. They had something in common, these menall had begun their business lives by going through General Electric training programs before moving on to other things.

title: Top, Whizzer White in 1937, the allAmerica Colorado halfback. Bottom, White, with admirer, as a 21yearold Rhodes Scholar at Oxford in 1939.
description: Byron White was born in 1917 in Fort Collins, Colo., but grew up in Wellington, a tiny town in a sugarbeet growing area near the Wyoming border. His father, who had not finished high school, was branch manager for a lumber supply company and, for a while, mayor. White worked in the beet fields and on section crews for the Colorado and Southern Railroad.

title: Brown's 5 Field Goals Turn Back Penn, 2820
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 7 Brown University, a team that had ben plagued by numerous mistakes in two previous genies this season, made a complete turnabout today, forcing Penn sylvania into seven errers that led to a 2820 victory.

title: 2 Brooklyn Rabbis Fined For Running Bogus School
description: Two Brooklyn rabbis who had withdrawn pleas of guilty to operating a bogus mailorder university again pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Brooklyn Friday and received suspended sentences and $250 fines.

title: News of the Rialto
description: THE Broadway season has barely begun and already, it is clear that it is not going tobe the happiest one for male chauvinists. Just look at what's go ing on. List month Joseph Papp brought Jason Miller's That Championship. Season uptown and a sorry lot of specimens that allmale cast displays. Then there is Michael Cacoyannis directing his modernized version of tysistrata, with Mlina Mercouri in the title role. And that one is Aristophanes's antiwar comedy in which men are made to look like dolts. Now a communiqu informs us that all Is in readiness for the delivery of The Women, the 1936 comedy in which Clare Boothe Luce not only took a rather acerbic view of her own sex but also disclosed what they generally had to say about their opposites when they got together, behind the closed doors of beauty salons, maternity rooms and boudoirs. The Women made a lot of fellows uncom fortable back there in the thirties, made Mrs. Luce famous and made a lot of money for its producer, Max Gordon, running 637 performances.

title: Yorkville Synagogue Marks 100th Year, Rabbi His 50th With Congregation
description: The lives of Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its scholarly spiritual leader, Rabbi Joseph H. Lookstein, have been entwined for a half century.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: WACHIPAUKA POND, Glen cliff, N. H.Chipmunks and red squirrels clamored from the forest about the pond, and when the rising sun bathed the western shore ruffed grouse clucked as they fed on beechnuts and bunch berries

title: Miss McMahon Married
description: Miss Katherine V. Mc Mahon, daughter of Mrs. Rog er F. P. McMahon of Doug laston, Queens, and the late Mr. McMahon, was married yesterday in St. Anastasia Roman Catholic Church, Douglaston, to William J. Zaremba, son of Mr. and Mrs. Felix Zaremba of Sands Point, L. I.

title: Teaneck Recreation Center Aids Youths and the Elderly
description: TEANECK  The Teaneck Recreation Center opened here last week, after many years of drearning, a year of planning and eight months of hard work.

title: Letters To The Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Gardens
description: Bulb planting is in full swing; plant the little, early spring ones first; daffodils, tulips and hya cinths may be planted as late as Election Day. . . . Mow new lawns if grass is three inches tall.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Brian Garfield's DEATH WISH (McKay, $4.95) is a fan tasy of our times, bound up with a senseless crime indig enous to big cities. Hopheads invade an apartment, kill a wo man (having a good time about it) and frighten another women into eventual catatonia. The husbands of the two women have to pick up their lives. One of them decides to become an avenger. Not only for himself but for society.

title: Home Improvement
description: PTLASTIC pipe, first put to widespread use during and immedi ately after World War U, is being used more, and more in home plumbing systemsfor new construc tion, as well as for altera tions and additions. Unfortu nately, outdated and anti quated building codes still do not allow its use inside the house in many communities, but in those areas where these restrictions no longer exist, plastic pipe offers many advantages over metal pipe in home plumbing.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: The nowforgotten 191920 war (neither of the protago nist likes to remember it) be tween Poland and Russia ac tually cast long shadows. The Poles under Marshall Pilsudski, with their highflying cavalry, defeated the poorly supplied and exhausted Russians. Lenin, having no stomach for another winter of war, made peace. The Russians withdrew behind their borders, and hopes that the Red Army would be the agent of revolution in Europe were dropped in favor of Lenin's New Economic Policy. Mr. Davies says that the war con tributed to the replacing of Trotsky's International Com munism by Stalin's brand of Russiafirst. The Poles, for their part, developed an overween ing confidence in their invul nerability, a delusion that was shattered in 1939. This is an interesting job of historical writing, both in its superior excavation of events from ob scure archives and in connect ing these events to the main stream of history.

title: Music: North Patchogue Fire Department Band Is Getting Ready for a Hot Season Next Year
description: NORTH PATCHOGUE, L. I. A couple of weeks ago, Eugene J. Romeo made his annual trip to Plainview to buy new music for the North Patchogue Fire Department Band, He came back with a stack of scores that included Herb Alpert arrangements, songs from Broadway musi cals,' Dixieland pieces, even Richard Rodgers' Slaughter on Tenth Avenue.

title: Fame and Power Wins $79,975 Illinois Derby
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) Fame and Power, owned by Harvey Peltier of Thibodeux, La., took the lead after six furlongs today and won the $79,975 Illinois Derby by al most four lengths at Sports mans Park.

title: MANHATTAN FOUR WINS IN ROWING
description: PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Oct. 7Manhattan College took ad vantage of a flooding tide to win the varsity fouroared race in the Columbus Day Regatta of the New York Rowing As sociation today. The water was three feet above normal on the Orchard Beach Lagoon but re mained relatively calm in the 25mileperhour tailwind.

title: If You Go ...
description: ...to Governors Island you will first need written permission from: Commanding Officer (A6), U.S. Coast Guard Base, Governors Is ]and, New York 10004. Groups of 15 to 45 persons are provided with a guide. Individuals and groups of fewer than 15 are supplied with maps of the island and given the opportunity to roam at will.

title: U.S. JOINING ILLINOIS IN SUIT ON POLLUTION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) The Justice Department and Illinois joined yesterday in fil ing a civil pollution suit against the United States Steel Corpora tion to prevent, discharges from its Waukegan, Ill., plant into Lake Michigan. It is the first such joint Federalstate pollu tion suit ever flied.

title: PRELATE TO HONOR MARTYR IN POLAND
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7  John Cardinal Krol, the Arch bishop of Philadelphia, will go to Poland Tuesday for final ceremonies in the yearlong beatification of the Rev. Maxi milian Kolbe, a Polish martyr killed by the Nazis.

title: Office Rentals Increasing in Bergen
description: HACKENSACK  Tenants are starting to trickle into. new office buildings in Ber gen County, many of which stood deserted  like high rise ghost townsduring the last year.

title: TANZANIA, UGANDA AGREE TO END STRIFE
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tan zania, Oct. 7 (Reuters)Tan zania and Uganda have agreed to end hostilities and to pull all forces back from their com mon border by Oct. 19.

title: Environment
description: Corn, the most extensively harvested crop in the United States and the food staple for most of Latin America, is being threatened on two fronts, ac cording to reports issued in recent weeks:

title: Sagamore Toccoa Captures 36th BestinShow Honors at Bryn Mawr Event
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., Oct. 7 A silverbuff cocker spaniel, who answers to the name of Bunny, sloshed through the sticky going on rainsoaked Recreation Field today to take her 36th bestinshow trophy when she led a field of 2,206 in the Devon Dog Show Associ ation's 60th fixture.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 7 (AP) East Carolina's unbeaten team took command of the Southern Conference football race today with a 210 victory over Richmond's defending champions on the running of Carlester Crumpler and a vi cious defense.

title: Mrs. Brod Has Child
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon J. Brod of Riverdale, the Bronx, on Sept. 22 at the Albert Ein stein Hospital in the Bronx. The child has been named Rachel Lisa.

title: Davis Excels as Alabama Defeats. Georgia, 257
description: ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 7 (AP) Terry Davis passed for one touchdown and scored another following long third  period drives yesterday as thirdranked Alabama defeated Georgia, 257 in a Southeastern Conference football game.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTONPresident Nixon, who has promised a generation of peace in international affairs is bid ding to become a peace can didate in the field of labor management relations as well.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTON  A leading spe cialist in Soviet affairs told a sym posium the other day that it is now Love Story between the United States and the Soviet Union. But, he added, let us pray that this time there will be no unhappy ending. For serious political and emotional prob lems remain to be resolved.

title: Cancer Cure Reports Irk Scientists
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  A widely reported new cancer cure, which no scientist really had or even said he had, cast a shadow over an international scientific conference that just ended here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: C,C,N.Y. DEDICATES SCIENCE BUILDING
description: Dr. Robert E. Marshak, the president of the City College of New York, yesterday dedicated his school's new 14story Sci ence Hall to the students.

title: U.S. JUDGE BACKS LIE DETECTOR USE
description: DETROIT, Oct. 7A United States District Court has ruled here that the results of a lie detector test can be admitted as evidence in the perjury trial of a suspended Detroit police man. Defense and Justice De partment lawyers believed it to be the first such ruling by a United States Federal Court.

title: Art Show in Trenton Flashes, Pings and Thumps
description: TRENTON  Keeping up with the avantgarde in art is always a difficult task, but the State Museum is making a valiant stab with its latest exhibition, The Responsive Environment, which opened on Saturday, Sept. 30, and runs until Nov. 26.

title: Miss Allison Maitland Cookiey Is Betrothed to Larry T. Hyland
description: MANASSAS, Va., Oct. 7 Maj. Gen. Howard Harrison Cooksey, commander of the Army's First Regional Assist ance Command in Vietnam, and Mrs. Cooksey have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Allison Maitland Cooksey,. to Larry Thomas Hyland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hyland of Betterton, Md.

title: Indiana Beats Syracuse, 102 in Driving Rain
description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 7Indiana University's highscoring of fense, hampered by a heavy rain, managed to make one touchdown run and set up a field goal for enough to beat Syracuse, 102, today before 18,444 persons in Archbold Stadium.

title: Canucks Beat Seals, 32
description: CANCOUVER, British Colum bia, Oct. 7 (UPI)  Bobby Lalonde scored the winning goal on a secondperiod power play as the Vancouver Cauncks opened their season with a 32 victory over the California Golden Seals tonight.

title: Most Adults in Nassau Completed High School
description: Twothirds of the adults over the age of 25 in Nassau County have completed at least four years of high school, according to the Cen sus Bureau.

title: Great Lakes Powwow Stresses Indian Awareness in Dances and Meetings
description: MARQUETTE, Mich., Oct. 7 With two black braids swing ing above the shoulders of his bright red jacket, Dickey Laugh ing, a Mohawk from Akwesasne in upstate New York, stomp danced around the ground floor of the Holiday Inn here.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: New & Novel
description: Five priests, members of an obscure order, decide to leave the seminary and set up a radi cal commune in a twofamily house. (The other half of the premises is occpied by a Bos ton policeman, wife, motherin law and two depraved sons.) What this has to do with clang birds, what they are, you will have to discover from the author's whimsical epigraph. From me, you can have the dis closure that it is a bitterly fun ny onceover of relevancy and religion. After a year of pro test, the score is relevancy 2; religion 3, two priests having left the church. On the other hand, a nonCatholic is taking instruction, mainly because of an affair she has had with a straying member of the com mune.

title: PENN STATE WINS 3D IN ROW, 3517
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 7 (AP) Penn State's John Hufnagel and John Capelletti led a 28 point firsthalf explosion and a 3517 intersectional football victory over Illinois today.

title: FIGHTING SPREADS CLOSER SAIGON; B52'S RAID NORTH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Oct. 8Fighting spread in an area from only nine to 20 miles northof Saigon this weekend as Communist forces around the South Vietnamese capital pressed an apparently new phase in their sixmonth old offensive.

title: Woodmere Wins, 1412
description: WOODMERE, L. I., Oct. 7 Allen Margolis and Bob Wal lace, linebackers for Woodmere, each made key tackles today to prevent conversion attempts and permit Woodmere to hang on to a 1412 decision over St. Paul's. Woodmere has now won three straight for a 31 record. St. Paul's has an 03 mark.

title: Wisconsin Defeats Northwestern, 2114, as Ferguson Rushes for 197 Yards
description: MADISON, Wis., Oct. 7 (UPI)Rufus (Roadrunner) Fer guson rushed for 197 yards and broke the Wisconsin career scoring record of Alan Ameche with two touchdowns today in a 2114 Badger Big Ten tri umph over Northwestern.

title: R. H. Lafferandre to Wed Mary Maxson
description: EAST ISLIP, L.I., Oct. 7 The engagement of Miss Mary Leslie Maxson to Rob ert Halsey Lafferandre, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hal sey Lafferandre of Sayville, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Leslie Max son of East Islip and Pom pano Beach, Fla.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: A massive symposium on the ecological effects of interna tional development programs. Most of the papers study in dividual cases and argue that the impact of many programs, ranging from the manufactwre of powdered milk to the build ing of the Aswan Dam, have done more harm than good. The conclusion is that there was too little effort to evaluate eco logical factors when these pro grams were being planned. Fresh questions are raised here, since the general assumption has been that only advanced nations offend against nature.

title: Raiders Strike in Pnompnh
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 7 (AP)  Enemy infiltrators struck at this capital today with the most spectacular at tack since the Indochina war came to Cambodia two and a half years ago.

title: The Shredder: the End of the Road for 200,000 Cars a Year
description: JERSEY CITY  A clump of orange and black barn like structures at the foot of Linden Avenue is the end of the, line for 200,000 cars a year.

title: BLASS IS WINNER
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 7  The Pittsburgh Pirates, the defend ing champions of baseball, de feated the Cincinnati Reds, 51, today in the opening game of the National League playoff.

title: Gardens
description: TULIPS, pride of Dutch growers and joy of many home gardeners, were once truly wild. Years of hybridization have wrought many changes in the miniature forms that survive in only a few botanical tulips.

title: Northeastern Ground Game Puts Hofstra to Rout, 286
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Oct. 7 Northeastern University's run ning attack, led by it freshman, Keven Foley, and a sophomore, Chris Aylward, routed Hofstra today, 286. Foley ran for 70 yards and one touchdown, while Aylward gained 54 yards and scored touchdowns on runs of 5, 3 and 6 yards.

title: Approach to the Queens Tunnel Is Due for Repairs
description: A bill authorizing more than $3million for rehabili tation of the Queens Mid town Tunnel viaduct is scheduled to be considered by the Board of Estimate this week.

title: SOVIET TOPRATED IN SERBIAN POLL
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 7A recent survey of opinion in Yugoslavia's Serbian republic suggests that histori cal bonds and sentiment are more durable and influential than the zigzags of politics and propaganda in shaping basic attitudes.

title: Art Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Nine Lies About America
description: Deceit, deceit, everywhere deceitbut especially on the political and cultural left, says Arnold Beichman, and most out rageously in the writings of the youth lovers (Marcuse, Slater, Sontag, Roszak, Reich and the rest). They say America is al ready a fascist country or is on the road to fascism, that the country is guilty of genocide, that the Bomber Left ... is a moral force They claim the white American worker ... is a retrograde, decadent, self ish creature: a honky, that our political system is an ut ter fraud, particularly the two party system, that American values are wholly materialistic, that America is insane, and that our primary need is for a violent revolution.

title: Maryland Triumps, 230
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md,, Oct. 7 (UPI)Maryland's quarterback, Al Neville, ran 25 yards for one touchdown and passed 9 yards for another in leading the Terps to a 230 victory over Wake Forest today.

title: Bill on Flood Control Is Gaining
description: TRENTON  Assembly Speaker Thomas J. Keah pre dicts that the Cahill admin istration will have enough votes to push its version of a controversial floodplains pro posal through the Assembly when it convenes for its fall session next month.

title: SHOP TALK
description: FANWOODNo one driv ing down South Avenue, this borough's main street, would guess that Fanwood has shops where browsing is worthwhile.

title: The Buckley rapierand how it is honed
description: Only an oxymoron (as Wil liam F. Buckley would say), or a numbskull (a word I prefer) would attempt a comprehen sive review of this volume of essays, interviews and columns. Culled from his writings over a threeyear period, and deal ing with all imaginable (and some unimaginable) topics, they provide a quite revealing in sight into what might be called the new Buckley. To sum marize, Bill Buckley has aban doned the task of trying to for mulate a coherent theory of conservatism and has settled for inveighing against the so called liberal Establishment.

title: Stanley J. Bauer, 58, Dies; ExRepublican State Senator
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 7 (UPI)  Former Republican State Senator Stanley J. Bauer was found dead in his room at the Touraine Hotel Thursday. He was 58 years old.

title: Wrong Teams Seem to Win Big Ones
description: About Pro Football

title: WASHINGTON STAR GAINING READERS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  Sharp increases in both circu lation and advertising have brought a wave of optimism to the pool of red ink at The Evening Star and Daily News, Washington's only remaining afternoon newspaper.

title: Sophia C. Maxon Lawyer's Fiancee
description: MUNCIE, Ind., Oct. 7 Mr. and Mrs. Harry Russell Maxon Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sophia Cot trell Maxon, to Dana Tarbell Ackerly 2d of Washington, son of Mrs. E. Tremain Brad ley of New Canaan, Conn., and Dana C. Ackerly of Southport, Conn., and New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I appreciate very much be ing the recipient of the kind remarks contained in the ar ticle Edward Duren Stone Finds the Universal Pays [Sept. 10].

title: New & Novel
description: Is another Goodbye, Mr. Chips what the world is wait ing for? The late R. F. Delder field evidently thought so, and his judgment has thus far been impeccable. So here is a schoolmaster's cavalcade of En gland between World Wars, told in the author's best stand up style, and rife with episodes designed to pluck at the heart strings.

title: KnifeWielding Is Reported Common at Site of a Midtown Slaying
description: The tall, bespectacled youth rushed into Grant's grill just off Times Square yesterday after noon, waving a gleaming switchblade.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: He calls himself a techno crat and, while accurate, this is also a modestly misleading characterization for Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani of Saudi Arabia.

title: WALL STREET
description: Browsing through the elec tronic calculators on display at so many department stores these days can be an edifying experience, especially if you are in the market for stocks instead of calculators.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SISSETON, S.D.In one of theft: rare childhood squab bles, George McGovern so provoked his sister Olive about 40 years ago that she vowed she would vote against him when he ran for Pres ident. Even the spats contri buted to the boy's selfesteem.

title: Black Concern to Sell Juice
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Oct. 7 (Reuters)A new company has been organized to market Florida citrus products aimed at black consumers, The company, Soul Delight Products, Inc., with headquarters here, will market canned orange and grapefruit juices.

title: ABORTION BACKERS HOPEFUL OF GAINS
description: DETROIT, Oct. 8Proabor tion forces believe they are on the verge of major victories that will soon make abortion on request available throughout much of the country.

title: Procrustean Bed
description: The national budget forces a President to translate his political and social philosophy into hard arithmetic terms. Mr. Nixon took office four years ago as a budget balancer. But, following the recession of 196970 which his policies helped to induce, Mr. Nixon announced that he had become a Keynesian; he proceeded to pile up budget deficits in excess of $80 billion in an effort to restore the economy to high employment before the 1972 election.

title: Deserters Find Sweden a Home
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 28 Ask Robert L. Angelo, who deserted the Army more than four years ago, when he was home last and he fidgets a moment, looks around his of fice above one of Stockholm's main streets and says; This morning.

title: The Navy Game
description: WASHINGTONAs the war in Viet nam begins to, close out for us and we strive for a zero draft, I can see where it is going to become more and more difficult for the military service to ac quire the talents tit will need. Depend ing on the economic situation in the country, it is difficult for me to see how, the military can attract the smart high school, graduate. He can easily attend college now that they are so accessible and he can find a reasonable paying job without a great deal of difficulty. What incentive, does he have to join the military, especially if the mood of the nation is antimilitary? What could easily happen is that the Military will attract those who either cannot make the grade in a civilian environment or do not want to exert the effort in a sense, the military could become a large Government spohsored social correction agency.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Writer Weds Rona Schwab
description: CARMEL, N. Y., Oct. 8 Miss Rona Schwab, an as sistant psychologist at Mon tefiore Hospital in the Bronx, was married here this after noon to Michael Knight, a reporter for The New York Times, Rabbi Philip Schecter of the New Morning Com munity Congregation in New York performed the cere mony at the Dreamwold Inn.

title: MRS. LEO ROSENBERG
description: Mrs. Florence W. Rosenberg, wife of Leo H. Rosenberg, the first broadcaster to send elec tion returns over the air, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hos pital. She was 73 years old and lived at 308 East 79th Street.

title: The Brooklyn Tree Finds a Friend
description: The Ailanthus, a much maligned tree with a long list of enemies (most of whom call it a contemptible weed) has found a new and important friend  the New York. Botanical Garden.

title: WILLIAM O. KAISER
description: William O. Kaiser, who re tired several years ago as vice president of Kaiser Men's Ap parel, Inc., 408 Sixth Avenue, died Wednesday in Hollywood, Fla., at the age of 64.

title: Pnompenh Is Fearful After Raid Within City
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 8 (Reuters)Fears of a new enemy offensive dam pened the holiday spirits of residents of this capital as Cambodia prepared to cele brate its second anniversary as a republic tomorrow.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Mrs. Kay Worden is a Weston, Mass., housewife Who feels deeply about the Vietnam war. During the Republican convention she put a mildlyphrased advertisement tin The Miami Herald asking people to write to President Nixon about the war. She also took a room in the Hotel Fontainebleau and said in the ad that she would be there to talk to anyone interested.

title: Patrolman Is Shot, 13 Suspects Seized In Harlem Incident
description: A patrolman investigating a complaint that a man had been pistolwhipped, threatened with a knife and robbed at a Harlem social club was shot in the right shoulder early yesterday as he and another patrolman tried to enter the club.

title: WelfareJob Law Stirs Bitterness and Confusion
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  Workfare, the controversial concept of a new law forcing welfare recipients to take jobs, has generated tremendous bit terness and confusion in the three months since the Federal measure took effect.

title: Andrea Green Wed
description: FREEPORT, L. I., Oct. 8 Miss Andrea F. Green, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Green of Merrick, was mar ried here this afternoon to Ronald B. Schuman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Schuman of Cedarhurst. Rabbi Ronald Goldstein performed the cer emony in the Union Reform Temple.

title: MRS. FELIX M. WOLSKY
description: Mrs. Ruth Fish Wolsky, office manager of the Martin Adver tising Agency, 15 East 40th Street, and wife of Felix M. Wolsky, owner of the agency, died Friday in Beth Israel Hos pital. She was 75 years old and lived at 939 Woodycrest Ave nue, the Bronx.

title: ExSenator Prescott Bush Dies; Connecticut Republican Was 77
description: Prescott Bush, former United States Senator from Connecti cut and the father of George Bush, the United States repre sentative at the United Nations, died here yesterday afternoon at the Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. He was 77 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: CITY CHARTER UNIT PLANS FELL STUDY
description: The newly created state com mission to revise New York City's Charter will have broad powers, including subpoena powers, and will conduct a souptonuts reexamination of everything that makes the city tick, according to Senator Roy M. Goodman, the commissions's chairman.

title: KISSINGER MEETS HANOI AIDES AGAIN SECRETLY IN PARIS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 Henry A. Kissinger, the Presi dent's adviser on national secu rity, held another private meet ing in Paris today with North Vietnam's top negotiators. The White House said they would meet again tomorrow and left open the possibility of an un precedented third consecutive meeting on Tuesday.

title: Rep. Mink of Hawaii Wins Renomination to 5th Term
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 8United States Representative Patsy T. Mink easily won the Demo cratic nomination for her fifth term yesterday in the nation's last primary.

title: Schweitzer's Hospital at Lambarene Aiming to Specialize in Rehabilitation
description: LAMBARENE, Gabon, Oct. 4  Bordered by the wide Ogooue River and the thick, equatorial jungle, the Albert Schweitzer Hospital faces the same problems of change and of fundraising that many an urban health facility does.

title: 125,898 Fans Here Watch Giants Win and Jets Lose
description: New York was an autumn festival yesterday for pro football fans as both the Giants and Jets played home games. A total of 125,898 fans turned out at Yankee Stadium and Shea Stadium.

title: John Dienhart Sr., ExEditor Of Chicago Herald, 79, Dies
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 8 (AP) John Dienhart Sr., whose career in journalism spanned more than 60 years, died yes terday in a hospital here. He was 79 years old.

title: ENEMY REPORTED MOVING ON SAIGON BY A RIVER ROUTE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Oct. 9Fighting be tween Government troops and Communist guerrillas continued yesterday as close as 10 miles north of Saigon, but South Viet namese failed to dislodge the guerrillas from three hamlets they have controlled all week end, military spokesmen said.

title: Rosewall Wins in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Oct. 8 (AP) Ken Rosewall of Australia, making spectacular returns from all over the court, beat Fred Stolle, a fellow countryman, 75, 63, 6.3, in the final today of the $33,222 World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: Women Eligible for Award.
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 (AP) For the first time women will be eligible this year for the Philadelphia Junior Cham ber of Commerce Man of the Year award, the Jaycees presi dent, Thomas S. Rittenhouse said. He said that the Junior Chamber of Commerce, already under threat of expulsion from the national organization for allowing women into its ranks, will change the name of the award to The Outstanding Young Leader of the Year.

title: Campaneris, Hit by Pitch, Fires Bat at Hurler
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 8  John (Blue Moon) Odom threw a threehitter at the Detroit Tigers today, but it was a bat that Bert Campaneris threw at Lerrin LaGrow that ignited one of the most inflammatory in cidents of the 1972 baseball season.

title: Jobless Rate of 7.4% Is Highest in Decade
description: TRENTON, Oct, 8Though there are some signs of an economic pickup, unemploy ment in the state stands at 7.4 per cent of the work forceits highest point in more than a decade and well above the national figure of 5.5 per cent.

title: The Dance: Old Wine in New Bottles
description: The City Center Joffrey Ballet is continually chang ing. Dancers join, dancers leave, the repertory develops, the school program expands it is the most positive virtue of a theatrical institu tion that it can enjoy an organic life. The result is that each season the Joffrey Ballet is slightly different from the season before. It has a few new ballets, a few new dancers and quite a few dancers in roles.

title: BERNARD MEM PSYCHIATRIST, 88
description: BUTNER, N.C., Oct. 8Dr. Bernard Glueck, psychiatrist and psychoanalyst who testi fied in defense of Nathan F. Leopold and Richard Loeb in their trial for the thrill mur der of Bobby Franks in Chicago in 1924, died on Thursday. He was 88 years old and had lived here for eight years after suf fering a stroke in Chapel Hill, where he was on the faculty at the University of North Carolina Medical School.

title: Columbia Keeps Net Title
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 8 Columbia won its third straight title in the Eastern Intercol legiate Athletic Conference fall tennis championship that ended in Princeton's Jadwin Gym nasium today. The Lions scored 35 points. Penn State was runnerup with 31. Sixteen schools took part in the tour ney.

title: Auto Racer Is Killed
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Oct. 8 (UPI)Louis Wuster hausen, 36 years old, of Austin, Tex., was killed in an auto race here today. His car collided with one driven by Cleve Smith Qf Bloomington, Ill., on the third turn of the first lap on the two mile oval track.

title: Crash Toll in Mexico Is 208; Train Crew Faces Charges
description: SALTILLO, Mexico, Oct. 8 (UPI)Discovery of 32 more bodies raised to 208 today the number of people killed in the train disaster near here Thurs day night that the authorities say was caused by the irrepson sibility of a speeding and drink ing train crew.

title: Hispanic Adviser Replaces Cross as Youth Unit Head
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday named Mrs. Amalia V. Betanzos, his executive secretary and ad visor on Hispanic affairs, to re place Ted Gross as Youth Serv ices Commissioner. He resigned Saturday amid charges of ir regularities in his agency's budget.

title: Israeli Smuggling Suspect
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 8 (UPI) The police arrested a seventh suspect today in an attempt to smuggle grenades, rifles and submachine guns abroad last month for use in attacks against Arab guerrillas. He was identified as Vladimir Silver lieb, 24 years old, a new immi grant from the Soviet Union. Six other suspects, including the leader of the militant Jew ish Defense League, Rabbi Meir Kahane, have been released on bail.

title: Squeezing the Goose
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki al Yamani of Saudi Arabia, chief negotiator for five Persian Gulf oilproducing nations, has said of recently completed talks with nine Western oil companies that his aim was to squeeze the golden goose without killing it. Although details of the agree ment reached here last week have not been announced, it is evident that the squeeze is on.

title: Israelis on Front Line Watch Syrian BuildUp
description: SURMAN, IsraeliOccupied Syria, Oct. 6  From the Is raeli outpost overlooking the shattered ruins of this former Syrian village, the flat, brown plain stretches north and east to Damascus, some 40 miles away.

title: Rangers Lose 2d in Row As Hawks Triumph, 51
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 8The New York Rangers, beaten only once in their first 18 games last sea son, lost their second game in as many nights of the young National Hockey League season tonight, 51, to the Chicago Black Hawks.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The McGovern campaign plans to use Senator Thomas F. Eagle ton of Missouri in television commercials to confront the lin gering effects of his dismissal from the Democratic ticket.

title: KISSINGER MEETS HANOI AIDES AGAIN SECREUY IN PARIS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  Henry A. Kissinger, the Presi dent's adviser on national secu rity, held another private meet ing in Paris today with North Vietnam's top negotiators. The White House said they would meet again tomorrow and left open the possibility of an un precedented third consecutive meeting on Tuesday.

title: The heavy, unrelenting pressure the Israelis have put on U.S. Jewry to vote for Nixon is thoroughly demeaning.
description: What America needs most today is more democracy. By that I mean we need to bring everyone, particularly the presently powerless and underprivi legedJews most certainly included into the fullest possible participation In our economic and political life. Without this, I do not see America attaining the social stability and main taining the national power which permit us to exercise international leadership.

title: Garden Grows on 12th St. Rubble
description: To say that autumn is riot of color would be a clich. But not on Seventh Avenue at 12th Street.

title: MRS. STETTEN DEAD; CIVIC LEADER WAS 85
description: Mrs. Alice Mayer Stetten, a civic leader and widow of Dr. DeWitt Stetten, a surgeon, died Saturday at her home, 240 Central Park South. Her age was 85.

title: Italian Shoe Exports Decline as Costs Climb
description: ROME, Oct. 8  Signora, next year I will have to charge you almost 50 per cent more for shoes like these, said Ro berto, a midtown shoe sales man here, to a middleaged woman trying on a pair of blackleather sandals.

title: Jersey Expects to Have Open Admissions
description: New Jersey's Board of High er Education is expected to approve on Oct. 20 a new master plan that would guar antee admission to a com munity college to every resi dent of the state aged 18 or older.

title: Chou Names a Possible Successor
description: Premier Chou Enlai of China yesterday mentioned a high Communist party offi cial as a possible successor to Chairman Mao Tsetung and himself, a Knight News paper dispatch from Peking said.

title: MRS. CHARLES C. PARLIN
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Oct. 8 Mrs. Miriam Boyd Parlin, for many years a missionary in China, died Friday evening at her home, 123 Hillside Avenue. She was 72 years old.

title: Cattle Prices Are Rising
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) Cattle prices are rising after a summer slump but are $40 less a head than their July peak, the Department of Agriculture reported.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8De spite the prospect of a Repub lican sweep in the 1972 Presi dential race, Democrats appear likely to retain a slim majority in the Senate and a comfortable one in the House in the cur rent Congressional elections.

title: Soviet Is Keeping Up a vigilant Civil Defense Despite Arms Pacts With U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 8At the modernistic military bookstore on the broad Sadovoya Ring, a set of colored posters on the construction of fallout shelters is on display and available to anyone with 2 rubles and 60 kopecks, or $3.14 in his pocket.

title: Youth Aide, an Intimate of Poverty
description: Woman in the News

title: Pastrami City: A Day in the Life of a Delicatessen
description: There are 6,000 delicates sens in the Pastrami City, and they all have stories. This is the story of one of them:

title: REBROFF'S FLAIR ENHANCES SONGS
description: Ivan Rebroff is a man of par adoxes. A folk singer who started in opera, a basso whose voice can jump three octaves to the soprano range, a Soviet music specialist who sings those songs with a German ac cent (and who spent two years as Tevye in the Parisian Fid dler on the Roof), Mr. Rebroff has also managed to find a sim ultaneous best friend and worst enemy in electronic am plification.

title: Jericho Downs Brookville, 5.2, as Rizzo Leads Attack
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., Oct. 8Paul Rizzo scored two goals and led the Jericho polo team to a 52 triumph over Brookville today at Bethpage State Park.

title: Rus in Ube?
description: With their hearts in the right place but their judgment wrong, Bloomingdale's and the Parks Department are about to wreak the latest unnecessary damage on Central Park in the form of an entertainment pit on the Mall. How curiously the city chooses to celebrate Olmsted's sesquicentennial with proposals destructive the spirit and substance of his genius. How unfailingly inferior ideas are imposed as scars on his grand design. And how often facilities that should be temporary and movable become permanent blots on the landscape.

title: The Talk of Wenatchee
description: WENATCHEE, Wash., Oct. 5Around here, life is just a bowl of apples.

title: Stewart Takes U. S. Grand Prix
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Oct. 8Jackie Stewart of Scotland and his French teammate, Fran cois Cevert, turned an easy one, two victory today in the United States Grand Prix.

title: U.S. Breaks Off Talks on Future on Micronesia

title: When the Feds Were Writers
description: PHILADELPHIA  Can a Govern mentsponsored Writers' Project, such as existed during the New Deal era for more than seven years, be estab lished in our own time? A fascinating question but a difficult, one to answer. For like the other W.P.A. arts projects fathered by the Roosevelt Administra tion  theater, art, and music  the Writers' Project was a freak enter prise, a creature of the Depression's desperate atmosphere created by a special breed of politicians who be lieved that writers (as well as artists, actors and musicians) had a right to eat just like other people.

title: KINGS HP BRUINS ON 2 LATE GOALS
