A dazzling in ternational exhibition, The Age of Neoclassicism, has crammed paint ings, sculpture, furniture and ob jects into the Royal Academy and the Victoria & Albert Museum. The Tate Gallery is offering the mysti cal and eerie landscapes of Caspar David Friedrich, the German Romantic painter, an exhibition warmly received by critics.

title: Noise Peril Noted
description: Can noise harm your health? You bet it can, warns a voluntary hospital of the United Hospital Fund in one of its regular envi ronmental memos. The amount of noise in New York City has grown so intense and the hazard to health so severe that noise pollution is now as serious a health problem as air and water pollution. Air pollution can contribute to colds, bronchitis, asthma, lung diseases and emphy sema, and New York City has had a 500 per cent increase in the emphysema mortality rate in the last 10 years.

title: Susannah York Plays Disturbed Woman
description: As for "Images," save the pieces. Also the housea house fronting a lake and a magnificent, craggy sweep of Ireland  where most of the action (confusion) takes place.This clanging, pretentious, tricked-up exercise, shown last night at the New York Film Festival, is almost a model of how not to dramatize the plight of a schizoid. Then how do you? Simply, clearly, with some sort of progressive story line minus a technical smoke screen. Above all, don't let the camera have a nervous breakdown ahead of the heroine.Finally, since she's tentatively a normally behaving woman, with a loving, if short-sighted husband, why stir in a musical score befitting "Dracula Rises From the Grace"?As played by Susannah York, our girl is also some sort of writer, scribbing away furiously in a diary or journal that sounds like Emily Bront on pot.After a prologue, crammed with opening doors, hallucinations and jangling telephones, Miss York and her spouse, Rene Auberjonois, slip away to that country retreat, where a dead lover starts reappearing (walking in and out of the film) and a lecherous neighbor closes in.If the middle portion of the picture, in which the heroine is shown amorously grappling with the two men and her husband tossed in, is supposed to be unhinging Miss York, include us. Either she can't count or she can't cope. That's her Waterloo. An inevitable murder sets off such a teasing, exasperating whodunit postscript that the corpseand the pictureare left ice-cold.As for why Robert Altman, the brilliant director of the comedy, "M*A*S*H," elected to write and direct this mish-mash, that's his own business. It just doesn't work. Miss York, confined mainly to sly petulance and a few yowls, has also done better, as in "They Shoot Horses, Don't They?" The rest of the small cast does well enough, more or less as trickery props.We'll hold out for clarity, credibility, at least some kind of audience stance in the study of a schizoid about to crack, such as in the brilliant, French "Life Upside Down." Or Roman Polanski's "Repulsion." Forget "Images."

title: Film Festival: 'Merchant of Four Seasons' and 'Bad Company'
description: Her lips are cherry red, and when she smiles, they uncover even rows of pearly teeth. Beneath the soft swirls of her upswept blonde hair, her face all but radiates perfection. She is supernaturally beautifullike an angel, or the goddess of some 1940's movie. Kind, clear-eyed, compassionate; she is Erna, the good sister of Hans, the fruit peddler. And she figuresnot too prominentlyin Rainer Werner Fassbinder's new movie, "Merchant of Four Seasons."I am interested more in her beauty than in her character (she is played by an actress named Hanna Schygulla, who, in fairness, deserves some of the credit) because it is a beauty that belongs neither to our time nor quite to our life.Partly, it is from another time, the late 40's, which suggests the style adopted by all the women who have any style in "Merchant of Four Seasons." And partly it is another life, a life that is at once too bright, too warm, too vibrant; and at the same time too alien and artificial to be real.If you can form a picture of Erna's face you will have some notion of the style that pervades this film about Hans, who disgraces his middle-class Munich family by peddling fruit, whose big scrawny wife, Irmgard, is highly attractive to other men, and whose existence is a series of minor shocks and grinding disappointments. He suffers a heart attack, and changes his way of business and begins to succeed and to become a credit to his family.And then his despondency really matures, and in the course of one sociable evening, knowing just what he is doing, he drinks himself to death  with toasts to everyone: family, buddies, wife, daughter and even to the love of his life.When somebody at Hans's funeral notices a woman standing off to one side carrying a bouquet of red roses and asks Irmgard who she is, Irmgard rather casually answers: "The love of Hans's life  I phoned her . . ." Thus she acknowledges the most extravagant dream of her late husband in a commonplace courtesy.The extraordinary range of interaction between the stolidly commonplace and the extravagantly romantic is one aspect of the imaginative freedom of "Merchant of Four Seasons." And it is such freedom that allows the film its intellectual playfulness, its seriousness, its furtive ecstasy, its spare realism, its cruelty and its sometimes unnerving decency.Mr. Fassbinder, born in 1945, is still very young, and incredibly prolific and probably the surest talent in the new German cinema. He makes movies that look like nobody else's, but that look like the discovery of a wonderfully idiomatic way to make movies. His work is neiher easy nor ingratiating, but it is very exciting, and sometimesas in the manifestations of the sublime Erna  moving beyond all expectation."Merchant of Four Seasons," a movie I like very much, played early yesterday evening at the New York Film Festival.

title: Red Smith

title: SAMUEL I. WARD
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 8Samuel I. Ward, an industrialist and a benefactor of the University of Hartford, died yesterday of can car in Hartford Hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: PATENT REMEDIES ABUSED, F.D.A. SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 The Food and Drug Adminis tration warned today that Americans are taking worth less, unnecessary and some times potentially harmful amounts of patent medicines and nonprescription remedies.

title: Aide Says Pentagon Does Not Receive Reports on Civilian Damage in North
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8A senior military officer has testi fied in secret before a Senate panel that the Pentagon and the Administration do not nec essarily receive specific re ports detailing civilian damage and casualties resulting from United States air strikes in North Vietnam.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) Senator George McGovern proposed today a national ener gy program emphasizing re search for new and improved sources of power and strict enforcement by the agencies regulating the energy industries.

title: Music: Pollini Gives a Piano Recital
description: When Maurizio Pollini made his debut here in 1968, he played Chopin, Bartok, Schoenberg and Stravinsky and made a splendid impres sion the interpretive demands of the two programs differed greatly and that Mr. Pollini fulfilled those of the first more convincingly than he did those of the second.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Maj. Gen. Edward G. Lansdale's recent OpEd article, After the War, Still Vietnam, contains most of the familiar clichs and nonfacts of apol ogists for the war. Of particular inter est, however, is Mr. Lansdale's state ment that the Politburo, of course, needn't resort to a bloodbath to weed out the opposition. As an alternative, it could stampede these people out of the country, just as the million refu gees fled from North Vietnam in 1954. The language of the last sentence is masterful in its deceptiveness, suggest ing that it was the North Vietnamese who stampeded the refugees out.

title: VIOLENT CRIMES RISING IN SUBURBS
description: Violent crime in the nation's suburbs is increasing nearly twice as fast as in the large cities. But suburban crime rates, on a per capita basis, are still so low that even at the present rate of increase, there is no chance that suburbanites will soon be in as much danger of violence as city residents.

title: The Lavelle Case
description: The hearings by the Senate Armed Services Committee in the case of Lieut. Gen. John D. Lavelle have left the most important issues involved in the controversy in totally unsatisfactory suspension. The censure of the general, together with a virtually blanket clearing of all other persons and echelons, has all the earmarks of a coverup. Making one officer the scapegoat for more widespread wrongdoing would be an injustice in any case; if the intent is to wipe out the traces of a more serious deception, the matter would assume grave national importance.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON Oct. 8 (AP)New Jersey's tap water is fit to drink, but increasing amounts of chemicals, including pesti cides and herbicides, are find ing their way into reservoirs.

title: CHARLES J. DAVIS
description: QUARRYVILLE, Pa., Oct. 8 Charles J. Davis, who retired in 1956 as a vice president and director of William Iselin & Co., Inc., New York factors, and sub sequently operated the Green bree Dairy Farm here, died yes terday. He was 77 years old.

title: Nets Lose to Cougars
description: BURLINGTON, N. C., Oct. 8 (AP)The Carolina Cougars outscored the New York Nets, 6328, in the second half and took a 10989 victory in an American Basketball Associa tion exhibition game tonight.

title: BACH GROUP GIVES MATTHEW PASSION
description: The Munich Bach Choir and Orchestra took up the St. Matthew Passion of Bach at Philharmonic Hall on Sunday afternoon and some three and a half hours later laid it to rest. With Karl Richter con ducting from a twomanual harpsichord and providing col orful swashes of improvisation as leader of the continuo, the German group delivered the mighty score in full and at length, uncut even in the nor mally clipped recitatives.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: RUTHERFORD, Oct. 8  Traditionally wary of new faces, Rutherford welcomed back this weekend a large number of wayfayers who were once familiar. Everyone was a hospitable host except the weathrman.

title: Ancient Indian Sites Are Dug Up
description: WASHINGTON, Conn., Oct. 8 Before the bulldozers, high ways, and housing develop ments encroach on this small rural Litchfield County town, amateur archeologists living here are hoping to uncover the remains of extensive, but hith erto ignored, preColonial In dian civilizations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 1  No Title

title: A PHILIPPINE AREA IS SUDDENLY QUIET
description: COTABATO, the Philippines, Oct. 5This usually turbulent heartland of MoslemChristian warfare has become dramatic ally quieter since President Fer dinand E. Marcos proclaimed martial law for the Philippines two weeks ago, and officials here are hopeful that the new tranquillity means an end of the conflict.

title: Candidates Chosen in Israel For Two Posts of Chief Rabbi
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 8Chief rabbis for Israel's two religious communities are to be elected next Sunday, and after nomina tions closed in Jerusalem today it appeared that candidates backed by the Government were certain to be chosen.

title: Crawford Wins 6Mile Run
description: Jim Crawford of the United States Army, stationed at West Point, won the sixmile cross country run, sponsored by the Road Runners Club of New York, at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. It was the third straight victory for Crawford, who was clocked in 31 minutes 16.6 seconds. He finished 250 yards ahead of James Schindler of Bedford, N.Y. Schindler's time was 32:07.

title: Credit Markets
description: The Washington Metropoli tan Area Transit Authority, which has begun construction of what will be a 97.7mile rapid transit system upon com pletion in late 1979, will dip into the bond mar ket tomorrow for its first infusion of private money.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MUGGED VETERAN ASSISTS POLICE
description: Moments after he had been mugged and robbed of $20 Saturday night, a veteran who had been wounded in Vietnam ran into a Bronx tenement after a gunman and was shot at twice before the man was captured.

title: A Revitalized Cincinnati Blends Old and New Spirit
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 8Huge picture windows on the top of a hillside, rain turning the waterlights into a sur realistic blur, a waiter cre ates flaming crepes for pa trons dressed elegantly for the Symphony. If Tony Ben nett strolled into the room singing I left my heart... the instinct would be to look for the nearest cable car.

title: Sorority Changes Name
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 8 (UPI)  The Theta Sigma Phi national sorority for professional wom en journalists voted today to change the organzation's name to Women in Communications, Inc. Nearly 300 representatives of chapters from 79 campuses and 80 cities are attending the convention.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 8 (AP)The State Department of Labor and Industry said today that more than 100,000 workers in New Jersey would benefit from the increase in the minimum wage that takes effect tomorrow.

title: ALLISON IS VICTOR IN CHARLOTTE 500
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 8 (AP)Bobby Allison held off a charging Buddy Baker for the final 10 laps today to capture the national 500mile stock car race by a car length.

title: Steel Group Seeking Help In PollutionControl Costs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8A steelindustry committee has recommended to President Nixon more liberal tax treat ment for the cost of pollution control facilities at steel mills and a $3billion Federal kitty for lowinterest loans to fi nance such investment.

title: 125,898 Fans Here Watch Giants Win and Jets Lose
description: New York was an autumn festival yesterday for pro football fans as both the Giants and Jets played home games. A total of 125,898 fans turned out at Yankee Stadium and Shea Stadium.

title: Brewer Takes $300,000 Pacific Golf by Beating David Graham in Playoff
description: INZAI, Japan, Oct. 8 (AP) Gay Brewer missed a chance for victory in a three  hole playoff today then triumphed in a suddendeath playoff in the Pacific Masters golf tour nament. He defeated David Graham of Australia for the $65,000 first prize in the world's richest golf event.

title: Steel Intake Is Heavy
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8The steel market is absorbing large quantities of domestic and for eign material without any signs of indigestion.

title: Perreault Stars for Sabres
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 8 (AP)Gil Perreault assisted on Rene Rob ert's tiebreaking thirdperiod goal, then scored on his own to lead the Buffalo Sabres to a 53 victory over the Atlanta Flames.

title: Hispanic Adviser Replaces Gross as Youth Unit Head
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday named Mrs. Amalia V. Betanzos, his executive secretary and ad visor on Hispanic affairs, to re place Ted Gross as Youth Serv ices Commissioner. Hi resigned Saturday amid charges of ir regularities in his agency's budget.

title: LEO CANTOR
description: Leo Cantor, director of de livery for The New York Times from 1925 to 1933, died Satur day in Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx. He was 84 years old and lived at 1240 Walton Ave nue, the Bronx.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: I have never voted for a Republican Presidential candidate. This year I shall vote for President Nixon, I have enlisted as an active worker in the campaign for his reelection.

title: Romance Is Misplaced In Matchmaker Stakes
description: Horse racing's intriguing Matchmaker Stakes, set for its sixth running today at Atlantic City, was designed strictly as a run for love.

title: Miss Margaret Mason Warnock Wed to Eugene Edward Carlough
description: OLD CHATHAM, N. Y., Oct. 8Miss Margaret, Mason Warnock and Eugene Edward Carlough were married here this afternoon in a Quaker ceremony at Powell House, a conference center belong ing to the New York Yearly Meeting of the Religious So ciety of Friends.

title: DRIVE TO REGISTER VOTERS HERE LAGS
description: Unless the number of new registrants picks up dramati cally tomorrow, the last day of a fourday voter drive, the results of the special effort to enroll new voters here will be very poor, a Board of Elec tions spokesman said yester day.

title: Retiring Paris Envoy Sums Up Diplomatic Life
description: PARIS, Oct. 8Though he says I'm really green in the diplomatic area, Ambassador Arthur Kittredge Watson has some advice for his unknown successor.

title: THERAPY SCORED BY HOMOSEXUALS
description: Members of the Gay Activ ists Alliance yesterday assailed a group of psychologists and psychiatrists meeting here, charging that aversion ther apy for homosexuals amounts to brainwashing.

title: Suzanne L. Taffet Bride of Dr. Fefer
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 8  Miss Suzanne Lee Taffet, daughter of. Mr. and Mrs. William B. Taffet of Scars dale, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Enrique Feier, a pharmacologist with the Food and Drug Adminis tration in Washington. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Pincus Feier of Bogota, Colombia.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BILLINGS, Mont., Oct. 8 (UPI)A resolution endorsing Senator George McGovern without reservation was unan imously passed today by the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Work ers' District 2 Council, repre senting six states.

title: Jersey Plans To Admit All To Colleges
description: New Jersey's Board of Higher Education is expected to approve on Oct. 20 a new master plan that would guar antee admission to a com munity college to every resi dent of the state aged 18 or older.

title: INVENTIVE PROGRAM BY LIMON DANCERS
description: There Is a Time is Jos Limn's danced rsum of cy clical experience as observed by the writer of Ecclesiastes. It is a fine dance in balance and invention, and made its first appearance Saturday after noon in Mr. Limn's series of programs for the City Center American Dance Marathon at the ANTA Theater.

title: Latin Americans to Go On Oceanographic Trip
description: MIAMI, Oct. 8The 3,805 ton Discoverer, one of the world's most sophisticated deepsea oceanographic ships, will leave Miami tomorrow on a 10week voyage to carry out marine research projects in the Caribbean.

title: Enter the F.B.I.
description: David Dinkins is not running for pliblie office this year. The blunt spoken president of New York City's Board of Elections has, nonetheless, taken to the stump to alert the public to what he quite properly considers a transcendent issue.

title: G.E. REPORTS GAINS IN COAL GASIFICATION
description: The chief of the General Electric Company's research and development said at a weekend meeting that his com pany was making a significant investment in coal gasification research and development.

title: Aida Chang Bride Of Robert Y. S. Li
description: Miss Aida Chang, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Simon K. H. Chang of Hollis, Queens, was married here yesterday after noon to Robert Y. S. Li, son of Dr. and Mrs. P. C. Li of East Fishkill, N. Y. The Rev. Dennis W. K. Wagner per formed the ceremony in Christ Church (United Meth odist).

title: The Proceedings in the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.Burma, Burundi, Ru mania, Syria, the Philippines, Yemen, Mauritania, Somalia, Byelorussia, Algeria, Southern Yemen and Pakistan are ten tatively listed to speak in the general debate.

title: Personal Finance
description: What's a priceearnings ratio, these days? A confusion of figures in the minds of many stockholders.

title: Brewer Takes $300,000 Pacific Golf by Beating David Graham in Playoff
description: INZAI, Japan, Oct. 8 (AP) Gay Brewer missed a chance for victory in a three  hole playoff today then triumphed in a suddendeath playoff in the Pacific Masters golf tour nament. He defeated David Graham of Australia for the $65,000 first prize in the world's richest golf event.

title: Canada Sends Icebreaker To Aid of U.S. Navy Ships
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) The Coast Guard said today that the Canadian Government had ordered one of its ice breakers to go to the assist ance of two United States ships disabled in a heavy ice pack far above the Arctic Circle.

title: An Indian 'Adversary':Satyajit Ray Work Is A Moving Comedy An Ex-Medical Student Seethes at Injustices
description: If it weren't for the New York Film Festival, few of Satyajit Ray's post-Apu trilogy films would ever have been seen in this country, a fact that the great Indian director acknowledged Saturday evening in a short speech before the current festival's screening of "The Adversary" at Alice Tully Hall. This is a comment on the American public's moviegoing tastes, which are actually no worse than anybody else's. It also says a great deal about the kind of films that Ray makes.For a number of reasons, a Ray film doesn't demand our immediate attention in the way that a Buuel or a Bergman or a Godard does. A Ray film carries no guarantee to shock. Its characters are too involved in one form or another of daily survival to fret about metaphysical matters. It won't outrage us. Regarded in India as the most un-Indian of Indian films directors, he is, to us, quintessentially Indian.This has to do with the rhythm of his films, which is so regular as almost to lull us to sleep in a place (a movie theater) where custom has taught us to expect a continuing succession of alarms of varying tones and volumes. It also has to do with Ray's vision of Indian life, which is anything but exotic or sensuous. His male characters, especially, seem at first somewhat timid, dressed in their occidental clothes that hang on them like the hand-me-downs from someone else's civilization."The Adversary" is about such a man, a former medical student named Siddhartha who shares a crowded Calcutta flat with his widowed mother, an uncle, a pretty younger sister with a fairly well-paying job, and a younger brother, who is supposed to be a student but who apparently spends most of his time working for revolutionary causes.Siddhartha is caught betwixt and between. He seethes with rage about social injustices, about economic corruption, but he is powerless to express it. The best he can do is act rudely at job interviews. "Do you like flowers?" he is asked by a prospective employer at the botanical gardens. "Not unconditionally," says Siddhartha. "Who was Prime Minister at the time of independence?" the employer goes on. "Whose independence?" the young man answers."The Adversary" is about Siddhartha's taking hold of himself when he falls in love and after he has endured a series of small but awful humiliations. These have the effect of making him accept his individuality, and of increasing his awareness of the fact that to be a part of a generalization, as humanity is a generalization, is not necessarily defeat."All people are the same," he tells his girl at one point, meaning that one body is much like another as far as bones, muscles, nerves and arteries are concerned. "Not exactly alike," says the girl. Men and women are different. Temperaments are different."The Adversary" moves so quietly, with such seeming politeness to jaded film senses, that it takes a while to realize that for all its somberness it's a particularly moving comedy. The methods are so conventional, they seem reserved, but the director's sensibility is profoundly compassionate.A Ray film is worth attending to, even during lapses that are not his. The English subtitles on the festival print translate not only the Bengali dialogue, but also the the English dialogue. "I don't smoke" says a young man in English. "I don't smoke," says the English subtitle. That, however, is the most mysterious thing about an otherwise clear and beautiful movie.

title: Advertising:
description: Add two more names to the list of fellows who want to use the handy old tele phone as an advertising medium.

title: Analyst Sees New Interest in Oil Stocks
description: Oil stocks are showing new signs of life, with shares of some industry leaders post ing 1972 highs in early Oc tober. Exactly what's been happening to oil issues? What are their problems and their potentials? Frank K. Wood fin, senior petroleum analyst at Standard & Poor's, has been following the oils for 20 years. He expressed his views last week in an inter view with Vartanig G. Vartan of The New York Times. Portions of their conversa tion follow:

title: Winds Split a Sail but 12 Boats Finish in the Mayor's Cup Race
description: The Statue of Liberty looked poised to drop her torch as the starting signal when 13 racing schooners lined up opposite her yesterday to vie for the Mayor's Cup.

title: Clydebank Settlement Set
description: GLASGOW, Oct. 8, Reuters Scottish union leaders settled their dispute today with the Marathon Manufacturing Cor poration of Texas, which bought the Clydebank Shipyard, which went into bankruptcy last year. They agreed to a formula, whichit was hopedwould result in production of oil rigs from the shipyards, which used to build the big Queen liners.

title: G.O.P. Intensifies Drive To Attract Jews to Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8After months of working through the socalled establishment in the Jewish community, the men running President Nixon's re election effort have taken their vigorous campaign to increase his share of the normally Democratic Jewish vote into the neighborhoods and the streets of the cities.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BRYAN, Tex. Oct. 9 (AP) Four days after Walter T. Dun can wrote a $200,000 check that helped make him the year's largest listed political donor, a 220acre parcel of land he owned in Texas was sold at a foreclosure auction because he had failed to make the payments.

title: Roberts Discerns Dangerous Climate of Hysteria on Issue of Corrupt Judges
description: Bronx District Attorney Bur ton B. Roberts charged yester day that a dangerous climate of hysteria has developed about the issue of corruption among the judges.

title: Asians in Uganda Join Anniversary Festivities
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Oct. 9 (Reuters)President Idi Amin today took the salute, as for the first time in the 10 years of Uganda's independence several hundred Uganda Asians joined their African fellow citizens in a huge cere monial parade.

title: Roles of Filipino Civil Officials In Provinces Seem Unchanged
description: BACOLOD, the Philippines, Oct. 7Out in the provinces of the Philippines, military men are playing a much more im portant role under martial law than before, but governors, mayors, judges and other civil authorities continue to func tion and to administer their areas of responsibility with little change.

title: G.E. SETS MARKS IN SALES AND NET
description: The General Electric Com pany reported yesterday new highs in sales and earnings for the three and nine months end ed Sept. 30.

title: Overseas Money Order Set
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank introduced yesterday a new in ternational money order serv ice to be sold by correspondent banks in Europe and Asia. The money orders will be sold in amounts up to $500 to facili tate payment of dollar accounts either overseas or in the United States. The money orders will be more quickly negotiable than drafts on a particular bank.

title: Dr.Alton Lawrence, Compiled Columbia Records Library
description: Dr. Alton Forrest Raymond Lawrence, a recording archivist who assembled over, a 10year period the, record library for Columbia Records, Inc., died yesterday at the Medical Arts Center Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived at 331 West 71st Street.

title: Bus Line in Connecticut Will Halt Service Today
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 9Connec ticut's secondlargest bus com pany today ordered a suspen sion of service tomorrow in New Britain, Waterbury, Bridgeport and 16 outlying towns, intensifying the state's, public transit crisis.

title: FIJI HELD IN ASSAULT ON MAN IN MIDTOWN
description: A news correspondent from Fiji has been charged with felonious assault and was being held without bail after he al legedly struck a man during what he reportedly thought was a mugging attempt.

title: Lerner Stores Corp. Cites 20.9% Increase in Sales
description: The Lerner Stores Corpora tion and G. C. Murphy, retail chains, reported yesterday in creased sales in September over the like 1971 month.

title: Philippine Aide Reports Big Drop in Crime Rate
description: MANILA, Oct. 9  Brig. Gen. Fidel Ramos, chief of the Philippine constabularly, or national police, said today that the crime rate had dropped from an average of 1,800 incidents a week before martial law was proclaimed Sept. 23 to 48.5 weekly.

title: Allegheny Unit Names Head
description: Richard P. Simmons has been named president of the Al legheny Ludlum Steel Corpora tion, a subsidiary of Allegheny Ludlum Industries, succeeding William B. Pierce, who recently retired. Mr. Simmons had been executive vice president and chief operating officer since April.

title: DELAY IS POSSIBLE ON BILL ON POTATOES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) Legislation to prevent specula tion on Irish Potato futures ap peared today to be too far down the list to, be acted on Oct. 14.

title: Massachusetts Gets Grant
description: BOSTON, Oct. 9 (AP)Mas sachusetts has been awarded a $20,000 grant from the Federal Environmental Protection A gency to complete a water management plan for the Southeastern Regional Econom ic Planning and Development District, Lieut. Gov, Donald R. Dwight said yesterday.

title: 20 IN NASSAU JAIL SLASH OWN WRISTS
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I., Oct. 9 Twenty inmates of the Nas sau County Jail slashed their wrists and arms last Friday in a protest that was not made public until today by Sheriff Michael P. Seniuk.

title: Personalities: New Pact for Wilt
description: Wilt Chamberlain, the most valuable player in the Na tional Basketball Association last season, ended his almost monthlong holdout yesterday and reported to the Los An geles Lakers' at Loyola Uni versity in Los Angeles, The 36  year  old, 7  foot  1 inch Chamberlain, in his 14th pro season, had refused to re port while he renegotiated the final year of his old con tract.

title: Fair Offers Various Routes to Health
description: The man with the golden tan and flowing tresses turned to Michelle, Maurer at Madison Square Garden yesterday and asked:

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI)  Mrs. Richard M. Nixon christened today a highly decorated bus that will tour the country for the Republican party.

title: JAPAN TO DEVELOP PLANE WITH BOEING
description: TOKYO, Oct. 9 (AP)  Ja pan's Aircraft Industry Delib eration Council decided today that Japan would develop a new commercial transport plane jointly with the Boeing Com pany Of the United States.

title: Man Battles Tiger To Free Daughter At a Zoo in Omaha
description: OMAHA, Oct. 9 (UPI)An enraged father wrestled a young Sumatran tiger away from his 5yearold daughter at a zoo here yesterday. The ani mal had jumped out of a 10 loothigh pit, clamped its jaws around the child's head and dragged her 10 feet across the ground.

title: Music: Rare Indian Trio
description: Sunday night at Philhar monic Hall was one of those times when evertyhing except the music goes wrong. The performers were Ravi Shan kar, the sitar player, All Ak bar Khan, sarod player, and Alla Rahka, table player Indian classical musicians of the first order, playing su perbly in a rare appearance together.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As a cousin and friend of the late Miss Adelaide Milton DeGroot, I have been following with chagrin the arti cles describing the sale by the Metro politan Museum of Art of her valuable gifts of the Rousseau painting Mon keys in the Jungle and Juan Gris's Le Gueridon.

title: Washington Urges Caution
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  White House officials cautioned today against drawing too many conclusions from the fact that Mr. Kissinger was meeting for a third day with North Viet namese representatives in Paris this week.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Long School Strike Settled
description: Classes for 8,700 children in North, Hills, Pa., delayed by a teachers' strike that began Aug. 24, open today, according to United Press International. The strike was the state's long est public school labor dispute.

title: TANKER HITS YACHT; L.I. MAN IS DROWNED
description: BABYLON, L. I., Oct. 9One man was killed and another in jured today when an empty oil tanker struck their cabin cruiser anchored in Fire Island Inlet.

title: Bill Permitting G.I.'s to Get Heavier Packages is Signed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) President Nixon signed today a bill increasing the, maximum size and weight of packages sent to or from armed forces bases overseas and in Alaska or Hawaii.

title: Business Briefs
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Oct. 9 (UPI)  India and Bangladesh have decided to suspend temporarily their six month old border trade.

title: ONE OF 4 HAMLETS REPORTED TAKEN BY SAGON FORCES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Oct. 10Several hun dred Vietcong, guerrillas con tinued to hold on yesterday in at least three hamlets within 20 miles north of Saigon, Gov ernment military spokesmen said.

title: Chess: Flash of Insight, Not Analysis, Gives Kavalek Brilliant Victory
description: SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 9The rich stock of opening ideas. Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky came up with in their recent world champion ship match is the spur for dozens of encounters here in the Chess Olympics.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: On the Sept. 6 the City Planning Commission held a public hearing on plans for the asphalt plant site at Ninetieth Street and York Avenue known as Park Plaza East.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9 Mrs. Eleanor McGovern asked Americans today to change our leaders so we can change our policy and thus rescue our sons and retrieve our soul from the tragedy in, Southeast Asia.

title: 5 Pilots Say Their Group Flew Unauthorized Raids
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9Five Navy pilots said in interviews today that their attack squad ron participated, under the guise of protective reaction, in at least three planned raids on a North Vietnamese airfield beginning last December.

title: Ship Refloated in Michigan
description: HOLLAND, Mich., Oct. 9 (AP)The 546foot freighter Algorail, which sank Friday in the Holland Channel near Lake Michigan with a 15foot hole in her bow, has been refloated. The vessel, carrying a load of rock salt, struck a channel wall while trying to maneuver off a sand bar. She will proceed to Thunder Bay, Ont., for further repairs.

title: New England Fishermen Request Aid Against Inroads by Big Foreign Fleets
description: STONINGTON, Conn., Oct. 8 New England fishermen have appealed for swift Govern ment action to prevent the ruinous depletion of stocks of fish in coastal Atlantic waters, mainly by huge foreign fishing fleets.

title: ERRORS OFIAROD IN VOTER ROLLS
description: Witham 3. Diamond, a Re publican Assembly candidate from the Upper East side, charged yesterday that tens of thousands of city voters had received postcards from the Board of Elections incorrectly listing their election districts and polling places.

title: Bridge. L. I. Bridge Expert Dies at 37; Reigning PlayerofYear Here
description: The New York bridge com munity has lost one of its most talented young experts Frank Mela, of Great Neck, L. I., who died Saturday fol lowing a heart attack at the age of 37. He was the reign ing playeroftheyear cham pion of the Greater New York Bridge Association based on his 1971 record. He had won the same title in the Nassau Suffolk Association, which he served as a board member.

title: Today Is the Last Day For Voter Registration
description: Today Is the last day for city and state residents to register to vote in the November election.

title: Head of Youth Board Defends Institute
description: Stuart Scheftel, chairman of the city's Youth Board, de clared yesterday that a sepa rate Youth Boatd Research In stitute mechanism had made it possible for the city to run its summer Neighborhood Youth Corps for 50,000 youths and to move quickly to hire 35 ad ditional street workers to cape with a sudden proliferation of gangs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Politicians Woo Italians at Columbus Parade
description: A plethora of politicians of disparate political persuasions clustered together yesterday on a buntingdraped wooden stand on Fifth Avenue, sharing one thing in common in this elec tionyear: a belief in the effi cacy of the ItalianAmerican vote.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Oct. 9At the Cozy Cafe, early this morning, some of the fellows were drinking their first toffee of the day from thick, chipped mugs and bemoaning the fact that they weren't bom rich.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Brisk selling of soybean fu tures contracts lowered prites sharply yetserday. The nearby November deliver closed at 83.34 a bushel, down from 83.38 Friday. Other soybean contracts showed losses of somewhat less than 4 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Baby's Death Laid to Methadone

title: Register to Vote Today
description: As ineffective, burdensome and antidemocratic as it is, New York City's voter registration program offers prospective voters one last chance today to sign up to participate in the November balloting. This is the final day of neighborhood or local registration and is the end of this election's registration process. Branch and cen tral registration drives terminated last month.

title: A Gag on Reason
description: In an extraordinary maneuver designed to prevent the voices of reason from speaking out against prejudice and political expediency, the antibusing forces in the Senate have moved to limit debate on the House approved segregationist measure. Not a single word had been spoken on the bill when twenty Senators last week filed a petition for closure.

title: U.S. CRESS PLAYERS BOW TO SOVIET TEAM
description: SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 9 The United States team lost today, 31, to the Soviet Union in the 12th round of the chess Olympics here. On the top two boards, Lubomir Kavalek drew with Tigran Petrosian and Robert Byrne drew with Vasily Smyslov. But Pal Benko lost to Mikhail Tal and Arthur Bisguier lost to Anatoly Karpov.

title: OutofCourt Settlement
description: EUGENE, Ore., Oct. 9 (AP) An outofcourt settlement has been reached in a $500,000 damage suit filed by a Falls Creek, Ore. man against North west Outward Bound School, Inc. Glenn Howden filed the suit against the Eugene school, chargin negligence in a wil derness outing in September of 1971 during which his wife, Joyce Ann Howden, and an other woman, Lorene Larhette, died.

title: Reporter's Safeguard
description: News Analysis

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 9Assembly Man Anthony Imperiale took the occasion of today's Colum bus Day parade here to toss his politically independent hat to wardbut not quite intothe 1974 Newark mayoral ring.

title: Jazz: Hull Back With a Lively Group
description: Gene Hull, who once led one of the best big jazz hands in the Northeast, has turned a page in his ca reer and is now heading a sixmember pop/rock jazz combo called Free Spirit, cur rently at Shepheard's.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Egypt Asks Sudan To Pull Out Troops Remaining at Suez
description: CAIRO, Oct. 9 (AP)  Egypt has asked the Sudanese Gov ernment to withdraw the rest of its troops from the Suez Canal, Egypt's official Middle East News Agency has reported.

title: J. P. Morgan Earnings Rise in Quarter
Clash Likely Between Sugar Industry and Farm Union
description: MIAMI, Oct. 9A confronta tion in the Florida cane fields, as well as in the courts, ap pears likely in the coming weeks between the sugar in dustry and the United Farm Workers Union.

title: Romulo Accuses Major Powers of Failing the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 9Dr. Carlos P. Romulo, For eign Minister of the Philippines, sharply criticized the major powers in a speech before the General Assembly today.

title: Health Maintenance Program Hurt by Lack of Action
description: Despite its promotion by the Nixon Administration almost two years ago, there is growing evidence, the socalled health maintenance organiz tion will not become a major alternative to the current Meth od of delivering the nation's health services in the near fu ture.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: DETROIT, Oct. 9The plan for peace in Vietnam that Sen ator George McGovern will un veil over national television to morrow night will enable Amer icans to lift this terrible war from the conscience of a na tion, he said here tonight.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 9 (AP) A new 25member Cabinet was formed today in the Sudan, and the President, Maj. Gen, Gaafar alNimeiry, also took the posts of Premier and Defense Minis ter, the Middle East News Agency reported.

title: Film Festival: Complex L' Arnour Fou
Authors Draw Model Contract With Publishers as a Breakthrough
description: A model contract considered to be, a major breakthrough for future negotiations between writers and publishers has been submitted by the Authors Guild to its 3,700 members.

title: SNELL UNDERGOES SPLEEN OPERATION
description: after he was drafted No. 1 by the Jets out of Ohio State (also drafted Na. 3 by the Giants) in 1964. He then won rookie of the year honors in the Ameri can Football League.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9Once I at tended a professional football game. The Washington Redskins were play ing the Dallas Cowboys. A kind neighbor gave me the tickets. He was very kind indeed, because in Wash ington as in several other football cities, it is impossible to buy tickets.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI)  The Committee for the Reelection of the Presi dent, anticipating Senator George McGovern's speech tomorrow night on Vietnam policy, issued today what it termed a chronological look at McGovern's Vietnam rec ord.

title: Rough Riders Win, 4530
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 9 (Canadian Press)  The Ottawa Rough Riders moved back into first place in the Eastern Confer ence of the Canadian Football League by beating the Calgary Stampeders, 4530, today.

title: Reed Returns to Disabled List As Knicks Open Season Tonight
description: Willis Reed will be on the disabled list tonight when the New York Knickerbockers open their 27th National Basketball Association campaign against the Seattle Supersonics at Mad ison Square Garden. Game time is 7:30.

title: $520,000 Legal Fee Involving a Coop Blocked By 3 City and State Agencies
description: Three government agencies are blocking payment of $520,000 legal fee from the builder of a MitchellLama co operative complex to a politi cally connected lawyer who was a, member of the City Planning Commission while performing the legal services.

title: Turkish Ban on Poppy: Delayed Impact Seen
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 4 Turkish and American officials engaged in the fight against illegal narcotics believe it will take considerable time before Turkey's ban on the growing of opium poppies can markedly reduce the flow of heroin to the United States.

title: Biehl P. Clarke, Directed Chamber of Commerce Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) Biehl P. Clarke, director of governmental and politicalpar ticipation programs in the pub licaffairs department of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, died Saturday of a heart attack. His age was 46.

title: Miriam Hopkins Is Dead at 69; Screen and Stage Star of 1930's
description: Miriam Hopkins, the viva cious blond, star of Becky Sharp and some 35 Other mo tion pictures, most of them in the 1930's, died early yesterday morning at the Alrae Hotel, 37 East 64th Street. She would have been 70 years old on Oct. 18.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: WEST MILFORD, Oct. 9 A lion reached inside a car being driven through Jungle Habitat here today and mauled a visitor.

title: Woman in the News
description: At the Columbus Day parade yesterday, City Coun cilman Muriel Lola Bon sole Stromberg sat beside her mother In the re viewing stand at. 69th Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Taking note of the barrage recently leveled at him by George McGovern, President Nixon at his news confer ence last week adroitly fired back without seeming to fire back:

title: A Reunion Marks City Ballet's Tour
description: TBILISI, U.S.S.R., Oct. 9 All of a sudden I have mil lions of relatives, chirped George Balanchine during an intermission at one of the New York City Ballet's per formances in this capital of Soviet Georgia, the homeland of his forefathers.

title: CENTROWITZ WINS SCHOLASTIC RUN
description: Matt Centrowitz of Power Memorial outran hun dred schoolboys through the hill's of Van Cortlandt Park in the bronx yesterday.

title: HOME RULE AIDE QUITS IN DISPUTE
description: The chairman of United Towns for Home Rule, the group that has led the opposi tion to the state Urban Devel opment Corporation's housing plans in Westchester County, announced yesterday that he was resigning because others in the group's leadership want ed to take it off a present course he characterized as moderate.

title: CREDIT MARKETS SHOW ADVANCES
description: Credit Markets

title: 3 Seized Here With Cocaine Put at $500.000. U.S Slays
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI) Three men were arrested and $500,000 worth of cocaine was seized last Saturday at Ken nedy International Airport in New York by Customs agents, Assistant Treasury Secretary Eugene T. Rossideis announced today.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 Sargent Shriver continued the Democratic national ticket's sallies into vital battleground states today as he began a two day thrust into Pennsylvania.

title: Allen of Redskins Confuses Experts With Player Changes
description: About Pro Football

title: 10 Food Concerns Cited for Violations Of City Health Code
description: The Health Services Ad ministration yesterday released the names of 10 restaurants and food establishments cited for violations of the city's health code.

title: 2 Suspects Held in Georgia In Carolina Trooper's Killing
description: VILLA RICA, Ga., Oct. 9 (UPI)The Georgia Highway Patrol said tonight it had arrested two suspects in the slaying of a South Carolina highway patrolman.

title: BRITAIN DROPPING FIXED BANK RATE
description: LONDON, Oct. 9The bank rate, which for 270 years has been the peg for monetary policy and interest rates in Brit ain, was abolished today by Anthony Barber, the Chancellor of the Exchequer.

title: 20MILLION WASTE LAID 10 HOSPITALS
description: The city's public hospitals could save up to $20million a year by eliminating unnec sary beds, the Citizens Budget Commission asserted yester day.

title: Peking Tells U. N. Which Expenses It Won't Pay
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 9China took a hard line today on the United Nations budget, listing the items she would oppose financing.

title: The Selling of Sex: A Look Through a Solemn Sodom
description: The thing about Sodom is that it is so solemn. Here is a girl. She is wearing a gray nightgown, and she is danc ing on a stage. She is doing something like a hula, and she is bouncing her hips. There is baby fat on them.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Inquiry Into Bronx Death Begun

title: BYRNE IS APPOINTED AS CHESS COLUMNIST
description: Robert Byrne, a United States chess cochampion, has been appointed chess columnist for The New York Times. He replaces Al Horowitz, who has been on a leave of absence.

title: Drive to Legalize Marijuana Is Funded by Nonprofit Comparzy in California
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 9The dis tributors of a cigarette paper made especially for pot smokers are providing the prin cipal financial hacking for proposal on the California bal lot Nov. 7 that would legalize the use of marijuana by adults.

title: A Daughter of Khrushchev Is Disclosed to Have Died
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 9 (UPI)A correspondent's chance stroll in a cemetery, the former Novo Devichy Convent, has disclosed the previously unannounced death of the youngest of the four daughters of Nikita S. Khrushchev.

title: KISSINGER'S TALKS IN PARIS CONTINUE; A 3D DAY PLANNED
description: PARIS, Oct. 9Henry A. Kissinger and his deputy, Maj. Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., met privately with North Viet namese negotiators here for the second day today, and anoth er session was scheduled for tomorrow.

title: U.S. Views Move Calmly
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The British decision to abolish, the bank rate was received calmly in financial circles here, partly because official Washington was enjoying the Columbus Day holiday and partly because the action was seen as having nosignificance for international exchange rates or the dollar.

title: Maryland Court Upholds Maiden Name in Voting
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct, 9 (Reuters)The Maryland Court of Appeals ruled today that a married woman may use her maiden name for voting pur poses, as long as she has used her maiden name consistently in all other occasions.

title: Hawaii Dock Workers Settle With One Concern in Walkout
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 9 (UPI) Striking Hawaii dock workers, after reaching contract agree ment with one major shipping company, stepped up pressure today against three others in the walkout's second day.

title: WALTER R. KIRNER, CHEMIST, WAS 77
description: CLINTON, N. Y., Oct. 9  Dr. Walter R. Kirner, an or ganic chemist who had served as director orchemistry for the National Science Foundation, died Saturday of a heart ail ment here, He was 77 years old and lived in Kensington, Md.

title: Those Traditional Hotels for Women: Standing Still in Time
description: Back in the 1940's and 1950's, when a young woman of good stock arrived in New York City to attend school or go to work, she would more than likely take up residence at a hotel ex clusively for women.

title: AGE OF HUMAN BONES PUT AT 20,000 YEARS
description: EL CENTRO, Calif., Oct. (UPI)A person who died about 20,000 years ago and was buried beneath a pile of rocks may provide scientists with the oldest human skeleton found in the Western Hemisphere.

title: Man and Woman Get $100,000 in Gems In 47th St. Robbery
description: A welldressed man and woman took advantage of the Columbus Day parade yester day to rob a West Side dia mond merchant of gems worth more than $100,000, according to the police.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Contingent in Vietnam Reduced by 700, to 35,200
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 9 (AP)  United States troop strength in Vietnam dropped by 700 men, to 35,200 last week, the United States command an nounced today.

title: Domestics At. Session Ask Gains
description: More than a thousand household workers, more commonly referred to as do mestics, concluded a three day convention here yester day and resolved, among other things, to seek from their employers better wages, improved working hours and a recognition that being a domestic is no low busi ness, that, indeed, a domes tic is a respectable pro fessional.

title: Epidemic of Dysentery Affected Excursions on Colorado Rapids
description: At least 132 passengers who shot the Colorado River rapids on rafts last summer were vic tims of an epidemic of dysen tery that they acquired on the excursions, officials of the United States Public Health Service reported.

title: Prisoners Rights Suit Filed
description: BOSTON, Oct. 9 (AP)A suit to give Massachusetts prisoners voting rights has been filed with the clerk of the Federal District Court here, the Prison Rights Project announced to day. William Crain, a Boston lawyer and director of the proj ect, said the class action suit was filed Saturday for John Carillo, president of the Nation al Prisoners Reform Associa tion, and for all inmates in Massachusetts correctional in stitutions.

title: CITY POST IS QUIT BY MRS. ELDRIDGE
description: Mrs. Ronnie Eldridge, a $33, 500ayear deputy city admin istrator and one of Mayor Lindsay's chief political advis, ers, resigned yesterday to man age Representative Bella S. Ab zug's reelection campaign in Manhattan's West Side District.

title: MRS. RANKIN WINS BY FIVE STROKES
description: SOUTHBURY, Conn., Oct. 9 (AP)  Mrs., Judy Rankin braved the wind and the cold at the Heritage Village Coun try Club today and pulled away for a fivestroke victory in the second Ladies Profes sional Golf Association Heritage Village open.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: October 9, 1972

title: For Sale Sign Is Posted At Allied Chemical Tower
description: The Allied Chemical Tower, the Times Square landmark formerly known as the Times Tower, is for sale.

description: WHAT DOES QUALITY LIFE INSURANCE COST? $100,000 Yearly Renewable & Convertible Term, annual premium, age 40, 0383.00. Full details, rates your age, rail or have your agent call North Atlantic Life, Jericho, N. Y. (510) 9356900Advt.

title: U.S.SOVIET EXPERTS PLAN SPACE MISSION
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 9 (UPI)  American and Soviet space scientists, including Col. Thomas P. Stafford of the United States Air Force and Alexei Yeliseyev of the Soviet Union, met today to plan the 1975 United StatesSoviet space rendezvous, Tass, the official Soviet press agency said today.

title: The Bridge Case as a Limitation on Privilege of Press
description: News Analysis

title: People and Business
description: Alfred E. Perlman, a veter an railroader who was presi dent and chief operating of ficer and then vice chariman of the bankrupt Penn Cen tral Transportation Com pany, was elected chairman and chief executive officer yesterday of the Western Pa cific Railroad Company. Mr. Perlman, who will be 70 years old next month, had been president since Dec. 1, 1970.

title: Stage: Naive Pretensions of Dude
description: Inchoate energy has its attractions and there were big and powerful gobbets of theatricality hanging around all over the Broadway Thea ter, where Dude made its bow last night. But this god son of Hair never quite makes it. Its pretensions are always clearer than its achievements, yet even those pretensions are not without a certain naivet that might endear the show to come.

title: MORTON HELFER
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 9  Mor ton Helfer, executive director of the Children's Center in Hamden, died today of a heart attack at Yale New Haven Hospital, He was 69 years old and lived in Hamden.

title: YOUTHUNIT STUDY BY COUNCIL URGED
description: Connell President Sanford D. Garelik called last night for a full investigation of the Youth Services Agency by the City Council and said there was rea son to believe that the District Attorney's office would look into the agency's activities.

title: Bar Told to End Bias Against Young Males
description: The State Division of Hu man Rights has ruled in favor of a 20yearold Hamburg, N. Y., youth who said that a restaurant in his home town had refused to serve him li quor while it served drinks to girls under 21.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: VAN NUYS,. Calif., Oct. 8 Emma Tucker did not know she was going to register to vote. At age 83, she cannot move around easily, and she did not have a ride.

title: Steel Production Rises 0.4% in Week To 2,568,000 Tons
description: Steel production for the week ended Oct. 7 totaled 2,568,000 net tons, or an index level of 105.3, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yester day. This compared with the 2,557,000 tons poured in the week ended. Sept. 30 when the index stood at 104.8. The per centage gain for the week amounted to 0.4.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 9The Ca hill administration is moving to control the large number of demonstrations staged annually in the state capital.

title: Notes on People
description: The former British Prime Minister, Harold Wilson, off ered his views on freedom of the press. The onetime head of the Labor Government said that proLabor prose rarely appeared in the Brit ish press, and suggested why.

title: Reserve Urged to Adopt Floating Discount Rate
description: DALLAS, Oct. 9A leading American banker called on the Federal Reserve System here today to adopt a float ing discount rate, tied directly to interest rates in the money market.

title: Kenya Kleenex Deal Set
description: NEENAH, Wis. Oct. 9 (UPI)  The Kimberly Clark Corpo ration has licensed Hygiene Products, Ltd., of Kenya to make Kleenex Facial Tissues and Kotex Sanitary Napkins The licensee is a joint venture of Hamilton, Ltd., the Kimber lyClark distributor in Kenya, and Lee Ngugi of Nairobi. Pro duction will begin early next year.

title: Italian Community in Village Blames Outsiders, Not Racial Bias, for Clashes
description: When he was growing up in the Italian section of southern Greenwich Village, John (Hap py) Ferri remembers that walk ing on the grass in Washington Square was forbidden.

title: Sanguillen Belts Homer, Bats In Decisive Run
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 9The Pittsburgh Pirates moved within one game of the Nation al League pennant today when they rallied in the late innings to defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 32.

title: Lawyer Charges an Offer To Spy on the Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9An Assistant Attorney General of Tennessee said tonight that he was approached in the summer of 1971 and was asked to con duct political espionage against the Democratic Presidential candidates.

title: Dream Sequence
description: Sports of The Times

title: INSTITUTE SCORED ON HEART STUDIES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9An associate of Ralph Nader made public a report today criticizing a program of the National In stitutes of Health that aims at developing artificial heart de vices for man.

title: Corona's Trial, Resumes Today With His Lawyer in Limelight
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., Oct. 9  Testimony in the trial of Juan V. Corona resumes tomorrow, with the 38yearold Mexican national who is charged with the largest mass murder in the nation's history no longer the center of attention.

title: Nissen Flyweight Victor
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 9 (AP)Henry Nissen, com monwealth flyweight champion, outpointed the Thai champion, Vittya Ploenchit, tonight in a 10round fight. Nisgen was a halfpound lighter at 114.

title: DONALD ROBERTSON OF JERSEY JOURNAL
description: Donald Robertson, circulation manager of The Jersey Journal, Jersey City, died Sunday of a heart ailment in New York Hos pital. He was 46 years old and lived at 126 Beacon Boulevard, Ketinsburg, N. J.

title: Cable TV Planning 23 Major Concerts
description: A season of 23 major con certsincluding 10 live pro grams by the New York Philharmonicis planned for cable television here by, three of the city's foremost art in stitutions, Lincoln Center, the City Center and the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: March Up Fifth Hails Ocean Voyage of 1492
description: It was Cristoforo Colombo's day yesterday as a Fifth Ave nue parade and other ceremo nies honored the 480th anni versary of the Italian explorer's serendipitous discovery of the Americas.

title: SNELL UNDERGOES SPLEEN OPERATION
description: The name of Matt Snell was added to the growing list of New York Jets' invalids yester day. The Jets' fullback was operated on by Dr. John Vieta, chief of surgery at Lenox Hill Hospital, for removal of a rup tured spleen.

title: Agnew vs. Shriver
description: One of the established axioms of American politics is that people do not vote for a Vice President. In four of the last eight elections, the Number Two man on the losing ticket failed to deliver his own state. Yet in that same period three elected Vice Presidents have gone on to become President of the United States. Thus in the nature of life and politics, the voter who chooses next month between Richard Nixon and George McGovern for President should be aware that the runningmates those two contenders are not just incidental adornments to the ticket. The voter will also be choosing between potential Presidents, Agnew and Shriven.

title: Delta Gets British Backing
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 9 (UPI) Delta Air Lines, Inc., announced today it has obtained $85mil lion in new 10year financing from a syndicate of British banks in order to buy Rolls Royce jet engines for its fleet of 14 Tristar airbuses on order from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation. The deal is a re negotiation of a financing pack age first arranged with the British banks last year to cover engines for 12 Tristars.

title: Advertising: New 1972 Hopeful
description: With just the proper amount of music and red, white and blue bunting, a Presidential candidate's cam paign headquarters opened right under the Kodak photo mural in Grand Central Ter minal yesterday.

title: M'GOVERN IN PERIL IN 3 MAJOR STATES
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9No one in Senator George McGov em's campaign pretends that he can win unless he takes Ohio, Michigan and Pennsyl vania, or at least two of them.

title: Antitrust on Wall Street
description: James J. Needham, new head of the New York Stock Exchange, has weighed in with a heavy attack on the Antitrust Division of the Justice Department for criti cizing a proposed rule of the Securities and Exchange Commission that would prevent most financial institu tionssuch as mutual funds, pension funds or insurance companiesfrom becoming members of stock exchanges.

title: McGovern Talks Tougher In Latest TV Commercials
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 Television viewers are glimps ing a new, tougher George McGovern as the Democratic Presidential campaign heads into its final month.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, Oct. 9 (AP)Japanese import licenses, a leading trade indicator, totaled $1.95billion in September, up 28.6 per cent from a year earlier, the Ministry of Inter national Trade and Industry announced today.

title: U.S. Keeps Eye on Bank Branches in London
description: LONDON, Oct. 9In 1960 there were six American na tional banks with branches in London. By the beginning of last year the number had grown to 16. Now there are 20, and two more have ap plied to Federal authorities in Washington to open branches here.

title: Bunker Sees Thieu Again
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Oct. 10 (UPI)The United States Ambassador, Ells worth Bunker, met privately for 45 minutes today with President Nguyen Van Thieu at the Presidential Palace. It was their third conference in a week. The topic of the meet ing was not announced, but political observers believed it dealt with the continuing peace negotiations in Paris.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE IN SLOW TRADING
description: The stock market ambled along an upward course yester day as the New York Stock Ex change recorded its slowest trading in nearly a year. The DowJones industrial average climbed 3.39 to 948.75.

title: Market Place
description: If you think the action is swift on the Big Board as institutions drop fat bundles of stock into that trading place, you should see the kind of maelstrom that can develop when traders become disenchanted with an over thecounter situation.

title: Vietnam Negotiations
description: Last week President Nixon said the secret Vietnam talks had reached a sensitive stage. Yesterday the White House announced that the current round of meet ings between Henry Kissinger and Hanoi's representa tives in Paris would go into an unprecedented third consecutive day today. One need not prejudge the out come to conclude that these are the most intensive and potentially the most importantefforts to end the Vietnam war since substantial United States involvement began a decade ago.

title: Honolulu to London, Nonstop
description: LONDON, Oct. 9 (AP)  An Air Canada Boeing 707 landed here today after a nonstop test flight from Honolulu and claimed a world distance rec ord for the type. The 7,770mile trip took 13 hours 39 minutes.

title: The Concordes Are Coming!
description: LONDONConcorde's fast and un eventful flight from England to Aus tralia and the Orienthalfway round the world and backhas brought ap preciably nearer the time when super sonic commercial air services will be everyday comfortable and ordinary.

title: VARIETY OFFERED AT ANTIQUE FAIR
description: The New York Antiques Fair, running through Sunday at the 69th Infantry Armory, Lexing ton Avenue and 26th Street, is a far cry from Connecticut an tiques shows, which recently ushered in the fall season.

title: Capt. Paul Cassard Dies; Navy Officer in World Wars
description: Capt. Paul Cassard, a re tired Navy officer who served in both World Wars, died here on Sunday. He was 82 years old and lived at 1700 York Avenue.

title: RoundTrip FareCollection System To Be Instituted Today on S.I. Ferries
description: Onetime, roundtrip fare collection, a system that has worked well on bridges here and elsewhere in the coun try, will be instituted this morning on the Staten Island ferries.

title: Nursing, Maligned and Pitied And Yet It's a Growing Field
description: When Mrs. Bonnie Gremse, a Cornell University graduate, announced she was going to enroll at nursing school, her mother said, You're too intelligent for that. Her stepfather urged her to apply to medical school instead and her friends predicted that she would be committing intellectual suicide.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Firestone Tire & Rubber Company said that it planned a multimillion dollar expansion and moderniza tionprogram at its vinyl resin operations at Pottstown, Pa., and Perryville, Md. The expansion would increase Fire stone's vinyl resin capacity by 43 per cent, to 400 million pounds a year.

title: Turkish Ban on Poppy: Delayed Impact Seen
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 4 Turkish and American officials engaged in the fight against illegal narcotics believe it will take considerable time before Turkey's ban on the growing of opium poppies can markedly reduce the flow of heroin to the United States.

title: Teamwork by Latins Bringing Growing Number of Drug Hauls
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 9  Newly forged cooperation be tween United States narcotics agents and South American police forces has led to the seizure of two large drug ship ments bound for the United States.

title: Books of The Times
description: KISSINGER: The Uses of Power. By David Landau, 270 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $5.95.

title: PRICES ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: The American Stock Ex change and the overthecoun ter market posted their second consecutive advance yesterday, but volume fell sharply be cause of the Columbus Day holiday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CAPT. A. D. KRAMER, NAVY CODE EXPERT
description: MIAMI, Oct. 9 (UPI)Capt. Alwin D. Kramer, U.S.N., re tired, whose work during the crucial hours before the Japa nese attack on Pearl Harbor led to a congressional inquiry, died at Lutheran. Medical Cenx ter yesterday after a long ill ness. He was 69 years old.

title: Iraq Petroleum Co. Awaits Further Talks
description: LONDON, Oct. 9 (Agence FrancePresse) Negotiations between the Iraqi Govern ment and the Westernowned Iraq Petroleum Company are making progress, and I.P.C. will take no legal action un til a further statement on mediation progress, the com pany said tonight.

title: LABOR LAWYER GETS POST WITH MURPHY
description: Bertram Perkel, a 42yearold labor lawyer, has been ap pointed special counsel to Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murhpy.

title: CYRIL H. JONES, 79, OF MILTON ACADEMY
description: HYANNIS, Mass., Oct. 9 Cyril Hamlen Jones, former headmaster of Milton Acade my and a former officer of the National Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation, died yesterday in Cape Cod Hospi tal. He was 79 years old and lived in Little Bluff Cotuit.

title: Politicians Woo Italians at Columbus Parade
description: A plethora of politicians of disparate political persuasions clustered together yesterday on a buntingdraped wooden stand on Fifth Avenue, sharing one thing in common in this elec tionyear: a belief in the effi cacy of the ItalianAmerican vote.

title: The Concordes Are Coming?
description: MARBLEHEAD, MassConcorde is the equivalent of an economic step back into the nineteenfifties.

title: Ida Lupino in Comeback After 15 Years
description: HOLLYWOOD  After 15 year absence from the movies, Ida Lupino is back in Junior Bonner, now play ing in the Metropolitan area, and she's giving the kind of gutsy, intelligent perform ance that made her a drama tic star in such early Lupino classics as Ladies in Retire ment and The Hard Way.

title: A Bomb Scare Empties New School Center Here
description: More than 400 students, faculty members and employes at the Graduate Faculty Center of the New School for Social Research were evacuated and classes were canceled for the rest of the evening because of a bomb scare last night:

title: Micronesians in Fight Over Strip Mining
description: SUVA, FijiA tiny com munity of displaced South Pacific islanders is battling against the British Govern ment and international phos phate interests over the rav aging of their oncefertile home island by strip mining. The islanders have won the first round.

title: TV Stations Will Air More Jersey News
description: NEWARK, Oct. 9The New Jersey Coalition for Fair Broad casting announced a series of binding agreements today with six New York City television stations that will require the stations to provide increased news and public affairs cover age of the state.

title: Police Report Snowfalls In Two Upstate Villages
description: COLTON, N.Y., Oct. 9 (AP) What may have been the first snowfall in New York State this fall was reported by state police patrol early today in this village on the north western slope of the Adi rotidacks.

title: ONE OF 4 HAMLETS REPORTED TAKEN BY SAIGON FORGES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Oct. 10Several hun dred Vietcong guerrillas con tinued to hold on yesterday in, at least three hamlets within 20 miles north of Saigon, Gov ernment military spokesmen said.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Inquiry Is Begun Into Bronx Death

title: WOMAN ASSAULTED ON EAST SIDE STREET
description: A 30yearold woman was robbed and sexaully molested at knifepoint last night on East 67th Street, two blocks from a police station, according to the police.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The 1972 Danish Parliament may not ratify the much heralded agreement, reached earlier this year by American and Danish representatives, to phase out and completely ban by 1976 high seas fishing for Atlantic salmon, accord ing to Richard A. Buck, chair man of the Committee on the Atlantic Salmon Emergency (C.A.S.E.).

title: House Contest
description: CLIFFSIDE PARK, N. J., Oct. 9  Although New Jersey doesn't pick a Governor until next year, a potential early heat has started in this year's version of the Ninth Congres sional District.

title: Cable TV Planning 23 Major Concerts
description: A season of 23 major con certsincluding 10 live pro grams by the New York Philharmonicis planned for cable television here by three of the city's foremost art in stitutions, Lincoln Center, the City Center and the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Poorer Countries Lag Further in Food Production
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 9Three major studies by the Food and Agriculture Organiza tion indicate that developing nations  even with foreign aid, expert help and modern technology  cannot grow enough food to meet their needs.

title: E.U.C. CONSIDERS NEW TRADE ZONE
description: LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 9  Spurred by France, the Common Market is pressing to devise general commercial strategy a for nonmember Mediterranean countries.

title: Typecast Takes $117,300 Man. o'War Stakes
description: A 6yearold mare named Typecast turned the $117,300 Man o'War Stakes into the Woman o'War yesterday at Belmont Park by thrashing 10 male rivals in the 14th running of the weightforage event.

title: ARCHBISHOP PROPHETA
description: Archbishop Walter Myron Propheta, founder in 1965 of the American Orthodox Catho lic Church, died Sunday in Montefiore Hospital after a long illness. He was 60 years old and lived in the parish house of the Church of the Resurrec tion, 675 East 183d Street, the ??.

title: Dartmouth Dean Appointed
description: HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 9 (AP) Dr. Carl F. Long, 44yearold associate dean and a Member of the faculty for 18 years, was named today as the eighth dean of the 101yearold Thayer School of Engineering at Dart mouth College. Dr. Long suc ceeds Dr. David V. Ragone, who resigned last spring to be come dean of the College of Engineering at the University of Michigan.

title: STRICT NOISE CURBS URGED BY COALITION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI)  Contending that the health and hearing of more than 80 million Americans are at stake, a coalition of labor, civic and medical groups called today for the enactment of tough anti noise legislation before Con gress adjourns.

title: DISEASE IMPERILS FLORIDA'S PALMS
description: MIAMI, Oct. 9Florida's co conut palms, affected by a rap idly spreading deadly disease first noticed here last year could become virtually extinct in the next 10 years, some specialists fear.

title: 8 Dead in Car Collision
description: GAINESVILLE, Ga., Oct. 9 (UPI)A station wagon carry ing members of two families to church services collided with another car last night, killing eight, persons and injuring four. Seven of the 11 persons in the station wagon, including four children, and the driver of the other car, Troy Lee Armour, 28

title: A Little Rock Pioneer Leads Minority Apprentice Program for Construction
description: Fifteen years ago, Ernest Green was one of nine black students who walked through hostile mobs to integrate Cen tral High School^in Little Rock, Ark. Today he heads a pro gram that is a pioneer in the techniques of recruiting minor ity workers for the building trades.

title: Savannah Classes Halted
description: SAVANNAH, GA., Oct. 9 (UN)  Classes were suspended at Savannah State College today in sorrow over the death of 22  year  old Melvin Bostick, who was struck by a hit and run car as he collected funds for the college scholarship fund. Mr. Bostick was at a busy downtown intersection, the police said, when persons in a car he had stopped grabbed him and his money collection box. He fell beneath a rear wheel.

title: 3 Buried Alive in CaveIn
description: BARBOURSVILLE, W. Va., Oct. 9 (AP)Three men were buried alive today when the sides of a 10foot deep sewer ditch collapsed on them. The police identified the men, all employes of the Earp Construe. tion Company of Huntington, as Tom S. Saunders, James C. Egnor, and Ricky Glenn Dam ron. The bodies were recovered.

title: BRITAIN DROPPING FIXED BANK RATE
description: LONDON, Oct. 9The bank rate, which for 270 years has been the peg for monetary policy and interest rates in Brit ain, was abolished today by Anthony Barber, the Chancellor of the Exchequer.

title: 5 Pilots Say Their Group Flew Unauthorized Raids
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9Five Navy pilots said in interviews today that their attack squad ron participated, under the guise of protective reaction, in at least three planned raids on a North Vietnamese airfield beginning last December.

title: 18 Researchers Get Grants To Study Cancer Abroad
description: American Cancer Society grants were announced here yesterday for 18 cancer re searchers throughout the world who will leave their native lands to work with scientists in other countries.

title: Woods Hole Ferry Is Set
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass., Oct. 9 (AP)A contract has been awarded for a new ferry for theWoods Hole, Martha's Vine yard and Nantucket Steamship Authority. The contract has been awarded to Bellinger Ship yards, Inc., of Jacksonville, Fla.

title: TV OUTLETS TO AIR MORE JERSEYEIS
description: NEWARK, Oct. 9The New Jersey Coalition for Pair Broad casting announced a series of binding agreements today with six New York City television stations that will require the stations to provide increased news and public affairs cover age of the state.

title: Jury Hung in Third U.S. Trial of Wolfson Here
description: The third Federal prosecu tion of Louis E. Wolfson, the financier accused of having lied to the Securities and Ex change Commission and having filed a false statement on a corporation he headed, ended in a mistrial yesterday.

title: Ginzburg Parole Due Today
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 9 (UPI)  Ralph Ginzburg, the publisher, will be paroled from Federal prison tomorrow, after having served eight months of a threeyear sentence for send ing obscene material through the mail. Officials at Allen wood Prison Farm confirmed today that Ginzburg would be paroled.

title: Mets Make Harrelson Available
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 9  Be hind the scenes of the Na tional League playoff, the New York Mets have opened their tradetalking season and even have offered their supposedly untouchable shortstop, Bud Harrelson.

title: Business Briefs
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., Oct. 9 (AP)Federal Judge Ben Krentzman sent Glenn W. Turner's securitiesviolation trial back to a state court today 90 minutes after the state judge delayed the trial while awaiting Judge Krentzman's decision. Pinellas County Circuit Judge William A. Patterson said the trial would begin in the county courthouse at Clear water tomorrow morning.

title: DOMINICK LEONE
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Oct. 9 Dominick Leone, founder of D. Leone, Inc., a real estate man agement firm, died today in Englewood Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Palisade.

title: EVERETT J. SHIFFLETT
description: Everett J. Shifflett, a retired partner in the international public accounting firm of Has kins & Sells, died Sunday in Phoenix, Ariz. He was 72 years old and formerly lived in Bronxville, N. Y.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The 1972 Danish Parliament may not ratify the much heralded agreement, reached earlier this year by American and Danish representatives, to phase out and completely ban by 1976 high seas fishing for Atlantic salmon, accord ing to Richard A. Buck, chair man of the Committee on the Atlantic Salmon Emergency (C.A.S.E.).

title: Holiday Inns to Expand
description: Holiday Inns, Inc., announced yesterday it had granted fran chises for units at seven sites in Brazil to Roy E. Winegard ner, a Cincinnati businessman. The hotel chain said Mr. Wine gardner, with Brazilian part ners, planned Holiday Inns at six sites in the So Paulo area and a site near Copacabana Beach in Rio de Janerio.

title: MIKHAIL SLONIMSKY
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 9 (AP)Mik hail L. Slonimsky, a novelist, whose work closely reflected changes in the Soviet political, climate, has died at the age of, 75, Izvestia, the Govermnent newspaper reported today.

title: DR. S. EMLEN STOKES
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., Oct. 9 Dr. S. Ernlen Stokes, pedia trician for more than 50 years, died of cancer today in the Burlington County Memorial Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived on Chester Avenue in Moorestown.

title: McGovern Outlook Bleak In 3 Key Industrial States
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9No one in Senator George McGov ern's campaign pretends that he can win unless he takes Ohio, Michigan and Pennsyl vania, or at least two of them.
