description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  Four of President Nixo's ad visers declined today to appear before the House Banking and Currency Committee to answer questions about the breakin at the offices of the Democratic National Committee.

title: Letter to the Editor 1  No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: UNION OFFICIAL SEES APPAREL SALES GAIN
description: Manufacturers sales of wo men's and children's apparel in the final four months of this year should increase by more than 9 per cent, compared with the level a year ago, Dr. Lazare Teper, research director of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, said yesterday.

title: House Contest
description: There are three other candi dates running for the House of Representatives in the 20th Congressional District for the seat held by the late William F. Ryan.

title: U.S. Women Take Lead
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 11 (AP) The United States, the de fending champion, took the firstround lead today in the women's amateur team golf tournament on the soggy Hindu Country Club course.

title: Rebate on Auto Insurance Ordered in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, Oct. 11 (AP)  Re bates on 1971 automobile insur ance premiums, averaging $12 a car for Massachusetts motor ists, were ordered today as result of a sharp decline in claims payments resulting from the twoyearold nofault auto insurance law.

title: Metropolitan Unveils Arp Sculpture in Park
description: A twoton stainlesssteel sculpture by the European master Jean Arp was dedicated yesterday by the Metropoli tan Museum of Art, which has installed the work in a Central Park setting at the southwest corner of the museum.

title: Books of The Times
description: The lightning of success has not been striking, the same author twice of late at least not if you consider what happened to Jim Bouton with I'm Glad You Didn't Take It Personally, or Laurence J. Peter with The Peter Prescription. So it was with a certain degree of wariness that I cracked open Supermoney by Adam Smith the other day, and began to read. Adam Smith is of course George J. W. Goodman, the editor of an investment counseling magazine and a man who knows his way up and down Wall Street. And Supermoney is the sequel to The Money Game, a relentlessly witty book that rose to the top of the bestseller lists a few years ago, explained to the world how the stock market game was really played and made us all giggle. But reading Supermoney with the sound of those flopping sequels still echoing down the hall, I couldn't help but wonder: Is there anything more to say about the Money game? And can it still make us giggle?

title: CONGRESS DEADLOCK BLOCKS TRANSIT AID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 House and Senate conferees were unable to agree today on how to parcel out the multi billiondollar Federal Highway Trust Fund, and the deadlock major highway bill for the year.

title: TEXTILE UNION GETS TWO 6% INCREASES
description: A new twoyear contract be tween the Textile Workers Un ion of America and 125 dyeing and textile processing com panies in the metropolitan area will provide for two annual pay increases of 6 per cent for 7,000 dye workers, the union announced yesterday.

title: Inmates in Capital Seize 10 Hostages, Release Them All After 22 Hours
description: WASHINGTON, Thursday, Oct. 12Inmates of the District of Columbia jail staged a rebel lion yesterday that ended after 22 hours with the release of the last of 10 hostages early this morning.

title: Boston Paper Backs Nixon
description: BOSTON, Oct. 11 (AP)The Boston Herald Traveler and Record American today en dorsed President Nixon for reelection, saying that his White House record is good and worthy of a strong vote of confidence from the peo ple. The newspaper is pub lished by the Hearst corpora tion.

title: Music Hall Closing In Contract Dispute With Its Orchestra
description: The Radio City Music Hall announced last night that it was suspending operations to day for the first time in its 40year history because mem bers of its orchestra had re jected a final contract offer.

title: Inmates in Capital Seize 10 Hostages, Then Accept Plan to Free Them
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11  Rebelling inmates of the Dis trict of Columbia Jail seized the director of the city's Depart ment of Corrections early to day and threatened to kill him and nine other hostages if they were not set free.

title: ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC FADES
description: A threeday upswing on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market ended yesterday as prices de clined in slow trading.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 11 (AP) Al McDonough tallied three goals, leading the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 52 N.H.L. vic tory tonight over the St. Louis Blues.

title: France Makes Protest
description: PARIS, Oct. 11The French Government formally protested the bombing of its Hanoi diplo matic mission today.

title: House Votes 265 to 75 for StripMining Controls
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) Legislation to provide for regulation of the strip mining of coal and the conservation and reclamation of stripmining areas was passed by the House today and sent to the Senate. The vote was 265 to 75.

title: The Guys in the Next Bloc
description: AUSTIN, Tex.There is something wild about the way people of the Southwest are voting. Ideologically opposed people find common cause in astonishing alternations. Wallace people and McGovern people have a converging resentment of taxes, and government has become a they: It's us against them. The emerging new Southwest blocs of voterswomen, peace people, pot smokers and homo sexualsare just as intense in their causes as the older blocs ever were.

title: New G.E. Computer Service
description: BETHESDA, Md., Oct. 11 (UPI)  The General Electric Company today announced a new computer service it said combined for the first time the economy of remote batch data processing and use of the world's largest information net work. The new G.E. system called Mark III, is available by local telephonecall access in 250 cities in North America. Also, 30 cities in Europe can be reached via satellite or cable telephone to use Mark III facil ities.

title: Correction Officers Picket Nassau Jail
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I., Oct. 11Almost 100 uniformed and offduty Nassau County correc tion officers picketed for about three hours in front of the county jail here this morning Lo protest that they were al legedly not receiving equal rights with those given the prison inmates.

title: Rehnquist Memorandum
description: Justice William H. Rehnquist has gone to extraordi nary lengths to justify his participation in cases which had been within his jurisdiction as a Justice Department official prior to his appointment to the Supreme Court. The cases involved a challenge by a group of war resist ers of the Army's surveillance of civilians and a similar challenge by Senator Mike Gravel of the Justice Depart ment's right to question his aides about his intent publish the Pentagon Papers. In both instances, Justice Rehnquist's participation resulted in 5to4 rulings in favor of the Government.

title: Mideast OilPact Meeting Is Set
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 11  Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's Minister of Pe troleum, has invited oil minis ters from Persian Gulf oilpro ducing areas to meet in Ku wait Sunday for an examin ation of an accord negotiated with major Western oil com panies on participation in pro duction.

title: ExSenator Torn Stewart, Scopes Trial Prosecutor
description: NASHVILLE, Oct. 11 (UPI) Former United States Senator Tom Stewart, who was the prosecutor in the 1925 Scopes monky trial, died today at the age of 80.

title: Fleetwood Closes Plant
description: Fleetwood Enterprises, Inc., cility in Ashland, Ohio, because said yesterday that it had closed its modular housing fa order backlogs were insuffi cient to allow profitable oper ations. The company had previously closed its modular housing plant in Quincy, Mich.

title: Music Hall Closing In Contract Dispute With Its Orchestra
description: The Radio City Music Hall announced last night that it was suspending operations to day for the first time in its 40year history because mem bers of its orchestra had re jected a final contract offer.

title: Diplomacy by Terror
description: The devastation of the French diplomatic mission Hanoi during an American air attack yesterday dramatizes the inherent contradictions of Administration policy the effort to settle the war in Indochina.

title: Dr. James Alan Rosen Dies; Retired Gynecologist, 64
description: Dr. James Alan Rosen, a gynecologist and obstetrician who retired two years ago for health reasons, died Tuesday night at his home, 200 Central Park South. His age was 64.

title: Women's Campus Rights
description: The community of scholars, which prides itself on freedom from prejudices, clearly has not treated women as equals. Admission to graduate school, the gateway academic power, often is easier for male applicants. Women faculty members have frequently been denied equality of academic status and pay. Predominantly male academic departments tend, perhaps unwittingly, to recruit more men to fill vacancies.

title: FOREIGN SERVICE LOSES COURT TEST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10A threejudge Federal court here has declared unconstitutional a provision of the Foreign Serv ice Act of 1946 requiring that anyone appointed a United States Foreign Service officer must have been a United States citizen for at least 10 years.

title: Griffith Wins Split Verdict From DeNucci in Boston
description: BOSTON, Oct. 11 (AP)Emile Griffith, the fivetime world boxing chainpion, scored a 12 round split decision over Joe DeNucci tonight at the Garden.

title: JUDGES HERE TOLD TO FORGO HOLIDAY
description: The traditional twoweek Christmas holiday for State Su preme Court judges in Man hattan and the Bronx has been revoked by the Appellate Divi sionat least for this year.

title: CONFEREES SNAG ON HIJACKING BILL
description: Chances for Congressional passage of an antihijacking bill this year all but collapsed yes terday when a SenateHouse conference on differing ver sions ended in hard disagree ment.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Twentytwo members of a class in environmental design created a room of their own with nothing in it.

title: 19 Tunisians Killed in Crash
description: TUNIS, Oct. 11 (Agence FrancePresse) Nineteen Tuni sians were killed and 43 in jured when an army truck col lided with another vehicle near Medenine, in southeast Tunisia, on Monday, it was announced here today. The truck was bringing back Tunisian workers who had emigrated clandes tinely to Libya.

title: RABBI MAX ZUCKER
description: PASSAIC, N. J., Oct. 11 Rabbi Max Zucker, who retired, in 1966 after 41 years as rabbi of Temple Emanuel, died yes terday of pneumonia at Moult Sinai Hospital, Miami Beach. His age was 74.

title: Hartsfield to Join Braves
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 11 (UPI) The Atlanta Braves, needing a first base coach to fill Manager Eddie Mathews's former job, brought Roy Hartsfield, a Los Angeles Dodger coach, back to his native Atlanta today. Eddie Robinson, the Braves director of player personnel, said that the 46yearold Hartsfield, who had been with the Dodgers since 1969, would join the Braves immediately.

title: Film Festival: A Gem From Truffaut
description: Franois Truffaut's "Two English Girls" is a film of such beautiful, charming and comic discretion that it isn't until the end that one realizes it's also immensely sad and even brutal, though in the nonbrutalizing way that truth can sometimes be.The film was shown last night at the New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall and opens its commercial engagement Sunday at the Fine Arts Theater, where, I trust, it will remain through Thanksgiving, Christmas and beyond.The source material is "Les Deux Anglaises et Le Continent," the second novel by Henri-Pierre Roch, who didn't get around to writing his first until he was 74. That was "Jules et Jim," which Truffaut adapted into his finest film in 1961.A bit too much will probably be made of the fact that "Two English Girls" reverses the central situation of "Jules and Jim," in which the two heroes spend their lives being turned on and off by the liberated Catherine.The new film, like the earlier one, is set largely in an undefined past  that is, sometime in pre-World War I Paris, though the exact time is left fuzzy, as times usually are in fables. Instead of two young men, the victims (who are in great measure the mistresses of their fates) are two proper English girls, sisters, who share a profound attachment for the same young Frenchman.In many ways, however, "Two English Girls" is more closely linked to such later (and dissimilar) Truffaut films as "The Soft Skin," "Mississippi Mermaid" and "Stolen Kisses," each a variation on the conflict between a love that is obsessive (sometimes called pure) and a mortal one that is always aware of compromise."Jules and Jim" touches on this. "Two English Girls" is about nothing else. "Jules and Jim" also has to do with a number of other things, including social satire, and is and ambitious work of a much younger director. "Two English Girls" is less lyric, more spare, completely preoccupied by not only the the extremely complicated moral barriers to love, but also by the physical impediments.In no other film he has made has Tuffaut ever expressed the ruthless ecstasy of the scene in "Two English Girls" in which Claude (Jean-Pierre Laud) finally takes the virginity of the pure Muriel (Stacey Tendeter). Unlike her sister Anne (Kika Markham, who accepts her sexuality, though with scarcely more happy results, Muriel, who manages to look like both Queen Elizabeth and Catherine Deneuve, behaves like a princess in a fairy tale. She hides behind dark glasses, as if she had suffered a wicked enchantment, and says such things as "I want all of Claude or nothing. If it's no, let it be like death."The film covers seven years in the lives of the curious trio, much of it as if the film were the daily journal that was Roch's favorite literary form. The scenes are sometimes so short they are almost subliminal, with the voice of the narrator (Truffaut) often supplying a text. Purists, I expect, will again object to this tampering with the accepted relationship between image, which the purists think is paramount, and word, which has always been thought to be a lesser tool of cinema.The effect, nevertheless, is lovely, and even appropriate, since fables begin with spoken words. The performances are fine. Laud may well beas Truffaut calls himthe greatest French actor of his generation. At least I think that explains why he seemed so off-puttingwhich he was supposed toin "Bed and Board" and here, as the earnestly free-loving rake, so appealing.The film is filled with wonderful things, but I especially remember the sequence in which Anne and Claude spend a week in a cabin on a lake in Switzerland. "They were more resolute than in love," says the narrator. "Their program was simple: live first and define it later." At the end of the week, we see them in a long-shot, rowing away from the islandin separate rowboats.

Ac cepted bids ranged from a low of 7.8 per cent to a high of 8.001 per cent. Last month, bids ranged from 7.764 to 8 per cent.

title: Double Bill of Horror Arrives
description: Wise horror fans will skip "Vampire Circus" and settle for "Countess Dracula" on the new double bill at the Forum. Both are Hammer Productions, England's scream factory, but the first was dealt a quick, careless anvil. With some care and attention, the Countess fares considerably better.How's this for a new vampire gimmick? She's a doddering old palace crone, restored as a ravishing, lusty young blonde each time her servants deliver her a new, village blood victim. Meanwhile her sexual quarry is a handsome young Hussar officer next door. Add, for good measure, an Iago-like steward, as the countess's paramour.Until the two-thirds mark, it all works very well indeed. Peter Sasdy's direction is smooth and pointed and the dialogue has a crisp, cutting edge. The dcor and the costumes, given a nice Balkan-Turkish flavoring, are beautiful and so is the music. The horror uncoils steadily, cushioned by a kind of stylish relish on all sides, including the acting.Furthermore for all the thematic gore, the story has a cool, built-in poignancy in the scenes of the desperate old countess grasping at youth and beauty. One minute she creaks like parchment, the next she's a Playboy centerfold. Ingrid Pitt, as both, is truly a sight.But the picture runs out of gas, along with the desperate old woman. An intriguing set-up, ripe for a slam-bang finale, slackens disappointingly, with much prolonged milling around. Hammer lets things flap instead of socking a home-run clout, leaving Miss Pitt and such capable veterans as Nigel Green and Maurice Denham more or less on their own."Countess Dracula" is better than most in a sea of trashy competition. Good bad girl!

George Crumb's Vox Balaenae, which was per formed for the first time here on Tuesday night by the Aeolian Chamber Players, sounded like one of the less er creatures in the compos er's increasingly impressive collection. On first immer sion, the score (subtitled Voice of the Whale) caught one's fancy chiefly for Mr. Crumb's exceptional ability to draw evocative sonorities out of instruments.

description: The Cincinnati Reds won the National League pennant yesterday in Cincinnati when Bob Moose of the Pittsburgh Pirates threw a wild pitch with two out in the ninth inning, letting George Foster, a pinchrunner score front third with the tiebreaking run in a 43 victory.

While they were being stopped for a rou tine traffic check, marijuana and other drugs were found in their vehicle, according to Jarvis Seccombe, the Den ver County District Attorney. The charges against Abdul Jabbar and one of the com panions were dropped be cause of insufficient evi dence, Seccombe said. Each charge against Allen carries a maximum penalty of a year in and $500 fine.

It was most surprising to me, therefore, to find the endorsement of George McGovern in your news paper last week.

title: Letter to the Editor 7  No Title
description: Since Senator George McGovern is far, behind in the Presidential race (editorial Sept. 28) it is apparent the vast majority of the American people do not agree with the editors of The Times, who support McGovern's elec tion.

title: French Submarine Sink
description: LORIENT, France, Oct. 11 (AP)The French submarine La Sirene sank at its moorings in this northern port today after emergency bulkheads failed to stop water pouring in through an open torpedo tube. The 700 ton vessel will be refloated over the next few days. There were no injuries.

title: Lyons Leads by a Stroke With 70 in Seniors Golf
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Oct. 11Toby Lyons of Burn ing Tree, who won the title in 1968 and 1969, took a one stroke lead today in the first round of the eighth annual senior championship of the Metropolitan section of the Pro fessional Golfers' Association by scoring 35, 3570 on the 6,564 yard, par36, 3571 course at the Briar Hall Golf and Coun try Club.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When an observer becomes trapped by the lack of ubiquitousness during the simultaneous unfolding of a couple of highpowered baseball dramas, he sometimes will elect to try to absorb both in one greedy gulp by way of the magic lantern. Admittedly it would be preferable to have a magic carpet for instantaneous transportation from Isle ball park to the other. Unfortunately, however, my usually reliable magic carpet had to go to the shop for repairs.

title: Advertising:
description: Once you've hit the viewer with the same commercial three times, all the rest is overkill, a psychologist said at meeting of advertising people yesterday.

title: Robbery Suspect Seized
description: GARNERVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 11Bobby Bryan, 24 years old, was arrested at the Fairview Apartments here early today by two deputy sheriffs and a Federal Bureau Investigation agent who charged him with the armed robbery yesterday of $9,441 from the North, Rock land branch of the Nanuet Na tional Bank here. The money and the gun allegedly used in the robbery were recovered in the apartment, authorities said.

title: ZEVI SCHARFSTEIN, HEBREW EDUCATOR
description: Dr. Zevi Scharfstein, a He brew educator, died yesterday in New Haven while visiting his daughter, Mrs. Sulamith Chern off. He was 88 years old and lived in Long Beach, L. I.

title: Exhibition to Show 2 Centuries of Hudson River Art
description: Contemporary Hudson Riv er paintings will be featured alongside prints of 19thcen tury works by masters of the Hudson River School at a showing in Nyack, N. Y., be ginning Sunday afternoon. The exhibition will mark the opening of the Hudson Valley Gallery at 152 Main Street. It will run through Oct. 28. It will run through Oct. 28.

title: Chou Gives Details of Flight and Death of Lin Piao to U.S. Editors
description: Premier Chou Enlai of China has said that Lin Piao, the Defense Minister who reported ly fled the country when his plot to assassinate Chairman Mao Tsetung was uncovered, was burned to death when the private plane secretly ordered by his son for the escape crashed in Mongolia en route to the Soviet Union.

title: Sabres Down Kings, 73
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 11 (AP) Rick Martin, who set a National Hockey League rookie record of 44 goals last season, got his first two of the 197273 cam paign tonight, helping the Buf falo Sabres beat the Los An geles Kings, 73.

title: Steve Thompson Returns To Bolster Jets' Defense
description: The word that the New York Jets need help on their defensive line has apparently spread all the way to Santa Barbara, Calif., and the tiny religious enclave of Steve Thompson, their retired de fensive tackleend, who an nounced he was returning to professional football and the team yesterday.

title: Sonics Beat 76ers, 105100
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 (AP) The Seattle SuperSonics out scored Philadelphia, 3013, in the second quarter tonight and went on to a 105100 National Basketball Association victory over the 76ers.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) College students should be wary of a buy now, pay later insurance swindle that has turned up on at least one cam pus, State Senator James H. Wallwork warned today.

title: N.B.C. HEAD SCORES F.C.C.'S DOCTRINE
description: Julian Goodman, president of the National Broadcasting Com pany, called yesterday for the outright elimination of the Fed eral Communications Commis sion's Fairness Doctrine"the presentation of contradictory views on controversial issues as a Government standard for the coverage of news on televi sion and radio.

title: Anniversaries
description: BERENSONFannie & Jack. Hwy 60th. Many More. Daughter Judith Mann, Grand children Lois Beth, Bruce, Steven, Robert.

title: A TradingStamp Panic Strikes Plaidlands Here
description: Thousands of New Yorkers clutching brown paper bags filled with books of trading stamps, have been collecting in long, shuffling lines at Plaid Stamp redemption cen ters in frantic moves to re deem stamps that will no longer be issued by the 200 A. & P. supermarkets here.

title: Lorna Luft, Another Kid in the Family of Singers
description: Lorna Luft has a towel wrapped around her neck. Her room at the St. Regis reeks with the aromatic pungence of BenGay. The fresh  faced. 20  year  old daughter of Judy Garland, halfsister of Liza Minelli, made her New York night club debut in the St. Regis Maisonette on Monday night and her voice is so hoarse she can barely speak.

title: Big Board Studies Holidays
description: The New York Stock Ex change said yesterday that it planned to explore the pros and cons of closing in observ ance of all Federal holidays. However, the exchange said it would remain open for business on Veterans Day, Oct. 23. James J. Needham, chairman of the exchange, had said previ ously that the exchange was considering closing on Veter ans Day.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: LONG POND, Lempster, N. H.All through the bright and gusty afternoon, Vic Pomiecko and I flailed the clear waters of this western New Hampshire trout pond with a variety of flies, and, by 5:30, we had caught two fairsized brook trout and two splake.

title: Senate Panel, in a Secret Session, Votes 13 Special Tax Relief Bills
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The Senate Finance Committee, in an unannounced action today, approved 13 special tax relief bills, including one that could mean substantial tax refunds for some airlines.

title: Nixon Back at White House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) President and Mrs. Nixon re turned to the White House to night after a short stay at their Camp David, Md., retreat.

title: DIPLOMAT IS HURT
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Oct. 11The buildings of the French diplomatic mission to North Vietnam Were wrecked, today during an American bombing raid on the Hanoi area, and Pierre Susini, its chief diplomat, was seriously injured.

title: Hogan Stitt Bitter Over Nadjari Post
description: District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of Manhattan described himself yesterday as still bit ter over the appointment of a special State prosecutor to combat corruption in the city's legal system and said he had told Governor Rockefeller:

title: House Votes Bonuses to Get Skilled Military Volunteers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 Bonuses ranging from $600 to $17.000 to attract doctors and men with needed skills into an allvolunteer military won approval today in the House.

title: PAUL RICCA DEAD; GANG FIGURE, 74
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (UPI) Paul (The Waiter) Ricca, often called the elder statesman of the Chicago crime syndicate, died today of a heart attack, at Presbyterian St. Luke's Hos pital. He was 74 years old.

title: Letter to the Editor 6  No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 BUILDINGS BURNED, MAN SHOT IN BELFAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Thursday, Oct. 12 (UPI)  A gunman shot a British soldier through the head, attackers kid napped a policeman and angry Protestant mobs in Beltast burned down two bars and a factory during the night, a Brit ish Army spokesman said early today.

title: STATE DENIES A LOSS OF AID TO RETARDED
description: The State Department of Mental Hygiene denied yester day that the 11 schools for the mentally retarded face $36million loss in Medicaid funds because their accredita tion had been changed to lower category.

title: Letter to the Editor 5  No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Act on Exports
description: TOKYO, Oct. 11 (AP)The Japan Machinery Exporters As sociation said today it would put into effect an export price cartel to regulate blackand white television and tapere corder exports to nine Euro pean countries, except West Germany, beginning Oct. 20. Officials said the cartel, which sets minimum export prices rather than impose quantitative controls, is expected to remain in effect until Dec. 31.

title: PENSION PLAN ABUSE BY MILITARY HINTED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr., releasing figures on the retire ment of generals and admirals, said today that it appeared there may be abuse of the sen ior officers' pension system.

title: Rev. William B. Spofford Dead; Witness Editor and Labor Ally
description: TUNKHANNOCK, Pa., Oct. 11  The Rev. William B. Spofford, editor of Witness, the national Protestant Episco pal weekly, and a wellknown militant clergyman who often clashed with conservatives, died at his home here Mon day. His age was 80.

title: Emergency Landing
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 11 (UN) A United Airlines DC10 with 103 persons aboard, made an emergency landing last night after a faulty warning light caused the pilot to shut down one of the huge jet's three engines. The plane was the first DC10 to land at Memphis International Airport.

title: Common Market Studies Gold Role
description: PARIS, Oct. 11  The Eu ropean Common Market is mov ing toward a decision that in effect would freeze the gold reserves of its member states until an international determi nation about the metal's role in the monetary system is made, according to official sources.

title: Personal Finance
description: Wouldn't it be much eas ier to put up with the an ual chore of filling out incometax forms if someone were able to find a way to reduce some of the paper work?

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) Governor Cahill today pro claimed the week of Oct. 16 23 as County Government Week and announced a move to develop closer ties be tween the state and the 21 county governments.

title: A. B. A. Head Sees Tighter Money in 1973
description: DALLAS, Oct. 11  The an nual convention of the nation's banking profession ended here today with a prediction by the newly elected president of the American Bankers Association that tighter money  but no credit crunchwas in store for 1973.

title: State Aides Agree on SportVehicle Controls, Differ on Controller
description: ALBANY, Oct. 11State of ficials agreed here today that something must be done to con trol the A.T.V.'sall terrain vehiclesthat are roving in creasingly in the wilderness. But they all said someone else should do the job.

title: Integration Plan Delayed
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 11 (AP) A school desegregation plan for Chattanooga was delayed today when the United States Court of Appeals for th Sixth Circuit sent it back to a lower court for further study. The plan, which was re manded to Federal District Judge Frank Wilson of Chatta nooga, would set ratios of not less than 30 per cent nor more than 70 per cent of any race in the city's elementary and junior high schools.

title: Letter to the Editor 8  No Title
description: I noticed that eight out of ten cor respondents whose letters appeared Oct. 5 disagreed with your editorial choice of Senator McGovern for Presi dent. Is this indicative of the general reader response to your endorsement of Senator McGovern? I'm sure many of your readers would be interested in a tabulation of Times readers. How about a box scoreto date.

title: A Sinister Affair
description: The Watergate, affair has taken an astonishing and profoundly disturbing turn.

title: Wine Making at Home: If You're So inclined, Now Is the Time
description: What this country really needs is a good 50cent bottle of wine. You laugh, but it's possible if you're willing to make your own.

title: Statement Phoned From U.S. By JOSEPH B. TREASTER
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 11As reports of damage to the French mission in Hanoi be gan to reach Saigon today, the American high command was swamped with inquiries. At first spokesmen would only confirm that United States planes had been operating over North Vietnam today.

title: People and Business
description: William J. Casey, who has been making about one speech a week lately and thereby winning the title of most talkative chairman of the Securities and Exchange Comimssion in history, made another one yesterday. This time he spoke at the New York district conference of the Securities Industry As sociation about the need for selfdiscipline and self policing.

title: CANADIENS RALLY AND TIE LEAFS, 22
description: TORONTO, Oct. 11 (UPI) Yvan Cournoyer's second goal of the game with 1 minute 54 seconds remaining in the final period gave the Montreal Ca nadiens a 22 tie tonight with the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Councilman Katz Urges Botein To Withdraw as an Arbitrator
description: Bernard Botein, former pre siding justice of the Appellate Division, was urged yesterday to disqualify himself as the arbitrator in a dispute involv ing a $520,000 legal fee paid to a politically connected law yer, on the ground that Mr. Botein himself had been hired by the lawyer two years ago and paid a fee of over $100, 000.

title: LINDSAY FREEZES YOUTH UNIT FUNDS
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday or dered an immediate freeze on program commitments and con tracts for the Youth Board Re search Institute pending a review of both the operations and need for its activities.

title: CONGRESS GETS BILL ON BIG BOARD RULE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) A bill to repeal a New York Stock Exchange rule against transactions by members off its floor was introduced in the House today.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Fiberfil division of Dart Industries, Inc., said yesterday in Los Angeles that it had obtained a favorable judgment against E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. for infringement of a basic patent covering the manufacture of glassreinforced thermoplastic injection molding resins.

title: The Guys in the Next Bloc
description: CHICAGOIt used to be an article of faith that the Middle West was a conservative bastion, inhabited by a people whose emotional outlet was hissing President Roosevelt in the newsreels. This idea has persisted, at least outside the region, and it is high time it was corrected.

title: The Situation in Idi Amin's Uganda: Unpredictability Is the Order of the Day
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 11 When the presidents of Zaire and Uganda met in Kampala last week, Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire came away believing that President Idi Amin had agreed to extend the Nov. 8 deadline for expelling thousands of alien Asians.

title: Notes on People
description: When the two passengers listed as Mr. and Mrs. Green aboard the El Al flight from New York left their plane in London, they were sur rounded by police and es corted to a waiting car. They both have flu and need a rest, said an Israeli official. The Greens were Foreign Minister Abba Eban and his wife, who often travel under assumed names for security reasons. They were scheduled to fly to Tel Aviv tomorrow.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BUCHAREST, Oct. 11 (AP)The United States team practiced on soggy red clay courts today and hoped for more sunshine before defending the Davis Cup against Rumania.

title: Market Place: Horizon's News Is Met by Panic
description: It was the Horizon Corpo ration's turn to unsettle in vestors yesterday. The Ari zona landdeveloper indicated before the opening bell on the New York Stock Ex change that secondquarter sales might be down 15 or 20 per cent from a year ear Her and that earnings for the period could be even more significantly affected.

title: U.S. LASHES OUT AT CUBA IN U. N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 11The United States lashed out angrily at Cuba in the General Assembly tonight.Exercising its right to reply, the United States was repre sented at the podium in a sur prise move by Mrs. Julia Rivera de Vincenti of Puerto Rico. In fiery Spanish she told the As sembly that her people were tired of Cuban interference in the affairs of Puerto Rico and the United States.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird accused Senator George McGovern today of advocating a policy of unconditional sur render in Vietnam.

title: LAKERS TOP KINGS IN OPENER, 12994
description: OMAHA, Oct. 11 (AP)The Los Angeles Lakers opened defense of their National Bas ketball Association title in pre cisionlike fashion tonight and defeated the Kansas City Omaha Kings, 12994.

title: Murtagh Reported Chosen As Anticorruption Judge
description: State Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh has been se lected by Governor Rockefeller to be the presiding justice for the special grand juries that will hear evidence gathered by the state's new anticorruption prosecutor, according to a high official source.

title: 43 Defeat of A's Sets Up Final Playoff Came Today
description: DETROIT, Oct. 11  The large, elaborate black and sil ver American League cham pionship trophy sat on a desk in the Oakland locker room, three outs away from being presented to the WesternDivi sion winner. Oakland A's 1972, was the inscription on the large silver plate on the front of the trophy.

title: Angels Drop Rice as Pilot, Name ExCollege Coach
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 11 (AP) Bobby Winkles, a former coach of collegiate baseball champion Arizona State Univer sity who joined the Angels this season, was named manager of the California team of the American League today, replac ing Del Rice.

title: U.S. IS REGRETFUL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The United States moved quickly today to express regret over the damage to the French Mis sion in Hanoi, but said the de struction might have been caused by a North Vietnamese antiaircraft missile and not by American bombs.

title: The Guys in the Next Bloc
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On the West Coast, even Orange County is no long er reliable. After John G. Schmitz was elected to the state legislature eight years ago, he was asked why he had told the voters he was a member of the John Birch Society. I had to do something to win the liberal vote in Orange County, he replied cheerfully.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11I was elected to smash the labor bosses.Representative Rich ard M. Nixon, quoted in an in terview on his first day in Con gress, Jan. 3, 1947.

title: Business Briefs
description: GENEVA, Oct. 11A United Nations attempt to con clude an international agreement regulating world trade cocoa was deadlocked tonight on a minimum price for exporters. The 60nation cocoa conference decided to extend its work beyond its Friday deadline in an attempt to get an accord on a draft agreement. Arrangements have been made to enable the conference, now in its fifth week, to continue until Tuesday.

title: Reds Win Pennant
description: The Cincinnati Reds won the National League pennant yesterday in Cincinnati when Bob Moose of the Pittsburgh Pirates threw a wild pitch with two out in the ninth inning, letting George Foster, a pinchrunner score from third with the tiebreaking run in a 43 victory.

title: Kennedy Says 45 Babies, Died in a Test
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said yesterday that 45 infants died in a 1958 Los Angeles study on ways of reducing the high mortality rate of prema ture infants.

title: U.S. WarCrimes Hearings Are Begun in Copenhagen
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 11 (Reuters)A group called the International Commission of Inquiry Into United States War Crimes in Indochina be gan hearing witnesses today amid strong criticism from Op position politicians and the press.

title: Celtics Beat Pistons
description: DEPROIT, Oct. 11 (UPI) John Havlicek scored 29 points and Boston shot 50 per cent from the floor in the second half tonight as the Celtics, de fending Atlantic Division cham pions, downed the Detroit Pis tons, 121108, in the N.B.A. opener for both teams.

title: ANACONDA UNIT SETS HIGHER TUBE PRICES
description: The Anaconda American Brass Company, a unit of the Anaconda Company, said yes terday that it would increase list prices for copper water tube items of four inches in diameter or under by 2.25 per cent, effective Oct. 24. On the same day, increases of 3 per cent will go, into effect for one quarterinch and threeeighth inch items.

title: Racism in East Africa
description: Apart from the severe human hardship inflicted, the most alarming aspect of President Amin's abrupt expul sion of Asians from Uganda is that it was highly popular with the country's African majority. He may indeed have decreed the tragic exodus at this time to shore up a support that was melting away in the face of his earlier repressive acts and a declining Ugandan economy.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 11A form er assistant United States at torney and a law partner of Representative Cornelius E. Gal lagher, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of incometax evasion and the filing of a false tax return for 1966.

title: FUNDS ARE URGED FOR CHECKING CABS
description: The Taxi Comraission chair man, Michael J. Lazar, renewed his plea yesterday for Board of Estimate approval of a $2 million taxicab inspection sta tion in Long Island City, Queens.

title: M'GOVERN POLICY ASSAILED BY STEIN
description: Herbert Stein, President Nixon's chief economic ad viser, came to the New York Society of Security Analysts where Senator George Mc Govern spoke Aug. 29and warned that a Democrat vic tory in November would result in inflation, taxation, stagna tion and vacillation.

title: CON ED CHIEF URGES OFFSHORE DRILLING
description: Charles F. Luce, chairman of Consolidated Edison of New York, Inc., called yesterday for immediate steps towards open ing the Continental Shelf off the East Coast for oil and gas ex ploration.

title: Planning Commission Approves Building With Mormon Church
description: Despite attacks on the Mor mon churth as racist, the City Planning Commission voted 4 to 2 yesterday to approve the construction of a 38story mixeduse structure containing apartments and a Morman church opposite the Juilliard School of Music.

title: SAMUEL J. BROAD
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 11 Samuel John Broad, a former president of the American Insti tute of Accountants, died today in White Plains Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 159 Brite Avenue.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, Oct. 11 (Reuters)Premier Kakuei. Tanaka said today that he might consider imposing an export sur charge if additional measures were needed to curb Japan's growing trade surplus. Earlier this week Mr. Tanaka ruled out a Finance Ministry proposal for a 10 per cent surcharge to curb exports. Officials are now working on an alterna tive program to increase imports to reduce the trade sur plus, now running at a rate of $8billion a year.

title: Acheson Remembered
description: Tragic nemesis is apparently catch ing up with Richard M. Nixon. He is being forced, as President, to pursue the same temptations of naive states manship that once led Alger Hiss, on a much lower level, to collaborate secretly with Communist officials and to lie about it when caught.

title: U.S. IS REGRETFUL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The United States moved quickly today to express regret over the damage to the French Mis sion in Hanoi, but said the de struction might have been caused by a North Vietnamese antiaircraft missile and not by American bombs.

title: Bill on Marine Mammals
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) The Senate completed today Congressional action on a bill designed to protect marine mamals. It bans most killing, capturing or importing and all imports on pelts or, pelt prod ucts from baby Canadian Harp seals.

title: I.B.M.'S EARNINGS UP 20% IN QUARTER
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and the Burroughs Corporation, two of the nation's largest data proc essing equipment manufac turers, announced sharply high er earnings yesterday for the quarter and nine month periods ended Sept. 30.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TEANECK, N. J., Oct. 11During his sevenyear stint as a catcher in the major leagues with the Giants, Orioles and Senators, John Orsino lived the affluent life. That included, among other things, firstclass hotel rooms, first class steaks, jet charter air travel, doortodoor luggage accommodations and the admiration of fans, young and old.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest re port on changes of stock own ership by major shareholders, directors and officers of its listed companies.

title: Theater: Right You Are
description: The Roundabout Theater, one of New York's staple repertory companies, is back in business for its 197273 season, with a repertory that will later Include Molnar's The Play's the Thing and Ibsen's Ghosts. It opened last night with Pirandello's Right You Are If You Think You Are, a play not seen lo cally since the APA/Phoenix production some six years ago.

title: BudgetCeiling Dispute
description: News Analysis

title: Being Permissive  While Feeling Authoritarian
description: One of the factors that often creates confusion in the minds of children is an attitude of masked authori tarianism on the part of parents, according to Dr. Beulah Parker, a psychiatrist who is on the clinical faculty of the University of Cali fornia Medical School.

title: Merger News
description: The GAC Corporation an nounced yesterday that the planned sale of its subsidiary, GAC Finance, Inc., to the Bank America Corporation, the hold ing company of the Bank of America, will bel for a substantial premium over the $65  million book value of GAC's holdings in the fi nance operation. A spokesman for GAC said the figure applies only to the finance operations and not related insurance oper ations that will be disposed of separately.

title: DIPLOMAT IS HURT
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Oct. 11The buildings of the French diplomatic mission to North Vietnam were wrecked today during an American bombing raid on the Hanoi area, and Pierre Susini, its chief diplomat, Was seriously injured.

title: The Guys in the Next Bloc
description: ATLANTAThe ancient racial dem agoguery of our forefathers' time is not enough to win Southern political campaigns now. The days of packing the onegallus farmers into the court house squares for downhome segrega tionist harangues are gone as the only method of winning elections.

title: HAMLET RETAKEN OUTSIDE SAIGON
description: TANAN, South Vietnam, Oct. 11South Vietnamese militia men recaptured this battered hamlet near Saigon today after a desultory weeklong battle, but other groups of enemy in filtrators were still said to be holding positions as close as eight miles to the capital.

title: Hopkins Rites Tomorrow
description: A funeral service for Miriam Hopkins, the stage and screen actress, will be held tomorrow at 11 A.M. in the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Mad ison Avenue at 35th Street. Miss Hopkins, who had starred on Broadway and in some 35 Hollywood films, died Monday at the age of 69.

title: Conferees Back Product Safety Unit, Bar Giving It F.D.A.'s Power
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 11  Senate consumer advocates have abandoned efforts to transfer functions of the Food and Drug Administration to a proposed independent commis sion.

title: SENATE AGAIN BARS CLOSURE ON BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The Senate refused again today to end debate kind vote on legisla tion that would prevent long distance busing to accomplish school desegregation.

title: JEWISH GROUPS SIFTING LETTERS
description: Jewish organizations in the city have adopted new securi ty techniques as a result of the recent terrorist tactic of mailing explosives to Israeli diplomats and supporters of Israel.

title: Murtagh Reported Chosen As Anticorruption Judge
description: State Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh has been se lected by Governor Rockefeller to be the presidingjustice for the special grand juries that will hear evidence gathered by the state's new anticorruption prosecutor, according to a high official source.

title: Wig Seller Is the First Merchant Jailed Under City Consumer Act
description: Bess Myerson, the city's Com missioner of Consumer Affairs, announced yesterday that the owner of a mailorder wig con cern has been jailed here for violating the Consumer Protec tion Actthe first merchant to be jailed for violating that act.

title: A HIJACKER IS SHOT AT FRANKFURT FIELD
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Oct. 11 (Agence FrancePresse) A hijacker was shot and cap tured here today by Frankfurt policemen.

title: Vera Micheles Dean, 69, Dies; InternationalAffairs Specialist
description: Vera Micheles Dean, an au thority on international affairs who served for 30 years as research director and editor for the Foreign Policy Associ ation, died in her sleep Tues day night. Mrs. Dean, who made her home at 70 East 96th Street, was 69 years old.

title: CRUSADERS DOWN NORDIQUES BY 20
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 11 (AP) Gerry Cheevers turned in shutout in his first World Hockey Association game to night as the Cleveland Cru saders defeated the Quebec Nordiques, 20, in opening their W.H.A. campaign.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Hughes Aircraft Corpo ration has received a $106.5 million Navy contract for an additional quantity of firecon trol systems for the Phoenix missile used in the F14 car rierbased fighter, it was an nounced yesterday.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Restaurants are rated for food (four stars to none) and for atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: How to Use the Concentrates
description: 1. Reconstitute the juice: If using 5 quarts of concentrate to make 5 gallons of wine, combine with 15 quarts of water in an open plastic, wood or glass container at least 6 gallons in capacity.

title: Registration Drive Results Here Called Very Poor
description: The city's voter registration drive achieved very poor re sults despite all the publicized efforts to place new voters on the rolls here, a Board of Elec tions official said yesterday.

title: KISSINGER HOLDS PARLEYS IN PARIS FOR A FOURTH DAY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 Henry A. Kissinger and the North Vietnamese representa tives in Paris held their fourth consecutive secret negotiating session today. The White House again refused to say whether they were making any progress.

title: Teacher Mugged While Leading Pupils in Park
description: A Brooklyn school teacher leading a class of fifthgraders on a field trip in Prospect Park Tuesday afternoon was beaten and robbed as 10 children and a woman aide watched help lessly.

title: WEEWIS' PRESENTED BY JOFFREY BALLET
description: Margo Sappington's Wee wis is a pseudoserious and stridently superficial ballet on the relations of men with wom en and men with men. If one accepts it as such and ignores its frenzied reach for contem poraneity, there are performing pleasures to be seen in it. The City Center Joffrey Ballet pre sented the work Tuesday eve ning.

title: Balloon for Galaxy Study Comes to Earth in Texas
description: PALESTINE, Tex. Oct. 11 (AP)A balloon launched to find how a galaxy is born came down 10 miles south of Brady today.

title: News Analysis
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 12In his campaign for reelection, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau is painting a bold face on his portrait of Canada's new for eign policy.

title: PIPELINE WILL CARRY FUEL TO LA GUARDIA
description: The major airlines using La Guardia Airport will build an aviation fuel pipeline from Long Island City to the airport, eliminating the present system of transporting the fuel by barge.

title: WINNIPEG DOWNS RAIIRS, 6 TO 4
description: With a game that had a bizarre combination of ingre dients, including wideopen scrambling and an exciting denouement, the World Hockey Association last night came to Madison Square Garden.

title: Flyers Defeat Canucks
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12 (AP) Two goals by Simon Nolet and the stickwork of Bobby Clarke carried the Philadelphia Flyers to a 73 victory tonight over the Vancouver Canucks.Nolet scored his first goal to tie the game at 22 in the first period. Then Clarke set up Bill Flett for a tally and Philadelphia went in front to stay.

title: Members of Panel
description: Following are the members of the New York State Com mission on the Quality, Cost and Financing of Elementary and Secondary Education:

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
CON ED IS GUILTY IN KILLING OF FISH
description: The Consolidated Edison Company was found guilty in State Supreme Court yesterday of violating the state conserva tion law with its nuclear power installation on the Hudson Riv er at Buchanan, N. Y., and was held liable for a fine that could reach $1.3million.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: A Conservative party candi date for the House of Repre sentatives from Brooklyn's 15th Congressional District said yes terday that he had asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the police to investigate some dirty pool that he said has marred his battle for elec tion.

title: Jaycee Suit on Women
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 12 (UPI) The Rochester chapter of the Jaycees filed a Federal suit to day in Washington, seeking to let women join the men's serv ice organization. State and na tional Jaycees suspended the Rochester chapter last spring because it had 23 women mem bers, against the organization's bylaws. The Rochester chapter is the nation's second largest, with 800 members.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Financial Accounting Foundation published yester day a draft of the rules the new Financial Accounting Standards Board is expected to follow when it goes into operation early next year. If the rules of procedure are accepted by the foundation's trustees, the board will first define the accounting issue involved, then hold public hearings and make public its proposed statements. Final statements of the board will require five affirmative votes of the seven members.

title: MRS. KING GAINS WITH CHRIS EVERT
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Oct. 12 (UPI)Mrs. Billie Jean King, the topseeded player and Chris Evert, the No. 4 player, won by identical scores today in the second round of the $100,000 Virginia Slims tennis tourna ment.

title: RUSKIN IS SEEKING RECORDS ON GROSS
description: City Investigation Commis sioner Robert K. Ruskin has subpoenaed the records of a management consultant con cern involved with the Youth Services Agency and has opened an inquiry into allegations that an agency executive as sistant falsified documents to obtain his job.

title: State Finds a Misuse of City U. Funds
description: A state audit has disallowed $255,832 in payments made by the City University from a spe cial $2million discretionary fund that was in existence from 1967 to 1971.

title: U.S. Instructor Killed
description: SAIGON, Friday, Oct. 13 (AP)  An American military instructor was reported killed yesterday and another wounded when a South Vietnamese Army convoy was ambushed by Communist forces about 25 miles southeast of Saigon.

title: Soviet Missile Tests Are Set
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 12 (AP)The Soviet Union announced today that it would conduct an 18day series of missilefiring tests in the Pacific, about 1,860 miles east of Japan, beginning Friday.

title: Personalities: Jackson Loses His Zip
description: John Ralston, the coach of the Broncos, told yesterday in Denver why Rich Jackson, a star defensive end had been traded to the Cleveland Browns for a future draft choice. He just hasn't been playing like the Rich Jackson everyone remembers, said Ralston. He's a legend in this town. But we were not sure he would be starting Sunday's game.

title: Advertising:
description: News that Walter J. Rau scher had quit American Air lines came as a surprise yes terday to marketing men in the airline industry.

title: RICHARD S. KULZE, LAWYER, WAS 66
description: Richard S. Kulze, counsel to the South African Consulate, who as president of the South African Rock Lobster Associa tion for over 30 years helped to popularize African lobster here, died Wednesday in New York Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 630 Park Ave nue.

title: Saigon Announces the Recapture Of District Capital in Quangugai
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, Oct. 13South Vietnam ese troops fighting in the central coastal province of Quangngai reported yesterday that they had recaptured district capital that fell to the Communists a month ago.

title: General Disorders
description: Judging by statistics extracted from the Pentagon by Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr. of Virginia the United States armed forces are being led by the lame and the halt.

title: MEDICAL GROUP HERE FROM CHINA
description: Eleven medical specialists, including two women, arrived here from China yesterday as the first scientific delegation from mainland China since the revolution there.

title: Willard Carlisle Butcher
description: New president and chief operating officer of the bank. ...Most often described as friendly, sharp, aggressive... Born 46 years ago in Bronx ville, N. Y....Magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa at Brown University...Joined the bank's managementtrain itv, program in 1947... Started in credit work at the Grand Central branch... Made branch vice president in 1958...Senior vice presi dent in 1960 in charge of 15 midtown Manhattan branch es...Eight years later to the international department as area executive for Europe and Sub Sahara African... Vice president in charge of international division in 1969 ...Named vice chairman in charge of planning, expan sion and diversification ear lier this year...Appoint ment was part of reorganiza tion aimed at building a top management structure along program lines, rather than along the traditional lines of organization or geography. ...Looks and dresses like a banker but is informal in ap proach and enjoys selling the bank and his ideas...Lives in Wilton, Conn., with his wife, the former Elizabeth Allen. They have three daugh ters and one son....Served as treasurer of the American Heart Association in 1966.

title: ATLANTA IS WARM TO NIXON ON VISIT
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 12This Old Confederate city, now a symbol of the new South, gave Pres ident Nixon visual evidence to day of what the pollsters have been saying for months: Wal lace country is now Nixon coun try.

title: Mrs. McGovern Ill, In Capital Hospital
description: WASHINGTON, Friday, Oct, 13Mrs. George McGovern was admitted to the Georgetown University Hospital here last night with severe abdominal pains after complaining of fa tigue earlier in the evening.

title: CUNNINGHAM GETS 28 IN COUGARS' VICTORY
description: RICHMOND, Oct. 12 (UPI) The Carolina Cougars, led by Billy Cunningham, held off a late drive by the Virginia Squires tonight and posted a 123115 triumph in a ragged season opener for both Ameri can Basketball Association clubs.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The average cost of pre paring a chicken dinner for a family of four fell to $4.32 in August in the New York northeastern New Jersey areaa 13cent drop from the July figure, according to Herbert Bienstock, regional director of the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor.

title: TIFFANY WILL START OPERATION IN JAPAN
description: Tiffany & Co. will open its first jewelry department in Japan Oct. 27 in the Mitsukoshi department store in Tokyo, Walter Roving, Tiffany chair man, told a press and analyst group here yesterday.

title: Arms and Security
description: On Election Day, the American public will have the opportunity to choose between two sharply divergent formulas for defending the security of the nation.

title: A Land of Saffron Robes
description: It was over two months ago that, very afraid, I prostrated myself before the Abbott of Wat Bovornives in Bang kok, and asked permission to study Buddhism and Buddhist meditation with him.

title: Man Found in Car Trunk Tells of Abduction
description: A Manhattan businessman disappeared on his way to work yesterday morning and after a bizarre eight hours that saw an abortive rendezvous for ran som, a news blackout by the police and, finally, an anony mous tipwas found unhurt in the locked trunk of a car parked near a Queens ceme tery.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Judge Stanley H. Fuld initiates some very disturbing notions into any hopes for revamping the present judicial structure. [News story Sept. 28.]

title: House Contest
description: YONKERS, Oct. 12  Two years after he relinquished his seat in the House of Repres entatives to make an unsuc cessful face for the Senate, Richard L. Ottinger is still believed to be a Congressman by 40 per cent of voters polled in his area.

title: Thieu Bars Coalition and Would Kill Foe to Last Man
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 12President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that history had shown that coalition with the Communists meant death.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 11  One of the most critical and com petitive phases of the political battle between President Nixon and Senator George McGovern cannot be seen on television, measured by the polls, or gauged at party rallies and dinners.

title: African Films at College
description: Four onehour documentaries on Africa made by Eliot Eliso fort will be screened today at the Finley Student Center ofi City College, Convent Avenue and 133d Street. Mr. Elisofon will discuss the films, The Congo, The Bend of the Niger, The Slave Coast and Africa's Gift, following they screenings.

title: Paine, Webber Earnings Slump as Revenues Gain
description: Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, a leading investment house, disclosed yesterday that its earnings in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 had declined sharply, despite an increase in gross revenues.

title: GASRELEASE BLAST PLANNED BY E. G. & G.
description: A Bostonarea research and development company said yes terday it had developed a new, cleaner means of using nuclear devices to release natural gas from rock.

title: Kaiser Aluminum Reports Big Drop In Its Net Income
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation reported last night a sharp drop in prof its for the third quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30 despite higher sales. The com pany attributed the earnings decline to inadequate prices and increases in labor and other costs.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 12Sen ator George McGovern used the taperecorded voice of a young man, identifying himself as Vietnam veteran and choking with remorse, to tell an over flow crowd in the quadrangle of the University of Minnesota here today about American bombing in Indochina.

title: State Trooper Shot Dead After Robbery in Michigan
description: NILES, Mich., Oct. 12 (UPI) A Michigan state policeman was shot and killed today min utes after a $38,000 holdup of the First National Bank of Southwestern Michigan.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CASA NUEVA The Span ish Theater Repertory Com pany, formerly the Green with Mews Spanish Theater, has a reasonable explanation for its name change. The company has moved from the Mews, where it started in 1969, to the Gramercy Arts Theater, 138 East 27th Street (8892850), where it has a longterm lease and starts its new season tonight at 7:45.

title: GUARD IS ACCUSED OF CHEATING BLIND
description: A helpful and obliging guard at a savings bankwho had a reputation for going out of his way to assist blind cus tomers with their deposit and withdrawal slipswas charged yesterday with grand larceny and forgery.

title: Notes on People
description: Wearing his silvergray hair a bit shorter than the last time he was seen in public, former President Lyn don B. Johnson appeared at the Lady Bird Johnson Awards ceremony in Stone wall, Tex., did a little shout ing and talked about his health. When the sound fal tered during the colorslide part of the highway beautifi cation award ceremony, Mr. Johnson yelled, Louder. Louder. Then he said he was feeling fine and told a story about an old woman who said, When I walks, I walks slowly. When I sits, I sits loosely. And when I feel a worry coming on, I just go to sleep. That's what I'm do ing now, said Mr. Johnson, who suffered a heart attack in April, following that old woman's advice.

title: Music Hall Reopens Tomorrow As Contract Sessions Resume
description: The Radio City Music Hall will reopen tomorrow as result of an agreement by the management and orchestra members to resume negotia tions in their contract dispute next week.

title: Chase Replaces President After Competitive Decline
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, which has been losing its com petitive position to its rivals and has suffered a decline in its earnings, replaced its presi dent yesterday.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Although heated debate is expected in the Danish Par liament on whether to ratify the agreement, reached by United States and Danish representatives earlier this rear, to phase out the Danes' highseas netting of Atlantic salmon by 1976, Joseph F. Cullman 3d, president of the Internatidnal Atlantic Sal mon Foundation (I. A. S. F.), says that I.A.S.F. sources in Copenhagen, quoting the (Danish Minister of Fisheries . . . are optimistic that . . . the bill will pass and the treaty will be signed.

title: People and Business
description: Commissioner Hugh F. Owens of the Securities and Exchange Commission called for greater Federal regula tion of investment advisers yesterday, thereby emphasiz ing to the financial commun ity, his philosophical differ ence of opinion on this subject with his chairman, William J. Casey. For it was only on Wednesday that Mr. Casey spoke out in favor of selfdiscipline rather than Government policing for money managers.

title: U.N. Debate Seen as Defining Where Things Stand
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 12The general debate, long and for most people tedious business, came to close last night.

title: Cardinal Krol Invites Wyszynski to U.S.
description: WARSAW, Oct. 12  John Cardinal Krol of Philadelphia said today that he had invited the Polish primate, Stefan Car dinal Wyszynski, to visit the United States and that he hoped that the improved at mosphere between church and state in Poland would enable Cardinal Wyszynski to accept.

title: A's Win Pennant With a 21 Victory Over Tigers
description: The Oakland As won the American League pennant yes terday before 50,276 by defeat ing the Tigers, 21, in Detroit. It was the deciding game of the fivegame playoff series.

title: Men in the News
description: When Gerald Maurice Edel man, B.S. in chemistry, M.D. in internal medicine, was ac cepted as a graduate student at Rockefeller University 15 years ago, he arrived on cam pus three months before the rest of his class.

title: BILL TO BAR BUSING KILLED IN SENATE AS CLOSIIRE FAILS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 Legislation designed to prevent the crosstown busing of stu dents to desegregate public schools died in the Senate today.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Oct. 12Upsala is changing a number thingsfrom the name of its field to its pregame approach for the Vikings' homecoming football game with Wilkes Saturday.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP)The Price Commission will be forced to act if it finds that the nation's businesses are spending wastefully, such as padding expense accounts or buying executive airplanes just to avoid profitmargin restraints, its chairman, C. Jackson Grayson Jr. said today. He added that he saw no evidence of any such spending occurring on a widespread basis, adding that he was relying on the intelligence of businessmen and their responsibility to stockholders and to the nation to prevent it from happening.

title: Merger News
description: The United Brands Company announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to pur chase for an undisclosed amount of cash 600,000 com mon shares of the Foster Grant Company from the trust of the late Joseph C. Foster and 50,000 shares from the Dela mere Company, Inc. Based on the current price of Foster Grant, which is traded in the overthecoun ter market, the transactions are valued at more than $20mil lion. The purchase would give United Brands and Delamere each, about a 30 per cent owner ship of Foster Grant, which has 2.15 million shares outstanding. Foster Grant, a leading manu facturer of chemicals, plastics and sunglasses, had sales of more than $100million in the year ended Sept. 30, 1972.

title: In Japan, Today Is a Moderately Lucky Day (but Look Out for Butsumetsu)
description: TOKYO, Oct. 12  Friday the 13th may cause Ameri cans to watch out for black cats and stay out from under ladders, but it hold no fears for the Japanese, whose su perstitions are quite differ ent.

title: C.B.S. in Joint Venture
description: April House, Inc., a giftbook and decorativeproducts con cern, has been formed as a joint venture of Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., and two individuals, Dr. Herbert H. Jacobs and Webster Schott. Dr. Jacobs and Mr. Schott were previously associated with Hall mark Cards, Inc. The new con cern will have its offices in Lenexa, Kans.

title: ISLANDERS SCORE FIRST VICTORY, 32
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 12 Bring on Boston, the fans yelled tonight in Nassau Collseum.

title: TREVINO DEFEATS SANDERS, 2 AND 1
description: WENTWORTH, England, Oct. 12 (AP)Lee Trevino's sore throat got worse but his golf got better today as he beat a fellow American pro, Doug Sanders, 2 and 1, and advanced to the semifinals of the Picca dilly world matchplay tourna merit.

title: State Overhaul Proposed For Secondary Education
description: A fundamental reorganiza tion of the state's secondary schools to, end a system that leaves tens of thousands of graduates with neither the prospect of continued study nor a marketable skill was proposed yesterday by the Fleischmann Commission.

title: Police Prevent a 17Story Plunge
description: Patrolman Michael Mc Crory overpowered and sub dued a man threatening to jump from the roof of a gar ment center office building yesterday while thousands of lunchhour spectators gath ered below and traffic was backed up along Broadway for blocks.

title: Delaware Fund Gain Seen
description: The Delaware group of mu tual funds reported yesterday that if sales continued at the present pace, they would set a new thigh of $134million this year. James P. Schellenger, president, said ninemonth sales totaled $106million, while re demptions amounted to $51 million, leaving net sales at $55million.

title: Congress Presses Ahead, Seeking to End Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 Congress sped through a heavy backlog of major and minor legislation today, pushing for adjournment by midnight Sat urday.

title: Macmillan Set to Drop Crowell Collier Name
description: Crowell Collier & Macmil lan, Inc., the multinational educational company, is plan ning to change its corporate name to Macmillan, Inc., ac cording to preliminary proxy material to be filed today with the Securities and Ex change Commission.

title: Bob Hope Gets Award
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) Bob Hope received the As sociation of the Army's highest award last night. He was awarded the George C. Mar shall Medal for his selfless and outstanding service to the Unit ed States.

title: Film Fete
description: Picture Atlantic City in winter. The leaden sky, the sea, the deserted boardwalk, the Convention Hall, a few old souls shuffling through the shabby decay of the grand hotelspicture these easy images of indefinable sadness, and you almost won't need a movie. You cer tainly won't need a movie like The King of Marvin Gardens, which played last night in the New York Film Festival and opens tomorrow at the Columbia I theater.

title: The Science of Self
description: Round the clock every day a ceaseless surveillance system protects every normal human being, a mechanism that is on the alert to detect and destroy foreign invaders. These invaders may be diseaseproducing viruses or bac teria, tissues transplanted from another person, or normal cells newly turned malignant.

title: 16 Pianists to Give a MiniMiniMonster Concert
description: Eugene List will try again tomorrow night to unlock the mystery of the 19thcentury mind, this time using 704 keys.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your recent editorial criticizing the Lindsay administration (and Man hattan Borough President Percy Sut ton) for rejecting the concept of a major addition to the Tombs detentien facility, you said correctly that we had the responsibility to provide a viable alternative. We are doing just that.

title: Kissinger Returns From Paris Talks On Vietnam Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 Henry A. Kissinger returned to Washington tonight and re ported to President Nixon on his four days of private talks with North Vietnam's negotia tors in Paris.

title: CURB ON SPENDING GAINS IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12The Senate Finance Committee, un able to agree on a spending ceiling bill of its own, decided today to bring to the Senate floor, without a recommenda tion one way or the other, the version requested by President Nixon.

title: Prime Minister Is Writer
description: TOKYO (AP)Japan's new prime minister, Kakuei Tanaka, has become a bestselling au thor with his book, The Re vamping of the Japanese Is lands. It outlines his plans for the relocation of highly central ized industrial complexes and population centers.

title: Noise Inspectors Now Issue Warnings, But Fines Are Only a New Meter Away
description: The city's new noise pollu tion inspectors are out in the street this week, casting a wary eye and cocking a sus picious ear toward jackham mer operators, hornhonkers, Good Humor men with bad humored bells, screeching parrots, barking dogs or any device or sound source or sources causing unnecessary noise.

title: Judith Mann, Lawyer, Is Bride
description: Miss Judith Margaret Mann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Gerald Mann of Nunda, N. Y., was married here yesterday afternoon to Vincent Serrano Villard Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Villard of New York and Tomkins Cove, N.Y., and a descendant of William Lloyd Garrison, the abolitionist.

title: Dr. Paul Friedman, 73, Is Dead; Psychiatrist and Suicide Expert
description: Dr. Paul Friedman, psychia trist, expert on suicidal ten dencies and analyst for many rabbis, actors, writers, play wrights and novelists, died of a heart attack yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 1165 Park Avenue.

title: Buffalo Hunt Protest Fails
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 12 (AP) A move by the Human Soci ety to stop Arizona's annual buffalo hunt, conducted annu ally on fencedin rangelands, apparently has failed. Attorney General Gary Nelson said yes terday that he saw nothing in humane about the hunt, adding that it has been done for years as a game management meas ure. The hunt is scheduled for Friday.

title: 9 Auto and AirConditioner Ads Challenged in New F. T T. C. Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12  The Federal Trade Commission challenged nine automobile and airconditioner advertisements today, charging that they were misleading and unfair.

title: Dartmouth Backs McGovern
description: HANOVER, N. H., Oct. 12 (AP)Senator George McGov ern, the Democratic Presiden tial nominee, led President Nix on, 45 to 38 per cent, in a poll of 1,700 Dartmouth College stu dents conducted by Dartmouth Students for Nixon.

title: Troubled Vatican
description: The last thing in Martin Luther's mind when he hammered his theses to the door of the castle church in Wit tenberg was a religion separate and distinct from Catholicism. And the last thing in Pope John XXIII's mind, when he opened Vatican Council II ten years ago in Rome, was a Catholicism sub stantively different from the one he had known for seventy years.

title: KISSINGER IS BACK FROM PARIS TALKS ON VIETNAM PEACE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 Henry A. Kissinger returned to Washington tonight and re ported to President Nixon on his four days of private talks with North Vietnam's negotia tors in Paris.

title: Greek Foreign Post Is Filled
description: ATHENS, Oct. 12Phaedon Anninos. Kavalieratos, a 60 yearold career diplomat, was sworn in today as Deputy For eign Minister, a post that gives him virtual control of Greek foreign affairs.

title: Israelis. Perform The Mahler First
description: The Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, currently on tour in the United States, played in Carnegie Hall Wednesday night before a full audience and a full security guard. These days nobody takes chances with Israeli nation als, and every entrance to the hall was carefully watched.

title: CARL P. DOELGER JR.
description: CHATHAM PORT, Mass., Oct. 12  Carl Peter Doelger Jr., who retired as director of the Peter Doelger Realty Com pany in New York in 1965, died Sunday at the age of 80.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Oct. 12 (UPI) Britain had another huge deficit in her visible trade with the rest of the world last month with the after effects of the dock strike again playing havoc with the figures, the Govern ment said today. The De partment of Trade and In dustry said the picture was seriously distorted and bears no relation to the underlying position.

title: Apples in an Autumn Dessert
description: In the menu below the dishes marked with an as terisk are followed by a recipe.

title: String Fete
description: A few years back, if one recalls correctly, some con cern was being voiced that the exotic Western art of stringquartet playing might be going into a decline. The reasons were hardly inscruta ble: string playing had come upon bad times, and there fore a paucity of young groups capable someday of succeeding the Budapest, the Juilliard and the Amadeus seemed inevitable.

title: Cordero Victor on 3 Favorites
description: Angel Cordero Jr., the musicminded riding star from Puerto Rico, endeared himself to chalk players at Belmont Park yesterday. He ended the drought of favor ites, after 19 straight choices, over a threeday span, had failed to reach the winners' circle.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.2 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 124.2 from 124 last week.

title: State Bounty Is Urged On Narcotics Sellers
description: The Ocean HillBrownsville School Board has proposed that the state offer a taxfree bounty of between $250 and $2,500 to anyone who pro vides information that leads to the arrest and conviction of a seller of narcotics.

title: Hospital Agency Planning to Sae City For $70Million Aid
description: The board of directors of the Health and Hospitals Corpora tion, the semiautonomous agen cy that runs New York's 19 municipal hospitals, voted yes terday to sue the city for $70 million.

title: Corporate Demands for Credit Pick Up, Reserve Reports
Searching for Graft
description: Governor Rockefeller went only halfway toward meet ing the challenge of official corruption last month when he named Maurice Ii. Nadjari as special prosecutor to war on widespread graft of the type uncovered by the Knapp Commission. Fulfillment of the Nadjari assignment required that a single judge of outstanding qualifications be designated to impanel special grand juries and preside over cases initiated by the super D. A.

title: GRANT HELP TRAIN BLACK PHYSICIANS
description: The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation has given a $5mil lion grant to Meharry Medical College, the Nashville school that has trained more than half the black doctors and dentists practicing in this country.

title: U.S. Opposes Soviet Draft Of a Satellite TV Treaty
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 12The United States ob jected today that a proposed Soviet treaty to regulate tele vision broadcasts from satel lites ran counter to America's strong 200yearold belief in free information.

title: CHILE EMERGENCY CALLED IN STRIKE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 12 (AP)  The Chilean Govern ment, confronted with a crip pling nationwide trucking strike, declared a state of emergency today in Santiago and in a large part of populous central Chile.

title: Republicans for McGovern
description: About 25 dissident Republi cans gathered in the rain yes terday to show their support for the Democratic Presidential candidate. Gilbert Colgate, a member of the City Human Rights Commission and co chairman of Republicans for McGovern, said the Nixon Ad ministration was insensitive to the needs of the under privileged. The group says it has 1,300 members in New York.

title: Equity Financing
