description: An offering of 2.5 million common shares of the Potomac Electric Power Company at $15 per share was made yesterday by an underwriting group managed by Merrill Lynch, Dillon, Read and Gold man Sachs. Net proceeds will be used to retire shortterm borrowings. The utility's stock closed at 15, up  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Notes on People
description: Wearing his silvergray hair a bit shorter than the last time he was seen in public, former President Lyn don B. Johnson appeared at the Lady Bird Johnson Awards ceremony in Stone wall, Tex., did a little shout ing and talked about his health. When the sound fal tered during the colorslide part of the highway beautifi cation award ceremony, Mr. Johnson yelled, Louder. Louder. Then he said he was feeling fine and told a story about an old woman who said, When I walks, I walks slowly. When I sits, I sits loosely. And when I feel a worry coming on, I just go to sleep. That's what I'm do ing now, said Mr. Johnson, who suffered a heart attack in April, following that old woman's advice.

title: A's Win Pennant With 21 Victory Over Tigers
description: The Oakland A's won the American League pennant yes terday before 50,276 by defeat ing the Tigers, 21, in Detroit. It was the deciding game of the fivegame playoff series.

title: Anheuser Plans Coast Unit
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 12 (UPI) AnheuserBusch, Inc., today exercised its option to buy more than 300 acres in Solano County, Calif., as a site for a new $40million brewery to serve the San Francisco area. The brewery will have a ca pacity of 2 million barrels a year and will employ 300 per sons.

title: Order to Shift Juveniles Broke Capital Jail Revolt
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 12  The anticrime bill passed two years ago for the District of Columbia paradoxically pro vided the turning point in the jail rebellion here that ended early today with the release of 12 hostages.

title: HANOI AREA RAIDS REPORTED CURBED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 12 (AP)  United States planes attacked North Vietnam again today, but new restric tions were reportedly imposed on raids in the vicinity of Hanoi after the heavy damage there to the French diplomatic mis sion yesterday.

title: Agnew Endorses Candidate For Senate in New Mexico
description: ROSWELL, N. M., Oct. 12 (AP)  Vice President Agnew campaigned today in support of Pete Domenici, the Republi can candidate for United States Senator, but did not give him all the aid that Mr. Domenici had hoped for.

title: BILL TO BAR BUSING KILLED IN SENATE AS CLOSURE FAILS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 Legislation designed to prevent the crosstown busing of stu dents to desegregate public schools died in the Senate today.

title: CURB ON SPENDING GAINS IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12The Senate Finance Committee, un able to agree on a spending ceiling bill of its own, decided today to bring to the Senate floor, without a recommenda tion one way or the other, the version requested by President Nixon.

title: 2 Die in School Bus Crashes
description: NACOGDOCHES, Tex., Oct. 12 (UPI)  Two accidents in volving homeward bound school buses on opposite sides of Na cogdoches and within an hour of each other yesterday killed two students and injured 20 others, including 19 students. Those killed Were Jerry Vick, 10 years old, and Patsy Gris ??.

title: 3 Groups Say Times Violated Bias Code In South Africa Ads
description: Three organizations filed complaint yesterday with the city's Commission on Human Rights charging The New York Times with violating the city's Administrative Code by pub lishing advertisements for dis criminatory employment in South Africa.

title: State Scored on Care Of Disabled Children
description: At least 200,000 mentally, physically or emotionally handi capped children in New York State are waiting out their childhood years at home un treated, or are lingering un detected in classrooms, listen ing to lessons beyond their com prehension, according to yester day's Fleischmann Commission report.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 12 (UPI)A Passaic mother whose) 26monthold daughter was put up for adoption while she was serving a jail term last year told a judge in Paterson today that she wanted her child back.

title: Credit Markets
description: The money and capital mar kets remained yesterday in the grip of malaise apparently cre ated by the lack of tangible support to rumors about im proved prospects for peace in Vietnam.

title: Gunn Suggests a Policy Shift To Give Public TV Autonomy
description: Hartford Gunn, president of the Public Broadcasting Serv ice, suggested yesterday a radi cal change in funding policies that would give the nation's 227 public TV stations almost total control of their program ing.

title: $1,440 Buys the Scent; Bottle Is $3,060 Extra
description: A bottle of perfume for $4,500? That's what a 32 ounce crystal flacon cost that arrived the other day at Ken nedy Airport.

title: About Pro Football
description: Televiewers can watch the Jets and Giants on Sunday. The JetsPatriots game will be televised here on Channel 2 at 1 P.M., followed by the Giants at San Francisco at 4 P.M. Channel 4 will tele cast Cincinnati at Kansas City after the World Series game or at 4 P.M. On Mon day night, Chan nel 7 at 9 o'clock, it will be Green Bay at Detroit. Here is a preview of all games with wonlosttied rec ords in parentheses.

title: Stars Turn Back Rockets In A.B.A. Opener, 115104
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 12 (AP)Jimmy Jones scored 26 points in pacing the Utah Stars to a 115104 victory over the Denver Rockets tonight in the season opener for the American Basketball Association teams.

title: Panel Justice Begins in a Bronx Court
description: I'd, give him seven years, said State Supreme Court Jus tice William Kapelman, his tone tough and angry. It's a crime of violence. I think the community is entitled to pro tection.

title: U.S. Declines Comment
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12De fense Department officials de clined comment today on re ports that the Joint Chiefs of Staff had authorized new bombing targets two weeks ago and that new restrictions had now been placed on strikes in the Hanoi area.

title: Aide to Nixon's Campaign Tied to Secret U. S. Data
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Former Assistant Attorney General Robert C. Mardian obtained confidential information from the Justice Department for potential use in President Nixon's political campaign after leaving the Government to work for the Committee for the Reelection of the President, according to sources close to the Water gate investigation.

title: Panel Justice Begins in Bronx: 3 Judges Confer on Sentences
description: I'd give him seven years said State Supreme Court Jus tice William Kapelman, his tone tough and angry. It's crime of violence. I think the community is entitled to pro tection.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ATHENSModern Greece is accus tomed to having a democratic society without a democratic state, but when ever any government has been in of fice too long, not permitting this ebul lient people to play its favorite game of party politics, It is heading for trouble. Such is the situation today for the regime of George Papadopoulos, chief of the conspiracy of colonels which seized power here in April, 1967.

title: Whalers Defeat Blazers, 43, As 11,692 See W.H.A. Opener
description: BOSTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) Larry Pleau banged in a short shot with 2 minutes 11 seconds left to play tonight to give the New England Whalers a 43 victory over the Philadelphia Blazers in a World Hockey As sociation season opener that was played at the Boston Gar den before, a crowd of 11,692.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct, 12A de tective was shot and serious ly wounded today by a man believed to be an escaped murderer.

title: Congress's Responsibility
description: Senate Majority Leader Mansfield's warning that you might as well abolish Congress if it gave the President power to enforce a spending ceiling was obvious hyper bolebut it touched an important issue. In all demo cratic states, the power to determine how much the Government spends and what it spends it for has been an ultimate weapon, jealously guarded and defended by legislators. The 221to163 vote of the House of Representatives to surrender a major part of that power to President Nixon represents a serious flight from responsibility. It is bound to injure and diminish the prestige of Congress even if, as we hope, the Senate refuses to go along.

title: 1,049 Holding Passes for Rides On Jersey Turnpike and Rails
description: TRENTON, Oct. 12A large number of present and former officials ride the New Jersey railroads and the New Jersey Turnpike free of charge and use the facilities of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey without charge.

title: Men in the News
description: LONDON, Oct. 12At 2:45 this afternoon, Dr. Rodney Robert Porter walked from lunch at Oxford's Trinity Col lege into his office in the biochemistry department. A receptionist shouted excit edly, You've won the Nobel Prize!

title: Theater: Hurry, Harry
description: Muggings, massage parlors and disasters such as Hurry, Harry have all conspired to give Broadway a bad name. Hurry, Harry, by the way, Is a musical that last night had the courage and effron tery to open at the Ritz The ater.

title: American, Briton Share Nobel Prize For Medicine in '72
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 12  An American and a Briton were awarded the 1972 Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine to day for their separate research on the chemical structure of antibodies.

title: ATLANTA
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 12President Nixon is Speaking these days with a new quiet confidenceeven with a kind of philosophical elder statesman's calmbut there is a catch.

title: Market Place: Analysts' Efforts Termed Sketchy
description: Aunt Jane, the ubiquitious small investor who everyone is so worried about, has been reading her brokerage house's research reports very care fully of late, and she is not impressed.

title: Inside Jersey Jail, Reporter Experiences Some Initial Kindness and Respect
description: Peter J. Bridge, a reporter for the nowdefunct Evening News in Newark, was sent to the Essex County Jail last Wednesday for having refused to answer some questions be fore a grand jury that is in vestigating allegations of cor ruption against the Newark Housing Authority.

title: Sicily Gets Hollywood Version of the Godfather
description: PALERMO, Sicily, Oct. 12 (UPI)The godfathers of Sicily met the godfather of Holly wood and went home slightly envious.

title: A's Score 2 Runs on 1 Hit to Beat Tigers, 21, and Capture Pennant
description: DETROIT, Oct. 12  The American League championship trophy, removed from the Oak land clubhouse after being placed there prematurely 24 hours earlier, was returned to the A's today after they won the pennant by edging the De troit Tigers, 21.

title: AllPower Yacht Show Annapolis Experiment
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 12  In a deliberate power grab, the United States yacht show opened today and became the first outdoor, inthe water purely motor boat exhibit in the country, if not the world.

title: FUTURES IN COCOA DROP DAILY LIMIT
description: Cocoa futures dropped the daily limit of one cent a pound yesterday in a wave of dis appointed selling.

title: David Rockefeller
description: Board chairman and chief executive officer... Known by employes at the bank as D R Shy, scholarly, one of the richest and most pow erful men in business... Born here 57 years ago... The youngest son of John D. Rockefeller Jr.... Graduate of Harvard... Ph.D. in eco nomics from the University of Chicago... Unpaid sec retary to Mayor La Guardia in early forties... Enlisted in the Army as a private in 1942... Discharged as cap tain in 1945 after service in North Africa and France... Awarded Legion of Merit... Commendation Ribbon... French Legion of Honor... Chairman of Rockefeller Uni versity Aided in redevel opment of Lower Manhattan ... and formation of Nation al Urban Coalition, Inter national Executive Service Corps and Council of the Americas... Director of Business Committee for the Arts... Largest individual shareholder in what is world's third largest bank, which he joined in 1946... Holds more than 300.000 shares worth more than $21million... Philanthropist, developer, in vestor... Lives with wife, Margaret, here and on a Westchester County family compound at Pocantico Hills, has two sons, four daughters.

title: HICKS AND HOT LICKS SHOW AMPLE SKILLS
description: Imagine a group that man ages to touch virtually every musical base between rock and the Andrews Sisters and you will have a minimal idea of, what Dan Hicks and His Hot Licks are all about. Performing at Carnegie Hall Tuesday night, they not only gave a little push to the nostalgia wave of the 1940's that's been washing over us lately, but they also man aged to do it with splendid rumor and solid musical profes sionalism.

title: State Overhaul Proposed For Secondary Education
description: A fundamental reorganiza tion of the state's secondary schools to end a system that leaves tens of thousands of graduates with neither the prospect of continued study nor a marketable skill was proposed yesterday by the Fleischmann Commission.

title: PATMAN BALKED ON WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 Any prospect of a Congres sional investigation before Elec tion Day into the breakin at the Democratic National Com mittee and the alleged financial irregularities connected with it apparently evaporated today. Wright Patman, chairman of the House Banking and Cur rency Committee, failed twice to collect enough committee Democrats to make a quorum.

title: PRODUCTION OF CORN DOWN 5% FOR 1972
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) The nation's corn crop, part of it going to the Soviet Union in a $1billion grain sale, will be 5,265,817,000 bushels, down 5 per cent from the record harvest in 1971 but 3 per cent more than forecast in Septem ber, the Agriculture Depart ment said today.

title: TWO KOREAS OPEN POLITICAL PARLEY
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, Oct. 12North and South Korea started a political conference here today in a move to im prove their relations and seek eventual reunification of their divided nation.

title: SENATE, BY 84 TO 2, CONFIRMS ABRAMS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12The Senate voted 84 to 2 today to confirm the nomination of Gen. Creighton W. Abrams as Army Chief of Staff.

title: U.S. AGENT AMMO SLAIN IN DRUG RAID IN MIDTOWN MOTEL
description: A Federal agent and two sus pected narcotics sellers were killed, and a second agent was seriously wounded when an alleged narcotics transaction erupted into a gun battle last night at the Sheraton Midtown Motor Inn.

title: Fighting Emphysema
description: One of the United Hospi tal Fund's member hospitals has an unusual reconditioning laboratory as part of its rehabilita tion program. It approaches the problems caused by em physema with a deep study of each patient, and the laboratory's special ists can then prescribe a rou tine that allows the patient to function better in daily living. The laboratory is just one of the many ways in which all the United Hospital Fund's 54 member voluntary nonprofit hospitals are allevi ating the urban problems of the nineteenseventies. Con tributions may be made to the fund at 3 East 54th Street, New York, N. Y. 10022.

title: Benhet Reported Overrun
description: SAIGON, Friday, Oct. 13 (UPI)  Communist troops overran the former United States Spe cial Forces camp at Benhet in the Central Highlands yesterday after virtually leveling it with more than 1,500 rockets and Motor and artillery shells, mili tary sources said today. tary sources said today.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 12  The United States Attorney's office today charged the owners of the Brookchester Gardenapart ment complex in New Milford, one of the state's largest such developments, with collecting $38,080 in illegal rent increases since last December.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Peter J. Bridge, a reporter for the nowdefunct Evening News in Newark, was sent to the Essex County Jail last Wednesday for having re fused to answer some ques tions before a grand jury that is investigating allega tions of corruption against the Newark Housing Author ity.

title: Service for Goodman
description: A memorial service for Paul Goodman, the writer, who died in August, will be held at the Community Church of New York, 40 East 35th Street, Sun day, Oct. 22. Eugene Istomin, the pianist, will play the Wald stein sonata of Beethoven, and Betti McDonald, soprano, and Ned Rorem, composer, will per form Mr. Rorem's Songs 1947 1955 on Poems of Paul Good man. Mr. Goodman's brother. Percival, will preside.

title: Herbert Parsons Patterson
description: At 47 years of age replaced as president of bank he joined 23 years ago. . . . His only employer, all connections will be severed. . . . The very model of a major banker. . . . Considered the new mold of banker.... Slender .. . sharp featured, blond hair. Served in Navy. . . . Grandson of Rufus Patterson, founder of the A.M.F. Corporation (orig inally American Machine and Foundry) and serves on A.M.F. board of directors.... Greatgrandson of the famous 19th century banker Henry Crews. . . . Fashionable New York East Side upbringing Groton . . Yale. . . pro fessional manager, ambitious, highly competitive. . . . Aware of and seeking new vistas for bank. . . . Of the oldschooltie but not inter ested in countryclub banking of elders. . . . Spent most of business life dealing with so phisticated problems of cor porate finance principally on the international side. . . . Upon taking position of pres ident in 1969 admitted lack of expertise in automation and metropolitan retail bank ing . . Intense and hard working. . . Noncommuni cative to those outside of Chase, although he often spoke for bank before Gov ernment and other bodies.... First wife died.... Now mar ried to the former Patricia Shepard Norris. . . Has a stepson David and daughter Natheryn. . . Lives in Man hattan. . . . Trustee of Com munity Service Society, New York Community Trust, Com mitte for Economic Develop ment. Brookings Institution. ...Director of United Fund.

title: Joan Baez Blends Song and Comment In 2 Short Concerts
description: Inflation, which reaches all of us with the inevitability of death and taxes, has come to Joan Baez. For several years Miss Baez has been insisting, successfully, that the top ticket price for her concerts be no more than $2. But Tuesday evening she gave two short concerts at the Felt Forum and the tickets were $2.50. Both concerts were benefits for Medi cal Aid for IndoChina.

title: Nolan to Start Reds' 3Man World Series Rotation
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 12The morning after the night be fore, the city of Cincinnati picked up the pieces of a surging celebration while the Reds rested for the World Series and named Gary Nolan as their opening pitcher.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey, said that the Federal revenuesharing funds that New York City got should be used for the first priority of hiring more foot patrol men. People walk in fear of their lives, the Brooklyn Democrat said. The morale of the civilian is bad because he misses the foot patrol man.

title: BUSINESSMAN URGES CAREER EDUCATION
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 12 (UPI)Americans are spending nearly $30billion a year to edu cate students for potential fail ure, Augustine R. Marusi, presi dent of Borden, Inc., told a Capital University forum here this week.

title: ExPratt Chief to Head Committee for Children
description: The appointment of Henry Saltzman, former president of Pratt Institute, as execu tive director of the Citizens' Committee for Children of New York was announced yesterday by the committee's board of directors.

title: CLARK GROUP FILES REPORT ON BOMBING
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 12 (AP)Ramsey Clark, former United States Attorney Gen eral, said today that President Nixon was making American bombers play God for the people of North Vietnam, but he said the North Vietnamese would not be bombed into sub mission.

title: Irate Students Mob Queen on Scottish Campus
description: STIRLING, Scotland, Oct. 12 (AP)  Hundreds of students shouting obscenities and chant ing monarchy out mobbed Queen Elizabeth II when she visited Stirling University to day.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 12Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and Imamu Amiri Baraka, the black play wright and political leader, took part today in the ground breaking for a 16 story lowand moderateincome housing proj ect named Kawaida Towers in the city's North Ward.

title: TV: A.B.C. Presents Its New Fare for Children
description: Children's television is a problem, not only for chil dren and parents but also, as they will readily concede off the record, for the com mercial networks. Everyone, including the guy down the street who never watches TV, has an opinion on the sub ject.

title: Sprint Missile Fails
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (Reu ters)A defensive missile failed over the Pacific yesterday and an investigation is under way to find the cause, the Defense Department said today.

description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SEMTLE, Oct. 12  The dainty 92pound woman walks toward the front of the stage and steps onto a soft drink box so that her curly head will appear above the rostrum.

title: DepartmentStore Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12  The Department of Commerce re ported today that department store sales last week were estimated at $861million, up 9 per cent from $789million a year earlier. Total retail sales were estimated at $8,826,000, 000, up 10 per cent from the yearearlier $8,046,000,000.

title: Says a Close Watch Will Be Maintained on Bank Profits
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 12In a jawboning warning to banks and other lending insti tutions, Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Re serve Board, asserted, today that he saw no reason for any strong upward pressure on longterm interest rates in the near future.

title: Abrams Confirmed
description: The Senate voted 84 to 2 yesterday to confirm the nomination of Gen. Creighton W. Abrams as the Army Chief of Staff. Details on Page 9.

title: Giants, Upto Their Helmets in Congratulatory Mail, Hope for Happy P.S. in San Francisco
description: When the New York Giants win big, as they did here last Sunday, stacks of congratula tory fanmail cover the table in the team's Yankee Stadium locker room.

title: CLINGAN REPORTED A DEMOCRAT NOW
description: Eldon R. Clingan, the Liberal party's Councilman at Large for Manhattan and the minority leader of the City Council, has switched to the Democratic party, City Hall sources re ported yesterday. As the switch became known, Edward A. Mor rison, a deputy Mayor and the New York County chairman of the Liberal party, called on Mr. Clingan to give up his Council seat.

title: Sales Climb to a Peak
description: The RCA Corporation achieved new highs in sales for the third quarter and first nine months of this year. The quarterly report, released yes terday, also showed gains in earnings for both periods.

title: In a Mobile Home: Cozy and It's Yours
description: RALEIGH, N. C.Like many another young couple across the nation, 21 yearold Gary Moras and his wife, Pam, 19, couldn't afford to buy a house. And like many another couple they didn't like the idea of living in an apartment. So  like thousands of other young couplesthey went out and bought their own mobile home.

title: MRS. JOSEPH T. HAND
description: ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 12 Mrs. Theresa Delaney Hand, a former buyer for Best & Co and the wife of Joseph T. Hand, a director and retired treasurer of Tootsie Roll Industries, Inc., died Wednesday in Orange Me morial Hospital. She was 71 years old and lived in Living ston.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A savingsbank guard with a reputation of being help ful and obliging to blind customers was arrested and Charged with grand larceny and forgery yesterday.

title: Fighting Emphysema
description: One of the United Hospi tal Fund's member hospitals has an unusual recondition ing laboratory as part of its rehabilita tion program. It approaches the problems caused by em physema with a deep study of each patient, and the laboratory's special ists can then prescribe a rou tine that allows the patient to function better in daily living. The laboratory is just one of the many ways in which all the United Hospital Fund's 54 member voluntary nonprofit hospitals are allevi ating the urban problems of the nineteenseventies. Con tributions may be made to the fund at 3 East 54th Street, New York, N. Y. 10022.

title: Their Pasta Is Fresh and the Meat First Rate
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their at mosphere, service and dcor (four triangles to none).

title: Fashion Show Gives Wives A Chance to Carry the Ball
description: Being the wife of a foot ball player isn't all sitting in the stands and cheering.

title: Blue Not in Party Mood In Clubhouse Celebration
description: DETROIT, Oct. 12Twenty four players, one manager, four coaches and one owner with assorted relatives celebrated Oakland's pennant with cham pagne, embraces and kisses. But the 25th player, Vida Blue, remained aloof from joy and ecstasy that belonged to the A's today.

title: U.S.Polish Hero Honored
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) The Philadelphia house where an American Revolutionary War hero, Thaddeus Kosciuszko, re signed will be designated as national historic site. Legisla tion to authorize the Interior Department to so honor the AmericanPolish soldier was passed Tuesday by Congress.

title: Cruiser Blast Caused 20 of 21 U.S. War Dead
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 12 (UPI)The United States command said today that 21 Americans died in the Vietnam war last week, the highest number in a year.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Oct. 12 (AP)Gaylord Freeman, the chair man of the First Chicago Corporation, predicted today that the United States prime rate for commercial bank lending would rise a quarter point to 6 per cent by yearend and reach 6.5 per cent toward the middle of next year. He made his remarks to newsmen after a meeting of security analysts on the occasion of the listing of First Chicago's stock on the London Stock Exchange.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Oxford Dictionary Finally Recognizes FourLetter Words
description: LONDON, Oct. 12 (UPI)The Oxford English Dictionary, con sidered the authority on British English, has included four letter words for the first time.

title: Diamond Goes 60 Miles In 1st Leg of Bond Tour
description: BATAVIA, N. Y., Oct. 12 (AP)After pedaling about 60 miles through a steady rain and patches of fog, the State Environmental Conser vation Commissioner, Henry L. Diamond, reached here this afternoon.

title: Books of The Times
description: Subject: BERNARD SHAW: COLLECTED LETTERS, 18981910. Edited by Dan H. Laurence. Illustrated, 1017 pages. Dodd, Mead. $25.

title: Ivy League Roundup
description: There will be important aerial warfare tomorrow on at least two Ivy gridirons the first at Baker Field, where Columbia faces Har vard, the second at Schoell kopf Oval in Ithaca, where Cornell meets Penn.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12  Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. suggested today that a link existed between a campaign contribution to President Nixon by the head of the McDonald's hamburger chain and the Ad ministration's insistence that a subminimum wage for teen agers be included in any new minimum wage bill.

title: TWO SCHOOL ISSUES HEARD BY JUSTICES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12  Lawyers from Colorado and Texas insisted before the Su preme Court today that the courts were not competent to deal with the complex issues posed by racial imbalance and unequal allocation of funds in the public schools.

title: Abrams Confirmed
description: The Senate voted 84 to 2 yesterday to confirm the nomination of Gen. Creighton W. Abrams as the Army Chief of Staff. Details on Page 9.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Seldom has the failure of a policy of our Government been so dramati cally obvious or as rigorously docu mented as Vietnamization.

title: '68 Talks in Apartment
description: PARIS, Oct. 12 (Reuters)  Jean Saintny, France's dele gategeneral in North Vietnam from 1954 to 1958, said today that the secret negotiations be tween Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho started at his apartment here three years ago.

title: Books of The Times
description: I've always read that Ford Madox Ford was a difficult, if not impossible, person. I never believed it. Until I read Return to Yesterday, I used to think that the man who could write The Good Soldier and Parade's End must have at least a hun dred redeeming qualities. In any case, out of gratitude for these two books, I would gladly have forgiven him all the peculiar ities ascribed to him, and more. But now that I've read these reminiscences of his, which have been out of print and hard to find for more than 30 years, I can't imagine why he wasn't loved by everyone he met.

title: Nixon Sends Regrets
description: PARIS, Oct. 12 (AP)Presi dent Nixon has sent a personal message to President Pompidou expressing regret for the dam age at the French general dele gation headquarters in Hanoi, the elyse Palace announced today.

title: 6 CITY EMPLOYES HELD FOR BRIBERY
description: Five inspectors for city agen cies and a clerkinvestigator were arrested yesterday on charges of shaking down the operator of Coney Island Board walk games.

title: Ruskin Subpoenas Consultant's Data In Inquiry on Gross
description: City Investigation Commis sioner Robert K. Ruskin has subpoenaed the records of a management consultant con cern involved with the Youth Services Agency and has opened an inquiry into allegations that an agency executive as sistant falsified documents to obtain his job.

title: Rail TonMileage Registers Rise of 22.3% in the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12The Association of American Rail roads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads last week totaled an estimated 16.8 billion tonmiles, 22.3 per cent above the cor responding week a year ago. Traffic in the comparable week of 1971 was affected by dock and coal strikes.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MANCHESTER, N. H.For once the voters of New Hamp shire have an opportunity to choose between two fine men, equally qualified in competence, integrity, character and in their private lives to be Governor, said William Loeb, the conserv ative publisher of The Man chester Union Leader, in a page 1 editorial the other day.

title: Ohio G.M. Plant Struck; Thousands May Be Idled
description: DETROIT, Friday, Oct. 13  A General Motors Corporation parts plant was struck at 12:01 A.M. today by the United Auto mobile Workers, and hundreds of thousands of workers could be idled unless the walkout ends quickly.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Houston, Oct. 12 (UPI) Frank Hughes put in a 25foot shot in front of the net at 18:24 of the third period to give the Houston Aeors a 32 victory over the Chicago Cougars in their opening game tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Margarita, Spanish Princess, Is Married to Doctor
description: ESTORIL, Portugal, Oct. 12 The wedding of the Infanta Margarita de Borbn, 33 yearold daughter of Don Juan de Borbn pretender to the Spanish throne, and granddaughter of the late King Alfonso XIII of Spain, to Dr. Carlos Zurita y Del gado, a 29yearold Madrid heart specialist, took place today in this seaside resort near Lisbon.

title: Chase Replaces President Alter Competitive Decline
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, which has been losing its coin petitive position to its rivals and has suffered a decline in its earnings, replaced its presi dent yesterday.

title: Art Garfunkle Weds
description: NASHVILLE, Oct. 12 (UPI) Art Garfunkle, the singer and actor, today married Miss Lin da Grossman, at her home here. The private ceremony was conducted by Rabbi Ran dal M. Falk. Mr. Garfunkle was part of the Simon and Gar funkle singing team that split up last year. Paul Simon, who attended the wedding, now does a single, and Mr. Gar funkle has gone into acting.

title: Art: The Sculptures of Willem de Kooning Shown
description: The exhibition of new work by Willem de Kooning that has now come to the Sidney Janis Gallery, 6 West 57th Street, includes a large selec tion of paintingsamong them some of the best the artist has produced in the last decadebut it is the sculpture that nonetheless dominates our attention. This is Mr. de Kooning's first as sault on the sculptural me dium, and the result is a body of work not only com pelling in itself but one that affords an illuminating per spective on his art as a whole.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW WEAKNESS
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in overthe counter trading finished lower yesterday for the second con secutive session in continued slow activity.

title: CHARLES MARTIN, 73, ANACONDA OFFICER
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 12 Charles W. Martin, who retired from the Anaconda Company in 1964 after 42 years as general administrator for Anaconda and its subsidiary companies, died Saturday in New Rochelle Hos pital. He was 73 years old and lived at 30 Bonnie Way.

title: Board of Estimate Votes Against Sale Of North Brother I.
description: The sale of North Brother Island was rejected yesterday by the Board of Estimate, with only Mayor Lindsay and Con troller Abraham D. Beame vot ing to offer the 20.5acre East River island to private in vestors.

title: Berkey Unveils Instant Camera
description: A new instantpicture camera that will be available in time for Christmas sales was un veiled yesterday by Berkey Photo, Inc. The company's Keystone division, which is producing the camera, has been working on the project for three years.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Fund for FloodControl Study Gains

title: STOCK PRICES OFF IN SLOW TRADING
description: Sagging prices in leading glamour issues pulled the entire stock market down sharply yes terday. The result was a drop of 8.96 points to 937.46 in the DowJones industrials and further dampening in investor spirits.

title: Aboard B52 Bomber High Over Vietnam A Crew Takes Part in an Impersonal War
description: ANDERSEN AIR FORCE BASE, Guam, Oct. 4Six hours and 14 minutes after taking off from this Pacific island base, Capt. Terry Jennings' B52 shuddered and 32,500 pounds of highexplosive bombs plum meted toward South Vietnam.

title: Capt. Albert Francis, 83, Dies; Hero in Morro Castle Rescue
description: Albert R. Francis, former master of the cruise liner Mon arch of Bermuda and a hero of the Morro Castle disaster in 1934, died on Wednesday at his home in Tucker's Town, Bermuda. He was 83 years old.

title: American and Briton Will Share Nobel Prize for Medicine in 1972
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 12  An American and a Briton were awarded the 1972 Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine to day for their separate research on the chemical structure of antibodies.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Brooklyn District Attorney Eugene Gold announced the indictments of five city agen cy inspectors and a clerk investigator on charges of re ceiving bribes ranging from $20 to $100 from operators of games on the Coney Is land Boardwalk. The Fire De partment and the Depart ments of Consumer Affairs, Buildings and Water Supply and Electricity were involved.

title: Bombing in Laos Reported
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 12 (Reuters)  Laotian military sources said today that two North Vietnamese planes bombed and strafed a northern Laotian village three days ago, killing six persons and injuring two.

title: Earnings Off 6.4% By CLARE M. RECKERT
LINDSAY UPSTATE TO AID M'GOVERN
description: WATERTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 12  Lindsay for Governor posters, all of them handmade, sprouted along more than 100 campaign miles upstate today as the Mayor tried to win votes for Senator George McGovern, the Democratic candidate for President.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Launches Cosmos524
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 12 (AP)The Soviet Union has launched the 524th unmanned earth satellite in its secret Cosmos series, Tass reported today. The Govern ment press agency said that the craft was launched yesterday into an orbit with a high point of 334 miles, a low point of 172 miles and an orbit slant of 71 degrees.

title: Salvatore Falcone, 81, Dies; Linked to '57 Mafia Summit
description: MIAMI, Oct. 12 (UPI)Salva tore Falcone, a Miami grocer who the government said was a top patricipant at the Mafia summit meeting in Apalachin, N. Y., in 1957, died Monday at the age of 81.

title: Building Costs Rose 5.9% Over Nation During Year
description: Construction casts acress the nation rose by an average of 5.9 per cent during the year ended Sept. 30, compared with a 7.8 per cent rise in the pre ceding year, the Dodge Build ing Cost Service Department of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times
description: DETROIT, Oct. 12The Green Bay Packers engage the Detroit Lions at football next Monday night, and thanks to people named Blue Moon Odom, Vida Blue, Reggie Jack son and Fury Gene Tenace they will have a field to play on. There were 50,276 sportsmen and sportswomen in Tiger Stadium today prepared to honor the Tigers as cham pions of the American League by tearing the playpen apart in obedience to the established baseball convention. They were excused from vandalism, however, when the Oakland A's won the fifth and deciding game of the pennant playoff, 21, largely through the offices of Odom, who got sick from nervousness; Blue, who turned grumpy in victory; Jackson, who finished the day on crutches, and Tenace, a goat in yesterday's defeat. Instead of clawing up the turf and dismantling the stands as they started to do last week when the Tigers won the league Eastern championship and again when the Tigers squared the playoff series yesterday, the clients merely dispersed, stiff with cold and sullen.

title: Advertising:
description: A large group of industry pennypinchers got together at the Plaza Hotel yesterday in hope of acquiring addition al pinching practices.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Nixon Administration's recent edict of checking and screening Arab residents and travelers to protect Israeli citizens in this country por tends grave implications for the per sonal freedoms and liberties of not only the Arab residents and travelers but I dare say, in time, for the over one million Americans of Arabic de scent. And then how long will it be before this Government returns to the policies of internment that were practiced on the JapaneseAmericans during World War II?

title: Extensive Revamping of Vocational Education Urged
description: The Fleischmann Commission, asserting that the state's high schools are training teenagers for jobs that will not exist in great numbers in the near fu ture, urged yesterday an exten sive revamping of the Voca tional education system.

title: CANADIENS TAKE THIRD IN ROW, 30
description: MONTREAL. Oct. 12 (UPI) Ken Dryden picked up his sec ond shutout in three games and the Montreal Canadiens kept their undefeated streak going tonight as they beat the Atlanta Flames, 30.

title: EDWARD M'LEAN, A FEDERAL JUDGE
description: Federal Judge Edward C. McLean died yesterday, appar ently of a heart attack, after collapsing at the entrance to the United States Court House at Foley Square. He would have been 69 years old Mon day. He lived here and in Darien, Conn., and had a sum mer home in Roxbury, Conn.

title: U.S., HUNGRAY REACH A WARCLAIM ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 The United States and Hunga have reached tentative agree nent settling American war damage and property claims, a Government official here dis closed tonight.

title: MUNICH BACH CHOIR OFFERS MAGNIFICAT
description: Crisp, efficient performances of Bach's Magnificat and Mo zart's Requiem were offered by the Munich Bach Choir and Or chestra Wednesday night in the third of their fourconcert se ties at Philharmonic Hall.

title: JERSEY OFFICIALS RIDE RAILS FREE
description: TRENTON, Oct. 12A large number of present and former officials ride the New Jersey railroads and the New Jersey Turnpike free of charge and use the facilities of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey without charge.

title: Vatican Orders Dutch To Cancel catechism
description: ROME, Oct. 12The Vati can publicly ordered two Ro man Catholic bishops in the Netherlands today to withdraw immediately as gravely defi cient a new catechism for high schools.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Pratt and Whitney divi sion of the United Aircraft Cor poration received a $73.4mil lion contract for jet aircraft engines for the Navy and Air Force, it was announced yester day.

title: EXECUTIVE FOUND IN TRUNK OF CAR
description: A Manhattan businessman disappeared on his way to work yesterday morning and  after a bizarre eight hours that saw an abortive rendezvous for ran som, a news blackout by the police and, finally, an anony mous tipwas found unhurt in the locked trunk of a car parked near a Queens ceme tery.

title: REVENUE SHARING PASSED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 The House of Representatives passed today the final version of the revenuesharing bill, de feating a lastminute attempt by New Yorkers to eliminate the cutback in the bill's money for social services.

title: BLACKOUT POLICY IS EASED BY N.F.L.
description: Pro football has opened the door a bit on its television blackout policy. Commissioner Pete Rozelle said yesterday the next Super Bowl game, scheduled for Los Angeles on Jan. 14, would be televised locally there provided all the seats were sold out 10 days before the game.

title: Bridge: Game Given Financial Aid By Some European Nations
description: Some of the wealthier Eu ropean Governments take an enlightened attitude toward organized bridge, which re ceives some financial aid.

title: Miss Tavacoli Marries Here
description: Miss Mercedes Tavacoli and Francis Leonard Kellogg, Special Assistant to the Secretary of State with the rank of ambassador, were married yesterday in Gene va, where the civil ceremony was performed by the chief registrar, Gerald Boujou.

title: Chou and Bonn Aide Meet
description: PEKING, Oct. 12 (AFP)Pre mier Chou Enlai talked today with West Germany's Foreign Minister, Walter Scheel, who yesterday signed a joint com muniqu here officially establish ing diplomatic relations between China and West Germany. Ob servers here believe that Mr. Chou and Mr. Scheel discussed bilateral questions as well as European security and the Common Market.

title: TORY PARLEY BACKS HEATH ON REFUGEES
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 12After noisy and bitter de bate, the Conservative party's annual conference today dis posed of one of its most can sitive issues by backing the Government's decision to admit Asians expelled from Uganda. The struggle over the motion, which congratulated the Gov emment on its swift action on the refugees, reflected the uneasiness in the party and in the country over the influx of Asians ordered out of Uganda by Maj. Gen. Idi, Amin.

title: Youngsters Go Native at Museum's New People Center
description: African drums pounded out an infectious rhythm and a tall black woman, barefoot and wrapped in a blue native dress and turban, swayed with the music, swooped her arms in a graceful arc, spun around and stamped her feet.

title: Aide to Nixon's Campaign Tied to Secret U.S. Data
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Former Assistant Attorney General Robert C. Mardian obtained confidential information from the Justice Department for potential use in President Nixon's political campaign after leaving the Government to work for the Committee for the Reelection, of the President, according to sources close to the Water gate investigation.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Protest Closes Brooklyn School

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Both New York and national Republican leaders are so deemphasizing Vice President Agnew that he is a virtual shadow candidate in many areas of the nation, including this state.

title: ATLANTA IS WARM TO NIXON ON VISIT
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 12This Old Confederate city, now a symbol of the new South, gave Pres ident Nixon visual evidence to day of what the pollsters have been saying for months: Wal lace country is now Nixon coun try.

title: Deciphering the Structure
description: Dr. Edelman and Dr. Porter almost became teammates 15 years ago as they strove to ward a goal of clarifying the scientific picture of how the body produces antibodies to combat infectious and some other diseases.

title: Nastase Draws Smith in Opening Match And They May Decide Davis Cup Final
description: BUCHAREST, Oct. 12 When he heard the two names in the draw for the first match, Me Nastase smiled and waved to Stan Smith and Smith grinned and waved to his Rumanian friend across the room. The 1972 Davis Cup has been full of goodwill and that's why the United StatesRu mania final is being held in Bucharest.

title: Professor Falls to Death
description: A 30yearold man identified by the police as a professor at New York University jumped or fell to his death from his eighth floor livingrem window at 110. Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village last night, Leonard Mar elli, left a note, the police said, but its contents were not disclosed.

title: 45% of High School Pupils Here Said to Take Drugs
description: Nearly half the high school students in New York City are more than occasional users of some psychoactive drug, ac cording to the report yesterday by the Fleischmann Commis sion.

title: ALI FOSTER SIGN FOR NOV. 12 BOUT
description: STATELINE, Nev. Oct. 12 (AP)Muhammad Ali and Bob Foster signed contracts today for a 12round heavyweight bout here Nov. 12.

title: HANOI ALERT BARS FRENCH AIDE'S JET
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Oct. 12 (Agence FrancePresse)An airraid alert here today report edly prevented the French Am bassador to Peking from arriv ing to take temporary charge of his country's diplomatic mission, which was wrecked yesterday during an American attack on the Hanoi area.

title: The Opera
description: With its many perform ances in English and Italian, the New York City Opera's production of Don Giovanni has absorbed a lot of voices. Wednesday night, a perform ance of the Mozart work in English had another baritone in the title role and three singers making their debuts with the company. In view of the changes, the performance went reasonably well, and Frank, Corsaro's much criti cized staging has been tamed to a point where it is almost routinely dull.

title: Bache to Enter Government Bond Field
description: Bache & Co., the nation's secondlargest retail brokerage house, has decided to enter the Government bond business in a move that represents a major effort to broaden the concern's range of financial services.

title: Price Changes
description: The GeorgiaPacific Corpo ration announced yesterday a nationwide voluntary price roll back on plywood and lumber, beginning Monday. This marks the company's second price re duction for the products since Sept. 1.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TEANECK, Oct. 12The Mayors of seven Bergen County municipalities announced today that they would mount an of fensive against approval of the state's proposed $650million transportation bond issue.

title: FIFTH AVENUE COACH REPORTS AN ACCORD
description: Fifth Avenue Coach Lines an nounced here yesterday that a preliminary agreement for settlement had been reached in the company's prolonged lawsuit against several of its former officers and directors.

title: Miss Davis Arrives Here After a Tour Of 6 Red Countries
description: Angela Davis, the black mili tant and avowed Communist who was acquitted of murder, kidnapping and conspiracy charges earlier this year, re turned to the United States last night after a sixweek tour of the Soviet Union and other Communist countries.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 12 the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation here announced a grant of $5million today to Meharry Medical College of Nashville to support, over fiveyear period, an expansion of the college's programs to train health professionals for service in underdoctored communities.

title: ExHousing Repair Aide Is Indicted
description: The former deputy director of the Housing and Develop ment Administration's Emer gency Repair Program was indicted yesterday on charges of conspiracy, bribery and per jury, stemming from the opera tion of the controversial pro gram last year.

title: Percy's Campaign Aid Held Most in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 Senator Charles H. Percy of Illinois, seeking reelection to a second sixyear term, has raised more than $1million in campaign contributions, or more than any other candi date for Congress this year, the national citizens' lobby, Common Cause, said today.

title: Mrs. McGovern Rests In Hospital in Capital
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 13 Mrs. George McGovern was resting very comfortably in Georgetown University Hos pital here today, her hus band's campaign office said.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Johnny Bench swung hard and the ball, soaring high, landed beyond the outfield wall at Riverfront Stadium for a home run. Watching it on a TV set here the other day, Doug Schustek, an independent TV producer, leaped and pounded his left fist on a desk so hard that his wrist watch stopped. He was happy for Johnny Bench and he was happy for the Cincinnati Reds, but mostly he was happy for himself. In his office at Stadium Productions, Inc., there is a big brown cardboard box. In it is a videotape of a TV

title: 2 British Nationals Held 5 Years By the Chinese Are Deported
description: HONG KONG, Saturday, Oct. 14 (Reuters)  Two British brothers, Percival and Frederick Farmer, who had been detained) by Chinese authorities since September, 1967, arrived here today from China.

title: ARABS SAY YEMENS WILL DISCUSS PEACE
description: ADEN, Southern Yemen. Oct. 13The Arab League's peace mission announced today that the two Yemens had agreed to a comprehensive plan aimed at settling the dispute that has brought fighting between them.

title: Fleischmann Aide Corrects NarcoticsAbuse Statistic
description: Roger Hooker, an associate director of the state's Fleisch mann Commission, said yester day that a commission official had erred when he said on Thursday that 45 per cent of New York City students in the 10th through 12th grades were more than occasional drug users or weekenders.

title: SENATE RESTRICTS NIXON AUTHORITY TO CUT SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13The Senate passed the spending ceiling bill tonight, after first approving some limitations on the authority that it gives the President to cut Government spending this fiscal year to no more than $250billion.

title: M'CARTHY WEIGHS EDITORSHIP HERE
description: Former Senator Eugene Mc Carthy said yesterday that he had tentatively agreed to be come a senior editor of Simon and Schuster, the New York publishing house.

title: Jones of Tams Suspended
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 13 (AP) The Memphis Tams suspended and fined Wilbert Jones today for failing to show up for the American Basketball Associa tion team's game with Indiana last night.

title: MAN SAYS ROBBERS LOCKED HIM IN CAR
description: A man who had been robbed and stuffed into the trunk of his car and then driven by thieves from Baltimore to New York extricated himself with a crowbar and escaped after the car was abandoned, the police said yesterday. He was treated at Harlem Hospital for minor lacerations.

title: POST PLEA HEARD BY U.S. PAY BOARD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  Spokesmen for The New York Post and for 325 commercial printing shops in New York City urged the Pay Board today to reduce wage rates now in force.

title: Paul Tartter Weds Vivien C. Rothman
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Oct. 13 Miss Vivien Carol Rothman and Paul Ian Tartter, seniors at Brown University, were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. John Rothman. Mr. Tartter is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jean Royal Tartter of Arlington, Va.

title: SIX U.S. UNITS JOIN DRUG TASK FORCE
description: In an intensified attack on major narcotics wholesalers in the city, lawyerinvestigator teams from six Federal agen cies will work with the Joint New York Narcotics Task Force, Mayor Lindsay an nounced yesterday.

title: Yen Revaluing Feared
description: TOKYO, Oct. 13The rate of the dollar to the yen de clined sharply this week in the Tokyo foreign market under strong selling of the dollar.

title: Oil Slick Reaches Lake
description: PIUTES FARMS, Utah, Oct. 13 (AP)A portion of a vast oil slick from a ruptured pipe line seeped into Lake Powell today despite a system of Styrofoam floats and log booms that had been thrown up in an effort to stop it. Meanwhile, cleanup operations began, in cluding burning any oil on the surface of the San Juan River, which carried the oil 100 miles downstream to the lake.

title: 2 AMERICAN PRIESTS HELD IN PHILIPPINES
description: MANILA, Oct. 13 (UPI)  Two American Roman Cath olic priests doing missionary work in the Philippines have been arrested and placed in military camps on charges of violating the martiallaw de cree, the Government said to day.

title: Bridge: The Luck of the Irish Team Turns Out to Be All Bad
description: The rubberbridge player who tries duplicate for the first time is given to under stand that the advantage of comparing with others play ing the same deals is that luck is eliminated. As he soon discovers, this is a naive misrepresentation of the truth.

title: CAR CRASH KILLS 4 ON QUEENS PARKWAY
description: A husband and wife and their two small children were killed last night when their car collided headon with a car that had jumped over a divider on the Interborough Parkway in Queens, the police reported.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 13Sar gent Shriver, campaigning hard throughout the day in Cleve land, the key to Democratic hopes in Ohio, caused a small furor when he delivered a par tisan speech before a national nursing group.

title: Mr. Nixon's Silence
description: In his campaign for reelection, President Nixon has been avoiding that low road which he has often been criticized for pursuing in the past. The trouble is, he has been avoiding the high road as well. Except for such brief prepackaged excursions as he made this week to Atlanta, he is not taking any road at all, apparently hoping to win by standing still while his opponent knocks himself out.

title: G.M. to Scrap 1,000 Cars Outmoded During Strike
description: NORWOOD, Ohio, Oct. 13 (UPI)All but 40 of the 1,100 Chevrolet Camaros and Pontiac Firebirds that were in various stages of completion at the General Motors plant here when it was struck last April will be scrapped.

title: 'The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie'
description: As in a dream things go fearfully wrong for the characters in Luis Buuel's brilliant (and brilliantly titled) new comedy, "The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie," but the Ambassador of Miranda and his Parisian friends, the Snchals and the Thevenots, and Mrs. Thevenot's sister, Florence, always manage to cope gracefully. On second thought, Florence is not quite as consistent as the others.One martini and Florence is inclined to throw uplooking beautiful one minute and like a dead goose the next, her head dangling out the Ambassador's Cadillac window.For the most part, however, the Ambassador, the Snchals, the Thevenots and Florence survive a series of magnificently bewildering circumstances, employing the kind of elegance, self-interest, delicacy, intelligence, rudeness and short attention spans that Buuel apparently finds to be the power, the curse and the appeal of the European upper middle class.The world of "The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie" is one of absolutely everything interrupted.For some peculiar reason, every time the friends sit down to dine, odd things happen. An Army arrives or, just as the food is being served, a curtain goes up and the friends find themselves on a stage playing to an audience. "I don't know my lines," M. Snchal (Jean-Pierre Cassel) says with wild-eyed, middle-of-the-night fright.When Mme. Thevenot (Delphine Seyrig) is at the flat of the Ambassador (Fernando Rey) for an afternoon tryst, her husband (Paul Frankeur) stops byand you haven't seen such a flurry of garter belts and little white gloves in 40 years of moviegoing. Things get so bad that fate even conspires to interrupt (though not permanently) the very profitable heroin smuggling operation that the Ambassador conducts with the help of M. Snchal and M. Thevenot.One must, I suppose, talk about "The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie" rather gravely. It is, after all, Buuel's 28th feature since "L'Age D'Or" in 1929 but, except for "The Exterminating Angel" and "Belle de Jour," he has never since employed the special freedom of Surrealism for such astonishing and lucid results.Several years ago, Buuel said of "The Exterminating Angel" that "its images, like the images in a dream, do not reflect reality, but create it." A lot of "The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie" is made up of dreamsat times, of dreams within dreams, at other times, dreams that one person has dreamed that another dreamed. Sometimes they are just the dreams of a passer-by. You've never seen so many wish fulfillments. However, much of it is not a dream, and all of it is real  the unique creation of a director who, at 72, has never been more fully in control of his talents, as a filmmaker, a moralist, social critic and humorist.One must talk about these things; yet they tend to flatten the special exhilaration that "The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie" inspires when you see it. That exhilaration has to do with the awareness that you're watching a genius at work through any number of indications, some almost minuscule.Take, for example, the sort of small to-do that ensues when Mme. Snchal (Stphane Audran) and Mme. Thevenot, with Florence (Bulle Ogier), go for afternoon tea at a fancy Paris hotel. Florence asks to change her seat. She can't stand looking at the cellist. "I hate cellos," she pouts. "Most orchestras have dropped them." Like others in her class, Florence is a woman in the thrall of cockeyed fashion.Or take the character of the clergyman (Julien Bertheau). "You've heard of the worker priests?" he asks the astonished Mme. Snchal as he applies for the job of gardener. "Well, I'm a worker bishop."In addition to being extraordinarily funny and perfectly acted, "The Discreet Charm" moves with the breathtaking speed and self-assurance that only a man of Buuel's experience can achieve without resorting to awkward ellipsis. It was shown last night at the New York Film Festival and opens Sunday, Oct. 22 at the Little Carnegie. As I have not said in several years: Don't miss it.

title: Music: Les Menestriers
description: One of the most winning and offbeat ensembles from Europe in some time made its United States debut at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Thursday night. The group was Les Menestriers, a quin tet of young persons from France who play and sing medieval and Renaissance music with the informality and enthusiasm of modern folk minstrels. They dress casually and chat agreeably about the krummhorns, viols, rebecs and other old instru ments they play.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: FREEHOLD, Oct. 12  The race for New Jersey's Third Congressional District seat is regarded here as a lowpro file rerun of the 1970 contest, but one that could be strongly affected by the Presidential election.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 A brainwave analyzer has been developed as an aid in the diagnosis of diseases and injuries affecting the human nervous system. Among the conditions ex amined are tu mors, epilepsy and stroke. E. Roy John, di rector of the Brain Research Laboratory at the New York Medical Col lege, and Robert Laupheimer, an electrical engineer, were granted Patent 3,696,808 this week for the system. One institution using the sym metry analyzer is the Rock land State Hospital, which operates several in research. The manufacturer, the Neuro Data Corporation, Cliff side, N. J., of which Dr. John is president, has completed its first production run.

title: Belfast Soured and Exhausted by Constant Violence
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 13After turbulent and violent months, Belfast and the province have settled into the rhythm of sporadic sniper fire and explosions, army searches, threats and counterthreats by Roman Catholics and Protest ants, and apparently mindless sectarian murdersmore than 60 since July, most of them by terror squads on both sides.

title: 2D TEACHER ROBBED IN FRONT OF CLASS
description: A teacher in a Bronx elemen tary school was robbed of her pocketbook and $5 in front of her fifthgrade class yesterday by a man who pulled a knife on her, according to the police.

title: People and Business
description: The man who wrote for Senator George McGovern the controversial statement, Money made by money should be taxed at the same rate as money made by men, made a speech of his own on Wall Street yesterday. Rob ert K. Lifton, the only busi nessman on the Democratic Presidential nomihee's eco nomic advisory council, talked to some 20 members of the Wharton Graduate Business School Club of New York about his favorite candidate's economic policies.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI, Oct. 13A judge here has ordered three men as sociated with President Nixon's campaign fundraising to ap pear in a trial of Bernard L. Barker, the suspected leader of the Watergate breakin.

title: A Federal Code of Ethics Is Outlined by McGovern
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 13Senator George McGovern outlined here today a sevenpoint code of ethics for the Federal Gov ernment to break what he called the growing link between those in power who seek money and those with money who seek favors.

title: BROKERS ENJOINED ON S.E.C. DEBT RULE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission won temporary 5re straining orders here yesterday against two New York broker age firms to prevent them from violating an S.E.C. regulation that their debts must not ex ceed 20 times capital.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Literary Digest, a once repu table magazine, died in 1936 when its Presidential poll, based on several million telephone calls, predicted a Landon victory. Franklin D. Roosevelt, of course, won 46 states.

title: BOTH SIDES AGREE PROBLEMS REMAIN IN VIETNAM TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 The United States and North Vietnam today agreed in effect that numerous difficult prob lems remained to be settled be fore peace in Vietnam is possi ble.

title: 100 in an IRT Train Seek Cover as Two Scramble for a Gun
description: About 100 passengers on a northbound IRT train entering Grand Central station during the morning rush hour scrambled for cover yesterday when two shots were fired as two men on the train fought for possession of a gun.

title: BURST BY CELTICS SUBDUES LAKERS
description: BOSTON, Oct. 13 (AP)A sevenminute scoring burst led by John Havlicek and Don Nelson in the second period helped the Boston Celtics, de feat the Los Angeles Lakers, 112104, in a National Basket ball Association game tonight.

title: A Federal Code of Ethics Is Outlined by McGovern
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 13Senator George McGovern outlined here today a sevenpoint code of ethics for the Federal Gov ernment to break what he called the growing link between those in power who seek money and those with money who seek favors.

title: Aluminum Shipments Up
description: The Aluminum Association reported yesterday that net shipments of sheet and plate in August increased by 18.7 per cent to an estimated 403 mil lion pounds from 340 million pounds a year earlier.

title: Police Report Rise This Year in Crime Against the Person
description: Most categories of crimes against the person, especially rape, increased in the city in the first eight months of this year over the comparable pe riod of last year, while crimes against property decreased, ac cording to statistics released yesterday by the Police Depart ment.

title: Peace Plan of McGovern Is Criticized by Harriman
description: NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 13 (AP) The Vietnam peace plan of Senator George McGovern, the Democratic Presidential nomi nee, would not bring about a responsible withdrawal of troops or a responsible settle ment of the war, W. Averell Harriman, former chief United States negotiator at the Paris peace talks, said here last night.

title: MAJOR FUTURES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Prices of some major com modities dropped sharply yesterday in futures trading, following higherthanexpected production estimates in the De partment of Agriculture's crop report issued late Thursday.

title: Personalities: Palmer in Tourney
description: Arnold Palmer announced his entry yesterday in the $150,000 Kaiser International open golf tournament, which will be played next week at the Siverado Country Club in Napa, Calif. Others in the field include Jack Nicklaus, seeking to become the first man in history to win $300, 000 in a single season; Billy Casper, Lee Trevino, George Archer, Jerry Heard and Grier Jones, all among the lead ing money winners. Gene Littler, making a comeback after cancer surgery, also has entered the vent, which carries a first prize of $30,000.

title: A's Regain Campaneris for Series Opener Today
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 13The Oakland Athletics regained Bert Campaneris today, but suf fered a damaging blow when they lost Reggie Jackson for the World Series, which opens here tomorrow in the home of the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Still on the Sick List
description: The finding of the Citizens Budget Commission that the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation has failed to correct the most fundamental faults of the municipal hospital system gains in authority from the manifest fairness the commission has demonstrated in assessing the corporation's twoyear record.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: MIDNIGHT MONSTER CONCERT TONIGHT 16 Pianists. 8 Pianos. Philharmonic Hall. Advt

title: McGovern Speech Scheduled
description: DETROIT, Oct. 13 (AP)The Economic Club of Detroit an nounced today that Senator George McGovern would speak at a breakfast meeting of the club members and their wives at Cobo Hall next Wednesday.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Restaurants on this page are rated for food (four stars to none) and for at mosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: Film Fete: 'Assassination of Trotsky'
description: Joseph Losey's career in recent years has vacillated with quite wonderful agility between distinguished motion pictures, like "Accident" and "The Go-Between," and odd-ball movies, starring one or more of the Burtons: "Secret Ceremony" and "Boom." I'm sure that any student of Losey could argue for the thematic continuity of all his work (even the failed allegory of "Figures in a Landscape"), but for their audacity and imaginative density I prefer the odd-ball movies. And among these I would place "The Assassination of Trotsky," which stars Richard Burton as Leon Trotsky, and is a very odd project indeed.The movie deals with Trotsky's last months, mainly from May, 1940, when a night-time raid on Trotsky's Mexican compound failed; until August of the same year, when an incredibly clumsy assassination attempt by a man known as Frank Jacson succeeded. Jacson (Alain Delon) was a secretive, even shy man, who gained his access to the compound through Sylvia Ageloff (Romy Schneider), an intimate of the family; and much of the film is given to developing not a motive, but a private world-view, for the assassin.As you might expect, history weighs heavy over such a movie, not least in a performance by Burton that almost looks historical. Much of the dialogue is taken from journals or accurate accounts of Trotsky's life, and it sounds as if he spent his life polishing up speeches for the movies.Thus, a nostalgic Wordsworthian Trotsky, to his grandson: "You should have been with us in the old days. What happiness it was to be alive! Storming the Winter Palace. . ." Or, in a hopeful mood: "Ah! It's a long time since I felt so well. . . Today I could climb mountains. . ."this is, of course, the morning of his assassination.The mere fact that Trotsky may have said such things doesn't excuse them in a movie. There is a lot more not to be excused in "The Assassination of Trotsky," but to be borne with by anybody who cares about the often beautiful things that Losey does with his camera, his always superb feeling for dcor, his ways of placing his characters in a time scheme that is not simply historical.I suspect that what goes on beneath the narrative in "The Assassination of Trotsky" is very complex. I can only say at this point that it has to do with a fantastic use of corridors, with continually shifting levels of reality, with a penchant for turning mirrors into muralsthe murals of Orozco and Rivera, the very structure of Losey's Mexico City and of the agony he is dramatizing.All the actors are made up to resemble their originals with extraordinary accuracy, and none seems more accurate than Valentina Cortese as Natalia Sedov, Trotsky's wife. Her role is comparatively small, but I think it is the loveliest performance in the movie."The Assassination of Trotsky" played last night in the New York Film Festival, and it opens Sunday at the Coronet Theater.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: The destruction of the French dip lomatic mission in Hanoi was one of those rare events that illuminate our condition. If we Americans look, we can see what has become of us in the Vietnam war. We can see what sort of men lead us.

title: EXPERT TESTIFIES ON TURNER BEHALF
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 13 (AP A legal expert testified today that the type of cosmetics dis tributorships sold by a Florida businessman, Glenn W. Tur ner, would not be commonly recognized as a security.

title: Rockets Edge Cavaliers
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 13 (UPI) A pair of foul shots by Jimmy Walker with 2:04 to play gave Houston a 10point lead tonight and the Rockets hung on for a 109108 victory over Cleveland despite a 40point effort by the Cavaliers' Austin Carr, his pro high.

title: Saigon Says Base Falls To Foe in Heavy Fighting
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Oct. 14  Heavy fighting was reported yester day in the jungles of the Cen tral Highlands with North Viet namese troops overrunning a ranger camp after two days of heavy artillery barrages.

title: DISMISSALS URGED ON MACKELL STAFF
description: The State Attorney, Louis J. Lefkowitz, was urged yesterday to require District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens to dismiss those of his employes who invoked their Fifth Amend ment privilege and declined to answer questions before a Fed eral grand jury.

title: Sugarman Uncovers New Fund Misuse In Emergency Audit of Youth Agency
description: Human Resources Adminis trator Jule M. Sugarman re ported yesterday that his emer gency audit of the Youth Serv ices Agency had uncovered additional misuses of funds and that all agency records had been turned over to the City Commissioner of Investigation for further action.

title: Olympic Horsemen In National Show Beginning Today
description: HARRISBURG, Oct. 13 (AP) The 27th annual Pennsyl vania National horse show opens tomorrow with riders from four countries competing for $40,000 in prizes.

title: TITO, AT 80, TRIES TO REBUILD PARTY
description: BELGRADE Yugoslavia, Oct. 13  A mood of a gathering political storm is building up in Yugoslavia as President Tito, who is 80 years old and con scious of diminishing time, is striving to rebuild the reform weakened Communist organiza tion as a tightly disciplined authority to hold the country together after he leaves power.

title: Only 2,248 See Q's Lose To Rockets in A.B.A. Debut
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 13 (AP) The San Diego Conquistadors, also known as the Q's, dropped a 109100 decision to the Denver Rockets tonight in the Q's American Basketball Asso lciation debut.

title: CUNNINGHAM HELPS COUGARS TOP PACERS
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 13 (AP) Billy Cunningham and Mack Calvin sparked the Carolina Cougars to a 14point halftime lead tonight and they went on to hand the defending American Basketball Association cham pions, the Indiana Pacers, a 10688 defeat.

title: School Mourns Loss of Course
description: Several hundred students and teachers at Theodore Roosevelt High School in the South Bronx staged a funeral march at dawn yesterday to protest the demise of remedial reading and other special courses lost in budget cuts.

title: Telephone Co. to Give Scores During Series
description: The New York Telephone Company will provide World Series scores on telephone number 6371212.

title: TRIP TO A PRISON HONORS DEAD SON
description: LOMPOC, Calif., Oct. 13 (UPI)A San Francisco couple drove home today with the body of their dead son after taking it on a 600mile journey so that his imprisoned brother could attend memorial services.

title: 46 Injured in Racial Clash On a Carrier Off Vietnam
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 13  The Pacific Fleet Command an nounced today that 46 persons, both black and white, were in jured in an incident aboard the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk Wednesday off North Vietnam.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HAMILTON, N. Y., Oct. 13 (AP)Members of Colgate University's 1932 football team which was undefeated, untied, unscored on and uninvited, will gather on the field again Saturday. They will receive the plaudits of a Homecoming Day crowd at the game with Holy Cross.

title: 40 BLACK PUPILS REASSIGNED HERE
description: Forty black youngsters from a Brownsville housing project  who have not attended classes since the fall term began on Sept. 11  were assigned yesterday to two integrated Brooklyn junior high schools, one in he East Flatbush sec tion and the other in Canarsie. They are scheduled to report on Monday.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 13  The Rutgers board of governors today approved a controver sial policy of arming the campus police, authorized a $10.8million field house, and in a surprise move gave stu dents classes off on Election Day.

title: Financing U.S. Deficit
description: PARIS, Oct. 13Japan in ef fect has become the principal financing agent for the United States balanceofpayments deficit.

title: CASEY CITES STUDY OF REALTY TRUSTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 William J. Casey, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that the agency has concluded that it is not now necessary to regulate real estate invest ment trusts as closely as in vestment companies, such as mutual funds.

title: McGovern Gains $300,000
description: BOSTON, Oct. 13 (AP) George McGovern's fundrais ing efforts in Massachusetts this week earned about $300, 000, his aides report. Sources of the money, according to a spokesman, were $150,000 from a cocktail party in Boston, $100,000 from a Boston Armory gala, $30,000 from an art auc tion and $20,000 from other fundraising events across the state.

title: 3 Injured Giants Uncertain for Tomorrow's Game
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 13 The New York Giants worked out at Candlestick Park this afternoon, in preparation for Sunday's game against the 49ers', still uncertain about the physical condition of three players: Rocky Thompson, Bob by Duhon and Dan Goich.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Eldon R. Clingan, Council man at large from Manhattan and minority leader of the City Council, confirmed that he had switched from the Liberal party to the Demo cratic party. He said he intended to resign as minor ity leader Jan. 1, but that he planned to retain the seat to which he was elected as a Liberal.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: The Jersey Journal, which has traditionally backed the Hudson County Democratic party, endorsed the re election bid of President Nixon in an editorial in yesterday's editions.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:The height of idiocy has been pro posed concerning the Empire State Building extension. How in sanity's name can any responsible city official allow this overkill project to pro ceed? Can you imagine the results? Traffic tied up in an overly congested area for years to come; danger to pedestrians from falling objects; air pollution from demolition and con struction; etc.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Employment Service Program Direc tor Paul J. Elston's letter of Sept. 25, replying to Ira Glasser's letter of Sept. 17, would warrant a derisive laugh if the subject matter did not involve so flagrant an exploitation of the labor of helpless citizens forced to seek public assistance.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is understandable that relatives, friends, newsmen and others should want immediate release and contact with returned P.O.W.'s, but having spent four years in German P.O.W. camps myself, I am sure that the mili tary authorities are showing these men the greater kindness by return ing them to civilian life slowly.

title: MRS. ROGER S. WARNER
description: IPSWICH, Mass., Oct. 13 Mrs. Mary Hooper Warner, a horticulturist, died yesterday in a nursing home at the age of 93. She lived here and in Bos ton. Mrs. Warner, the widow of Roger Sherman Warner, Boston lawyer who died in 1940, was a trustee of the Mas sachusetts Horticultural Society.

title: Editor Said to Seek to Buy the Apollo
description: Clarence B. Jones, the 40 yearold editor and publisher of The New York Amsterdam News, the nation's largest and best known black weekly is reportedly seeking to buy the worldfamous Apollo Theater, Harlem showcase for black entertainers.

title: Columbia's Research Ship Is Home
description: PIERMONT, N. Y., Oct. 13 Columbia University's research ship, the Vema, returned to her home port here today after a two and onehalf year voyage around the world, covering 125,000 miles and reaching 160 million years back in time.

title: State Levies $25,000 Fine Against Dean Witter & Co.
description: A $25,000 fine has been lev ied against Dean Witter & Co., the brokerage firm, for failure to notify New York State of changes in its officers and di rectors, it was disclosed yes terday.

title: TEACHERS IN ITALY STRIKE FOR 2 DAYS
description: ROME, Oct. 13Italy's edu cation system was paralyzed from the elementary level to the universities today as teach ers started a twoday strike to protest against what their unions termed the shameful condition of the schools.

title: KENNEDY ORDERS BUGGING INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, as chairman of a Senate judici ary committee, has ordered a preliminary inquiry into the Watergate bugging incident and charges of political espionage and sabotage in the Presidential campaign.

title: ELLSBERG APPEAL IS OPPOSED BY U.S.
