description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13The Justice Department told the Supreme Court today that it would set a precedent that could cause havoc in the courts if it delayed the Pentagon pa pers trial of Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. while the Justices considered an appeal of a wiretapping issue in the case.

title: Alexander's Net in Year Off 72% on 5% Sales Gain
description: Alexander's Inc., one of New York's largest retailers, reported yesterday a substan tial decline in net profit on a 5.7 per cent rise in sales in the fiscal year ended July 29.

title: Business Briefs
description: The First National City Bank and the Mellon National Bank and Trust Company, as expected, announced yes terday increases in their prime interest rates on business loans to 5 per cent, effective for the week beginning Mon day. This week, the two banks posted 5 per cent rates.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Lockheed Missiles & Space Company, a subsidiary of the Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration, has received a $157.4 million addition to a Navy award for procurement of the Poseidon submarinelaunched ballistic missile, it was an nounced yesterday.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Fruehauf Corporation said yesterday that it would delay the opening of a plant to make modular housing units in Milan, Mich. It also said it had terminated the employment of Roblee Martin, vice president and general manager of its Fruehauf Building division.

title: Art: A Memorial for Sidney Gross
description: Memorial exhibitions are not usually the happiest of occasions. For an artist whose reputation was not particularly formidable dur ing his lifetime, the memorial show can prove to be a critical test. Even artists with popular reputations pass after their deaths into a limbo from which they are only rescued in time. The critic confronting such a show is vulnerable as well. His judgments and prejudices may well help to bury an artist whose life's work de better.

title: Music: Poem of Ecstasy
description: When Pierre Boulez took over the New York Philhar monic, he had the reputation of being an austere musician with a profound dislike for romantic or postromantic mu sic. The last piece in the world that one would ever expect to hear under his baton would be the decadent, juicy, over rich, sensuous Poem of Ecstasy by Alexander Scriabin.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13The Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Oct. 10:

title: Engagements
description: WALKERBECKERThe engagement is an nounced between James Edward Bruce, younger son of Mr. R. E. and the Hon. Mrs. Faure Walker of Beards Place, Ditch ling, Sussex, England, and Carvn Lois, twin daughter of Dr. and Mrs. R. L. Becker of Gracie Plaza, 1701 York Avenue, New York Cite, New York.

title: Flood Perils Grow as Land Is Covered by Developers
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 13Most of the time, Salt Creek is a lazy little stream that works its muddy way through 14 grow ing suburbs west of Chicago, gurgling happily and bothering no one.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Once again I see we have a garbage crisis. Our Jerry Kretchmer proposes a further poisoning of the ocean (City Wants Waste Dumped in Ocean, news story Sept. 27) while in the Bronx Sanitation Commissioner Elish says that in two years the Pelham Bay land fill will be full and then the junk will have to be towed to the Staten Island landfill, (Garbage Crisis Feared in Bronx, news story Sept. 27). The trouble is that this landfill will also be full in a couple of years, for we produce garbage at a rate which approximates that of our G.N.P.

title: Protestants in Peking: A Church Survives
description: PEKING, Oct. 13There are a number of fine old churches still standing in Pekingsome derelict and boarded up, others in use as community centers, still others converted into work shops. But the only Protestant church that still functions as such doesn't look like a church at all.

title: Rumania Ties U.S., 11, As Smith Tops Nastase
description: BUCHAREST, Oct. 13Once again, Stan Smith's unexciting tennis was too much for Ilie Nastase, but when today's Davis Cup matches with Ru mania were over, the United States had come away with only a 11 tie.

title: Soviet's Grain Shortage Brings Readjustments in the East Bloc
description: WARSAW, Oct. 13  The Soviet Union's poor harvest and heavy purchases of West ern grains and other foods are apparently having a consider able effect on Eastern Europe. Some Communist bloc na tions are selling to the Soviet Union to help fill the shortages while others are negotiating for purchases of grain to re place supplies normally pro vided by Moscow.

title: 3 Die in Plane Crash
description: OLIVER SPRINGS, Tenn., Oct. 13 (UPI)  Three persons were killed today when their singleengine Cessna crashed into Windrock Mountain and exploded into flames during a thunderstorm. The victims were identified as David Col hns, Loren Long, pilot of the plane and son of the principal owner of the Craven Tool and Die Company of Glendale, Cal if., and Samuel Taylor.

title: N.B.A. Yields to Baseball
description: The National Basketball As sociation announced yesterday that next Tuesday night's game in Oakland between Golden State and the Baltimore Bullets had been rescheduled for Mon day night to avoid a conflict with Tuesday night's World Series game in Oakland.

title: BUS SUBSIDY SET BY CONNECTICUT
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 13  With public bus services in 64 towns in Connecticut either out or on the verge of collapse, the state has offered to make up 25 per cent of the operating losses of any local transit authority.

title: STOCK PRICES OFF ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed lower yester day for the third straight day.

title: Bomb Found at Orly
description: PARIS, Oct. 13 (AP)  A home made bomb was found to day in an ashtray near El Al Airlines' checkin counter at Orly Airport, the police report ed. Police explosive experts said that it could not have exploded without its wick being lighted and even then would have caused only light damage.

title: Psychologist Honored By Flight Safety Group
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP)Dr. John T. Dailey, developer of the behavioral profile credited with helping to forestall airplane hijack ings and extortion attempts, was named today as winner of the 1972 Adm. Luis de Florez Flight Safety award.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: After an absence of one year, Mexico will return the National Horse Show this year, Woody Gatehouse, the national's president, announced yesterday. The show is scheduled for Madison Square Garden, Oct. 31 through Nov. 7.

title: New New Haven Cars Still Around the Bend
description: The longawaited new com muter cars for the New Ha ven division of the Penn Cen tral will not go into service this month as originally scheduled, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority an nounced yesterday.

title: CLINGAN EXPLAINS SNITCH OF PARTY
description: Eldon R. Clingan, Liberal party Councilman at Large from Manhattan and minority leader of the City Council, con firmed yesterday that he had switched to the Democratic party.

title: Senators Honor Jordan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI)I In spite of a rush for adjourn ment, the Senate gave an hour and a half tribute today to Len 13. Jordan, Idaho Republican who is retiring. Mr. Jordan, 73 year's old, has served in the Senate since 1962.

title: KENNEDY ORDERS BUGGING INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 Senator Edward M. Kennedy, as chairman of a Senate judici ary committee, has ordered a preliminary inquiry into the Watergate bugging incident and charges of political espionage and sabotage in the Presidential campaign.

title: REVENUESHARING HEED INADEQUATE
description: The Federal revenuesharing bill, passed yesterday, will mean reductions in new social services planned in poor areas of the city, particularly for children and the elderly, ac cording to top city officials.

title: SENATE RESTRICTS NIXON AUTHORITY TO CUT SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13The Senate passed the spending ceiling bill tonight, after first approving some limitations on the authority that it gives the President to cut Government spending this year to no more than $250billion.

title: U.S., in Shift, Said to Bar 2d Soviet Grain Windfall
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13The Nixon Administration re neged on a tentative maritime agreement with the Soviet Union two weeks ago to prevent Moscow from getting a further windfall out of its large purchases of American grain, a high Administration official said today.

title: U.S. PLANS TO AUDIT MOST SHARE FUNDS
description: A Treasury official said yes terday that the Federal Govern ment would not audit regularly all of the Federal funds to be spent by local governments under the new $30.2billion revenuesharing program.

title: MRS. PAUL PATTERSON
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 13 (AP) Mrs. Elsie Maclean Patterson, widow of Paul Patterson, presi dent of the A. S. Abell Com pany, publishers of the Balti more Sunpapers, died yester day at the age of 83.

title: CITY IS REBUFFED ON OCEAN DUMPING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13In a defeat for New York City and a victory for New Jersey, Con gress enacted strick controls to day on the dumping of garbage and other wastes into the open sea.

title: Domestic Deliveries Increase by 15,000 In 10Day Period
description: DETROIT, Oct. 13Domestic new car sales were at record levels from Oct. 1 to 10, the first full 10day selling period of the 1973 model year.

title: WINE TALK
description: In the best of all possible worlds, no one would need a vintage chart. After all, how can a vintage chart possibly account for the good wines that crop up in every had year? And what about the bad ones that inevitably turn up in the highly rated years?

title: Picture of Negro on Pamphlet Is That of an ExAmbassador
description: The Negro face on the fake Conservative party political fly er sent around the almost all white Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn belongs, it turned out yesterday, to Jerome H. Hol land, former ambassador to Sweden.

title: LEONARD GEROW, RETIRED GENERAL
description: PETERSBURG, Va., Oct. 13 (AP)Gen. Leonard T. Gerow, who commanded the V Corps in the Normandy invasion in World War II died last evening in Kenner Army Hospi tal at nearby Fort Lee. He was 84 years old.

title: COLLEGE ASKS LESS IN DONALDSON SUIT
description: The trustees of Hanover Col lege, a small liberal arts col lege in Hanover, Ind., who, last December sued Donaldson, Luf kin & Jenrette for $3.7million, have dropped most of the charges against the New York brokerage and money manage ment firm.

title: American Can Shows Loss Following Unusual Costs
Tenant Income Data Went To Ireland for Processing
description: Income affidavits filed by 30,000 tenants in MitchellLama, middleincome housing develop ments here were flown to Shan non, Ireland, to be processed for computerization, it was dis closed yesterday.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ELIZABETH, Oct. 13Mayor Thomas G. Dunn, who walked out of a political debate yes terday after charging that his life had been threatened, said today that he had filed charges of harassment against a New York City television reporter and his camera crew.

title: 3-Piece 'Film Portraits' Has Variety
description: The keen edge of the new program at the uptown Film Forum is not so much content but variety. We have here three short movies about a woman and a special dress; the case of a youthful dope addict, and the plight of a community of land squatters threatened with uprooting.I liked the first bestLiane Brandon's "Betty Tells Her Story"for its artless, often touching simplicity. A plump, pleasant-faced woman sits in a chair and tells the camera about an incident of her earlier years, the purchase of a special party dress that somehow got lost.She tells the story twice, the first time with girlish delight. The second time, analyzing her "strange kind of special feeling" at the memory, she wistfully concludes that "it was the first time anybody ever told me I looked beautiful."And the last time, too, would be a safe guess by one viewer. Never mind, dear lady. Your prosaically detailed story, including a nagging repetition of "ya know," is material with which Dorothy Parker could have made a classic short story about the human heart.Martha Coolidge's "David: Off and On" is an impressively trim, probing record of her troubled brother, a youthful dope addict and dropout. Miss Coolidge has used family-album stills, a crisscross interview format with her 21-year-old subject and a prowling camera to suggest his four years in and out of mental institutions.The shanty bohemians of North Vancouver in "Livin' on the Mud" are more interesting as a happy, self-sustained community of independent people. Sean Malone winningly evokes a seedy utopia, threatened and finally destroyed by urban development (bulldozers). One outburst by a fierce, tearful woman is haunting in a sad, subtly candid film documenting the death of a harmless, happy life-style.

title: U.S., in Shift, Said to Bar 2d Soviet Grain Windfall
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13The Nixon Administration re neged on a tentative maritime agreement with the Soviet Union two weeks ago to prevent Moscow from getting a further windfall out of its large purchases of American grain, a high Administration official said today.

title: Sylvania in Japan Venture
description: TOKYO, Oct. 13 (Agence FrancePresse)  A Japan United States joint venture for production in Japan of lighting fixtures has been established between Japan Shin Nippon Denkl and the Sylvania divi sion of GTE International, Inc., a subsidiary of the General Tel ephone and Electronics Corpora tion, according to the Japanese concern, The new corporation, the NEC Sylvania Corporation, will be capitalized at $6.5mil lion and will be equally owned by the two partners.

title: Warning by Allende
description: SANTIAGO, Oct. 13 (Agence FrancePresse)President Allen de warned in his radio speech early today that the trucking strike could bring the country to the brink of civil war.

title: Democratic Loyalty Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) There ain't no such animal as Democrats for Nixon! says Representative Henry B. Gon zalez, Democrat of Texas. Iie bought a $374 advertisement in today's Washington Post to ap peal to Democrats to unite be hind Senator George McGovern. Mr. Gonzalez said Democratis in Bexar County, where he is honorary chairman of the party, are sticking with Mr. McGov ern. We are in the tradition of Sam Rayburn: We are Demo crats without prefix, suffix or apology, he said.

title: Bucks Set Back Suns
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 13 (AP) The Milwaukee Bucks pulled away in the fourth quarter and defeated the Phoenix Suns, 117 105 tonight in the N.B.A. opener for both. Kareen AbdulJabbar scored 40 points to lead the Bucks. Phoenix finished without Coach Bill van Breda Kolff, who was chased after his second technical foul late in the third period.

title: Saigon Recalling Envoys
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Oct. 14 (Reuters) South Vietnam is recalling its ambassadors from Washington, London and Paris for consul tations, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: In 1960 Carlos Castaneda, looking for information on medicinal plants for a stu dent thesis, niet Juan Matus, a Yaqui In dian shaman from Sonora, Mexico. Cas taneda became don Juan's apprentice, an encounter that he reported in two extra ordinary books, The Teachings of Don Juan and A Separate Reality. His new book, Journey to Ixtlan, takes us to 1971 and apparently to the successful comple tion of his apprenticeship.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 13Basketball practice begins at St. Peter's College tomorrow, led by a new coach and surrounded by a controversy threatening to disturb the team.

title: Cambodian Fighting Reported
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 13 (UPI)Fierce fighting was reported today along Route 5, Pnompenh's vital road link to rice  producing areas in the northwestern provinces.

title: PENNSYLVANIA BLAST KILLS 5, INJURES 6
description: DUPONT, Pa., Oct. 13 (UPI) Five men were killed and six injured today when an ex plosion ripped through a dyna mite plant in this northeastern Pennsylvania community.

title: Gabriel Kohn's Sculptures on View
description: The changes that have overtaken the art of sculp ture in the last decade have been so swift and sometimes so drastic that they have often left us wondering if sculpture as a distinct art would survive so many ag gressive challenges to its es thetic integrity. Pulled in one direction by painting, in an other by designers of envi ronments, in still others by the conceptualists and the misplaced pastoralism of the earthworkers, sculpture has tended at times to lose its own momentum. One has had the impression of ener gies being dissipated and ob jectives obscured.

title: Incident in Washington Square Park
description: It is Sunday afternoon in Washington Square Park. My 3yearold son is on my shoulders and my wife is walk ing beside us. As we head into the park, on the path that bisects the in tersection of Waverly Place and Uni versity Place, our attention is drawn to two men who are moving much too quickly.

title: Ballet: Joffrey Premiere
description: A trifle, yet a very fetch ing one, popped up at the City Center Thursday night as the City Center Joffrey Ballet's newest production. Benjamin Harkarvy's Grand Pas Espagnol is a well traveled, enjoyable, pure dance work and it has reached its latest destination in good shape.

title: 7th Annual Mums Festival Colors Quiet Village's Streets and Spirit
description: SAUGERTIES, N. Y., Oct. 13  Mums is the word in Saugerties this week as it celebrates its seventh annual Chrysanthemum Festival.

title: Chinese Medical Unit Visits Bethesda
description: BETHESDA, Md., Oct. 13 Specialists in surgery, chemo therapy and radiation treat ment from the United States and China sat in a 12thfloor lounge here this afternoon and discussed their common war against man's most feared ene mycancer.

title: Foreigners in Philippines Worried by Martial Law
description: MANILA, Oct. 13At the end of the third week of mar tial law, Manilans for the most part appeared to have gotten used to it. Today foreign resi dents began to complain.

title: BOTH SIDES AGREE PROBLEMS REMAIN IN VIETNAM TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 The United States and North Vietnam today agreed in effect that numerous difficult prob lems remained to be settled be fore peace in Vietnam is possi ble.

title: Secretariat Goes for No. 6 Today in the Champagne
description: The young set comes into im portant focus at Belmont. Park this afternoon as an expected 10 colts and two geldings turn out for the 101st running of the Champagne. If the dozen 2yearolds start in the $125, 000 added mile event, the purse will come to $146,500.

title: Danish Group That Resisted Nazis Is Honored Here
description: They were Danes, our friends: it didn't matter if they were Jewish, and it doesn't now, remarked Dr. Joergen John Gersefelt yes terday.

title: Aide Reports Burger Unaware Of Lobbying on Product Safety
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13One of Chief Justice Warren E. Bur ger's top administrative aides declared today that he acted without the Chief Justice's knowledge when he accompa nied a lawyerlobbyist in an effort to persuade Representa tive Carl Albert, the Democrat ic Speaker of the House, to nar row the legal remedies in a pending product safety bill.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City Charter Unit Holds First Session

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I would like to raise a few points in response to the Oct. 7 letter from Dr. Jerome Jaffe and Myles Ambrose.

title: Marathon: Three Great Ladies of American Dance
description: One disadvantage of the City Center American Dance Marathon now at the ANTA Theater is that it is running past all too quickly. Three great ladies of the American dance, Carmen de Lavallade, Pauline Koner and Bella Lewitzky, came together for a program on Thursday night, repeated it last night, and will appear twice more this afternoon and evening, and then it's off into the wide blue yonder, or wherever marathon dancers go when they are not marathoning.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DENVER, Oct. 13 (AP)Genesee Mountain has been eliminated from consideration as a site for special ski jumping in the 1976 Winter Olympics, the Denver Olympic Committee announced today.

title: Pravda Says Summit Gave Nixon an Edge
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 13 (AP) Pravda cast a jaundiced eye today on the tumult of Amer ica's election campaign and said that President Nixon owed much of his popularity to the Moscow summit meet ing in May.

title: MARKET DROPS AS TRADING LAGS
description: The stock market took an other beating yesterday in re sponse to broad and persistent selling pressure in both glamour and bluechip issues.

title: Merger News
description: The BankAmerica Corpora tion, the holding company of the Bank of America, an nounced yesterday afternoon that it had made an offer to acquire GAC Finance, Inc., a subsidiary of the GAC Corpo ration.

title: Music: Bream's Tone
description: That excellent servant of two masters, Julian Bream, brought his lute and guitar to Town Hall on Thursday night for another of his in strumentally divided but mu sically cohesive programs. Mr. Bream attracted a large, mostly young, audience that listened as carefully to a 17thcentury Fantasia by the Netherlands lutenist Gregorio Huwett (or Howett in some reference books) as to a group of Spanish guitar pieces by Turina.

title: Briton Leads Italian Golf
description: COMO, Italy, Oct. 13 (AP) Brian Huggett of Britain shot a threeunderpar 65 today and took a twostroke lead in the Italian open golf championship with a 36hole total of 132.

title: YORKERS MEETING DRAWING TO END
description: YONKERS, Oct. 13Yonkers Raceway will wind up its 23d year of harness racing tomor row night with declines of 19 per cent in average nightly at tendance and 8.9 per cent in mutuel wagering compared with corresponding racing dates of two years ago.

title: Concert: Israeli Works
description: In a worths effort to show that Israeli composers are up to date, Zubin Mehta led off his second concert with the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra in Carnegie Hall On Thursday night with Josef Tal's Sym phony No. 2. It was writtten in 1960 and involves serial ism to a certain degree.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LANSING, Mich., Oct. 13 (UPI)The Secretary of State's office here said on Thursday that a request from Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama to have his photograph removed from the American Independent party ballot in Michigan had come, too late for any action to be taken.

title: Protest Weakens South African Cleric
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Afri ca, Oct. 13 (Reuters)A white Anglican priest who has forced himself to live on only $6.25 a month for six, months is on the point of collapse as he pre pares to end his ordeal tomor row.

title: State Denies 10% Fare Increase For Transport of New Jersey
description: NEWARK, Oct. 13The New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commissioners turned down today a Transport of New Jer sey request for a 10 per cent increase in instate bus fares of 60 cents or more.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) The White House press sec retary, Ronald L. Ziegler, and a Pulitzer prizewinning report er, Clark R. Mollenhoff, en gaged in a tense confrontation today over the accuracy of a quote that Mr. Mollenhoff at tributed to Mr. Ziegler last week.

title: Pygmy Whale Is Beached In Florida Near Jacksonville
description: MARINELAND, Fla., Oct. 13 (UPI)A 500pound pygmy sperm whale was reported in good condition by Marineland officials today after stranding itself on the sand at Atlantic Beach near Jacksonville.

title: Nixon FundSharing Bill Voted by Senate, 59 to 19
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  Congress completed action to day on revenuesharing legisla tion, providing President Nixon with one of the chief domestic legislative proposals of his four years in the White House.

title: Flood Perils Grow as Land Is Covered by Developers
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 13Most of the time, Salt Creek is a lazy little stream that works its muddy way through 14 grow ing suburbs west of Chicago, gurgling happily and bothering no one.

title: Turner Aides Choose Jail
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., Oct. 13 (UPI)Two business associates of Mr. Turner chose to go to jail today rather than testify against the Orlando millionaire at his trial on charges of vio lating securities sales laws.

title: Notes on People
description: Dr. S. L Hayakawa, whose firm handling of campus dis orders in 1968 and 1969 brought him national promi nence, resigned as president of California State University at San Francisco. Dr. Haya kawa became acting head of San Francisco State in 1968 during campus disturbances and the next year became president. He said yesterday he had asked the university to appoint him president emeritus and that he would stay in his present post until a successor has been found possibly for several months.

title: 3 New York Hockey Clubs to Play Today
description: Indicative of the strides hoc I key has made here, New York will present thiee bigleague clubs playing on the same day for the first time in the 68year history of professional hockey.

title: IRVING G. WOLFF
description: Irving G. Wolff, a lawyer in this city for the last 42 years, died yesterday apparently of heart attack, at St. Vincent's Hospital after a brief illness. He was 65 years old and lived at 16 West 16th Street.

title: Rise of 5% in Prices Set By TuftedCarpet Maker
description: Sequoyah Industries, Inc.. a producer of tufted carpets, said yesterday it would increase prices across the board by about 5 per cent.

title: 46 Injured in Racial Clash On a Carrier Off Vietnam
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 13The Pacific Fleet Command an nounced today that 46 persons, both black and white, were in jured in an incident aboard the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk Wednesday off North Vietnam.

title: City Rebuffed as Congress Votes Curbs on Ocean WasteDumping
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13In a defeat for New York City and a victory for New Jersey, Con gress enacted strict controls to day on the dumping of garbage and other wastes into the open sca.

title: Burglars Get Gems Valued at $400,000 In Diamond Center
description: An overnight burglary at a salesroom in the West 47th Street diamond center netted burglars netted more than $400,000 in unset gems, the po lice reported yesterday.

title: Food for the Americas
description: One of the intellectual leaders of the Americas made a valiant effort this week to recall the United States to a revised order of foreign policy priorities, urging as a starting point an expansion of the Green Revolution to feed the hungry of this hemisphere. The plea came from Pedro G. Beltran, former Prime Minister of Peru and publisher of one of the finest newspapers in Latin America from which Peru's military rulers expelled Dr. Beltran as editor and owner earlier this year.

title: Bullets Rout Hawks
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 13 (AP) Stan Love and Phil Chenier sparked a Baltimore scoring streak in the closing minutes of the first half tonight and the Bullets went on to a 11598 victory over the Atlanta Hawks.

title: French Campaigners Focus on PostElection Moves
description: PARIS, Oct. 13French poli ticians are moving the election campaign into full swing. But although the balloting is still six months away, plans are already focusing more on ma neuvers to be made after elec tion day than on winning votes.

title: SHOP TALK
description: About 40 years ago a Southerner named Mary Chess started making floral perfumes and toilet waters that she sold to department stores. The result was that a couple of generations of women grew up on the bot tled scent of tuberoses, helio trope, white lilacs, carna tions and gardenias. Later two floral blends were added: tapestry and yram.

title: U.S. SCORES PLAN FOR TRADE ZONE
description: PARIS, Oct. 13The United States has officially taken ex ception to European Economic Community plans to establish a preferential trading zone with nonmember Mediterra nean countries, diplomatic sources said today.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Oct. 13 (Reuters)The Bank of England today set its new minimum lending rate at 7.25 per cent. The rate is geared to the 91day Treasury bill average rate, which rose to 6.6891 per cent from 6.6676 last week. The new rate replaces the now defunct British bank rate, which was 6 per cent after being posted at that level on June 22 during heavy pressure against sterling in currency markets.

title: Wall St. Paper Bill Passed by House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) A Wall Street paperwork re form bill was approved by the House tonight but appeared doomed in a dispute with the Senate over provisions involv ing banks and the securities industry.

title: State Senator John H. Hughes, Syracuse Republican, 68, Dies
description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 13  State Senator John H. Hughes, the Republican chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Crime and one of the most powerful members of the Legis lature, died here today of a heart attack at the age of 68.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: The environment won't be an issue in 1972, but don't tell that to a factory worker who risks his life and health by simply doing his daily task, or the city dweller who risks his life by breathing or who comes home to find his home threatened by an already redundant expressway.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: DETROITAmericans all want cars and one of the problems is that 75 per cent of us get them. The very popularity of the automobile now seriously threatens its usefulness. In many of our cities we are confronted by pollution, congestion, noise, delay, ugliness and urban breakdown on a scale that has not been seen since the last days of imperial Rome.

title: CHILE TAKES OVER RADIO BROADCASTS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 13 The leftist Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens took control of radio broadcasting today as thou sands of small businessmen and shopkeepers went on strike in defiance of the state of emer gency declared yesterday.

title: Knicks Take On Lakers Tonight
description: Seemingly in midseason form earlier this week as they routed the Seattle SuperSonics by 24 points to open the National Basketball Association season, the Knicks will have an op portunity tonight at Madison Square Garden to measure their talents against more formidable foesthe Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Soviet Team Wins 11th Chess Olympics
description: SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 13The Soviet Union won the Chess Olympics here today, gaining on its close rival, Hun gary, in the final round to fin ish 1 points ahead.

title: First Three Digits Drawn In State's Bonus Lottery
description: ALBANY, Oct. 13 (AP) The number 189 was drawn) today as the first three digits in the New York State lot tery's final bonus drawing be fore the start of a new bonus system.

title: When Children Violate the Law
description: Young people continue to come be fore courts (New York State's Family Court disposed of 24,000 juvenile of fense petitions in the most recent rec ord year, 19701971), and continue to be sent away to confinement in re mote institutions (about 1,400 were in New York's training schools at sum mer's start, 1972).

title: O'Brien Charges Political Espionage
description: Lawrence F. O'Brien, the na tional campaign chairman for the McGovernShriver ticket, accused the Nixon Administra tion yesterday of sanctioning tactics of political espionage that bordered on those of a fascist state.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It is interesting and yet tragic to see how our Government operates just by the example of the politics in volved in the no fault auto insur ance issue.

title: The Quality of Education
description: The Fleischmann Commission on the Quality, Cost and Financing of Elementary and Secondary Education New York State did not have to look far or hard to identify the schools' most conspicuous failure. That failure is personified by a hopeless army of youths who leave school, either at graduation or before, with insufficient mastery of either the basic or vocational skills needed for decent jobs and meaningful careers.

title: POST PLEA HEARD BY U.S. PAY BOARD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 Spokesmen for The New York Post and for 325 commercial printing shops in New York City urged the Pay Board today to reduce wage rates now in force.

title: Antiques: Paris Master
description: The Sonnabend Gallery's exhibition of Art Deco furni ture by the Parisian cabinet maker, EmilJacques Ruhl mann, shows how elegant work of the 1920's can get.

title: Doctors Rule Jackson Out of Series
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 13  Dave Duncan was sitting next to me on the plane and he cried for me. I cried with him. It's nice to be able to share that with somebody.

title: Art: Alexander Calder's Joy in Life
description: Oneman shows by Alex ander Calder appear with the regularity, if not fre quency, of the rising of the sun, and like that phe nomenon they are eternally fresh  predictable, even repetitious, but always some thing to wonder at. The only difference is that with Cal der there are no gray days.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: TOKYO, Oct. 13  American politics have come to the Ginza. Supporters of Senator George McGovern approached Ameri can residents and tourists in front of the McDonald's ham burger stand in Tokyo's main shopping district the other day, seeking to persuade them to vote for the Democratic candi date. They plan to continue the street electioneering for the rest of the month.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Vice President Agnew de clared last night that the fun damental issue in the national campaign was how the candi dates put the American phi losophy to work.

title: Pistons 10091 Victors
description: DETROIT, Oct. 13 (AP)The Detroit Pistons scored 10 straight points over a four minute span early in the second period tonight as they beat the Chicago Bulls, 10091. The Pis tons tied a club mark by yield ing only 34 points in taking an 8point halftime lead.

title: DAVID B. SKLAIRE
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 13David B. Sklaire, a retired certified public account ant and a Ford dealergroup executive, died Tuesday, ap parently of a heart attack, in the Franklin General Hospital, Valley Stream. He was 68 years old and lived at 410 Elm Street.

title: Newspaper Carrier Day
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI)  President Nixon today proclaimed Oct. 14 as National Newspaper Carrier Day in hon or of the youngsters who de liver the nation's newspapers.

title: ULSTER POLICEMAN KILLED BY MISTAKE
description: BELFAST, Oct. 13 (UPI)  British soldiers shot and killed a police detective today as he and an army sergeant drove through a roadblock after a night on the town.

title: PUBLISHER SHIFTS WORK SCHEDULES
description: In an effort to help its 3,000 employes beat the subway rush, hour, the McGrawHill Publish ing Company has followed the advice of the Midtown Task Force on Staggered Hours and has abandoned the traditional 9 A.M.to5 P.M. work day.

title: The Dressy Look Registers at High School
description: They're called gangbust ers at Brandeis High School, where both boys and girls wear them with Fred As taires and at Music and Art they're known as hus tiers.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI)President Nixon will deliver a radio campaign speech Sunday on the Ad ministration's fight against crime.

title: OFFER BY INCHCAPE IS REJECTED BY P.&O.
description: The Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company, the world's largest passenger shipping line, said in London yesterday that it had rejeCted the takeover bid from Inchcape & Company, a British finance and trading concern.

title: Danish Industrialist Strives to Save Crumbling Enterprises
description: COPENHAGEN  One of Scandinavia's most glamor ous researchindustrial com bines, the Topsoe Group, has declared itself on the verge of bankruptcy and is break ing up in a welter of confu sions.

title: Market Place: Amex Delisting Sets Precedent
description: Investors will remember Intercontinental Industries, the American Stock Exchange company whose shares spi raled upward after officials said the company was get ting into modular homes in a big way and planning to acquire Central Foundry.

title: BEN M. POULTEN
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 13 (AP)Ben M. Poulten, assistant director of the Rhode Island Legislative Press Bureau and onetime State House corres pondent for most of the state's daily newspapers, died at the State House yesterday. He was 71 years old.

title: JAMES P. CANNING
description: James P. Canning, fundrais ing manager for the Catholic Charities of Brooklyn and Queens the last six years, died, apparently of a heart attack, yesterday in Brooklyn. He was 56 years old and lived at 2015 Foster Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: MRS. W. A. DAVIDSON
description: Mrs. Sylvia Hershman David son, wife of Cantor Walter A. Davidson of Temple Beth Email of Flatbush, died yesterday in Maimonides Hospital, Brooklyn. She was 62 years old and lived at Ill East 21st Street, Brook lyn,

title: Herman A. Affel, Executive at Bell Laboratories, Dies
description: WATERVILLE, Me., Oct. 13 Herman A. Affel, retired as sistant vice president for switching and transmission de velopment at the Bell Labora tories, died yesterday in Thay er Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: Blazers, on Thin Ice, Put Off Home Opener
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 (AP)  The World Hockey Association game between the New England Whalers and the Philadelphia Blazers was postponed tonight after the ice was deemed unsafe.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WENTWORTH, England, Oct. 13 (AP)Lee Trevino foiled an incredible comback by Tony Jacklin today by carding a birdie on the final hole for a 1up victory. The triumph moved him into the final of the Piccadilly world match play golf tournament.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 13  The number of Puerto Rican stu densts attencing ?? in New Jersey has more than tripled in the past tour years.

title: Somers Horse Show Today
description: SOMERS, N. Y., Oct. 13 Primrose Farms will hold the second of its fallwinter horse show series tomorrow with 22 classes scheduled in four divi sions.

title: BURST BY CELTICS SUBDUES LAKERS
description: BOSTON, Oct. 13 (AP)A sevenminute scoring burst led by John Havlicek and Don Nelson in the second period helped the Boston Celtics de feat the Los Angeles Lakers, 112104, in a National Basket ball Association game tonight.

title: MRS. KING GAINS IN $10,000 TENNIS
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Oct. 13. (UPI)Topseeded Mrs. Billie Jean King and Chris Evert easily eliminated their oppo nents to set up a semifinal match between the two tomor row in the $100,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament.

title: Canadian Exchanges Elect
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 13 (Canad ian Press)  Michel Belanger, 43yearold economist with the Quebec Treasury Board, today was named president of the Montreal and Canadian Stock Exchange. He will be the first FrenchCanadian to hold the position. Mr. Belanger will take over Jan 1, filling the post left vacant with the retirement of Charles B. Neapole last June.

title: RALPH D. WHITMORE, A FILM ENGINEER, 84
description: Ralph Delano Whitmore, an engineer with the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation from 1929 to 1960, died yester day in Presbyterian Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 116 Pinehurst Avenue.

title: G.M. and Union Set Talks on Weekend In Walkout in Ohio
description: DETROIT, Oct. 13  The United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Cor poration said today that they would bargain over the week end in an effort to end the strike, at a key partsmaking plant at Mansfield, Ohio, that began this morning at one minute after midnight.

title: House Race
description: LAKE SUCCESS. L. I., Oct. 13Eight years ago, Lester L. Wolff, a 45yearold liberal Democrat, was swept into the House of Representatives in the Lyndon B. Johnson flood tide from a district that had always been Republican.

title: Prisoners in Capital Jail Hold 2d Protest of Week
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI)Seventyseven prisoners barricaded themselves for three and onehalf hours today in a dormitory at the District of Columbia jail, where about 50 inmates seized 12 hostages in 22hour rebellion tow days ago.

title: IRVING KOTZEN
description: Irving Kotzen, a real estate broker in this cit for many years, died yesterday in a nur sing home in Cedar Grove, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived at 309 East Mosholu Parkway North, the Bronx.

title: Aide Reports Burger Unaware Of Lobbying on Product Safety
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13One of Chief Justice Warren E. Bur ger's top administrative aides declared today that he acted without the Chief Justice's knowledge when he accompa nied a lawyerlobbyist in an effort to persuade Representa tive Carl Albert, the Democrat ic Speaker of the House, to nar row the legal remedies in a pending product safety bill.

title: 76ers Lose 3d in Row
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 (AP) The Buffalo Braves broke an 86.86 tie with an 8point streak early in the fourth quarter to night and downed Phiadelphia, 104101, for the 76ers third straight loss.

title: 2% Gain Is Largest Rise Since March Inventories Jump
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  Strong gains in sales and inven tories of manufacturing and trading concerns occurred in August, the Commerce Depart ment reported today.

title: Times Promotes NewsStaff Aide
description: The appointment of Peter Millones as assistant manag ing editor for administration was announced yesterday by A. M. Rosenthal, managing editor of The New York Times.

title: Narcotics Agent in Serious Condition
description: A Federal narcotics agent who was shot in a gun battle that resulted Thursday night in the deaths of another agent and two suspected narcotics deal ers was reported in serious con dition yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital.

title: Penn State Bars Queen
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Oct. 13 (UPI)Penn State has canceled the traditional selec tion of a queen for its annual homecoming celebration this year after several campus groups labeled the practice sexist land derogatory.

title: Rockets Edge Cavaliers
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 13 (UPI) A pair of foul shots by Jimmy Walker with 2:04 to play gave Houston a 10point lead tonight and the Rockets hung on for a 109108 victory over Cleveland despite a 40point effort by the Cavaliers's Austin Carr, his pro high.

title: Jets Win Before 7,892
description: ST. PAUL, Oct. 13 (AP)  Duke Asmundson shoveled in a rebound with 1:29 to play to night as the Winnipeg Jets ral lied to defeat the Minnesota Fighting Saints, 43, in the World Hockey Association.

title: VASILY S. PUSTOVOYT, A FOOD SCIENTIST
description: MOSCOW. Oct. 13 (AP) Vasily S. Pustovoyt, agricul tural scientist, who developed the sunflower as a major oil crop in the Soviet Union, has died at the age of 86, Tass an nounced today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Production Is Lower
description: DETROIT, Oct. 13 (AP) United States auto production eased a bit this week, though the industry once again sched uled output of more than 200, 000 cars, Automotive News reported yesterday.

title: Equity Financing
description: St. Paul Securities, a closedend bond fund spon sored by the St. Paul Companies, said yesterday its initial public offering of 9,302,000 common shares at $15 a share, had been sold. The shares, aggregating $139.5million, were sold through an underwriting group managed by Smith Barney, Walston & Co., and Dain Kalman & Quail Inc.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  United States District Judge Joseph C. Waddy today set a trial date of Oct. 31 for a suit by Common Cause, the citi zens' lobby, to force dis closure of the names of those who contributed more than $10 million to President Nixon's re election campaign.

title: Hijack Fiasco
description: Among the more conspicuous failures of an exception ally irresponsible Congress must be listed the demise of a bill designed to strengthen this country's defenses against aerial hijacking at home and abroad. As in so many other cases of pigeonholed or contorted legisla tion, a sizable share of the blame lies with the Admin istration, which refuses to practice at home what it preaches abroad about the need for determined action to control hijacking and other forms of terror.

title: NORDIQUES SCORE OVER OILERS, 60
description: QUEBEC CITY, Oct. 13 (UPI) J. C. Tremblay, former de fenseman with the Montreal Canadiens of the National Hockey League, scored a goal and Serge Aubray provided shutout goaltending tonight as the Quebec Nordiques beat the Alberta Oilers, 60, in a World Hockey Association game.

title: CHILE TAKES OVER RADIO BROADCASTS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 13 The leftist Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens took control of radio broadcasting today as thou sands of small businessmen and shopkeepers went on strike in defiance of the state of emer gency declared yesterday.

title: Hanoi Reports Hitting Ships
description: HONG KONG, Saturday, Oct. 14 (Reuters)The North Viet namese press agency reported today that two American war ships were shelled and set ablaze Thursday night by North Vietnamese shore batteries lo cated in Thanhhoa Province.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI)The Federal National Mortgage Association said today that it would demand higher yields when it began buying conventional mort gages with loantovalue ratios of more than 90 per cent.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 13At the end of its sixmonth investiga tion into allegations of corrup tion in the Newark Housing Authority, a special Essex County grand jury today hand ed up a presentment criticizing nine public officials.

title: Rain Yields to Pain in 2d Day Of Diamond's Tour de State
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 13 Rain on the first day and cold weather on the second made the start of a 533mile crossstate bicycle trip to promote an environmental bond issue more of an ordeal than an excursion for Henry L. Diamond, the state's Com missioner of Environmental Conservation.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LONDON, Oct. 13  Along Shaftesbury Avenue, American youths hand out campaign bro chures and wear buttons read ing J'Aime McGovern. In Belgravia drawing rooms, sup porters of President Nixon are making plans for fundraising auctions and private parties for visiting White House officials. At Heathrow Airport, tourists are given stickers bearing the phrase McGovern's in My Bag.

title: WILLIAM CHAMBERLAIN
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 13 (UPI)William H. Chamberlain, former Illinois Secretary of State, died last night at the age of 41. He underwent lung sur gery four months ago and had been hospitalized intermittently since June 1.

title: The 16th Lord of the Manor Runs L. I. Fish Market
description: GREENPORT, L. I.  To most village residents, Rod Pell has always been the genial, whitehaired proprietor of a wharfside fish market not far from the bustling downtown dock. What few realize is that this 62yearold Greenport native is not merely the neighborhood fishmongerin some circles he is known only as Mr. William Rodman Pell 2d 16th Lord of the Manor, the titular head of one of America's oldest and most prestigious families.

title: The untrustworthy Highway Fund
description: After years of skirmishing, border raids and local guerrilla actions, the great highway struggle has broken out in open warfare. At issue is the fate of the Highway Trust Fund, which grows by more than $5billion a year, pumps money into the states to build more roads for more automobiles and has had more to do with determining the physical character and social style of America's cities and suburbs than any other Government program.

title: Unbeaten Air Force Sets Back Boston College, 13 to 9
description: NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 14 Dave Lawson, a freshman, kicked field goals of 26 and 20 yards today and Greg Smith caught a 10yard scoring pass from Rich Haynie to lead undefeated Air Force to its fifth straight victory of the season. The Falcons defeated Boston College, 139, before a crowd of 22,313 in Alumni Field.

title: A's Defeat Reds, 3 to 2, in the World Series Opener
description: Two home runs by Gene Tenace and solid relief pitching by Vida Blue enabled the Oakland A's to beat the Cincinnati Reds, 32, yesterday in the opening game of the World Series.

title: Cahill Proposes Using $40Million in RevenueSharing Funds for School Aid
description: TRENTON, Oct. 14  Gov. William T. Cahill announced today that he would ask the Legislature next month to approve $40million of New Jersey's share of the new Federal revenuesharing funds as additional aid to local public schools.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE RATE of the dollar to the yen tell sharply in Tokyo last week in anticipation of a further revaluation of the yen. Spot dollars sold at lowest possible legal rate of 301.1 yen, but future dollars hit a record low rate of 284.30 yen.  Paris reported an influx of dollars into Japan at the rate of $50million a day, or more than $1billion a month.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Roger Starr concluded his analysis of the MitchellLama housing program [Housing Hopes Dealt a Blow, Oct. 1] with a call for pioneering legislation to supplement the indirect MitchellLama subsidies. Finally, he said, without true political courage in the execution of the program, the legislative imagination will be useless.

title: Music
description: SO FAR, the Romantic Revivaland there really is something of a Romantic Revivalhas managed to avoid the violin literature. Charles Treger is going to take care of that. The Atnerican violinist is giving three Town Hall concerts, starting Tuesday (the other two will take place on Nov. 21 and Dec. 5, also Tuesdays), named A romantic Revival for the Violin. A series of this kind has long been overdue. There have, been violinists in recent yearsRuggiero Ricci, for oneWho have given concerts with rarelyplayed romantic music on the programs. But Treger is the first to give a series surveying the field.

title: Criminals At Large
description: In Harry Harrison's MONTEZUMA'S REVENGE (Doubleday, $4.95) occurs one of the great lines. The hero, a secret agent recruited by the F.B.I., is enjoying an Italian meal in a restaurant in Acapulco. Suddenly he finds his head lying on the table. They've  they've drugged the spaghetti! With this one nice stroke, Harrison puts into perspective the absurdity of so many spy stories.

title: TopRanked U.S.C. Routs California
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14 (AP) Mike Rae ran for two touchdowns and Sam Cunningham plunged for two more as topranked Southern California romped over California, 4214, today in a Pacific8 Conference game.

title: movies
description: WITH a dull sense of terror that gnaws at the gut like a spreading cancer, we investigate the means of warding off the depredations of our fellow maninstall complicated locks on our city doors, buy ferocious dogs to Protect us in the country, carry chemicalspray fountain pens to blind muggers, learn karate, practice marksmanship, secrete gunsand in the process, quite forget that Man at his best is God's Most transcendent miracle.

title: 100 in Jersey Jail Are Foiled in Revolt
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Oct. 14 The police and sheriff's deputies with nightsticks and police dogs forced 100 rebellious inmates back into their cells at the Burlington County Jail here early today after the prisoners had seized a cellblock and a guard as hostage.

title: Four novels: dewinding competing, indulging and breaking free
description: She thought of her sisters, of other women, of herself, greeting each other in restaurants. That quick penetrating glance. Searching each other's faces for tiny signs that the other has aged just a little since the last time, that something enviable had begun to desert them. It never mattered whether you found what you were looking for, or failed to find it; you looked away with disappointment,either way.

title: ACTRESS CAMPAIGNS FOR McGOVERN HERE
description: Shirley MacLaine campaigned for Senator George McGovern throughout the city yesterday, hitting hard at the Nixon, Administration on the issue of dishonesty and corruption in government.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Toynbee on the generation gap, the purpose of life, the contrast between ideas and reality. He was asked a series of questions by a Japanese professor, who had been reflecting on the concerns of Japanese youth. The answers, which appeared in the Japanese press, are now revised for book publication. This is not new Toynbee, but he speaks clearly, sincerely, eruditely and with occasional wisdom.

title: Trans 18': A Proposal to Reclaim a NeonandAsphalt Mess
description: EAST BRUNSWICK  The Independent Coalition running for Township Council here disclosed plans last week to recycle ail overdeveloped, traffic jammed Route 18 intoa futuristic city center.

title: Candidate Sargent Shriver is
description: In my first glimpse of him, he was milking a cow somewhere in upstate New York. By such means do politicians make the network news. It was impossible to tell from the tube whether the suit was by Cardin and the shoes by Gucci, but one of the few things we all know about Sargent Shriver who dresses him. If you're going to milk cows in New York, there is a lot to be said for dressing properly for the job. Sarge and the cow stuck in my mind, for I knew the man only by his stereotype, which was Yaleman and sportsman, Kennedy clansman by marriage, energetic dogooder and everybody's favorite lightweight. The name Sargent by itself suggests noncommissioned rank in the Kennedy officer corps.

title: McBryde of Manhattan Sets Mark in Rider Track Meet
description: TRENTON, Oct. 14Ken McBryde, a Manhattan College, freshman and former New York State athlete of the year, set a Rider College Stadium record, today as the Mount Vernon athlete triple jumped 51 feet 2 inches to win that event in the Rider College allcomers invitation.

title: Items at Most Airports Overpriced at Least 10%
description: Air travelers are charged at least 10 per cent more  and often much more than that for just about every commodity that they buy at most of the nation's major jetports.

title: L.I.'s Liberated Women
description: Long Island's women liberationists are older and wiser.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: The court action against U.S. Steel requiring installation of pollution control devices in its Pennsylvania plants (U.S. Steel Forced Into Vast Antipollution Program, Aug. 27) will undoubtedly result in cleaner air and water in the Pittsburgh area but will generate other problems resulting from the expenses imposed on those steelmaking operations.

title: Local
description: Jimmy Shannon threw for two touchdown passes, both to his favorite target, Anthony Percia, and New Utrecht went on to defeat Lincoln, 280, yesterday in a Brooklyn P.S.A.L. game at Lincoln Field. It was the second victory in four games for the Utes and Lincoln's third defeat in four contest's.

title: About Motor Sports
description: It was a case of too many chiefs and so George Bignotti, the most successful chief mechanic in United States Auto Club racing, has parted company with the Vel'sParnelli Jones racing team after an association of three years. All the principals say there were no hard feelings, but that things just did not work out for the man they once called, the heart of our whole organization and the key to our team.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The current Presidential campaign is said to afford the citizenvoter an unusually clear and distinct choice among political alternatives. That does. But little is said about the philosophies that underlie these alternatives.

title: WEISKOPF UPSETS TREVINO, 4 AND 3
description: WENTWORTH, England, Oct. 14 (AP)  Tom Weiskopf destroyed an uncharacteristically quiet, worried Lee Trevino, 4 and 3, in the final today of the Piccadilly world match play championship.

title: Horse Show News
description: The same United States Equestrian Team that won the silver medal in the Olympic Games in Munich last summer will appear at the National Horse show Oct. 31 through Nov. 7 in Madison Square Garden.

title: DONALD F. MORAN
description: EAST MEADOW, L.I., Oct. 14  Donald F. Moran, foreman mailer for The New York Times, died Thursday in the Nassau County Medical Center after a stroke. He was 45 years old and lived at 97 Lee Avenue, Hicksville.

title: After we get out, will there be
description: What would happen if the United States cut off all the guns, bullets and bombs the Thieu regime needs to survive? George McGovern, who promises to do just that if given the chance, has a scenario.

title: TRINI LOPEZ IS BACK WITH SONGS, GUITAR
description: Trini Lopez, whose recording of If I Had a Hammer made him the darling of the discotheques 10 years ago, is back in town for, the first time in two years and making his first appearance at the Copacabana.

title: Maple Leafs Win From Kings, 64; Ellis Scores 200th
description: TORONTO, Oct. 14 (UPI)Right wing Rick Kehoe registered a pair of goals and Ron Ellis scored the 200th goal of his National Hockey League career tonight to lead the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 64 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Music: Krupa's Drums
description: Between Gene Krupa's current selfdecreed allotment of only four or five, onenight engagements a month (the aftermath of a heart attack in 1960) and the general lack of possibilities for such engagements in midtown Manhattan, the celebrated swingera drummer has not been seen in a midcity club for a couple of years.

title: Sugar Fortified With Vitamin A Called Boon to Health by Latins
description: GUATEMALA  Central American technicians have developed a method of fortifying sugar with Vitamin A. The process is being hailed here as a major accomplishment in improving the health of the people in an area where malnutrition is still a problem.

title: Miss Nina Hirschfeld Engaged To Michael J. Russell of Dallas
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert Hirschfeld of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nina Hirschfeld, to Michael James Russell of Dallas. He is a son of Maj. Roy J. Russell, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Russell of Austin, Tex.

title: 2,000 MARCH HERE IN WAR PROTEST
description: Nearly 2,000 participants in a daylong People's Fair to End the War in Indochina walked up Madison Avenue yesterday led by the Van Troi AntiImperialistic Brigadea contingent of more than 50 Asian youths wearing red headbands.

title: Chattanooga, Once Sootiest City, Attains Clean Air
description: CHATTANOOGA, Oct. 14Six years ago, motel operators here were accustomed to complaints from travelers that fallout from the city's corrosive murk was peeling paint off their cars overnight. Chattanooga was ranked by Federal officials as the nation's sootiest city.

title: Campaign Financing Is a Budding Issue in Europe
description: BONN, Oct. 12  Campaign financing is a budding issuefor a variety of reasonsin the four West European countries facing national elections in the coming months.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: I am sure that Mr. Page, as quoted in Paul Good's article, Not gun nuts, but pistol enthusiasts (Sept. 17) meant only praise for 14 Jewish lawyers who alone, if anybody could, might be able to extricate innocent lawbreakers from the clutches of varied and ambiguous state firearms laws.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Can we trust Senator McGovern as President? Several tacit assumptions of many people is that Senator McGovern is not a trustworthy man because he has changed his values at various times, and we trust a man only when we know what his values are.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe filibuster in the Senate had been droning on for days when the wiry, balding Senator in the first row stood up last week to speak. If there is any issue that demands legislation, it is this, the Senator declared, and he proceeded to criticize the Senate for letting a small band of willful men thwart the clear desire of the majority.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO END TRAIN CROSSINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 The sound of the train whistle will virtually fade from the main railroad line between Boston and Washington in the next five years as the Federal Government spends $30million to eliminate grade crossings in the Northeast corridor.

title: Organic Farming in Pembertonl
description: PEMBERTON TOWNSHIP Jutting out from roadside pines bounding an almost hidden gravel driveway, are two handpainted wooden signs reading simply, Organic Farm.

title: Giants Hope for Upset of 49ers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14 This is the game the New York Giants hope they can steal, their first meeting in four years with the San Francisco 49er's, and their first visit here since 1960. The game at Candlestick Park tomorrow will be televised home at 4 P.M. New York time on Channel 2.

title: Fred Grimes Sr. Is Dead; Distributed 100Foot Ads
description: HILLSBORO, Tex., Oct. 14 (UPI)Fred Grimes Sr., who spread his name from coast to coast and in several foreign countries in the 1940's and 1950's with signs up to 100 feet long advertising his service station, died today. He was in his 80's.

title: Preps
description: TABOR, Mass., Oct. 14Cliff Whalen, the tailback, gained 221 yards in 34 carries today as Tabor Academy defeated Choate School, 216. It was the third straight victory for Tabor and the third successive loss for Choate. John Lenane scored

title: U.S. Concern and Soviet Sign Ship Container Pact
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 14  Container Transport International, Inc., has just signed a multimillion dollar contract to lease 1,500 containers to SovFracht, the Soviet organization for chartering sea tonnage, for use in the Soviet Pacific merchant fleet.

title: Fight Is Brewing Over Cut In T axes For. Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Oct 14Federal revenue sharing will probably lead to tax cuts in Connecticut, but not without political row over what kind of cuts they should be and who should get credit for them.

title: Local
description: Bayside, runnerup last year in the P.S.A.L. to Thomas Jefferson, appears to have lost its running power. The Commodores, playing at their home field yesterday, continued to falter as Port Richmond triumphed, 86.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Sigismond Stojowski once observed of Schubert's music, He dates to be simple because there is no vulgarity in him. This phrase comes back to me now as one eminently suitable for describing the art and life of Robert Casadesus, master pianist and composer, whose death the world of music now profoundly mourns. Having had the privilege of being closely associated with him over many years, I find his passing brings a particular feeling of emptiness, for he was that increasingly rare musical phenomenona man who quite simply lived in his music.

title: Cultural Merger Produces Culture
description: It was plainly where I belonged; where I was meant to be. Through the huge windows in this highceilinged room in a 75room mansion I could see the bright Sunday afternoon sun blazing down on a welltended expansive lawn.

title: A Center Gives Help To Wornen In Bergen
description: HACKENSACK The Women's Center of Bergen County was founded early this year to meet the needs of women, to inform them of their rights  and to be a gathering place and focal point for the women of Bergen County.

title: Plot Against Life Of Johnny Carson Charged to Three
description: VAN NUYS, Calif., Oct. 14 (UPI)The police arrested three persons last night in an alleged extortion plot that threatened the life of Johnny Carson, his wife and his family.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  No more than a dozen men here and in Hanoi know how far they may be from a deal to end the war in Vietnam  if, indeed, the negotiators and their superiors now know. After one of the more dramatic weeks of both diplomatic and political maneuver, the rest of us can only venture some educated guesses from the snippets of comment and evidence.

title: BUCKNELL TOPPLED BY LEHIGH, 21 TO 0
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 14Lehigh knocked Bucknell from the unbeaten football ranks today before a crowd of 14,000 with a 210 triumph.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Eli Goldston once identified himself as a kosher dill pickle at a Yankee pot roast. He had just been introduced by Henry Cabot Lodge as chairman of the United Fund of Boston, post previously held by Charles Francis Adams of the Raytheon Company.

title: Photography
description: A COMBINATION regular 8mm and Super 8 movie projector that allows the user to project films in either forward or reverse at normal speed (18 frames per second), in slow motion (6 frames per second) or in still motion has just recently been introduced by Bell and Howell, 7235 N. Linder Ave., Skokie, Ill. 60076: The projector also permits step motion of as slow as two frames per second, and it is possible to turn the takeup reel by hand to move individual frames past the lens as slow or as fast as desired. In addition there is a high speed rewind that can be instantly activated at the end of a reel or at any point in the middle of a reel.

title: Wendy Eberhardt Wed
description: HICKSVILLE, L. I., Oct. 7  The marriage of Miss Wendy Lynn Eberhardt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Eberhardt, to Daniel Paul Mc Groarty, son of Mrs. John Mc Groarty of Baldwin and the late Mr. Mc Mc Groarty, took place here at noon today in the Parkway Community Church. The Rev. Douglas MacDonald performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Don Cornelius. The couple are on the faculty of Lutheran High School in Brookville.

title: Correction Panel Urges Replacement of Prison Chaplaincy System
description: A task force appointed by the city's Board of Correction has called for abolishing the chaplaincy system in city prisons and replacing it with system it feeis would make more effective use of clergymen and laymen from local churches and synagogues.

title: Glomming The Apple: A Howto Story
description: YOU'RE young and your money's tight and you're determined to dig the Monster Metropolis anyway, if only for a few full days. You don't want to get hung up in the perennial pursuits of The City (dollars and decadence, power and perversity, excellence or eccentricity, applause or anonymity). You only want to Check It Out.

title: $72Million Plan Is Proposed to Redevelop Elmira
description: A $72million plan for the redevelopment of the city of Elmira, which was devastated last summer by the tropical storm Agnes, was proposed yesterday by the State Urban Development Corporation.

title: The Stepford Wives
description: Strange things are happening in Stepford, an uppermiddleincome suburban community. The distaff side of the young married set is becoming pathologically homeoriented, rejecting evenings of consciousnessraising in favor of giving another coat of wax to the kitchen floor. Even the two most nonconformist of Stepfordiennes undergo  gulp!drastic transformations a few months after settling in. Meanwhile, Stepford husbands are up to Heaven knows what at the Men's Association, where lights burn late every night. One of the Association's moving spirits (to drop a single clue) is Diz Coba: his nickname is based on he fact that he was the genius behind the creation of those nearhuman figures in Disneyland.

title: An End Is Sought To State Secrecy
description: TRENTON  State officials said this weekend that a comprehensive review of New Jersey's laws and regulations governing the secrecy of government. documents may lead to legislative recommendations aimed at opening the state administration to greater public scrutiny.

title: Poor Health Limits Johnson's Aid to McGovern
description: JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Oct. 14Former President Lyndon B. Johnson, slowed by his April heart attack, is taking a quiet role in the Presidential campaign.

title: MorrisSomerset
description: Bound Brook's 165  pound running back, Sam Jones, scored two touchdowns, gaining 159 yards in 17 carries, to pace his team to a 2012 victory over previously unbeaten Middlesex for its 13th consecutive victory in Bound Brook.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Money in Politics
description: For the first time in many Presidential campaigns, money has become a sizable political issue. Its importance this year is due (in about equal parts) to the enactment of the new law requiring full disclosure of campaign receipts and expenditures, and to the greed and cynicism of the Nixon Administration's political operations. If it were not for the law, the press and the public would not have gained so clear or so early an insight into the activities of the President's campaign organization. If it were not for the character of the Administration's politics, that insight would not be so devastating.

title: Local
description: Madison won its fourth straight game yesterday, defeating Midwood, 2514, at Madison. The triumph gave Madison its best start since the 1955 season. That year, Madison lost three and tied one in its last four games, but, this year, the Golden Tornadoes are strong contenders for the Public Schools Athletic League Brooklyn Division I title.

title: Donald Dupuy Weds Florence Ann Nelson
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14 Miss Florence Ann Nelson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. O. Taft Nelson of Sands Point, L. I. was married here this afternoon in the Calvary Presbyterian Church to Donald Dean Dupuy of Redondo Beach. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Robert M. Young.

title: Hennings's Three Touchdown Runs Lead Yale to a 53to19 Rout of Brown
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 14Yale scored 25 points and Brown none in the first period of their Ivy League game here today. Was the final score going to be 1000? Not quite. It wound up 5:319 for the Elis and might have been even more decisive but for the fine performance of Pete Beatrice, Brown's sophomore quarterback.

title: STANFORD STOPS WASHINGTON, 240
description: STANFORD, Calif., Oct. 14 (UPI)  Mike Boryla completed; 24 passes to lead Stanford to 240 victory over previously unbeaten Washington today in the Pacific8 Conference.

title: Music Hall Shows Resume As Negotiations Continue
description: The Radio City Music Hall reopened at 10:30 A.M. yesterday, and 650 people turned up for its first show since the 6,200seat theater closed after the last Wednesday night show for the first time in 40 years, because of a contract dispute with its musicians.

title: Except for a famous bugging
description: WASHINGTON: On the sixth floor, police caught five clumsy conspirators, reputedly linked with the Republican party, trying to bug Democratic National Committee headquarters. On the seventh floor, Martha Mitchell raised hell by telephone. On the 14th, thieves burglarized the penthouse owned by Rose Mary Woods, President Nixon's private secretary. And in United States District Court, a group of apartment dwellersclaiming to speak for some halfdozen members of Congress, several Cabinet officers, the directors of the Voice of America, the Agency for International Development and the United States Mint, at least one ambassador and the president of the National Academy of Sciences  filed suit. They alleged that their luxury housing in the same building, the most expensive in town, was afflicted with faulty kitchen appliances, cranky airconditioning, temperamental plumbing and a plethora of damp flaws in walls, windows and ceilings. In short, the sound and fury emanating from the site of all these goingson has often involved prominent or powerful personalities, has usually been highly audible, and has frequently received attention in the press.

title: Sewer Plan In Nassau Is Likely to Be Shelved
description: MANHASSET, L. I.  The Nassau County Board of Supervisors is expected to shelve a sanitary sewer project tomorrow that has been fought by hundreds of angry residents of this North Shore area in two stormy public hearings.

title: Clinics Aid Disturbed In 2 Cities At Low Cost
description: PASSAIC  Dome light flashing, the police ambulance squeals to a stop in front of a rundown apartment house in a downtown section of the city.

title: Blood Bank Is in 25th Year
description: EAST ORANGE  A baby is born prematurely; a 4yearold is critically injured in a car crash; a college student bleeds internally as the result of a motorcycle accident; a 70yearold is hospitalized with pernicious anemia.

title: Flames and Sabres Tie. 11
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 14 (UPI)The Atlanta Flames capitalized on fine defensive work by the goalie, Phil Nlyre, tonight to battle the unbeaten Buffalo Sabres to a 11 tie in the first National Hockey League game played in the South.

title: Ontario Town Mounts Exhibition As Tribute to Bertrand Russell
description: HAMILTON, Ontario, Oct. 14  About 300 Friends of Bertrand Russell, from several countries including the United States, have gathered here this weekend for a round of reminiscence and discussion honoring the late radical British philosopher on the centenary of his birth.

title: Bruins Top Islanders, 74, for First Victory
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 14For a precious few seconds tonight the expansionist Islanders led the Boston Bruins. And then, as Bill Torrey, the general manager, was to describe it, The kids realized where they were and who they were beating.

title: Education
description: LONDONSchool busing  distraught parents  disgruntled teachers  boycotting students. The London school system, with more than 165,000 secondary students aged 11 to 17, is torn these days by these same issues and problems that afflict education in New York and many other cities in the United States.

title: CENTROWITZ BEST IN ST. JOHN'S RUN
description: Matt Centrowitz remained unbeaten in scholastic crosscountry yesterday with a sluggish victory in the St. John's University run al Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

title: FATAL JET FACED USE AS MONUMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP),  The F86 Sabre jet what killed 22 persons when it crashed into a Sacramento ice cream parlor had been stripped down and sold to be used as a monument in Canada.

title: The Great Bridge
description: Bells rang, whistles blew, cannon boomed, a calliope shrieked out America, and orators praised and pointed. It was May 24, 1883, the most important day of public ceremony in New York since the opening of the Erie Canal, for it marked the completion of the magnificent East River Bridge, widely regarded then and now as the most beautiful suspension bridge in the world. The occasion was a jour ferie for all New York and Brooklyn. There were only a few dissentersthe builder, who deplored all the fuss; the militant Irish, who objected because the celebration was held on Queen Victoria's birthday, and the first rustic visitor to be conned into buying the bridge.

title: Jerome Gratry, Banker, Weds Barbara Bolton
description: KIRTLAND HILLS, Ohio, Oct. 14Miss Barbara Bolton was married here this afternoon to Jerome Rene Gratry, son of Baroness Gerard de Thoisy of Paris and Charles P. Gratry of Geneva. The Rev. James Johnston performed the Episcopal ceremony in St. Hubert's Chapel.

title: Freak Show Curb Voided
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 14 (UPI)The Florida Supreme Court has struck down a 1921 law against freak shows, saying the state has no business telling anyone that they cannot earn an honest living.

title: The Nation
description: LOS ANGELESThe registration books closed across the nation last week, and as the final total started to drift in, it appeared that the McGovern forces had done wellbut not well enough to overturn the basic assumptions underlying the Presidential election, now less than a month away.

title: Susan Fiske Is Bride
description: DORSET, VT., Oct. 14The marriage of Miss Susan Barker Fiske to John Anthony Leal took place here this afternoon in the United Church of Dorset. The Rev. Hal C. Miller 3rd performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Farrimond Fiske of East Dorset. Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Leal of Norwich, N. Y., are the bridegroom's parents.

title: King Coal's Comeback Bid
description: BARRACKVILLE, W. Va.Deep in the hilly coal country of West Virginia, Andy Morris laments his industry's problems as he drives a visitor through the early morning mist to a cluster of underground mines.

title: New York
description: Some may think of it as social work, Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said last week. I think of it as police work of the best kind and highest quality. The Police Department, hardly renowned as the addict's friend, announced last week an experimental program designed to encourage drug users to seek treatment before they begin to steal. Some of the key elements in the project:

title: Gael E. Kenedy, John W. Greene Marry in Chapel
description: Miss Gael Elizabeth Kenedy, a greatgranddaughter of P. J. Kenedy, foundtr of P. J. Kenedy & Sons, publishers of the Official Catholic Directory, was married here yesterday afternon to John Winand Greene. The bride's cousin, the Rev. Eugene Kenedy Culhane, performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the chapel of St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church.

title: Sloop of War
description: It's our old shipmate Richard Bolitho once again, sailing wooden ship with a crew of 115 iron men. This time he's in command of his very first vessel, the 18gun sloop Sparrow. What may dim the appreciation of Bolitho's prowess is that he is exercising it against usi.e., the American revolutionariesuntil Cornwallis throws in the sponge.

title: 61 STOP THE MUSIC TAKES CHAMPAGNE
description: For the second time in three years, a disqualification turned champagne into vinegar for a great 2yearold in the $146,500 Champagne Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: 3 MEN ARE KILLED IN ULSTER VIOLENCE
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 14 (Reuters)Two men were killed and three others were wounded in three shootings in Belfast tonight.

title: Census Publication Is Third in a Series
description: The new Census Bureau publication on which parts of this report are based is General Social and Economic Characteristics: United States Summary, 1970 Census of Population. It is available for $2.25 from the Government Printing Office, Washington, D. C., 20402, or from Department of Commerce field offices, such as the one at 26 Federal Plaza in Manhattan. It is a companion volume to two earlier, less comprehensive United States Summaries, Number of Inhabitants and General Population Characteristics. A fourth volume in the series, Detailed Characteristics, is in preparation.

title: Views of Review
