description: TO THE EDITOR: Your account in The Week in Review, Oct. 8, of the meeting of the American Council of Education probably afforded some amusement to the thousands of women in higher education who over the years have been harassed, ignored, unhired, or if hired, unrewarded with salaries and ranks commensurate with those of their equally qualified male colleagues. What apparently was news to the 1,400 college and university presidents and top administrators at the meetingthat women have been systematically discriminated against in educational institutionscertainly was not news to these women.

title: Textile Plants Battle Noise
description: Noise pollution in textile plants is among the worst in all industry. It is beginning to decline, but progress in solving the problem is very slow.

title: Mrs. Phreaner Is Wed To Edmund B. Round
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 14Mrs. Susannah Watson Phreaner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Hann Watson of Bryn Mawr Pa., was married here this afternoon to Edmund Balfour Round, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Edmund Balfour Round of Lyndhurst, Ohio, by the Rev. Todd Wetzel in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: By Popular Demand and Wanika Triumph in Divisions of Mermaid Stakes
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 14 (AP)Elberon Farm's By Popular Demand and W. M. Jeffonds Jr.'s, Wanika recorded their first stakes victories today, winning the divisions of the 25th Mermaid Stakes at Atlantic City Race Course.

title: U.S. IS IMMUNE IN JOB BIAS SUIT
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 14A Federal judge this week dismissed the United States Government as a defendant in a job discrimination case under the legal doctrine of sovereign immanity, which states that a government cannot be sued without its consent. But at the same time, he rebuked the Government for invoking that doctrine.

title: Mayor Urges Easing New Code Against Noisy Repairs at Night
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday a proposed amendment to the city's new antinoise code that would permit city agencies to perform night maintenance such as pothole work, and also permit variances in commercial areas in the present ban against construction at night.

title: Colonels Down Squires, 130110
description: LOUISVILLE, Oct. 14 (AP)Artis Gilmore scored 27 points, grabbed 19 rebounds and tied an American Basketball Association record with 10 blocked shots tonight as the Kentucky Colonels won, 130110, from the Virginia Squires.

title: Wetlands in Suffolk in Peril
description: North of the centuriesold community of Stony Brook lies the green and silent peninsula of Crane Neck. To the north of it is Long Island Sound, and on its east lies Conscience Bay, a body of water that may turn out to be named appropriately for our time. And at the top of the lush peninsula, entering from an inlet in the Sound, is a 125acre marsh called Flax Pond.

title: MacDonald Scores 2, Penguins Beat Seals for 3d Straight, 52
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 14 (AP) Lowell MacDonald the left wing, scored his firts two goals of the National Hockey League season tonight to lead the Pittsburgh Penguins toa 52 victory over the California Golden Seals tonight.

title: Full Pocket Wins Dash
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (AP)Full Pocket, the oddson favorite, turned back a challenge by Fame and Power on the final turn today and won the $21,250 Marshall Field Memorial Handicap at Sportsman's Park.

title: Iowa Tops Northwestern
description: EVANSTON, III., Oct. 14 (UPI) Iowa scored touchdowns the first two times it had the ball, then relied on Rick Penney's alert defensive play at safety to hold off Northwestern, 2312, tcday.

title: The argument of Women's Liberation, Midge Decter says, is with liberation
description: The theme of this book is the disparity between what it feels like to be a woman and what Women's Liberation says it feels like. Midge Decter  writer, editor, wife, mother, and author of 'The Liberated Woman and Other Americans (1971)begins her new book by saying that Women's Liberation sprang into existence over the issue of housework. From its outset, she writes, the movement has claimed that women are demeaned at home and demeaned on the job. They serve their husbands, who service them at will; they wait on their bosses, who underpay and condescend. On top of that, a feminine mystique in league with a doctrine of masculine supremacy has conned women into thinking they like doing all the dirty work.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAING
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (UPI)The Field newspapers  The Chicago SunTimes and The Chicago Daily Newsare endorsing President Nixon for reelection.

title: Highway Bill Killed as Conferees Differ Over Mass Transit Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14  A HouseSenate conference committee was unable to agree tonight on whether to allow Federal highway monye to be spent to build urban transportation systems, and the entire highway bill was killed for the year.

title: OIL PERIL TO LAKE IS BELIEVED EASED
description: MEXICAN HAT, Utah, Oct. 14Oilmen and United States Bureau of Reclamation crews expressed belief today that a 120,000gallon oil spill had been sufficiently contained to end the major threat of permanent damage to Lake Powell and the shoreline of Glen Canyon National Recreation Area.

title: Bank Says L.I.'s Economy, Growing in Diversity, Will Weather Grumman's Loss of Space Contract
description: MINEOLA, LI., Oct. 14Long Island's economy will weather the Grunman Aerospace Corporation's loss of the $2.6billion space shuttle contract without serious dislocations, the Franklin National Bank believes.

title: Preps
description: Joe LaFauci again led Poly Prep to victory yesterday as his team walloped New York Military Academy, 466. Poly has won three straight after an opening game tie. N.Y.M.A. is 03.

title: BergenPassaic
description: Unbeaten River Dell Regional took over sole possession of first place in the Northern Bergen Interscholastic League yesterday with a 1412 victory over previously unbeaten Northern Highlands at Allendale.

title: 4 Colleges in Boston Area Join to Recruit Students
description: BOSTON, Oct. 14 (AP)Four area colleges have joined in a collective program to recruit prospective students.

title: Pesticide Compensation Bill Seen Costing Billions
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14Critics of a new pesticide control bill approved by Congress charged today that a littlepublicized provision set a precedent for Federal legislation that could lead to payments of billions of dollars to manufacturers of many products.

title: New York
description: My feeling, said State Supreme Court Justice Edward R. Dudley, is we ought to have short breaks to retool the batteries. Nonetheless, he announced last week that the traditional twoweek Christmas holiday for State Supreme Court judges in Manhattan and the Bronx would be revoked this year. Only on Christmas Day and New Year's Day will the courtrooms be closed.

title: COLGATE RALLIES, TIES HOLY CROSS
description: HAMILTON, N. Y., Oct. 14 (AP)  Tom Parr bulled to touchdown with 22 seconds left and passed for an extra point to give Colgate a 2121 tie with Holy Cross today.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Congratulations to Harris Green for his article, Are Today's Composers Adrift in a Void? He does well to expose the pretentious, selfserving rationalizations of the likes of Boulez and Wuorinen. However, I feel that, by opposing the aridity of contemporary music to the timeless rewards of older music, he ignores one fact which is often overlooked by those who have been offended by much of today's music: namely, that there is a tremendous body of music being written today which shares Green's values of expressiveness and humanism.

title: The Nation
description: Remember Dick Tuck, the Merry Prankster of the 1964 Presidential campaign? His forte was the infiltration of Republican election effortsas when he put a girl aboard the Goldwater campaign train from whence she dispensed Johnson press releases.

title: City Perks Up as Bond Seller
description: New York City sold a bond issue last Wednesday at the lowest rate in three and half years, and the politicians who ran the sale and the investment bankers who peddled the securities were quick to trumpet the good news.

title: State's Democrats Are Gloomy About Maintaining Their Seats in Legislature
description: Democratic legislative leaders are saying publicly that they can take control of the Assembly in the elections next month, but rankandfile Democratic legislators are saying privately that if they can get by without losing any seats it will be, as one put it, some kind of victory.

title: Navy Unveils its Tomcat Fighter, a $10.2Million Carrier Plane
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 14  The Navy substitute for the troubleplagued F111 war plane, the F14 Tomcat fighter, was unveiled here today at the commissioning of the first two squadrons to which the new twinjet aircraft will be assigned.

title: Sampling of Facts in Report on Census
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 In the Census Bureau's new report on the 1970 Census, the 289 pages of graphs, tables and appendices provide thousands of assorted facts. Here is a random sample.

title: Preps
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 14Dalton School opened holes in the Wheatley line all afternoon today and punched out a 306 victory. Center Jeff Levine led the interior line blocking that enabled Dalton to register four shortyardage touchdowns and capitalize on three of its four conversion attempts. Dalton has a 31 record.

title: Chess: A New, Youthful Team Puts Sweden Back in the Spotlight
description: SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Oct.  Not since 1954 has Sweden had a team that could make the championship finals of the biennial Chess Olympics. Its aging triumvirate faded out altogether in 1967 with the death of Grandmaster Gideon Stahlberg. Grandmaster Gosta Stoltz's death a few years earlier and Erik Lundin's retirement left a power vacuum that is only now beginning to be filled.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: The editor of McCall's takes a long look at communications in our society. Staking out a position somewhere between Marshall McLuhan and Spiro Agnew between Reader's Digest and the East Village Other, he deals with what he calls the picture of the world that you and I carry around in our heads. Who put it there, why, how, under what conditions? His inquiry leads him ultimately to moral concerns, and although he does not provide the answers he asks the right questions in abundance. He has sympathy for the younger journalists sometimes inchoate criticism of the media and scorn for the successful editorspublisherspundits who have lost touch with what ordinary Americans put up with in real life.

title: U.S. WON'T SHUN USE OF U.N. VETO
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 14  Secretary of State William P. Rogers says that the United States will exercise its veto power in the United Nations Security Council far more readily than it has in the past.

title: Pop
description: BIRTHA: Birtha (ABC/ Dunhill DSX 50127). Birtha doesn't come from Detroit, but it should have. This new West Coast band approaches rock n roll with the tough, gutsy drive that has become the hallmark of Motor City bands. There's absolutely no messing around with fancy effects on this debut album, which will jolt anyone who thinks that the proper place for young women rock n roll musicians is behind acoustic guitars. Of course, the history of selfcontained female groups hasn't been a happy one. They are usually viewed as novelty acts to be stuck somewhere between the tap dancing chickens and the Siamese twins. Fanny, probably the best known of these groups because of its unfortunate choice of a name, has yet to originate any strong material. Birtha (which is not a slang expression for any part of the anatomy, so far as I know) performs a great many original

title: Miss Beth L. Holman Plans Bridal
description: Miss Beth Louise Holman, a senior, at Radcliffe College, and Stephen Kearns Sawyier, a student at the Harvard. Graduate School of Far Eastern Languages, man to be married Dec. 16 at the Harvard Memorial Chapel in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Racing's Tax Revolt
description: Would a lower tax on horseplayers at New York tracks produce higher revenue for the state?

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The small investor is rapidly replacing the weather as the subject about which everyone talks, but does nothing. I think it is time words were replaced with deeds.

title: Rockets Defeat Braves, 121113
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 14 (UPI)Mike Newlin scored 25 points and hit four free throws tonight to cool off a late Buffalo rally as the Houston Rockets scored a 121113 victory over the Braves.

title: Elements Dampen a Flour Creation but Not the Artist's Appreciation
description: The thought was to create artistic patterns right in front of the New York Cultural Center, so a sculptor volunteered to pour 400 pounds of baking flour in the street and let the passing cars and buses do the brush strokes.

title: Historic Jersey Village Marks 275th Birthday
description: CRANBURY, N.J., Oct. 14Maple and oakbowered Main Street of this pleasant hamlet of 2,000 was lined today with she very young and the very old and with many visitors from surrounding towns, for a parade that marked the 275th anniversary of the first white settlement here on the banks of Cranberry Brook, as it was then known.

title: God's plenty is here, at least till the later pages
description: Anthologies of poetry exist, at their best, to transfix, to console and sanctify (at least before these aims were questioned by Wallace Stevens) and to transmit shocks of unexpected and relieving assent. The young need them most, in order to sort out and make sense of their own emotions, to be reassured that their hidden feelings are not obscure and shameful private diseases, but, as Carlyle said about the universe, Godlike and my Father's. Admission into the human community of passionate thought and expression ought to be mediated by the schools, but in their frightened censorship they have laundered literature of all its subversive and therefore arresting aspects.

title: RUPTURED SPLEEN CAN BE A KILLER
description: The ruptured spleen, a condition that can result from surprisingly minor injuries, has become known to doctors as a hidden time bomb that can kill anytime from hours to weeks afterward.

title: Music
description: RENATA scam has sung half a dozen roles at the Metropolitan Opera since her debut here seven years ago, but it will not be until Tuesday night that she will have appeared in an opera by her favorite composer, Bellini. She will be heard in the revival of La Sonnambula, in the production created in 1963 for Joan Sutherland. It was a successful showcase for the vocal virtuosity of the Australian soprano, but Miss Scotto believes that her interpretation will put the opera in a new perspective, one that she hopes will help to make it as popular here as it is in her native Italy. As she puts it in her heavily Italianate English, For many years I asked the Met to do Sonnambula, because nobody here really knows it.

title: News of Dogs
description: The West Highland white terrier ranks only No. 38 of the 116 breeds listed by the American Kennel Club. Last year 6,754 Westies were registered. Near the top of the ladder, in the fifth slot, is the miniature schnauzer, with 45,305.

title: U.C.L.A. DEFEATS ORE, STATE, 377
description: CORVALLIS, Ore., Oct. 14 (AP)Rich Gunther, a defensive tackle, set up two touchdowns with a recovered fumble and a blocked quick kick recovery as the University of California, Los Angeles, defeated Oregon State, 377, in a Pacific8 Conference football game.

title: Three Plans for Peace in Vietnam
description: As George McGovern last week set forth his proposals for ending the Vietnam war, Henry Kissinger was conducting his latest series of secret talks with Communist representatives in Paris. Whether those talks have produced any loosening in the deadlock between the two sides is not known. What is known is the last public positions taken on the major issues by President Nixon, the Vietnamese Communists as represented by North Vietnamese Premier Pham Van Dong, and Senator McGovern. They are:

title: L.S.U. Beats Auburn, 357
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 14 (AP)Bert Jones threw three touchdown passes to Gerald Keigley and ran for one to lead eighthranked Louisiana State to a 357 Southeastern Conference football victory over ninthranked Auburn tonight.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: H. Essame, now in his 75th year, was a soldier; his military histories crackle with authenticity, a firsthand feel and an affection for enlisted men. In his latest book he returns to World War I and addresses himself to what he thinks are the lingering myths about the war put forth by such authorities as Basil Liddell Hart and disillusioned poets and novelists. Essame examines the battles of the watershed year 1918 and hands out credit and blame with an even hand to the officers and men of the French, British, Australians and Americans. He agrees with General Pershing, who, when the Germans were in full retreat, called for unconditional surrender; perhaps, he says, if Pershing's policies had been pursued the Germans would not have marched home in good order Hitler would not have been able to claim a stab in the back, and perhaps there would have been no World War II.

title: REDS PROBLEMS BEGIN AT THE TOP
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 14Four times Johnny Bench came to bat today and four times he led off.

title: KINGS POINT WINS FROM DREXEL, 166
description: KINGS POINT, L.I., Oct. Tolin Reshore of Centerport set school record for field goals today as the Merchant Marine Academy defeated winless Drexel 166, on Captain Tomb Field. Reshore hooted three for a season total of seven.

title: Bus Line Gives DoortoDoor Service
description: HADDONFIELD  An experimental bus system offering personalized doortodoor service for its passengers is slowly beginning to attract business after being stalled by a 75day strike and the usual summer doldrums.

title: Stars Triumph by 10690
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 14 (UPI)The Utah Stars held off a determined fourthquarter rally by the Dallas Chaparrals to take a 10690 victory tonight. Utah dominated the action from the opening buzzer and built a 7963 lead midway in the fourth period, but the Chaps, closed the gap to 9484 before the Stars pulled away.

title: Lawyer to Marry Miss Goldsborough
description: BUXTON, Md., Oct. 14Mr. and Mrs. Phillips Lee Goldsborough 3d have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Gambrill Goldsborough, to Edward Francis Glynn Jr. of New York. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Glynn of the Town of Mount Royal, Montreal.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: Mark Twain, exclaims the dust jacket, lives. If so, he is being murdered. This corn pilation of dear ole Dixieland clichsdamyankihs, sowbelly whipperwill peas, snuff dippin and good ole Jack Daniels down yonder astrummin on de ole corn pane  owes its loyal, lovin', laughin', cussin', brawlin harddrmkin style much less to Mark Twain than to George Fitch, whose komedy klassic At Good Old Siwash, about roughandready football types at Midwestern cow colleges, was published by Little, Brown in 1911. Time hasn't improved the idiom Sergeant Grimes has chosen for this quasiautobiography, and the unrelieved Dixie dialect doesn't help (he insists on addressing the reader as ole buddy in an eyetoeye monologue so close you can smell the corn on every syllable). Much of the book is about the Sergeant's adventures in the infantry at home and in the Pacific during World War II. Typical earthy, Southern humor: 'dealin from the bottom of the deck is a heap more dangerous than usin broken glass for toilet paper. To the little ole reader who never did get his fill of Li'l Abner and the Beverly Hillbillies, Sergeant Grimes may be a real, genuine laff riot.

title: CENSURED LAWYER LOSES APPEAL BID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 The Supreme Court denied a hearing this week to Martin Erdmann, former chief trial attorney of the New York City Legal Aid Society's criminal branch, who has been censured for professional misconduct by New York's appellate judges because he criticized the judiciary in a magazine interview.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: THE Research and Development Department of the Hoosic Tunnel Company has studied Are Today's Composers Adrift in a Void? by Harris Green carefully. It seems to us that Green, in following the composers into the void in which they are adrift, has himself contracted a severe case of weightlessness. The Committee suggests massive doses of Vitamin B (flat) and Vitamin C (sharp). This will provide Green with augmented seconds that might give him more weight and gravity for his next article.

title: ARKANSAS TOPS BAYLOR, 31 TO 20
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Oct. 14 (UPI)Dickey Morton, a tailback, scored on runs of one and three yards today in leading Arkansas to a 3120 victory over a stubborn but outmanned Baylor eleven.

title: Sports of The Times
description: It's all over now for Matt Snell, who is recuperating from surgery for a ruptured spleen. Some people hardly noticed. Maybe that's because John. Riggins is the New. York Jets big running back now, but Riggins understood.

title: Recordings
description: THERE is nothing quite as pleasant as reviewing a new set of recordings of Dvorak's music. It may not be the most stimulating or the most profoundly moving music in the world, but its unfailing sweetness, melodic inventiveness, harmonic originality and perfection of scoring cannot fail to find a response in the listener. This fact holds true for seven disks of recent issuance. Not all the works are topgrade Dvorak but even those that are not arouse a feeling of pleasure and good will.

title: Bowl Scouts View Alabama
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Oct. 14 (AP)Representatives of the Sugar and Cotton Bowls watched the FloridaAlabama football game today. Buddy Dyke was at the game from the Cotton Bowl and Claude Simons and A. B. Nicholas Jr. represented the Sugar Bowl.

title: Notes on People
description: Unfortunately, human beings tend to make errors in favor of themselves, said Elmer H. Klinsman as he sat in his Newark office after taking over as the director of the Internal Revenue Service in the state. Mr. Klinsman, a 56yearold, Plainfieldborn weekend golfer who has collected taxes in Manhattan, Boston, Syracuse and Brooklyn, said that for a while, he would just look, listen and learn in his new post. Then, said Mr. Klinsman, who lives in Summit, he will begin to implement his revenue philosophy: To try our damnedest to let the average taxpayer know we are on the job getting after the people who aren't paying their taxes.

title: RUTGERS DEFEATS LAFAYETTE, 21 TO 7
description: EASTON, Pa., Oct. 14Rutgers used a solid running game centered on Jim Jennings to beat Lafayette, 217, today.

title: PetFish Dealers Fear a New Law
description: SADDLE RIVER  When the polyethylene bag was invented, the tropical fish industry ballooned. Its bubble may burst, pet supply wholesalers say, because of a proposed Federal law affecting fish imports, modeled after other regulations restricting the sale of turtles and banning the import of certain birds to prevent communicable disease.

title: Preps
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Oct. 14With Dave Del Bello directing the attack, The Hill walloped Haverford, 3514. Del Bello ran for one touchdown and tossed passes for two others. Steve Verbit scored twice for The Hill. Pete Lindquist scored all the Haverford points.

title: Miami T ops Tulane, 2421, Ending Losing Streak at 8
description: MIAMI. Oct. 14The University of Miami raliled for a 2421 upset victory over Tulane tonight by scoring a touchdown on an illegal fifth down play that went unnoticed by the officials as Ed Carney threw 32 yards to Wilt Beckman in the end zone.

title: Art
description: LARRY POONS is only 35 years old, but his development as a painter, in the nine years since his first oneman show, has already entailed more drama and controversy than most artists know in a lifetime. Indeed, it has often been all but impossible to see and judge his work with clarity, so thick has been the cloud of esthetic and ideological issues kicked up by the vicissitudes of his style.

title: World News Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. Oct. 14Fighting was reported continuing between Yemen and Southern Yemen today, despite a reported ceasefire agreement.

title: Views of Review
description: To THE EDITOR: In The Week in Review of Oct. 1, the headline, Must He Also Get Morning Sickness?, concerning the rights of fathers to paternity leaves, is not only not very humorous but it completely confuses the issue.

title: HEINZ POL, AUTHOR AND JOURNALIST, 71
description: Heinz Pol, author and journalist, who retired last year as United Nations and American correspondent for the newspaper Frankfort Rundschau of West Germany and also as a correspondent for The National Zeitung in Basel, Switzerland, died Friday at his home in New Milford, Conn. His age was 71.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 14The University of Massachusetts kept its undefeated streak intact with a 4415 victory over Boston University today at Alumni Stadium.

title: CONGRESS SHELVES WELFARE REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 Senate and House negotiators shelved the Nixon Administration welfare reform plan late tonight but approved a vast array of new benefits for many of the nation's aged, blind and disabled.

title: Preps
description: CONCORD, N. H., Oct. 14Phil Fernald led undefeated St. Paul's past St. Sebastian's, 140, today. Fernald, a quarterback, scored both his team's touchdowns on runs of 5 and 10 yards. St. Paul's is 201, while St. Sebastian's is 11.

title: Article 17  No Title
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind. Oct. 14 (UPI)The Indiana Hoosiers routed the Wisconsin Badgers, 337, today in a Big Ten football game decided by a record four field goals by a Swedish kicker, Chris Gartner, plus two touchdown passes and a scoring run by Ted McNulty.

title: London vs. New York: A Tale Of Two Cities
description: LONDON WITH the exception of a fouledup telephone system, all services designed for the public seem to be superior in London: transportation (remarkably comfortable and convenient); the police (consistently courteous and helpful); health plans (government subsidized, expertly staffed); the parks (spacious, clean, safe, ablaze with flowers); and, of course, the theater.

title: SOVIET REPORTS BEST ASIAN CROP
description: MOSCOW. Oct. 14Harvest reports coming in from two widely separated graingrowing regions of the Soviet Union indicate that a gamble taken 15 years ago by Nikita S. Khrushchev might have paid off once again.

title: the traveler's world
description: CORNING, N. Y.The grapes hang full and heavy in the vineyards of the Finger Lakes region, rich with sugar and growing richer as they wait in the warmth of autumn sunshine for the final harvesting. The leaves are pretty well turned and the summer tourists have given way to the fall foliage tourists, generally a quieter lot, more interested in the spectator side of enjoying nature than racing up and down the long fingers of water in noisy outboards.

title: Nassau North
description: Levittown Division scored 28 Ipoints in the second period yesterday to turn a 16point Glen Cove lead into a 5022 victory in a North Shore Division III game.

title: Preps
description: WOODMERE, L.I., Oct. 14Joe Feliciano plunged for a score with 1 minute 15 seconds left, giving Fieldston a 148 triumph over Woodmere Academy. Woodmere (32) took an 80 lead on Jeff Leavy's 2yard touchdown run and Bob Wallace's conversion run.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP.
description: Regional brokerage houses, linked to Wall Street by memberships on the New York and American Stock Exchanges and other trading markets, have been building impressive growth patterns of their own, as well as expertise and good prospects, by working closely with companies with headquarters in their areas.

title: School Gets $1.5Million
description: Kent, Conn., Oct. 14The Kent School is to receive two grants totaling $1.5million for the construction of a new athletic field house, according to Sidney N. Towle, headmaster of the private coeducational preparatory institution. A $1million grant will come from the Charles E. Merin Trust. The remaining $500,000 has been pledged personally by Robert A. Magowan an alumnus of the school.

title: The Breast
description: Better the banal than the boorish is an alliteration that paraphrases the paraphraserauthor John Gardnerand describes, all too well, his comment on the new Philip Roth novel, The Breast.

title: Gerritsen Beach In Battle of T's
description: Since 1921, when Gerritsen Beach was converted from a large swamp area into a residential community, controversy has surrounded its appropriate spelling. Local residents maintain that Gerritsen is spelled with two t's, while authorities prefer to spell it with a single t.

title: Jets Favored Over Patriots Today
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Oct. 14 True, it's only the New England Patriots that the New York Jets are scheduled to meet in Schaefer Stadium tomorrow but as they learned two weeks ago in their defeat at the hands of Houston, no one can take any team in the National Football League for granted.

title: Son of Glut Wins Stakes
description: SALEM, N. H., Oct. 14 (AP)Son of Glut, a $1,700 purchase as a yearling, led all the way in winning the $11,075 RockingRockingham Park wound up a Rockinham Park wound up a 77day thoroughbred meeting. Son of Glut paid $5 for $2 to win in the sixfurlong race.

title: Lucchesi Released
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 (AP) The Philadelphia Phillies have eleased their former manager Frank Lucchesi from his position as major league scout, Lucchesi reported today. Phillies officials were unavailable for comment.

title: Gerritsen Beach Volunteers Keep the Lid on Fires in Area
description: The old folks waved and cheered, the teens sat on the curb and rooted and the tots wore fire hats and buttons proclaiming: Kiss Me, I'm a Fireman! The event was the Gerritsen Beach Fire Volunteers 50th anniversary parade and bazaar, held recently on Gerritsen Avenue in Brooklyn.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: No doubt, trade with the Soviet Union might be beneficial, and efforts by government and business to bring it about should be applauded. But realism counsels a look at the record. The Soviet Union has a foreign trade monopoly; it directs every aspect of international commerce according to a plan based on internal considerations and not in harmony with comparative cost advantages that would benefit all trade partners.

title: Rome Improvement
description: THE durability and final appearance of any exterior paint job will depend to a great extent on how careful the homeowner is in preparing the old surface, as well as in how he applies the new coating. Merely slapping a fresh coat of paint on over an old, dirty, peeling or badly chalking surface may make the house look fine for a short whilebut it will almost certainly result in premature failure with heavy blistering and peeling that will make the job even harder next time.

title: Dowdy Protests Innocence Before Nearly Empty House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) Nearing the end of a 20year House career, Representative John Dowdy, Democrat of Texas, took the floor for almost an hour yesterday to proclaim his innocence of bribery, conspiracy and perjury and warn that the honor and integrity of this body is under attack.

title: St. George and the Godfather
description: Mailer is our literary Rojack; he can get away with murder. And seems, on the face of it, a journalistic crime for him to circle back, doing MiamiandMiami, after his Miami and the Siege of Chicago. But how could he resist? The political conventions are now literary events, places where writers mill in and out telling other writers there is nothing to write about. They are the big quadrennial cocktail parties. This time we got not only the novelists (Wilfrid Sheed, Kurt Vonnegut, Joe McGinniss) but a dramatist like Arthur Miller and a cntic like Elizabeth Hardwick. Esquire, having run through available American literati, imported Chinese and Russian observers to the Miami conventions. miration over what it sees. Even riots and wars must be photogenic to get shown at all. For many Americans the events in Miami were Cronkite's conventions, and cuddlylovable for being such. TV, covering the event, merges with it. A writer's job is to stand off, even to putdown.

title: Kennedy Is Backed on Subpoenas in Watergate Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) The Democratic majority of a Senate Judiciary subcommittee has approved plans by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the chairman, to subpoena witnesses in an inquiry into the Watergate bugging incident.

title: Jean McIntosh Is Betrothed to Lyman L. Jones Jr.
description: DARIEN, Conn., Oct. 14Dempster McIntosh, former Ambassador to Uruguay, Venezuela and Colombia, and Mrs. McIntosh have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Gordon McIntosh, to Lyman Louis Jones Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Jones of Hammond, La. The wedding is planned for Nov. 11 at Christ Episcopal Church in the Georgetown section of Washington.

title: Profit Charge Denied
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) Kenneth E. Frick, head of the Agricultural Stabilization Conservation Service, denied in an interview today that the Agriculture Department had tried to promote speculator profits by driving cotton prices down.

title: MICHIGAN DOWNS MICH. STATE, 100
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 14 (AP)  Gil Chapman, a sopho more wingback, raced 58 yards down the left side on a reverse for a touchdown with less than nine minutes to play today to pad a precarious 30 lead and give fifthranked Michigan 100 Big Ten football victory over Michigan State.

title: Anna Apparent
description: It is depressing to find writer whose skills are as finely tuned as Nina Bawden's involved in such a clotted chronicle as this. There is enough fuel in AnnaApparent to run a daytime TV serial for at least a year. Maybe more.

title: Local
description: Wingate scored two touchdowns during a secondhalf rally to defeat Boys, 148, at Midwood field. Hamilton Barksdale connected with Maurice Rodriquez twice for 8 points, first on a 45yard touchdown pass play and then on the conversion. Robert Foy's fourth quarter score was Wingate's margin of victory.

title: Rollyn G. Osterweis Is Affianced
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 14Prof. and Mrs. Rollin G. Osterweis have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rollyn Gay Osterweis, to the Rev. Daniel H. Krichbaum of Detroit. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Krichbaum of Salem, Ohio.

title: Trinity Triumphs. 70
description: TROY, N. Y., Oct. 14 (AP)Saul Wiezenthal scored on a sevenyard run today to give Trinity a 70 victory over Renesselser Polytechnic Institute.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO BD TRAIN CROSSINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 The sound of the train whistle will virtually fade from the main railroad line between Boston and Washington in the next five years as the Federal Government spends $30million to eliminate grade crossings in the Northeast corridor.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MANILA. Oct. 14 (Agence FrancePresse)President Marcos today authorized the reopenings of almost all schools in Manila and other urban centers, apparently reassured that inc threat of disturbances from the centers of student activism had diminished. About a million students and about 70,000 teachers and professors will return to 890 high schools colleges and universities Monday three weeks atter they were, closed under martial law.

title: Local
description: YONKERS, Oct. 14  Fordham Prep used a powerful running attack today to defeat Lincoln of Yonkers, 2614. Larry Bellone and Irest Kozicky, halfbacks for the Little Rams, moved the ball freely on the ground as Fordham evened its record at 22 while dropping the home team to 13.

title: TEXAS SHUT OUT BY OKLAHOMA, 270
description: DALLAS, Oct. 14Big Durland Moore of Oklahoma blocked a quickkick attempt into the end zone and Lucious Selmon recovered it for a thirdperiod touchdown today as the 2dranked Sooners rushed past Texas, 270, handing the Longhorns their first shutout in 101 games.

title: Polly Plimpton Married To Nathaniel B. Smith
description: WIANNO. Mass., Oct. 14Miss Anne Gay Plimpton and Nathaniel Belknap Smith were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Lewis Mudge, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Cape Cod home of Mrs. Fritz Bradley Talbot, grandmother of the bride.

title: World News Briefs
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 14Chile's leftist Government placed four more provinces under the state of emergency decree today as a nationwide trucking strike continued into its fifth clay.

title: Editorial Article 1  No Title
description: Editorial Article 1  No Title

title: wrong Guess on the L.I.R.R.
description: Columbus Day, 1972, will go down in the history of the Long Island Rail Road as the day of the big mistake.

title: ADVERTISING POINT OF VIEW
description: When the public announcement was made a year ago that the advertising industry had established a selfregulation mechanism, I reacted with enthusiasm. At the time, the industry was feeling the effect of several unprecedented Federal Trade Commission actions and the new machinery created the hope that voluntary action might make expanded Federal intervention unnecessary.

title: Social Announcements
description: Social Announcements

title: Cowtown Is Where the Rodeo Begins
description: WOODSTOWN  Cowtown in South Jersey is far from where the buffalo roam, but steerwrestlers and bullriders are as plentiful there at the Saturday night rodeos as spots on an Appaloosa mustang.

title: Ball State Wins, 287
description: MUNCIE, Ind., Oct. 14 (AP) Kevin Canfield returned the opening kickoff 85 yards for touchdown today to start Ball State to a 287 victory over Dayton. Canfield also teamed with Phil Donahue, the quarterback, on scoring passes of 12 and 20 yards in the second quarter.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI)The Chiil Aeronautics Board today authorized Pan American World Airways to suspend its passenger service between the United States, Iceland and Finland.

title: Mrs. Barrows Reweds
description: DORSET, Vt., Oct. 7Mrs. Harriet Simmons Barrows, a partner in the realestate firm of Snare Associates here, and Richard Williams of Fairfield, Conn., and Manchester were married here this afternoon in the United Church of Dorset by the Rev. Hal Miller 3d. Mr. Williams, a widower, is senior vice president of American Aviron, Inc., in Rye, N. Y. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Music: Munich Bach Choir Is Heard
description: Bach's setting of the Passion story according to St. John is much more forthright and brief than his setting of the same story according to St. Matthew. Perhaps for this reason, the performance of the former work by the Munich Bach Choir and Orchestra in Philharmonic Hall Friday night had much to recommend it. The sturdy, clear tone of the chorus, the admirable playing of the solo instrumentalists and the almost aggressive leadership of Karl Richter put a valid emphasis on the comparative directness of the musical narrative.

title: Westchester
description: Ken Moll ran for two touchdowns as undefeated Harrison won its third game of the season, 280, yesterday at Ardsley after being held to one score in the first half.

title: Preps
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Oct. 14Pete McCandless, son of the Princeton University football coach, Jake McCandless, won his statistical battle today with Corky Ellis, his quarterback counterpart on Lawrenceville, but McCandless and Andover dropped a 4422 decision nonetheless.

title: SYRACUSE SCORES OVER NAVY, 3044
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 14 (AP)  Syracuse's reawakened offense struck for three touchdowns in the opening quarter today. With Bernie Ruoff's three field goals in the second half, the Orange defeated Navy, 3014.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: Why do you not suggest to one of the many producers you know that they revive Floradora?

title: Letters To the Editor
description: I believe that many of your readers were both disappointed and disturbed by the Sheed essay.

title: Coins
description: MRS. MARY T. BROOKS, director of the Mint, has announced that the opening date for ordering United States 1973 proof coin sets has been postponed. In past years, the Mint began accepting requests on Nov. 1. However, a change was necessitated to allow time to make equipment and packaging modifications for inclusion of the Eisenhower dollar in next year's sets.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I must applaud Harris Green for his courageous piece on noncomposers.

title: From filing cabinet to emotional fortress
description: City apartments have become emotional fortresses for their occupants. At least, that's what designer John Saladino lieves. When he revised a highrise apartment for M. Anthony Fisher, he sought the illusion of greater space, a background to satisfy a city dweller's emotional needs, a place of serenity and textural delight with a mix of old and new. To relieve the monotony of living in what he calls a filing cabinet, Saladino used color and angled walls to reorient the boxy space along strong diagonal lines. This turns the rooms into one flowing space with the kitchen set in the center as an island. The designer raised and opened the doorways to the ceiling and set the sofa banquette atop a stepped platform. The openness of the rooms, the diagonal walls of color, and bronzetinted mirrors effectively demolish the Lshaped box.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Grace Lich te riste in's article, Alice Cooper? David Bowie? Ugh! And Ugh Again! was more worth of Readers Digest than The New York Times.

title: Striking Way Triumphs
description: MIAMI, Oct. 14 (AP)Striking Way took the lead soon after the start and held on to, win the sixfurlong Miramar Handicap at Calder Race Course today. Striking Way won by a nose from First Bloom and paid $15.40.

title: OBSERVER
description: I was seated in my swivel chair peeling the paint off my old $15 handmedown but honest flattop desk with my finger nails. It didn't improve the appearance of the desk, but it helped take my mind off the beating I'd just taken from three gorillas in the pay of the Democratic National Committee.

title: Citizens, Industry Fight Incinerator
description: HACKENSACK  An unusual combination of big business and citizen environmental groups opened a vigorous campaign here today to fight a planned giant incinerator in the Hackensack Meadowlands.

title: The Nation
description: The Spending Ceiling Bill. The name conjures up images not calculated to turn the public eye away from that World Series game on TV: acres of dollar signs, pages of impenetrable Federal budgets, hordes of cost accountants. Yet last week Washington was the scene of an epochal battle over the measurea battle over such issues as Presidential politics, Federal tax increase, constitutional powers and social and welfare needs.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Ever since some enterprising aborigine stripped to his loin cloth and slithered into a reedy lake to swim under water and seize a silly duck by the legs, man has endeavored unceasingly to outwit waterfowl.

title: Wings Defeat Flyers, 50
description: DETROIT, Oct. 14 (UPI)Marcel Dionne scored goals in the first and second periods tonight, powering the Detroit Red Wings to a 50 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers behind the shutout goaltending of Roy Edwards.

title: New College President Looks to Community
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I.The spirit of the Renaissance man has arrived on eastern Long Island in the person of Harry A. Marmion, new president of Long Island University's Southampton College. Dr. Marmion officially took charge of the nineyearold college on Sept. 1, according to an announcement by the university's Chancellor, Dr. Albert BushBrown.

title: Laymen Learning To Treat Heart Cases
description: Heart resuscitation training for the man in the street?

title: Rockets Beat Pacers, 9690
description: DENVER, Oct. 14 (AP)Byron Beck scored 24 of his 26 points in the first three quarters when the Denver Rockets built a 7561 advantage and then held on for a 9690 victory over the Indiana Pacers tonight.

title: An ancient and a modern land
description: In Cairo, I was once arrested for reporting the presence of a Nazi Jewbaiter. Ten years later, this same warcriminal, Johannes von Lehrs, was still directing hate propaganda. Nobody in the West or in the Soviet bloc made any effort to stop him. Earlier, as a teenager over the English Channel, I thought we were fighting to stop Hitler's extermination of the Jews. Then I looked into the eyes of an applecheeked old man who told me with saintly concern that Hitler's death was an inconvenient interruption of the curing of a disease called Jewishness. For those denied the shock of such an encounter, there are these two books.

title: Traffic Flow Will Be Cut On Section of Archer Ave
description: The Traffic Department announced recently that because of construction work, there will be several changes in the traffic flow along Archer Avenue in Jamaica. The avenue, between 147th Place and 152d Street, will be reduced to two lanes for about three years and become oneway, eastbound.

title: Exuberant Galilee Wedding Ends Feud in ZionistPioneer Clans
description: ROSH PINNA, Israel  The celebration began in the late afternoon, in the small towns and kibbutz villages of northern Galilee.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In a recent column Tom Wicker again wrote in support of busing for racial balance. While I do not share the opinion of the great majority of my Richmond neighbors that busing is unjust, I believe that because of the intensity of the opposition we should pay more attention to alternate ways of achieving the goals behind busing for racial balance. These alternative ways, in terms of the public schools, include:

title: Miss Clausen Has Nuptials
description: Miss Estelle T. Clausen of New York was married here yesterday noon to Charles M. Jones of Glen Ridge, N. J., director of planning for the manufacturing group of General Telephone and Electronics. The Rev. Dr. Bryant M. Kirkland performed the ceremony in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: CONGRESS REJECTS WELFARE REFORM AND HIGHWAY BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Sunday, Oct. 15  SenateHouse conferees reached agreement last night on a spending ceilinga major obstacle in Congress drive to adjourn  but the legislators were unable to wind up the work of the 92d session because of a lastminute power struggle with the President over a water pollution bill.

title: a bloodbath in South Vietnam?
description: Several years have passed since Presidents have dared to look voters in the face and proclaim the Vietnam war either a fight for freedom or an indispensable commitment to the defense of San Francisco. In this election year the principal argument for prolonging the American war in Indochina is that we cannot abandon our friends. Sir Robert Thompson, President Nixon's chief guerrilla war consultant, recently amended his prediction of the number of probable victims of deliberate Communist revenge in South Vietnam from several hundreds of thousands to well over one million. President Nixon has also matched his escalation of the air war over the last three years with escalating predictions of massacres to come if the U.S. fails to keep the Communists from taking power in Saigon. In the Orwellian age, the daily saturation bombings of Indochina are defended as missions of mercy.

title: ATLANTA
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 12President Nixon didn't visit Atlanta this past week, he captured it and turned it into a stage setting for national television.

title: Media
description: In 1960, the National Broadcasting Company censored the use of W.C. on the Jack Paar Show. The initials stand for water closet, which in Britain stands for toilet. Last Monday, the Public Broadcasting Service offered publicTV viewers across the country an educational entertainment called V.D. Blues. Nobody raised any questions about the initials.

title: Telephone Co. to Give Scores During Series
description: The New. York Telephone. Company will provide World Series scores on telephone number 6371212.

title: Corcho Bliss
description: The title role in this airy caper is taken by a Border badman who figures in a burst of lighthearted nonsense as tangy as a chili tortilla. The time is 1911. The characters are broad caricatures out of the days of Pancho Villa.

title: Alabama Defeats Florida, 24 to 7, For 5th Straight
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. Oct. 14 (AP)Terry Davis directed a 74yard drive that consumed almost 9 minutes and pulled thirdranked Alabama away; from Florida, 247, today.

title: She Views Sweaters as a Way of Life
description: When Bonnie Cashin enters the Coty Awards Hall of Fame later this week, seven mannequins will come on the stage of Agnes Tully Hall wearing the identical hooded sweater, each in a glowing spring color. Their leather skirts or pants will be in the same shade and so will their gloves.

title: Local
description: Jeffersoh, the defending P.S.A.L. champion, breezed to its 13th consecutive victory, overwhelming Erasmus, 440. The Jeffs are 4.0 and Erasmus is 04.

title: Rockland
description: Nanuet knocked Suffern out of the undefeated ranks in the Public Schools Athletic League yesterday, 127, which marked toe first time the Golden Knights had won three straight.

title: Raiders Down Nationals, 86, by Scoring 4 Goals in First Period
description: In a display of wild shooting and quick scoring, the New York Raiders defeated the Ottawa Nationals, 86, in a World Hockey Association game yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden.

title: Black Hawks Top Blues, 42
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 14 (AP) Dennis Hull fired two goals and added an assist tonight as the Chicago Black Hawks remained unbeaten in four National Hockey League games by stopping the St. Louis Blues, 42.

title: Paunchy StreetGame Finalists Belly Up for Their Gold Medals
description: Raucous cries of Johnny on the pony and the sound of Spaldeens thwacked by open palms and mop handles were heard in the city for a few hours yesterday at the finals of the first annual New York City Street Games.

title: Nixon Role in Coast Land Deal Unclear
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14More than a million dollars worth of real estate controlled by President Nixon was not included in the statement on his net worth issued by the White House on Sept. 16.

title: Queens Unit Seeks to Save Borough Landmarks
description: The MorrellMorgan house in Little Neck was owned by the family of Mrs. Stephen H. Wells since the days of the Revolutionary War.

title: EssexHudson
description: John McGill and Dennis Joyner put on a fine display of running yesterday to extend Barringer's winning streak to 15 with a 420 victory over Weequahic at Newark Schools Stadium.

title: The Dance: A Joffrey Hit
description: The City Center Joffrey Ballet has no stars in the old bringthehousedown tradition, but especially fine performances such as those given by Starr Danias and Dennis Wayne Friday night in the season's first After Eden get a deservedly rapturous response.

title: Child to Mrs. Roberts
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 14 A daughter was born Sept. 18 to Mr. and Mrs. Grant Van Allen Roberts in Norwalk Hospital. Mrs. Roberts is the former Miss Lucy Warner De Foe.

title: OIL PERIL TO LAKE IS BELIEVED EASED
description: MEXICAN HAT, Utah, Oct. 14Oilmen and United States Bureau of Reclamation crews expressed belief today that 120,000gallon oil spill had been sufficiently contained to end the major threat of permanent damage to Lake Powell and the shoreline of Glen Canyon National Recreation Area.

title: HORSE SHOW MEDAL TO KATIE MONAHAN
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 14Katie Monahan of Bloomfield Mills, Mich., finally, after nine tries, achieved today her goal of winning the hunter seat medal of the American Horse Shows Association. Competing in a record group of 136 riders, she received the championship ribbon at the opening session of the 27th annual Pennsylvania National Horse Show.

title: Queens Auctioneer Adds Woman's Touch
description: In most respects, it was a typical automobile auction: The Police Department's Long Island City storehouse was filled with cigarchomping usedcar dealers, burly wrecking company operators and a handful of young people looking for a good buy among some 640 confiscated, abandoned and stolen vehicles that they examined in city pounds earlier in the week.

title: BALANCHINE GETS A BOLSHOI OFFER
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 14  Mrs. Yekaterina A. Furtseva, the Soviet Minister of Culture, suggested yesterday to George Balanchine that he stage one, of his ballets with the Bolshoi Company and thereby expand cultural exchange between the Bolshoi and the New York City Ballet Company.

title: In recent years the demand for gas has outstripped supply. Liquefied gas from Algeria may cut shortage.
description: WASHINGTON  It may be wishful thinking, but some energy economists believe they see a harbinger of a new approach to the pricing of natural gas (and perhaps electric power) in the Federal Power Commission's revised decision authorizing the importation of liquefied natural gas from Algeria.

title: Atlantic County Ranks 20th In Family Income in State
description: Longport, Linwood, Margate City and Northfieldin that order  are the most prosperous communities in Atlantic County, according to a Census Bureau tabulation of family incomes.

title: Chileans Follow the Dollar, Ignoring the Flag
description: YOU sometimes overhear discussions of subjects besides politics and money in Chile, but such departures from the norm are usually caused only by acts of God, like the earthquakes that send the knowledgeable scurrying from bed to doorjambs, where they acquire dubious safety if the tremblor shakes the house down. However, earthquakes that rattle the beds are not daily occurrences in Chile (twice weekly is more like it), so the rest of the time people are engrossed in politics and money. Chile's escudo buys wonderful things if your tastes are not jaded and you hurry to spend it before the ink is dry.

title: Preps
description: Horace Mann turned the ball over to McBurney three times within 22 yards of the McBurney goal line and dropped an 186 Ivy League game as a result.

title: Kings Conquer Pistons, 113101
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 14 (AP) Nate Archibald's 38 points and 14 assists sparked the Kansas CityOmaha Kings to a 113101 National Basketball Association victory tonight over the Detroit Pistons. It was the Kings first game at their new Kansas City hone.

title: MAIL CLERK HURT BY LETTER BOMB
description: A mail clerk had both hands mangled yesterday when an envelope similar to those that have been sent by Arab terrorists exploded as he was handling it in a Bronx post office.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAING
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14 (AP) The Los Angeles Times announced yesterday, in an editorial prepared for its Sunday editions, that it would endorse President Nixon for reelection.

title: Debra Schlessel to Wed
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 14Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Schlessel have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Debra Sue Schlessel, to Robert Ian Bruck, also of Great Neck son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Bruck.

title: Miss Milbauer Wed To William Leckey
description: SPRING LAKE, N. J., Oct. 14Miss M. Claire Milbauer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Milbauer, was married here at noon today to William J. Leckey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthias J. Leckey of Bronxville, N. Y.

title: How Many Miles To Camelot?
description: Jerry lzenberg, a nationally syndicated sports columnist with the Newark Star Ledger, has been keeping careful watch on the American sports scene for more than 20 years. Among the subjects he examines here are: the boycott and demonstrations by blacks at the Olympics in 1968; the continuing struggle between the Amateur Athletic Union and the National Collegiate Athletic Association for control of amateur athletics in this country; the rise of the hitandrun promoter; the incredibly hypocritical and selfserving treatment of Muhammad All by boxing authorities when he refused to enter the military; the headintheground attitude by sports people about gambling; the dilution and decline of major  league baseball; the attempts by politicians and selfstyled patriots to cloak themselves and their causes in whatever soggy goodwill is left to sports; and the frightening truth that the disturbed values of professional sports are being imposed regularly on the kids who formerly played by their own rules on the sandlots. Izenberg's account is happily studded with reminders that sports are not inherently evil and with remembrances of people he has met who personify the qualities that captivated him as a young and idealistic sports fan.

title: Empire State
description: Vanity, thy name is architecture, and men bemused by the race for the tallest building in the world. If there was ever a Can't Win proposition, this is it. Today's first is always tomorrow's second and the title is as ephemeral as the clouds that gave the skyscraperfirst called the cloudscraperits name.

title: ANTIQUES
description: BAY HEADLong before President Nixon's trip sparked the boom in purchases of exotic wares from China, collectors of Ming through Ching porcelains were customers at Fred B. Nadler's combination home and shop here.

title: Nov. 7: It's a clear choice all right, but what's the real difference?
description: WASHINGTON: Who said, I for one, would be very liberal with regard to amnesty? George McGovern, right? Wrong. Richard Nixon.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 14Ted Grevcs set a school record with four touchdowns and led Ithaca College to a 3813 football victory over Fordham University today before 1,013 homecoming fans.

title: Material made a clich by novelists like Herbert Gold
description: Perhaps the nicest thing about Herbert Gold's informal autobiography is that it reminds one of Henry Miller without the sexual posturings. The two are similarly selfreferential, bedeviled by the need to be more than America seems to allow, exhilarated by the hope of remaking the self through acts of exuberant storytelling. But where Miller's is an art of improvisational variety, Gold elects to pursue a Meaning, committing himself from his opening words to kind of thematic overkill:

title: BenGurion Looks at The Bible
description: This is a remarkable book by a remarkable statesman. David BenGurion, the former Prime Minister of Israel. For him, Israel and the Jewish people are special, and the source of their uniqueness is to be found in the Bible. That is the key to their past, present and future. Therefore, he has devoted his life to a study of the political, social, spiritual and intellectual development of his small nation as it is revealed in the Bible. He does so with such vigor and vividness that he is able to communicate his enthusiasm to others.

title: Museum in Bellport Honors A Famous Former Resident
description: BELLPORT, L.I.The dedication of the new BellportBrookhaven Historical Society Museum in this small village on the South Shore of Long Island last month was more than a dedication.

title: Preps
description: LENOX, Mass., Oct. 14Cranwel scored a third period touchdown and a two point conversion, but allowed Canterbury to rally for a 88 standoff when the visitors scored touchdown late in the fourth quarter.

title: FRED GOLDSMITH, 79, JAM MANUFACTURER
description: Fred M. Goldsmith, who retired in 1966 as president of MacTavish Preserves, Inc., manufacturer here of jams and dietetic jellies, died Thursday in Mount Sinai Hospital.He was 79 years old and lived in Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Edith Hardcastle to Wed
description: GROTON, Mass.; Oct. 14Miss Edith Abbot Hardcastle and Robert Clinton Vaughan plan to be married *next month. Their engagement has been announced by Miss Hardcastle's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Yellott Fitzhugh Hardcastle Jr. The future bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Bromley Vaughan of Coventry, R. L A 1965 graduate of the United States Naval Academy, he served in the nuclear submarine service for five years. Miss Hardcastle is an alumna of Oberlin College.

title: A New Center For Mental Ills
description: PISCATAWAY  A new concept in mental health care will become a reality this week when the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey opens a psychiatric center at its Rutgers Medical School campus here.

title: WALL STREET
description: Like most other glamour issues, the mobile home stocks have come tumbling down from lofty levels in the last few months, partly because of the general malaise afflicting investors and partly because of some questions about the fundamental outlooks for these stocks. The Mobile Home Manufacturers Association has reported that shipments in July were up 11 per cent from the total for July of 1971. Included in the total for the month this year were 2,376 units purchased by the Government. A more optimistic appraisal comes from Patrick Sheehan of Blyth Eastman Dillon. He is aware of the same trends in shipments that the other analysts mentioned, but he looks at them in a different way.

title: BLIND WOMAN FAILS IN BID TO SUE CITY
description: A woman has lost her bid to bring the city to trial for negligence, despite an affidavit that two policemen participated in a campaign of terror, allegedly waged by a rejected suitor, which ended in a lye attack that blinded and scarred her for life.

title: C. W. Post Is Helping Students To Adjust
description: GREENVALE, L. I.Based on the premise that from the time he enters school until he graduates the student is besieged by an unending series of experiences and adjustments, C. W. Post College of Long Island University has been endeavoring to help him with his problems.

title: Travel Notes: Learning the Trade by Mail
description: TOURISM has entered the curriculum of a number of colleges, but it's also possible to prepare for a career in the travel industry at home through a correspondence course from the American Society of Travel Agents (ASTA). The idea is not new; besides ASTA, a nonprofit travel trade association, several commercial correspondence schools offer courses. What is new is the nature of ASTA's completely revised course.

title: Consumer Nonprotection
description: Three years ago President Nixon Wrapped himself in the toga of two dead champions of consumerism, Upton Sinclair and Rachel Carson, and sent Congress a proposal for a Buyer's Bill of Rights. The fruits of that initiative have been depressingly meager, partly because the original bill never measured up to its expansive title and, even more, because every Congressional move for effective consumer protection ran into Administration resistance.

title: The World
description: BARCELONA  Normally courses at the country's two largest universities, here and in Madrid, are scheduled to start at the beginning of October. But by the end of last week they had not begun. In Valencia the entire university administration resigned last week, following the example of the staff at ancient Salamanca University earlier. Students are rebellious, faculties fearful and parents exasperated.

title: Science
description: Biologically, the I of me is unique. Each of us is born with a chemical constitution as individual as our fingerprints.

title: Plant Given Clearance
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) The Atomic Energy Commission's Appeals Board has ruled that the Vermont Yankee Nuclear Power Corporation's generating plant on the Connecticut River could operate at 100 per cent of capacity under its temporary license.

title: Turning a Sawmill Into a Work of Art
description: LA CHAPELLEST. ANDRE, France  At the age of 11, Edgar Iene painted his first picture. It was a sawmill. Now, 57 years later, a sawmill has become his homecompletely renovated by Mr. Iene himself to become a work of art of another kind.

title: Government Quits In Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 14Premier Son Ngoc Thanh's Government resigned today, the Cambodian radio announced.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAING
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 14 (AP)lofting the South Dakota Senator's long stand against the Vietnam war, The St. Louis PostDispatch announced its endorsement today in its Sunday editions of the Democratic candidate. George McGovern, for President.

title: Miss Baldwin Wed To Thomas Bailey
description: MORRIS PLAINS, N. J., Oct. 14In St. Paul's Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Kristine Baldwin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Jay Baldwin, was married to Thomas Bailey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Everett Bailey of Burlington, Vt. The Rev. David Hamilton performed the ceremony.

title: Teaneck's Special Classes Are Helping 400 Children
description: TEANECKRobert Sokol knows how valuable special education can be for a handicapped child.

title: Local
description: Glenn Silverberg, a junior fullback, and Nathaniel Jackson, a sophomore halfback, excelled yesterday as unbeaten John Adams turned back Flushing, 286, in a Queens Public School Athletic League televised game from Memorial Field, Flushing, Queens.

title: U.S. Reports Settlement With Hungary on Claims
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI)  The State Department has signed a preliminary agreement to settle $58.1million in United States citizens claims for interests taken over by the state and for wardamaged property in Hungary.

title: Peace by Annihilation
description: After the latest and longest round of highlevel peace talks in Paris, both North Vietnamese and American officials agreed last week that numerous difficult problems remained in the way of a settlement. That was selfevident as President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam reaffirmed his rejection of any compromise, and as the United States Government continued to underwrite President Thieu's intransigence with a prolongation of the most intensive air assault in history.

title: Rockefeller Forecasts a Budget Surplus of $66Million
description: Governor Rockefeller forecast a $66million surplus yesterday in the state budget for the year ending March 31, on the basis of revised estimates of income and spending.

title: Tenace's Pay Goes Up 28 Per Cent in a Day
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 14 Gene Tenace, the hero of Oakland's upset over Cincinnati in the first game of the World Series today, was earning $18,000 a yearuntil shortly after he hit two home runs the first two times he went to bat.

title: MISS EVERT GAINS FINAL IN TENNIS
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Oct. 14 (AP)Chris Evert outlasted the game's reigning queen, Mrs. Billie Jean King, 64, 62, in 99degree heat today to move into the final of the $100,000 Virginia Slims championship.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: A sensible book about publicopinion polling by two pros. (Roll worked for Governor Rockefeller; Cantril provided the polls that L.B.J. waved around). The authors cite the effect of polls on primary races, the possibly mistaken use of low recognition response (Have you ever heard of soandso?) in making a good man drop out. They discuss examples of corruption by pollsters  some have proposed providing favorable figures for public consumption and true figures for private consideration. Polls do not, authors find, have a bandwagon effect, although they negatively influence big financial contributors if a candidate's figures are too thin, or, paradoxically, if he looks like a shooin. The authors devote a chapter to polling techniques and speculate about the future of polls. Every reporter who refers to polls in a thinkpiece should have this book by his typewriter.

title: Maine Gives P.O.W. Warm Welcome
description: GREENVILLE, Me., Oct. 14Walking next to his father near a lake he fished as a boy, Navy Lieut. Markham Gartley looked up at the clear, blue sky and filled his lungs with crisp autumn air.

title: The Great American Ice Cream Book
description: Before Mike Nichols made it, he was a waiter at Howard Johnson's. Everybody who came in asked, What kind of ice cream do you have? and he had to rattle off the entire Johnsonian litany. Hundreds of times a day. One hectic afternoon someone asked the fatal question and Mike went to pieces. Chicken, he replied.

title: Crusaders Top Oilers, 32, In World Hockey Contest
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 14 (UPI)  Gerry Pinder scored two goals, including the gamewinning tally with 11:25 left in the third period tonight to give the Cleveland Crusaders a 32 World Hockey Association victory over the Alberta Oilers.

title: Cortland Edges Brockport
description: BROCKPORT, N. Y., Oct. 14 (AP)Cortland State overcame a onetouchdown deficit today to defeat Brockport State, 197.

title: UnionMiddlesex
description: Westfield extended New Jersey's two longest success streaks yesterday with a 3415 victory over previously unbeaten Scotch Plains in Westfield.

title: The De Mont Case Isn't Closed
description: Rick De Mont, the asthmatic American swimmer who was denied one Olympic victory and was disqualified from the final of a second race in Munich last month, may still win permanent possession of his gold medal.

title: Barthes vs. Einstein
description: Concerning the quotation Joy Pratt finds disturbing in Edward Said's review of Roland Barthes's Mythologies:

title: Art Notes
description: WHEREVER it has been shownin San Francisco, in Wash=; ington and now at the Whitney MuseumExecutive Order 9066 has had a haunting effect upon those who see it. Most people pass,: through the exhibit in uneasy silence. A few gesture excitedly as they recognize family and friends. And still others break down and cry. All who weep are JapaneseAmericans, for Executive Order 9066 is the photographic story of the internii ment during World War II of 110,000 United States residents of Japanese ancestry.

title: Connecticut
description: Stamford Catholic High upset undefeated Stamford High yesterday, 73. The heavily favored Black Knights, defending state and Fairfield County champions, have not lost since the final game of the 1970 season. This year, Stamford was the county's lone undefeated team with three victories and a tie.

title: Overhaul for Mideast Oil
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The major oilproducing states of the Persian Gulf contain nearly 60 per cent of the world's currently proven oil reserves. But up to now their influence on the actual mechanics of the international oil businessas distinct from their prowess as revenue collectorshas been slight.

title: Fate of Old Senator Points Moral for House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP)  Impatient House members, who believe that a longwinded Senate has delayed the adjournment of Congress, got a laugh yesterday from a story told by Representative Tim Lee Carter, Republican of Kentucky.

title: Local
description: Tilden stopped South Shore, 310, to record its second victory in three Brooklyn II P.S.A.L. games and third in a row overall. The passing of Terry Randolph and the running of Pinckney McCleary and Egbert Mack sparked the Tilden offense. The defense, which has now allowed only seven points

title: Despite Outcry, Caning Prevails in British Schools
description: LONDON, Oct. 14A little more than 300 years ago a group of school boys went to Westminster to hand the Speaker of the House of Commons what they called a modest remonstrance against the use of caning in the schools.

title: New Man at Helm Of Arts Council
description: HACKENSACK  When John Everitt was head of the North Jersey Cultural Council, its followers used to describe him in terms of charm, charisma and personality. Constantine Vasiliadis, who replaced Mr. Everitt as executive director, concedes that his predecessor is a tough act to follow.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON  The two bestknown clerical figures in the Federal government are both Jesuits from the order's Province of New. England. But when it comes to their stands on the most explosive moral issues in politics right nowespecially the war in Vietnamthe similarities stop.

title: ITALIAN'S DEATH STILL MYSTERY
description: MINLAN, Italy, Oct. 8Investigators here know a great deal now about the adventurous life of Giangiacomo Feltrinelli, the publisher who introduced Pasternak's Doctor Zhivago to the West, but they still don't know how he died.

title: Brooklyn Wins on Kick, 32
description: Avi Rose kicked a 22yard field goal in the fourth quarter yesterday to give Brooklyn College a 32 victory over the New York State Maritime Academy. It was his second winning kick in two weeks. Brooklyn's defense held three times inside the 10yard line in the last quarter on fourthdown plays.

title: Child to Mrs. Leibowitz
description: A daughter was born Oct. 6 to Mr. and Mrs. Martin Leibowitz of New York in Beth Israel Hospital. The child, who has been named Rebecca Tiana, is a greatgranddaughter of Louise Homer, the contralto. Her mother, known professionally as Dr. Sarah Leibowitz, is assistant professor of physiological psychology at Rockefeller University. Her father is director of investment systents at Salomon Brothers, stockbrokers.

title: New York
description: It was a case of hair today, gone tomorrow, said Bess Myerson. Not content with clipping her customers, Mrs. Schmalz thought she could get away with a baldfaced scheme to defy the courts.

title: 2 Killed and 211 Injured In Explosion in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 14 (UPI)  Two persons were killed and 211 injured today in a gas explosion in a large Hong Kong department store, the police said.

title: Simpler preaching Is Urged
description: MADISONPreaching isn't dead, it has merely changed in style, according to Dr. Pieter de Jong, who was recently named acting dean of Drew University's Theological School.

title: New Hampshire Wins
description: DURHAM, N. H. Oct. 14 (AP  Passing by BO Osgood and a key interception edged New Hampshire to a 1714 football victory over Maine today.

title: BLACK CHURCHMEN END SIXTH PARLEY
description: The National Committee of Black Churchmen ended its sixth annual meeting last week after a symbolic march from the first Methodist church in the United States, at 44 John Street, to the site of the first African Methodist Episcopal church, at Church and Leonard Streets.

title: Dartmouth's Diversified Attack Overwhelms Princeton, 3514
description: HANOVER, N. H., Oct. 14 The foliage on the hillside that overlooks the local stadium was an eyepleasing mixture of greens, reds, golds and browns today, but on the football field the picture was all green as Dartmouth swept past inceton, 3514.

title: Deaths Caused by Drug Addiction Are Down So Far This Year
description: A decline In deaths attributed to drug addiction here so far this yearto 687 in the first nine months compared with 719 in the same period last yearwas announced yesterday by the city's Health Services Administration.

title: Stamps
description: STAMPS for the Christmas holidays  there are only 59 shopping days remaining  are beginning to make their appearance around the world. Two United States issues are scheduled from Washington on Nov. 9, a portrayal of Santa Claus on an 8c secular adhesive, and a conventional reproduction in miniature of classic religious art on another 8c denomination. Both will be multicolored from the Andreotti gravure presses of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing.

title: Exiles nightmare in London
description: Big things happen so subtly that they barely break the surface of George Lamming's richly lyrical style in this his seventh book and sixth novel. Jan Carew recently commented in these pages that Lamming is a chronicler of the secret journeys to the innermost regions of the West Indian psyche. He is more than that, for I can think of very few writers who make better use of the fictional moments of their stories to explore the souls of any of usWest Indian or not.

title: The World
description: TOKYOA question that continues to rumble through foreign offices and defense ministries throughout Asia, in the Kremlin and even in Washington is: Has Japan started down a road that could make her once again an aggressive military power?

title: Miss EarnshawNolte Is a Bride
description: MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 14Miss Catherine Levis EarnshawNolte and David Craig Ridgway were married here this afternoon at Christ Episcopal Church by the Very Rev. Michael J. Campbell.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONFor Vice President Agnew, the 1972 campaign has a whole series of purposes. But all of his goals are sought within a primary framework  the reelection of President Nixon  because without that, Mr. Agnew's own political future would suddenly look bleak indeed.

title: Preps
description: PROVIDENCE, R. L, Oct. 14  Scoring in every period. Moses Brown romped to a 35S victory over Governor Dummer today. Moses Brown has won twice and lost once while Governor Dummer is 03.

title: Sports of The Times
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 14Dick Williams of the Oakland A's is a managerial manipulator whose hobby is collecting second basemen. Just before the World Series opened under graying skies at Riverfront Stadium today, the stage director of this road company of Hair was asked how many second basemen he really had.

title: U.S. Takes 21 Davis Cup Lead
description: BUCHAREST, Oct. 14  Erik Van Dillen didn't let last year or yesterday bother him as he teamed with Stan Smith today to move the United States within one victory of its fifth straight Davis Cup.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: The towering World Trade Center is on its way to becoming the former tallest buildingor pair of buildings in the world. Whether the new champion is the Sears Building in Chicago or a modification of the Empire State Building, some Port Authority officials insist that a little obscurity will make them very happy.

title: Social Announcements
description: Social Announcements

title: Miss Moore Has Nuptials
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Oct. 14 Miss Caroline Daniels Moore, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Francis Daniels Moore, was married here this afternoon to James Todd Baldwin Tripp, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Vandervoort Tripp Jr. of Chestnut Hill.

title: Patricia Tully Bride of Richard Parker
description: Miss Patricia Ann Tully, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Tully of Plainview, L. I., was married here yesterday morning to Richard Kayser Parker. He is the son of Mrs. Frank E. Parker of Silver Spring, Md., and the late Dr. Parker.

title: Foyle's Lunch: Thought for Food
description: LONDONIn 1930, Christina Foyle, an optimistic, freethinking sort of woman and heiress to the world's largest bookstore, decided that London was ready to digest a series of literary luncheons. Characteristically, she wanted to begin with an offering others might have considered the piece de resistance, George Bernard Shaw. He declined, replying by postcard that it was useless to start anything new in England.
