title: Chinese Physicians Visiting U.S. Note Variance in a Cancer Rate
description: BETHESDA, Md., Oct. 14A cancer that arises in pregnant women is 10 times more common in China than in this country.

title: Two point two is good. Is one better?
description: I haven't had anything to do with my older brother for years now, but I can still recite all his sterling qualities. He was helpful, protective, and always there to get me out of scrapes. He was also imaginary.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: Has it ever occurred to the Tony and New York Drama Critics committees to revisit their award selections?

title: Mess Attendant Contract
description: FORT DEVENS, Mass., Oct. 14 (AP)Fort Devens has announced a $760,000 Government contract for mess attendant services at the base. The contract, let to Artistic Caterers, Inc., of Boston, is the first such action taken by the Army in New England.

title: Music: A Faith in Bluegrass
description: MILLBURN  For a man who had not even heard of bluegrass music as recently as two years ago, Roy Taylor, the principal of the Short Hills School, one of seven elementary schools in the Millburn Township school district, has developed extraordinary faith in the appeal of that lively Southern mountain music.

title: StripMining Controls Die in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 Legislation to control the strip mining of coal has died on the Senate floor, with its opponents, who might have been expected to cheer, showing clear signs of worry and its backers evidencing exuberance.

title: Tenace or Tenacci, a Pronounced Success
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 14He was born Fury Gene Tenace 26 years ago last Tuesday, but the young man isn't sure where the first name comes from. Apparently my father just liked horses, he said today, and his drooping brown mustache curled upward into a sickle moon of happiness. Fury may sound like a cowboy's mount in a Western movie, but Fury Gene Tenace looks like the athlete he is190 lithe pounds on a 6foot chassis, a high school football player who went on to play all nine positions on baseball teams before settling down as the regular catcher of the Oakland A's.

title: Roberta A. Copernoll Is Affianced
description: BELLEVUE, Wash., Oct. 14 Miss Roberta Anne Copernoll, assistant dean of students at Wheaton College In Norton, Mass., and David Benedict Johnson plan to he married in June. The prospective bridegroom, a student at the Columbia University School of Architecture, is descended from Alban Jasper Conant, the portrait painter and archeologist.

title: October is for baking
description: October is an oldfashioned kind of month when it's fun to do oldfashioned kinds of thingslike baking yeast pastries. Those cinnamon buns on the old Hoosier cabinet above with its builtin flour sifter came in plain and fancy versions. And the almond strips may be openfaced or all covered up. Either way, serve them fresh from the oven with coffee.

title: MOSCOW ACCEPTS SEA FREIGHT RISE; SIGNS U.S. ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14The United States and the Soviet Union signed a maritime agreement today after Soviet negotiators yielded to Administration demands and agreed to pay premium rates to American ships carrying Soviet grain purchases.

title: Westminster Rolls, 227
description: HUNTINGTON, Pa., Oct. 14 (AP)Gene McNaMara completed 19 of 33 passes for 185 yards as Westminster rolled to a 227 victory over Juniata today.

title: Nassau South
description: Baldwin speeded Berner's journey from the top to the bottom of South Shore Division I when it registered a 6.0 victory yesterday on a blocked punt that was recovered in the end zone.

title: Free Press Victory
description: A limited but significant victory for freedom of the press has come out of a Federal judge's ruling against police search of the offices of the student newspaper at Stanford University.

title: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title
description: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title

title: Preps
description: WINDSOR, Conn., Oct. 14Powerful Loomis rallied today to defeat Williston, 3321. Loomis is 31 and Williston has not won in three starts.

title: Kennedy Comments
description: BUTTE, Mont., Oct. 14 (UPI) Senator Edward M. Kennedy strongly denounced the Watergate incident here today.

title: Miss Sharon Neill Murray Bride of Francisco Lorenzo
description: In the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon, Miss Sharon Neill Murray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn Allan Murray of Boca Raton, Fla., and East Moriches, L. I., became the bride of Francisco A. Lorenzo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Olegario Lorenzo of Rego Park, Queens, and Vigo, Spain.

title: Gardens
description: MANY plants grow in problem places. The following ones suggested are not common, but readily available for a change of scene. They have proved durable over long periods when grown in poorly lighted places, over radiators and in dry atmosphere in over heated rooms.

title: Democrats Worried
description: Democratic legislative leaders say publicly that they can take control of the Assembly in the coming elections, but rankandfile Democratic legislators say privately that if they can get by without iosing any of their 71 seats it will be some kind of victory. Details on Page 68.

title: About Pro Football
description: The World Series in Cincinnati today has changed somewhat the format for televising of National Football League games. The National Broadcasting Company, which telecasts, the American Conference games of the N. F.L., had turned back to the league several football contests that would have conflicted with the World Series presentation on the network. One is the Jet game at New England. It will be seen on Channel 2 here, the Columbia Broadcasting System station, rather than Channel 4, N. B. C.'s station, beginning at 1 P.M. Then will follow from San Francisco, the Giants game against the 49ers beginning at 4 P. M. It is also on Channel 2, which broadcasts all the Giant away games.

title: RALLY BY CORNELL TOPS PENN, 2420
description: ITHACA, N. Y, Oct. 14Cor nell received lastminute heroics from John McKeown for the second straight week, as it rallied to defeat Pennsylvania, 2420, on Schoellkopf Field today.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate approved Gen. Creighton W. Abrams as the Army's new Chief of Staff last Thursday by the margin of 84 to 2, but the tally had little to do with the real issue involvedthe unauthorized bombing of North Vietnam.

title: Article 18  No Title
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 14 (AP) Otis Armstrong shredded Minnesota's defense for 152 yards rushing and ran for two touchdowns, one a 97yard kickoff return, as Purdue overwhelmed the Gophers, 283, today in a Big Ten conference football game.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor: Earaches and Flying
description: There were two small errors in the complimentary statement made about the Discover New York tour service in your article on sightseeing tours (Travel section, Sept. 24). The telephone number for the service is 6284553, the same as that of the Municipal Art Society bf New York, which operates the service. The cost of the fourhour tours $10 a person, not $12.50.

title: SHOP TALK
description: MONTCLAIR  When the natural look collided with the natural desire to look prettier, natural cosmetics were born. Natural cosmetics end up the same place other cosmetics do, but they begin with strawberries, avocados, papayas and quince.

title: Letters:
description: Many thanks to Jack Werre for tracking down and returning King Arthur to his rightful slot in time in his article on England's Arthurian trail (Travel section, Sept. 24). True, writers from Geoffrey of Monmouth in the 12th century to T. H. White in the 20th have led the legendary monarch across the ages. But they did so with the best in tentions: to show that the courage and ideals of such a figure as Arthur always have a place in history. In our time; of rapid change and breakneck progress, the quest for King Arthur remains a romantic yet edifying glimpse into the past.

title: The World
description: The housewives of Santiago, embittered by chronic shortages and rising prices, brought out their pots and pans last Tuesday and hustled to the center of the Chilean capital to hear opposition speakers lambast the leftist regime of President Salvador Allende Gosscns. Each attack brought forth a salvo of potbanging and applause.

title: Pest Controller Elected
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 14 (AP)William E. Blasingame of Decatur, Ga., was elected this week as president of the National Pest Control Association at the organization's convention here.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: LOOKING GLASS (Epic KE 31320). Looking Glass's first LP is not extremely anything in particular, and so can't do much to offend. It is neither very original nor very imitative, though there are several Poco harmonies, at least one Mad Dogs and Englishmen female chorus, and an. Elton Johnlike piano accompaniment. Several of the cuts are characterized by the rickyticky insistent rhythm that some music papers call infectious and describe as the key to hit records. Others are suitably serious and introspective or wild and rocking as the case may be, but however the externals may change, there is unity in the album as a whole. It is all uniformly drab.

title: Blue Saves Series Victory for Holtzman
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 14With Reggie Jackson on crutches in the dugout, the mustachioed Oakland A's staged a small folk] revolution today when they defeated the favored Cincinnati Reds, 32, in the opening game of the 69th World Series.

title: The Nation
description: SAIGON  With North Vietnamese infiltrators entrenched in the village of Binhnham, only eight miles north of Saigon, a squad of government militia commandered a Volkswagen bus to reconnoiter up the road. The soldiers were tired, they said, from a solid week of fighting, and they wanted to rest their legs. A few minutes later some shots rang out and two of the soldiers were dead.

title: Barbara Sansone Wed to R. M. Damiano
description: Miss Barbara Marianne Sansone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Sansone of New York, was married yesterday morning to Raymond Michael Damian, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Anthony Damian of Bayside, Queens. Msgr. Lawrence Kenny performed the ceremony at a nuptial mass in Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church here.

title: Art
description: SUNDAY, Oct. 1. Arrive Fort Worth in the evening. The usual bleak downtown section, totally deserted except for a porno movie (Get Your Kicks From Our Flicks, the marquee urges, and the trafficincluding a few middleaged coupleslooks brisk.) The hotel bar likewise deserted. In the elevator, I run into a New York art dealer who gives me an effusive greeting. Well, I guess every one's here now, he says.

title: Local
description: Ardie Segars's running and Gary Ettleman's passing played a major role as unbeaten Far Rockaway won its third game. 4424, at home yesterday and Canarsie dropped its second in four starts.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The United States Department of Housing and Urban Development has acted to delay, and has threatened to prohibit, construction on behalf of the New York City Housing Authority of lowincome housing for 250 families on the lower East Side. The current delay and threatened prohibition of housing there are based upon a ruling that the daytime weekday noise level is unacceptable to H.U.D. This is a prime example of bureaucratic nonsense.

title: The Voice of Autumn
description: It is time to say a good word for the autumn wind, particularly the wind of a friendly October day in the country. Not a gale that comes roaring down from the Arctic Circle, or one that rips through the woodland with a crashing of branches. A wind, rather, with a friendly voice and a tempered touch, a wind to walk with under blue skies and a golden afternoon or in starlight with just a touch of frost in the air.

title: McKissick Forms New Group To Help the Republican Party
description: Floyd B. McKissick, former director of the Congress of Racial Equality, says that he has formed a new Republicanoriented organization because he believes that the Democratic party, having made some accomplishments for black people, has done as much as it can do at this time.

title: State Crime Data Raising Questions
description: TRENTON  Lawenforcement officials are reacting cautiously to the latest annual crime statistics that show New Jersey's crime rate increasing at twice the national pace.

title: The Farm Picture: Some Crops Gain
description: TRENTON,A comprehensive report on New Jersey's agricultural profileissued as the annual fall harvest is under waydepicts an overall general decline offset by occasional pockets of bumper crops and official optimism from the state's Department of Agriculture.

title: Philippines Eases Curbs On Permanent Residents
description: MANILA. Oct. 14 (AP)Presdent Ferdinand E. Marcos's office today eased restrictions on the departure of foreign permanent residents from the Philippines.

title: 11 WHO ROSE TO FAME WIN ALGER REWARDS
description: Eleven men who overcame humble beginnings to earn acclaim in their professions will receive the 1972 Horatio Alger awards here on Oct. 27.

title: Music
description: F ALL off the chair! snarls the Distinguished Professor to his student, a demure Oriental cellist. Contrary to the rule, I'd like to see you onceget excited. Shyly, the cellist tackles the piece again while her teacher, heedless of two enormous No Smoking signs, lights one of the 60 or sot cigarettes of which he partakes daily. Her effort, alas, is in vain and the professor, before letting her off the hook, muses, It looks like you'll have to spend your nights finding out what excitement is. You don't seem to be learning it here. This breaks up the master class. Even the cellist cracks a ladylike smile.

title: A Man Never Knows When to Pack
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 14The Oakland A's are hoping they have the same success with Allan Lewis as they had with Gonzalo Marquez.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: IN response to Walter Kerr's article, Get 10 or 20 Playwrights Into a Room , I would like to make known an account of such a situation which occurred last spring when a group of playwrights from on, Off and Off Off Broadway met at Julie Bovasso's apartment. They included myself, Terrence McNally, Rosalyn Drexler, Lanford Wilson, Leonard Melfi, Ken Bernard, Marie Irene Fornes, Paul Foster, Robert Patrick, Jeff Weiss, Rochelle Owens, Murray Mednick, David Starkwhether, Sam Shepard and William Hoffman, to name but a few who were ultimately to become members of what is now incorporated as The New York Theatre Strategy, a playwrights production company.

title: Palestinian Guerrilla Groups Said to Clash in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 14 (Reuters)  Two Palestinian guerrilla groups clashed with mortars and automatic weapons today in the Bekaa area, close to the Syrian border, Lebanese sources reported.

title: Lemaire Paces 61 Victory
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 14The Montreal Canadiens, leaders In the East Division of the National Hockey League, outclassed and outwitted the New York Rangers tonight with 61 drubbing in the Forum.

title: Gov. Ogilvie Closing the Gap on His Challenger in Illinois Race
description: MOUNT VERNON, Ill., Oct. 13Mayor Richard G. Lugar of Indianopolis was here last night to make a campaign speech for Gov. Richard B. Ogilvie of Illinois.

title: movies
description: WHO says you can't turn Johann Sebastian Bach into Groucho Marx? Certainly not Ken Russell, the daring British director who promises to perform that very miracle in his next film. But that's not the film MGM has paid his fare from London to talk about; they'd settle for a puffy discussion of Savage Messiah, which is to open shortly in New York.

title: Funds Asked fordoHoKus Mansion
description: HOHOKUSOnce it was called the center of the most elegant society in the vicinity; today it stands a blind, derelict ghost, halfhidden by overgrown shrubs and weeds, its windows boarded and doors padlocked against vandals.

title: Views of Review
description: To THE EDITOR: Bias dies hard. Your objective report of the American Council of Education's meeting on Women in Higher Education, in The Week in Review of Oct. S, included bar diagrams labeled Faculty WomenStill Not Equal. The aim was presumably to dramatize visually the inequities suffered by women faculty members with respect to rank and salaries. Somehowsurely not inadvertentlythe graphic data that would have shown the blatant discrimination most effectively were left out!

title: Suffolk Draws Thousands With Foreign Parentage
description: Suffolk County was the principal magnet in the tristate metropolitan area for many thousands of foreign birth or parentage who moved out of New York City in the last decade.

title: Quebec Separatist Party's Loss In 2 ByElections Dims Future
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 14Quebec separatists have suffered possibly their most serious setback since the Parti Quebecois was formed less than three years ago. The decisive defeats of party candidates in two byelections last week are viewed here as casting a pall on the separatist party's future.

title: TALKS ON SPECIFICS IN PARIS INDICATED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 The Nixon Administration has let it be known that it believes Henry A. Kissinger's latest negotiations with the North Vietnamese in Paris were more concerned with substantive issues and less with polemics than in any of the previous sessions.

title: NIXON APPOINTS 16 TO TWO COUNCILS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI)  President Nixon appointed seven persons yesterday to the Consumer Advisory Council, a 12member group that advises the President on policies relating to consumer interests.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: Federal officials who see automated people movers as a promising answer to urban transportation problems have picked Denver as the first big city in which to demonstrate the concept.

title: Historians of West Are Shedding Cowboy Image and Gaining Acceptance
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 14Historians of the American West like to recall a possibly apocryphal incident that occurred when their brilliant colleague, the late Prof. Walter Prescott Webb of the University of Texas, spent a sumther at Harvard writing a history of the Western frontier.

title: Pop
description: FOLK singer John Denver is beginning to look like television's next youth culture golden boy. With the departure of the Smothers Brothers and the only intermittent success of David Steinberg, the networks have been hard put to find a performer who is both bland enough and volatile enough to appeal to both ends (and the middle, too) of those critical Nielsen demographics. With a couple of successful youthoriented specials, numerous talk show appearances, and several upcoming television projects already in hand, Denver just might become one of America's most familiar faces in the next year or so.

title: Mobile Ham Radio Operators on L.I. Are Banded Together
description: Gerald Gold, known also as K2SCI, mobile, eased his convertible out of his driveway and headed east on the Long Island Expressway. He took his microphone in one hand and pushed the talk button.

title: DELAWARE SUBDUES CONNECTICUT, 327
description: STORRS, Conn., Oct. 14 (AP) Verne Roberts and Blair Caviness scored, two touchdowns each today to lead Delaware to its ninth straight football victory, routing Connecticut, 327.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: WILL interest rates rise further? Almost certainly yes. Will there be a new credit crunch next year? Probably not. Should there be a tax increase in 1973? Not necessarily. Will there be one? Very unlikely for next year but perhaps for 1974. Should Government spending be reduced? Yes, indeed.

title: Paris Seeks to Become Headquarters Of the Broadened Common Market
description: PARIS, Oct. 14Fifteen years after it was created, the Common Market has only a temporary headquarters, a point that is noted on its official stationery.

title: Army Is Trounced By Penn State, 450
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 14 John Hufnagel, Penn Slate's quarterback, returned today to Michie Stadium, the scene of his first start and first big success in college football, and turned in one of the hest performances of his career in leading the Nittany Lions to a 450 victory over Army.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: In a recent issue of the Arts and Leisure section there was an article by Donal Henahan about the opera in which he stated that salaries were in fact higher than indicated by the contracts signed because of the tacit understanding that the star would call in sick periodically so as to increase his or her per performance pay. It would appear that this is true of the legitimate theater as well.

title: Four novels: dewinding, competing, indulging and breaking free
description: Although its setting is Californiaand New York, Gail Godwin's second novel seems to take place in a silent, unnamed landscape in which snow or cotton blunt and muffle the sounds that its characters and the outside world otherwise might rnal. Surrounded by this padding is Francesca Bolt, a pampered young woman who is almost literally dying of emptiness and passivity as the treasured possession of her husband,powerful, remote, allcompetent Cameron, who needs her to fulfill the only function he can't perform for himself: to be his flawlessly beautiful wife.

title: LATINS GET HELP IN AID FOR POOR
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 Representatives of 19 national development foundations that are helping the poor of Latin America to help themselves with lowinterest loans concluded a twoday meeting here yesterday with pledges of funding and support from United States and other international lending agencies.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: As long as Paul Good has seen fit to use a quote attributed to me that appeared in an earlier New York Times Magazine article as a peg for his Sept. 17 piece Gun Nutor Pistol Enthusiast?, I feel I must point out that he has lifted thy statement out of context and applied it indiscriminately to gun owners in the United States.

title: The Nation
description: Well, in our country, said Alice, still panting a little, you'd generally get to somewhere elseif you ran very fast for a long time as we've been doing.

title: Bowdoin Seeks Millions
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Oct. 14 (AP)  Bowdoin College announced today a 175th anniversary fundraising drive seeking $14.5million in the next three years and $38million over the next decade.

title: Miss Hennig Is Bride
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Oct. 14Miss Jennifer Lee Hennig and Carl FriisJacobsen were married here this afternoon by the Rev. John Van Zanten in the First Presbyterian Church. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George Carl Hennig. Dr. Hennig is associate in medicine at the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons in New York. The bridegroom is son of Mr. and,&Mrs. Carl FriisJacobscn of Arendal, Norway, where his father, now retired, was chief accountant at Den norske Creditbank.

title: Local
description: George Mason plunged 1 yard for six points and Brooklyn Tech's third victory as the Engineers pulled out a 2221 decision over Lafayette in a Brooklyn Division I game at Lafayette. Tech is undefeated in league play and 31 overall; Lafyaette is 21 in the league and 22 for the season.

title: A kind of Whole Earth Catalog of the counterculture
description: Michael Rossman's activism was born in Berkeley and came of age in the combats of 1964. In the wake of the Free Speech Movement, he dropped out from his apprenticeship to the technological priesthoodhe was teaching assistant and graduate student in mathematicsto become an itinerant organizer in educational reform. He issued an earlier report, passionate and often vivid, on Movement events in The Wedding Within the War (1971). Now, in On Learning and Social Change, he has provided part of an answer to the question of what transformations sixties activism must undergo as we move into the seventiesand the activists into their thirties. The book is in fact shaped by an underlying concern with the passage from an age in which change seemed within our grasp, into the decade when it begins to get hard, after the easy dreams of the sixties: when Amerika's true resistance to change, and for each of us our own, begins to come into the open.

title: B. Y. U. Topples U. T. E. P.
description: PROVO, Utah, Oct. 14 (AP)Fete Van Valkenburg rushed for two touchdowns to lead Brigham Young to a 2114 Western Athletic conference victory over TexasEl Paso today. Vanvalkenburg carried the ball 22 times for 67 yards, including touchdown runs of 10 and 5 yards.

title: Josh
description: There's no question about it: Josh is a beautifully written book. It has won the British Carnegie Medal and its Australian author has been honored for other books as well.

title: Gardens
description: MANY tropical plants will thrive for years in heated homes if there is sunshine.

title: Little Did My Grandma Know
description: HAVING told everybody so many top secrets, I would like to rest a while. But conscience presses me forward because I am aware that some of you want to know how to get big in television. I am now addressing those for whom the legitimate theater is not a viable answer. (The question doesn't matter. Either you got too soft of a voice, or eating every couple days means something to you, or just your feet get hot pounding the pavements, as we say on the Great White Way.) So television is more like your natural habitat.

title: Large Suburbs Overtaking Cities In Number of Jobs They Provide
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14The mushrooming suburbs of America's major metropolitan areas, which already have more population than the cities that produced them, are fast approaching an even more striking milestone in urbanization.

title: DropIn Office Is Lending a Hand to the Troubled in Newark
description: NEWARKA sign that hangs in a downtown storefront office says: I can get by with a little help from my friends.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor: Earaches and Flying
description: Regarding the reopening of train travel between Montreal and New York, one sometimes gets the feeling that the people who run AMTRAK don't want it to succeed. The new train will only run at night, thus depriving travelers of one of the main attractions of train travel: seeing the country. Moreover, while the coach fare of $19.50 is reasonable, if one wants to sleep (and who would want to sit up all night staring into the darkness?) one is obliged to purchase a firstclass ticket which, together with the roomette, comes to the ludicrous sum of $47more than the air ticket!

title: CELTICS TRIUMPH OVER BULLS, 9688
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (AP)Don Chaney and John Havlicek scored 9 consecutive points in a threeminute flurry and then added 6 more to pull the redhot Boston Celtics to a 9688 triumph tonight over the Chicago Bulls in a National Basketball Association contest.

title: Peter E. Lynn to Marry Robin J. Altchek
description: Dr. and Mrs. Maurice Richard Altchek of Brooklyn and Danbury, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Robin Jane Altchek to Peter Edward Lynn. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Lynn of Jericho, L. I.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article A Luxury Building Strives for Stability [Sept. 24] was, like New York law, biased in favor of the landlord.

title: Education
description: For the past two years, the 18member Fleischmann Commission has been making a massive study of education in New York State at the behest of Governor Rockefeller and the Legislature. In its first report last January, the commission called for the state to take over the raising and distributing of all nonFederal funds for public schools, emphasizing the need for parity among rich and poor school districts and the need to reform property taxes, the main source of funds for education.

title: Growing Scrutable
description: On the record of one year in the United Nations, the People's Republic of China has shown itself to be neither wrecker nor catalyst in the institutions of world diplomacy. Chinese spokesmen remain uncompromising in verbal endorsement of the principles of global revolution, but the actual behavior of the Peking Government follows the dictates of classic power politics by traditional nationstates.

title: A'S TOP REDS IN OPENER, 3 TO 2, ON TENACE S 2 HOMERS; HARVARD TRIPS COLUMBIA, 2018
description: Harvard turned back Columbia, 2018, in an Ivy League game at Baker Field yesterday in which conversion points proved vital. Profiting by three Lion fumbles, the Crimson repeated its victory of a year ago when it held off the Lions at Cambridge, 2119.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor: Earaches and Flying
description: I feel that the doctor's response to the reader's inquiry regarding the problem of earache and flying in the letters column (Travel section, Sept. 17) fails to approach the most important part of the problem. Many people develop pain in the ear during the descent phase of flying without having suffered any prior difficulties or respiratory infections. I have used a simple method suggested to me by a professional associate who is a specialist in this field. About 30 minutes before descent, it as suggested that the nose be sprayed several times with a decongestant such as neosynephrine, or similar medication. This apparently permits enough shrinking of the nasal passage and opening of the Eustachian tubes to neutralize the differences in air pressure as the plane descends. I have found that this has almost always prevented the severe pain that I had previcmsly observed in members of my family. This method has also been used with success by other people.

title: SeeandTouch Museum Is Moving in Brooklyn
description: Every day, 7yearold AddSomtners Visits the Brooklyn Children's Museum, called MUSE. He beams with pride as he looks at his own drawing Man on the Moon. Susan Applebaum, a 16yearold counselortrainee, took an optical illusion test and watched her eyes play tricks. Which line is longer? the quiz asked. Are the two horizontal lines parallel? Which distance is longer?

title: PILOTS STILL LIKE THE JINXED F111
description: TA KHLI AIR BASE, Thailand (AP)Standing under the wing of an F111, Lieut. Col. Glen R. Ludy remarked, Flying this airplane after anything else Is like driving a Cadillac after a Chevy.

title: To the Thinking Horse in 1910, It Was o Temporal o Mores!
description: BEFORE my father acquired our first automobile, the Mitchell Six, a succession of beloved horses named Romeo, Juliet, Merrylegs and Beauty had drawn the wagons, carriages and buggies of our family, and these horses were still talked about like absent friends. Around 1910 our horse was Dow. I remember Dow as a medium brown, medium elderly, gentlemanly horse, sociable and fond of children. He drew us to church on Sundays in the surrey. He took my father off in the

title: MEN'S WEAR
description: Many men who don't even know what coordinates are may wind up wearing them this fall. At least that's the intention of men's wear retailers, who are filling their counters and racks with the colorful items.

title: OHIO STATE BEATS ILLINI TEAM, 267
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 14 (AP)  Harold Henson bulled over for three touchdowns today, powering Ohio State to 267 Big Ten triumph over Illinois.

title: Irving's De Profundis
description: Clifford Irving's book on the Hughes affair (What Really Happened, Grove, paper $1.95) may be the first autobiography ever written under oath. Irving tells us, Robert Morvillo, Chief of the Criminal Division of the United States Attorney's Office of the Southern District of New York has explained to meand without mincing his wordsthat if the facts contained in this book are at variance with sworn testimony and the body of truth known to the prosecutors and the courts, Richard Suskind and I are open to a charge of perjury which carries a sentence of up to five years imprisonment. Since Irving is now serving a twoandahalf year sentence and Richard Suskind six months, that fiveyear beef should indeed serve as a puissant truthdetector.

title: Bridge
description: Tournament players and rubber bridge players are two quite different breeds. The tournament player likes to earn prestige, and expects the security provided by a good bidding understanding with a regular partner. The rubber bridge player is less scientific but more adaptable; he will tolerate the frequent vagaries of incompetent partners, knowing that each one will be an opponent twice as often as a partner, and in return for the satisfaction of some financial gain he will accept the possibility of corresponding losses.

title: Headliners
description: People only read my poetry because they see my beastly face on television, said Sir John Betjeman in 1961. I will be completely forgotten five years from now. Some indication of his error was forthcoming last week; he was designated Britain's Poet Laureate. The title dates back to Chaucer's time and has been occupied by such awesome figures as Wordsworth and Tennyson, plus some lesser breeds without the awe. The theory, more honored in the breach of late, is that Laureates dash off verse for state occasions. Not Sir John. I cannot write to order, he said. He is possibly his nation's most popular poet, and not simply because of his TV appearances (often as a crusader for the preservation of Victorian landmarks). Said The Times of London: His success restored people's faith poetry as a public metier  instead of stepping further into deeper and abstract thought, like some of his modern colleagues, he revived the traditions of English poetry that we learnt and sometimes loved at school.

title: The Nation
description: SIOUX FALLS, S. D.At the tag end of a bonewearying tour last week that took him from the black ghettos of Baltimore and Philadelphia through labor halls, colleges and meetings of party regulars on into the cornfields of Iowa, Sargent Shriver squeezed in one last trip.

title: Nassau Volunteers Sought For Food Aid Program
description: WOODMERE, L. I.  The Five Towns Community Council is seeking volunteers to assist in a program designed to reach those people who are over 65 who may be eligible for the Federal Food Assistance Program.

title: BUTZ IS ACCUSED ON COTTON PRICES
description: BOSTON, Oct. 14 (AP)Jean Westwood, chairman of the National Democratic Committee, said here today that the Nixon, Administration had deliberately and incorrectly predicted a substantial increase in market demand for cotton, thereby producing a huge surplus and a sharp drop in prices.

title: Four novels: dewinding, competing, indulging and breaking free
description: Welcome to Nihilon, where nihilism is the official philosophy of the land ( selfexpression plus selfindulgence equals nihilism ), the old are sent to war because the young are too precious, bribes and extortion are the rule, only drunken driving is allowed,and fatal auto accidents are used as a form of population control. There is also lots of nudity, a constant trend toward border war and internal revolution, and a general flavor of chaos, or, at least, great disorder, prevails: President Nil decrees that life should be a great lawless adventure. Here, those who long for order and safety must do so secretiy, and people are jailed for being honest. A prologue explains that since most of the capitalistic freedomjoving nations are going in the same direction,  five researchers are being dispatched to Nihilon to gather material for a guidebook (the last one was prepared 25 years ago).

title: THE 1972 CSAPAIGN
description: JEFFERSON, Iowa, Oct. 13The golden hoods of corn and soybeans are surging out of the Middle West, and they are far more golden this fall than usual.

title: Vida Always True Blue, A Team Man, He Says
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 14The Oakland A's may be doing the Cincinnati Reds a favor by scheduling Vida Blue to start in the fourth game of the World Series.

title: Jane E. Tuohy, Leo Whelan Jr. Married on L.I.
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 14Miss Jane Ellen Tuohy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Tuohy, was married here today to Leo Augustus Whelan Jr., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Whelan of Belmont, Mass. The ceremony was performed in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Walter J. Burghardt, editor of the publication Theological Studies, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Ballet Company to Perform in New Rochelle Tuesday
description: ORANGE  In its 14 years, the New Jersey Ballet Company has rarely had a week as busy as the one now coming up.

title: Instead of fighting for a place on it,
description: A shaft of light cuts through the gloom of the Las Vegas Hilton's Ballroom Internationale, striking a slight figure in a blue plaid suit standing just below the stage. An enamel American flag gleams in his lapel, a heavy gold peace medallion hangs from his neck; his right hand, resplendent with precious stones and their settings, is raised in victory salute. As the applause mounts, the hand contracts into a black fist, then drops, a gesture so brief as to pass almost unnoticed.

title: Oklahoma State Loses
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., Oct. 14 (AP)Dave Strock booted an 18yard field goal with 12 seconds remaining today and Virginia Tech's eleven scored a 3432 upset of 19thranked Oklahoma State.

title: SAIGON REPORTS SHARP FIGHTING
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Slipday, Oct. 15 (AP)Sharp but scattered fighting was reported across South Vietnam yesterday and United States planes maintained the intensity of their bombing assault against the North.

title: Yonkers Will Vote on a Proposal Abolishing the City Manager
description: YONKERS, Oct. 14  One politician here says there is a sleeper on the Nov. 7 ballot in Yonkersa proposition that leas aroused little voter interest, but, according to political and civic leaders, could strongly influence the future of the state's fourth largest city.

title: China Pushes the Teaching of the Roman Alphabet
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 14In a rural commune in China's Chekiang Province the peasants management committee has called on all teachers to develop the ability to render the Chinese language phonetically and to give lessons in standard Chinese.

title: Local
description: George Washington, playing its first season of varsity football since 1941, won its first game in four starts yesterday by defeating Monroe, 286, in a ManhattanBronx P.S.A.L. game at Washington Field.

title: If It Isn't Banned, Foyle's Should Have It
description: FOYLE'S occupies a clutter of buildings on Charing Cross Road in London. It stocks about five million books, new and old, on 40 miles of shelves. On an average day it will be patronized by thousands of book lovers, who will mingle with numerous shoplifters, several hundred employes and one house detective. The scene, it has been said, is a perfect preview of the last stages of chaos.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: MMVINA REYNOLDS: Nialvina (Cassandra CFS 2807). Some people just won't stay put in the grooves of their records. This bit of plastic looks like an album, it's wrapped up like an album, but it's actually more like an Aladdin's lamp. There is a person inside who, given the chance, will emerge in threedimensional, almost tangible form, spin right off your turntable, plant herself in front of you and make you pay attention whether you had intended to or not. Malvina Reynolds will not be ignored. She knows she has things to say, and she probably knows that she says them better than any of her followers and emulators.

title: Contempt Citations Upheld For 2 Louisiana Newsmen
description: BATON ROUGE, Oct. 14 (AP) United States Court Judge E. Gordon West has upheld his earlier contempt conviction of two Baton Rouge newsmen because they published reports of, an open hearing held in the judge's court.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAING
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 14The, Fire Department's mobile intensive coronary care unit accompanied Senator George McGovern's motorcade yesterday in Seattle, A van from New York City's mobile disaster unit blocked his path in the Columbus Day parade. A bus in his San Francisco entourage last nightFriday the 13thcould start only by rolling downhill, and then it crashed into a taxicab.

title: NINA JOINS U. S. IN AN ARMS ISSUE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 14  Separately and for different reasons, the United States and China have come out against a world disarmament conference proposed by the Soviet Union.

title: The Best American Short Stories 1972
description: The Yeats quotation was given me several years ago by an editor at The New Yorker. The Schweitzer came off the wall of a drycleaning establishment up the street from my old apartment in New York. They are both essential to the success of a short story.

title: Theater: Virginia Woolf en Espanol
description: Who's afraid of Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? in Spanish? Anyway, don't be afraid, even if you don't understand a word. By now, isn't everybody more than familiar with what's going on?

title: Joe Cocker Held in Australia
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Oct. 14 (AP)  Joe Cocker, the British rock star, and six members of his group were arrested and charged with possession of marijuana today after policemen raided their hotel suite Mr. Cocker and the others were released on bail.

title: Udalls Cove Park Backed by Planners
description: The City Planning Commission has unanimously approved plans to create a wetlands wildlife refuge on the Queens side of Udalls Cove.

title: 2 Italian Jets Collide in Air
description: PADUA. Italy, Oct. 14 (AP). Two Italian Air Force fighterbombers collide in flight today and crashed near Ronchi. Roth pilots were killed, authorities reported.

title: Lucy Stephens Lyden Fiancee Of Robert Stephen Anderson
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 14  Miss Lucy Stephens Lyden, personnel manager for Kenyon & Eckhardt, advertising agency in New York, and Robert Stephen Anderson, a vice president in the research department of the New York Securities Company in New York, have made plans to be married next March.

title: JOHN S. WILSON'S
description: STONY BROOK, L.I. The series of winter jazz concerts, which an organization of jazz buffs called the International Art of Jazz, has been putting on in Suffolk County since 1964 is moving into an academic atmosphere for the first time this year.

title: Preps
description: HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., Oct. 14 Peddie allowed Admiral Farragut only one first down and 20 total yards in romping to a 330 victory. Scot Toth a middle guard, anchored the defense and returned an intercepted pass 20 yards. Toth was one of five Peddie players to score touchdowns.

title: Soviet Orbits Satellite
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 14 (AP)The Soviet Union orbited today a new Molniya1 communication satellite to maintain telephone, telegraph and television service with distant parts of this huge country. The satellite will provide communication and television transmission to the extreme north, Siberia, the Soviet Far East and Central Asia, Tass, the official news agency, said.

title: Marina Plan Is Opposed by L.L Conservationists
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I.Local conservationists are up in arms about a proposal to improve marina facilities here that they say will do irreparable damage to what they consider to be the last unspoiled, harbor on Long Island's North Shore.

title: NOTRE DAME TOPS PITT TEAM, 4216
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 14 (AP)  A 56yard touchdown run by Art Best, a freshman carrying the ball for the first time for Notre Dame, capped la 4216 Irish victory over Pittiburgh today.

title: U.S. Holds Price Line On Income Tax Book
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP)The Internal Revenue Service, the agency charged with enforcing price controls, has succeeded in talking the Government Printing Office out of increasing the price of one of its bestsellers, Your Federal Income Tax.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: DEAR Joan, We're Going To Interview You To Death. That could as easily have been your headline, rather than I'm Still an Actress! I Want to Act!

title: The man who made the rag business respectable
description: For half a century, women have treasured their Norells as if they were emeralds or Renoirs. They wear them lovingly for years, content that they're dressed in the best that money can buy, then pack them away respectfully because they can't bear to part with them. A Norell dress never seems to wear out.

title: LETTERS
description: In her article Campaign's Economic Nonsense (Sept. 17), Eileen Shanahan deplores the lack of meaningful debate on economic issues during the present Presidential campaign. Such an issue is Senator George McGovern's tax program and, in particular, his recommendation that unrealized capital gains be taxed at death.

title: Supermoney
description: Delighted with the assignment to review Adam Smith's new surefire best seller, we decided not to trust our judgment, but to seek counsel from a real insider, Harry the Hedge. Harry joined the trainee program at Merrill Lynch after graduating from Penn State, and then started out as a customer's man at the White Plains office. He was a great success selling Steel to Westchester ladies investment clubs, and might have been promoted to office manager some day if he had not answered the call of the Great Bull Market. Harry went out on his own with 26 of his biggest customers in 1965 and made $31million following the fortunes of Kentucky Fried Chicken and Four Seasons Nursing Homes. Five per cent of the first 2million and per cent of the next 29 was his. Not really big league, but enough for a standing invitation to meatball sandwiches at Scarsdale Fats.

title: Son Born to Mrs. Nesti
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 14 A son was born Sept. 16 to Dr. and Mrs. Richard P. Nesti at the Vermont Medical Center. Mrs. Nesti, as Dr. Frances Nesti, is a pediatrician with offices here and in Essex Junction, where her husband, an orthopedic surgeon, has his practice. The child has been named Leon John.

title: Maine Paper Prefers Nixon
description: PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 14The Maine Sunday Telegram will say in an editorial tomorrow that, given a choice whether to hire President Nixon or Senator George McGovern as President of the United States, it would hire Nixon as the better man for the job. The newspaper is the only one published in Maine on Sunday.

title: Mayor to Expand His Power to Promote
description: Mayor Lindsay plans to introduce major changes in the muchcriticized city civil service system aimed at expanding his ability to select and promote new employes.

title: Health Foods Only a Fad?
description: LOS ANGELES  Will Crunchy Granbla ever replace Rice Krispies? Can tiger's milk and rose hip vitamin C ever become as American as applie pie?

title: Television
description: WHEN the new television season began a few weeks ago, a visiting critic from London kept clipping reviews out of the daily paper, proudly professing, I am told, that in his country such lavish attention is never devoted to such trivia as an ordinary TV series. It is precisely this kind of cultural myopia, tinged with elitist snobbery, that may account, at least partially, for the decline of the British Empire.

title: New & Novel
description: Ditch Valley is Gopher Prairie revisited, albeit in the original accents of a fresh, new voice. Daryl Henderson writes of a Kansas hometown (193971) in a manner calculated to create a collage of impressions: sharp, bitter, darkly reminiscent.

title: Oklahoma Woman Honored For South American Flights
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) Geraldine Cobb, Oklahomaborn pilot, was named whiner of the Harmon Aviatrix Trophy today for a series of humanitarian flights last year over the Amazon Basin.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Sheed's article does us all disservice.

title: Scotland Students Apologize To Queen for Demonstration
description: STIRLING, Scotland, Oct. 14 (Reuters)A petition signed by 930 Stirling University students today expressed apologies to Queen Elizabeth II for a rowdy demonstration against her during a campus tour Thursday.

title: 2,000 Years in Flesh and Stone
description: They are 20thcentury creatures with earthtoearth problems; they bargain, giggle and mention Brigitte Bardot as an earnest of their knowall. They wear Tshirts made in the U.S.A.

title: Tories Leave Convention With a Surface Bravura
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 14 Conservative party delegates, welltailored, wellcoiffured and welllectured, streamed out of the Empress Ballroom at noon today after four days of pledges, parties and politics.

title: Movies
description: WHERE do you go from Young Winston? Old Winston? No, not if you're writerproducer Carl Foreman, who dropped by the other day to put in a good word for his current movie about the tender years of Winston Churchill and to tell us about his next film, Finding Ernie. And, for the first time since The Victors in 1963, Foreman will also serve as director, working from a script by John Collier. If you're a working moviemaker, Foreman says, it's only natural to have that drive to direct., Actually, I wanted to direct High Noon back in 1952until we were. fortunate enough to sign Fred Zinnemann. Finding Ernie is a big challenge; it's about a British girl who builds a raft and is determined to sail it from South America to Australia.

title: 3 People, 50 Numbers, 3 Cheers
description: O H Coward! is an island of entertainment in the sea of our troubles. And a tight little island it is. Tightness is its quality, its special merit, the key to its merriment. A glazed gentleman with pale eyes named Roderick Cook, whose hauteur has the quality of talcum powder on ice, has carefully scanned every note Noel Coward ever wrote, plucked 50 or more of the very best tunes from the lot, made certain that he and two companion performers could not only remember the lyrics but could pitterpatter them at us as though their tongues were typewriter keys, and has then frozen them in space, imperturbably, impeccably.

title: Dance
description: IT would be impossible for anyone to keep up with everything that is going on in American dance nowadaysthere is simply too much of it. Last week, for example, the City Center Joffrey Ballet was in residence at the New York City Center, and at the ANTA Theater the City Center Dance Marathon continued with appearances by the Jose Limn Dance Company, the Rod Rodgers Dance Company. Lotte Goslar's Pantomime Circus, the Bella Lewitsky Dance Company, Carmen de Lavallade and Pauline Koner. Across the river in Brooklyn the Dancers of Mali had a week's season, and last night the Harkness Ballet appeared at the Colden Center in Queens. The Ballet Players were at Riverside Church, Gus Solomons Jr. and his company appeared at the Cubiculo, and also later at the Cubiculo there was a dance concert with Toby Armour, the Chuck Davis Dance Company, the Laura Foreman Dance Company, Phoebe Neville, Ken Rinker and Kei Takei. Another concert was given by Charles Stanley.

title: An eclectic experiment in prestovaudeville
description: Most critical works on Aristophanes are about as useful as Aristophanes's criticism of Euripidesand less amusing. The epithet Aristophanic (usually interchangeable with Rabelaisian) denotes coarse humor, addenda to pudenda, and the comic cacophony of belches and slaps with a stick. A lively association, but no reason to rank him as a classic. Then there is the joyless view of Aristophanes the politician, denouncer of despotism and militarism, the passionate pacifist. To prove this, one need go no furtherand few dothan the Lysistrata. Nowadays this play is offered as dramatic anticipation of the Women's Strike for Peace, lifted to high art by a tidal wave of synonyms for the sexual act. 0 Aristophanes, you were brave, thoughtful, committed and free!

title: Pots, Pans and Peppercorns
description: MIDLAND PARKTullio Cominetto has to be the busiest man in town. Mtsician artist, writer, teacher of gourmet cooking, and most recently the proprietor of the PanTree, a shop that carries an extensive line of professional cooking ware.

title: TROTTERS MOVING TO WESTBURY OVAL
description: Mindful that Yonkers Raceway concluded its season last night with maxisized deficits in attendance (17.3 per cent) and mutuel handle (7.9), and the management at Roosevelt Raceway will be striving for a softer drop in both categories, when Part 3 of the Nassau County threeply harness racing campaign gets under way at the Westbury plant on Long Island tomorrow night.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: I feel called upon to set the record straight in a sensitive area. Maurice Peterson, in an interview with Ron O'Neal, quotes O'Neal as saying that I frankly told him, I really don't think Black people should do Shakespeare. O'Neal remembers incorrectly what for him was, no doubt, an unsatisfactory conversation. I did not make the remark attributed to me, and the past gives ample evidence of my real position on this matter.

title: Uruguayan Plane With 45 Is Missing on Andes Flight
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 14 (Reuters)Chilean Air Force planes searched today for Uruguayan Air Force transport plane missing over the Andes with 45 people aboard, including players and supporters of a Montevideo rugby team.

title: Girl Scouts Find Prospect Park Map to Point
description: In midJuly, a team of Girl Scout leaders met near Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn to test the efficacy of a new map designed to enhance the public's enjoyment of Prospect Park and the Botanic Gardens. The assay was a walking tour of much of the bushveld covered by the map, and the Girl Scout leaders chosen to participate had had no previous experience in the use of detailed cartographic materials.

title: Local
description: Ron West repeatedly swept past defenders as he amassed 187 yards rushing to lead Brandeis to a 3612 trouncing of Stuyvesant. West, a junior halfback scored three touchdowns on runs of 35, 66 and 61 yards. Jose DelGado scored the other two touchdowns on pass receptions.

title: Stoned thinking
description: A New Way of Looking at Drugs and the Higher Consciousness. By Andrew Weil. 229 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $5.95.

title: Cougars Conquer Nets, 12678, for 3d Straight Victory as Cunningham Stars
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Oct. 14 The Carolina Cougars lambasted the New York Nets, 12678, in an American Basketball Association game tonight to post their third straight victory. They had previously beaten Virginia and Indiana.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP)The. Federal Aviation Administration imposed yesterday a truthinleasing law on individual operators of charter flights.

title: Blast Kills 7 South Koreans
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 14 (Reuters)Seven persons, including five South Korean soldiers, were killed yesterday when a rocket shell that was picked up in a rice paddy exploded, reports reaching here said today. Ten other soldiers and six villagers were injured in the six explosion, which occurred near the frontier with North Korea, about 30 miles northeast of here.

title: Mr. Hoving's Lemonade Stand
description: IF you have a taste for that sinister form of humor called black comedy, the Metropolitan Museum has been offering a fortnight of laff riots as its opening attraction of the season. But the show hasn't really been all that funny, even though one must admire the aplomb of its star, Thomas P. F. Hoving, who, having been taken by surprise as the villain of the piece, improvised a performance in which he assumed the role of hero.

title: Story of Tombs Suicide: Lapse in Communication
description: In the two weeks before he hanged himself with bedsheet in his cell at the Tombs on Sept. 9, William Wing showed repeated and unmistakable signs that he was psychotic and bent on selfdestruction.

title: FOREIGNERS BUY HOMES IN ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 14  More than 11 per cent of the investment in residences in Israel last year was made by foreign Jews, mostly Americans, purchasing second homes. The $45million they are estimated to have spent is quite apart from the substantial investment by those who have moved here.

title: Ronny Greenwald Wed to Fellow Lawyer
description: GREAT NECK ESTATES, L. L. Oct. 14Miss Ronny Jo Greenwald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin D. Greenwald, was married here this evening to Joel Davis Siegal of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Siegal of Plainfield, N. J., and Hallandale, Fla. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 The most certain thing about the 1972 governorship elections is uncertainty.

title: Rev. C. A. Bevan Jr. Weds Nina V Flick
description: BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Oct. 14Miss Nina Virginia Flick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George. Luther Flick Jr., of Glen Ridge, was married here this evening to the Rev. Charles Albert Bevan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bevan of Camden.

title: Nixon Aide Is Called a Contact for Political Spying
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14  A 32yearold California lawyer has sworn that a former employe of the Treasury Department told him that he engaged in undercover activities in behalf of efforts to reelect President Nixon and that his White House contact was Dwight L. Chapin, the President's appointments secretary, The Washington Post reported tonight.

title: Miss Hulton Has Nuptials
description: In the chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Stephanie Jane Hulton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adam Stephen Campbell Hulton of New York, became the bride of Edward Arthur McCabe. The Rev. Dr. Victor Baer performed the ceremony.

title: Belgrade Lets Food Prices Rise Despite Protests by Union Chiefs
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 14Responding to the forces of Marxist Yugoslavia's market economy, sugar began to reappear this week on the shelves of supermarkets and neighborhood groceries. But the event produced few smiles from shoppers when they noted the new price, up 7.5 per cent.

title: Efforts Intensified Here  In LetterBomb Search
description: An official of the United States Postal Inspection Services here said yesterday that for the last month the agency had shifted personnel and employed sophisticated devices to intercept letter bombs such as the one that exploded yesterday in a Bronx post office.

title: NEBRASKA ROUTS MISSOURI, 62 TO 0
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 14 (AP)  Dave Humm threw three touchdown passes and Johnny Rodgers posted a record today as Nebraska defeated Missouri, 1620.

title: COLORADO DOWNS IOWA STATE, 3422
description: BOULDER, Colo., Oct. 14 (AP)Charlie Davis and Steve Haggerty scored two touchdowns apiece and Fred Lima, a barefoot kicker, booted a pair of field goals, including a 57yarder for a Big Eight record, as Colorado whipped Iowa State, 3422, today.

title: Miss Bartlett, Richard Fricks Wed in Suburb
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 14Miss Genevieve Wilson Bartlett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aurelius T. Bartlett 2d, was married here this afternoon to Richard Park Fricks, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Fricks of Rising Fawn, Ga, The Rev, Mark Sisk performed the ceremony in Christ Church Episcopal in Bronxville.

title: The Tooth Trip
description: A hip dentist? Well, practically. Thomas McGuire, D.D.S., has written a simple, slangy book for people who don't know much about teeth  which is almost tverybody. He tells how to examine your teeth, care for your gums, how to eat right, how to act in the dentist's chair. This is not a guide to dentistless dentistry, although you'll see the man less if you follow this dentist's preventivecare program.

title: Victor Davis Werner, 71, Dies; Lawyer and Republican Official
description: Victor Davis Werner, a prominent lawyer here and former vice president of the National Republican Club, died yesterday at North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, L. I. He was 71 years old and lived at 19 Westmoreland Place, Douglaston, Queens.

title: Lakers Trounced Here
description: Joy was unconfined last night at Madison Square Garden for a crowd of 19,694a record for professional basketball in New Yorkas the Knicks played in top form while demolishing the Los Angeles Lakers, the National Basketball Association champions, 125100.

title: Photography
description: EVERYTHING I had heard about Frederick 44 Sommer's photography led me to expect a body of work of a striking spontaneity and originality. So it came as a mild shock that so many of his pictures now at Light gallery (through Nov. 4) look like clever and well  planned translations into photography of images better known in versions done by painters.

title: MonmouthOcean
description: Brick Township, one of the strongest teams in New Jersey, extended its unbeaten streak to 16 games yesterday with 280 victory over Long Branch in Long Branch.

title: 170 Are Reported Killed In Jet Crash in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 14A Soviet Aeroflot Ilyushin62 airliner crashed last night while preparing to land in the rain at Moscow and all aboard were killed in what was apparently the worst civil air disaster in history.

title: The new Millburn Township Law Enforcement Building at 435 Essex Street
description: MILLBURN  A $1.2million Law Enforcement Building, which houses this community's 52man police force and legal institutions, was dedicated here last week.

title: Newhouse Jewels Stolen
description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 14The police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation are investigating the theft of $75,000 in jewels reported yesterday by Mrs. Samuel I. Newhouse, wife of the owner of Newhouse Publi cations. Mrs. Newhouse told the police the jewelry was in her luggage on a flight yesterday from Kennedy Internationa Airport to Syracuse, where the Newhouses attended today's Syracuse Navy football game.

title: Speedy Paroles Questioned By the State's Prosecutors
description: NEW BRUNSWICKProsecutors in the state's 21 counties are questioning the speed with which the New Jersey Bureau of Parole is releasing prisoners.

title: To de Addita:
description: Vell! It is soitenly suprize dot de pipple vot tuk diffrunt from you Vasps have come inta dere own.

title: Trying to Trade With China
description: As the fall portion of the Canton Fair opens its doors today, a number of American businessmen will try again to repair the longtorn ties between the United States and mainland China.

title: Key South Shore Game Struck Down by Strike
description: Followers of Nassau County football will have to wait awhile to discover who's who in the South Shore Division IV race. New Hyde Park and Roosevelt, both undefeated, had their game postponed yesterday because of a teachers strike in the Roosevelt school district.

title: New Inquiry on Kent State Urged by Victims Parents
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) Parents of four Kent State University students killed by National guardsmen two years ago have asked a Federal court to order the investigation into the shooting reopened.

title: Isaac B. Mailer, Accountant, Fatherof the Writer, Was 80
description: Isaac B. Mailer, an accountant and the father of Norman Mailer, the writer, died yesterday of heart failure at his home, 128 Willow Street in the Brooklyn Heights section of Brooklyn. He was 80 years old.

title: Letters:
description: The story on King Arthur's origius recalled our trip to England. We could not resist visiting a spot that was billed in a guidebook as King Arthur's Round Table and located in a village called Eamont Bridge, just south of Penrith which is in the northern Lake Distric of Cumberland and not far from Keswick, the favorite haunt of many poeple We discovered a large field with a depression in the center; and a sign, at cording to my snapshot, read:

title: Miss Molly Crawford Houston Bride of Edward Leo Savard
description: MERIDEN, Conn., Oct. 14 St. Andrew's Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Molly Crawford Houston to Edward Leo Savard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo E. Savard of Easton, Mass.

title: Elks Denied Licenses
description: BOSTON, Oct. 14 (AP)Beano licenses issued to 31 Elks lodges in Massachusetts will not be renewed, the state says, because the organization refuses to admit black members. Letters signed by Gov. Francis W. Sargent were sent to the lodges this week citing a state executive order that directs all state agencies to use their powers to end discrimination.

title: Preps
description: PAWLING, N.Y., Oct. 14 The unbeaten Hotchkiss team has three quarterbacks and each had a chance to throw touchdown pass today in his team's 250 victory over TrinityPawling. It was Hotchkiss's third triumph.

title: Education
description: College newspapers are of an infinite variety. Some concentrate on campus news and gossip. A declining number still serve as a public relations medium for the institution, under the benevolent eye of the faculty adviser. But the trend is toward more cosmic concerns, with the freedom to speak out and to devote much space to national and international news.

title: Pop
description: COMMANDER CODY & HIS LOST PLANET AIRMEN: Hot Licks, Cold Steel & Truckers Favorites (Paramount Records PAS6031). Pianist George Frayne, alias Commander Cody, knows exactly where he's taking his group, whose first album Lost in the Ozone firmly established the unit. That direction is straight down South where the plaintive wail of the pedal steel guitar mingles with the airy sound of the fiddle. Occasionally, Cody and his boys detour into rock n roll guitars and boogie piano music.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I read with great interest Rabbi Tries the Landlord's Role [Sept. 24]. I think it sums up a problem that we haven't been able to solve as yet.

title: Soviet Publishing Officials Cancel Tour of U.S.
description: A scheduled 15day visit to the United States of a delegation of publishing officials from the Soviet Union has been abruptly canceled because of the reported illness of its ranking member.

title: Handbook Available on Parts of Brooklyn
description: A Community Resources Handbook for residents of Brighton Beach, Gerritsen Beach, Manhattan Beach, Coney Island, Sea Gate and Sheepshead Bay has been published by Kingsborough Community College's Institute for Public Service.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTONA judge formerly employed by a governmental agency, declares the new Code of Judicial Conduct approved last August by the American Bar Association, should disqualify himself in a proceeding if his impartiality might reasonably be questioned because of such association.

title: CORAGGIOSO TAKES KEENELAND FEATURE
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 14 (AP)Coraggioso, flying the blue and white of M. E. Waldheim's Bwamazon Farm, tools the lead with a little over an eighth of a mile to go today and won the $55,370 Alcibiades Stakes at Keeneland.

title: Michigan U. Professor Is Reinstated After Ouster for Showing Antiwar Slides Stirs Campus
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 14 The University of Michigan has reinstated a chemistry professor who had been relieved of his teaching duties for showing an antiwar slide show to his organic chemistry classes.

title: A Record Billion in New Funds To Be Available to City in Year
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame announced yesterday that an extraordinary $1.079billion in new funds would be available within the city's debt limit for the next capital budget the highest such growth in the city's history.

title: North Stars Tie Canucks, 11
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 14 (AP)Charlie Burns scored on a wild scramble in front of the net with 8:11 left in the game tonight to lift the Minnesota North Stars to a 33 tie with Vancouver in a seesaw National Hockey League game.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: However serious the question of Black English may be, and however serious its impact on education, Toni Bambara's review of J.L. Dillard's book on that subject (Black English, Sept. 3) failed to convey the seriousness, and failed to rise to the significance of the issue.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I have always thought it ridiculous and demeaning that candidates for high office should be obliged by public pressure to reveal their means. It seems to me that if the voter cannot trust the candidate for the White House or Congress to perform his duties without consulting his portfolio, the candidate should not be elected.

title: A Course for Blacks Is Periled
description: TRENTONA basiceducation experimental program, developed by and for the black community here, may be forced out of existence despite praise by educators, a positive preliminary evaluation by a national testing service and parental support.

title: Curry Tops Bridgewater
description: MILTON, Mass., Oct. 14 (AP) Tom Rollins and Brad Quinn turned Bridgewater mistakes into touchodwns today as Curry coasted to a 206 victory.

title: World News Briefs
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Oct. 14  Uganda troops killed 35 guerrillas captured during last month's abortive invasion from Tanzania during a riot at an army camp, a military spokesman announced today.

title: A Judge Breaks Tradition, Letting Jurors Take Notes
description: HACKENSACK  Bergen County Judge Arthur J. ODea has broken with a courtroom tradition that prohibits jurors from taking notes during a trial. The tradition dates to the signing of the Magna Carta 700 years ago.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor: Earaches and Flying
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Fire Officer and 3 Others Die As Ozone Park Building Burns
description: Four persons, including a 50yearold fire lieutenant who suffered a heart attack, died early today as a fire engulfed an old threestory frame building in the Ozone Park section of Queens. Several firemen were treated at the scene for injuries.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Senate gave final Congressional approval yesterday to a bill establishing the Gateway National Recreation Area at the entrance to New York Harbor. The measure authorizing what in effect would be the first national park in a heavily congested urban area was passed routinely in the Congressional adjournment rush and now goes to President Nixon, who undoubtedly will sign it since he has supported the project.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: In a recent Good Word column. Wilfrid Sheed states that Ezra Pound was against pogroms. Pound broadcast twice a week on the Italian Fascist radio. Transcripts of his broadcasts were made by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: G. M. Rolling in Korea
description: SEOUL, South KoreaThe General Motors Corporation has begun producing cars in South Korea in a joint venture with the Shinjin Motor Company. G. M. is the first American auto manufacturer to make a direct equity investment in Korea.

title: U.S. Servicemen May Send and Get Heavier Packages
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 United States servicemen overseas may now receive and send larger parcels of mail.

title: Sugar Beet Raisers Agree to Purchase Largest Processor;
description: The Great Western Producers Cooperative, representing thousands of sugar beet growers, signed a purchase agreement yesterday to acquire the Great Western Sugar Company, the nation's largest processor of beet sugar, for what is expected to be about $90million.

title: L.I. U.'s Brooklyn Center Begins Work on Library
description: The Brooklyn Center of Long Island University, noted for its constant expansion over the last few years, has begun construction of a new library.

title: Mrs. McGovern Is Better
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) Mrs. George McGovern, the wife of the Democratic Presidential nominee, was reported in excellent condition today after suffering an attack of abdominal pains. But doctors kept her in. Georgetown University Hospital over the weekend to rest before she goes back on the campaign trail.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Unless Le Duc Tho and Dr. Henry Kissinger are engaged in an incredible international hoax designed to get President Nixon reelected, which not even cynical old Nixonwatchers are likely to believe, there probably are only two possible explanations for their repeated secret meetings, the last of which went on for four days.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 14 (UPI)Senior military commanders of India and Pakistan began today their seventh round of talks at the Indian border post of Suchetgarh on the delineation of the line of control in the disputed state of Kashmir, the Indian defense ministry announced.

title: Suffolk
description: Brentwood ran its undefeated streak to 21 games yesterday and gave its best offensive performance of the season in defeating Sachem, 356. The triumph was the fourth this year for Coach Joe Campo's Indians.

title: Four novels dewinding competing, indulging and breaking free
description: A man disappears from his wife, his friends his job. He's been playing around with selfhypnosis and memory, and one day he physically disappears, it's not important how, and finds himself moving backwards into his life, reliving it from the present going back, but watching himself with all the perceptions he had before he began dewinding. Faceless when we meet him as a middleaged New York professional, George Wood gradually takes on character and dimension as he moves back through his life: to a bungled love affair in his notdistant past; to the funeral of his sarcastic, bitter and mysterious mother; back to his first meeting with his chilly, impassive wife; further, into an earlier marriage; then life as a Connecticut schoolboy; a love affair with an adored fellow classmate, later turned famous actor, adolescence and shocking discovery.

title: The World's Largest Ship Is Launched by Japanese
description: KURE. Japan, Oct. 14 (Reuters)Theworld's largest ship, the 477,000  dealweight  ton, tanker Globtik Tokyo, was launched here today.

title: Was This Festival Necessary?
description: IF anyone should be witless enough to ask you whether film festivals are necessary, feel free to answer, witlessly, both yes and no. It probably depends on what you thought of the last festival movie you happened to see. Had anyone asked me that question 10 days ago, when I was coming out of Alice Tully Hall after seeing Marguerite Duras's Nathalie Granger, I might very well have slugged him, but sleepilythe film having been such a minimal experience in visual, aural or even, heaven knows, intellectual stimulation that I'd spent much of its 83 minutes staring at a red exit sign. It wasn't that I wanted to leave. I was beyond that. I couldn't move. Every time I looked at the center of the screen I felt as if I were beginning a sodium pentothal countdown from 10. I knew I'd never never make it to six.

title: Center Aiding Young Set By North Shore Hospital
description: MANHASSET, L. I.North Shore Hospital has announced plans to construct a $4million center for child development, maternal health and the care of handicapped children. The center, which will be housed in the PaysonWhitney Tower on the hospital's grounds here, will be built next year.

title: Pakistan Protests to India On the Shooting of P.O.W.'s
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Oct. 14 (UPI)Pakistan protested to India today against what it said was repeated use of force against Pakistani prisoners of war detained in India.

title: FREDERICK J. MOORE, I.B.M. DIAGNOSTICIAN
description: PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Oct. 14Dr. Frederick Jessup Moore, senior staff consultant in the advanced systems development division of the International Business Machines Corporation, died Wednesday in Northern Westchester Hospital at Mount Kisco. He was 62 years old and lived here.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor: Earaches and Flying
description: In reference to the article, Welcome to New York, by Torben Krogh (Travel Section, Sept. 3): If the author had noted the cab medallion number and/or license plate number and driver's name, and complained to the Taxi and Limousine Commission, we would have summoned the driver for a hearing. If found guilty, he could have been fined or have had his license suspended.

title: Son to Mrs. Ross
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Harold K. Ross of 817 Fifth Avenue on Oct. 3 in the Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. Ross is the former Miss Sheron Green of New York. The child, whose father is a vice president with Brokerage Resources, Inc., is named Todd.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ATHENSMost Greeks are skeptical when told the, truthwhich is that Washington would prefer to see King Constantine invited back from exile to install a temporary executive under former Premier Karamanlis (also in exile) and head this country back to parliamentary democracy.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Clouds of gloom continued to hang over Wall Street last week and the stock market sagged lower. No real change in the fundamental outlook occurred and analysts had difficulty explaining the sustained malaise of investors.

title: Letters:
description: According to Thoreau's Concord Is Willing to. Leave Nature's Work Alone (Travel section, Sept. 17), Concord is worried as to whether Henry Thoreau went skinnydipping in Walden Pond. Can anyone imagine the Henry Thoreau who boasted he loved to wade the rivers of Concord endwise clad only in a straw hat, and who wrote so rapturously about the esthetic appeal of nude bathers that Havelock Ellis cited the passage in his Studies in the Psychology of Sex, would have hampered his enjoyment or swimming with se mundane an appendage as a bathing suit? Not only did he swim in the raw, but his good friend Ellery Channing tells us that Henry showed little Victorian constraint in shedding his clothes to go swimming even if others were around. All of which reminds me that some years ago Concord police haled a young man into municipal court. Old Judge Prescott Keyes (whose grandfather undoubtedly swam in Walden Pond with Thoreau and whose greatgreatgrandfather fought at Concord Bridge) asked what the charge was. When told it was for swimming nude in Walden Pond, he roared: Dammit, that's the only way to swim in Walden Pond. Case dismissed!

title: Julia Biddle Is Bride of Josiah Marvel
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14Miss Julia Caldwell Biddle, daughter of Mrs. George S. Mikhalapov of Devon and Mount Desert, Me., and Oliver Caldwell Biddle of Philadelphia, was married here this afternoon to Josiah Marvel, son of Mrs. Frank A. Elliott of Philadelphia and the late Josiah Marvel of Greenville, Del., former Ambassador to Denmark.

title: PERTINENT
description: To THE EDITOR: May we take this occasion on the part of Actors Equity Association to congratulate Lewis L. Lloyd on his excellent and pertinent article If We Can't Pay Our Artists, We Should Not Have the Arts.

title: Annual Football Madness Sweeps Dallas
description: DALLAS, Oct. 15As they have been doing every October since World War II, thousands of Oklahomans and Texans stood elbow to elbow in downtown Dallas Friday night, drinking and offering to fight each other in an annual celebration of the rites of fall and the University of Texas and University of Oklahoma football game.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
