description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15Among some political observers it has become a sport to poormouth George McGovern as a Presidential candidate. His failings, it is said, have cost the Democrats what should have been a good if not favored position in 1972.

title: Sabres Beat Leafs
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 15 (UPI)Randy Wyrozub scored what proved to be the gamewinning goal midway through the second period tonight as the Buffalo Sabres defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 32.

title: Letter to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Mr. McGovern has made his most significant statement to date concerning his policy approach to Supreme Court appointments, which was reported in the last two paragraphs of an article appearing on page 52 of The Times of Oct. 5. Mr. McGovern said he can and will see that there are blacks, PolishAmericans, ItaloAmericans, GreekAmericans and representatives of other groups on the Supreme Court, as part of his commitment to a Federal payroll reasonably proportional to ethnic origin.

title: SADAT STRESSES LINK WITH SOVIET
description: CAIRO, Oct. 15President Anwar elSadat tonight pledged that Egypt would do her utmost to overcome the strain that developed in her relations with the Soviet Union after his request for the withdrawal of Soviet military personnel.

title: A Soviet Source Puts Death Toll In Crash at 176 World's Highest
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 15 (AP) A reliable Soviet source reported today that 176 people were killed Friday night when a Soviet passenger jet crashed and exploded near Moscow's international airport.

title: Griese Hurt, Morrall Excels
description: At 38 years of age, Earl Morrall is a National Football League starting quarterback againand still able to handle the assignment.

title: Former Democratic leader
description: Completing 14year term on Supreme Court this year. Former Democratic leader of Nassau County  Led the field in Democratic primary for Court of Appeals nomination  Chairman of Supreme Court committee that wrote twovolume manual on how to instruct juries. Leader in campaign for cooperation between courts and the press to protect rights of defendants  Wartime Navy officer  Born June 7, 1916, in Baltimore. Graduate of Johns Hopkins University, with top scholarship prize, and University of Maryland Law School  Married, has a daughter  Lives in Cedarhurst, L. I.

title: BERNARD OCKO DIES; A SOLO VIOLINIST, 70
description: Bernard Ocko, a solo violinist with many leading orchestras, died yesterday of a heart attack in Winter Park, Fla., where he lived. His age was 70.

title: City Solicits Old Books
description: New Yorkers have been urged to bring their unwanted books to the new curvilinear Grace Building at 43 West 42d Street, north of Bryant Park, from today through Thursday, between 9 A.M. and 5 P.M. August Heckscher, the Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administrator, said the books would be sold at a Celebrate the Book festival to raise money for the New York and Brooklyn library systems.

title: ISRAELIS REPORT STRIKE BY PLANES IN LEBANON, SYRIA
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 15Israeli Air Force planes struck at guerrilla targets in Syria and Lebanon today, a military spokesman said. The raids reflected a new policy of active pursuit of the Arab commando organizations outside Israel, according to senior military sources.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: CASSVILLE, N. J., Oct. 15 A little bit of preRevolutionary Russia lives near the crossroads of Routes 571 and 528 in central New Jersey.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: AUSTINMy friend John Henry Faulk is of the opinion that Democrats for Nixon are much like his Cousin Claud. Claud used to be very big with the Baptists, was a deacon, sang in the choir and such until one day he had a fight with the preacher and went off to join the. Catholics. All his friends said, Claud, it sure is strange to think of you bein a Catholic. To which Claud replied, I ain't no Catholic, I'm a Baptist for the Pope.

title: Littlest Moviemakers Go on Location
description: It was the first day of shooting on location for The Best Friends.

title: Petrified Mastodons Are Found in Greece
description: SALONIKA, Greece, Oct. 75 (AP)The petrified remains of mastodons and of dogs and horses with three toes, estimated to be 13 million years old, have been uncovered near this city in northern Greece, scientists announced today.

title: RALPH G. CARLUCCI
description: Ralph G. Carlucci, an agent for the New York Life Insurance Company for 20 years, died Friday of a heart attack at his home, 15117 35th Avenue, Flushing, Queens. He was 53 years old.

title: Connecticut Clears Away Barriers to Seat on PBW
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 14  Connecticut has cleared away the last real barriers to membership on the PBW Stock Exchange in Philadelphia, and made formal application for a seat, State Treasurer Robert I. Berdon said today.

title: 101 Foreign Ministers Busy at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 15The delivery of a major foreign policy address during the General Assembly's opening weeks is supposed to be the main reason that foreign ministers come here every autumn. At last count there were 101.

title: Copper Producers to Meet In Paris on U.S. Maneuver
description: PARIS, Oct. 15 (Reuters)The world's four main copperproducing countries prepared today for an emergency meeting here tomorrow in the light of a U.S. legal move against the Nationalization of Chilean copper.

title: St. Francis Prep Triumphs Over Chaminade, 13 to 12
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 15St. Francis Prep overcame a major obstacle to the Catholic Schools Football League championship today by defeating previously unbeaten Chaminade, 1312, at Hofstra Univirsity. It was the fourth straight victory for the Little Terriers, the first team to score against Chaminade in four games.

title: CityInformation Phone To Be Ended on Oct. 31
description: The city will discontinue on Oct. 31 its 24hour telephone service number, 9991234, which has been supplying transit, traffic and emergency information for an average of 275,000 calls a month.

title: Addiction Adviser Held on Drug Charge
description: A former convict who carried cards identifying him as a counselor for a governmentsponsored narcotics agency was arrested yesterday in Brooklyn and charged with the illegal possession of a large quantity of marijuana, heroin and hashish.

title: Confrontation in Chile
description: Chile is mired in its worst political and economic crisis since Salvador Allende's Marxistdominated Popular Unity coalition came to power two years ago, backed by only 36 per cent of the voters. If President Allende persists in his attempt to impose a pervasive socialism, now clearly opposed by a majority of Chileans, he will risk provoking civil war or a military coup. Either would be disastrous.

title: 7 SOVIET CLERICS PLAN TO VISIT U.S.
description: Seven of the Soviet Union's topranking religious leaders will visit the United States next month as guests of the Appeal of Conscience Foundation.

title: Phyllis A. Peck Bride Of Kenneth Makovsky
description: In the Park East Synagogue yesterday afternoon, Miss Phyllis Ann Peck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Peck of Flushing, Queens, was married to Kenneth Dale Makovsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Makovsky of St. Louis. Rabbi Arthur Schneier, cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Gen. Viktor Bubanj Dead; Led Yugoslav Armed Forces
description: BELGRADE, Oct. 15 (AP)Col. Gen. Viktor Bubanj, chief of the general staff of the Yugoslav armed forces since 1970, died here today at the age of 53.

title: SOLON LI BRESCOT
description: Solon Librescott,. an industrial engineer, died yesterday in Woodland Nursing Home, New Rochelle, N. Y. He was 89 years old and lived at 2215 First Avenue.

title: Letter to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your editorial of Oct. 1 on Yale's abolition of failing marks on student records misses the point in several serious ways.

title: 7 Run Quietly for 3 Seats On State Court of Appeals
description: Seven candidates running for three seats on the state's highest court are in the hottest race in the court's history, and all are bedeviled by the same question:

title: Opera's Young Avoid Rush to Fame
description: You are a young opera singer, rising fast, and your name is being spread around among the cognoscenti as an artist who mayjust may be on the verge of an international reputation. What do you think about it all? What are your problems? How do you handle the allimportant next steps in your career?

title: Boeing to Raise Cattle
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 15, (AP)The Boeing Company, known as an aerospace giant, is going into cattle raising. Boeing has signed an agreement with Pioneer Livestock of Oregon, Inc., to establish a 20,000head cattle feedlot near Boardman, Ore., on Boeing's 100,000acre, multiplelanduse site.

title: Nanette Dembitz Democrat
description: A lawyer for more than 30 years  Specialized first in labor law  Later was counsel to New York Civil Liberties Union and Legal Aid Society  Would be first woman on Court of Appeals  Appointed Family Court judge in 1967 for term running through 1978  Was Planned Parenthood national board member, 196467  Prominent in American Jewish Congress since 1950  Author of legal articles  Born Nov. 22, 1913, in Washington  Graduate of University of Michigan and the Columbia Law School  Married to Alfred Berman, lawyer  Has a son and grandchild  Lives in Manhattan.

title: SCHOOL SETS SERIES ON NEWS MEDIA ROLE
description: A series of lectures, panel discussions, research projects and seminars on the role of the media and public opinion in public affairs has been, begun this year by Fairleigh Dickinson University.

title: Congress Expected to Give Final Approval This Week to Bill Increasing Social Security Taxes and Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15With little more than token grumbling, Congress is expected to give final approval this eeek to a bill increasing Social Security taxes next year to finance a vast array of new benefits for millions of the nation's aged, blind and disabled.

title: Union Calls Off a G.M. Strike; Short Walkouts Seen as Tactic
description: DETROIT, Oct. 15The United Automobile Workers is, calling off a strike at the Genrid Motors Corporation's car plant in St. Louis.

title: Japanese Fishermen Saved
description: TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 16 (UPI)Two Japanese fishermen who endured 63 hours in a rubber lifeboat in a typhoon said today that 16 of their shipmates were swept from the boat to their deaths during the storm. Masaaki Ida, 32 years old, and Takekatsu Abe, 30, were rescued by another fishing vessel 625 miles east of Tokyo. Their tuna boat capsized Thursday.

title: Walk paces Suns Victory
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 15 (AP)Neal Walk scored 27 points and pulled clown 21 rebounds to pace the Phoenix Suns to a 10798 triumph over the Baltimore Bullets tonight. The Suns lost a 20point lead late in the game, but surged ahead again.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Sept. 6 OpEd article by Nguyen Tien Hung which appeared alongside my own article and under the map made by me could be considered by your readers as an indirect refutation of my remarks and create doubts as to the validity of my testimony.

title: 5 Die in Guatemala Gunfight
description: GUATEMALA, Oct. 15 (Reuters)At least five people died in a gunfight today as Government security forces rescued a kidnapped owner of several movie houses. A police communique said Rodolfo Rosemberg was found yesterdaynine days after he was kidnappedin a house at San Juan Tolalapa, about 35 miles from here. It did not identify the persons killed.

title: Blues Beat Hawks, 31
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP)The St. Louis Blues, getting firstperiod goals from Frank St. Marseille, Danny O'Shea and Phil Roberto, beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 31, tonight for their first victory in 15 games here. Wayne Stephenson made 41 saves for the Blues.

title: LAKERS TRIUMPH OVER CAVALIERS
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 15 (AP)Happy Hairston, of the Los Angeles Lakers pulled down 261 rebounds and scored 21 points, and Jerry West tallied 31 to: night as the Los Angeles Lakers scored a 9533 National Basketball Association victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers, who have vet to vin. Jim McMillian also had 21 for the Lakers, while Austin Carr had 26 for the Cavaliers, who lost their third game.

title: 5 DIFFERENT TALENTS SPICE A DANCE BILL
description: I doubt whether anyone could assemble five more disparate talents on a single dance program than Kei Takei, Toby Armour, Laura Foreman, Chuck Davis and Phoebe Neville. About the only thing they have in common is an individual creative approach and each presented one work on the Cubiculo Five New Dances program Friday evening.

title: Bernard S. Meyer DemocratLiberal
description: Completing 14year term on Supreme Court this year  Former Democratic leader of Nassau County  Led the field in Democratic primary for Court of Appeals nomination  Chairman of Supreme Court committee that wrote twovolume manual on how to instruct juries  Leader in campaign for cooperation between courts and the press to protect rights of defendants  Wartime Navy officer  Born June 7, 1916, in Baltimore  Graduate of Johns Hopkins University, with top scholarship prize, and University of Maryland Law School  Married, has a daughter  Lives in Cedarhurst, L. I.

title: POLICEMAN WOUNDED IN BROOKLYN BATTLE
description: Fifteen shots were exchanged by two plainclothes men and two men they sought to question last night at Hopkinson Avenue and Fulton Street in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. One of the policemen was wounded.

title: Seals Down Flyers, 41
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 (AP) Ivan Boldirev scored two goals as the California Seals defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 41, tonight for their first victory of the season.

title: NEW PREMIER PICKS CAMBODIAN CABINET
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 15 (UPI)Hang Thun Hak, the new Premier, announced today a new 15man cabinet, considered to be Cambodia's first constitutional Government since the republic was founded two years ago. The most important addition, diplomatic observers noted, was the inclusion of President Lon Nol's influential adviser and younger brother, Lon Non.

title: Jamieson Victor in Golf
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 15 Jim Jamieson scored a 69 on the 6,544yard, par70 Fenway Golf Club course today to win the Parliament tournament held for the benefit of the St. Agnes and White Plains Hospitals. Chi Chi Rodriguez and Mickey Mantle carded a 74 each.

title: Growing Foreign Takeovers Worry Italians
description: ROME, Oct. 15Italy's postwar economic history has been characterized by a notably open and relaxed attitude toward foreign investment. But the alarm that greeted recent rumors of a possible West German takeover of RinascenteItaly's major department store chain reflects a vague sense of malaise over the possibility that hospitality may lead to colonization.

title: LIFE POSTPONES ENDORSING NIXON
description: Life magazine has held up publication of an editorial supporting the reelection of President Nixon and at the same time a group of Life staff members have circulated a petition expressing support for Senator George McGovern.

title: Anik Satellite to Link Canada
description: TORONTO, Oct. 15The world's first domestic communications satellite will rise from Cape Kennedy next month to serve all of Canada in a single sweep.

title: EXG.I.'S SAID TO JOIN ULSTER PROTESTANTS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 15 (Reuters)  American Vietnam veterans have joined militant Protestants in the Ulster Defense Association, the paramilitary organization said today.

title: Miss Takiff Bride Of Joshua P. Smith
description: UNION, N. J., Oct. 15Miss Deborah Susan Takiff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Takiff of Elizabeth, was married here this afternoon to Joshua Peter Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Smith of New Rochelle, N. Y.

title: NEW CHIEF RABBIS CHOSEN IN ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 15The chief rabbis of Israei's two religious communities were voted out of office today and were replaced by younger men with records of greater leniency in the interpretation of Torah law. Hardliners seeking reelection to the Supreme Rabbinical Council also were defeated.

title: Judith Strassman Bride of Eric Herbst
description: Miss Judith S. Strassman, an analyst with the New England Merchant National Bank of Boston, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Eric Herbst, a postdoctoral research assistant at Harvard University, Rabbi Harry Halpern performed the ceremony in the East Midwood Jewish Center in Brooklyn.

title: Books of The Times
description: Enough of celebration: let us accept him as the best we have, and simply ask, whither Norman Mailer now? For Richard Poirier, in one of the best of the Viking Modern Masters series yet to appear, the process of defining Mailer's mastery is one of winnowing. Mailer's early worksThe Naked and the Dead, Barberry Shore, The Deer Parkwere stylistically inadequate to his visions, writes Mr. Poirier. The late worksOf a Fire on the Moon and The Prisoner of Sexgive hints of exhaustion, evidence that Mailer's imagination of himself is becoming dangerously rigid and circumscribed, particularly when he indulges in rather simple and fashionable concerns about the future of the imagination in an age of science and technology. And considering the work as a whole, Mr. Poirier is forced to admit. It is  a chaotic mixture that awaits some larger redemptive effort; so that despite The Armies of the Night and Why Are We in Vietnam? Mailer now is like Melville without Moby Dick, George Eliot without Middlernarch, Mark Twain without Huckleberry Firm. Paradoxically Mailer is a master without a masterpiece.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Credit Markets
description: The credit markets this week head into a period of relatively heavy financing activity amid growing concern that the Government will clamp a lid on higher interest rates. Last Thursday, Arthur F. Burns, speaking as chairman of the Committee on Interest and Dividends, said he saw no reason for any strong upward pressure on longterm interest rates in the near future.

title: Theater: A 2d Look at Tom Stoppard Double Bill
description: There is nothing quite so surprising as surprise. For some time I had intended to revisit Tom Stoppard's double bill, The Real Inspector Hound and After Magritte. The cast was almost completely changed from its April opening at the Theater Four on West 55th Street, and I had it in my memory bank to go back to see how Inspector Hound was investigating his new recruits. But I could never find the time.

title: 4Yard Scoring Run by Evans Beats 49ers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15That one major upset the New York Giants needed to bring excitement to their 1972 season was achieved today with a hardearned, lategame touchdown drive that brought them a 2317 decision over the San Francisco 49ers.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ENGLEWOOD, Oct. 15The board of directors of Englewood Hospital is scheduled to meet here Tuesday to decide whether to extend its homecare nursing facilities to four communities in Hudson County.

title: Offaly Beats Kerry, 2213, For Irish Football Crown
description: DUBLIN, Oct., 15 (AP)Offaly won the allIreland senior football championship before 70,000, including 90yearold President Eamon de Valera and Prime Minister Jack Lynch, in Croke Park today, defeating Kerry by 1 goal 19 pointsa total of 22 pointsto 13 points. Mick McTague scored 10 points for Offaly.

title: 8 BLACKS ACCUSED OF KILLING WHITES
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 15  Eight members of a group called De Mau Mau gang, which was formed by dishonorably discharged black veterans of Vietnam, where charged today with nine murders, including the mass slayings of two white families.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Andrew Soltesz Jr., the acting warden of the Burlington County jail, said a full investigation would begin today into the twohour inmate takeover last Saturday the jail's second floor. He said the investigation, under the direction of the Burlington County sheriff, Francis Brennan, was expected to result in charges of vandalism and inciting to riot. It was Mr. Brennan who made the decision to storm the jail after 30 to 40 inmates in the cellblock refused to negotiate unless the guards were excluded from the talks.

title: Trudeau Mistrusted on Prairie
description: NEEPAWA, Manitoba, Oct. 13Now that he has finished harvesting his wheat and barley, Lloyd Sirett has some time to think about Canada's parliamentary election campaign, and he has decided to support Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau.

title: FOLLMER CLINCHES CANAM RACE TITLE
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Oct. 15 (AP)George Follmer of Newton, Pa., driving a Porsche 91710, won the Castrol Grand Prix CanAm race on a drying track today before a record crowd of 46,300 at Laguna Seca Raceway.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NORTH BERGEN, Oct. 15 More than 1,200 elderly residents filled a highschool auditorium here yesterday for a day of speeches, seminars and workshops marking this city's first Conference on Aging.

title: Fiscal Responsibility
description: The economic philosophies of President Nixon and Senator McGovern can be seen to differ most sharply in their approach to taxation.

title: NATIONALS BOW, 75, FOR 3D LOSS IN ROW
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 15 (UPI)The Ottawa Nationals continued their losing ways in the World Hockey Association tonight when they dropped a 75 decision to the Cleveland Crusaders. It was Ottawa's third loss in three games. The club has given up 22 goals

title: Boeing to Raise Cattle
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 15 (AP)The Boeing Company known as an aerospace giant, is going into cattle raising. Boeing has signed an agreement with Pioneer Livestock of Oregon, Inc., to establish a 20,000head cattle feedlot near Boardman, Ore., on Boeing's 100,000acre, multiplelanduse site.

title: 5 NEW PLAYS LISTED FOR CAMPUS STAGING
description: Five new plays performed last summer at the National Playwrights Conference of the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., will be given full productions this season at three universities.

title: News Analysis
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15The question that increasingly bedevils those who watch Senator George McGovern's Presidential campaign is this: How do you reconcile the big crowds that turn out for the South Dakotan's rallies with lugubrious forecasts that are heard on all sides?

title: Large Food Chains Feel Financial Pressure
description: WASHINGTON  Five of the 10 largest supermarket chains in the country are in bad financial shape while halfadozen food chains in the metropolitan New York area are on the brink of insolvency, Clarence G. Adamy, president of the National Association of Food Chains, declared in a recent interview here.

title: Article 2  No Title

title: AntiDemocratic Spying Tied to High Republicans
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15An elaborate campaign to disrupt Democratic campaigns and spy on candidates has been linked to a leading White House official, to other Administration figures and to President Nixon's campaign organization.

title: Nanette Dembitz
description: A lawyer for more than 30 years  Specialized first in labor law  Later was counsel to New York Civil Liberties Union and Legal Aid Society  Would be first woman on Court of Appeals  Appointed Family Court judge in 1967 for term running through 1978. Was Planned Parenthood national board member, 196467  Prominent in American Jewish Congress since 1950  Author of legal articles  Born Nov. 22, 1913, in Washington  Graduate of University of Michigan and the Columbia Law School. Married to Alfred Berman, lawyer  Has a son and grandchild  Lives in Manhattan.

title: M'GOVERN REGAINS SOME DEFECTORS; STILL FAR BEHIND
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15In the last month, Senator George McGovern has started to reclaim sizable numbers of potential Democratic defectors, but President Nixon still holds a wide overall lead, according to the third New York Times/ Yankelovich electoral vote survey.

title: Mayor, at Rock Concert in Park, Assails City Slobs
description: The city threw a free rock concert in Central Park yesterday afternoon to celebrate autumn and mark a $10,000 contribution for treeplanting.

title: Progress With Hungary
description: The apparent detente in SovietAmerican relations is being followed by a greater cordiality between the United States and the Warsaw Pact nations of Eastern Europe. Prime beneficiary among the smaller Communist powers is Poland, a land from which nearly three million Americans can trace their origin, Poland has received visits not only from President Nixon but also from several members of his Cabinet as well as from other high officials. Now it looks as though Hungary is next in line.

title: Joseph Kaminski, Composer, Israel Philharmonic Soloist
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 15 (AP) Joseph Kaminski, composer and longtime concertmaster and first violinist of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, died here Friday. He was 68 years old.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Oct. 15 (UPI)Eddie Joyal knocked in one goal and assisted on two others tonight as the Alberta Oilers defeated the Winnipeg Jets, 5 2.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 15 (AP)Mike Antonovich, who passed up his senior year at the University of Minnesota to turn professional, scored the winning goal midway through the final period to give the Minnesota Fighting Saints a 32 World Hockey Association victory over the Chicago Cougars tonight.

title: Giants, Jets Win
description: The New York Giants upset the 49ers, 2317, yesterday at San Francisco and the New York Jets trounced the New England Patriots, 4113, at Foxboro, Mass. Page 49.

title: 150,000 at Auschwitz Pay Homage to Polish Martyr
description: OSWIECIM, Poland, Oct. 15More than 150,000 Polish Catholics gathered here today between the barracks and the crematoriums of the AuschwitzBirkenau extermination camps to honor one of their priests who sacrificed his life here 31 years ago to save another prisoner.

title: Pumpkins Glowing Faces Taking Their Places Here
description: The pumpkins are coming The pumpkins are coming!

title: Bruins Top Penguins. 84
description: BOSTON, Oct, 15 (UPI)Wayne Cashman and Phil Esposito put in two goals each and four teammates got one apiece tonight to power the Boston Bruins to an 84 rout of the Pittsburgh Penguins in a National Hockey League game.

title: Executive Will Head An AddictCare Unit
description: The appointment of Ward B. Chamberlin Jr., former executive vice president of, the Educational Broadcasting Corporation, as president and chief executive officer of PACT (Provide Addict Care Today) was announced yesterday.

title: Riggins, Boozer Combine for 318 Yards
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Oct. 15John Riggins and Emerson Boozer put together the best rushing efforts of their careers today, combining for 318 yards as the New York Jets literally and figuratively ran over the New England Patriots, 4113, before a capacity crowd of 60,999 in Schaefer Stadium.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Several years ago, in a major policy shift, Richard Nixon announced that the American military posture would henceforth be one of sufficiency, not superiority. At the SALT talks this year he successfully negotiated an arms limitation treaty which merely recognized certain faits accomplis. This was immediately followed by announcements of new plans for expanded military programs that would maintain American superiority in weapons. In the 1972 election campaign he has defended these programs with clichs left over from cold war Stalinist days.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: HOUSTONThe electoral votes of Texas have, traditionally, been counted in the Democratic column. In 1964, those electoral votes helped send Texas Democrat to the White House. Texas Democrats have, however, shown in recent years that they are more independent than Democrats in most states. They are not so attached to party loyalty as they are to fundamental issues.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Levitt Assails Pollution Program

title: KNICKS DEFEATED BY HAWKS, 109101
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 15The Atlanta Hawks moved into a modem new home tonight and acted quickly to keep alive an old tradition  domination of the New York Knicks.

title: Wankel in Your Future?
description: American car manufacturers have good reason to show restraint in making massive commitments to the Wankel engine. This ingenious device is a clear improvement in many respects over the clumsy piston engine, which has locked a stranglehold on Detroit's design and production concepts for the past halfcentury, but it is not the panacea for all this country's future automotive needs.

title: Sports of The Times
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 15Not even the grass was alive on the floor of Riverfront Stadium today. There were 53,224 witnesses in the gaudy fivetiered stands gazing morosely down upon the Cincinnati Reds, and what they saw looked like something that had been in the water about five days. The Reds are champions of the National League, but as contenders for the baseball championship of the universe they looked as phony as the bogus turf on which they drooped to a 21 defeat. Yesterday a comparative stranger named Fury Gene Tenace beat them into submission with a bat. Today they were hopelessly outmatched against Catfish Hunter, top man on the excellent pitching staff of the Oakland A's. So now the World Series heads west with the A's needing only two more victories and the Reds stone cold dead in the market place unless they can win four out five.

title: 3 Runs, 13 Hits, 2 Losses and 25 Red Faces
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 15Never before in Cincinnati have so many seen so little. The Cincinnati hitting attack in this World Series has been as peaceful and as calm as the Ohio River that flows behind Riverfront Stadium. There's more action in five minutes in a bar across the river in Newport, Ky., than the Reds have generated the last two games.

title: GEORGE DASHEFSKY, ENGINEER, DESIGNER
description: George J. Dashefsky, who retired in 1963 as director of the materiel laboratory at the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn, died last Tuesday in Madrid while traveling in Spain. He was 73 years old and lived at 350 Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn.

title: Littlest Moviemakers Go on Location
description: It was the first day of shooting on location for The Best Friends.

title: Tighter State Control Set To Help Indian Economy
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 15Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has decided to resort to more state control of the economy as a solution to the current problems spiraling prices, growing unemployment and a scarcity of essential commodities.

title: CHRIS EVERT WINS BOCA RATON FINAL
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Oct. 15 (AP)  Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., overcame a 52 deficit in the first set and defeated Kerry Melville of Australia, 75, 64, today to win the $100,000 Virginia Slims tennis championship.

title: ISRAELIS PLANES STRIKE 5 TARGETS IN LEBANON, SYRIA
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 15Israeli Air Force planes struck at guerrilla targets in Syria and Lebanon today, a military spokesman said. The raids reflected a new policy of active pursuit of the Arab commando organizations outside Israel, according to senior military sources.

title: Italy's Democracy Works In Its Own Special Way
description: ROME, Oct. 15The military sentries outside Montecitorio Palace, a huge structure with a convex baroque facade and a motley history, snap to attention some 1,200 times on most days from October to July every time one of the 630 onorevoli, or honorable members, enters or leaves the Chamber of Deputies.

title: BROWNING PRIZES TO 5 ARE POSTED
description: The second annual Browning Achievement Awards for distinguished international accomplishment in five major areas were announced yesterday by the New York Community Trust the community foundation for the Greater New York area. The awards each consist of a $5,000 honorarium and a medal.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BFLFAST, Oct. 15 (Agence FrancePresse)  A fouryearold child who was shot and wounded a week ago died in hospital here tonight.

description: All Canada Will Be Connected By Communications Satellite communication companies, because Telesat management decided at the start only entire channels would be leased.

title: Saigon Envoys Gather for Conference
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 15The chief of South Vietnam's delegation to the Paris peace talks returned home this evening for consultations with President Nguyen Van Thieu on the latest efforts to end the war.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15Under the orders and direction of the White House, Federal agencies have begun mailing millions of pamphlets to elderly citizens describing the Nixon Administration's performance and initiatives in programs affecting them.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 (AP)  The Philadelphia Inquirer, saying George McGovern has inspired little confidence in his capacity for national leadership, today endorsed President Nixon for reelection.

title: Parole Boards, Despite Intense Criticism, Continue to Decide on the Fate of Prisoners
description: The 26yearold black man, who was 18 when he was sent to prison for robbery, manslaughter and attempted murder, spoke softly but directly. Out in the yard of the prison at Auburn, N. Y., someone was playing a jaunty tune on a trombone.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is distressing that as influential a molder of public opinion as The Times believes that the local noisecontrol law is in the best interests of the City of New York. [Editorial Sept. 28.]

title: OHIO TEACHER FIRST IN A.A.U. SENIOR RUN
description: Paul Talkington, a 25yearold Akron, Ohio schoolteacher won the national Amateur Athletic Union senior 30kilometer championship yesterday at Central Park. Talkington, competing for the Summit Athletic Club, which finished second in the team standing, was clocked in 1 hour 35 minutes 4 seconds for the 18.65mile race. He finished 60 yards ahead of John Vitale of the New Haven Track Club.

title: Brownstone Buyers Get The Word: Expect Woes
description: For those who dream of owning an oldfashioned brownstone on the West Side, the message at a special seminar here yesterday was: There are problems, but it is possible.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 16yearold boy who had just been given a summons for attemped auto theft early yesterday walked out of a police station in Brooklyn and stole a patrol car, the police said. They said that William McRae, of 2246 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, was recaptured after a carandfoot chase in which he smashed into two cars before abandoning the police vehicle.

title: Advertising:
description: The Ford Motor Company, Whose corporate advertising account has been handled by Grey Advertising since 1966, has asked its other two ad agencies to jump in and contribute.

title: EXSHERIFF JOHN HOY OF WESTCHESTER, 74
description: YONKERS, Oct. 15 (UPI)John Edward Hoy, a retired sheriff of Westchester County, died today at his home here after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

title: Bridge: Are Odds Against a Finesse? Just Wait a Few More Tricks
description: Bridge is a fluid game, and a player must be ready to adapt to changed circumstances. Even percentages, the mathematical bedrock of the game, are subject to change.

title: OAKLANDININS, 21, IN WORLD SERIES
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 15The amazing A's from Oakland made it two straight over the favored Cincinnati Reds today with a 21 victory that gave them a commanding lead in baseball's 69th World Series.

title: 199 Danes Who Helped Save Jews Are Honored
description: Survivors of Nazi concentration camps expressed gratitude yesterday to 199 Danish men and women who risked their lives to save 8,000 of their Jewish compatriots from the Nazis.

title: Rebuilt School Is Dedicated
description: NEW ROCHELLE, Oct. 15The school district officially completed a $13.6million rebuilding program today with the dedication of the rebuilt high school, most of which was destroyed by a fire four years ago. More than 700 parents, city and school officials attended the ceremonies at the 2,800pupil Whitney M. Young Jr. auditorium.

title: Domenick L. Gabrielli
description: Steuben County District Attorney, 195357  SuAttorney, 195357  Supreme Court justice since 1961  Named to Appellate Division, Fourth Department, in Rochester in 1968 for fiveyear term  Presided over special trial involving criminal conspiracy charges in Buffalo, 196568  Would give Court of Appeals the power to decide what cases it would hear, to screen numerous unnecessary appeals  Born in Rochester Dec. 13, 1912 Graduate of St. Lawrence University and Albany Law School. Navy officer in World War II. Married, has two children  Lives in Bath in Steuben County.

title: Sakai Wins Asian Tourney
description: TOKYO, Oct. 15 (AP)Toshiro Sakai of Japan defeated his fellow countryman Jun Kuki, 63, 63, in the men's singles final of the first Asian tennis circuit tournament to, day.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGHN
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 13In the taverns that dot Eastern Avenue, talk is limited because the street has become a truck route and the constant roar of diesel engines cuts conversation to shreds.

title: $110MILLION ORDER IS AWARDED TO G.E.
description: The General Electric Company announced yesterday a $110million order for combined gas and steam turbine generating plants from Southern California Edison. A spokesman for the company's Gas Turbine products division said the order was the largest in its history.

title: Cowboys Down Colts, 210, as Morton Hits on 22 of 30 Passes for 2 Scores
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 15The Dallas Cowboys played their best game of the season and the Baltimore Colts their worst today. The Cowboys won, 210, as Craig Morton bloomed. The oftenmaligned Dallas quarterback completed 22 of 30 passes for 279 yards and two touchdowns, by Calvin Hill and Ron Sellers.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 15A sentencing policy ordered by the State Supreme Court in gambling cases is coming under increased criticism from trial attorneys and civilrights groups.

title: RANGERS REBOUND FOR 62 TRIUMPH
description: It just happened to be the Minnesota North Stars bad luck that they had to be around when the New York Rangers, with blood in their eyes, came out of their lastplace slump last night to trounce the visitors, 62, at Madison Square Garden.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15 (UPI) Senator George McGovern accused President Nixon today of breaking a threeyearold promise to feed America's nine million impoverished children.

title: Low Is Proposed as Legal Aide In Council's HiringAbuse Study
description: City Council leaders have recommended that former Councilman Robert A. Low be named special counsel in the Council's investigation of alleged numerous abuses of the Civil Service system by Mayor Lindsay's administration.

title: Rogers, Discussing French Mission, Says Faulty Bomb Drops Do Occur
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The Nixon Administration has concluded in private that offtarget American bombs, and not a North Vietnamese antiaircraft missile, were probably responsible for the damage done to the French and other diplomatic missions in Hanoi last week, a highranking official said today. And Secretary of State Willien P. Rogers, in a television interview, left the clear impression that he did not care to targue with reports of witnesses that a United States Navy F4 fighterbomber had dropped the bombs, although he said a final determination had not been reached.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: President Nixon, in his radio address last night on his Administration's achievements in law and order, praised Frank Tummillo, a 25yearold Federal narcotics agent who was killed here Thursday night in a gun battle with alleged cocaine dealers.

title: Rudi Snares a Ranking With Gionfriddo, Mays
description: CINCINNATI, Oct, 15 Joe Rudi made no attempt to be dramatic about it as he described the spectacular catch he made off the leftfield wall on Denis Menke in the ninth inning today, a catch that probably preserved the World Series victory for Jim (Catfish) Hunter and the Oakland A's. The most appreciative listener he had was Hunter, whose nods, of constant approval made him a silent cheering section.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times is to be commended for its continuing encouragement of the concept of expanding job opportunities for rehabilitated addicts, as reflected in an editorial dated Sept. 27.

title: Personal Finance: Courts Limit I.R.S.
description: The Federal courts recently handed down two significant rulings that limit the ability of the Internal Revenue Service to levy taxes against money settlements received for damages.

title: 8 BLACKS ACCUSED OF KILLING WHITES
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 15  Eight members of a group calledDe Mau Mau gang, which was formed by dishonorably discharged black veterans of Vietnam, were charged today with nine murders, including the mass slayings of two white families.

title: U.S. Keeps Davis Cup, 32, On Smith's 5Set Triumph
description: BUCHAREST, Oct. 15Stan Smith continued an old habit today and gave the United States the Davis Cup for the fifth straight year.

title: Bethpage Beats Fairfield In Dover House Polo, 64
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., Oct. 15Adie Von Gontard 3d and Fred Braunstein scored two goals each as Bethpage defeated Fairfield, 64, and won the Dover House polo championship today at Bethpage State Park.

title: NEW GILDA JOINS CITY'S TIGOLETTO
description: Ruth Welting, a prizewinner in the Metropolitan Opera Auditions of 1968 and for some time now a member of the New York City Opera, came into her most prominent role here when she appeared as Gilda in the City Opera performance of Verdi's Rigoletto Saturday night.

title: Think Tank Aids Teaching in Bronx
description: A miniature think tank has been established at James Monroe High School in the Bronx by freeing four regular teachers from all classroom duties and charging them with producing and instituting ideas to improve the school's teaching and student services.

title: FOOD CHAINS FEEL PROFIT PRESSURE
description: FOOD CHAINS FEEL PROFIT PRESSURE ship, you're asking for the millenium.

title: Crisis Of the Spirit
description: What the United States seems to lack today is any one large, vocal and powerful group whose selfinterest also coincides with the principles that once kept the American dream alive. The American people seem to have become largely incapable of rousing themselves out of their debilitating selfsatisfaction. The result is a paralysis of the spirit, entirely uncharacteristic of Americans during the previous stages of their history.

title: Senators May Turn Down Compromise on Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15Senate leaders forecast today further controversy and possible rejection by the Senate of a compromise spending ceiling bill worked out by a SenateHouse conference committee and accepted by the Administration.

title: London Sunday Times Recalls Bad Old Days
description: LONDON, Oct. 15 (AP)The Sunday Times of London celebrated its 150th anniversary today by giving readers a facsimile of its first edition and demonstrating that some things are slow to change.

title: A.B.C. Rebukes Rivera for McGovern Speeches
description: Gcraldo Rivera, a reporter on the Eyewitness News program on television station WABC, has been reprimanded for making partisan political speeches on behalf of the Presidential candidacy of Senaior George McGovern.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: William J. vanden Heuvel; chairman of the city's Board of Correction, said yesterday he was thinking of running for District Attorney in Manhattan, the post now held by Frank S. Hogan. At the appropriate time, which is next year, I will make my decision, he declared. Mr. vanden Heuvel, made his comment on the WCBS television program Newsmakers.

description: There they were, on the stage of Philharmonic Hall Saturday night8 pianos, 16 pianists, 8 page turners. And there they were, about 2,700 listeners, mostly young people, having a ball. Philharmonic Hall was sold out, and an entranced audience watched Eugene List and his enthusiastic cohorts from the Eastman School smite to the right and smite to the left and made the greatest piano noise the new auditorium has ever heard.

title: Report Finds Big Foundations Lack Impact on Key Problems
description: The country's 33 wealthiest generalpurpose foundations are, on the whole, sick, malfunctioning institutions, according to a twoyear study sponsored by the Twentieth Century Fund.

description: STATELINE, Nev., Oct. 15 (AP)Harrah's Racebook quoted 75 odds today that Oakland would beat Cincinnati in the third World Series game Tuesday night at Oakland.

title: Japan Rearms
description: Japan's plans to double military spending to about $15 billion over the next five years is certain to revive anxious memories of Japanese militarism in Asia despite Premier Tanaka's assurances that the arms buildup would be purely defensive. The proposed new defense budget does have a disquieting appearance of running directly counter to the trend toward detente in the area, dramatized by Mr. Tanaka's friendly visit to Peking.

title: OAKLAND WINS,21, IN WORLD SERIES
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 15The amazing A's from Oakland made it two straight over the favored Cincinnati Reds today with a 21 victory that gave them a commanding lead in baseball's 69th World Series. The offbeat champions of the American League, reviving memories of the New York Mets of 1969, did it with another cast of instant heroes, starting with Jim (Catfish) Hunter.

title: J. NORMAN CARPENTER
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 15 J. Norman Carpenter, a retired vice president of the Kings County Trust Company, which later was merged with the Kings Lafayette Bank, died today at his home, 89 Pine Street. He was 94 years old and had a home also in Bellport.

title: Racial Motive Hinted
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP)Sheriff Elrod said that the nine white victims in the slayings  killed in four separate incidents in Illinois between May and September  apparently were randomly chosen by members of De Mau Mau gang.

title: Laos's Opium Country Resisting Drug Law
description: NAM KEUNG, Laos, Oct. 2 Hidden beneath the dirt floors of this remote Yao tribal village near the intersection of Laos, Burma and Thailand are about 6,000 pounds of opium. But the blackrobed Yao, who for centuries have cultivated the opium poppy for medicine and barter, do not know what to do with it.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGHN
description: The national campaign committee of the Communist Party, U.S.A., has contracted to buy two time periods on a nationwide radio network for its Presidential candidate, Gus Hall. The party said his name is now scheduled to appear on ballots in 13 states.

description: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title

title: Sadat Assails U.S.
description: CAIRO, Oct. 15 (UPI)President Sadat, in his speech, said that the way American politicians compete to please Israel has become a comedy, perhaps a tragedy.

title: ITALIAN CHURCH BARS DISSIDENTS
description: ROME, Oct. 15A group of Roman Catholic priests and laymen at odds with the Vatican ended a Biblereading assembly in a workers suburb today after having been evicted from a church institution and having temporarily found hospitality in a leftwing center amid pictures of Marx and Lenin.

title: 35,000 Watch 6,000 Children March in Bay Ridge Ragamuffin Parade
description: South Brooklyn rang with music and applause for two hours yesterday afternoon as more than 6,000 children from all over the city marched in the sixth annual Bay Ridge Ragamuffin Parade.

title: Alan in the News
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 15The shooting had hardly subsided in Israel's 1948 war of independence when Rabbi Shlomo Goren, then chaplain of the armed forces, discovered that Israeli paratroopers were not keeping kosher mess halls. He was told that there were no religiously observant paratroopers. So he became one. He broke a leg in training, but 10 days after the cast was removed, he returned, earned his wings and got his kosher kitchen. Rabbi Goren, who was elected today as Chief Rabbi of Israel's Ashenazic, or European, community has come to be known over the years as a man who puts knowledge, ingenuity and sheer will to work in reconciling the frequent contradictions between national necessity and rabbinical law.

title: Pumpkins'r Glowing Faces Taking Their Places Here
description: The pumpkins are coming The pumpkins are coming!

title: LINDSAY WHITE, 63; SERVED U.S. IN GHANA
description: Lindsay H. White, a former diplomat who since 1970 was assistant coordinator of reimbursable programs for the Board of Education, died Saturday of pneumonia in La Guardia Hospital, Forest Hills, Queens. He was 63 years old and lived at 2125 34th Avenue, Long Island City, Queens.

title: Raiders Blank Blazers Before 4,500 at Garden
description: Derek Sanderson, his hair just a little neater, his mustache perhaps not so radical, returned to the scene of his crimes yesterday. It was not quite what he was accustomed to.

title: Emilio Bacardi of Rum Firm; In Cuba's War With Spain
description: MIAMI, Oct. 15 (AP)Emilio Bacardi, son of the founder of the Bacardi rum industry and the last surviving ranking officer of Cuba's war of independence with Spain, died yesterday at his home here. He was 95 years old.

title: Will Miami Keep 5th Down?
description: Tulane officials indicated yesterday that it would be sporting for Miami of Florida to concede a 2117 loss to Tulane instead of accepting the 24.21 victory over the Green Wave Saturday night that was gained on an obvious illegal fifthdownplay.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I would like to correct any misunderstanding that might have arisen from your Oct. 1 editorial FailSafe Education. The grading systeth in Yale College is A, B, C, D. Failing grades will continue to be reported where justified although they will not be recorded on the public transcript. Furthermore, withdrawal from Yale College will continue to be required in cases where the number of failures is inconsistent with satisfactory progress toward a bachelor's degree. HORACE D. TAFT

title: ALLEGHANY PLANS TO SETTLE CASE
description: The Missouri Pacific Railroad Company, the Mississippi River Corporation and the Alleghany Corporation announced yesterday they had reached an agreement in principle to settle the longterm litigation brought against the Missouri Pacific and Mississippi River by representatives of the Class B shareholders of Missouri Pacific, including Alleghany.

title: Rex Reed's Success Is Reflected In His Clothes and His LifeStyle
description: Rex Reed opened the double doors of his apartment. He was wearing tan corduroys, a blue Shetland sweater over a blue and white checked shirt, and Gucci loafers. Later be mentioned that his underwear comes from Paris.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TRENTON, Oct. 15Brisk and clear autumn weather and the promise of a full bag brought out large numbers New Jersey hunters yesterday for the start of the waterfowl season.

title: Levitt Assails Priorities Of CleanWater Program
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt yesterday criticized the state's waterpollution control program, saying it had approved projects on a firstcomefirstserved basis instead of giving top priority to major polluters.

title: 7 Vie Quietly for 3 Seats On State Court of Appeals
description: Seven candidates running for three seats on the state's highest court are in the hottest race in the court's history and are bedeviled by the same question:

title: LINDSAY'S TV SHOW IS BACK ON THE AIR
description: Mayor Lindsay reintroduced his weekly television program With Mayor Lindsay last night with what he called an upbeat discussion of our great city.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGHN
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 15Bob Hope, the comedian, starred in a twohour vaudevilletype show here this afternoon entitled Bob Hope and Family Presents Joseph C. Richards for Congress.

title: NEW NAME ADOPTED BY CHILDAID GROUP
description: The Association for the Aid of Crippled Children announced yesterday that it was changing its name to the Foundation for Child Development to reflect its current philanthropic goals.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Many U. S. Jews Are Torn Over Trading With Soviet
description: Trade with the Soviet Union has become an emotional and divisive concern for many American Jewish businessmen since Moscow's imposition of an emigration tax.

title: JOACHIM MAASS
description: ??? Maass, a German novelist who chose to leave Germany under Hitler in 1939 and had taught at Mount Holyoke and Haverford Colleges, died yesterday in the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 71 years old and lived at 651 West 171st Street.

title: Arab Oil Ministers Confer With Sheik Yamani on Deaf
description: KUWAIT, Oct. 15Sheik Ahmad Zaki Yamani Saudi Arabia's Minister of Oil and Minerals, conferred today with oil ministers of Kuwait, Iraq, Abu Dhabi and Qatar on the agreement reached in New York with major Western oil countries giving producer countries ownership participation in oil production.

title: Buyers Continue to Flock Here Despite Their Fear of the City
description: They wouldn't be caught dead in certain spots such as Eighth Avenue and the Port Authority bus terminal after nightfall.

title: Hugh H. Jones RepublicanConservative
description: In private law practice for 30 years  President of State Bar association, 197172  Named chairman of bipartisan state committee on prison reform after Attica riots  Served as chancellor, Episcopal Diocese of Central New York, for 15 years  Chairman, State Board of Social Welfare, 196469  Born New Hartford, N. Y., March 19, 1914  Graduate of Hamilton College and the Harvard Law School  Received Bronze Star as World War II Navy officer  Married, has five children and three grandchildren  Lives in New Hartford and has law offices in Utica.

title: Nixon Says He Kept Vow To Check Rise in Crime
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 President Nixon said today that he had brought what he called a frightening trend of crime and anarchy to a standstill during his term in office. He pledged to do more to protect the moral and legal values of the nation in a second term.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATES DALLAS BANKING
description: DALLAS, Oct. 15The Department of Justice has initiated an investigation of banking procedures in Dallas because of questions raised under the Federal antitrust laws.

title: McGovern's Aides Take Gloomy View in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Oct. 15  Senator George McGovern's Democratic Presidential campaign in New Jersey was reported in deep trouble today by two of his top state aides.

title: DR, RALPH SHAW, LIBRARIAN, DEAD
description: Dr. Ralph R. Shaw, an internationally known librarian who distinguished himself as an inventor, educator, publisher and bibliographer, died of cancer Saturday in Honolulu, where he lived. His age was 65.

title: MRS. MADELINE SEAVER
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Oct. 15 (UPI)  Mrs. Madeline Terry Lorenz Seaver, an information officer in the White House under Presidents Roosevelt, Truman and Eisenhower, died Friday at the age of 51.

title: RUSSIAN PREDICTS 3ENGINE ROCKETS
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 15The Soviet Union's leading rocket designer has predicted that by 1980 there will be flights into deep space powered by a combination of chemical, nuclear and electric engines.

title: Film Festival: Last Tango in Paris
description: The feelings of love, anguish and despair that erupt all over the place in Bernardo Bertolucci's new film, Last Tango in Paris. are so intense, so consuming, that watching the film at times comes close to being an embarassment. It's an invasion of selfassuring, middleclass privacy, the sort of effect I associate with the work of Francis Bacon, the Irishborn English artist, some of whose paintingsin the colors of dead flesh and drying blood are used by Bertolucci in the film's title credits.

title: Satellite Launched to Give Detailed Data on Weather
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 15 (AP)A satellite designed to give scientists a threedimensional look at the world's weather was launched here today for the National Oceanic and Atmosphere Administration.

title: Beaux Arts Trio Returns In Fine Ensemble Form
description: As regularly as birds fly south for the winter, the Beaux Arts Trio comes back to the Hunter College Playhouse to play a series of concerts for chambermusic enthusiasts. That, in any case, is the way it has been fnr nine years now, and if the ensemble continues to perform as beautifully as it did in its annual return Friday night, the tradition will continue for years to conic.

title: Unprovoked, Lebanese Say
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 15 Israeli fighter planes today carried out what responsible sources here described as an nprovoked attack against targets in southern Lebanon, killing two civilians and wounding 16 more. Two persons were reported missing.

title: BENJAMIN MAUGHAM
description: Benjamin Maugham, a vice president of the J. Walter Thompson Company, advertising, and senior associate director of 1. Walter Thompson Company, Ltd., London, died yesterday of cancer in London. His age was 57.

title: Plane Crashes on Road
description: BAD OEYNHAUSEN. West Germany, Oct. 15 (Agence FrancePresse)  A twinengined light aircraft crashed on a feeder road for the HanovertoOberhausen autobahn, killing all three people on board today, a police spokesman said here.

title: New Jersey Notes
description: NEWARK, Oct. 15Much has been written about Mrs. Richard M. Nixon and Mrs. George McGovern and the wives of other candidates, but little so far about the spouses of three other candidates who might represent a wave of the future.

title: 150,000 at Auschwitz Pay Homage to Polish Martyr
description: OSWIECIM, Poland, Oct. 15More than 150.000 Polish Catholics gathered here today between the barracks and the crematoriums of the AuschwitzBirkenau extermination camps to honor one of their priests who sacrificed his life here 31 years ago to save another prisoner.

title: THOMAS F. BURKE
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Oct. 15Thomas F. Burke, who retired in 1956 as a vice president of the National Biscuit Company, Inc., in charge of the bread division, died Friday in Muhlenberg Hospital, Plainfield. He was 80 years old and lived at 420 Birch Avenue.

title: Hegan Is Disappointed; Hoped to Emulate Dad
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 15 Mike Hegan, eon of Jim Hegan, the Yankee coach, made an important play in the ninth inning of today's World Series game, but after he had made it, he was disappointed.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Adventurous shoppers now have a way to order all manner of goodies without leaving their homes. The Catalogue of Catalogues, a new book published by Random House, lists more than 400 shops all over the world from whfch items can be ordered by mail.

title: New Collegiate School Head
description: Dr. Richard F. Barter, headmaster of the Manlius Pebble Hill School in Syracuse for the last five years, has been appointed headmaster of Manhattan's Collegiate School, one of the nation's oldest preparatory schools. The announcement was made yesterday by George E. Doty, president of the board of trustees of the 334yearold school at 241 West 77th Street. Eugene Dea, currently acting headmaster, will continue as head of the institution's upper school.

title: Giants, Jets Triumph
description: The New York Giants upset the 49ers, 2317, yesterday at San Francisco and the New York Jets trounced the New England Patriots, 4113, at Foxboro, Mass. Page 49.

title: TV: Jail, a Kind of Life
description: The Jail, an 80minute documentary filmed inside the San Francisco County Jail, will be shown on Channel 13/WNET this Friday at 10 P.M. The film was made by Michael Anderson, Paul Jacobs, Saul Landau and Bill Yahraus over a period of nine weeks last spring.

title: A Bit of Imperial Russia Lives On in Jersey Resort
description: CASSVILLE, N. J., Oct. 15A little bit of preRevolutionary Russia lives near the crossroads of Routes 571 and 528 in central New Jersey.

title: 4 Die in Brooklyn In Gunplay Linked To 2 Social Clubs
description: Four men were shot dead early yesterday in two apparently unrelated incidents at two Brooklyn social clubs within three blocks of each, other.

title: Screen: 'Fellini's Roma'
description: "Fellini's Roma" is perhaps three-quarters Fellini and one-quarter Rome; a very good proportion for a movie. Although an appreciation of the city informs every part of the movie, Rome is not so much the subject as the occasion for a film that is not quite fiction and surely not fact, but rather the celebration of an imaginative collaboration full of love and awe, suspicion, admiration, exasperation and a measure of well-qualified respect.It is also, for me, the most enjoyable Fellini in a dozen years, the most surprising, the most exuberant, the most beautiful, the most extravagantly theatrical. The audience I saw it with kept interrupting the film with applause. This isn't something you normally do at the movies, but it seems proper enough for "Fellini's Roma."It is altogether typical of Fellini that he should film his "Roma," his tribute to a great city, mostly indoors on a sound stage. When he does go outside, he treats the very streets as a sound stage, with unreal lights and shadows playing over the facades.Or he turns to the process of his own filmmaking, to introduce a further element of the fantastic into a landscape that might already seem fantastic enough. Thus, in a sequence showing the Raccordo Anulare, a great highway skirting Rome, jammed with traffic in a stormy twilight, the subject becomes the camera crane itself, with its spotlights, its plastic rainshield flapping wildly in the wind, like some extraordinary, swooping, probing monster."Fellini's Roma" begins with the young Fellini in the north, in Rimini, first learning about Rome in school, from friends or from conversations overheard in taverns. It follows Fellini as a young man (played by Peter Gonzales) in his introduction to the city at the beginning of World War II, and then it continues in more or less self-contained sequences, shifting back and forth between the present and the not-so-distant past. Fellini, the real Fellini, makes a brief appearance, and there are celebrity spots for Gore Vidal and Anna Magnani (a bad idea), but mostly we are in the presence of what excites the director's imagination and his mind.That mind, whether you portant phenomenon of contemporary filmmaking, and "Roma" gives it a kind of freedom I have seen in no other Fellini movie. Its capacities for pleasure and terror, for sympathy and irony, are all perfectly met in "Roma," where, for example, a strange conceit called an Ecclesiastical Fashion Show begins with roller-skating priests ("They move faster to Paradise") and ends with a marvelously delicate, intricate, heraldic float constructed of human skeletons; or where the waiting room of any brothel (there are two, a fancy one and a poor one) seems a teeming antechamber to heaven's portal or hell's gate. It is as if Rome in the 20th century were the last great expression of the late Middle Ages.But there is also the ancient world and its modern counterparts, and perhaps no other image in the film really matches one brief glimpse of a monumental Fellini whore standing in the midst of fallen stone heads and torsos, no more permanent or wonderful than she, in a rain-driven field outside Rome.Yet there is another image, a face, a fresco at the bottom of a shallow pool of clear water, parl of an ancient Roman villa uncovered in subway excavations (this is all artifice) explored by the Fellini production crew.What matters is not the face itself, but the sense of wonder that Fellini not only offers but also shares, as if that were why he makes movies in the first place. I suspect that is why there are so many journeys of discoverya short ride, a walk into the past or another world  in Fellini's work; and why "Roma," which is almost wholly a journey of discovery, seems so richly to epitomize his career."Fellini's Roma" opened yesterday at the Ziegfeld Theater.

title: Urban Areas Pivotal in Southern Fairfield Race
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 15To hear the two candidates from Connecticut's Fourth Congressional District tell it, southern Fairfield County is practically urbanized.

title: Wings, Off to Best Start Ever, Drub Kings, 82, for 4th in Row
description: DETROIT, Oct. 15 (UPI)The Detroit Red Wings, off to the best start in their 47year history, registered their fourth National Hockey League victory in a row tonight, an 82 rout of the Los Angeles Kings. Mickey Redmond and Gary Bergman got two goals apiece for the victors.

title: Joan L. Foster Becomes Bride Of 0. A. Twigg
description: Miss Joan Laurie Foster was married here yesterday afternoon to Oliver Alfred Twigg, son of Mrs. P. James Aspinall of Weymouth, England, and the late Philip F. Twigg. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. James R. Foster and the late Mr. Foster.

title: Many U.S. Jews Are Torn Over Trading With Soviet
description: Trade with the Soviet Union has become an emotional and divisive concern for many American Jewish businessmen since Moscow's imposition of an emigration tax.

title: 10 Visitors Tell About Medicine in China
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The first medical group from mainland China to visit the United States in 23 years held its first news conference here today and answered questions politely, at length and with flashes of humor.

title: Nixon Says He Kept Vow To Check Rise in Crime
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15President Nixon said today that he had brought what he called a frightening trend of crime and anarchy to a standstill during his term in office. He pledged to do more to protect the moral and legal values of the nation in a second term.

title: Fire Hits Las Vegas Motel
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 15 (UPI)Gov. Mike O'Callaghan was among more than 30 motel guests evacuated from their rooms in a predawn fire today in the roof of The Algiers Motel. There were no injuries.

title: Fire Fatality Is Linked to False Alarm
description: The Fire Department charged yesterday that at least one of four persons who died in a blaze in Ozone Park, Queens, Saturday night could have been saved if firemen had not been out to a false alarm elsewhere.

title: Senators May Turn Down Compromise on Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15Senate leaders forecast today further controversy and possible rejection by the Senate of a compromise spending ceiling bill worked out by a SenateHouse conference committee and accepted by the Administration.

title: Miss Schneider Wed to D. N. Sussman
description: ROSLYN, L. I., Oct. 15Miss Phyllis Ellen Schneider, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Schneider of Great Neck, was married this evening to David Neil Sussman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Sussman of Washington.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: Steuben County District Attorney, 195357  Supreme Court justice since 1961  Named to Appellate Division, Fourth Department, in Rochester in 1968 for fiveyear term  Presided over special trial involving criminal conspiracy chargas in Buffalo, 196563  Would give Court of Appeals the nower to decide what cases it would hear  Born in Rochester Dec. 13, 1912  Gradute of St. Lawrence University and Albany Law School  Navy officer in World War II  Married, has two children  Lives in Bath in Steuben County.

title: Republican Agent: A Secretive Man With Friends in High Places and Plenty of Money
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15 Donald H. Segretti, the 31yearold lawyer accused of recruiting agents to harass and disrupt Democratic political campaigns, has led a shadowy and secretive life since his discharge from the Army last year.

title: Chinese Report Transplant Of Right Foot on Left Leg
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 15 (UPI)  Chinese doctors have successfully transplanted a wornan's right foot onto her left leg, the Peking radio said today.

title: Maryland, Virginia Tie, 11
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Oct. 15, Va. (AP)Maryland scored with 15 seconds left in regulation and then battled Virginia through two overtime periods to a 11 tie in an Atlantic Coast Conference soccer, match today.

title: Advertising:
description: A prominent critic of the Federal Trade Commission has charged its staff with leaking confidential information to militant consumerists.

title: Racing Shilts to Big A And Roosevelt Today
description: Thoroughbred racing switches to Aqueduct and harness racing transfers to Roosevelt Raceway today. Aqueduct racing will end Dec. 16 and trotters will operate at Westbury, L.I. for 54 nights.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your two correspondents (Sufrin and Wormser, letters Oct. 2) overlook that originally lower rates were applied to capital gains because such gains, presumed to have accrued over a number of years, should not be subjected to sharply progressive tax in the year of realization. This purpose has been lost sight of since the anomalous reduction of the holding period to six months; nevertheless, capital gains are usually the result of decades of patient investment to which the application of the maximum progressive rate is inherently unfair. The Internal Revenue Code abounds with other provisions seeking to average out such bunching of income.

title: Packers 17Point Rally Conquers Lions by 2423
description: DETROIT, Oct. 16 (AP)Scott Hunter threw a 15yard, touchdown pass to LeLand Glass with 1 minute 54 seconds left and Chester Marco! booted the conversion, giving Green Bay a 2423 victory over the Detroit Lions tonight and putting the Packers in sole possession of first place in the National Football Conference's Central Division.

title: ONE DIES, 16 INJURED IN FOUR FIRES HERE
description: One person was killed, 145 persons were evacuated and 16 firemen suffered minor injuries yesterday as a result of fires in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Manhattan.

title: U.S. Is Protesting Soviet Curbs On Travel by Correspondents
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16The United States has protested to the Soviet Union twice in the last week against continued travel restrictions on American correspondents.

title: Chile, Assailed by Kennecott, Seeks Support
description: PARIS, Oct. 16Chile, under attack by the Kennecott Copper Company in the French courts as a result of nationalization of company property, sought the support of other nations today at a special meeting of the Intergovernmental Council of Copper Exporting Countries.

title: Howard J. Barringer Dead; Headed F. W. Dodge Corp.
description: Howard J. Barringer, retired president of the F. W. Dodge Corporation, specialists in construction news and marketing, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home, 49 Lawrence Lane, Bay Shore, L. I. He was 73 years old.

title: DAY OFF 15 GIVEN AS GIANT REWARD
description: The New York Giants, after their 2317 victory at San Francisco Sunday, were told to take the day off yesterday instead of gathering for their normal Monday meeting and light workout, and that's the ultimate expression of approval a team can get from its coaches.

title: Agena Is Still Sending Data
description: SUNNYVALE, Calif., Oct. 16 (UPI)The Agena, one of the most intricate unmanned spacecraft ever built, has completed its first year in orbit and is still transmitting data from 425 miles back to earth. The satellite which was designed to operate six months, has functioned so well that some experiments aboard will be extended six more months, according to Robert T. Johnson, the Lockheed company manager for the Air Force program. The satellite has traveled more than 133 million miles in 5,233 earth orbits.

title: Salvation Army to Expand
description: NEWARK, Oct. 16 (UpnThe Salvation Army announced plans today to allocate S14million to expand and improve its services in northern New Jersey (Aer the next 15 years.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Professors Borowitz and Siegel have provided us with a disappointing display of as simplistic an approach to the socalled Jewish vote as could be imagined from two leading seminary mainstays. Siegel is way behind the times and characteristically naive.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 16Daniel Horgan, the McGovern campaign director in New Jersey, today disputed reports that the Democratic Presidential race was in serious trouble here as the Democrats began an allout drive in the state.

title: ABRAMS ZORN IN, IS SENT TO SAIGON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 Gen. Creighton W. Abrams was sent to South Vietnam today less than 12 hours after he was sworn in as Army Chief of Staff.

title: Ratnoff Taking Credit For Tag Used in Trailer
description: Theodore Ratnoff, the former Knapp Commission wiretapping expert who fled to England after being indicted here, said yesterday that he provided the bug planted in the Canarsie junkyard trailer by Brooklyn District Attorney Eugene Gold's organized crime investigators.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Peter Del Grande, the Camden city recreation directorand city Republican chairman, went on trial in Camden yesterday on charges that he conspired to extort $23,000 from a New York City supplier of swimming pools and playground equipment.

title: SATELLITES TO HELP FIGHT CITRUS BLIGHT
description: MIAMI, Oct. 16 (AP)Florida citrus growers are planning a massive replanting program, aided by space satellites, to overcome a blight that some experts say could wipe out half of Florida's 60 million citrus trees in a decade.

title: Hughes to Sell Stock
description: Howard Hughes will sell his oiltool business to the public. The stock offering may bring him as much as $140million. Mr. Hughes will retain, under the name of Summa Corporation, the other parts of the Hughes Tool Company Details on Page 55.

title: Whalers Down Cougars, 41, On 3Goal 2dPeriod Burst
description: BOSTON, Oct. 16 (AP)The New England Whalers scored three goals within 5 minutes 24 seconds of the second period tonight to register a 41 World Hockey Association victory over the Chicago Cougars.

title: Advertising:
description: The people who run Stouffer's restaurants and who have been making frozen entrees for retail sale since 1954, have for the last couple of years been moving into the frozen bakegoods business.

title: A SOVIET CARRIER IN 73 IS INDICATED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16American military analysts say there is increasing evidence that the Soviet Union is preparing to deploy its first aircraft carrier.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The trend toward casual, seemingly uncontrived clothes has had its effect on accessories. The change is particularly notable in jewelry, which has taken on additional importance with the advent of simpler fashions.

title: $80Million Order for Jets Is Placed by Beech Aircraft
description: The Beech Aircraft Corporation said yesterday that it had ordered 50 Beechcraft Hawker 125 business corporate jet aircraft, from both the 400 and 600 series, from Hawker Siddeley Aviation of England.

title: About Pro Hockey
description: Was that the New York Rangers playing the Fighting Saints? And was that a football game between the Jets and Raiders? And what's Boston doing on Long Island?

title: City Nurses Refuse Duties They Regard as Nonvital
description: Nurses in many of the municipal hospitals refused yesterday to carry food trays to patients, fill out laboratory slips or deliver telephone messages to doctors making ward rounds because the nurses say these duties interfere with their nursing functions and should be performed by nonnursing personnel.

title: TV: Odd Sandcastles and Goodnight, My Love
description: Tonight's madeforTV movies are Sandcastles, on the Columbia Broadcasting System at 9:30, and Goodnight, My Love, on the American Broadcasting Company's network at 8:30. Both, in different ways, are oddities.

title: Court to Hear Fee Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UPI) The Supreme Court agreed today to examine a ruling that California candidates for public office need not pay a filing fee if they swear they are not finaneially able to do so. The Court will hear the case later this term and decide it by written opinion.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President made an unscheduled visit and address to a convention of families of prisoners of war at the StatlerHilton hotel here. The president also met with Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird and Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, the new Army Chief of Staff.

title: Senate Passes Tax Aid for Authors and Artists
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 16 The Senate passed tonight catchall tax and tariff bill containing 17 provisions, only few of which had been discussed in hearings or reports available to the public.

title: Black Supporters of President Under Fire
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16Sammy Davis Jr. was repeatedly booed two weeks ago at the annual Black Expo in Chicago, and a record shop owner here in Washington has stopped selling the entertainer's recordings.

title: Merger News
description: Interco, Inc., announced yesterday it had signed memorandum of intent to acquire Russ Togs, Inc., a major producer of women's and children's dresses and sportswear, through an exchange of capital stock.

title: BREAKUP OF IRK IS ANTITRUST GOAL
description: The Justice Department called yesterday in Federal District Court here for the breakup of the multibilliondollar International Business Machines Corporation into several discrete, separate, independent and competitively balanced entities.

title: Credit Markets
description: Interest rates continued, albeit unevenly, on their recent upward course yesterday as underwriters began to wade into a heavy calendar of financing scheduled for this week. Taxexempt and corporate bonds declined in price, while Treasury issues managed to post a small gain. Money rates were unchanged to slightly higher. The taxexempt sector, described by one trader as pretty bloody today, focused much of its attention on two of last week's biggest deals  the $303.95million offering by New York City and Wisconsin's $35million offering.

title: Silvercup Bakers Assumes Ward's Operations in Area
description: Silvercup Bakers, Inc., has arranged with the Ward Baking Company, Inc., a subsidiary of Ward Foods, Inc., to assume Ward's bakery and distribution operations in the New York metropolitan area.

title: Arrests Reported
description: MANILA, Oct. 16 (AP)The armed forces arrested an undetermined number of men and confiscated arms and explosives in raids in the greater Manila area, Information Seccetary Francisco S. Tatad said today.

title: Chinese Foreign Minister Is Expected to Visit Bonn
description: BONN, Oct. 16  The Chinese Foreign Minister, Chi Pengfei, will visit West Germany next year, it was announced here today.
