title: Emergency Imports End Rice Shortage in Pnompenh
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 15A shortage of rice that led to looting and panic in this encircled capital a month ago has been alleviated for this year, at least, by record imports of rice from Thailand and the United States.

title: Gold Used Electronic Bug To Get Evidence on Mafia
description: Out in Canarsie, since spring at least, the pupils at Nazareth High School have been noticing a lot of Cadillacs coming and going near the autowrecking yard across the street.

title: Connecticut Lottery Head Out
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Oct. 16 (UPI)Donald W. Horton resigned today as director of the Connecticut State Lottery. Mr. Horton, a resident of New Canaan, said he wanted to return to his private practice as a dataprocessing consultant.

title: McGovern Sees Sabotage
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16Senator George McGovern charged today that the Nixon Administration had devoted more manpower to efforts to sabotage the Democratic campaign than it had assigned to planning for the conversion of the economy to a peacetime footing.

title: M'CAFFERTY OUT AS COLTS COACH
description: Don McCafferty, the good guy who succeeded the tough guy, Don Shula, as coach of the Baltimore Colts, lost his job yesterday.

title: Court Bars Challenge to. Curb on Propaganda Sent by Hanoi
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16The Supreme Court declined today to hear a challenge to the Government's authority to invoke a tradingwiththeenemy law to stop Communist propaganda from North Vietnam at the nation's borders.

title: East Germans Offer Refugee Amnesty
description: BERLIN, Oct. 16East Germany announced today that it was dropping all criminal proceedings against refugees and others who left the country without permission before last Jan. 1.

title: Jimmy Bostwick Leads, 31, In Court Tennis Title Bid
description: Jimmy Bostwick, the 35yearold challenger, took a 31 lead in sets over his 38yearold brother, G. H. (Pete) Bostwick Jr., the defending titleholder, in the world open court tennis championship series that began yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club. The scores were 63, 26, 65, 64.

title: Court Allows State to Reopen Two Blocked Welfare Projects
description: Federal Tutige Arnold Bauman ruled inyie yesterday that the state could go ahead with two previously blocked demonstration projects designed to provide work for welfare recipients.

title: PRESIDENT SAYS 'OPINION LEADERS' FAILED HIM ON WAR
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16President Nixon attacked today the socalled opinion leaders of this country for not supporting him last May after he ordered the bombing of North Vietnam and the mining of its ports to deter the specter of defeat.

title: 20 Eakins Photos Discovered In Old House Near Philadelphia
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) Twenty photographs believed taken by Thomas Eakins, the great 19thcentury American painter, have been discovered from an old house near Philadelphia by an art historian who was looking for something else.

title: RALPH NEWMAN SR., LED BROKERS GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16Ralph M. Newman Sr., past president of the National Association of Investment Brokers, died Friday at the home of a son, John Jr., in Wilmington, Del. He was 74 years old.

title: Ulster Group Accuses British of Killing 4 Youths
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct: 16 (AP)Protestant vigilantes said that British soldiers battling Belfast street mobs shot and killed three teenage boys tonight and that a British armored car ran over and killed a 10yearold boy.

title: Porsche Audi Prices Up
description: Volkswagen of America's Porsche Audi Division announced yesterday price increases ranging from $100 to $199 for most 1973 models. The Associated Press reported. All Audi autos, the company said, will cost $100 more,

title: 6 UNIONS SUPPORT MINORITY HIRING
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 16Six Westchester building and construction unions, with a total of more than 11,900 metnbers, have agreed to nearly double minoritygroup employment in the county's construction trades by 1977.

title: Body of Brooklyn Hoodlum Is Found in Trunk of Auto
description: The body of a 43yearold Brooklyn man, identified by the police as a hoodlum with seven arrests on charges including robbery and grand larceny, was found yesterday afternoonn, in the trunk of a car parked outside a bar and grill in the Flatlands section.

title: Chicago Police Seek to Link Six Held in Slayings to Other Killings
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 16With six alleged members of a purported black terrorist gang called De Mau Mau in jail on murder and robbery charges, the police continued to search today for two other young blacks and for links to other unsolved murders in the area.

title: Old Orkney Cathedral Is Sturdy Once More
description: KIRKWALL, Scotland, Oct. 13Ten months ago the Viking cathedral honoring St. Magnus that has dominated this capital of the Orkney Islands for 800 years was on the verge of collapse.

title: DOMINICK PELUSO, QUEENS COUNSEL
description: Dominick R. Peluso, counsel to the Queens Public Administrator and former City Hall reporter for The Daily News, died of cancer yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion, ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 46 years old and lived in Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: OPPONENTS CLASH ON DEATH PENALTY
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy joined clergymen, civic organizations and legal groups yesterday in urging the State Legislature not to restore the death penalty.

title: Miami Will Not Forfeit Its FifthDown Victory
description: MIAMI, Oct. 16 (AP)The University of Miami refused today to forfeit its 2421 football victory over Tulane in which the winning touchdown was scored on a fifthdown play.

title: Dr. Lauren B. Hitchcock Dead; Engineer an Expert on Pollution
description: Dr. Lauren B. Hitchcock, a consulting chemical engineer and early leader in the fight against air pollution, died Sunday in Dorset, Ontario, where he and his son were closing his summer cottage. He was 72 years old and a resident of Buffalo.

title: Reuss Charges Deal by F.T.C. To Ease Detergent Restrictions
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 Representative Henry S. Reuss, a leading Congressional supporter of environmental protection, charged today that the Government was bowing to demands of the multibilliondollar detergent industry that proposed Federal restrictions on phosphate cleaners be eased.

title: 14YEAROLD ROBS STORE AND IS SLAIN
description: CARSON, Calif., Oct. 16 (UPI) The son of a wealthy harbor area family waited until his parents left for church last night, borrowed the family car to rob a liquor store and was shot to death when he threatened to kill a highway patrolman.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Articles Called Hearsay
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16President Nixon's reelection forces reacted on three fronts today to charges that important Nixon aides had created and sustained a widespread effort to disrupt the Democratic campaign.

title: Allies Assure Tho
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 16 (Agence FrancePresse)  Le Duc Tho, North Vietnam's adviser to the delegation at the Paris peace conference, received Soviet and Chinese assurances of support when he stopped in Moscow and Peking on his way to Hanoi, the North Vietnam News Agency reported tonight.

title: JACOBI WORKS GIVEN IN A TRIBUTE TO HIM
description: A concert In memory of Frederick Jacobi, a composer and teacher of composition at the Juilliard School who died 20 years ago this month, filled the Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night with an invited audience.

title: Crackdown on the Mobs
description: Even to the thousands of feet of color film complete with sound track, the massive inquiry into organized crime by District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn has turned up a reallife counterpart of The Godfather. The evidence gathered in the yearlong investigation expected to result in the indictment of scores of gangsters and their reputed confederates in the police force, in a wide range of business enterprises and in labor unions.

title: U.S. Cuts Troop Strength In South Vietnam to 34,600
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 116 (AP)  American troop strength in Vietnam dropped by 600 last week, to 34,600 men, the United States command announced today.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BOSTON, Oct. 16 (AP) Reoresentative Louise Day Hicks, Democrat of Massachusetts, holds a load of 2 peren tage points over her independent challenger, John J. Moak ley, in the Ninth Congressional District race, according to poll conducted Oct. 89 by the Becker Research Corporation for The Boston Globe.

title: SHANKER PROMISES TO BACK L.I. STRIKE
description: ROOSEVELT, L.I., Oct. 16Albert M. Shanker, president of the New York Congress of Teachers, today promised the striking Roosevelt Teacher Association the full support of the largest teachers union in the nation and said his organization would pay legal fees, interest on loans and family support should the strike, now in its fourth day, continue long enough to create hardships.

title: Divers Search a Reservoir For 2 Hunters in Jersey
description: PARSIPPANY, N.J., Oct. 16 (UPI)  Scuba divers using underwater lights and grappling hooks searched a 40footdeep section of the Boonton Reservoir here today for the bodies of two duck hunters. The missing menidentified as Richard Terillo, about 27 years old of Rockaway, and Vincent Durino, 23, of Parsippany  disappeared Saturday when their boat capsized about 300 yards from shore, the police said.

title: CropDamage Aid by F.H.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) The Farm Home Adminitration has authorized ??? emergency loans to New Hamp shire farmers whose crops have been maged by rain an flooding, Representative ??? C. Cleveland. Republican of New Hampshire, said today the loans, at 1 per cent interest will be made to finance ??? and livestock production and other expenses necessary to restore normal farming opealions.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: We call upon all candidates for the New York State Legislature for a clear statement of their position on prison reform. Candidates have the obligation to tell the people where they stand. The reason is selfevidentwithout legislative action in 1973 urgently needed reform is not possible.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: This year, when the Christmas season is over, a magnificent 65 foot Norway spruce now growing near Old Bridge, N. J., will be lopped into pieces at Rockefeller Center and carted away to the city dump. A similar event takes place year after year.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Mrs. McGovern to Campaign

title: Reports From Concerns in Chemicals Include PPG and Monsanto
description: Thirdquarter net income of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co rose by 3 per cent over the corresponding 1971 quarter, while sales gained by 8 per cent, the nation's biggest chemical producer reported yesterday.

title: Eight Major Banks Join In LatinAmerican Venture
description: ZURICH, Oct. 17 (Reuters)The Swiss Bank Corporation said that it had joined with seven other major commercial banks to found. Libra Bank, Ltd., in London to specialize in financing in Latin America.

title: T.W.A. and Burroughs Settle 1970 Damage Suit
description: T.W.A. and Burroughs Settle 1970 Damage Suit

title: No Fight on Ostpolitik
description: In a bitterly fought West German election campaign one fact stands out: Chancellor Willy Brandt's Eastern policy is not a major issue. His effort to build better relations with the Soviet Union, East Germany and other Warsaw Pact countries has even continued during the election drive, drawing minimal protest from the oncehostile Christian Union opposition parties.

title: Letters to the Editor; (Less) Information, Please
description: To the Editor: Recently, the telephone number that supplies accurate time signals has added information about winning New York State lottery numbers. This useless intrusion of extraneous information makes it much harder to set watch with real accuracy.

title: Advertising:
description: Among the least publicized specialists in the world of advertising are mailinglist brokers. They're the chaps that bring the client and the list owners together and then get a piece of the rental costs.

title: GRAND JURY WRITS SERVED ON HUNDREDS OF MEMBERS OF 5 MAFIA FAMILIES HERE
description: At 8:45 A.M. yesterday, a sleepyeyed Carmine Tramunti, the alleged boss of one of New York's five Mafia families, stepped out onto the front porch of his $50,000 home in White stone, Queens. He yawned, stretched, scratched his beefy midsection and looked up at the overcast sky, unaware of the eyes watching him.

title: About Pro Football
description: The loss of Bob Griese, the Miami Dolphin quarterback, for the rest of the season with a dislocated ankle and broken leg, is not expected to alter dramatically the power structure in the National Football League. The Dolphin's the league's only unbeaten team, have an easy schedule ahead with the Buffalo Bills coming up Sunday. Also Earl Morrall is the perfect kind of quarterback to replace Griese. The 38yearold Morrall, who cost Miami $100 when he was obtained on waivers from Baltimore last May, relishes the blameless role of a replacement. A good passer, he flourishes while playing for a strong team like the Dolphins. When the playoffs come and the power structure sorts itself out, then Griese's absence may become serious.

title: College Sports Notes
description: The AlabamaTennessee football game will not be shifted to Saturday night to accommodate the American Broadcasting Company, but will be played in the afternoon in Knoxville, Tenn., as originally scheduled. A.B.C. has settled for a national telecast of the TexasArkansas game Saturday night. Paul (Bear) Bryant, Alabama's football coach and director of athletics, refused to ap prove the switch after Tennessee approved the A.B.C. request. Bryant said Alabama fans making the trip to Knoxville would have to make too many changes in their plans.

title: Plane With Hale Boggs Aboard Missing in Storm
description: ANCHORAGE, Oct. 16 (UPI) A light plane carrying the House Democratic majority leader, Hale Boggs of Louisiana, 58 years old, disappeared tonight in a rainstorm on a flight from Anchorage to Juneau.

title: California Warned to Curb Use of Electricity or Face Severe Shortages
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16California faces power shortages, depletion of fuel reserves and a deteriorating environment unless the state's projected consumption a electricity is sharply curtailed, according to studies by the Rand Corporation.

title: BREAKUP OF I.B.M. IS ANTITRUST GOAL
description: The Justice Department called yesterday in Federal District Court here for the breakup of the multibilliondollar International Business Machines Corporation into several discrete, separate, independent and competitively balanced entities.

title: Business Briefs
description: The initial sales of variable life insurance policies by eight businesses in California was jointly announced yesterday by Richard D. Barger, California insurance commissioner, and officials of the Aetna Variable Annuity Life Insurance Company, a subsidiary of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company.

title: Protests by White Parents Shut 2 Canarsie Schools
description: About 200 white parents invaded the John Wilson Junior High School in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn early yesterday morning in a protest against the assignment there of 29 black youngsters from Brownsville, and prevented the staff and pupils from entering. Two hundred other parents blocked the school entrance.

title: SENATE SLASHES FOREIGN AID BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) The Senate voted a sharp cut in foreign aid appropriations today, adding another potential roadblock to efforts to conclude the business of the 92d Congress tomorrow night.

title: POUND IS BATTERED IN A SELLING WAVE
description: LONDON, Oct. 16 (AP)The pound was hit by a wave of selling today and plunged more than one United States cent to close at $2.:1060.

title: Woman Dean at Harvard
description: BOSTON. Oct. 16 (AP)Dr. Mary C. Howell, a Newtonville pediatrician has been named the first woman associate dean for student affairs et the Harvard Medical School the university announced today. Dr. Howell, 40 years old, has six children.

title: Ruckelshaus Backs Water Pollution Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16The administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency has strongly recommended that President Nixon sign the $24.6billion water pollution bill, although just a month ago he called it inflationary and said that the agency could continue its work without the bill.

title: Updated Federalism
description: A rare example of constructive cooperation by Congress and White House has brought final passage of revenue sharing, the most fundamental change of this century fiscal relationships between Federal, state and local governments.

title: Nets Put DePre on Waivers
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 16 (AP)Joe DePre, a guard, was placed on waivers today by the New York Nets of the American Basketball Association. Coach Lou Carnesecca announced.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Now that we have had sufficient time to digest the McKay Commission's Attica Report and have suffered the cycle of personal accusations, recriminations, countercharges and official buckpassing, perhaps is not too soon to recall that Attica, as the commission understood, is but a symptom of an underlying disease that infects our community and, indeed, the country.

title: Personalities: Richard Given Nordique Leave
description: Maurice (Rocket) Richard has apparently found it more difficult coaching two hockey games than scoring 544 goals and playing 978 games in his 18 seasons with the Montreal Canadiens in the National Hockey League. Richard was given oneweek leave of absence yesterday as coach of the Quebec Nordiques of the World Hockey Association to recover from nervous strain and to consider his future with the club. Quebec has split its two games.

title: Mr. Thieu calls for a Bandunglike conference of Asian nations to find peace. He'd include North Vietnam.
description: SAIGON, South VietnamFor the past few years everyone has talked about peace. In recent months more and more talk has been heard about peace, about one solution or another, about the coming ceasefire and so forth.

title: News Analysis
description: For the 1,700 members of the city's five Mafia families, the good old days may be over. The subpoenas served on several hundred of them early yesterday morning were a rude reminder of more difficult times at hand. Ruder still was the remark of a Federal narcotics agent after he learned of the subpoenas. When Mafioso can't even feei secure in Brooklyn times have really changed, he said.

title: 5 ARRESTED HERE IN COCAINE PLOT
description: Five persons, including two college instructors here, were arrested yesterday on charges of having conspired to smuggle large quantities of cocaine into the United States from Bogata, Colombia.

title: CHIEFS IN DRAGNET
description: A special force of 3,200 policemen swept through New York City and its suburbs yesterday serving grand jury subpoenas on htindreds of members of the metropolitan area's five alleged Mafia crime families.

title: Hawaii Teachers to Strike
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 16 (Ap)The Hawaii Slate Teachers As sociation announced today plans to strike the state's public school system Oct. 24 in al dispute Ver the hiring of new teachers.

title: Steel Mills Nationalized
description: MANILA, Oct. 16 (Reuters)President Ferdinand E. Marcos nationalized the country's two steel mills today.

title: KNICKS APPROACH ROCKETS WARILY
description: After a surprisingly poor performance that led to their firsts defeat of the young National Basketball Association season Sunday night in Atlanta, the Knicks will confront warily the rebuilt Houston Rockets tonight at Madison Square Garden.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 16Herbert J. Stern, United States Attorney for the District of New Jersey, called upon a convention of parents and teachers tonight to unite in a crusade to restore faith in clean government.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Sepanator George McGovern's rdro for the Presidency is runrung at about the same pace ni Nrw York as the two most disristrous Democratic races in the state in the last 20 yearsAdlui E. Stevenson's run for President in 1956 and Arthur, J. Goldberg's gubernatorial bid in 1970, a voter survey showed yesterday.

title: S.E.C. Scores Abuses in Short Selling
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16The Securities and Exchange Commission, which for years has been worried about fraud in the marketing of hot issues of stock, disclosed today that it is similarly worried about cold issues, stock that nobodyor hardly anybodywants to buy.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 16Black community leaders are expressing optimism that they may soon achieve a goal they had set after the 1967 riots: to break down the barriers in the contruction industry and have the black community participate fully in the rebuilding of Newark.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: IN THE NATION
description: The spectacle of Richard Nixon piously pledging to halt the erosion moral fiber in American life and the denial of individual accountability for individual action is obscene.

title: Film Festival to Cast a New Mold
description: Though no precise plans have been made, there are strong indications that the New York Film Festival will be cast in a somewhat different shape next year, in its public accommodations and its artistic content.

title: CARRERAS SPARKLES AS ROBUST EDGARDO
description: Jos Carreras is becoming one of the City Opera's busiest tenors. His most recent assignment has been Edgardo in Lucia di Lammermoor, a role he sang for the second time Sunday afternoon.

title: About Pro Football
description: The loss of Bob Griese, the Miami Dolphin quarterback, for the rest of the season with a dislocated ankle and broken leg, is not expected to alter dramatically the power structure in the National Football League. The Dolphin, the league's only unbeaten team, have an easy schedule ahead with the Buffalo Bills coming up Sunday. Also Earl Morrall is the perfect kind of quarterback to replace Griese. The 38yearold Morrall, who cost Miami $100 when he was obtained on waivers from Baltimore last May, relishes the blameless role of a replacement, A good passer, he flourishes while playing for a strong team like the Dolphins. When the playoffs come and the power structure sorts itself out, then Griese's absence may become serious.

title: Horses Return to the Big A, But Not All the Bettors Do
description: The New York Racing Association season entered its final phase yesterday with the return to Aqueduct.

title: Telephone Co. to Give Scores During Series
description: The New York Telephone Company will provide World Series scores on telephone number 6371212.

title: U.S. Financial Comments
description: R. H. Walter, chairman of U. S. Financial, said yesterday the company had no intention or legal obligation to restate its audited 1971 financial statements. Mr. Walter made the statement in response to a formal request by the New York Stock Exchange in order to refute rumors that U. S. Financial would be required to restate its 1971 earnings.

title: BAR ON MIGRANTS DENIED IN FLORIDA
description: MIAMI, Oct. 16  A Federal judge here has denied a request by the United Farm Workers Union that the importation of some 10,000 Jamaicans to harvest Florida's 19721973 sugar cane crop be stopped.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16The; rising public interest this year in election and campaign finance reforms is making new and unwelcome trouble for members of Congress, affecting even the$20millionayear institution of free Congressional mail.

title: Wise Delay in Ulster
description: Britain has wisely postponed until next year a plebiscite on the future political status of Northern Ireland. The outcome of such a vote at this time would not be in doubt; Ulster's Protestants could probably roll up a twotoone majority for keeping the province part of the United Kingdom. But the whole emotional exercise would diminish hopes for peace and orderly political evolution when the need is to enhance them.

title: ElectionDay Closings Set
description: The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that they would close for the Presidential election Nov. 7. Spokesmen noted that the decision as to whether to close on Election Day generally is made each year and that the closing this year does not necessarily mean the exchanges will close on future Election Days.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: It would be a fitting tribute to the memory of the late Joseph Paul, the Californian who led the effort to save his state's last freeflowing rivers from dam builders, if State Senator Peter Behr's wildrivers bill is signed into law by Gov. Ronald Reagan this year.

title: About Pro Hockey
description: Was that the New York Rangers playing the Fighting Saints? And was that a football game between the Jets and Raiders? And what's Boston doing on Long Island?

title: Restaurants Jersey Ordered To Post State Sanitary Reports
description: TRENTON, Oct. 16  The New Jersey Public Health Council tonight ordered all restaurants in the state to post the results of their state sanitary inspection reports conspicuously near their entrances.

title: A Summary of Actions on Various Cases Taken by the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Girl, 15, Scores a Point
description: Although it was originally understood that the Public Schools Athletic League had refused to allow the placing of Diane Andrede, a 15yearold sophomore at Melville High in Seatuket, L. I., in the St. John's University run at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, her score will be officially recorded. Marty Lewis, the P.S.A.L. crosscountry commissioner, made the announceinent after the run last Saturday. Miss Andrede finished 76th.

title: PRICES ON AMEX AND COUNTER DIP
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market declined yesterday for the fourth consecutive session in slugghish trading.

title: Spreading Suburban Menace: Shoplifting, Mainly Among Young
description: The group of high school students in Connecticut's affluent Fairfield County were part of an encounter session and when the subject got around to shoplifting they had no trouble comparing experiences, recounting exploits.

title: Rain Threatens Third Series Game
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 16  The World Series scene shifted to California today, with the Oakland A's needing only two more victories over the Cincinnati Reds but with rain threatening to disrupt game No. 3 tomorrow night.

title: RULING IS STAYED ON ABORTION LAW
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 16The Supreme Court of the United States today stayed a Federal court ruling in Hartford that had struck down Connecticut's trict new abortion law as unconstitutional.

title: INCOME RISES 5% Al BANKAMERICA
description: The BankAmerica Corporation and the Chase Manhattan Corporationrespectively, the parent companies of the nation's largest and thirdlargest banksreported sharply contrasting results for the third quarter yesterday.

title: 3 Aides of Nixon Denounce DisruptionTactic Charges
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16President Nixon's reelection forces reacted on three fronts today to charges that important Nixon aides had created and sustained a widespread effort to disrupt the Democratic campaign.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: * Ed. Fricke's Famous Sea Food Restaurant, 53 Bergen Pike, (via Main Street from Route 46), Ridgefield Park, N. J. (201) 6412014.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: GARFIELD, N.J., Oct. 16 (UPI) About 1,000 persons, including lawenforcement officers, members of his family, friends and college fraternity brothers gathered today to mourn Frank Tummillo, a Federal Narcotics agent who was killed in a shootout with two suspected drug traffickers in New York City last Thursday.

title: Jets Resume March for Title Behind Revived Running Game
description: After getting sidetracked by Houston and Miami, the New York Jets resumed their march toward Super Bowl VII with their 4113 victory over the New England Patriots Sunday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Fares on Penn Central trains between New York and Trenton and New York and Perth Amboy will go up an average of 5.5 per cent on Oct. 26, the railroad announced yesterday.

title: Thieu Sees Top Aides
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 16 President Nguyen Van Thieu conferred with his ambassadors to the Paris peace talks and to the United States for eight hours today.

title: Equity Financing
description: Burns International Security Services, Inc., yesterday announced that its directors had authorized purchase on the open market or in negotiated transactions of up to 50,000 shares of its class A common stock. The company plans to hold the shares for use in future acquisitions or for stock option plans. The company's stock closed at 12, up , on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: GENEVA, Oct. 16Eight LatinAmerican countries supported Chile in a joint declaration today in her denunciation of the action of the French court.

title: Satisfied, Bavaria Says
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Oct. 16 (Reuters) The Bavarian government said tonight it was satisfied that it had taken all possible measures to protect the teams at the Olympic Games.

title: MRS. G. H. HALLETT JR.
description: MONTAGUE, N. J., Oct. 16Mrs. Ruth Dickinson Hallett, wife of George H. Hallett Jr., former executive secretary of the Citizens Union, died yesterday at her summer home here. She was 78 years old and lived at 235 East 22d Street, New York.

title: Saigon Government Orders British Journalist to Leave
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 16A British freelance journalist was ordered to leave South Vietnam today because he had written several articles critical of the South Vietnamese Government, Government spokesmen said.

title: Hyphenated Terms Dropped
description: SANTA FE, N. M., Oct. 16The New Mexico Press Association has voted to drop the use of hyphenated American terms such as MexicanAmerican and Italian  American in newspapers. At its annual meeting held here last weekend, the association passed a resolution declaring that the word American should precede national or ethnic origins when this identification is considered necessary and that such terms as American of Mexican descent or American of Italian descent should be used.

title: WALTER G. WINNE, JERSEY OFFICIAL
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 16 (AP)Walter G. Winne, former Bergen county prosecutor who in 1951 was indicted and cleared of misconduct charges, died yesterday at the Van Dyke Nursing Home. He was 83 years old.

title: Williams Hails Law Increasing Benefits For Longshoremen
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. said today that Congressional passage of a new longshoremen's compensation law late Saturday night was a significant contribution toward more comprehensive workmen's compensation law reform.

title: CHIEFS IN DRAGNET
description: A special force of 1,200 policemen swept through New York City and its suburbs yesterday serving grand jury subpoenas on htindreds of members of the metropolitan area's five alleged Mafia crime families.

title: U.S. Withdraws Its Challenge Of Poverty Official's Eligibility
description: The new chairman of the city's policymaking Council Against Poverty has had his eligibility for the post challenged by the Federal Office of Economic Opportunityonly to have the Federal agency withdraw the challenge and discipline the deputy district director who made it.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP)President Nixon will fly to Philadelphia Friday to sign the revenuesharing bill in Independence Hall before the Governors, Mayors and Congressmen he has invited to attend.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Mixed at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16Yields on United States Treasury bills were mixed in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Chrysler Recalls 1,985 Cars
description: DETROIT, Oct. 16 (AP)The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it was recalling nearly 2,000 new cars for a possible steering defect The company said it had advised the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration that 1,985 owners of 1973 model'Plymouth Valients and Dodge Darts have been asked to return their cars to dealers for inspection of a possible loose nut in the steering assembly.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Nurses in municipal hospitals throughout the city refused to carry trays to patients, to fill out laboratory slips and, in some cases, to deliver telephone messages to doctors making ward rounds because the nurses say these duties interfere with their nursing function.

title: CHINESE DOCTORS BEGIN VISIT HERE
description: Eleven doctors from China, the first such group to visit the United States in 23 years, were officially welcomed to New York yesterday after flying in from Washington. But even before they arrived at their midtown hotel, they had encountered a common New York phenomenonthe traffic jam.

title: Warriors Top Bullets, 9796. On Barry's Shot at Buzzer
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 16 (UPI)Rick Barry tipped in his own missed shot with no time remaining tonight, lifting the Golden State Warriors to a 9796 victory over the Baltimore Bullets in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Manret Place: Land Concerns Stock Is Uneasy
description: The dramatic slide in the shares of the Horizon Corporation last week, giving that company's stock a surprising priceearnings ratio of 2, dramatized the turmoil surrounding the nation's land sales companies.

title: French Envoy Injured In Hanoi Going Home
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Oct. 16 (Agence FrancePresse)Pierre Susini, the French diplomatic mission chief who suffered serious injuries and burns in Wednesday's air attack on Hanoi, was scheduled to leave here today for Paris by way of Vientiane.

title: PRESIDENT SAYS OPINION LEADERS FAILED HIMON WAR
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16President Nixon attacked today the socalled opinion leaders of this country for not supporting him last May after he ordered the bombing of North Vietnam and the mining of its ports to deter the specter of defeat.

title: NEW PLAYS FOCUS ON LINCOLN'S WIFE
description: This seems to be Mary Todd Lincoln's season on Broadway as 197172 was that of Mary Queen of Scots and Elizabeth 1.

title: 2 HARLEM YOUTHS HELD IN EXTORTION
description: Two members of a gang of Harlem teenagers that had switched in recent months from snatching women's purses on the subways to extorting large sums of money with bomb threats have been arrested, the transit police said yesterday.

title: MORE DETAILS GIVEN ON CLASH ON CARRIER
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 16 (AP)More than 100 men were involved in the racial fight in which 46 men were injured aboard the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk off Vietnam last week, the Navy said today.

title: Lowery Says He Has Enough Men, Despite Attrition
description: Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery declared yesterday that despite Mayor Lindsay's attrition program, the Fire Department had enough men now to provide the best fire protection in the United States.

title: Books of The Times
description: The books about Africa keep getting sadder. More and more, the text belies the beautiful pictures. In The African Experience, Eliot Porter has turned his lens on what seems timeless in this country. Six giraffes look like old models in their longnecked, awkwardelegant postures. There is a mosswrapped forest that might be painting by Max Ernst. A termite castle is remarkably like a medieval one. A mother elephant and her newborn calf seem to be a monument to maternity. The heights of an immense mountain are as sadly blue as a faded pair of jeans. The hugeholed baobab tree boasts of an incredible fertility in the earth. Lions, leopards and cheetahs look past us with their pale eyes, knowing this twolegged animal is dubious game.

title: The 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: This report is based on a survey of 670 registered voters in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut by Daniel Yankerovich, Inc., for The New York Times. The random interviews, by telephone were conducted between Oct. 1 and 10.

title: UNCERTAINTY OF SUIT SEEN HURTING STOCK
description: In Wall Street, analysts tend to regard efforts to break up corporations under the antitrust laws in two basic ways.

title: StakedOut Police Waited Near Homes of Targets
description: At 8:45 A.M. yesterday, a sleepyeyed Carmine Tramunti, the alleged boss of one of New York's five Mafia families, stepped out onto the front porch of his $50,000 home in Whitestone, Queens. He yawned, stretched, scratched his beefy midsection and looked up at the overcast sky, unaware of the eyes watching him.

title: Attacks Disrupting Traffic Along Key Saigon Routes
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Oct. 17 (AP)Continued enemy attacks in the Saigon area, although small in scale, reportedly disrupted traffic yesterday on several of the major roads radiating from the capital.

title: BURTON H. LEIBLER
description: Burton H. Leibler a vice president of HelmsleySpear, Inc., which specializes in the sale of motor hotels, died of cancer yesterday at the Phelps temorial Hospital, North Tarrytown, N. Y. He was 42 years old and lived in Briarcliff Manor, N. Y.

title: H.L.W. Gives 3 Brooklyn Institutions 15 Acres of Land in Manhattan Beach
description: The Federal Government yesterday turned over more than 15 acres of property in Brooklyn's Manhattan Beach area to three institutions, for the development of their educational, health and socialwelfare programs.

title: Music Man Is Newest Hit in Warsaw
description: WARSAW, Oct. 16Would you believe siedemdziesantszesc trombones led the big parade? Neither did the Polish producers of The Music Man, which has just opened here, so the show's big number begins The biggest parade  instead of 76 trombones

title: Copier Maker's Costs on New Products May Slow Income Rise
description: Operations of the Xerox Corporation in the third quarter and first nine months of 1972 resulted in records for revenues and profits, with percentage increases continuing at high levels, the company reported yesterday.

title: Policeman, Captive, Slays One of 2 Men Trying OT 13 Holdup
description: A policeman in plainclothes pulled a pistol from an ankle holster yesterday and killed one man and frightened off another, thus foiling an attempt at a holdup of an Offtrack Betting Corporation office near City Hall. His action saved $28,000 in OTB funds on hand.

title: Civil Rights Unit Extended
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UPI) President Nixon signed a law today extending the Commission on Civil Rights for five years and broadening its authority to include sex discrimination. The commission, which was due to expire early next year, acts mainly as a research arm for Congress and the President.

title: THIEF KILLS WOMAN SHOPPING WITH SON
description: A 32yearold Brooklyn mother of three was fatally stabbed by a thief last evening as she and her 12yearold son were going shopping in the Brownsville section.

title: New LowCost Scanner Is Announced by I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines corporation announced yesterday a new lowcost optical scanner that can read a number of type styles and even handprinted numbers.

title: Hungary Struggles With Gypsies, Too
description: New York City is not the only city with a gypsy cab problem. Nepszabadsag, the newspaper of the Hungarian labor unions, reported last week that gypsy or clandestine taxis had become a serious source of concern not only in Budapest, but also all over Hungary.

title: SELECTION BEGUN FOR JURY ON GRAFT
description: In a brief ceremony in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, Justice John M. Murtagh yesterday began the process that will result in the creation of special grand juries in each borough to hear evidence of corruption in the city criminal justice system.

title: At Retrospective, Hundreds Salute An Ailing Norell
description: The bravos resounded off the rafters at the Metropolitan Museum of Art last night as the stage filled with dozens of gleaming sequined dresses in every shade from silver to dark green. A radiating mass of lights, the dresses formed the finale of the first retrospective showing of fashions by Norman Norell, a designer for 50 years.

title: MARCOS APPROVES NEW NEWSPAPER
description: MANILA, Oct. 16The martiallaw Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos today authorized the publication of a new daily newspaper, The TimesJournal.

title: Joe Cocker Guilty on Drugs
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Oct. 16 (Reuters)Joe Cocker, the British rock star who was arrested Saturday on drug charges, pleaded guilty today to possession of marijuana. Five members of his group and the wife of one also appeared with Cocker, 23 years old, and pleaded guilty to drug charges. The magistrate set bail of $1.150 for each, pending sentencing.

title: Taxi Industry, Beset by Trouble, Looks for Ways to Stay on Duty
description: New York City's medallion taxi industry, beset by higher fares, dwindling public support and the inroads of aggressive gypsy cabs, is as battered and shaky as some of the cars it operates on Manhattan streets.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct 16Larry Sciacchetano has returned to his alma mater, Montclair State College, as wrestling coach. If his record as a competitor and coach is any indication, Sciacchetano may move Montclair State into the national rankings, and soon. During his seven years as coach at New York State Maritime College, Sciacchetano had a record of 68 victories, eight losses and two ties, and put the merchant marine school on the intercollegiate map.

title: Business Briefs
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16 (AP)Stability for mortgage interest rates next year was predicted today by officials who addressed the 29th annual meeting of the National League of Insured Savings Associations.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Tuition Loan Plan Is Based on Future Earnings
description: A Ford Foundation study recommends a payasyouearn tuition loan program for students that would peg the amount a graduate would repay to the size of his income in the years following graduation.

title: Court Declines to Hear a Plea On Propaganda Sent by Hanoi
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16The Supreme Court declined today to hear a challenge to the Government's authority to invoke a tradingwiththeenemy law to stop Communist propaganda from North Vietnam at the nation's borders.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16Those persons who persistently fault President Nixon for refusing to discuss the issues this fall are missing the point.

title: REMARKS BY CHOU ARE REASSESSED
description: PEKING, Oct. 16 (Reuters)Diplomats and knowledgeable observers here are considering with extreme caution the widespread speculation in the foreign press about China's future leadership that followed a meeting last week between Premier Chou Enlai and 22 members of the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

title: 3 Israeli Security Officials Ousted in Munich Killings
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 16Premier Golda Meir announced today that three senior officials of the security service had been dismissed because of the failure to provide adequate protection for the Israeli Olympic team in Munich.

title: ExCourt Officer Pleads Guilty To Trying to Bribe a Detective
description: A former court officer here pleaded guilty yesterday to attempted bribery of a detective.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (Reuters)The Federal Open Market Committee voted by 101 at its July 18 meeting to maintain a moderate growth in the money supply. The directive was released by the Federal Reserve Board today. In addition, the committee determined to keep the growth of private nonbank deposits at an annual rate of between 3 to 7 per cent in the JulyAugust period, while continuing to avoid sharp fluctuations and large cumulative changes in moneymarket conditions.

title: Theory Explains Strategy That Halted Aztec Advance
description: In 15thcentury Mexico, when the mighty Aztec nation was conquering surrounding territories and vanquishing many other Indian societies, the littleknown Tarascan civilization was one of the few that proved able to defeat the Aztecs.

title: Hughes to Sell Stock
description: Howard Hughes will sell his oiltool business to the public. The stock offering may bring him as much as $140million. Mr. Hughes will retain, under the name of Summa Corporation, the other parts of the Hughes Tool Company. Details on Page 55.

title: Business Briefs
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation announced yesterday formation of a new subsidiary, the GTE Satellite Corporation, aimed at providing a domestic satellite communications system.

title: Potato Futures Prices Rise; Orange Juice Shows a Decline
description: Freezing weather in Maine and a bountiful orange crop in Florida had dramatic impacts on futures trading yesterday.

title: THREAT TO I.B.M. DISTURBS MARKET
description: A loss of 14 points in International Business Machines helped unsettle stock prices yesterday as the market skidded in another nervous session. The DowJones Industrials fell 8.80 to 921.66.

title: GROSS IS ACCUSED ON $10,000 OUTLAY
description: Over the protests of his two top fiscal officers, Ted Gross, then the City Commissioner of Youth Services, bought $10,000 worth of television equipment for his agency without the required prior authorization by the Board of Estimate, according to interviews and records disclosed yesterday.

title: I.B.M.: The Pleasures and Penalties of Sheer Size
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has learned to its sorrow that being one of the nation's largest industrial companies and the giant of its field can bring brickbats as well as roses.

title: 4 FLEE QUEENS JAIL AFTER SAWING BARS
description: Four inmates escaped from the Queens House of Detention for Men last night after sawing through the bars of a window on the third floor and fleeing down a rope made of bedsheets.

title: ABRAMS SWORN IN, IS SENT TO SAIGON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 Gen. Creighton W. Abrams was sent to South Vietnam today, less than 12 hours after he was sworn in as Army Chief of Staff.

title: H. Wolcott Fenner, A Ringling Officer, Edited Circus Book
description: Wolcott Fenner, senior vice president of Ringling Bros, and Barnum & Bailey Combined Shows, Inc., died Saturday of a heart ailment at his home in Washington. He was 61 years old.

title: Export Controls Asked
description: TOKYO, Oct. 16 (UPI)  Japan's most powerful business organization urged the Government today to impose controls on sales of Japanese goods overseas in order to avoid another revaluation of the yen.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 lames W. McCord, one of seven men indicted on charges of burglarizing and bugging the Democratic National Committee headquarters, was paid $207.25 last Jan. G by the Committee for the Reelection of the President for conducting a technical inspection of the Watergate apartment of John N. Mitchell, then the Attorney General.

title: STRIKE IS HALTED AT KEY G.M. PLANT
description: DETROIT, Oct. 16The United Automobile Workers called off a strike today at a key General Motors partsmaking plant at Mansfield, Ohio.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: OCEAN CITY, Oct. 16 (AP)Mrs. Elinor Eipper of Pitman was reelected to a second term as moderator of the United Presbyterian Synod of New Jersey here today.

title: Kennedy Bids U.S. Investigate G.M. Locomotive and Bus Role
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, charged today that the General Motors Corporation might have deliberately brought about the decline of rail and bus passenger transportation because selling automobiles was more lucrative than selling buses and locomotives.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The advice of Gem Mark W. Clark in a recent OpEd article, Turning on the Heat in Vietnam, is most revealing because it illustrates the sick kind of thinking which got us into the war in the first place and is now being used to prolong the conflict and justify the terrible human suffering. The United States military has been echoing deceits for so long that now even generals have fallen for their own propaganda and continue to view the war in simplistic terms. General Clark announces that there are exactly four possible alternatives open to us, that the Vietnamization program has succeeded exceptionally well, that the solution to the problems of Vietnam can be found by intensifying the bombing and that the Vietnam war is really a conventional war just like the one we fought in Korea.

title: Banker Is N.Y.U. Trustee
description: John W. Larsen, president and trustee of the Bowery Savings Bank, will begin a fouryear term on the board of trustees of New York University as an alumni trustee. Mr. Larsen, a resident of Ridgewood, N. J., was graduated from the N.Y.U. School of Commerce in 1939 and from the graduate school of business administration in 1950.

title: Charles Jaffa, Lawyer, Dies; Jewish Hospital Executive
description: Charles Jaffa, a lawyer who was vice president of the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn and former president of its nurses training school, died yesterday at his home, 875 Park Avenue. His age was 86.

title: SOVIET COVERAGE OF CRASH SKIMPY
description: MOSCOW. Oct. 16For the discerning reader, there was no more to arouse attention than five husbandandwife obituary notices in the Moscow press recording their untimely leaths.

title: Big Board Backs S.E.C. On Institutional Members
description: The New York Stock Exchange endorsed in principle yesterday the proposed rule of the Securities and Exchange Commission regarding the thorny matter of institutional membership.

title: SHRIVER BIDS U.S. CURB JOB LOSSES
description: Sargent Shriver, looking for financial help and more exposure with industrial workers in a twoday visit to the New York metropolitan area, yesterday proposed new restrictions on American companies that transfer business and jobs abroad.

title: 3 Israeli Security Officials Ousted in Munich Killings By TERENCE SMITH
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 16Premier Golda Meir announced today that three senior officials of the security service had been dismissed because of the failure to provide adequate protection for the Israeli Olympic team in Munich.

title: Sports of The Times
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 16  The National Leaguers had such sublime belief in their propaganda line that they really were convinced the championship playoff between the Cincinnati Reds and the Pittsburgh Pirates had definitely determined which was baseball's best team. Not wanting to sound too greedy, they condescended to admit that Oakland, the winner over Detroit in the other playoff, might be the third best team. Nothing certain about it, you know. But the selfevident truth of preponderant Redleg supremacy over the A's would assuredly evolve from the World Series. Oh, yeah?

title: BOMB IN ARGENTINA KILLS A U.S. WOMAN
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 16 (AP) A powerful bomb explosion in the new Sheraton Hotel killed an American woman tonight and seriously injured two other Americans, the police reported.

title: Lindsay Elevates Cavanagh
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday appointed James A. Cavanagh, a career civil servant, as first deputy director of the budget to succeed Andrew P. Kerr, newly designated Housing and Development Administrator Mr. Cavanagh had been deputy budget director since 1970.

title: Chess:
description: By the time Mikhail Tal won the world chess championship in Moscow in 1960 by a 128 score over Mikhail Botvinnik, his reputation as a swashbuckling attacker was well established. A typical Tal game featured outrageously daring sacrifices leading to virtually unfathomable complications through which he charged to victory again and again.

title: SOUR NOTES MAR WELCOME TO A'S
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 16Like most things concerning the volatile Oakland A's and their owner, Charley Finley, the welcomehome celebration for the team when it returned from Cincinnati last night had contradictory elements.

title: WARRANT IS REVOKED ON DAHLBERG ARREST
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 16 (AP) A warrant for the arrest of Kenneth Dahlberg, a major fundraiser for President Nixon's reelection campaign, was revoked today.

title: Chilean Policemen Fight Demonstrators
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 16, (AP)Policemen clashed several times today with groups of businessmen and youths as shopkeepers, striking in sympathy with truckers, kept their doors closed in defiance of the leftist Government.

title: SPEEDUP IS URGED IN URANIUM PROCESS
description: The Atmoic Industrial Forum, Inc., yesterday called on the Atomic Energy Commission and private industry to speed up the uraniumenrichment program to prevent nuclear power plants from running out of fuel in the nineteeneighties.

title: Ruckelshaus Backs Water Pollution Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16The administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency has strongly recommended that President Nixon sign the $24.6billion water pollution bill, although just a month ago he called it inflationary and said that the agency could continue its work without the bill.

title: Jamestown Teachers Strike
description: JAMESTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 16 (UPI)A strike by 450 publicschool teachers forced cancellation of classes for about 8,125 pupils in this Chautauqua County City today. The teachers struck after negotiators for the teachers and the school board failed to reach agreement on a new contract.

title: Toxic Legislation
description: Once again the Nixon Administration is displaying its tendency in environmental matters to talk boldly and carry a small twig. The immediate issue is the bill to control toxic substances, which is scheduled for floor action today in the House of Representatives.

title: SUPREME COURT BACKS I.C.C. RULE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UPI) The Supreme Court affirmed today a 1969 Interstate Commerce Commission ruling that trucking companies designated as heavy haulers may not carry any freight that is not inherently a bulky commodity requiring special equipment.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: FREEHOLD, Oct. 16  The bribery and conspiracy trial of Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin of New Jersey opened today in Superior Court, with indications that it could become a test of the Republican Administration of Governor Cahill.

title: SHOW JUMPING PRIZE WON BY STEINKRAUS
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 16William C. Steinkraus of Noroton, Conn., the captain of the United States Equestrian Team, won the international individual championship at the Pennsylvania National Horse show today riding Main Spring. Steinkraus was one of four riders to turn in perfect second rounds over the ninefence course and he had the fastest time of 27.9 seconds.

title: Bridge:
description: It is sometimes necessary to keep passing with a powerful hand, but few players below the expert rank are capable of the necessary selfcontroland even an expert may find the maintenance of a golden silence more than flesh and blood can stand.

title: PAYMENT SURPLUS SWELLS IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Oct. 16 (Reuters)Japan had an unexpectedly large surplus of $590million in her balance of payments for September, owing to steppedup exports and static dmports, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Trudeau Mutes Campaign Style
description: KAMLOOPS, British Columbia, Oct. 15Pierre Elliott Trudeau is no longer the flamboyant, flip campaigner who stirred so much excitement during the 1968 election.

title: Morales, Sammartino Win In Straight Falls at Garden
description: The team of Pedro Morales and Bruno Sammartino won in straight falls over Mr. Fugi and Toru Tanaka last night in the featured exhibition of professional wrestling at Madison Square Garden before 15,423 surprisingly quiet specators.

title: Man in the News
description: A whitehaired, blueeyed, ruddycheeked judge picked up the telephone in his office one day last week and answered a call from Governor Rockefeller.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 (AP) Fares on Penn Central trains between New York and Trenton and New York and Perth Amboy will go up an average of 5.5 per cent on Oct. 26.

title: People and Business
description: When Robert W. Haack retired as president of the New York Stock Exchange on July 31, he indicated that he expected to serve on six or seven boards of directors. Well, the leaves have turned, and the 55yearold executive has already taken on six directorships, not including the trusteeship at the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York that he held while head of the Big Board.

title: Protests by White Parents Shut 2 Canarsie Schools
description: About 200 white parents invaded the John Wilson Junior High School in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn early yesterday morning in a protest against the assignment there of 29 black youngsters from Brownsville, and prevented the staff and pupils from entering. Two hundred other parents blocked the school entrance.

title: Lartigue, a Record of a Long Life in Photographs
description: I have taken pictures for no one but myself, says the French photographer Jacques Henri Lartigue. Like Proust, I couldn't let my life slip by without having a record of it.

title: MAX R. BRUNSTETTER, TAUGHT AT COLUMBIA
description: Dr. Max R. Brunstetter, a former provost and a professor emeritus of Teachers College, Columbia University, died Saturday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. His age was 70.

title: Union Calls for Boycott
description: UTRECHT, The Netherlands, Oct. 16 (UPI)The Dutch Transport Workers Union instructed Rotterdam dockworkers today to boycott the West German freighter Birte Oldendorff.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 16The trial of Maj. Gen. James F. Cantwell was ordered delayed for at least 10 days today by the Appellate Division.

title: Egyptian Premier, in Moscow, Seeks Aid
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 16The Premier of Egypt, Dr. Aziz Sidky, flew into Moscow today for talks with the leadership and promptly, though in veiled language pressed Moscow to provide the means to expel Israel from occupied Arab territory.

title: Center to Aid Retarded Is Dedicated in Harlem
description: The first center in Central Harlem to evaluate mentally retarded children and refer them for treatment was formally opened yesterday.

title: WESTBURY OFFERS TWO EXTRA RACES
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 16There's a catch to it, but harness racing fans will be able to watch 11 events tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway, which kicked off its final 1972 meeting tonight.

title: Hughes to Sell OilTool Business to Public
description: Howard Hughes is selling the oilwell drillingbit business, the foundation on which his fortune  estimated at more than a billion dollars  was built.

title: BRIBE TRIAL OPENS FOR CAHILL'S AIDE
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 16The bribery and conspiracy trial of Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin of New Jersey opened today in Superior Court, with indications that it could become a test of the Republican Administration of Governor Cahill.

title: McGovern Sees Sabotage
description: Los ANGELES. Oct. 16Senator George McGovern charged today that the Nixon Administration had devoted more manpower to efforts to sabotage the Democratic campaign than it had assigned to planning for the conversion of the economy to a peacetime footing.

title: Dance Marathon Setting Feast Pace
description: The great thing that the City Center American Dance Marathon is offering at the ANTA Theater is, quite simply, variety. The marathon, running well and hardly puffing, last night opened the third week of its sixweek stint with something new and something revived. It made up an entertaining program.

title: BLOOD, SWEAT GIVES COLORLESS CONCERT
description: Reason, and the memory of a concert in Central Park last summer, leads one to the realization that the new Blood, Sweat and Tears cannot actually be as monotonous and colorless as the group was made to appear in a concert at Philharmonic Hall Sunday night (which was repeated last night).

title: STEEL PRODUCTION ROSE 0.9% IN WEEK
description: Domestic steel production for the week ended Oct. 14 rose by 0.9 per cent to 2,591,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The index level reached 106.2. The comparable figures for the week ended Oct. 7 were: Production of 2,568,000 tons and an index level of 105.3.

title: Notes on People
description: Ah, you look like a Krol, said John Cardinal Krol, the Archbishop of Philadelphia, as he strolled among the people of Siekierczyna, Poland, where his father was born.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: UNION CARBIDE HAILS INVESTING OVERSEAS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP)  The Union Carbide Corporation says that the pull effect of its overseas plants in 30 countries has actually increased exports from its United States plants.

title: Spanish Payment Surplus Off
description: MADRID, Oct. 17 (Reuters) Spain had a balance of payments surplus of $118.8million last month compared with a surplus of $235.1million in August and one of $127.3million in September, 1971, the Bank of Spain reported today.

title: Canarsie Parents Block Black Pupils From Entering School for 2d Day
description: About 150 Canarsie parents blocked the steps of John Wilson Junior High School yesterday, preventing, for the second day, 34 black children from entering the school.

title: Theater League Backs8 P. M. Curtain
description: The League of New York Theaters has indicated its willingness to push back the evening theater curtain times half an hour to 8 P.M. on weekdays and 8:30 P.M. on Saturdays in exchange for a cashbacked steppedup campaign of support for Broadway by restaurateurs and allied interests.

title: Lutz Tops Addison, 64, 62, In Tennis at Vancouver
description: VANCOUVER, British Colubia, Oct. 17 (UPI) Eighthseeded Bob Lutz, of Tiburon, Calif., advanced to the second round of the $50,000 Rothman's International tennis tournament today by defeating Terry Addison of Australia, 64, 62.

title: JOHN C. TYSEN, 59, HEAD OF PREVIEWS
description: John C. Tysen, who as president and then chairman since 1961 of Previews, Inc., became one of the world's leading real estate brokers, died of a heart ailment Monday night at his apartment, 4 East 66th Street. He was 59 years old.

title: Kringle Leads Seniors Golf By Three Strokes With 72
description: NEPTUNE, N, J., Oct, 17Ed Kringle of the Lincoln Park Driving Range posted a par 72 today to take the firstround lead in the sixth annual New Jersey Professional Golfers Association seniors championship at the Jumping Brook Country Club.

title: Telephone Co. to Give Scores During Series
description: The New York Telephone Company will provide World Series scores on telephone number 6371212.

title: Personalities: N.F. C. Passers Still Looking Up to Snead
description: The Giants and Jets may not be leading their divisions, but each New York;, football team has three players leading an individualstatistics category, which is a good sign.

title: More, Monthly Review, Wins Hollenbeck Award
description: More, the monthly journalism review, is the first recipient of the Don Hollenbeck award which is to be given annually, by New York Uni ersity's department of journalism.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (Reuters)The Federal National Mortgage Association announced today that it had issued $224.9million in fourmonth commitments at an average yield of 7.732 per cent and an average price of 94.66 at yesterday's auction.

title: Saigon Reports Fall of 6 Towns; Sees Enemy Drive as Political
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Oct. 18 (AP)South Vietnamese military spokesmen reported yesterday that six villages in the Central Highlands had been seized by Communist troops in what appeared to be a planttheflag campaign.

title: Many Cities to Cut Taxes Under Revenue Sharing
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 Though that was not really the idea behind the whole thing, many communities around the country plan to use the money they get under the new Federal revenuesharing program to reduce taxesproperty taxes in almost all cases.

title: BILLY WILLIAMS, 62, BLUES SINGER, DIES
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (UPI)Billy Williams, who rose to fame as a blues singer, died last Thursday in Cook County Public Hospital. He was 62 years old. Three hundred attended his funeral here today.

title: Personalities: N.F.C. Passers Still Looking Up to Snead
description: The Giants and Jets may not be leading their divisions, but each New York football team has three players leading an individualstatistics category, which is a good sign.

title: Official of Al Fatah Shot Dead in Rome
description: ROME, Oct. 17A Libyan Embassy employe, a Jordanian who is believed to have been a member of Al Fatah, the Palestinian guerrilla organization, was shot dead last night outside his suburban apartment.

title: KISSINGER FLYING TO SOUTH VIETNAM AFTER PARIS TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17Henry A. Kissinger was flying tonight from another meeting with the North Vietnamese in Paris to a meeting with the South Vietnamese in Saigon amid strong indications throughout the Government that negotiations for an Indochina ceasefire had reached a critical point.

title: U.S. Voices Disapproval
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17The United States has conveyed to the South Korean Government in the stiffest terms its disapproval of the imposition of martial law by President Park. State Department officials said today.

title: Knicks Hold Off Rockets to Win, 10395
description: The Knicks played like a different team in each half last night at Madison Square Garden. And so did the Houston Rockets.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Oct. 17  The New Jersey Devils, the only pro sports team in the state, opened their ninth hockey season on Friday the 13th but that didn't seem to bother them. They have been picked to win the Central Division of the Eastern Hockey League over the Long Island Ducks, a team they meet here tomorrow night.

title: Gold's Inquiry Into Mafia Will Call 2 L.I. Officials
description: District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn has obtained subpoenas for two Long Island public officials as part his investigation of several hundred Mafia figures in the city.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Cues Sink Squires, 117112
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 17 (AP)Chuck Williams connected on a 3point play with less than three minutes to play tonight to break a 105105 tie and give the San Diego Conquistadors a 117112 victory over the Virginia Squires.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Gold's Inquiry Into Mafia Will Call 2 L.I. Officials
description: District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn has obtained subpoenas for two Long Island public officials as part of his investigation of several hundred Mafia figures in the city.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: State Gets $120,000 Housing Grant

title: Mrs. Carol Schotland Garner Married to Robin L. Farkas
description: Mrs. Carol Schotland Garner and Robin Lewis Farkas were married here last evening at Mr. Farkas's New York residence by Rabbi Norman Kahan of Temple Sinai in Roslyn, L.I.

title: Golf Notables to Be Installed in Hall of Fame Planned at Pinehurst, N.C.
description: A multimillion  dollar World Gold Hall of Fame is to be built at Pinehurst, N. C. Completion of the first building phase is expected in midsummer of 1974. Don Collett, president of Pinehurst, Inc., announced yesterday that a temporary building would be opened to the public within a few weeks.

title: Sharks Stop Saints, 51
description: ST. PAUL, Oct. 17 (AP)Rus Gillow, Los Angeles Sharks goalie kicked out 37 shots tonight as the Sharks defeated the Minnesota Fighting Saints, 51.

title: SENATE REJECTS SPENDING CEILING SOUGHT BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17The Senate rejected tonight $250billion ceiling that President Nixon had wanted to impose on government spending in the current fiscal year.

title: KISSINGER FLYING TO SOUTH VIETNAM AFTER PARIS TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17Henry A. Kissinger was flying tonight from another meeting with the North Vietnamese in Paris to a meeting with the South Vietnamese in Saigon amid strong indications throughout the Government that negotiations for an Indochina ceasefire had reached a critical point.

title: Inco Sees Output Drop
description: The International Nickel Company of Canada told a group of security analysts at a special meeting in Sudbury, Ont., that production would be down about 14 per cent from the 1971 level and 16 per cent behind the 1970 level. L. E. Grubb, president, said that capital outlays would total about $150million this year, down from earlier predictions of S200million and well below the $244million spent in 1971.

title: RISE IN U.S. WELFARE PUT AT 5YEAR LOW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP)  Rising employment and belttightening by the states slowed the national welfare growth rate to a fiveyear low in the fiscal year 1972, the Government said today.

title: Delaware Tops Poll
description: Delaware was the unanimous choice yesterday for the third straight week in balloting for the Lambert Cup, presented at the end of each college football season to the outstanding Division If team in the East.

title: E. C. DONNELLY JR. OF OUTDOOR AD FIRM
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Oct. 17 Edward C. Donnelly Jr. president of John Donnelly and Sons, nationwide outdoor advertising sign company, died Sunday at his home. His age was 65.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 17 (AP) Governor Rockefeller of New York said today that Vice President Agnew has the inside track for the 1976 Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATE REJECTS SPENDING CEILING SOUGHT BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Oct. 18The Senate rejected last night the compromise version of the $250billion spending ceiling that President Nixon wanted to impose on the Government this year.

title: Lewis, First Black on Met Podium, Leads Boheme
description: There are not many frontiers left, even it you happen to be black, but one more can he crossed off the list after Monday night's performance of La Boheme at the Metropolitan Opera. Just 17 years after Marian Anderson broke through as the Met's first black singer, Henry Lewis became the first black to conduct a Met performance  and on his 40th birthday, to boot.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 17 (AP)Stan Smith of the United States, Ilie Nastase of Rumania and Manuel Orantes of Spain, frontrunners in the 1972 Grand Prix tennis standing, scored firstround victories in the 20th Count of Godo Trophy tournament today.

title: South Korea Chief Orders Martial Law
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 17President Park Chung Hee proclaimed martial law tonight throughout South Korea, suspended part of the Constitution, dissolved the National Assembly and suspended all political activities.

title: Stage: Pacific Paradise
description: Song flows easily from Maori lips and movement somewhat less so from their bodies and the combination produced a melodious lowkey production called Pacific Paradise. Some folk elements come through intact but the sensibility that shaped the show has been strongly influenced by the canoe and coral reef movie epics that have irreversibly romanticized our ideas of the South Pacific. The New Zealand Maori Company Ltd. presented the work Monday evening at the Palace.

title: Man in the News
description: It was 2:30 A.M. It was an hour when most people are asleep, especially men like Charles Joseph Hynes, who is accustomed to rising early, reaching his office in downtown Brooklyn around 7:45 A.M. and not returning home until nearly 8 P.M.and then frequently working some more. But in his 13 room Victorian home in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, Mr. Hynes could not sleep. It was Monday morning, and a year's work was reaching a climax as more than a thousand policemen moved into position to subpoena hundreds of suspected underworld figures.

title: Differ on Meaning
description: BONN, Oct. 17 (UPI)The West and East German state secretaries who exchanged the notes of ratification here today differed at once on whether the ceremony meant West Germany had recognized East Germany as a sovereign state.

title: 6 JEWISH SCIENTISTS PROTEST IN MOSCOW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17Six Soviet Jewish scientists in Moscow telephoned a message to the president of the National, Academy of Sciences here today protesting their treatment in the Soviet Union and the refusal of the Soviet Governj ment to permit their immigration to Israel.

title: CELTICS TRIUMPH, STAY UNBEATEN
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 17 (UPI)Four points by John Havlicek and a blocked shot by Dave Cowens in the final minute lifted the Boston Celtics to a 119115 victory over the Atlanta Hawks tonight.

title: 'Zionist' Terrorists Accused
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 17Al Fatah, the major Palestinian commando organization, accused proIsraeli terrorists today of killing the Fatah representative in Rome.

title: Morocco Puts 220 on Trial for Attempt on King Hassan's Life
description: KENITRA, Morocco, Oct. 17  A military tribunal was told here today that rebel Moroccan Air Force pilots pumped salvos of cannon fire into an airliner carrying King Hassan II, dropped their fuel tanks on it and bumped it with one of their warplanes last August.

title: Chinese Doctors Watch Surgery on Heart Here
description: The 11 Chinese doctors visiting this country went to the Bronx yesterday to observe one of the most advanced forms of openheart surgerygrafting a vein to bypass a perilous clot in a coronary artery.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 17  The prospects of President Nixon's campaigning in New Jersey were reported remote today by Governor Cahill, the President's campaign chairman in the state.

title: J.&L. and Republic Steel in Black
description: Steel companies yesterday began filing their reports for the third quarter. The first two to report  the Republic Steel Corporation and the Jones & Laughling Steel Corporation showed turnarounds from yearearlier results.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel's New Tactic
description: The most recent bombing of Palestinian guerrilla concentrations in Syria and Lebanon by Israeli aircraft was not a mere retaliation for terrorist acts committed. On the contrary, the raid was heralded in Tel Aviv as the first move in a new policy of hitting presumed terrorists before they have a chance to strike.

title: About Pro Football
description: The Baltimore players did not like the dismissal on Monday of their coach, Don McCafferty, by the new general manager, Joe Thomas. The Colt players met with McCafferty yesterday and then issued a statement saying that the coach has unjustly been made to bear the burden for our poor showing this year. It was signed by a sevenman committee representing the squad and addressed to the loyal fans of the Baltimore Colts.

title: ARTHUR J. ALTMEYER, ROOSEVELT AIDE, 81
description: MADISON, Wis., Oct. 17Arthur J. Altmeyer, a former assistant Secretary of Labor and one of the chief architects of the Federal Social Security System, died yesterday in a hospital here. He was 81 years old.

title: Theater: 6 Rms Riv Vu, a Diverting Place to Visit
description: There are times when lightness is all, and lightness is the very special stockintrade of 6 Rms Riv Vu, which opened, as cheerful as a rising souffl, last night at the Helen Hayes Theater. It is insubstantial but sweet, and for all its improbabilities contrives to say something about the way New York lives. It makes a pleasant evening with a decent trace of truth to it.

title: 2CAR MAKERS WINPRICE INCREASES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17The Price Commission authorized the Chrysler Corporation and the American Motors Corporation today to increase prices on 1973 model cars to cover the cost of federally required safety and antipollution equipment.

title: Sports of The Times
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 17Before the third World Series game was rained out a man asked Paul Richards, throwing a bat at a man's head worse than throwing a ball at his head? The question referred, of course, to the case of Dagoberto Blanco Campaneris, the Oakland shortstop whose misdirected attempt to skull the Detroit pitcher, Lerrin LaGrow, with a Louisville Slugger recently had caused Joe Cronin, president of the American League, and Bowie Kuhn, the supreme being of baseball, to recoil in horror.

title: Series Game Off
description: A rainstorm postponed the third game of the World Series between the Oakland A's and Cincinnati Reds in Oakland last evening. The teams will play tonight at 8:30, New York time. Oakland leads the four  of  seven  game series, 20. Details on Page 31.

title: Democrats Increase Lead Among Pennsylvania Voters
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 (AP) Democrats held a 280,815 voter edge in Pennsylvania's primary this spring and now appear to have increased that lead by 10 per cent, according to figures compiled by McGoverrnShriver state campaign headquarters here.

title: Thieu Is Reported Increasingly Nervous
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 17With North Vietnamese troops in the outskirts of Saigon and with the recent series of secret peace talks in Paris, President Nguyen Van Thieu has shown signs of increasing nervousness, ranking American and South Vietnamese officials say.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct 17 (AP)Governor Cahill said today that his administration planned to use $49million of the funds it expects to receive under the Federal revenuesharing program in the state's school system.

title: Big Crowds in Belgrade Greet Queen Elizabeth
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 17 (Reuters)Thousands of Yugoslays thronged flagdecked streets today to give Queen Elizabeth II of Britain a arm weicome to Belgrade.

title: From New York to the Bahamas on the LowCalorie Cruise
description: To many people, the word cruise brings forth visions of an eating orgy, where waiters are forever plying passengers with 18course meals as the ship sails slowly from one exotic port to another.

title: Williams Defends Trips
