description: A clammy mixture of rain and snow soaked the metropolitan area yesterday, creating nasty driving conditions and more than one case of the sniffles.

title: For Different Reasons, A's and Reds Feel It's All Over
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 19 By tomorrow afternoon's game time, a more cautious rationalism will prevail, but the atmosphere in each dressing room tonight after Oakland's ninthinning 32 decision over Cincinnati, was easy to read:

title: WOMAN ACQUITTED IN SLAYING ON L.I.
description: MINEOLA. L. I., Oct. 19After deliberating five hours yesterday, an allmale jury found Mrs. Carol Lasquadro not guilty of manslaughter in the first degree in the shooting of Nicholas Castello, a reputed underworld figure.

title: Books of The Times
description: BARE RUINED CHOIRS. Doubt. Prophecy, and Radical Religion. By Garry Wills. 272 pages. Doubleday. $7.95.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City Repair Work Put Off in Dispute

title: Housing Repairs Work Canceled In a Dispute Over City Payment
description: The city's principal emergencyhousingrepair contract has been canceled, with both the city and the contractor threatening legal action and contending that the other side had not lived up to the terms of the contract.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 19  With the election less than three weeks off, the New Jersey Poll reported today that President Nixon was holding a 23point lead over Senator George McGovern in a state that both candidates regard as important for their chances of winning the Presidential election.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: The formation of a committee of New York State blacks for the reelection of President Nixon was announced here yesterday by Governor Rockefeller.

title: Revenue Sharing Funds To Be Mailed in December
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UPI)  The first installment of Federal payments under the new revenuesharing program will be mailed to about 38,000 states, counties, cities and towns in the first week of December, the Treasury Department announced today.

title: Statement Is Jssued
description: The closest thing to an official comment today came in the form of a news release issued by the Ministry of Information, which said:

title: JOSEPH BAMFORD
description: PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 19 Joseph C. Bamford, a retired silk manufacturer and former president of the Paterson Fire and Police Commission, died today in Paterson General Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at Pines Lake, Wayne.

title: Boll Comments in Athens
description: ATHENS, Oct. 19Heinrich Boll, who is on a visit here, said today that he would give part of the Nobel Prize money to support jailed writers and their families.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: With mock sorrow, Senator George McGovern pointed out to an audience of prominent Roman Catholics here last night that he had come to their dinner and President Nixon had not.

title: Dollars Sold in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Oct, 19, (Reuters)  Rumors that Japan might have to revalue the yen upward this year or by early 1973 brought a fresh wave of dollar sales on the Tokyo foreignexchange market today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 19 (Reuters)  Viktor Saneyev, the Soviet Olympic champion, has broken the world record for the triple jump with a mark of 57 feet 2 inches, Pravda reported today. Saneyev bettered the record during a track meet at Sukhumi on the Black Sea. The previous record was 57 feet 1 inch, by Pedro Perez of Cuba last year.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 Clark MacGregor, President Nixon's campaign manager, citing an unidentified highly reliable source in the press, said today that Senator George McGovern's organization had stolen mailing lists and spied on Democratic primary opponents and on the Nixon campaign.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Internal Revenue Service will owe taxpayers up to 50 per cent more next spring than the year before, largely because of overwithholding, a Treasury official said yesterday.

title: BULLETS, 11 BEHIND, RALLY TO BEAT KINGS
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 19 (AP) Phil Chenier scored 24 points and Elvin Hayes added 23 to pace the Baltimore Bullets to a 9483 National Basketball Association victory over the Kansas CityOmaha Kings tonight.

title: Rock Opera: 4 Priests Present Virgin
description: Only a benign, hut, unfortunately, shortsighted, faith could have brought a rock opera called Virgin into Philharmonic Hall for a showcase performance Wednesday night.

title: TICKETRON MAGAZINE SET TO GO NATIONAL
description: Ticketron Entertainment Magazine, at present distributed in the metropolitan area to a readership estimated at 600,000, will go national in April.

title: Two Americans Reported Killed in War Last Week
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Oct. 19 (AP)Two Americans were reported to have been killed in the Vietnam war last week, five were missing and four were wounded, the United States command announced today. For the first time in seven years of weekly casualty reports, no American deaths from noncombat causes were listed.

title: Allen Hearing Set Today
description: DENVER, Oct. 19 (AP)A plea hearing is scheduled tomorrow for Lucius Allen, the Milwaukee Bucks professional basketball player, and a companion who are charged with possession of marijuana. Allen, 25, who does not have to appear in person at the hearing, was charged in Denver County Court with possession of marijuana and conspiracy to possess marijuana.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 19 (AP)The World Boxing Commission issued a 48hour ultimatum tonight to Joe Frazier, the champion, and George Foreman to set a date for a heavyweight title fight. The ultimatum, which expires Saturday, was one of the first actions taken by the W.B.C. convention.

title: Senior Citizens Score Nixon TV Commercial
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19The National Council of Senior Citizens today accused President Nixon of falsifying his record on Social Security and Medicare legislation in a fiveminute television commercial that is part of his reelection campaign.

title: People and Business
description: The country's third largest insurance company, the Equitable Life Assurance Society, yesterday elected Coy G. Eklund, 57, as its president, effective March 1, 1973. At the same time, J. Henry Smith, its 62yearold chief executive officer, will move up from president to chairman and Davidson Sommers will retire as chairman at the age of 67.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: FREEHOLD, Oct. 19  The prosecution suddenly rested its case in the bribery and conspiracy trial of Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin and two others today after being blocked from putting on its last two witnesses.

title: Heinrich Boll Wins Nobel for Literature
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 19The 1972 Nobel Prize for Literature was awarded today to Heinrich Boll for his contribution to a renewal of German literature in the postwar era.

title: Metropolitan Champion Play Begins in The Hilton Today
description: The Metropolitan Championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association, sectional tournament with long and distinguished history, begins at the New York Hilton Hotel today with the following schedule:

title: Navy Strikes Reef of Ill Willin Groton
description: GROTON, Conn., Oct. 19It was 100 years ago that the Navy first erected two brick buildings on a 100acre tract here on the east bank of the Thames River.

title: Rodino Would Take Over Crime Inquiry
description: Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr. said yesterday that he favored disbanding the House Select Committee on Crime and the placement of its functions in the House Judiciary Committee.

title: Impasse Panel Named in Dispute Of Nurses With City's Hospitals
description: The city's Office of Collective Bargaining named an impasse panel yesterday to attempt to resolve the contract dispute between 5,500 staff nurses and the 19 municipal hospitals in which they work.

title: Three Spins of Mental Machine Produce Victory
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 19The wheels spun furiously in the Dick Williams mental machine in the ninth inning tonight and he immediately thought his way into a stranglehold on World Series victory for his A's. Often accused of overmanaging his heroes, the doughty skipper of the A's could do no wrong with his archmanipulations as pinchhitters made hits and the Oaklands ripped off four singles for the two lastminute runs that spelled a 32 success and sent the home town crowd into ecstatic delight.

title: Port Notes
description: A growing demand in Europe for Kansas City steaks and fresh horsemeat is keeping the Port Authority's animal shelter at Kennedy International Airport humming these days.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Representative Shirley Chisholm gave a lift to Senator George McGovern's Presidential bid when she joined him on the campaign trail yesterday for the first time since his nomination.

title: 9 LEADERS START TALK ON MARKET
description: PARIS, Oct. 19The leaders of nine European countries that will make up the enlarged Common Market opened their first joint meeting here today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As professional art historians we are disturbed by published reports of recent actions of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in disposing of paintings to dealers without public announcement, and have expressed our reservations to the board of trustees of the museum. To date, the board has neither answered nor acknowledged our communication and the urgency of the situation prompts us to make public our concern.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 19Two McGovern volunteers said today that they remembered talking to Donald H. Segretti about doing campaign work for the Democratic Presidential nominee. Mr. Segretti is the 31yearold lawyer who has been identified in news reports as a key operative in a campaign of disruption and harassment against the Democrats.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 (AP)Princeton will play New Mexico State in the opening round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference's 12th annual Quaker City basketball tournament, according to the draw announced today. The tourney starts Dec. 27 at the Palestra.

title: Tom Black Bull's Education:Orphaned Indian Focus of 'When Legends Die' Forrest and Widmark Cast in Main Roles
description: People are always doing things for Tom Black Bull's own good, or, at least, that's what they tell him. When he's orphaned at age 14, the Indian boy is taken out of the Colorado mountains, where he was born and reared, and sent to school on the Southern Ute reservation. For his own good he's asked to diagram sentences that seem to have been composed in Pennsylvania Dutch: "The crowd after the thrilling finish applauded enthusiastically the act."Years later, when he shows promise as a bronco rider. Tom (Frederic Forrest) is adopted by a canny, hard-drinking former rodeo rider named Red Dillon (Richard Widmark), who teaches Tom the tricks of the tradeboth how to ride well and how to appear to ride badly, that is, how to throw a contestthe better for Red to hustle bets on the side. It's for Tom's own good and not much else, since Red wastes most of their winnings on broads and booze."When Legends Die," the first film to be directed by Stuart Millar, the producer ("Little Big Man," "Paper Lion," etc.), is an intelligent, gentle, almost reticent film about the education of Tom Black Bull to the point where he can decide for himself what is, after all, for his own good. It's also about Indian pride and identity, but it doesn't slug you over the head with these things in the manner of a movie like "Journey Through Rosebud."In fact, "When Legends Die" may be too intelligent, too gentle and too reticent for its own good, especially in a market increasingly geared to the labeling of films as either hits or flops, which is more easily done when films deal in large, melodramatic gestures. "When Legends Die" does not. It deals in small betrayals, hurt feelings and interior resolutions, the sorts of things more likely to send you out of the theater talking about good taste than feeling any particular elation.Widmark is tough and funny as the grizzled old hustler. He is genuinely baffled when the younger man suggests there may be something more to life than going From one tank town rodeo to another, riding in endless Main Street parades behind knobby-kneed majorettes, putting on good shows, getting drunk, often getting rolled. Frederic Forrest, comparatively new to films, seems equally good. He has that kind of finely photogenic face that appears to reflect most emotion when its owner does least"When Legends Die" opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall.

title: Threat of a Writ Puts End To Canarsie Parent SitIn
description: The Canarsie parents protesting the enrollment of 31 black children from Brownsville at the John Wilson Junior High School 211 ended their three day sitin at the school at 8 A.M. yesterday after being threatened with court action by the central Board of Education.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In a recent editorial, Blueprint for Parks, you use the words  that blight of road and park alike, the camp on wheels.

title: Link to Package of Heroin Is Denied by Miss McNair
description: The actress and singer Barbara McNair said yesterday that she never handled the package allegedly containing heroin for which she was arrested Tuesday in the Playboy Club in McAfee, N.J. To this day, I have no knowledge of its content, I never possessed it, she asserted.

title: STEINKRAUS RIDES TO THIRD VICTORY
description: HARRISBURG, Pa. Oct. 19Canada almost scored an upset in the international jumping class today at the Pennsylvania National horse show. The difference was a tenth of a second.

title: Equity Financing
description: An offering of 1,500,000 common shares of Orange and Rockland Utilities Inc. at $16.625 per share was made yesterday by an underwriting group managed by Merrill Lynch. Net proceeds will be used to reduce shortterm indebtedness incurred in connection with the utility's construction program. The company's stock was unchanged at 16 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Although Sir John Betjeman, as a bestselling poet, deserved to be named Britain's Poet Laureate, Prime Minister Heath would have served both his country's and Ireland's interests better had he instead put Sir John in charge of finding a solution to the Ulster problem.

title: Augustus Beck Dead at 73; A Times Production Aide
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 19 Augustus Beck, who had been an employe of The New York Times for 44 years at his retirement in 1964, died today at his home here. He was 73 years old.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Oct. 19Realizing they cannot run on the Cadets when Rutgers plays host to Army Saturday, the Scarlet Knights have two things in mind: force the Cadets to throw and do some throwing themselves.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET OPEN ARMS TALKS NOV. 21
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19The United States and the Soviet Union announced today that negotiations to put further limits on each side's offensive forces would begin on Nov. 21 in Geneva.

title: Man in the News
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, Oct. 19More than any other living German, Heinrich Theodor Boll is a national writer in that his works are read with equal intensity in both East and West Germany.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Rain forced the New York Jets to switch to an indoor practice session yesterday underneath the stands at Shea Stadium.

title: SelfDetermination in Vietnam
description: It seems inevitable with a Presidential election that partisan debate over foreign policy should accelerate. In view of the record of the present Administration, debate must focus on Vietnam rather than other areas where successes are harder to challenge. This should not be unexpected, nor should we think it undesirable, as long as the debate is confined to the real issues and the usefulness and correctness of current policy. Unfortunately, however, there is a growing tendency for dissidents, ranging from the increasingly violent peace activists to the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, to feel compelled to lecture us on the morality of our policies.

title: GROSS IS SOUGHT BY INVESTIGATORS
description: The lawyer for Ted Gross, former Commissioner of the city's Youth Services Agency, has been given until today to make definite arrangements for his client to appear before investigators looking into alleged irregularities in the agency, or a subpoena will be issued for Mr. Gross, a source close to the investigation said last night.

title: NEW YORK
description: There are so many noisy voices in the world these days, including the shrill and urgent voices of columnists, that it is seldom possible to hear the quieter thoughts of wiser and more thoughtful men.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The recent censure of the Metropolitan Museum of Art by the Art Dealers Association for the private sale of paintings by Van Gogh and Rousseau is both unwarranted and unbecoming.

title: TERMPAPER MILL ORDERED CLOSED
description: Court Backs Lefkowitz on Ghostwriting Group Here

title: Irate Westchester Commuters, Delayed, Halt an Express Train
description: Two dozen angry, frustrated Penn Central commuters, stranded at the Mount Vernon station in Westchester County by a train breakdown that blocked their local tracks, watched three New Yorkbound express trains whip past yesterday morning and could stand it no longer.

title: Bill to Curb Noise Voted by Congress In Its Final Hours
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) Just before the 92d Congress ended, a retiring member's final act in the House enabled environmentalists to send President Nixon a bill that could help Americans to enjoy a quieter future.

title: MONEY EXPANDING AT MODERATE PACE
description: Monetary expansion has proceeded at a moderate pace in recent weeks, the Federal Re serve System reported yesterday.

title: Earnings Climb 41%
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, the secondlargest chemical producer in the nation, reported yesterday a 41 per cent jump in thirdquarter earnings on a 9 per cent gain in sales.

title: ExAide of C.I.A. Says U.S. Bombed Leper Colony
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19A former Central Intelligence Agency official said in a new book published today that the Air Force bombed a North Vietnamese leper colony in 1966 after Air Force photo analysts mistakenly concluded that the buildingssurrounded by two rows of barbedwire fencewere a North Vietnamese division headquarters.

title: Environmental Congress Head Asks U.N. to Implement Plans
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19  Maurice F. Strong, secretary general of the United Nations environmental conference held in Stockholm last June, called on the General Assembly today to establish the financial and organizational machinery to carry out the conference's recommendations.

title: Australia Leads Men's Golf; U.S. Amateurs 7 Shots Back,
description: BUENOS AIRES. Oct. 19 (AP) Australia, bolstered by Anthony Gresham's twounderpar 69, moved into the lead today in the second round of the fourday amateur men's team golf championship for the Eisenhower Trophy.

title: Laird Tells of Moves to Bar Disobedient Military Acts
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird, insisting that the documented instances of unauthorized bombing of North Vietnam did not represent a breakdown of civilian control of the military forces, outlined today a series of steps that he said were aimed at further strengthening civilian authority.

title: Jewish Leader Here Is Sworn By Mayor to City Planning Unit
description: Mrs. Sylvia Deutch, director of the American Jewish Congress's New York Metropolitan Council, was sworn in yesterday by Mayor Lindsay as a $15.000ayear member of the City Planning Commission.

title: Lumber Controls Criticized at Hearing
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 19  A Price Commission hearing to day on alleged noncompliance with price controls in the lumber industry drew out plenty of criticism for the controls program, but little in the way of help for the commission.

title: ERVING REJOINS SQUIRES TONIGHT
description: NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 19 (AP) Julius Erving said today he would return to the Virginia Squires of the American Basket ball Association pending disposition of his court suit to break his fouryear contract with the Squires and play in the National Basketball Association.

title: Sale in Las Vegas Approved
description: CARSON CITY, Nev. Oct. 19 (AP)  The Nevada Gaming Commission approved today the sale of the Thunderbird hotel and casino in Las Vegas to Caesars World, Inc., of North Miami Beach Fla. Caesars said it is paying $13.5million for the Thunderbird and plans to build a new casinohotel on the site.

title: Manila Uprooting Thousands in Drive Against Guerrillas
description: CAUAYAN, the Philippines, Oct. 19The Philippine armed forces are uprooting thousands of villagers in a region through which small bands of guerrillas roam and moving the refugees to towns and villages securely in Government control.

title: NEW JERSERY
description: DEERFIELD, N. J., Oct. 19 (AP)In an echo of a similar tragedy that took the life of her husband 16 years ago, a woman tavern owner here has been shot and killed in a holdup attempt.

title: Showdown in Saigon?
description: With a certain irony, Henry Kissinger's current talks with President Thieu in Saigon stand as the most delicate link in the chain of negotiations which appears to have brought the search for a Vietnam peace to a sensitive juncture. It has often been suggested that when the moment of truth for a Vietnam settlement arrives, it will be this country's nominal ally who proves even more intractable than the enemy.

title: 2 Brooklyn Men Facing Trial Are Accused of Threat to Witness
description: Two Brooklyn men facing trial on Federal narcotics charges were accused yesterday of threatening to kill a prospective Government witness who had pleaded guilty along with another codefendant found shot to death on Tuesday.

title: Gibson Disagrees With Aide On Newark's Financial Crisis
description: NEWARK, Oct. 19Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson disagreed today with the view of this city's Business Administrator that Newark is as close to a fiscal catastrophe as any city in America can get.

title: Bronze by Remington Auctioned For a Record Price of $125,000
description: Frederic Remington's actionpacked bronze Coming Through the Rye was auctioned last night for $125,000, a record for an American sculpture. Last year, another cast of the piece set a record at 884,000.

title: PRESIDENT PLANS TO LIMIT SPENDING DESPITE CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19President Nixon intends to withhold funds that Congress has voted in order to keep Government spending as close as he can to $250billion this year, despi'e Congress's refusal to grant him explicit authority to do so.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 19 Tiny Rhode Island, which has not sent a Republican to the Senate in 42 years, is very nearly awash this fall with a small flood of professional political consultants vying to keep this Democratic record intact or to break it.

title: Personalities: P.G.A. Drops Creasey
description: Robert T. Creasey and the executive committee of the Professional Golfers Association have parted company. The committee said it had terminated the services of Creasey, who had been executive director since Jan., 1, 1966. His reported salary was $50,000 plus expenses.

title: U.S. Investigates Dallas Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19The Justice Department confirmed, today that it was investigating the existence and nature of relationships between commercial banks in Dallas County, Tex.

title: Police Chiefs Elect Head
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 19 (UPI)Don R. Deming, chief of the Winnetka, Ill., Police Department since 1953, was elected as the new president of the International Association of Chiefs of Police yesterday, succeeding George A. Murphy, police chief of Oneida, N.Y.

title: 850,000 DONORS PRAISED BY SHRIVER
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 19Appealing to Illinois businessmen for campaign funds, Sargent Shriver described the breadth of the Democratic ticket's 850,000 contributors today as a miracle in modern campaign financing.

title: Veal With Ham, and a Frozen Lime Pie
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Manila Seizes Lawyer at a U.S. Base
description: MANILA, Oct. 19  Philippine troops entered Subic Bay Naval Station yesterday and arrested an American civilian lawyer, Douglas Sorenson, in the martiallaw roundup of persons suspected of unspecified activities.

title: KISSINGER MEETS WITH RIR TWICE; BOTH SIDES SILENT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 19President Nguyen Van Thieu, Henry A. Kissinger and Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker conferred twice today for a total of five hours.

title: Regular Weekday Runs Set for L.I.R.R. Monday
description: The Long Island Rail Road, which had thousands of working commuters delayed up to two hours on Columbus Day, Oct. 9, because it ran on a holiday schedule, will observe a regular weekday schedule for Veterans Day on Monday.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr. said yesterday that he favored disbanding the House Select Committee on Crime and the placement of its functions in the House Judiciary Committee.

title: Laird Tells of Moves to Bar Disobedient Military Acts
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird, insisting that the documented instances of unauthorized bombing of North Vietnam did not represent a breakdown of civilian control of the military forces, outlined today a series of steps that he said were aimed at further strengthening civilian authority.

title: POLITICIANS CITED IN MAFIA INQUIRY
description: A handful of Brooklyn political figures will be subpoenaed before a rackets grand jury as a result of evidence arising from the surveillance of a Brooklyn trailer identified as a clandestine Mafia meeting place wellplaced informants said yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Quarterly Profit Soars
description: The Aluminum Company of America reported yesterday major gains in thirdquarter operations. The company placed, sales and operating revenues at $436.7million for the three months ended Sept. 30. This compared with $318.5million a year earlier. Net income soared to $24.5million, or $1.10 a share from the $4.1million, or 16 cents a share on fewer shares, in the like period of 1971.

title: Sports of The Tunes
description: OAKLAND. Calif., Oct. 19The Sparky and Dick Show, a primetimetelevision serial designed to promote the sale of shaving cream and establish the rounders championship of the world, has developed into the most impressively cerebral program since The $64,000 Question. This is fortunate indeed, for the physical aspects of the entertainment have been reduced to a minimum by execrable stage lighting.

title: Unbeaten Crusaders Top Raiders for 5th Straight
description: The New York Raiders of the World Hockey Association are counting on exciting hockey to attract fans in their first year, but they went about it the wrong way last night as they lost, 31, to the undefeated Cleveland Crusaders. Cleveland's record is now 50.

title: SONG RECITAL GIVEN
description: When Mozart's Lucio Silla was revived by the Manhattan School of Music in 1968, one of the more successful singers in that difficult enterprise was Anna Giancotti. Wednesday night the soprano returned to give a recital in the New York Cultural Center, restricting her material to Italian works songs by Bellini, WolfFerrari, Cimara, Pizzetti and Respighi and arias by Bellini and Puccini. This was obviously congenial music for the singer, because her feeling for the language and phrasing seemed right at all times.

title: TAMS DEFEAT CHAPS AT BUZZER, 115113
description: DALLAS, Oct. 19 (AP)Dave Lattin's jump shot at the buzzer lifted the Memphis Tams to a 115113 American Basketball Association triumph over the Dallas Chaparrals tonight.

title: The Frustrated 92d
description: The legislative power is shared by the President, who initially proposes most legislation and vetoes or signs bills into law, and by Congress, which works its will through its committees and through conferences between its two chambers. Under such a system of shared powers, compromise is inevitable. When the Presidency and Congress are controlled by different political parties, compromise becomes crucial.

title: Connecticut Court Refuses Gus Hall A Place on Ballot
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 19  A Superior Court judge ruled today that the names of Gus Hall, the Communist Presidential candidate, and Jarvis Tyner, his running mate, could not be printed on Connecticut's Nov. 7 election balolts because the Communist party had failed to prove that it collected the signatures of enough registered voters.

title: 4 Charter Airlines Score Rule Critics
description: Four charter airlines assailed as absurd and incredible yesterday assertions by Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines that newly liberalized Federal charter flight rules would cause massive diversion of passengers from scheduled airlines.

title: PRESIDENT PLANS TO LIMIT SPENDING DESPITE CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19President Nixon intends to withhold funds that Congress has voted in order to keep Government spending as close as he can to $250billion this year, despite Congress's refusal to grant him explicit authority to do so.

title: Threat of a Writ Puts End To Canarsie Parent SitIn
description: The Canarsie parents protesting the enrollment of 31 black children from Brownsville at the John Wilson Junior High School 211 ended their three day sitin at the school at 8 A.M. yesterday after being threatened with court action by the central Board of Education. The parents acted after a night of negotiations with the representatives of Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner produced the agreement to evacuate the Brooklyn school and keep it closed until next Tuesday, the day after Veterans Day.

title: About Pro Football
description: Both the Giants and Jets are favored to win at home on Sunday and that has not been true for some time. The Giants are an 8point choice over the Cardinals and the Jets by 7 over the Colts. Games on television here will be Dallas at Washington, Channel 2, 4 P.M., and either San Diego at Detroit, 2 P.M., or Cincinnati at Los Angeles, 4 P.M., over Channel 4. If the World Series is over by Sunday it will be the earlier game. The Monday night contest, Channel 7, at 9 P.M., is Minnesota at Chicago. Here is a preview of all games with wonlosttied records in parentheses.

title: James J. Frawley Is Dead; Owned Historic Restaurant
description: James J. Frawley, owner of Pete's Tavern at 18th Street and Gramercy Park, died on Oct. 12 in Hong Kong while on a trip around the world. He was 70 years old and had made his home the last few years in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Evangelist Draws the Sick and Anguished
description: With her arm extended gracefully in its draped chiffon sleeve, Kathryn Kuhlman shut her eyes tightly, faced upward and told the congregation, This is such an important moment.

title: Mets and Yankees Trade Minor League Farmhands
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 19 (AP)The New York Mets and New York Yankees completed a trade of minor leaguers today.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ESSINGTON, Pa., Oct. 19Senator George McGovern charged today that President Nixon had no respect for constitutional government and personal freedom

title: UNDEFEATED SABRES CRUSH CANUCKS, 60
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 19 (AP) Gil Perreault, Rick Martin and Rene Robert picked up 10 points as the Buffalo Sabres beat the Vancouver Canucks, 6.0, in a National Hockey League game tonight.

title: Theater
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 19 Having previously drawn inspiration from Turgenev (Journey of the Fifth Horse) and from 11thcentury English history (Ceremony of Innocence), Ronald Ribman, in his new play. A Break in the Skin, turns to contemporary America for a technological comic nightmare. The playwright continues to be unpredictable this time not only in choice of subject, but within the play from scene to scene.

title: Diamond Nears the Capital
description: SCHENECTADY, Oct. 19 (UPI)  The State Environmental Conservation Commissioner, Henry L. Diamond, pedaled into the state capital district today on his statewide bicycle trip promoting the environmental bond issue. The bond issue, totaling $1.15billion, is on the November ballot. Mr. Diamond, who began the 526mile trek last Thursday at Niagara Falls, began today's scheduled 57mile leg in suburban Scotia.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The news media often give the impression that the centuryold differences between blacks and the labor movement are as strong as ever. The most recent example is the extensive coverage devoted to the formation of a coalition of black trade unionists (news story, Oct. 3) and to the general treatment of efforts to integrate construction trades.

title: City Increases Productivity by Piling Up the Work
description: Like a desktop ant farm, one small nook of the city welfare bureaucracy has been fascinating Lindsay officials lately. It has become a classic case of how to finesse a 20fold increase in work from a group of civil servants.

title: At Rehearsal for Lysistrata, Melina Mercouri Speaks Out
description: On the needs that Melina Mercouri would do Lysistrata, Aristophanes's comedy about a sex strike for peace, some wag suggested that its name be changed to Never on Sunday. Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday or Saturday.

title: Reserve Wins Court Test On Daily Check Clearing
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)A Federal judge today refused to stop the Federal Reserve System from ordering banks to pay for checks on the day the checks are presented by the Reserve for payment. United States District Court Judge Charles Richey turned down a request for a preliminary injunction against the system's new rule on the collection of checks.

title: Legion Chief to Visit Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UPI) The American Legion's national commander, Joe L. Matthews, plans to visit the Soviet Union in December to inspect Soviet facilities for the treatment of disabled veterans, it was announced today.

title: Store Sales Increase 9%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $908million, up 9 per cent from $833million a year earlier. Total retail store sales were about $8.85billion, up 9 per cent from $8.09billion a year earlier.

title: Merger News
description: The United Tennessee Bancshares Corporation announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire the American National Corporation of Chattanooga, a onebank holding company, through an exchange of stock.

title: Uganda Broadens Category of Asians Due for Expulsion
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Oct. 19 (Reuters)  The President of Uganda, Maj. Gen. Idi Amin, today ordered the expulsion of all Asians with Kenyan, Tanzanian and Zambian citizenship.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Faulty Repaving of 153 Street Cuts Is Found Here
description: The Transportation Administration disclosed yesterday that it had found 153 badly repaved; street cuts in three days of checking thoroughfares in Manhattan, south of 86th Street. It said Consolidated Edison was responsible for 78 of the faulty repaving jobs.

title: Music Hall Negotiators To Meet With Mediator
description: Negotiators for the Radio City Music Hall and members of the orchestra are scheduled to meet this morning with Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, in a last ditch effort to resolve, their differences.

title: A, NEILSON KERWIN
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 19 A. Neilson Kerwin, former secretary of the North American Reassurance Company of, New York, died today in Lawrence Hospital after a brief illness. He was 67 years old and lived at 1200 Midland Avenue.

title: Books of The Times
description: Fact or fictionor that penumbra area in between denoted as memory, where fact is assumed to prevailthat is the tantalizing dilemma of the writer. Herbert Gold, one of our best craftsmen, has turned again to autobiography, the penumbra area, as he did once before in Fathers. The result was worth waiting for, if not a major

title: Business Briefs
description: Capital expenditures by United States industry next year could reach a total of $98billion, a gain of 10 per cent over the $89.1billion projected for 1972. Lionel D. Edie, investment counselors, said yesterday. Edie's annual survey showed durable goods industries as a whole planned a 13 per cent increase in spending for plant and equipment, with projections of 46 per cent more investment in primary iron and steel, and 57 per cent more in transportation equipment (excluding motor vehicles).

title: House of Commons Rejects Televising of Proceedings
description: LONDON, Oct. 19After six, hours of soulsearching, they House of Commons, which once imprisoned journalists for reporting its sessions and can still clear its galleries of the press and the public, tonight, rejected a motion to put itself on television.

title: Bret to Bid Adieu Oct. 28
description: Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris, the musical costarring Elly Stone and Joe Maslen, will end its Broadway engagement at the Royale Theater on Oct. 28 after 51 performances. The cast includes George Ball and Henrietta Valor.

title: Screen:
description: Jim Collier is a young black man who for a time lustfully longed for a white woman, any beautiful white woman, and then met a white woman and married her. They now have a baby. His history, which is real, has a certain universality: starting out in search of a dream and ending up with a wife. And it also has a definite particularity, involving as it does his hangups about whiteness, her hangups about blackness, and the little obstacles society puts in the way of racially mixed couples trying to maintain a marriage or a normal relationship.

title: JAPAN SAYS CHINESE ACCEPT TIE TO TAIPEI
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19The Japanese Foreign Minister, Masayoshi Ohira, said at a news conference today that China did not object to Japan's continued economic and cultural, ties with the Chinese Nationalist on Taiwan, despite last month's establishment of diplomatic relations between Peking and Tokyo.

title: Advertising:
description: It is understood that the gang over at Tinker, Dodge & Delano have opened a package from Borden's and in it found a prize  the Cracker Jack account.

title: BIAGGI AND FINO CALLEDININQUIRY
description: Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx and the man who preceded him in Congress, State Supreme Court Justice Paul A. Fino, have been questioned by Federal authorities about alleged abuses involving private immigration bills.

title: Court Voids Appointments To District School Boards
description: In the most farreaching decision on school decentralization since the system was instituted in the city two and a half years ago, a State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that every community school board vacancy to which an appointment has been made must now be filled by an election.

title: Telephone Co. to Give Scores During Series
description: The New York Telephone Company will provide World Series scores on telephone number 6371212.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WILMINGTON, Del.  The Governor who slammed the door on heavy industry with a ban on coastal pollution is struggling for reelection.

title: Railroad Freight Traffic Rose 21.2% Last Week
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19The Association of American Rail roads reported today that freight traffic last week reached a new high for a single week of an estimated 17 billion tonmiles, 21.2 per cent abowe zhe corresponding week last year Traffic in the comparable week of 1971 was affected by dock and coal strikes. Coal loadings accounted for more than 60 per cent of the total increase in tonmiles over the comparable week a year ago.

title: Counterproposals Reported
description: SAIGON. Friday. Nov. 20 (Agence FrancePresse) The talks between Henry A. Kissinger and President Thieu are concerned with working out counterproposals to North Vietnamese and Vietcong proposals for a tripartite government in South Vietnam, acording to political sources here.

title: City W elf are Aide And Her Husband Accused of Fraud
description: A supervisor in the city's Social Services Department and her husband were arrested yesterday on grand larceny charges involving the issuing and cashing of more than $26,000 in fraudulent welfare checks.

title: Ivy League Roundup
description: It is imperative that Roly Purrington, Yale's fine quarterback, perform at peak efficiency in the Bowl tomorrow because the Elis will be facing a Columbia team that is on the brink of elimination in the Ivy League football race. But if Purrington does not seem as sharp as he has been in Yale's three previous victories, he may have an excuse. The senior from Franklin, Va., will spend the entire morning taking his law board examinations. Yale and Columbia began playing 100 years ago, and the Elis have a 35131 wonlosttied record in the series.

title: Market Place: Wall St. Gets Urge to Merge
description: Dull stock markets, slow trading, high costs and a dim outlook have produced an urge to merge in Wall Street these days as the securities industry grapples anew with the negative forces that threatened it two years ago.

title: Perfectly, Perfectly Clear
description: During the darkest days of World War II, Winston Churchill delivered a oneparagraph message to the people, which began: The news from France is very bad.

title: Moscow Circus to Open Tour Of Eastern Cities on Nov. 14
description: The Moscow State Circus will make its fourth visit to this country Nov. 14. opening a threemonth tour of Eastern cities in Providence, R. I.

title: Liquefied Natural Gas Accord In Iran Signed by Companies
description: A $700million liquefied natural gas deal was signed here yesterday between the National Iranian Gas Company and consortium headed by the International Systems and Controls Corporation of Houston.

title: Teaching Schoolchildren That There Is an Art to Seeing Beauty
description: KATONAH, N. Y.Inside the entryway to a new school in northern Westchester hangs a shimmery, rainbowhued abstraction. The children pass by the painting and comment on it with possessive joy, for they bought it themselves, with $185 they raised, and gave it to the Somers Intermediate School. But if it hadn't been for the Katonah Gallery, a few miles away, they might never. have decided that a work of art should be their gift to the new school. For the gallery, in the last four years, has been fostering a special brand of art appreciation With exhibitions sent to the schools and with events at the gallery.

title: LETELLIER, O'HERN SHARE GOLF LEAD
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 19 (AP)Ron Letellier and Jim O'Hern led the way through the first round of the $100,000 Professional Golfers Association Club championship today with fiveunderpar 65's.

title: TV Review
description: Right after The Sonny and Cher Show this evening, the Columbia Broadcasting System is turning over two hours to C.B.S. News. The Air PiratesCan They Be Stopped? begins at 9 o'clock, and 99 Days to Survival, postponed from last March, takes over at 10. Burton Benjamin is the executive producer for both programs.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: EDISON, N. J., Oct. 19About 100 members of the Middlesex County Medical Society listened last night to a proposal by a guest that they join a national union of physicians.

title: 9Month Record Set
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, whose widely diversified products range from Scotch brand tapes to photographic equipment and health care products with expansion into pharmaceuticals, expects to post its 21st consecutive year of record sales and earnings in 1972, according to yesterday's financial report.

title: Spy Plane Joins the Search for Boggs in Alaska
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Oct. 19 (UPI)An Air Force spy plane joined scores of other aircraft today in the search for a plane missing with the House majority leader, Hale Boggs, and three other persons.

title: Restoration of the Pieta To Be Finished in 72
description: ROME, Oct: 19The restoration of Michelangelo's Pieta, the marble group vandalized five months ago, should be completed as a Christmas gift by the end of the year, the director of the Vatican Museum, Deoclecio Redig de Campos, said today.

title: Spain and Yugoslavia Tie
description: LAS PALMAS, Canary Islands, Oct. 19 (AP)Spain and Yugoslavia tied 22. in their World Cup Soccer qualification match here today.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF AS TRADING LAGS
description: The American Stock Exchange index finished yesterday at its lowest level in more than nine months as prices declined in slower trading.

title: House Contest
description: A series of what he calls Rockymanders failed to dislodge Representative John M. Murphy, a Democrat, from the House seat that he won on Staten Island in 1962. Now the Republican realigners, their partisan plans focused elsewhere in the state, have provided him with some timely help.

title: Letellier and O'Hern Card 65's To Pace Pinehurst Golf Field
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 19 (AP)Ron Letellier and Jim O'Hern led the way through the first round of the $100,000 Professional Golfers Association Club championship today with fiveunderpar 65's.

title: A's Win in 9th, 32, and Lead Series, 31
description: OAKLAND, Oct. 19The Oakland A's scored two runs in the ninth inning tonight on four straight singlesthree by pinchbittersand defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 32, in the fourth game of the 69th World Series.

title: Teachers College to Reopen
description: SEOUL, Oct. 19 (AP)Teachers colleges will reopen tomorrow in the first easing of martial law restrictions imposed Tuesday by President Park, the military command announced today. The command also lifted the ban on some kinds of assemblies in the Seoul area, like picnics, meetings of stockholders and guided tours arranged by travel agencies.

title: TRAINS BLOCKED BY IRATE RIDERS
description: Two dozen angry, frustrated Penn Central commuters, stranded at the Mount Vernon station in Westchester County by a train breakdown that blocked their local tracks, watched three New Yorkbound express trains whip past yesterday morning and could stand it no longer.

title: Policeman Cleared of Charge That He Accepted a Bribe
description: A policeman charged with accepting a bribe not to make a narcotics arrest was acquitted in state supreme court in Queens yesterday.

title: Police Raid Interrupts Operations at a Policy Bank in Chelsea
description: Plainclothes policemen raided three apartments in a luxury building in the Chelsea area yesterday and cracked open multimilliondollar policy bank that was described as a main nerve center for a new and burgeoning numbers operation run by Cubans.

title: Stage: Mother Earth, a Rock Revue
description: Strangely enough, I was really looking forward to Mother Earth at the Belasco Theater last night, and now I feel as if I am stealing wheatgerm lollipops from kids. I believe in motherhood, earthhood and ecology. Indeed I not only believe in ecology, I actually know what it means. But Mother Earth needed more cultivation before it ventured on Broadway.

title: BO SCOT'S TAFFY WINS SIRES STAKE
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 19An accident during a harness race at Vernon Downs, Vernon, N. Y., last night hospitalized Ben Webster with a dislocated right shoulder and is expected to sideline him for at least two weeks.

title: MISS DAVIS SIGNS TO WRITE MEMOIR
description: Angela Davis has signed an agreement with Bantam Books, Inc., and Bernard Geis Associates, Inc., to write a book entitled The Education of Revolutionary, Mr. Geis announced yesterday. He also reported that a settlement had been agreed upon with the creditors of his company, which has been in financial difficulties.

title: Record of Major Nixon Legislative Proposals and of Action Taken in the Second Session of 92d Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19Following is a summary of President Nixon's major legislative proposals and of the action taken by Congress in its 1972 session, along with bills not approved:

title: Senator Brooke Endorsed By Massachusetts A.D.A.
description: BOSTON, Oct. 19 (AP)The Massachusetts Chapter of the Americans for Democratic Action, a liberal political organization, endorsed the reelection hid of Republican Senator Edward W. Brooke yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The London Times of Oct. 6 reproduced in full your leading article on the British Labor Party Conference and now that my hand has stopped shaking with anger, I am writing to ask, in the nicest possible way, that you mind your own damn business.

title: Soviet Reported to Pledge Some Arms Aid to Egypt
description: CAIRO, Oct. 19Premier Aziz Sidky brought back from Moscow a Soviet promise to resume deliveries of spare parts and replacements for Soviet weapons now in Egypt, informed diplomatic sources said today.

title: PRICES UNSTEADY IN SUGAR FUTURES
description: A Paris sugar dealer sold a cargo (about 11,000 tons) of sugar to Iraq yesterday at a high price for prompt delivery. Sugar futures here rose quite sharply on the news, and then backed down again, on the New York Coffeee and Sugar Exchange.

title: Anniversariesand Some Great Music
description: The Israel Philharmonic Orchestra's concert at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night was a manylayered occasion, celebrating as it did not only the 25th anniversary of the founding of the State of Israel but the presentation of the AmericaIsrael Cultural Foundation's King Solomon Award to the evening's conductor, Leonard Bernstein. Furthermore, piling anniversary upon anniversary. Mr. Bernstein himself was marking milestones: It has been just 25 years since he first conducted the orchestra, then known as the Palestine Philharmonic, and 10 years since his last appearance in Carnegie Hall, which was home to the New York Philharmonic before the erection of Lincoin Center.

title: 9 LEADERS START TALK ON MARKET
description: PARIS, Oct. 19The leaders of nine European countries that will make up the enlarged Common Market opened their first joint meeting here today.

title: Credit Markets
description: The bond market, which had been gradually losing the ground it had gained in earlyOctober peace rallies, dug in its heels yesterday and managed a small advance.

title: Nevada Approves Hotel Sale
description: The Nevada Gaming Commission has approved the sale of the Thunderbird Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas to Caesar's World, Inc. Caesar's said it was paying $13.5million for the hotel and plans to build a new casinohotel, the Mark Anthony, on the site.

title: Study Says Navy's Antisubmarine Warfare Spending Will Rise From $2.5Billion to $4.5Billion by 75
description: The United States Navy's expenditure for antisubmarine warfare will rise from the current figure of $2.5billion to about $4.5billion a year by 1975 according to a study conducted by Frcst & Sullivan, a New York market research firm.

title: WOODCOCK BACKS CURBS ON IMPORTS
description: DETROIT, Oct. 19  The president of the United Auto Workers said today that he favored content laws to protect the jobs of American auto workers.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19The Democraticcontrolled Congress, which adjourned yesterday, never quite found its place in histcry as it alternated between confrontation and docility, between cooperation with and defiance of a Republican President.

title: Another Lawmakers Meeting
description: The President also met tonight with about 50 South Vietnamese legislators and other politicians, both proGovernment and Opposition, at a dinner at the presidential palace following his second meeting with Ambassador Bunker and Mr. Kissinger.

title: KISSINGER MEETS WITH THIEU TWICE; BOTH SIDES SILENT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 19President Nguyen Van Thieu, Henry A. Kissinger and Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker conferred twice today for a total of five hours.

title: An Armed Uprising in Al Fatah Over Arafat's Role Is Put Down
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 19An armed uprising within Al Fatah, the main Palestinian guerrilla organization, against the moderate leadership of Yasir Arafat has been quelled with the mediation of the Algerian Ambassador here.

title: HENRY GOLDGRAN
description: Henry Goldgran, a concert impresario and play producer, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Forest Hills, Queens. His age was 58.

title: Landon Praises Nixon
description: Hesston, Kan. Oct. 19 (UPI) Alfred M. Landon, the Republican Presidential candidate in 1936, praised President Nixon today as a tough trader in world politics. In dinner address to the Hesston Chamber of Commerce and Hesston college, the former Kansas governor and elder statesman of the G.O.P. said the fate of the world might hinge on Mr. Nixon's reelection. Mr. Landon critized the Detmocratic candidate Senator George McGovern for proposing cutbacks in the U.S. military commitments in Europe.

title: F.D.A. Recalls 2d Batch Of Israeli Canned Food
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 19 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration announced today the second major recall of Israeli canned farm products.

title: MARCEL PELLENC, 75, OF FRENCH SENATE
description: PARIS, Oct. 19  Marcel Pellenc, chairman of the Senate's Finance Committee, died here today at the age of 75.

title: Advertising:
description: In the colorful but cluttered offices of Ms. magazine the atmosphere is feminine, liberated, happy and optimistic.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two men held up an elementaryschool teacher Brooklyn yesterday in front of a classroom of 28 horrified firstgrade pupils. It was the third incident involving a city elementeary schoolteacher in the last two weeks.

title: Railway Express Struck; 15,000 Workers Affected
description: New York members of the Brotherhood of Railway and Airline Clerks struck the Railway Express Agency at 12:01 A.M. today as part of a nationwide strike, the Associated Press reported. About 100 union members were affected in the city.

title: JOHNSON CEREMONY WILL STRESS RIGHTS
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 19A national symposium on civil rights will be held here Dec. 11 and 12 in connection with the opening for public study of the one million papers on civil rights in the Lyndon B. Johnson Library.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 19 (AP)Governor Cahill said today that he stood by his nomination of State Commissioner of Education Carl L. Marburger to a second term, despite renewed opposition from teachers.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today Oct. 20, 1972
description: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today Oct. 20, 1972

title: Statement Is Issued
description: The closest thing to an official comment today came in the form of a news release issued by the Ministry of Information, which said:

title: Ballet: Chabriesque
description: The City Center Joffrey Ballet presented a new version of a not very old ballet Wednesday night at the City Center with Chabriesque.

title: The Food Can Be FineIf You Know How to Order
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: Spain and Yugoslavia Tie
description: LAS PALMAS. Canary Islands, Oct. 19 (AP)Spain and Yugoslavia tied 22, in their World Cup Soccer qualification match here today.

title: Gibson Disagrees With Aide On Newark's Financial Crisis
description: NEWARK, Oct. 19Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson disagreed today with the view of this city's Business Administrator that Newark is as close to a fiscal catastrophe as any city in America can get.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 With Congress adjourned and less than three weeks until Election Day, the White House announced plans today for additional campaigning by President Nixon next week.

title: CHILE STRIKERS ADD TO THEIR DEMANDS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 19 (AP)  Striking truckers and shopkeepers made new demands on Chile's leftist Government today after a week of turmoil that President Salvador Allende Gossens described in a midnight speech on television as the gravest in our nation in recent years.

title: 2 MUGGING SUSPECTS SHOT, A 3D CAPTURED
description: An offduty patrolman walking home from a Harlem police station early yesterday broke up the mugging of a man by six assailants by shooting two of the suspects and capturing a third.

title: Sanders, U.S. Wrestler, Killed in Auto Crash
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 20 (UPI)Richard Sanders, a United States Olympic wrestler, died in an automobile accident in southern Yugoslavia Wednesday, United States Consulate officials said today.

title: The American Nobel
description: American scientists made almost a clean sweep this year's Nobel Prizes in the physical and biological sciences. Yesterday three Americans shared the physics award and three other Americans split the chemistry laurels; last week an American and a Briton divided the prize for medical research.

title: 13 Men, 5 Women Are Indicted Here On Heroin Charge
description: Thirteen men and five women were charged with a heroindistributing conspiracy in an indictment that was unsealed yesterday in Federal District Court here.

title: L.I.R.R. JOB ACTION IS BARRED BY COURT
description: Long Island Rail Road trainmen, who had called in sick yesterday in unusually large numbers, were ordered by a Federal district judge last night not to continue the job action that the railroad said was taking place.

title: Final School Report
description: The Fleischmann Commission on the Quality, Cost and Financing of Elementary and Secondary Education New York State, in its final report, has put the spotlight on the size of the task expected of the public schools. The gap between those expectations and the schools actual accomplishments is alarming. Since the commission nevertheless concluded that New York's performance is better than that of virtually all other states, the findings and recommendations assume national importance.

title: Notes on People
description: A spokesman for the Russian Orthodox Church said the church would not reply to charges by the Soviet novelist Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn that there was a lack of religious freedom in the Soviet Union, The charge was made by Mr. Solzhenitsyn last spring in a letter to Pimen, who had just been installed as the Patriarch of Moscow and of all Russiathe highest post in the Russian Orthodox Church. At a news conference in Athens, where a delegation of Russian clergymen is meeting with their Greek counterparts, Metropolitan Juvenaly of Tula said the Solzhenitsyn complaint contained many inaccuracies that led us to conclude that he does not know church life nor the spiritual life of the Orthodox Church.

title: An Appraisal
description: BOSTONThe Old City Hall is alive and well and making money in Boston, offering elegant offices, French cuisine on its ground floor, and a landmark lesson in preservation and real estate development. Its exterior has been cleaned, its interior suavely rewrought, and its space is renting at top market prices, competitive with neighboring skyscrapers. Giant pots of rosy geraniums stand against the 110yearold colonnaded, gray granite walls, and gay, yellowumbrellaed tables dot its grassy forecourt on School Street, as Bostonians wax unexpectedly convivial and Continental. On the other side, Benjamin Franklin and Josiah Quincy on pedestals survey miracle.

title: Polo Final Tonight
description: DARIEN, Conn., Oct. 20The Fairfield County Hunt Club's A team from Westport, Conn., will meet the Greenwich Pitchforks tomorrow night for the Sherman Memorial fivegoal indoor polo championship at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.

title: Graffiti Epidemic Strikes 7,000 Cars In Subway System
description: Virtually all of the 7,000 subway cars in the city system have graffiti on them, W. R. Hamilton, supervisor of maintenance, said yesterday.

title: ROLE FOR NADJARI OPPOSED IN QUEENS
description: The chief assistant district attorney of Queens argued yesterday that the state's new anticorruption prosecutor was not entitled to investigate a case in which members of the Queens District Attorney's office invested in an alleged getrichquick scheme.

title: Pact Breach Charged
description: The Atlantic Technology Corporation of Somers Point, N. J., a manufacturer of electronic computer display devices, disclosed yesterday that it had begun action in Federal Court against F. S. Smithers & Co., a New York investmentbanking firm, and two of its officers.

title: KNICKS CONQUER CAVALIERS, 9289
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 20The Dr. arrived just in time.

title: 3 MORE IN HOUSE LISTED ON ALIENS
description: A Federal document says that three area Representatives have introduced private immigration bills on behalf of aliens close to organized crime.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 20In a glittering testimonial to culture and a reaffirmation of faith in the inner city, 3,000 musiclovers from as far away as Texas and Milan, Italy, turned out for the Opera Theatre of New Jersey's opening night procuction of Verdi's Attila.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: WASHINGTON  President Eisenhower observed that too much for arms, far from bolstering security, weakens it. The truth of that insight has never been clearer and more compelling than today. The point of weapons saturation has been reached and overreached.

title: Music: Starker's Cello Debut With Philharmonic
description: Janos Starker made somewhat of a belated debut as the solo cellist at Thursday night's Philharmonic concert. For some years now Mr. Starker has been regarded as one of the world's great instrumentalists, but for some reason he was never invited to play with the New York Philharmonic. This season the omission has been rectified, and the eminent cellist performed with all the mastery expected of him.

title: Market Countries Set Goal Of Uniting Policies by 80
description: PARIS, Saturday, Oct. 21The Government leaders of the six Common Market countries and of the three nations that will join the market in January pledged themselves early this morning to form a European union by 1980.

title: Car Crash Cuts Power Linel
description: WEST HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Oct. 20A car ran into a utility pole outside an Orange and Rockland Utilities substation here at 3 A.M. today and 2,600 customers were without power or telephone service for nearly seven hours. Craig Kidd, 22 years old of West Nyack, driver of the car, was listed hi satisfactory condition in Ramapo General Hospital, Spring Valley.

title: Big Outlay Planned By Chicago Edison
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company announced yesterday that it plans to spend $4billion on construction from 1973 through 1977. At the same time, the giant Chicago utility scheduled a preferred stock offering of about $50million for competitive bidding on Nov. 13.

title: 3 MORE IN HOUSE LISTED ON ALIENS Report Says Beneficiaries Were Linked to Crime
description: A Federal document says that three area Representatives have introduced private immigration bills on behalf of aliens close to organized crime.

title: Sports of The Times
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 20News item: Untata, South AfricaA witch doctor's advertisement in a local newspaper yesterday offered ways of returning bad spells to sender and interpretation of dreams for horse race betting. If the witch doctor has any clients in the American baseball establishment, chances are they are umpires, not Sparky Anderson. Nevertheless, the peerless little manager of the Cincinnati Reds had a whole bucketful of charms, amulets and curses going for him today, and they kept his team in the World Series for at least another 24 hours.

title: Soyer's Art On Display At Forum
description: Everything that seriousness, perseverance, a perceptive eye and a hardearned facility can do for an artist they have done for Raphael Soyer. At 73, he is one of America's most respected realist painters. Historically, he is an established fixture among the American Scene painters of the thirties and forties. His early paintings of careworn shop  girls and seamstresses, downandout men and leavetaking soldiers, had the poignancy of troubled times.

title: Merger News
description: The American Maize Products Company announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire from National Industries, Inc., its 75 per cent interest in the Cott Corporation, a bottler and distributor of carbonated beverages with sales of $72million last year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: You published two Interesting letters on Oct. 11one advocating that the U.S. move to reactivate U.N. consideration of the code of international offenses and a penal court to cope with the entire gamut of political crimes that still plague mankind; the second called the declaration of open support for war by the Deputy Foreign Minister of the People's Republic of Chinafor causes he terms justa flagrant contradiction of the letter and spirit of the United Nations Charter. May I add a third on the subject?

title: President Park of South Korea Calls Oil State Visit to Japan
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 20 President Park Chung Hee of sputh, Korea today called off his planned state visit to Japan. Kim Seong Jin, the presidential spokesman, said in announcing the cancellation that it was unavoidable due to the domestic situation.

title: Acupuncture Easing Urged
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20 (UPI) California law should be changed to allow nonphysicians to practice acupuncture so the ancient Oriental practice won't be driven underground, a State Assembly committee was told yesterday. The executive secretary of the State Board of Medical Examiners, William Fox, noted that at present only a licensed physician can engage in acupuncture.

title: WINE TALK
description: Most women set great store by growing old gracefully. Few do it as well as Nicole Barbe Clicquot, whose 200th anniversary is being celebrated this year. Well, not her anniversary exactly, but the anniversary of Veuve Clicquot, the champagne that bears her name. Veuve is French for widow.

title: In British Columbia Politics, a New Style
description: VICTORIA, British, Columbia, Oct. 18The Socialist government of this province, chosen in an upset election two months ago, is shaking off British Co. lumbia's old empire ways, but the pace is not exactly,. headlong so far.

title: A Career Diplomat
description: PARIS, Oct. 20France's senior representative in North Vietnam, Pierre Susini, who died here last night from injuries suffered in the bombing of his mission nine days ago, was 52yearold career diplomat.

title: CONSUMER PRICES SHOW SHARP RISE FOR SEPTEMBER Economic Aide to President Concedes Unhesitatingly It Was a Bad Month 0.4% CLIMB REPORTED Meany Says Trend Proves Stabilization Program Is Unfair and Inequitable
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 The Consumer Price Index recorded one of its largest increases of the year in September, a rise of fourtenths of 1 per cent, the Labor Department reported today.

title: PACT IS DRAFTED AT COCOA TALKS
description: GENEVA, Oct. 20A conference called by the United Nations to assure cocoaproducing countries of the underdeveloped world a stable income from their exports of this commodity ended inconclusively here tonight.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 20Ten women and their six children today picketed a statewide meeting of school board members to protest the booking of Gloria Steinem, the women's liberationist, as a speaker at the session.

title: HARRY A. JARVIS, 63; HEADED OIL CONCERN
description: BERLIN, Md., Oct. 20Harry A. Jarvis, former president of the Creole Petroleum Corporation, Venezuelan affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) died yesterday in a Salisbury nursing home after a long illness. He was 63 years old and lived in this community, where he was born.

title: New King Reigns in 700YearOld Sport of Royalty
description: There was another world series this week. In a challenge match for the world open court tennis championship, Jimmy Bostwick, a 35yearold sportsman, dethroned his brother, George H. (Pete), Jr., a 38yearold stockbroker, yesterday at the New York Racquet and Tennis Club, 72, in their 7of13set series.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Martin Tuman, a former assistant United States attorney, pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of incometax evasion and filing false incometax statements. After his arraignment in Federal District Court in Newark he was released on a $5,000 personal bond and was granted permission to attend a law conference in Acapulco, Mexico, next month. However, he was ordered to surrender his passport pending a hearing scheduled for after the conference.

title: New Issues Climb As Two Offerings Dominate Market
description: The newissues market, subdued in recent weeks, perked up this week with the successful sale of two large new offerings: 3.6million shares of H. F. Ahmanson & Co. common at $28 a share and a million shares of Noble Affiliates, Inc., at $21 a share.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (Reuters)The Treasury Department announced today that, under existing Treasury regulations, United States brokers will be able to deal gold futures on the Winnipeg Commodity Exchange. The Canadian Exchange plans to open trading in gold futures on Nov. 15.

title: E. LEWIS LIFTON
description: E. Lewis Lifton, president of the Leather Goods Corporation of America, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 35 East 75th Street. He was 57 years old.

title: 3 More G. M. Factories Struck; ShortWalkout Tactic Continues
description: DETROIT, Oct. 20  Three General Motors car plants were closed today as the United Auto Workers began its second series of short strikes against G. M.

title: Antiwar Veterans to March
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20 (UPI)Organizers of this year's Veterans Day parade, dedicated to the Vietnam veteran, have lost a court fight to keep an organization of antiwar Vietnam veterans from marching in what is billed as the city's biggest Veterans Day parade in a decade. United States District Judge Stanley Wiegel issued an order yesterday to allow Vietnam Veterans Against the War to take part in Sunday's parade.

title: Agreement on a Later Curtain Advances With Offers of Help
description: Broadway restaurateurs, travel agents, ticket brokers, union representatives, garage owners, liquor industry interests and allied fields agreed yesterday to provide financial support for promotion of the legitimate theater in exchange for later evening curtain times.

title: Stage: Birds Updated
description: The Birds is an unsacred masterpiece, wide open to interpretatipn and interpolation. I remember a production six years ago with Bert Lahr that said as much about the comic genius of Mr. Lahr as it did about Aristophanes. Merely by pronouncing the name of his character, Pisthetairos, the comedian sent the audience into spasms of hilarity.

title: A State Report Criticizes Scribner on Fuentes Case
description: The State Division of Human Rights is preparing to issue a report charging that Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, the city's School Chancellor, has prolonged the dispute involving Luis Fuentes by delaying actions he could take to alleviate the conflict in Community School District 1, on the Lower East Side.

title: PAKISTANI LEADERS AGREE ON CHARTER
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Oct. 20 (Reuters)Pakistan's political leaders today agreed on new constitution providing for a twochamber federal parliament, a president and a prime minister responsible to the legislature.

title: NEW PEACE RALLY SENDS STOCKS UP
description: Another peace rally erupted yesterday on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, sending glamour stocks booming higher and ending a nervous market week on a hopeful note.

title: Indians Get Partial Victory on Sacred Objects Sale
description: A group of upstate Indians from the Iroquois and Delaware nations, upset over the prospective auction of sacred wampum belts and masks at the Sotheby Parke Bernet galleries yesterday, won a partial victory in seeking return of the religious objects to their tribal halls.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 20  The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority plans to break ground for the New York Giants football stadium project in the Hackensack meadowlands by the end of November, according to an authority spokesman.

title: WESTBURY FIELD IS REDUCED TO 6
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 20  Speedy Crown, last season's Hambletonian winner and a 10time victor in 18 outings this year, is running a high fever and will be out of tomorrow night's $25,000 Premio Ivone Grassetto Trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: GRAINS ADVANCE ON PEACE REPORTS Buying Spree Lifts Pribes Out of Earlier Skimp
description: For the last two days there has been a rumor floating around the Chicago Board of Trade that the Soviet Union had asked that grain shipments from the United States move at a slower pace. Apparently there was some logistic problem in handling the grain at Russian ports.

title: U.S. Files Its First Suit Seeking To Curb Sales of Term Papers
description: BOSTON, Oct. 20The United States Attorney here filed today the first Federal suit aimed at discouraging the sale of professionally prepared research papers to college students.

title: 3 SlumRepair Inspectors Suspended as Incompetent
description: Three inspectors were relieved of their assignments to A federally funded slumrenovation program yesterday on the recommendation of City Investigation Commissioner Robert K. Ruskin.

title: Backward Tax
description: An electionminded Congress heaped billions of dollars in frosting on the generous increase in Social Security benefits that went into effect this month, but millions of workers are going to feel the pain next year in the form of a onethird increase in payroll taxes. In. 1974 the cost to middleincome workers of building up Federal retirement credits will be up by onehalf over the current total.

title: KISSINGER CONFERS WITH THIEU 2D DAY; AIDES STILL SILENT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 20Henry A. Kissinger and the United States Ambassador, Ellsworth Bunker, conferred with President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam for 3 hours and 40 minutes today.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTONWe're going to be taking good land and turning it into parking lots. The Olympics idea sounds fine in the abstract. But not when you start looking at it in terms of land lost, of things to build and pay for.

title: People and Business
description: Jerome H. Holland, the first black director of the New York Stock Exchange, took the lead yesterday in the derby involving black directors of major corporations with his election to the board of the Continental Corporation. Mr. Holland, 62, is also a director of four other big companies: the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the General Foods Corporation, the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and the Union Carbide Corporation.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: WASHINGTONA myth can be complex thing. It can start out as reality, as a convenient generalization. But the generalization can become oversimplified or exaggerated, and instead of an aid to thought it can become a serious obstacle to thought and lead to illconsidered actions.

Mr. Short, who has a bachelor of science degree in engineering, is a graduate of the University of North Dakota.

title: An Appraisal
description: Two landmarks of 20th century science are being honored by the Nobel Prizes in chemistry and physics announced yesterday. Although they represent areas of discovery remote from each other, both are of great potential importance to human welfare. And both were of the fundamental nature characteristic of basic research. In chemistry, the prize recognizes the achievement of three scientists in first deciphering the molecular structure of an enzyme ribonucleaseand identifying that part of the molecule that performs its vital role.

The device is being tested at the New York City Department of Health under a contract with the Federal Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
