title: NORMAN G. MAIDEN
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 20Norman G. Maiden, who retired in 1965 as a partner in Arthur Young & Co., public accountants, New York, died today in St. Agnes Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 161 Caterson Terrace, Hartsdale.

title: U. S. to Spur Private Enterprise To Build Plants for Solid Waste
description: Federal environmental officials, displeased with the slow progress in controlling water pollution, are planning a different approach to the solid waste control program that is just getting under way.

title: Screen: 'You'll Like My Mother,' a Thriller, Opens
description: "You'll Like My Mother," the ads tell you, is a thrilleras if with a title like that you needed to be toldand it is a thriller of a fairly conventional, comfortably old-fashioned sort.Filmed in the dead of winter in a marvelous old mansion with cluttered firelit rooms, carved wood staircases, a secret attic hideaway, an ancient family Bible in the library, a coach house full of carriages and sleighs, it all but immerses you in castoffs from a rich and deeply rooted past that most of us can only dream of remembering. It also fails as a movie, but not dishonorably, and not without scoring some local successes along the way.The heroine is the young, very pregnant widow of a flier killed in Vietnam, who goes to visit her husband's mother, whom she has never seen, on a call of obligatory sympathy. She gets a lessthan-cordial reception from the mother, and discovers a miserable simple-minded teen-age sister-in-law she never knew existed. But it is only when, faced with a deepening blizzard, she is forced to spend the night and realizes with sleepy horror that someone has drugged her bedtime cocoa, that she is in present danger  and from more than just a hardhearted mother-in-law.The story that follows is full of holes and not too full of surprises, and it is all developed in a screenplay that might most charitably be described as awkward. There is a schematic simplicity to the plot that feels more like television than the movies.But there is also a visual density that is genuinely cinematic and that makes location shooting (in a real turn-of-the-century mansion in Minnesota) seem worthwhile. And the almost complete absence of false leads and tricky terror tactics suggests the kind of ground-level faith in situations and events that is the beginning of true morality in the movies.Along with its several virtues of omission, "You'll Like My Mother" shares in the respect for character and performance typical in Lamont Johnson's movies "(The McKenzie Break," "The Groundstar Conspiracy," etc.)of which this is, in my experience, the worst. Patty Duke is expressive and surprisingly restrained as the young widow who must keep her wits about her. As her mother-in-law, Rosemary Murphy portrays a somewhat attractive villainess with an intelligent competence that is probably the best thing in the film.But I especially admired a new, rather lovely actress namedtoo perfectlySian Barbara Allen, who plays the simple-minded girl with more direct sympathy and less nonsense than you might expect in a movie the aim of which is to scare you."You'll Like My Mother" opened yesterday at several local theaters.

title: Muffed Opportunity
description: An opportunity to move toward an even more fundamental reform of the Social Security tax structure was lost when the Administration walked away from its own proposal for welfare reform in the crucial stages Senate debate. The last shreds of that proposal for putting a floor under family income vanished in the final draft of the Social Securitywelfare bill. Even the abortive experiments the Senate approved were killed.

title: Nobel Winners in Physics, Chemistry
description: The 56yearold Dr. Anfinsen, a tall, broadshouldered man with sandy hair, plans to celebrate his Nobel Prize in Chemistry with a cruise from Annapolis to Florida aboard his 31foot ketch, Good Girl. Loves sailing, music and biochemistry. At the National Institute of Arthritis, Metabolism and Digestive Diseases, a branch of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., he is chief of the laboratory of chemical biology Specialty is the relationship between protein structure and function and the genetic basis of the protein structure.  Born in Monessen, Pa., March 26, 1916. Graduated from Swarthmore College in 1937. Played football in college and says he tried for a while to squeeze a football career in between laboratory courses. M.S. from the University of Pennsylvania in 1939, and Ph.D. in biochemistry from Harvard in 1943 Held a series of research and teaching positions at Pennsylvania, Harvard and the Medical Nobel

title: Man in the News
description: It has a drab gray cover, 130 pages and 53 chapters running from Mayor to Department of Relocation. It is the City Charter, and very few people, including elected officials, bother to read it, even though it contains the words and concepts of selfgovernment in New York City. Louis Lauer began studying it last Monday, putting aside livelier reading such as Joyce Carol Oates's urban tragedy, Them, in preparation for the job he formally assumed yesterday as the general counsel and executive director of the State Charter Revision Commission for New York City.

title: Books of The Times
description: Anthony Burgess once described the heroine of Doris Lessing's most famous novel, The Golden Notebook, as intelligent, honest, burning with conviction, but she ends up as a bit of a bore. Of course he intended the judgment to cover Doris Lessing herself: The crusader's best medium is the manifesto, he continued, which is not the same thing as a novel. I'm afraid that even now, three years after the publication of Doris Lessing's The FourGated City, there are still those on either side of the Atlantic who'd agree with his judgment.

description: The National Broadcasting Company showed a varied trio of hourlong specials last night, clicking on in succession from 8 to 10 o'clock.

title: MRS. NILS J. WESSELL
description: BOSTON, Oct. 20Mrs. Esther Wahlquist Wessell, widow of the Rev. Nils J. Wessell of Plainfield, N. J., and mother of Dr. Nils Y. Wessell, head of the Sloane Foundation and former president of Tufts University, died yesterday at the age of 94.

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS FUNDSHARING BILL
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 President Nixon started  and may well have ended in the same stroke  his personal campaigning for Pennsylvania's 27 electoral votes by signing a $30.2billion revenuesharing bill outside Independence Hall today.

title: KISSINGER CONFERS WITH THIEU 2D DAY; AIDES STILL SILENT
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Saturday, Oct. 21Henry A. Kissinger and the United States Ambassador, Ellsworth Bunker, conferred with President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam for 3 hours and 40 minutes yesterday.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 Judge Paul F. McArdle, of the District of Columbia Superior Court, ruled today that Maurice H. Stans, finance chairman of President Nixon's reelection campaign, would not be extradited to Miami to testify at a trial of Bernard L. Barker, one of the men indicted in the alleged bugging of Democratic headquarters here.

title: Aurelio, Former Lindsay Aide, Employed by Rockefeller Center
description: Richard R. Aurelio, who as a chief aide to Mayor Lindsay often tangled with Governor Rockefeller, has been hired by Rockefeller Center, Inc., as a publicrelations consultant.

title: Manila Says U.S. Navy Aided in Arrests
description: MANILA, Oct. 20The official spokesman for President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that the arrest of an American lawyer and two other Americans on allegations that they had circulated literature illegal under martial law had been made on information provided by friendly sources in the U.S. Naval Command iti the Philippines.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The comments by William Schechter and Curtis P. Nettels on opinion polls (letters Sept. 27) reflect a number of misconceptions about polls that should be corrected.

title: GILBERT M. RODDY
description: WALTHAM, Mass., Oct. 20Gilbert M. Roddy, president and chief executive officer of the ArkwrightBoston Manufacturers Mutual Insurance Company and of the Mutual Boiler and Machinery Insurance Company, died Sunday in Concord. He was 61 years old.

title: U.S. Orders Wide Reforms At Mississippi Prison Farm
description: GREENVILLE, Miss., Oct. 20 (AP)  United States District Judge William C. Keady ordered the Mississippi State Penitentiary today to end corporal punishment and to relax censorship and discipline as the first steps toward eliminating unconstitutional conditions at the prison farm.

title: Market Place:
description: Investors are asking who is to blame for those disastrous drops in the price of individual stocks on bad news  Shulman Transport Enteprises, the Horizon Corporation, etc.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP)Britain's Ambassador to the United States, Lord Cromer, in effect charged today that the United States was more protectionist than the European Economic Community, the trade bloc that his country was now about to join. The United States practices protectionism both through tariffs and through such nontariff barriers as import quotas to a higher extent than does the Common Market, the diplomat told a luncheon meeting in Pittsburgh, designed to promote a Britain Now exhibition. The text of his speech was released by the British Embassy here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your readers will be interested in one further example of the planned butchering of the forest lands in the neighborhood of New York. A short mile north of the Rondout Reservoir in the Catskills, right next door to the State Forest Preserve, it is planned to construct a city of 900 rental houses on 200 acres. This will call for the building of factories to prefabricate the houses, of schools, shopping centers, medical facilities, etc.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: COATESVILLE, Pa., Oct. 20 (AP)President Nixon drove to the airport in this Chester County community today after the Independence Hall ceremony in Philadelphia and took off in a helicopter for a weekend at his Camp David retreat in Maryland. He arrived there at 5:02 P.M.

title: Art: Two Shows by. Shalom of Safed
description: Although he is having oneman shows in two New York art galleries just now (Lee Ault's, at 25 East 77th Street, and the New York Cultural Center on Columbus Circle), Shalom of Safed, the venerable Israeli primitive, says he is no artista disclaimer that pulls the teeth and takes the wind out of the sails of an art critic who was about to say the same thing in the form of an objection.

title: Prof. Philip Drinker Dies at 77; A CoInventor of the Iron Lung
description: FITZWILLIAM, N. H., Oct. 20Philip Drinker, retired professor of industrial hygiene at the Harvard School of Public Health and coinventor of the Drinker respirator, or iron lung, died yesterday at his home here. He was 77 years old.

title: Unfamiliar Works by Familiar Names
description: There was a time not long ago when exhibitions of the modern masters were strictly limited to the work of European artists. Not so today. To the School of Paris and its artistic satellites in the other capitals of Etirope have now been added the celebrated names of the New York School. Some of these may shine more brightly than others, but so far as established taste is concernedand it is only to established taste that exhibitions of the masters address themselves American artists associated with the New York School have now won something equivalent to critical parity with their European predecessors.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Senator James L. Buckley, Conservative Republican of New York, and the liberal Americans for Democratic Action are engaged in an exchange of tongueincheek correspondence over whether Mr. Buckley should be regarded as a 7 per cent liberal. The A.D.A., as do other pressure groups, such as the Conservative Americans for Constitutional Action, annually go over the Congressional rollcalls and rate Senators and Representatives on their voting records. In the latest ratings, for example, Mr. Buckley got a zero from the A.D.A. and a 95 per cent rating from the A.C.A.

title: MISSION BOMBING CONCEDED BY ES.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The Defense Department said today that it had concluded from an extensive investigation that it was an American bomb that inadvertently struck the French diplomatic mission in Hanoi Oct. 11.

title: TWO EXCITY AIDES GUILTY IN BRIBERY
description: Two former borough superintendents for the Municipal Loan Program, which was the target of city investigations last winter, were convicted in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday of conspiracy and taking bribes.

title: JAPAN ACTS TOMB YEN REVALUATION
description: TOKYO, Oct, 20The Japanese Government adopted today new measures designed to stave off growing foreign pressure for a second upward revaluation of the yen.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: WASHINGTONDuring the course of considering the Moscow SALT accords, the question of U.S. strategic defense options has become a dominant domestic issue, often overshadowing the agreements themselves. The signing of the SALT agreements does not automatically mean that we should either halt all new and ongoing strategic programs or that we should sustain and accelerate all our strategic efforts. But between these extremes, the precise implications of SALT for our unilateral strategic posture decisions are neither obvious nor simple to assess.

title: New London Renaming Main Street: It Will Become Eugene O'Neill Drive
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 20Eugene O'Neill, the winner of four Pulitzer Prizes and the only American dramatist ever to receive the Nobel Prize for literature, has finally made it in his home town of New London.

title: New Record Lows Reported In a Cold Wave Upstate
description: Arctic air sent temperatures plunging to new record lows in parts of upstate New York early yesterday.

title: MUSEUM PRESENTS BEETHOVEN SERIES
description: Beethoven's music is the subject of three series this season at Rogers Auditorium in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The first to get under way was that devoted to the composer's piano trios, with the initial program of three being played on Thursday night. The playersAlexander Schneider, violinist; Leslie Parnas, cellist, and Peter Serkin, pianistare justly admired, and the stage had to accommodate the overflow audience.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAGIN
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 20 (UPI) Sargent Shriver said today that the death last night of the French diplomat Pierre Susini, who had been injured in an American bombing raid on Hanoi, proved allegations that the United States conducted indiscriminate bombing in Vietnam.

title: Bucks Turn Back Pistons
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 20 (AP) Bob Dandridge scored 27 points and Dick Cunningham, filling in for the ailing Kareem AbdulJabbar, added a careerhigh 19 tonight to lead the Milwaukee Bucks to a 10986 N.B.A. victory over the Detroit Pistons.

title: 4 Boats Start Trysail Race
description: ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N. J., Oct. 20The Storm Trysail Club's fourth annual race to Chesapeake Bay today had only four starters off Sandy Hook Light.

title: Soviet Reported Shifting Funds to Food Production
description: MOSCOW, Oct., 20Soviet planners are engaged in a significant reallocation of Five Year Plan investments to compensate for this year's harvest setbacks and to prepare for 1973, according to Soviet and foreign sources.

title: Turner Trial Ends In a Jury Deadlock
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., Oct. 20 (AP)A mistrial was declared today in the securitieslaw case of Glenn W. Turner after the foreman of the sixmember jury said the panel was hopelessly deadlocked after 6 hours and 20 minutes of deliberations.

title: Equity Financing
description: Cenco Inc. yesterday filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a secondary offering of 332,426 common shares for sale through Lehman Brothers, Inc. The company's stock closed at 23, up  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 6 Americans Win Nobel Prizes In Physics and Chemistry Field
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 20Nobel Prizes in physics and chemistry were awarded today to six Americans.

title: Conspiracy Alleged
description: Two of the founders of the Stirling Homex Corporation, which is in reorganization under the Federal bankruptcy laws, filed suit in Federal District Court here yesterday charging the Chemical Bank of New York and the First National State Bank of Newark with fraud, deceit and conspiracy in allegedly forcing their company into bankruptcy. Two officers of Chemical were also named in the complaint.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Senator George McGovern was cheered enthusiastically by 1,000 trade unionists yesterday when he called for jobs for all those capable of working and accused the Nixon Administration of having favored special interests at the expense of the working people.

title: STARS HAND COUGARS 1ST DEFEAT, 127111
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Oct. 20 (AP)The Utah Stars, with a fourthquarter surge led by Willie Wise and Jimmy Jones, ended the Carolina Cougars fourgame winning streak with a 127111 American Basketball Association victory tonight.

title: Galletta In Tie For Lead
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 20 (AP)Mal Galletta shot a fiveunderpar 65 to gain a share of the lead with three other golfers today after the second round of the $100,000 Professional Golfers Association club professionals championship.

title: JENKINS EXCELS AT PENN NATIONAL
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 20Rodney Jenkins began collecting rewards of championship trophies for his efforts today at the 27th annual. Pennsylvania National Horse Show, which ends tomorrow evening.

title: CHINESE DOCTORS PLEASE STUDENTS
description: BOSTON, Oct. 20  The 11 Chinese doctors touring the United States discovered today that a substantial number of young American medical students share their philosophy toward medical care.

title: Business Briefs
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Oct. 20 (Reuters)The Kennecott Copper Corporation withdrew today its request for the seizure of a West German ship and its cargo of disputed Chilean copper. The freighter, the Birte Oldendorff, left tonight for an unknown destination with the 1,250 tons of copper still in her holds. Under its original itinerary, the freighter was to sail from Rotterdam to Hamburg via Antwerp.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: There have been several letters criticizing New Yorkers for their apathy in the face of crime in their streets. Most of the letters conclude by saying that we will never end crime as long as people look on passively. Of course that's true, but what these critics of New York citizenry seem to omit is a method of helping people to be more assertive.

title: $1Billion Expected By Western Groups In Mideast Oil Deal
description: Western oil companies said yesterday they would receive $1billion for selling a 25 per cent interest in their Middle East petroleum production to five Persian Gulf nations if an agreement reached previously on sharing ownership is successfully concluded.

title: Soviet Said to Waive Exit Fee for 60 Jewish Families
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 20Jewish sources said here tonight that 60 more Soviet Jewish families have been told that they can emigrate to Israel without paying the high exitvisa taxes that Soviet authorities set earlier this fall.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAGIN
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 20An accord to reduce air polution at the Clairton, Pa., works of the United States Steel Corporation was signed here today.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 20A tight contest has developed in the race for the United States Senate in Georgia, with a Republican making a serious challenge for the seat for the first time since Reconstruction.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: CAMDEN, Oct. 20A new mass transportation system designed to serve as a model for the United States will begin here a week from tomorrow.

title: Haddock Limit Reached
description: GLOUCESTER, Mass., Oct. 21 (AP)Haddock fishing in areas off the New England coast will be closed for the year Friday, because the year's catch has reached the internationally set limit of 15,000 metric tons, National Marine Fisheries Service announced today.

title: New York after dark
description: What does it feel like? It feels like the sting of a silent angry beea minor irritation at first. Then the accumulating topheaviness swells your head and you pitch forward, feeling an angry bellow well

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The five students in your Oct. 8 feature article do not really represent fully the American presence abroad. There are now many black American college students abroad on scholarships and on their own money. Unfortunately, we blacks are often not included in such articles as yours. Last year I studied for a master's degree in French literature at the Sorbonne on my own. I speak the language and lived very pleasantly with the French people. I would like other blacks to know that Europe is possible for us as well as for the whites. Whites no longer set the standards for our education, and it is great. For us it is a struggle. Europe is not our dream, it is only an education in a different form. And I want to make the point that jobs are available, too. I was offered many interesting jobs in publishing and teaching. However, I was there to study and travel, and that's what I did.

title: A Lecturer's Notes, Or That You Learn If You Talk a Lot
description: You can learn a lot through lectures, especially when you give them: the value of imagined gifts, the danger of unscreened questions, or even how to respond to a lovely, inquiring woman. I give about 50 lectures a year in the United States and abroad, and here are some of the things I've learned on the platform and on the road.

title: Muskie Joins McGovern on Stump in Pennsylvania
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 21Senator Edmund S. Muskie guided Senator George McGovern across the coal country of Pennsylvania today, urging the state's voters to reject Richard M. Nixon this year as they did in 1968.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:Patuxent Prison (A model, clockworkorange prison, by Phil Stanford, Sept. 17) is not, as Szasz says, worse than the way they use mental institutions in Russia, but it bears striking resemblances to the uses of Soviet psychiatry. At Patuxent, as in Soviet mental hospitals, loss of liberty is made unbearable for some inmates by the mental torture inherent in the demand of confession and ideological conversion as a condition for release. Adding to the torture is the fact that the decision as to whether the inmate is released or remanded for more therapy must appear, at least to the prisoners, to be arbitrary and capricious.

title: Dr. Hans Thacker Clarke Dies; Biochemist at Columbia Was 84
description: BOSTON, Oct, 21Dr. Hans Thacher Clarke, professor of biochemistry at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons from 1928 to 1956 and head of the department for part of that time, died here today. He was 84 years old and lived in Cambridge and had a summer home in Scotland, Conn.

title: Plane Falls in Sea off Athens; 35 Feared Dead, 18 Get to Shore
description: ATHENS, Sunday, Oct. 22 (AP)  An Olympic Airways plane with 53 persons aboard on a domestic flight plunged into the sea near the Athens airport last night in a blinding rainstorm. Officials said 18 persons escaped from the plane and swam ashore.

title: Health Jobs Van To Tour the State
description: PRINCETON  The New Jersey Association of Hospital Auxiliaries will soon be dispatching a 35foot mobile van to bring healthcareer information to junior and senior high school students throughout the state.

title: Garrison's Wife Sues
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 21 (UPI)District Attorney Jim Garrison's wife has sued for separation from her husband, who she says abandoned their home and five children earlier this month, Mrs. Leah Ziegler Garrison filed the suit in Civil District Court Wednesday.

title: Blackout in Coney Island
description: The failure of an underground feeder cable left about 730 customers in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn without electricity last night from about 8 to 9:30 o'clock. A spokesman for Consolidated Edison said the 10block affected was bounded by West 19th and West 24th Streets and Neptune and Surf Avenues.

title: Agnew Is Confident Of President's View In Watergate Case
description: CHICAGO, Oct, 21  Vice President Agnew avoided today substantive answers to questions about alleged political espionage and sabotage.

title: New Homes for Aging Due
description: MAPLEWOOD  To slow an exodus of older citizens to other communities, a nonprofit corporation formed by four Maplewood churches and a synagogue plans to build a housing center for the elderly.

title: Prices
description: We have our good ones, and we have our bad ones, commented Dr. Marina Whitman, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, and September was a bad month. Last Friday the Labor Department reported a September rise in the Consumer Price Index of fourtenths of 1 per cent across the nationone of the largest increases of the year.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The summer I spent in Europe after graduating from Fordham University was the most educational and enjoyable period of my life to date. My experiences were both comparable to and in contrast to those of your five young Americans.

title: New &Novel
description: Another breathcatching undersea patrol by the hero of Run Silent, Run Deep, Commander Edward Richardson of the submarine Eel, is burdened by a pair of hoodoos, during Operation Wolfpack in the Yellow Sea, circa 1945. One is the haunting memory of Japanese naval captain, whose lifeboat was deliberately rammed by the Eel. The other is the presence of Capt. Joe Blunt, the Wolfpack chief, who shows increasing signs of the Queeg syndrome.

title: The Apostle IslandsSilence So Intense You Can Hear It
description: Sometimes beavers start to cut a tree, then leave the job unfinished and the tree dies. The leaves drop and the soft twigs are blown from the larger branches. The bark peels and the skeleton stands gray and lonely until an eagle conies to perch on it. In a clearing made by beavers in the middle of Stockton Island, just such an eagle sat on just such a tree and looked at me unafraid. There were fresh coyote tracks across the light snow. And suddenly I was sure that no human being had set foot in this beaver clearing since I had last visited it five years, before.

title: See Mt. Trashmore, Because It's There
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va.They have hoarded 640,000 tons of garbage here and disguised it as a mountain. The result suggests something God may have used for practice, until he got the hang of things and produced the Alps and the Andes.

title: Gardens
description: MAIDENHMR ferns comprise a large Worldwide genus of over 200 species. In this locality, the wellknown species is northeastern maidenhair or fivefingered fern, Adiantum pedatum, but most of the delightful and interesting species grow in the tropics or subtropic areas.

title: A PortugeseSenegalese Border Incident Brings Out Heavy Oratorical Artillery in the U.N. Security Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21Nine days ago in the late afternoon a small group of Portuguese armored vehicles halted within a few yards of the border between Portuguese Guinea and Senegal and opened fire on a Senegalese post at Nianao.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The recent letter from Henry Teasley justifying the support of President Nixon by blacks makes the argument that blacks have supported the Democrats for promises, and promises was all they got. This Is not true.

title: Democrats Lead Poll At Watergate Complex
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21In at least one poll of almost no significance, the McGovernShriver ticket is winning hands down.

title: 144 Horses Bought at Yonkers On First Day of Old Glory Sale
description: YONKERS, Oct. 21Yonkers Raceway spent some $25,000 to rebuild and refurbish the heated, prefabricated facility where the 13th annual modern Old Glory Horse (standardbred) Sale began today with the first of four days of bidding and buying.

title: Bridge
description: Alertness is an indispensable quality in play and defense. Technical skill is not enough. A player who is not able to put forth consistent mental effort is unlikely to be a winner at any level.

title: KINGS POINT BOWS TO POST, 31 TO 26
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., Oct. 21 In a perfect blend of crunching running and sharp passing, C. W. Post College staved off wild fourthquarter rally by Kings Point, and defeated the Mariners, 3126, before 5,242 fans at Captain Tomb Field.

title: MRS. EDWARD J. QUIRIN
description: Mrs. Eleanor Lutz Quirin, a New York welfare leader and the wife of Edward J. Quirin, vice president of Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, died Thursday. She was 65 years old and lived at 190 East 72d Street.

title: Education
description: To some, it was like Little Rock, Ark, 16 years ago. There were the angry housewives, the police, and a busload of black children, waiting at the curb, unable to enter the school and unwilling to give up and go home.

title: Crimson Gets 20 in 4th Period, Routs Cornell, 3315
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 21 Knowing it had to execute to win, Harvard finally got its tricky multiple offense going with the efficiency of a firing squad against Cornell today.

title: Rockets Strike Bienhoa
description: SAIGON, Sunday, Oct. 22 (Reuters)Communist gunners fired 56 122MM. Sovietdesigned rockets into the airbase at Bienhoa near Saigon just before dawn this morning, military spokesmen reported.

title: CORONA'S BACKERS CRITICAL OF JUDGE
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., Oct. 21Through most of this week the trial of Juan V. Corona, the accused murderer of 25 farm workers, was in recess, but a brief session yesterday abruptly changed the atmosphere that has marked these proceedings.

title: Senators Are Given Ratings For Environmental Votes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UPI) The League of Conservation Voters said this week that during the last two years the Senate voted correctly only 40,5 per cent of the time in acting on 19 key environmental measures.

title: Spadea Designs Quality At Low Cost
description: MILFORDIt is anything but runofthemill, the historic stone mill dating to the 1700's on the banks of the Delaware, where patterns for homesewing set the pattern of success for the Spadea Syndicate.

title: A SevenStory Law School Is Dedicated at St. John's
description: Calling for new ideas and courageous experimentation in the face of demands for immediate and drastic change in our system of law, the state's chief judge, Stanley H. Fuld, Friday dedicated the new sevenstory home of the Law School of St. John's University, built into a slope on the Jamaica campus.

title: ALBATROSS, $2.60, 17LENGTH VICTOR
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 21Albatross, the top moneywinning pacer, made a runaway of the $25,000 Battle of Monmouth Pace at Freehold Raceway today, beating his archrival, Nansemond, by 17 lengths and setting a track record of 1:57 3/5 for the mile event.

title: Article 18  No Title
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 21 (AP)Clair Wilson ran 54 yards for one touchdown today and Bruce Murphy added two on 60yard run and a 10yard pass receptionall in the last seven minutesto spark previously victoryless Pittsburgh to 3520 victory over Boston College.

title: Music
description: A LITTLE anniversary is upon us. Last Thursday Carnegie Hall inaugurated Its tenth season of the International Festival of Visiting Orchestras. Through the decade, this series has gone far toward making New York an orchestral city. We all know that the New York Philharmonic is one of the world's great orchestras, but it is nice to have a jewel offset by other iewels. When Julius Bloom of Carnegie Hall got the idea to supplement New York orchestral fare, which by and large consisted of the New York Philharmonic plus shorter series by the Boston, Philadelphia and American Symphony orchestras, it was an idea whose time had come.

title: Music
description: WHEN the music department of Queens College was planning the current school year, it decided that that part of its budget sometimes used for engaging prestigious Distinguished Visiting Professor could be put to a different, perhaps better, use. What it did was to ask one of its members, Leonard Arner, to become coordinator for a special teacherperformer program. Now, Arner is the oboist of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, so what he did was to ask his colleagues in the Society if they would like to join him at Queens. Several of them liked the idea and agreed, including Gervase de Peyer, clarinetist; Loren Glickman, bassoonist; Paula Robison, flutist; Leslie Parnas, cellist, and Richard Goode, pianist.

title: Miles Davis Breaks Legs
description: Miles Davis, the jazz trumpeter, was reported to be satisfactory condition at New York Hospital yesterday, after suffering two broken legs and other injuries Thursday, when the sports car he was driving ran into a traffic island on the West Side Highway. Mr. Davis said he did not know how the accident occurred, His doctors say he will be in the hospital several weeks.

title: Lyn Gammill Has Nuptials
description: NOROTON, Conn., Oct. 21 Miss Mary Caroline Gammill was married here this afternoon to Lieut. Daniel Allen Walker of the Marine Corps. The Rev. Dr. Lawrence MacColl Horton performed the ceremony in the. Presbyterian Church, where he was assisted by the Rev. Rowan Allen Greer, an Episcopal priest.

title: Opera: Verdi's Attila Returns to Life in Newark
description: Attila, Verdi's ninth opera, was a big success when it was given its premiere in Venice in 1846. Four years later, it crossed the Atlantic for an American premiere at Nibto's Garden here. It seems to have been forgotten after that. Even the postWorld War I interest in early Verdi did not extend to this particular opera, and the derogatory comments of Verdi scholars kept the score in the libraries. A concert performance in Venice in 1951 and staging in Florence in 1962 broughtit renewed attention.

title: TEXAS TROUNCES ARKANSAS, 3515
description: DALLAS, Oct. 21 (AP)  Alan Lowry, the Texas quarterback, atoned for a costly fumble with two touchdown runs in 92 seconds tonight to spark the defending Southwest Confer ence champions to a 35.15 victory over Arkansas.

title: Photography
description: THE unique joint showing of the photographs of Jacques Henri Lartigue now at the Witkin Gallery, 243 East 60th Street, and the Neikrug Galleries, 224 East 68th Street (both through Nov. 12), is a rare opportunity to view an extensive body of original prints by one of the major influences of contemporary photography.

title: Unbeaten Amherst Inflicts 21.0 Setback on Rochester
description: AMHERST, Mass., Occ. 21Amherst downed the University of Rochester, 21.0, today and stayed unbeaten after four football games.

title: Who's medically fit for the White House?
description: WASHINGTON: The Constitution requires that the President of the United States be at least 35 years old, a resident of the country for 14 years and a naturalborn citizen. It says nothing about the state of his coronary arteries, his physical endurance and the slow, silent tides that wash his mind. A lot of people wish it did.

title: Preps
description: LAKEVILLE, Conn., Oct. 21 Brad Vanacore throw three touchdown passes and ran for another score to lead unbeaten Hotchkiss over Choate, 4827.

title: Preps
description: ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 21Tim Whelan, a senior halfback from Natick, Mass., scored his second touchdown of the game with four minutes remaining to give Andover a 127 decision over Mount Hermon today. Whelan capped a 45yard drive with a 17yard touchdown run after scoring on a 2yard run in the second period.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Article 6  No Title

title: Segretti Is Linked to Calls To Young G.O.P. Activists
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 21 Donald H. Segretti, reportedly a key figure in a Republican espionage and sabotage campaign, has been linked to a series of calls to the telephone numbers of two young Midwestern Republican activists.

title: Bay State Official Named
description: BOSTON, Oct. 21 (AP)Paul A. Chernoff of Watertown, appointed to the Massachusetts Parole Board in August, was named chairman this week

title: Kissinger Visits. Cambodia. After 4th Talk With Thieu
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Oct. 22  Henry A. Kissinger left Saigon for Cambodia this morning after a fourth day of talks with President Nguyen Van Thieu and other officials, wellinformed American officials said.

title: Institutions as Brokers
description: Should institutions be members of exchanges?

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONNo communications medium, not even a microphone, intruded between William Jennings Bryan and those throngs of voters he was attempting to sway directly, with his wisdom, his eloquence and the force of his personality. But today, your average Presidential candidate takes himself to the people primarily to provide a setting for the image the media will later transmit to far vaster audiences.

title: More Law Courses On Women's Rights Backed at a Parley
description: Law schools must broaden their careers by dealing more fully with the legal rights of women, several hundred law professors and students from around the country were told yesterday at the end of a twoday symposium at the Nev, York University Law School.

title: The Fireside Book of Tennis
description: After a century of relative obscurity, tennis came alive again with a historic decision (in 1968) to declare the game open. Despite heavy demands by its professional promoters and some muddleheaded obstinacy by national officials, peace was declared in time for Forest Hills, and the best players in the world once again were allowed to compete with each other.

title: MICHIGAN STATE ROUTS WISCONSIN
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct, 21 (AP)Mark Niesen, the quarterback, picked his way 56 yards up the rainslicked artificial turf for Michigan State's longest gain this season as the Spartans scored a 310 victory over Big Ten football rival Wisconsin.

title: NEBRASKA ROUTS KANSAS, 56 TO 0
description: LAWRENCE, Kan. Oct. 21 (AP)David Humm t:Firew four touchdown passes, a school record, as fifthranked Nebraska routed Kansas, 56.0, today.

title: UNBEATEN WINGS DOWN LEAFS, 31
description: TORONTO, Oct. 21 (UPI)Nick Libett's third goal of the season late in the second period proved to be the decisive one as the Detroit Red Wings stretched their unbeaten streak to five games by downing the Toronto Maple Leafs, 31, tonight.

title: SCHOOLBOY BEATS LIQUORI'S RECORD
description: Marty Liquori's scholastic crosscountry record at Van Cortlandt Park was finally broken yesterdaybut not by Matt Centrowitz.

title: New York 2, New York
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 21Playing with a sense of the historic, the newly born Islanders barely missed a remarkable upset tonight and bowed to the Rangers in the first meeting between two New York National Hockey League teams in 30 years.

title: the traveler's world
description: LIKE A lonely, ailing mallard duck, a diesel locomotive quacks its melancholy horn through New Hampshire and Vermont these autumn nights, whistling for White River Junction and Bellows Falls and Essex Junction (station stop for Burlington) and on to Montreal. The monotonic air horn lacks the romantic sadness of the twotone steam locomotive whistle that wailed like a brokenhearted blues singer through village and farm, but then that old whoooowhooooo through the night does not quite match the bustling public relations image of Amtrak. And it is the insignia of Amtrak, the Federal agency that now operates most of the pation's passenger trains, that flashes on the sides of the newly restored WashingtonNew YorkMontreal sleeper, all six cars of it.

title: Great Gorge Skiers Swap and Save
description: McAFEE  There was a crisp hint of winter in the air at the Great Gorge ski slopes as members of the area's Ski Club concluded their fourth annual swap salean event designed to facilitate the exchange of equipment and clothing among devotees of the sport with a minimum outlay of cash.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, Oct. 21 Egyptian Army officers tried to overthrow President Anwar el  Sadat's Government last week, the British Broadcasting Corporation said tonight.

title: Movies
description: YOU won't hear producer Jay Weston singing the blues, now that his movie Lady Sings the Blues has been successfully launched, He's happily nestling up to Network, which he describes as a big, multicharacter story to be filmed much in the style of Airport. The script, in fact, is the result of our analysis of the elements that made Airport one of the biggest hits in screen history.

title: The World
description: SEOULTanks and armored personnel carriers and machine guns were posted before the South Korean capitol and National Assembly here last week. Helmeted soldiers, with rifles and fixed bayonets stood guard at Government buildings, communication centers, opposition party headquarters and universities.

title: KUHN EXONERATES UMPIRES FOR NOW
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 21 (AP)Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball, said today that early investigation had shown no indication of any wrongdoing by the 11 major league umpires whose names turned up in address books of a Baltimore gambler.

title: Football Team Pulls Out Of Park
description: Brooklyn Technical High School's football team is no longer practicing in Fort Greene Park. The team moved out after Commissioner of Parks August Beckseher, in response to community pressure, banned the players from practicing in the park.

title: Miss Pennington Wed
description: WHEELING, W. Va., Oct. 21Miss Barbara Pennington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth A. Pennington of Wheeling, was married here this morning to Geoffrey C. Clifford, son of Dr, and Mrs. Thomas C. Clifford of Lenox, Mass., and West Windsor, Vt. The Right Rev. Robert B. Hall, Bishop Coadjutor of Virginia, performed the ceremony in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, He was assisted by the Rev. William M. Todd.

title: Albright 2Point Conversion Beats Wagner Here, 2221
description: Albright College made a 2point conversion run after a touchdown and went on to beat Wagner College, 22.21, esterday before a crowd of 8,500 at the loser's field in Staten Island.

title: Immigrant Jews and criminality
description: To the Editor: If, in How to make the city safe again, (Sept. 24), Roger Starr managed to unearth Police Commissioner Bingham's article from The North American Review he also should have found his wellpublicized retraction. The false statement regarding Jewish criminals caused a huge uproar among New York City Jews and was largely responsible for the organization of the New York Kehillah (Jewish Community)  see Arthur Goren's recent book, New York Jews and the Quest for Community: the Kehillah Experiment 19081922. To reopen a debate on Jewish criminality to republication of palpably erroneous statistics is the height of foolishness and does disservice to whatever useful ideas Mr. Starr might have to offer.

title: Australian Population Dips
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 21 (Reuter's)Australia's population showed a decline this year for the first time since 1916, according to official figures published here, The Commonwealth Statistics Bureau said the population at the end of June was 12,959,00012,000 less than at the end of March.

title: Religion
description: Most Americans have become accustomed to the Jehovah's Witnesses' earnestly persistent practice of knocking on doors to proselytize at seemingly unlikely hours. But, apart from occasional court actions involving their opposition to blood transfusions and military service, it has been a generation since Witnesses were openly harassed in the United States.

title: Rain Forecast at Series
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 21 (AP) A 70 per cent chance of rain was forecast for tomorrow's final game of the 1072 World Series between the Oakland A's and Cincinnati Reds. Temperatures were expected to be in the low 60's.

title: A Pause for Reflection
description: When Congress reached an impasse on the Highway Bill in its closing days, the highway lobby suffered its most serious defeat in a generation. As usual in such unexpected debacles the lobby's greed and obstinacy were its own undoing.

title: Kim Lillian Russell Is Married to Jean Pierre GrosDaillon
description: NORTHPORT, L.I., Oct. 21 In St. Philip Neri Roman Catholic Church here at noon today, Miss Kim Lillian Russell became the bride of Jean Pierre GrosDaillon. The Rev. Richard Scanlon performed the ceremony and the Rev. Arthur Bloom of St. Paul's Methodist Church of Northport assisted.

title: Canadiens Stay Undefeated
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 21 (UPI)Marc Tardif got two goals tonight as the Montreal Canadiens extended their undefeated record to six games with a 53 victory over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Laser Technique Tested in Nuclear Science Hunt for PollutionFree Power
description: Preliminary tests are under way, notably in Moscow, to determine the feasibility of a radical new approach to the longsought goal of controlled fusion the nuclear reaction that would produce virtually unlimited, pollutionfree energy.

title: OKLAHOMA STATE TOPS BAYLOR, 207
description: STILLWATER, Okla. Oct. 21 (AP)  Lee Stover, a safety, ran 55 yards for a touchdown after a spectacular pass interception and sparked Oklahoma State to a 207 victory over Baylor on rainfilled artificial turf today.

title: Preps
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn Oct. 21Ed Kelly's 10yard scoring run gave Canterbury a 66 tie with Westminster after Lee Carlson had given Westminster the lead in the second quarter. Each team missed kicks for the extra point. Canterbury has tied twice, won one and lost one. Westminster's record is 121.

title: Attempt at Explaining The Mysteries of Finance
description: MANSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 21 (AP)Concerned about a rising county assessment, the Mansfield Board of Selectmen wrote the Bristol County Commission for an explantion.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Egyptian President Anwar Sadat's call for a Palestinian government in exile recalls the golden days of the Algerian revolution, when Cairo was the seat of the Algerian government in exile. To understand the Arab reaction, it is well to recall also what happened after the Algerian revolution. Revolutionary heroes like Ben Bella and Ben Khedda promptly liquidated one another and the job was finished by Boumedienne, an obscure army colonel who now rules Algeria and who was unknown during the revolution.

title: Connecticut Audubon Society Sends Nature to Classrooms
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Oct. 21Nature arrived in the classroom here this week In the form of a descented skunk, a talking crow, a fivefoot boa constrictor and five other live snakes, plus assorted frogs and toads.

title: New &Novel
description: According to Josephine Lawrence (who appears to have been studying these matters) Golden Agers tend to move in on their daughters, never on their sons. Exhibits A, B and C in her 31st novel are three cases of impossible ancestors who make terrible nuisances of themselves.

title: Haddock Limit Reached
description: GLOUCESTER, Mass, Oct. 21 (AP)Haddock fishing in areas off the New England coast will be closed for the year Friday, because the year's Ditch has reached the internationally set limit of 15,000 metric Ions, National Marine Fisheries Service announced today.

title: World News Briefs
description: BERLIN, Oct. 21The United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union are about to open official talks here aimed at redefining continuing fourpower responsibility for Berlin and Germany, diplomatic sources disclosed today.

title: Suffalk
description: Brentwood, behind its quarterback, Jim Russell, defeated South Huntington, 276, yesterday to remain undefeated and untied for the season and to continue its unbeaten string to 22 games over a threeseason span.

title: PEN STATE TOPS SYRACUSE, 17 TO 0
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Oct. 21Penn State and Syracuse waged a football version of dig  in trench warfare in the front lines agam today, and Penn State got just enough edge from a fumble to break the early standoff and gain a 170 triumph over the Orange.

title: BUCKNELL SETS BACK LAFAYETTE, 26 TO 7
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 21Bucknell scored in each of the first three quarters and went on to post a 267 victory over Lafayette here this afternoon.

title: Bridgers Fight To Keep a Roof Over Our Heads
description: THE COVERED bridge, that charming timbered remnant of 19thcentury America, is being paid the highest compliment of all these days: Its admirers are building new ones. And determined efforts are being made to keep the surviving originals alive.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  One of the blessings that should arrive with the end of the current Presidential campaign is some decline in the politicization of economic statistics.

title: Philippines Orders Land Redistribution To Tenant Farmers
description: MANILA, Oct. 21President Ferdinand E. Marcos issued a martial law decree today alloting 12 acres of land to each tenant farmer in the riceand corngrowing areas of the Philippines and limiting landowners to holdings of 17 acres.

title: Number of Policemen Killed and Hurt This Year Drops After Rising in 1971
description: Though far more New York policemen were killed and injured in violent conflicts during 1971 than 1970, the number of such incidents has abated so far in 1972, according to Police Department reports.

title: Secrecy and Darkness Guard Attack on Mafia.
description: The dawn was still hours away, and across the metropolitan area members of New York's five Mafia families were sleeping, lounging in cocktail bars or empathizing with the heroes or villains of television late late shows.

title: News of the Rialto
description: COME Wednesday at The Players there is going to be a luncheon in honor of James Nederlander and Ralph Alswang. Nederlander is head of the Nederlander theater chain which, with the musical Via Galactica on Nov. 21, opens its latest addition, the Uris Theater, designed by Alswang. No doubt the usual toasts will be drunk, the usual posies tossed around. There will be talk, too, about the Theater Hall of Fame being installed in the Uris along with the disclosure of the names of the first elected list of performers who will be added to the roster originally chosen by the executive committee.

title: YOUTH FUNDS USED FOR STAFF PARTIES
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame called yesterday for an immediate end to the practice of spending public funds for staff entertainment after they had been approved for programs for disadvantaged youths.

title: Blacks Get Help in Hunt For Homes In Bergen
description: RIDGEWOOD  Six years after New Jersey adopted one of the most stringent openhousing laws in the nation, the Fair Housing Committee of Ridgewood, Glen Rock and Vicinity is still quietly struggling to help black families buy or rent homes in this overwhelmingly white, middleclass end of Bergen County.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Pension legislation is dead this year but the issue is still very much alive.

title: Critic Falls In With Bad Company
description: ONE morning in the autumn of 1863, Drew Dixon, a modest, cleanliving Ohio country boy who's been tapped for conscription, hides from the Union Army search party that's been sent to the farm to fetch him. The Dixons, whose other son was killed at Chickamauga, refuse to give up Drew to the War Between The States. Instead, they present him with his brother's gold watch and $100 and solemnly shake his hand. Drew, wearing a black Sunday suit that was probably his brother's because it's still too big for him, sets off in the general direction of Virginia City to wait out the war and, if possible, to make his fortune.

title: L.S.U. Tops Kentucky, 100
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 21 (UPI)  Bert Jones broke a school passing record set by Y. A. Title with a 34yard touchdown pass and led seventhranked Louisiana State to a 100 victory over Kentucky tonight.

title: Views of the Review
description: To THE EDITOR: I have just noticed your marks in the Headliners column of The Week in Review [see page 4]. These are neither beginning quotation marks () nor closing quotation marks (). Is this intentional?

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The interview with the five young Americans who had traveled abroad was extremely interesting. The answers to the various questions were lucid, descriptive and indicated close observations while traveling by all of them.

title: About Motor Sports
description: It seldom is news that the professional racing program of the Sports Car Club of America is in trouble. What is news now is the extent of disarray in the club's Denver headquarters. The most painful setback is the breakdown of negotiations for the 1973 renewal of the L&M Continental 5000 Championship. H. Copland (Cope) Robinson, director of advertising services, says L&M is shopping around for other ways to invest its racing budget. Among the S.C.C.A.'s other difficulties are:

title: Fauna and Flora, Ringed by Suburbia, Flourish
description: WYCKOFF  Ringed by rows of suburban homes, the Bergen County Wildlife Center is an 81acre oasis of native New Jersey flora and fauna. Just five years old, the park was created on the size of a pig farm as a center for recreation and nature study.

title: Sports of The Times
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 21It was like pressure cooker exploding. All the pentup fury of the Cincinnati Reds burst through for the first time today and the World Series is suddenly, unexpectedly tied. So will be a sevengame showdown just as Sparky Anderson had predicted right from the beginning. Admittedly, it sounded like wishful thinking when his Reds were one game away from extinction. But it now seems to be brilliant prescience.

title: NIXON AIDES YOW TO CUT SPENDING
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 21 President Nixon's two senior fiscal advisers assured more than 100 leaders of major businesses today that his Administration was striving vigorously to cut Federal spending to avoid a tax increase next year and possibly in 1974.

title: Preps
description: SUFFIELD, Conn., Oct. 21Loomis, capitalizing on seven recovered fumbles, routed Suffield, 270, today. Frank Caufield passed for two touchdowns, including a 65yarder to Doug Arnold, and Dennis Killoran scored on a Caufield pass and a 9yard run.

title: Now Korea
description: President Park Chung Hee's proclamation of martial law in South Korea strikes another embarrassing blow at the moral underpinning of United States policy in Asia.Fortythree thousand American troops, backed by massive economic and military aid, still stand guard at this free world frontier. Now the bastions of freedom have been breached, not by an external aggressor but by the very leader who was entrusted with preserving at least the semblance of free institutions on the Korean peninsula.

title: CIVIL SERVICE LAW HELD BROKEN HERE
description: Eightythree per cent of the 918 provisional employes in the city's Housing and Development Administration have held their jobs for excessive periods in violation of Civil Service regulations, the State Study Commission for New York City charged yesterday.

title: Golf in the Kingdom
description: The thought of Shivas Irons playing golf sometimes strikes me as an utter absurdity. Can you imagine other philosophers and mystics out on the course? Saint Francis, for example, laboring over a threefoot putt, or Plato slinging a bag of clubs over his shoulder and striding happily down the first fairway. How a spirit so mad for the deeper mysteries could devote a life to this frustrating sport is a question that still distracts me.

title: JERSEY PRO LEADING BY 1 AT PINEHURST
description: PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 21 (AP)Babe Lichardus of Westfield, N.J., took the 54hole lead of the professional Golfer's Association club pro championship today with a thirdround 70 for a total of 211.

title: Fashionsnothing for the over25's?
description: To the Editor: I am told that onehalf of our population is 25 years or younger. An examination of the ads and copy in the Fashions of The Times supplement (Aug. 27) shows you are acutely aware of it.

title: Washington State Kicker Scores 13 in 377 Victory
description: PULLMAN, Wash., Oct. 21 (AP)A kicking specialist, Joe Danelo, accounted for 13 points, including a school recordtying three field goals, as Washington State beat Oregon State, 377, in a Pacific8 Conference football game today.

title: Alekai Ali, a Standard Poodle, Captures Top Award at Albany. K.C. Event
description: ALBANY, Oct. 21  The poodle is this country's most popular breed. Of more than a million dogs registered by the American Kennel Club last year, 256,000 were poodles. Of late, however, they haven't been faring well in the show ring. So it was high time for one to assert his mastery. It was Ch. Alekai Ali of Stonebridge, a magnificent white standard owned by Dr. and Mrs. I. Willard Abrahams of Meriden, Conn., and he led a record field of 1,264 at the Albany Kennel Club Show in the Washington Avenue Armory.

title: Death Row Vacated At Ohio Penitentiary
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 21 (AP)The last two inmates held in death row at the Ohio Penitentiary have been transferred to the prison reception center.

title: Bates Wins First Game In Last 26 on Field Goal
description: LEWISTON, Me., Oct. 21 (AP)Bates College's kicker, Ralph Bayek, kicked a 22yard field goal in the final period today, breaking a 25game losing streak and leading Bates to a 1714 football victory over American International College.

title: Television
description: SEVERAL weeks ago an actor on Love Is a Many Splendored Thing, an afternoon soapopera on the Columbia Broadcasting System, was heard using the word crap. A top CBS executive, who happened to be watching the program, was horrified, and the corporate wheels began turning to warn stations on the West Coast, where the program is run on a delayed basis and where the word could be bleeped.

title: MORE PROFESSORS WORKING ABROAD
description: The number of American professors and researchers working in foreign universities increased last year, according to a census by the Institute of International Education.

title: Newark and Jersey City Are Having Trouble in Selling Their Municipal Bonds
description: NEWARK  Some time ago, William F. Greenley, senior vice president at the Fidelity Union Trust Company, received a telephone call from a fellow banker in Jersey City.

title: Yes, Married
description: Judith Viorst's first book of prose is not antiWomen's Lib. Mrs. Viorst just happens to be one of those women who opts for family life. She doesn't give her views on marriage in general. Instead she has given us a witty anatomy of a modern marriageher own.

title: Carol Waterhouse Bride
description: ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 21 Miss Carol Bradbury Waterhouse, daughter of Mrs. Randolph B. Waterhouse of South Orange and the late Mr. Waterhouse, was married here this afternoon in Our Lady of the Valley Roman Catholic Church to Richard Anthony Barrett, son of Judge Charles S. Barrett Jr. of the Superior Court of New Jersey and Mrs. Barrett, also of South Orange. The Rev. William McGuire performed the ceremony.

title: RABBIS ARE SHOCKED BY POLITICAL MORALS
description: Leaders of American Reform Judaism expressed shock last week at what they described as widespread evidence of gross immorality both in the government and in the current political campaign.

title: JOHN S. WILSON'S MUSIC
description: LAWRENCE TOWNSHIP  Suburbia is flooded these days with musical groups that play the big band sounds  usually made up of middleaged musicians who recreate nostalgic memories of Glenn Miller for equally middleaged and nostalgic listeners. But in Lawrence Township the big band sounds are being produced by a band that is different on several scores.

title: SCHOOL FOOTBALL
description: WILBRAHAM, Mass, Oct. 21 KimballUnion came here today unbeaten, unscored upon and averaging 42 points a game. It was left reeling by WilbrahamMonson with a 5020 loss. Tim Harrington ran for three touchdowns, and Bob Martin completed 11 passes for 153 yards and one touchdown and ran for another.

title: POP
description: GILTIERT O'SULLIVAN: Himself (MAM 4). Ladies and gentlemen, he begins, allow me to present myself to you, and then he doesn't. For the most part, Gilbert O'Sullivan works hard at not presenting himself, hiding behind musical and lyrical screens seemingly designed not to communicate. His intricate, internallyrhymed lyrics are as impenetrable and alienating as somebody else's injoke. The orchestrations, which are unusually nice popcrooner arrangements, keep the listener at an enforced distance away from O'Sullivan's thin, nonpopcrooner voice, The singer himself relies heavily on the effect of his words and his oddlyaccented phrases, yet he keeps swallowing lyrics in his more important songs. Whatever part of himself O'Sullivan wanted the album to present, it can't compare to the himself that is camouflaged and hidden.

title: Local
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Oct. 21 Scott Grosfeld scored on a 4yard run and a 25yard pass' from Roy Samuelson today to lead undefeated Dalton School of New York to its fourth victory, 3620, over Englewood, School.

title: MonmouthOcean
description: Ocean Township, the only unbeaten, untied and unscoredupon team in New Jersey, kept rolling with a 200 victory over Lakewood yesterday in Lakewood.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: When people began sending bombs through the mails, it became inevitable that one would explode prematurely and cause injury or death to persons other than the intended victims. The letter bombs recently mailed from Amsterdam were probably lifted by air to London and other world capitals and could have exploded while the plane were in flight. Passenger planes are also letter carriers, so it's quite possible that there would be a heavy loss of life.

title: All Signs Point to A delphi for Seminar
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I.There were stars during the daytime at Adelphi University recently, but they were not in the sky, or from Hollywood  they were on astrological charts.

title: New York
description: It was a perfect media event. Two busloads of newspapermen, radio and television reporters and their technological acolytes wound through Brooklyn for almost an hour last Monday, arriving finally at one of the borough's netherregions, Canarsie, before a nondescript junkyard. Eugene Gold, the diminutive Brooklyn District Attorney, was already waiting in his aquamarine Cadillac limousine.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 21 This city, 800 miles inland from the Pacific Ocean, might seem an unlikely site for an enterprise involved in international trade.

title: U.N. Reports a Decline In Women in Major Posts
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21 (Reuters) The United Nations Secretariat, under orders from the General Assembly to bring more women into professional posts, reported this week that it actually had a lower percentage of women in those jobs in 1972 than the previous year 18.54 per cent compared with 19 per cent in 1971.

title: Tenants Will Pay Rent
description: MANILA, Oct. 21 (AP) President Marcos said that the tenant taking over land would pay the landowner the rent to which he is entitled under a lease for 15 years. Payment would be guaranteed by the cooperatives and the Government, he added.

title: At the Garden: Art on Stamps
description: THE 24th National Postage Stamp Show to be held at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 17, 18 and 19 will be devoted to Art on Stamps. The show will, on its opening day, share firstday ceremonies with an 8c United States stamp honoring stamp collecting, and a 4stamp and souvenir card issue from the United Nations.

title: A Zoo That Goes to Children
description: WEST ORANGE  Some people come to this zoo; the zoo goes to others. Some creatures come to this zoo; the zoo sends others to their natural habitat.

title: East Brunswick Is Debating A Plan to Redevelop Route 18
description: EAST BRUNSWICKTo Mayor Joseph A. Mammon, the proposal for a futuristic redevelopment of a cluttered stretch of Route 18 is nothing more than a cynical electionyear gambit. Others dismiss the idea as folly or unfeasible, but some view it as visionary and worth fighting for.

title: Mackell Had SoninLaw Study Case He Is Linked To
description: District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens assigned his soninlaw, an assistant in his office, to examine a complaint about a getrich scheme when he knew that the soninlaw had invested in the scheme, according to sources close to the case.

title: Larger 3Second Area Proposed by Nat Holman
description: Still with it as he celebrates a Spirit of 76 birthday, Nat Holman has the feeling basketball's giants enjoy an unwarranted advantage.

title: Aznavour: His Music Is An Exact Equivalent of Romance
description: IT is Ironic, at the least, that in spite of the attention which has been paid to his recently published autobiography, Charles Aznavour's latest album, released here in July, has not been reviewed at all in America. Yet the autobiography is generally banal collection of anecdotes infused with inspirational advice, while the album contains the latest work by one of the best singercomposers in the world. The autobiography restates most of the themes found in the songs, of course, but those themes are lifeless and occasionally even ludicrous when stripped of their poetry and music and reheated into the real life from which they were somehow originally frozen.

title: Local
description: WEST ISLIP, L.I., Oct. 21St. John the Baptist, with three juniors doing all of the scoring, defeated Chaminade today, 140, in a Catholic High School Football League game. Bob Grimsland opened the scoring with a 5yard run and Gregory Geiger added a conversion run. Geiger also passed to Richie Cronin for 4 6yard touchdown.

title: Movies
description: OUTWARDLY, he is a smiling, happygolucky kid, the boy next door with the crinkly eyes and the cocker spaniel demeanor. Everybody's Little Brother. Outwardly. But the real Jeff Bridges is a tormented 22yearold actor who is filled with selfhate  an actor so in rebellion against society that, on his first day of interviews in New York, he presents himself in a scraggly blond beard that his father had begged him to shave and a circa 1950 gray and yellow rayon shirt that the bums on the Bowery would probably turn down. It's all part of his selfhate schtich, or so he keeps saying, as he sits there on the flowery orange sofa in his SherryNetherland suite, where Paramount has put him in the hopes that he will say something good about his latest movie, Bad Company, which was one of the highlights of the recent New York Film Festival.

title: As if Burroughs had written Lord of the Flies
description: It's hard these days not to notice that extremist poets kill themselves with agonizing frequency, but has anyone commented on the more subtle casualty rate among experimental novelists? We might call it the One Big Book syndrome, the great original work that tries to put everything together, to do the unsurpassable, not merely comment on the world but give shape to a new mode of consciousness. It happens unfortunately that the greater the success the more paralyzing the consequent ambition to surpass, to do something larger, wilder, more inclusiveor at least more drastic.

title: 1,000 ON GILA RIVER FLEE FLOOD WATERS
description: DUNCAN, Ariz., Oct. 21 (UPI)  All 1,000 residents of this farming community on the Gila River were safely evacuated today when flood waters swept over dikes and poured into the downtown area. Elsewhere in eastern Arizona, there were six floodrelated deaths.

title: Triple Bend, $11.40, Takes Vosburgh Sprint
description: Applying the principle of try, and try again, Frank McMahon's Triple Bend finally succeeded in making his way to the winner's circle in New York. Out of the money in his four previous appearances in this state, Triple Bend showed the form that made him so great a favorite with California fans by taking the $58,850 Vosburgh Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Siedlecki Scores 3 Times As Union Tops R.P.I., 3821
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Oct. 21 Union College turned two pass interceptions and a short punt into a 210 half time lead and went on to defeat Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute today, 3821, in the 70th renewal of New York State's oldest continuing football rivalry.

title: Bergen Politics: ATale of 2 Men
description: HACKENSACKMatthew Feldman and Anthony J. Statile are very much alike.

title: Canadians Ban a Textbook Biased Against Russsians
description: VICTORIA, British Columbia, Oct. 21 (Canadian Press)Education Minister Eileen Dailly has reported that a Grade 6 textbook with a controversial chapter on the politics of the Soviet Union would be withdrawn from use in British Columbia schools.

title: Jessie Colgate Plans Nuptials
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. James H. Evans of Pottersville, N. J. and Richard M. Colgate of Princeton, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jessie Morse Colgate, to Thomas Paul Southwick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Southwick of Chevy Chase, Md.

title: FORDHAM CONQUERS ST. JOHN'S, 14 TO 7
description: Fordham defeated St. John's, 147, before 1,200 fans yesterday on the Redmen's campus in Jamaica.

title: Cinderella Horse Starson L.I.
description: ST JAMES, L.I.  He still wears the scars of the heavy work harness that cut into his skin when he was an Amish plow horse in Pennsylvania, but to the busloads of children who visit him here each year the shaggy gray gelding is a hero.

title: Central Conn., Led by Ellis, Tops 3 Cross Country Foes
description: Central Connecticut defeated C. W. Post, St. John's and Adelphi in a quadrangular cross country meet yesterday in Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

title: Poles and West Germans Join to Make Their Schoolbook History More Objective
description: BRUNSWICK, West Germany  For generations young Poles and Germans learned that blood and tears, hatred and wars marked relations between their countries, but if present plans succeed a new chapter in the history books may open soon.

title: Dr. Lewis N. Brown Dies; Pharmacy Professor, 81
description: SAG HARBOR, L. L, Oct. 21 IDr. Lewis N. Brown, who retired in 1957 as professor of pharmacy at the College of Pharmacy of Columbia University, died yesterday in Southamptoh Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived here.

title: Rutgers Faces 1.5Million Loss
description: TRENTONRutgers, the State University, is in danger of forfeiting about $1.5million in state aid as a result of the growing problem of stopouts among the university's student body.

title: A Student Reports On Trip to China
description: PRINCETON  Americans today are finding it easier to enter the previously isolated People's Republic of China, but few are able to avoid the consequences of being a foreigner as successfully as Helen Zia did this summer.

title: Chess: Bilek Wears The Mantle Of Hyperrnodernism Well
description: Hungary has been a hotbed of hypermodernism from way back. At the turn of the century it was her illustrious if eccentric representative Gyula Breyer who declaimed: After 1 PK4, White's game is in its last throes.

title: Bypass Operation for Heart Disease Gains Favor and Stirs a Controversy
description: A coronary bypass operation for arte esclerotic heart disease that 11 doctors from China saw a Bronx surgeon perform here last week is a promising but controversial recent development that has grown popular and become profitable for surgeons and hospitals.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 21The Texas Legislature has voted to create a new state petroleum commission to work for construction of deep water port facilities off the Texas Coast.

title: STUDY OF CONGRESS FINDS STATE WEAK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21As summed up by one of the authors who participated in the study of Congress directed by Ralph Nader, the New York, Congressional delegation lacks political clout here because of its high rate of turnover caused by frequent redistrict; ing and because some New Yorkers tend of emphasize press releases rather than fol lowing through on legislation.

title: A Foot Is the Difference
description: DE KALB, Ill., Oct. 21 (UPI) Roger Passaglia of Northern Illinois kicked field goals of 37, 24 and 42 yards today to defeat West Texas State, 178.

title: Happy Homecoming
description: GRAMBLING, La., Oct. 21 (UPI)  Herman Christophe ran for 133 yards and a touchdown today to lead Grambling to a 2613 homecoming football victory over Jackson State. Grambling has a 43 wonlost record for the season.

title: Report Criticizes U.S. Jobs Program
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 The National Urban Coalition issued today a report describing the Government's public employment program as too little and too late and calling on Congress to expand and improve Federal emergency employment efforts.

title: Polish Tourists in U.S. Are Sometimes Immigrants
description: WARSAW  For several months last year, an enterprising woman in the mountainous southern region of Poland, traditionally a source of emigration to the United States, operated a virtual branch office of the American Embassy.

title: Dartmouth Romps Over Brown, 4920
description: HANOVER, N. H., Oct. 21Calvin Coolidge was finishing his second stint as President, land the stock market crash was still one year away when Brown last beat Dartmouth in football here.

title: PROBABLE ACCORD IS SEEN IN HANOI
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Oct. 21  The highest authorities here believe that a settlement of the Vietnam war is more probable than not, but there is no conviction that agreement is definite.

title: Man must accept the challenge of the environment
description: Jonas Salk, the developer of the first effective vaccine against polio, has already made a sufficient contribution to the wellbeing of mankind to last most people a lifetime. However, be has now made another valiant assault on the ills of the world, this time not by ministering to one particular infirmity, but by attempting to throw light on the general nature of man, his place in the world, and the ways in which he might come to a fuller realization of his inherent potentials The effort is not so spectacularly successful as his earlier conquest of a disease, but Salk's homily contains much wisdom, and it must be hoped that the world will heed it.

title: POP
description: T. REX: The Slider (Reprise MS 2095). At least every other week another group appears that's hailed by its publicists as the biggest thing since the Beatles. In the case of T. Rex and its superstar vocalist/songwriter/guitarist Marc Bolan, it may he true. In T. Rex's native England, Bolanmania has infected teenyboppers who were still sucking their thumbs when John, Paul, George and Ringo shook up the world, So far, Bolanmania hasn't. gripped the States in fact, Mr. Bolan's Carnegie Hall debut last season could hardly he called triumphant. But this third Reprise album, which coincides with the group's current American tour, just might convert the colonies.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: SIZZLING STEAKcompletedelivered In your door In an hour. DIALASTEAK ??3688.ADVT.

title: Mickey Mouse teaches the architects
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.: There is a nondescript, twostory building in Glendale, Calif., that houses 400 men who may have more influence on the shape America's cities will take than any planners, architects or urban designers could ever hope to. They are not part of a think tank, or a university, or foundation, or anything remotely like these; their operation, which is called WED Enterprises, Inc., owned and fully controlled by the company that made Mickey Mouse, Walt Disney Productions.

title: In Highland Park, A Hidden Castle
description: HIGHLAND PARK  Few passing motorists on River Road would suspect that a copy of a medieval castle is hidden behind the stone fence.

title: Local
description: New Utrecht took advantage of numerous Midwood mistakes yesterday for a 3020 P.S.A.L. Brooklyn Division I victory at Midwood Field. The Utes were naced by a twoway player, Joe Rodriguez who scored on both offense and defense.

title: M'GOVERN OFFERS BROAD URBAN PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 Senator George McGovern proposed today a comprehensive urban strategy, based on new Federal policies and outlays but emphasizing local leadership.

title: Mall Hires Filmmakers, 13
description: PARAMUSTwo 13yearold moviemakers are busy these days shooting a film on the construction of an enclosure for the Bergen Mall shopping center here.

title: Horse Show News
description: The Foxfield Full Crys, a precision jumping team of youngsters from Westlake Village, Calif., will make a repeat appearance at the National Horse Show this year.

title: OSSINING INMATES START NEW GROUP
description: OSSINING, Oct. 21Inmates at the Ossining Correctional Facility have started a new organization to create a work release program inside the prison and a job referral program outside it. They call it Project House of Tomorrow.

title: Youth Council Activities Are Available by Phone
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I.The Youth Bureau of the Town of Oyster Bay is recording information about all, of the activities run by the town's 11 youth councils.

title: Army Turns Back N.Y.U. In CrossCountry by 1746
description: Army coasted to its fourth crosscountry triumph in five decisions yesterday with a 1746 victory over New York University at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Westchester
description: White Plains beat New Rochelle in the battle between Westchester County's undefeated titans, 2012, at Parker Stadium in White Plains yesterday as the Tigers stretched their winning streak to 15 games.

title: Eagleton Sees Progress
description: Morehead, Ky., Oct. 21 (UPI) Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri, said yesterday that his withdrawal as Democratic vice presidential nominee may have hurt the Presidential candidate Senator George McGovern at first but the McGovernSargent ticket was 'climbing steadily now.

title: Segovia Hurt in Car Crash
description: LONDON, Oct. 21 (UPI) Andres Segovia canceled thell second leg of a fourcountry tour today as a result of in juries suffered last night in an automobile accident. His wife, Emilia, said the 78yearold Spanishbore guitar virtuoso would rest here until Tuesday. He had been scheduled to fly to Innsbruck, Austria, tomorrnw. Mr. Segovia sustained cuts and lacerations of his left leg when the taxi in which he was riding on Park Lane collided with two other vehicles.

title: Italian Official Fighting To Abolish State. Lottery
