description: ROME  Pope Alexander VII tried it but 17th century Romans paid no attention. Giuseppe Garibaldi tried it in Naples in 1860 and almost caused a revolution. Now, a lawyer from Lucca who is an under secretary of finance in the Italian Government wants to try his hand at abolishing the nearly 400yearodd game of lottothe state lottery.

title: Preps
description: MILTON, Mass., Oct. 21Milton scored in every period and remained undefeated today with a 346 rout of Governor Dummer.

title: MISTRIAL, TO TURNER, IS WASTE OF TIME
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., Oct. 21 (AP)Glenn W. Turner has described his 10  day trial on charges of violating Florida's securities law as a waste of my talent and a waste of my time.

title: Social Announcements
description: Social Announcements

title: Rockland
description: Nanuet's best season ever in the Public Schools Athletic League might be a championship year. The Golden Knights dazzled Clarkstown South yesterday, 346, for their fourth victory in five starts. Unbeaten North Rockland, meanwhile, won its 22d in a row by beating Suffern, 268.

title: NASSAU PLANNERS TO OPPOSE BRIDGE
description: MINEOLA, LI., Oct. 21The Nassau County Planning Commission announced today that it opposed the proposed Oyster BayRye bridge across Long Island Sound as detrimental to Nassau County residents.

title: CHAPOT CAPTURES PENN GRAND PRIX
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 21Frank Chapot and Good Twist finished the international jumping at the 27th annual Pennsylvania National Horse Show in the same manner they started it eight days ago by winning the International Class.

title: Rhodesia Restricts Bar Use
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 21 (Reuter)  The Rhodesian Government issued new regulations yesterday preventing blacks from being served in bars in white areas during the week after 7 P.M., more than three hours before the normal bar closing time.

title: The World
description: At last, a convincingif anachronisticexplanation of that Mona Lisa smile: She was simply amused. The suggestion was offered last week as two Britons claimed possession of originals of the da Vinci masterpiece. The rivals: Lord Brownlow, one of England's wealthiest peers and a former personal lordinwaiting to King Edward VIII; Dr. Henry Pulitzer, art dealer and former gentlemaninwaiting to King Zog of Albania. Neither disputes the authenticity of the Mona Lisa hanging in the Louvre; both claim that da Vinci painted more than one version. A gentleman in Spain has made similar claims. Possible, said one art expert, but not probable. Meanwhile, Lord Brownlow has offered to allow his Mona Lisa to be shown at an upcoming London exhibition, and Dr. Pulitzer has indicated he would entertain an invitation to do the came. It could he one of the great faceoffs of all time.

title: IRISH ARE STUNNED BY MISSOURI, 3026
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 21  Don Johnson, fullback, scored two touchdowns and Greg Hill booted three field goals today as Missouri upset previously unbeaten Notre Dame, 3026.

title: INDIA'S LAST DRYS BATTLE WET TIDE
description: AHMEDABAD, India, Oct. 10 In the liquor shop of the Cama Hotel here, the Government inspector of prohibition sat at his desk thoroughly hating his job.

title: Soviet Film Blames Allies for War Convoy's Loss
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 21As a final LendLease settlement between the United States and the Soviet Union was signed in Washington this week, the Russians released a new feature film dramatizing one of the most celebrated episodes in the Western allies effort to ship supplies to the hardpressed Soviet Union in World War II.

title: SUPERVISORS PRINT NEWARK NEWSPAPER
description: NEWARK, Oct. 21Officials of The Newark StarLedger, said today that the newspaper had published today's editions with management people running the presses.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Will someone please tell George and Joanne Devine [Commuting Is Better in Reverse, Oct. 8] that no one in a rentcontrolled apartment hasn't had a rent increase since the late nineteenforties?

title: Buckley Says Death Penalty Is the Ultimate Deterrent
description: Senator James L. Buckley said yesterday that he favored the death penalty as the ultimate deterrent to such crimes as trading in narcotics which destroy human lives.

title: MorrisSomerset
description: Dave Bennett scored his third touchdown of the afternoon with 40 seconds remaining yesterday as Roxbury remained unbeaten in five starts with a 2826 victory over Parsippany Hills in Parsippany.

title: Survey Finds That TV Comedy Program Improves Reading Skills of Pupils
description: The Electric Company, a funny, fastpaced educational television program that seeks to improve the reading skills of elementary schoolchildren by combining the techniques of Sesame Street and Laughin has been called highly successful by an evaluation team at Florida State University.

title: Tufts Tops Coast Guard
description: MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 21 (AP)  Mike Metzler threw a pair of touchdown passes to Mike Gorham as Tufts scored a 2914 victory over the Coast Guard today.

title: Nassau South
description: Uniondale and Freeport continued to set the pace in Nassau South Shore Division II football with impressive victories yesterday. Uniondale relaxed against Long Beach, 3820, while Freeport handled Valley Stream Central, 200.

title: 6 More Teachers Held Up In Schools Here in Week
description: Assailants with knives, guns or simulated guns accosted six more publicSchool teachers in classroom robberies last week, the police reported yesterday. In the last 12 days, nine teachers have been robbed, all but one in the presence of their pupils.

title: 5Run 7th Seals It; Blue, Nolan Chased
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 21The Cincinnati Reds continued their rousing revival today by crushing the Oakland A's, 81, and finally deadlocked the World Series at three games apiece with one to go for the championship.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: IN A RECENT conversation, David Rockefeller, chairmtn of the Chase Manhattan Bank, suggested that the time would soon be appropriate for a dialogue among political leaders, businessmen, economists, academicians and other interested parties on their recommendations for the future nature and scope of the nation's economiccontrols mechanism.

title: Court Upholds Liberties Union on Ad
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21A Threejudge Federal court here has ordered the Justice Department not to enforce key sections of the new campaignspending disclosure law pending a full ruling on its constitutionality.

title: 76ers Beaten, 11188
description: The return of Willis Reed to National Basketball Association competition was neither an artistic nor emotional landmark last night at Madison Square Garden, but the Knick captain was happy to be a part of a 11188 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers before a capacity crowd of 19,694.

title: Carol B. O'Neill, Robert S. Bast To Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Grover O'Neill Jr. of New York and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Boker O'Neill, to Robert Sinclair Bast, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lower Bast of Ambler, Pa., and grandson of the late Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce under President Dwight D. Eisenhower. A June wedding is planned.

title: New York
description: Mayor Zoran Popovich of McKeesport, Pa., greeted the news with: It's a godsend. I feel like Ronald Colman walking out of the blizzard and walking into ShangriLa.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: It's a damnable shame when you subject our greatest living poet, W. H. Auden, to the scribblings of the likes of Calvin Bedient. I refer, of course, to Bedient's review of Auden's Epistle to a Godson and Other Poems.

title: In the style of Bo Belinsky, Joe Numath, Lee Trevino and Muhammad Ali:
description: Tastefully hidden in a stuccoed underbrush of uppermiddleclass bungalows, the Los Angeles Tennis Club is exactly the sort of splendid shrine you'd expect to find in London, Boston, Newport or any of the hundred other hallowed plots where the defenders of 19thcentury virtue still wage a holy war against vulgarity and the encroachments of a plastic society. It is difficult to comprehend that the same civilization that produced the architectural horror of Grauman's Chinese Theatre, just few blocks to the northwest, could have constructed this masterpiece of serenity. The grounds are closecropped and stately. The greenpainted clapboard stands at center court creak admirably with age, their sunwithered planks seating no more than 5,000 spectators at best. A canvas roof stretches across the upper pavilion and along the balcony where movie stars mingle with the keepers of the faith. The conversation along the walks breathless and cultured. The ball boys are tall, lean and reasonably shorthaired, all stamped, no doubt, from the same cookie mold. Everywhere plebeian glances, the perfect decorum strikes him flush between the eyes. And wherever he thrusts his nose, he catches the pungent odor of pure incense.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Though a lifelong Democrat and liberal, I am distressed that The Times has chosen to endorse McGovern. You would have shown more wisdom and courage had you made a forthright declaration that in 1972 it is impossible to choose the better man simply because there is none. One can only vote, as so many plan to do, for the lesser of two evils, and as someone pointed out, when you select the lesser evil, you are still choosing an evil.

title: L.I. Coach Is Holding Court In Tennis
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I. He is a small, perky man with a ruddy complexion, thinning hair and sharp blue eyes is manner 19 genial and polite and his voice retains the accent from Australia, where he rose to fame as the most successful Davis Cup tennis coach in History.

title: Wetlands Institute to Work This Winter
description: STONE HARBOR  The South Jersey Wetlands Institute, a privately financed research and education facility here, has set out to broaden both the scientist's and layman's knowledge of the saltmarsh environment.

title: Help for Offenders Periled in Newark
description: NEWARKTwo years ago here in the Central Ward a group of young men helped residents recover from the 1967 riots and established an innovative rehabilitation program to assist first offenders.

title: Dr. Daniel Schlumberger Dead; Archeologist in the Middle East
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 21Dr. Daniel Schlumberger, leading French archeologist currently engaged in research as a visiting member of the Institute for Advanced Study here, died last night of a heart attack in Princeton Hospital. His age was 67.tated the work of the joint FrenchAmerican mission for the excavation of Antioch on the Orontes River in the Middle East.

title: WALL STREET
description: Glamour stocks are supposed to be capable or feats of market strength beyond the ability of runofthemill investments. They are glamorous, after all, because they make big profits for the sharpeyed investors who buy them early.

title: Whimsy of Youth Collected
description: An apartment in Forest Hills, Queens, houses one of the largest private collections of children's books in the United States.

title: An immense density of systematicities
description: Michel Foucault is one of a handful of French thinkers who have, in the last 10 years, given an entirely new direction to theoretical work in the socalled human sciences, the study of language, literature, psychiatry, intellectual history and the like. He is best known for The Order of Things (Les Mots et les choses), a rich and controversial work in which he introduced an archaeological method of great originality and, I believe, importance. This method, or rather its presuppositions, is the subject of The Archaeology of Knowledge.

title: Pratt Proves It Will Remain in Brooklyn
description: Eightyfive years ago, when Clinton Hill was considered one of Brooklyn's better neighborhoods, Charles Pratt, a kerosene magnate and partner of John D. Rockefeller, founded Pratt Institute, erecting its buildings within short walking distance of his huge mansion at the top of the Hill.

title: Mr. Social Security
description: Building a sound foundation of social protection for Americans against the economic hazards of old age, unemployment, poverty and illhealth was the lifelong endeavor of Arthur J. Altmeyer. A quiet, scholarly technician from Wisconsin, he helped draft the Social Security Act 35 years ago, then performed the even more exacting task of steering the new law through the administrative quicksands that threatened to engulf it in its first decade.

title: LINDSAY TO RETAIN A LIBERAL STANCE ON MAJOR ISSUES
description: Despite polls indicating that many voters are shifting toward conservatism, Mayor Lindsay has decided to fight for liberal positions on school busing, capital punishment and abortion when bills on these highly controversial subjects are argued at the next session of the State Legislature.

title: SCIENCE TEACHING AT ISSUE ON COAST
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 21A longstanding dispute within the State Board of Education over what California schoolchildren are to be taught about man's origin headed this week toward a public hearing reminiscent of the Scopes monkey trial of 47 years ago.

title: BergenPassaic
description: WoodRidge High is unbeaten, and the town's mayor, A. J. Borresen, is proud.

title: Notes: Who Pays The Piper?
description: WHILE the rest of Florida continues to exhort tourists to come on down, Fort Lauderdale, one of the state's major vacation centers, has executed an abrupt aboutface, creating a brouhaha of such magnitude that even the Mayor has threatened to move out of town.

title: Preps
description: KENT, Conn., Oct. 21Kent gained the lead, lost it and took it back again, all in the last period, in a 19.15 victory over Berkshire today.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: In Joseph Brodsky's very interesting account of his attitude toward literature (A writer is a lonely traveler, Oct. 1), he states, I do not share the contemporary point of view that countries should know more about each other. As Robert Frost said, Good fences make good neighbors. Mr. Brodsky allows himself to slip into the dangerous error of attributing to the writer (Frost) feelings voiced by one of his characters. In fact, the remark actually expresses an attitude with which the poem's narrative is obviously in total disagreement. The poem, Mending Wall, reads:

title: Nixon Asks C.A.B. Restudy Of Acquisition of Caribair
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UPI) President Nixon rejected today a Civil Aeronautics Board decision against Eastern Airlines acquisition of CaribbeanAtlantic Airlines, and returned it to the board for further consideration.

title: STATE TO RETHINK RELIEF RENT RULE
description: The state is reappraising a sixweekold order requiring that rents he paid directly to landlords when welfare tenants fail to pay them. The reevaluation is a result of questions raised by the City Department of Social Services.

title: Dance: National Ballet Season Opens
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The National Ballet opened its Kennedy Center season here at the Opera House last night. It was in splendid form, practically bursting at the seams with vitality.

title: POP
description: BOBBY WOMACK: Understanding United Artists UAS5577). Although he's one of the most respected rhythm n blues guitarist/songwriters, Bobby Womack hasn't yet hit the big time the way an Isaac Hayes or Ray Charles has. Certainly Womack has paid his dues, starting out in partnership with his brothers in the Valentinos, touring and playing guitar with the late Sam Cooke, writing It's All Over Now, which was a big record for the Rolling Stones, and recording with stars like Aretha Franklin and Wilson Pickett.

title: Navy Touchdown in Last 31 Seconds Inflicts First Loss on Air Force, 2117
description: AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., Oct. 21 (AP)Dan Howard took a pitchout and ran yards around left end to score with 31 seconds left today, giving Navy a 2117 upset football victory over Air Force Academy.

title: The Presidential Issue
description: The office of the Presidency occupies a central place in American life. A President conducts foreign policy and is supremely responsible in issues of war and peace. He is head of a huge administrative machine and shares with Congress in the preparation and evolution of legislation.

title: Harvard Law for Dakotan
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct, 21 (UPI)A straw poll of Harvard Law School students and faculty showed a strong preference for Senator George McGovern over President Nixon. Students who voted favored Mr. McGovern 698 to 131. Faculty members preferred Mr. McGovern 34 to 4.

title: PRISONS INTENSIFY MENTAL PROGRAM
description: The mental health staff in the city's prison system has increased fivefold in the last year, and basic medical services have been expanded and upgraded in each of the system's 10 institutions, the Health Services Administration said yesterday.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: We enjoyed reading about the travels of the five young Americans. My husband and I just returned from a short European trip and would like our two teenagers to go there some summer. Anything said by their contemporaries, or people near their age, means so much more than anything we could say to them. I think the advice and experience shared by these five young people will make an invaluable impression on our two young ones.

title: City Opera Revives Der Rosenkavalier
description: Devotees of Der Rosenkavalier are in luck just now. The New York City Opera has revived Richard Strauss's big, waltzy opera in an almostnew production that honors the company and the work. The first performance was given Friday night.

title: U.C.L.A. TRAMPLES CALIFORNIA, 4913
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 21 (UPI)Kermit Johnson exploded on touchdown runs of 55 and 45 yards today while shredding California's defense for 139 rushing yards in leading ninthranked University of California, Los Angeles, to a 49.13 victory.

title: Feminists Help Employers Curb Sexism
description: PRINCETON JUNCTIONThree New Jersey, women, members of the newly formed Association of Feminist Consultants, are providing professional consulting services to businessmen, industries and educational establishments on ways to improve the economic and social status of women.

title: Toledo Tops Dayton, 2017
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Oct, 21 (AP) Jim Mulinix turned a pass interception into a 28yard touchdown today as Toledo defeated Dayton, 2017.

title: Black U.S. Travel Agents, Meeting in Africa, See Tourism Forcing Changes
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Oct. 19  A fourday meeting of black American travel agents ended here yesterday with vows to make black travelers a respected and organized force for social change.

title: Marcia DunbarSoule Is Wed to Richard B. Dobson
description: ROXBURY, Conn., Oct. 21 Miss Marcia Winslow DunbarSoule and Richard Bruce Dobson, who are studying for doctorates at Harvard University, were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Elbert B. Hamlin performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: New &Novel
description: A Story Like the Wind is magic. It evokes the legendary, Merlinesque Africa the author knew as a child, and sets it on a collision course with contemporary realities. The heart of this big, incandescent novel is the life of a 13yearold boy, living on a farm in South Africa. Francois Joubert inhabits a world of indigenous heroes, from whom he absorbs a rich store of tribal myth and jungle lore.

title: Local Papers Filling Gap in Small Towns
description: ROCKY HILLMany of New Jersey's small towns and new housing developments, desperate for information about their local governments and public meetings, have found a new solutionthey publish their own newspapers.

title: Janet S. Ryan Has Nuptials
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Oot. 21In St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church here at noon today, Miss Janet Sue Ryan was married to Thomas Hunter Nevin by the Rev. Alfred J. Burke.

title: Should the doughboy be tickled before or after?
description: The conference room is like something out of a 1938 Lubitsch production, only here everything is real: the Florentine antiques, the rich paintings, the luminous rugs. In this impressive chamber eight men have convened. They are tastefully dressed and they exude success. Half of them earn more than the $42,500 we pay our Congressmen.

title: WOMEN GAINING IN ARAB NATIONS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21  No feminists are marching in the streets of Cairo or Khartoum, but a women's liberation movement is gaining a quiet hold on Arab nations.

title: Local
description: Brooklyn Tech took over sole ossession of first place in the gblic Schools Athletic League trooklyn Division I yesterday, efeating Madison, 166, at ladison. The losers dropped to a secondplace tie with afayette.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONDuring the first six months of this year, at least three million serious crimesmurder, rape, robbery, burglary, assault and thefts of more than $50were committed in the United States, according to police reports gathered by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. That unsettling statisticit indicates a doubling of crime in just seven yearswas the basis last week of an angry political dialogue. For the country now faces a relatively new phenomenon, the politics of crime, which seems to be serving more to confuse than to illuminate a troubling social problem.

title: British Shun Iceland Ships
description: HULL, England, Oct. 21 (AP) The Transport and General Workers Union declared a boycott today of all Icelandic ships and cargo, including fish, at British ports. The move was described as a reprisal for damage to the trawler Aldershot by an Icelandic gunboat within Iceland's disputed 50mile fishing limit.

title: Michael Hartmere Weds Anne Mulligan
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Oct'21Miss Anne O'Boyle Mulligan and Michael Hartmere were married here this afternoon at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church. Msgr. Philip Murphy, Episcopal Vicar of the Archdiocese of New York for Orange County, performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass. He also performed the ceremony when the bride's parents were married in Maybrook 27 years ago yesterday.

title: Village Board Approves Plan To Turn Pier Into Arts Center
description: A proposal to turn an unused city pier into a permanent, floating art festival for promising young artists was conditionally approved last week by the Greenwich Village planning board.

title: Political Sabotage
description: WASHINGTON  The Watergate saga rolls on, malodorous, noisy, kaleidoscopic, baffling. The latest thickening of the plot offers new characters from the White House and from utter obscurity, skullduggery more sinister and more widespread, dialogue glittering with anger and tension.

title: Polish Films Addedto Menu
description: After more than a decade of serving up Polish specialties at their catering palace in Greenpoint, a fatherandson team has added a new dish to the menuPolish movies.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Other quarterbacks have their passes measured in yards. But with Johnny Unitas, it's miles. He has passed for nearly 23 miles in his career with the Baltimore Colts, a tribute to his eminence at the position. This season at age 39, he leads the National Football League with 85 completions. But as if Ile were an old car, suddenly he has too many miles. He's the Colts second car now, virtually discarded, not temporarily but for the remainder of the schedule, possibly for the rest of his career. At first he laughed it off, but the anger has surfaced. All the great quarterbacks are egotists. They have to be. In his quiet way, Johnny Unitas always has been as sure of himself as Joe Namath is. Four years ago, for example, Earl Morrell was leading the Colts to the N.F.L. title. Johnny Unitas had a sore arm. His ego was sore, too.

title: Congress Votes a or Sewage Savings for Homeowners in Nassau and Suffolk
description: Action in Washington this week will allow Sewers to he built in Nassau and Suffolk Counties sooner and at considerably less cost to the taxpayers than lout officials anticipated.

title: CITY WILL SUE U. S. ON HOUSING FUNDS
description: New York City's Housing Authority is preparing a suit against the Federal Government for refusing to provide any more than $21,287,325 in subsidies against this calendar year's $30,684,500 deficit in its Federally aided projects.

title: Mrs. Iglehart Wed To Verner Z. Reed
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Oct. 21Mrs. Elizabeth E. Iglehart, formerly of Old Westbury, L.I., was married here this afternoon to Verner Z. Reed, a widower of Palm Beach and Stowe, Vt. The Rev. Fenton Moorehead, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home.

title: Counselor Comforts Patients In Bergen
description: HACKENSACK Vivienne Meffen, in street dress and an official name tag, walks the corridors of Hackensack Hospital these days, bringing comfort to patients and their families.

title: Local
description: BROOKVILLE, LI, Oct. 21Dennis Battagliano scored three touchdowns and gained 109 yards in 17 carries as Xavier ripped Long Island Lutheran today, 3314, to raise its record in the Metropolitan Football League to 30

title: Premier Says That Hanoi Would Accept CeaseFire
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam, in an interview made public today, Said that his Government was now ready to accept a ceasefire as the first step in a settlement of the Vietnam war.

title: The junk mail boom
description: A pretty new 8cent stamp was issued a few weeks ago, showing a customer receiving a package at the postoffice counter of an oldfashioned general store, under the legend 100th Anniversary of Mail Order. The Postal Service says it is honoring a business that Ihas contributed to the nation's standard of living, economic and cultural heritage; gave rural America a reliable source of goods. Its critics claim that mail order is hardly a shining example of reliability and that it has more than its share of crooked operators: The New York City post office gets some 3,000 mailorder complaints every month. But the direct mailers believe they deserve some credit. The past several years have seen booming development of their art, due in large part to the computer, which now not only keeps track of the names, addresses and statistics that identify customers, but writes the personalized copy that mailers believe adds extra dash to letter.

title: Guild Strike Halts Printing Of Cleveland Plain Dealer
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 21 (AP) The Cleveland Plain Dealer, struck by its newsmen, delivered only its women's section, comics, magazine section and advertising supplements as a Sunday paper, a spokesman far the newspaper said today.

title: By AUDREY SHAVICK
description: SUMMITThe phone jangles shortly after 7:30 A.M. each day at the Chateau Gourmet Food Market here. Most likely, it is a Short Hills dowager ordering her day's groceries and prime meats to be delivered.

title: AUBURN WINS, 2414, FROM GEORGIA TECH
description: AUBURN, Ala., Oct. 21 (AP)Randy Walls, who wasn't supposed to be much of A passer, went to the air today and led Auburn to a 2414 football victory over Georgia Tech, whose own passing wizard, Eddie McAsshan, found himself botled up by an Auburn defense, which also wasn't supposed to exist.

title: Judith Johnson Wed in Pittsburgh
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 21Miss Judith Jane Johnson and John Cunningham Oliver 3d were married here this afternoon by the Rev. Robert Cleveland Holland and the Right Rev. Austin Pardue at Shadyside Presbyterian Church.

title: Arehitecture
description: IN this country it is par for the course to win the battle and lose the war. There is no longer any question about the force or progress of preservation; in spite of continuing, loudlymourned losses, the United States is well on its way to saving something resembling a heritage, in tragically incomplete, but genuine triumph. It is a ceaselessly waged battle, with each awful defeat generating a newly knowledgeable and watchful citizens' group. These groups are legion and their results impressive, even measured against the failures.

description: HISTORY and geography were my worst subjects: I had trouble with dates, couldn't care less about capital cities, and the industrial use of waste products was of little concern to me, Certain phrases remained with me, though: Abraham Lincoln freed the slaves  Chicago/hogbutcher to the world  America is a melting pot.

title: Laugher Brings a Cure For Sparky's Indigestion

But fears reached panic levels last week as the authorities announced the existence of a black terrorist gang called De Mau Mau. Its goal, they said: The random killing of whites.

title: Letters to the Editor

title: Childress Hurt in Crash
description: ROCKINGHAM, N.C., Oct, 21 (AP)Richard Childress, a 31WinstonSalem, wrecked his yearold rookie driver from stock race car today at North Carolina Motor Speedway and was hospitalized at nearby Hamlet with injuries not believed serious

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: John Leonard's Last Word column of Oct. 8 on the Ford Foundation's grant to Encounter concludes with an unjustified implication which requires a reply. He asks why, of all the magazines in the world, only Enbounter should get a grant from us, and he concludes that people cannot be blamed for thinking there is something political about this exception. But he has his facts wrong. Encounter is by no means the only journal which has recently had Ford Foundation help, and neither our grants to magazines nor our grants to literary individuals are governed by a political means test.

description: NORTH SALEM, N.Y., Oct. 21  Mike Patrick piloted Wright's Island Farms Funny Girl to the junior jumper championship today with 10 points at The Hill horse show.

I was very disappointed to read that my father has changed his viewpoint from a dislike for Mr. Nixon to strong support.

title: The sorrow of some central hollowness
description: There is a character in Gogol's Dead Souls called Plyushkin, all of whose life energy goes into accumulating and hoarding things, down to the smallest pieces of sealing wax, scraps of paper and feathers. With a brilliantly appropriate metaphor, Gogol tells us that in the end he himself became a kind of gaping hole in humankind. The crucial human emotions have been crowded out by the amassed litter of his life. There is something about a lot of John Updike's characters that reminds me of the terrible inner hollowness of that man emotionally deadened by his submission to things. Not that Updike presents us with an American suburbia tenanted by untidy misers (though some of his characters are deep in clutter). On the contrary, he is astute enough to detect that a distaste for litter is one of the fostering emotions in much American suburban life. I am referring to the feeling I have of reading about people in whom the capacity for a key emotional response or experience has been omitted or eradicated, leaving a small central void that diminishes or undermines the authenticity of their other emotional experiences.

title: LETTERS
description: A recent article entitled Michelin Fights Back (Oct. 8) may have left an erroneous impression in the minds of those readers who are not familiar with the processing of complaints under the countervailing duty provision of American trade law.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: So many wild surmises and inane historical facto are contained in There Was a Real Count Dracula by Seth S. Goldschlager (Travel section, Aug. 27) that the record ought to be put straight. The two history professors quoted in the article [Raymond T. McNally and Radu Florescu of Boston College] should have pointed out that Vlad Dracula the Impaler was never linked in Transylvania to the Devil or associated with vampirism. Although Dracula is a homonym of the Rumanian word for devil, Dracula derived his name from the Military Order of the Dragon awarded to his father, Vlad III, by the Holy Roman Emperor for his defense of Christendom. This dragon had no connection with demonic forces. Neither in Transylvanian nor in Rumanian folklore were the Devil and vampire stories ever mixed up with the lore engendered by the cruelties of Vlad Dracula.

title: America on a Day: the Private World of a Compulsive Hobo
description: Gone, or almost gone, is the caricature of the classic hobo: unshaven face, ragged clothes, funny hat, stuffed kerchief on a stick across the shoulder, eating beans from a makeshift stove by the railroad tracks, sleeping in boxcars. That character belongs to the Depression, but a few oldstyle hoboes, or reasonable facsimiles, still exist. One of the most articulate of them, a solid, grayhaired man with a twotiered moustache, Steamtrain Maury Graham, stayed put long enough recently to describe the world of the hobo and his philosophy.

title: Express yourself!
description: The news in decorating today is that there is no news. People are pleasing themselves, says designer David Whitcomb. No longer do they simply follow the latest trend. And that's good. There's more freedom and individuality in home decoration now than we've seen before. Whitcomb's own Manhattan townhouse expresses his particular styleunstudied elegance. It took him seven years to put it all together, picking up items that he liked here and there as he chanced upon themand never worrying about conflicting styles or periods. Nevertheless, the whole look hangs together. The secret is two part. First, the designer's dramatic sense of scale. For an example, just glance at the huge baroque console in front of the living room window (bottom of facing page). And second, his sense of color. The whole house has an unusually fresh color palette. The living room, for instance, combines Chinese yellow draperies with a softer yellow carpet, rose sofa and walls lacquered in wine plaid. The room does not vibrate with intense color as one might suspect since most of the hues are diluted with white for a surprisingly subdued and elegant effect.

title: Battle of the Breakfast Table
description: Any mother with one or more of the gimme group at home can attest to the power of drycereal advertising. But it's getting harder to understand just what the kids are yelling gimme for.

description: Many prominent shade and flowering trees showed signs of troubles this year. This report from Dr. Edward J. Duda of the Bartlett Arboretum, Stamford, Conn., explains the situation with dogwoods and horsechestnut.

title: Ohio State Routs Indiana for 5th in Row, 447
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 21 (AP)Harold Henson and Greg Hare scored two touchdowns each as fourthranked Ohio State routed Indiana, 447, in a Big Ten football game today. Indiana lost its quarterback, Ted McNulty, the Big Ten passing leader, with a leg injury early in the first half.

title: Art
description: THE exhibition of paintings by Georges Braque which Douglas Cooper has organized at the Art Institute of Chicago Is subtitled The Great Years, and the subtitle is evidently intended to be something of a provocation. For most of us, as Mr. Cooper knows very well, tend to assume that Braque's great years belong to the period of classical Cubism  roughly, the years 19071914  when, In his celebrated collaboration with Picasso, he helped to create the central pictorial style of the 20th century. This, however, is very far from being Mr. Cooper's view of Braque's achievement. For him, Braque is the most consummate pure painter of the School of Paris, and the great years commence in 1918. The Chicago exhibition concentrates its attention on the later years when, despite Braque's increasing detachment from the artistic ferment that was still taking place in Paris, he remained, in Mr. Cooper's words, an artist of monumental stature.

title: Barcelona School, Closed Since Winter, Still Resists Madrid
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Oct 17 The bar association of this big industrial and maritime center may have recruiting problems if things continue to go on the way they have in the main law school here. The school closed on Feb. 18 after having held 18 days of classes, and when it will reopen no one knows.

title: Court Ruling Gives Queens Homeowners Hope of Relief From Sewer Levy
description: Because of a State Supreme Court decision on Staten Island, thousands of Queens homeowners have suddenly begun seeing hope of possibly getting out from under city hills of $200, $300 and $500 apiece for streets and sewers that they have long regarded as unjust.

title: Social Announcements
description: Roger and Gloria (nee Jackman), loyfully announce the birth of their son, Scott Arc on Oct. 6, 1972. Proud grandparents are Mr. and Mrs. Murray Jackman and Mrs. Cordel Armstrong, greatgrandmother, Mrs. Patricia Goldman.

title: The Newark Museum Blends Fine Arts and Sciences
description: NEWARK  Art and science, to many museumgoers, are natural enemies. Not so in Newark.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Trucks Remodeled By T. V. A. to Collect And Recycle Autos
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 21 The Tennessee Valley Authority has come up with an inexpensive means of collecting junk automobiles, and the method has drawn interest from municipalities in 34 states and has been copied by cities as large as Philadelphia.

title: Nassau North
description: Locust Valley had to score lot of points to overcome the five touchdown passes thrown by Bill Schilt of Carle Place yesterday and it did, turning in a 4642 decision that left the Valley on top of North Shore Division IV with a 4.0 record.

title: EssexHudson
description: Rich Allocco, Union County's leading scorer at the start of the day with 84 points, suffered a foot injury on the second play of the game yesterday.

title: Campaign Humor
description: Campaign Humor

title: Preps
description: EAST PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 21Bill Ohlsen threw a thirdperiod scoring pass to Bill Counihan and then connected with Jeff Buxton on the conversion to give Providence County Day School the lead as it scored a 2820 victory over Moses Brown.

title: The collaboration of two men and a plant
description: Anthropology is, for many of its American practitioners and amateurs, a way of trying to get out of our particular culture, or at least a way of finding out whether other ways of lite are possible and, if so, perhaps better than our own. Yet despite the impetus of such curiosity, the bulk of the writing actually published in this field only tends to confirm what we think we already know about the nature of man, society, the human condition. For when we study other cultures this way, we assume in advance that understanding means explanation in terms with which we are already familiar from our own experience and knowledge of what the world is like. To put it another way, anthropological understanding is a way of making the world feel safer, a way of extending the edge of order so that we can comfortably say that people are fundamentally the same everywhere and that cultural differences are merely something like different mental images of the same basic reality.

title: ALABAMA RALLY TOPS TENNESSEE
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 21 (AP)  Thirdranked Alabama scored two touchdowns within a 36second span of the final two minutes today, the last on a 22yard run by Terry Davis, and defeated 10thranked Tennessee, 17.10, in a Southeast Conference football game.

title: Education
description: Tell us how to get a lot better education for a lot less money.

title: Montclair Harriers Win
description: Montclair State won its secondstraight New Jersey State College Conference crosscountry championship at Van Curtlandt Park yesterday by downing Jersey City State on a forfeit. In dual meet, the Indians downed City College of New York, 15 to 46, as Tim O'Donoghue of Montclair was times in 25 minutes 40 seconds.

title: Mrs. Holly Hein Married Here
description: Mrs. Holly Clark Hein, daughter of Mrs. Frederick Clark Hein of New York and Paris, and Stephen M. Gordon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton A. Gordon of New York and Vineyard Haven, Mass., were married here last evening by Rabbi Martin Zion of Temple Israel at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: The World
description: WINNIPEGA little knot of people clustered around a silvery campaign bus in a windswept farm community west of here one day not long ago, listening to Robert L. Stanfield, the ProgressiveConservative party leader who wants to be Prime Minister of Canada.

title: SHOP TALK
description: ANDOVERThe Frogm o re Country Store and Cottage Restaurant here on Route 206 North are welcome sights along the road to a Sussex County campground. The motorist can drop in for coffee, penny candy or a $300 dress.

title: LAWYERS GROUPS FEUD OVER LISTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21A New York City lawyers group working for the reelection of President Nixon has used the addressprinting plates of a nonpartisan lawyers association to send out invitations for a luncheon speech by an Administration official.

title: Medicine
description: WASHINGTONA New York City salesman named Shep Glazer who walked into a hearing of the House Ways and Means Committee a year ago has precipitated a chain of events that may bring financial relief to millions of Americans suffering from incurable diseases and illnesses.

title: In Queens, View Down From Top Can Be Nice
description: Well, I finally did it I visited Kennedy House, the tallest building in Queens. It only took me six years to do it and that is how old it is.

title: 'SickOut Disrupts L. I. R. R.; Line Hopeful It Will Not Last
description: A sickout by Long Island Rail Road trainmen produced some disruption of service yesterday, but railroad officials expressed the hope that full service would be in effect tomorrow.

title: The World
description: A prosperous physician in West Germany received a telegram last week from his mother in East Germany saying his elderly father was mortally ill. Come, she cabled, before it is too late.

title: TESTIMONY HEARD ON BIAS CHARGES
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 21 The Superintendent of the Bridgeport Police Department, Joseph A. Walsh, testified yesterday that his men would never accept a black promoted to sergeant solely to increase minority representation in the department, no matter how good he was,

title: Parr Directs Colgate to 3526 Victory Over Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 21Princeton's football team had its first view of the wishbone offense this afternoon in losing to Colgate; 35.26, then wished the visiting Red Raiders did not have Tom Parr in their lineup.

title: Ukraine Church Doubles Holding
description: FRANKLIN TOWNSHIPSt. Andrew's Memorial Church here, a Byzantine structure built as the national headquarters for the Ukrainian Orthodox Church, has doubled its holdings in this Somerset County community.

title: Mrs. Taylor Lewis Is Bride of W. B. Hall
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 21Mrs. Taylor Bartholow Lewis of Ithaca, N.Y., and Royston, Vt., widow of Taylor Downer Lewis, a professor of civil engineering at Cornell University, was married here this afternoon to William Blakeslee Hall of Woodbridge, Conn.

title: Appeals Court Needed, Say Law Groups
description: MINEOLA, L.I.The Bar Associations of Nassau and Suffolk Counties took issue this week with the state's five highestranking judges in their stand against the creation of a Fifth judicial department to serve the 2.5million residents of Long Island.

title: DUDE An $800,000 Disaster
description: RIGHT after the opening night performance Dudewhich may go down in theatrical history as Broadway's most monumental disasterits author, Gerome Ragni, huddled in a taxi clutching his 7yearold son, Eric, to his bosom.

title: Pace Downs F.D.U., 2415
description: TEANECK, N. J., Oct. 21Pace College won its first football game of the season, 2415, by scoring 21 points in the second period and defeating Fairleigh Dickinson University tonight. The loss was the third in four games for F.D.U.

title: ALLENDE IS SEEN SURVIVING CRISIS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21Administration circles expect the Marxist Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens to ride out the current wave of strikes now spreading in Chile.

title: Local
description: Far Rockaway's undefeated and untied team, after a lethargic thre quarters, cut loose with 24 points in the final period to overwhelm Flushing, 388, yesterday in a Queens Public Schools Atheltic League game at Memorial Field, Flushing.

title: IN THE NATION
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 20Here is at least one reason why George McGovern's ward and precinct organizers in Chicago believe he has a fighting chance to carry that city and with it the crucial state of Illinois:

title: A guide to a sane divorce
description: Norman Sheresky and Marya Mannes begin their book Uncoupling, billed as a guide to sane divorce, with several chapters on marriage, suggesting at once that many of the ills of divorce grow directly out of the defects of the union it dissolves. If you are married, the authors tell us, it is already too late. Getting into the institution of marriage is a cinchwe need neither show familiarity with the laws governing the relationship nor with our partners expectations of it. But it's only when we get out, a far more costly and demanding process, that we find out what our marriages were about.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In all the pious editorials in The Times on Vietnam, a number of important issues remain unmentioned:

title: TOPRANKED U.S.C. EASY 347 WINNER
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 21 (AP) Anthony Davis and Sam Cunningham ran for two touchdowns apiece today as topranked Southern California defeated Washington, 347, in a Pacific8 conference game.

title: Nixon Vows to Back Individualist Values In a Second Term
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21President Nixon set forth today his vision of the moral values that animate the nation and pledged to champion those values in a second term.

title: G. O. P. Expects Landslide on L.I.
description: MINEOLA, L.I.In Long Island's rockribbed Republican counties of Nassau and Suffolk there appears to be a friendly rivalry developing as to which county will provide President Nixon with a larger plurality and at the same time decimate the Democrats of both counties.

title: A Day at the Racoes for Essex
description: FAR HILLS  The 52d annual Essex Fox Hunt Race Meeting, which last year attractd 15,000 people to watch some of the top steeplechase horses and riders in the East, will be held next Saturday at the Moorland Farms estate of Mr. and Mrs. William B. K. Bassett.

title: Preps
description: EXETER, N.H., Oct. 21Exeter spotted Deerfield a firstperiod field goal and then went on to a 279 victory, its seventh straight, fourth this season. Deerfield is the last school to defeat Exeter.

title: ROCKLAND AGREES ON CROSSING GATE
description: CONGERS, N. Y., Oct. 21Town officials said yesterday that they had reached agreement with the Penn Central to provide automatic gates at the railroad crossing here where an 83car freight train rammed crowded school bus last March, killing five Nyack High School students and injuring 45 others.

title: Reports of Harsh Treatment of Arabs in West Since Munich Killings Are Producing Deep Resentments
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 21 Reports of harsh treatment of Arab residents and visitors in Europe and the United States since the killings at the Munich Olympic Games are producing deep resentment in the Arab world.

title: McGovern Welfare Ideas Assailed by H.E.W. Chief
description: BOSTON, Oct. 21 (AP)The first of Senator George McGovern's welfare programs would put more than half the nation's population on welfare, and revised version would make more than 37 per cent eligible, Elliot L. Richardson, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare charged today.

title: KENNEDY CRITICIZES CYNICAL STRATEGY
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy accused the Nixon Administration last night of pursuing a cynical strategy of dividing the country in order to disguise its poor performance on virtually every issue that matters deeply to the people.

title: SCHOOL FOOTBALL
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 21Mark Fitzgerald, a quarterback, led a powerful TrinityPawling air game as his school routed Kingswood, 3414. Fitzgerald scored once and passed for two more touchdowns. Trinity Pawling is 22 and Kingswood 32.

title: Local
description: Lafayette received the openng kickoff and marched for.

title: KOREAS CONTINUE POLITICAL TALKS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 21 South Korea and North Korea will hold further political discussions next month toward negotiating a peaceful reunification of this divided land.

title: Oregon Upsets Stanford
description: EUGENE, Ore, Oct. 21 (AP) Hugh Woodward, a substitute kicker, booted three field goals today and Don Reynolds broke loose on an 85yard touchdown run as Oregon upset 13thranked Stanford, 1513.

title: Mary Schwartz Is Bride
description: RYE, N.Y., Oct. 21In the chapel of the Rye Presbyterian Church this afternoon, Miss Mary Virginia Schwartz was married to Luther Garfield Breeden Jr. by the Rev. Joseph E. Bishop. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Lawrence Deen Schwartz and the late Mr. Schwartz. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. A. F. Cooper of Fredericksburg, Va., and the late Mr. Breeden. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: It Le is Down Its Hair Pedigree
description: DUDE might have been waved away as just another failed musical if it hadn't been for two things: its pedigree and its challenge. We were entirely aware of both as we sat  in the foothills, in the mountains, in the valleys, among the trees  watching it on opening night. The pedigree? Dude was by the authors of Hair, that watershed rock festival that changed the minds of the country about what it wanted to look at and listen to. The challenge? The producers and authors of Dude made it plain by word and woodwind, by hammer and chisel, that they were out to restructure the contemporary theater in every conceivable way.

title: Criminals At Large
description: James McClure's first novel THE STEAM PIG (Harper & Row, $5.95) arrives like a slam in the kidneys. The locale is South Africa, the country of apartheid, the country where white cop and a black subordinate can work together on case, and can even trade friendly insults. But so far can they go and no further.

title: State Gets Parents To Aid Road Safety
description: WOODBRIDGE  An intensive program of education to guard against pedestrian accidents on the Garden State Parkway gained momentum last week when the New Jersey State Congress of Parents and Teachers joined the state police in publicizing safety measures.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PONTSAINTEMAXENCE, FranceThe Vietnamese peace negotiations have now reached a crucial point and the immediate snag is in Saigon. One is reminded that both South and North Vietnam are fully aware that politics is a very important aspect of policymaking in the United States. This is excruciatingly true in the weeks before a Presidential election.

title: IOWA STATE GAINS 55 TO 22 VICTORY
description: AMES, Iowa, Oct. 21 (AP)Mike Strachan and George Amunson each accounted for three touchdowns today to lift 20thranked Iowa State to a 5522 Big Eighth Conference football victory over Kansas State.

title: Business
description: Not since the 1911 breakup of the Standard Oil Company had there been so significant a move in the antitrust field. That was the considered opinion of many authorities last week as the Justice Department called for the division of the International Business Machine Corporation into several discrete, separate, independent and competitively balanced entities.

title: Diana L. Moore Becomes Bride Of an Architect
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 21 In St. James Episcopal Church here this afternoon Miss Diana Lindsay Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Moore of Upper Montclair, was married to Paul Eric Newman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul August Newman of Jenkintown, Pa.

title: The screws are on the welfare system Down and out in New York
description: The agency that dispenses welfare in New York City is called, somewhat pretentiously, the Department of Social Services, and that at least conjures up visions less depressing than the reality of the plain old relief line that clutters up the sidewalk on 14th Street every weekday morning. Sometimes it isn't long past dawn when the clients begin queuing up outside the locked doors of the Waverly and Gramercy welfare centers in an office building on the south side of the street, near Fifth Avenue. Waiting are mothers with little children in hand, old people in their 70's, 20yearold narcotics addicts with that washedout look on their faces. They try to get there early because the word is out that unless you have a spot up front you're likely to get turned away, or spend the better part of the day getting your problems taken care of.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The northwest wind was hitter. Worked by the waves, the grinding rocks and pebbles rattled and moaned on the beach, and behind me, often hidden by racing clouds, half a moon hung in the sky above the dark cliffs.

title: Oysters Surface in L.I. Festival
description: GREENPORT, L.I.Eat it with a fork? Squirt it with lemon juice? Smother it with sauce?

title: Nader Profiles Give Data For Evaluating Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 Ralph Nader made public detailed profiles of 92 Senators and 392 Representatives today in what he said was an effort to help voters judge Congress more knowledgeably and perhaps open their eyes to a need for reform.

title: Despite Wide Support, Backers of Environmental Bond Issue Are Worried
description: State environmental officials are counting heavily on the passage of Proposition 1, the $1.15billion Environmental Quality Bond Act of 1972, but they are afraid that most voters don't even know about it.

title: Anita Catoggio Bride Of John B. Trainor jr.
description: Miss Anita Rose Catoggio, daughter of Vincent A. Catoggio, United States Magistrate for the Eastern District of New York in Brooklyn, and Mrs. Catoggio of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married yesterday morning to John Bernard Trainor Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Trainor of City Island, the Bronx. The Rev. Peter Quinn performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the Immaculate Conception Monastery Church in Jamaica Estates.

title: Mrs. Kirsh Has Child
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kirsh on Oct. 5 at the University Hospital. The child has been named Marjorie Ellen. Mrs. Kirsh is the former Miss Felice Sara Rinder of Baltimore.

title: CLUB URGES CITY TO ASSIST H. I. P.
description: The City Club of New York is asking the city to use its money or its influence to see that the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York gets up to $20million in grants or loans to strengthen and revitalize itself.

title: NEW SOVIET IDEAS ON SCHOOLS AIRED
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 21I don't mind helping my little Sasha with his Russian homework, a young Moscow mother said the other day, but the new math Is really beyond me. And now the teachers have started calling in the parents to practice solving homework problems together.

title: SCHOOL FOOTBALL
description: EAST PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 21  East Paterson upset Monsignor Farrell, 210, today to end the Staten Island team's 33game unbeaten streak and 22game winning string. East Paterson, now with a 31 wonlost record, got two scoring passes from Tim Brock and two touchdowns from Doug Valentine.

title: Child to the Beckers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. William Watters Becker on Oct. 4 at the George Washington University Hospital. The child has been named Gevry. Her mother is the former Miss Carol Gevry Palmer of Providence, R.I. Her father is a partner in the Washington law firm of Becker, Cohen, Feldman & Becker.

title: Preps
description: WATERTOWN, Conn., Oct. 21Taft won its first game of the season, 36.14, from Williston. Mike Stone, the Taft quarterback, ran for three touchdowns and one conversion, and passed for another 2 points. Taft is 13, Williston 04.

title: God rest ye, gentle merriment!
description: The line of humorous writers in America is a long and proud one. It begins in the period of the Civil War, with the primitive faux naifs: Bill Arp, Josh Billings and Bill Nye. Mark Twain was next, standing alone and overshadowing his contemporaries. Then, as the century turned, came Kin Hubbard (Miss Eloise Moots has resigned from the Monarch 5 & 10 and'll give all her time to her hair), Finley Peter Dunne, George Ade (Whom are you? he said, for he had been to night school), Ellis Parker Butler and Irvin S. Cobb. Don Marquis was a bridge to the postWorld War I groupthe New Yorker group, to give it a convenient nameled by Ring Lardner. ( Shut upl, he explained.) Was anyone ever as wildly funny as Lardner? No, no oneexcept his compeers: James Thurber, Corey Ford (They ate their lunch with Gusto, who barked and wagged his tail happily), Franklin P. Adams, Ogden Nash and Robert Benchley (My grandfather, Private Benchley, formerly Corporal Benchley ). All these dear, delightful men are dead nowrest their merry souls!

title: Art
description: COMING out of the Museum of Modem Art's beautiful new exhibition, African Textiles and Decorative Arts, this reporter was aware of an unfamiliar sense of wellbeing that, upon analysis, turned out to have been induced only indirectly by the excellence of that show. It had to do, rather, with the response to the show as a symptom of a welcome change that has become perceptible In the critic's function as part of that nowheresomewhere everywhere jumble of commercialism, sacrifice, talent, patronage, prostitution and talktalktalk called the art world.

title: NIXON URGED TO GIVE, SAN CLEMENTE DATA
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 21 (AP)  Lawrence F. O'Brien, the Democratic national chairman, urged President Nixon today, to disclose the financial arrangements by which he obtained the Western White House.

title: Coins
description: PUBLIC interest in monies and medals of the world was reflected by the large attendance at the 10th annual convention of the Great Eastern Numismatic Association in the Americana Hotel. Many of the registered visitors at the recent fourday event were noncollectors, looking in on a coin show for the first time.

title: Passaic Coalition Is Guarding The River Valley Resources
description: BASKING RIDGEGrowing from an idea, nine people, and a bare light bulb in 1969, the Passaic Coalition is now the established watershed association for the entire Passaic River Valley.

title: U.S. Ship Hit, Hanoi Says
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 21 (Agence FrancePresse)  Shore batteries hit a United States warship and set it ablaze off Vinhlinh yesterday, the North Vietnamese press agency said today.

title: Sheldon Gerry Bride of Paul Withers
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Oct. 21Miss Sheldon Gerry, whose ancestor, Elbridge Gerry, was a signer of the Declaration of Independence and Vice President under James Madison, was married here this afternoon to Paul Morris Withers of Empshott, England, who represents his country in international polo matches.

title: Staten Island Newspaper Backs Nixon's Reelection
description: The Staten Island AdvanceI endorses the reelection of President Nixon in an editorial today, the Associated Press reported. The paper says a certain indecisiveness on the part of Senator George McGovern has raised legitimate doubts about his qualifications for the Presidency.

title: Television
description: CALL it The Bloodshot Private Eye Caper: The sun had just dropped into the Hudson like a cherry tomato bombing a bowl of dirty lettuce. On Sixth Avenue, the windows of the chrome and glass hotel broke the lights inside into a thousand little bolts of lightning as I shoved my way through the expense accounts bunched around the entrance. I knew the real storm was upstairs, where a bunch of usSpade, Marlowe, Archer, me and few more of the real brassplated McCoyswere meeting to give the new TV detectives the onceover.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: WESTERN oil companies will get $1billion for a 25 per cent interest in their operations in five Persian Gulf states on completion of agreement. Petroleum Association of the United States asked President Nixon to lift curb on oil prices as a way to increase production and reserves . A consortium headed by International Systems and Control Corporation of Houston signed a $700million deal with National Iranian Gas Company.

title: The Nation
description: SAIGONThe first indication that something big was up came early last week with the announcement that Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, the new Army Chief of Staff, was coming to Saigon. The general was friendly with President Thieu when he was American commander in Vietnam, and the knowledge that White House adviser Henry A. Kissinger had spent four days in Paris the previous week talking with the North Vietnamese about matters affecting Mr. Thieu's future invited speculation that General Abrams had something for the South Vietnamese leader's ears.

title: As if Nabokov had reported on Bobby and Boris
description: The Chess Match of the Century is over. Bobby Fischer's chair and Boris Spassky's pride have been pulled to pieces and reassembled. But what if The Times, say, had presumed upon Vladimir Nabokov's wellknown passion for chess and had managed to persuade our most illustrious novelist to travel to Reykjavik to cover the match? And what if Nabokov had then given us a book, not only analyzing chess strategies, but dissecting with all the tender mercy of his art the two players themselves, together with their families, friends, managers, judges, lesser chess masters and lesser reporters, while everywhere viewing the event as a scene in the play of art and history?

title: Kunstler Joins the Defense In Virgin Islands Murders
description: CHRISTIANSTED, St. Croix, V. I., Oct. 21 (AP)William M. Kunstler and another lawyer, Margaret Ratner of New York, were permitted yesterday to defend two of the men charged with murdering eight Americans at the Fountain Valley Club last months.

title: PATROLMAN SHOOTS RIDER WITH A GUN
description: A 50yearold passenger on a Brooklyn bus who was allegedly) menacing the driver with what later turned out to be a toy pistol was shot by a patrolman last night after the driver signaled for help by steering his bus into oncoming traffic.

title: Northeastern Flu Is Not Influenza
description: The first nip of winter in the Northeast has brought the first round of illnesses commonly referred to as the flu. However, these illnesses are almost certainty not the real fluknown medically as influenza and caused by one of several different strains of influenza viruses.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: The Defense Department, which has been accused of a lackluster record on vertical takeoff planes, has awarded North American Rockwell Corporation a $46million contract for construction of an unusual new design for the Navy.

title: Social Announcements
description: The family of Mr. and Mrs. Aron Lipman, formerly of Boro Park, now of Long Beach, L.I., Is Indeed proud to announce and offer congratulations to them on their seventieth wedding anniversary. May they remain In good health for many more years.

title: Stamps
description: THE American Bank Note Company, before the turn of the century a producer of United States stamps, until the Bureau of Engraving and Printing took over, and since then involved in occasional production contributions, is once again using its facilities in support of a United States stamp program  handsome American Commemorative Stamp Panels. The first of these is illustrated above. (The size is 81/2 x 11% inches.)

title: GROWING CARACAS PLANS A SUBWAY
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 13 This rapidly growing and congested city may soon he getting a subway system. A 30mile network costing 5800million is in the planning stage and the official responsible for it says he is hopeful that Government approval for the construction of the first five miles will come within the next three months.

title: Recordings
description: WHAT Georg Solti has been doing and continues to do for Wagner, what Raymond Leppard has accomplished for Baroque opera, and what Leonard Bernstein succeeded at this season with the Met's Carmen, Claudio Abbado seems to be in the act of performing with Rossini. That is, he has been realizing to the fullest the vitality, both theatrical and musical, of some very great and too often takenforgranted operatic masterpieces.

title: A theater in search of revolution
description: The public image of The Living Theatre is such that one would expect the diary of its cofounder, Judith Malina, to be a scandalous affair. Perhaps the public's image of the company was best expressed by the captain of the Aurelia, on which the theater group traveled from Europe to New York in 1968. The captain, worried about the possibly damaging effect of The Living Theatre on the morals of the younger passengers, spoke privately with Julian Beck, Mrs. Malina's husband, as follows: 1 have heard stories about you, that you couple anywhere and any time, in the corners of the dining room or in the corridors. Julian Beck replied, We talk of such things but we are really an inhibited company.

title: The Guest Word
description: Grateful to Norman Mailer? A rum sensation these days. But in St. George and the Godfather, reviewed last week by Garry Wills, Mailer writes with a huge fresh hatred of the warwhen many who feel the same are too tired to find new words for it. The book includes a few spurts of compulsory womanhating, and I can't go along with Mailer on the wad (midAmerica): he really seems to despise them for their obtuseness. But we've seen the same blindness among far more worldly persons, who are also glad to hear that the war is over. Anger at the public is fair enough, but we have to keep studying how that public has been manipulated. Mailer does some of this, but we need even more. However, he's one of the few reporters who hasn't called the Republican convention boring as indeed it wasn't. In fact, it was an education for anyone who isn't voting for Nixon. And there were many lessons for students of recent historyespecially about the pliability of history.

title: Oil: Participation vs. Nationalization
description: BEIRUT, LebanonThere are today in the Arab Middle East and North African oil community two main schools of oil policy, one committed to the participation approach and the other to the nationalization approach.

title: The Bing yearsa witty, arrogant, forthright memoir
description: For 22 years Rudolf Bing ruled over the Metropolitan Opera, and it still survives. Let that be said for him. Like another Austrian autocrat, Metternich, the Metropolitan's retired general manager will be knownwants to be knownchiefly as a defender of the old regime, a conservative, a preserver. As documented his biography, written with the help of Martin Mayer, Sir Rudolf's main energies went into maintaining the status quo, into achieving balances of power among artists and bankers, and into strengthening his ruling hand. Like Metternich, who returned to Vienna after the 1848 revolt and was made a prince, the Metropolitan's leader survived wars and rebellions and retired with full honors. He was knighted by the Queen of England and left the stage as hero of a magnificent gala performance that he himself arranged as the Metropolitan's tribute to his career.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  As the Democraticcontrolled 92d Congress stumbled toward adjournment last week, it suddenly realized it might be caught in a political mousetrap sprung by President Nixon.

title: New &Novel
description: The full moon shines eerily on the New England town of Pembroke, activating an unusually large quota of creeps. Someone among the town's trigger  happy bullies, snoops, xenophobes and potential psychos suddenly begins committing sex murders. Pembroke's answer is characteristic: vigilantes! To the fear of being curiously sectioned by a mad killer is now added the possibility of being shot, harassed or merely annoyed by the forces of law and order.

title: Lee Owen, Investment Adviser, Weds Susan Elizabeth Opie
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Oct. 21The Central Presbyterian Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Susan Elizabeth Opie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alden Opie, to Lee Scott Owen, son of Everett Montague Owen and Mrs. Irtvin Norris Blake, both of Richmond. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert T. Kelsey.

title: Camera World NewsBooks and Courses
description: SEVERAL new publications that should prove of interest to photographers have recently been released:

title: Bold Statement Scores by a Length in Congressional on Muddy Laurel Track
description: LAUREL, Md., Oct. 21 (AP)Bold Statement, carrying the blackandwhitedotted silks of Frank E. Power, delighted the form players in a crowd of 13,300 at Laurel Racecourse today in winning the $29,500 Congressional Handicap after a hardfought stretch battle with Sugar Mill Farms Seminole Joe.

title: IN THE NATION
description: IN THE NATION

title: Alaska Quake Recorded
description: PALMER, Alaska, Oct. 21 (AP)A moderate earthquake centered about 140 miles northwest of Anchorage was reported today by the Palmer Observatory here. The quake was not of sufficient magnitude to generate a tidal wave, the observatory said. No injuries was reported.

title: HEART VICTIM HOME WITH HER NEW BABY
description: EVERETT, Mass., Oct. 21Mrs. Edward Devanna, who underwent heart surgery eight hours before giving birth to a healthy sixpound girl, has returned from Malden Hospital with her child.

title: UnionMiddlesex
description: Willie Wilson, junior halfback, who runs, receives and kicks, scored 23 points yesterday as unbeaten Summit rolled to 410 victory over Caldwell at Caldwell.

title: CANDIDATES AIDED BY 30,000 DONORS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 About 30,000 persons have made contributions of $100 or more to Presidential election campaigns so far this year, official figures disclosed today.

title: Music
description: A24, Kyung Wha Chung has her teenybopper good looks working for her, but the confidence she exudes is that of the innate performer. Even at 9, she knew what she was about. When, in her native Korea, a concert audience became too inattentive for her taste, she stopped playing her violin, stamped her foot and stalked off the stage. These days, she is of a less tempestuous nature. In fact, one of her dilemmas is that she feels she must tone down the showbiz aspects of making a career in order to concentrate on making music.

title: ANTIQUES
description: TRENTON  The William Trent House here is an extraordinary landmark locked into an inhospitable setting of asphalt highways and mortar and steel buildings.

title: PEKING ELEVATES 3 FROM MILITARY
description: HONG KONG, Oct, 21 The appointment of three new ministers with military backgrounds has been disclosed by Peking, increasing the ratio of military men to civilians in China's Government and underlining the continuing influence of the armed forces on civilian affairs.

title: Stony Brook 3530 Victor
description: Brian Flynn ran for two touchdowns and passed to Solomon Henley for another on a 69yard play as Stony Brook's club team defeated Brooklyn's club team, 3530, yesterday. Darrell Bowers, the Brooklyn quarterback, ran for two touchdowns and passed for a third.

title: Television
description: THE United Nations General Assembly has before a proposal challenging that principle which has been a tenet of our democracy, a basic article of faith, since its very beginningfreedom of speech. This challenge comes as the result of farreaching new technology that has opened a new era of human progress, the miracle of satellite broadcasting. The satellite television broadcasts we receive today come into our homes through networks and individual stations. Through such worldwide linkage, over 600 million people on six continents saw the moonwalk on televisiona significant reminder of the enormous potential of satellite transmission.

title: ENVOYS OF HANOI SAID TO FORESEE PEACE MOVE SOON
description: North Vietnamese diplomats in Peking told foreign envoys yesterday that a major development toward peace in Vietnam was possible in the next two or three days, according to a Reuters correspondent in the Chinese capital.

title: A pursuit of elusive values
description: Ezekiel Mphahlele is an exiled South African writer now living in this country whose last work, The Wanderers, was a moving novel about an exile on the African continent and the nature of that exile. Voices in the Whirlwind is a collection of essays that could have been subtitled, Toward a Black Esthetic, because five of the six pieces are concerned with this difficult problem of definition.

title: William and Mary Raises V.M.I. Losing String to 17
description: LEXINGTON, Va., Oct. 21 (AP)A sophomore quarterback, Bill Deer, threw for three touchdowns today and Doug Gerhart and Todd Bushnell rushed for more than 100 yards apiece as William and Mary trounced Virginia Military Institute, 313, in Southern Conference football action.

title: Preps
description: CONCORD, Mass., Oct. 21With Steve Werntz completing passes at will, Middlesex defeated St. Mark's, 278, today. The victory was the fourth in games for Middlesex. St. Mark's has a 22 record.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: There's a lot of life left In denim fashions. In fact, the demand for bluejean fabrics is so heavy as to appear almost insatiable. Textile mills may be having trouble selling other fabrics, but those making denims are in an oversold position.

title: Pilot in Crash, Fatal to 22 Is Criticized
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 21  The man who taught Richard Bingham how to fly the surplus fighter plane that crashed into a crowded ice cream parlor and killed 22 people here testified this week that Mr. Bingham should never have been allowed to fly it.

title: Frances Farrell Wed
description: SANDS POINT, L. I., Oct. 21Miss Frances F. Farrell, daughter of Mrs. William Farrell of Port Washington and the late Mr. Farrell, and Paul. Jurkowski, son of Mrs. Louis Haberman of Irvington, N.J., and the late Samuel Jurkowski, were married here this evening in the Community Synagogue by Rabbi Martin S. Rozenberg.

title: A Mayor's Daughter Seized in Killing
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 21 The 19yearold daughter of Mayor William S. Hart of East Orange was arrested early this morning and charged with homicide in the stabbing of another teenage girl.

title: Boston Gets Trolley Grant
description: BOSTON, Oct. 21Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe has announced a Federal grant of nearly $33million to help the city buy 150 new trolley cars. The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority must contribute $16.4million.

title: Hempstead Fighting Water Rates
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I. The Hempstead Town Board has asked the State Supreme Court in Albany to compel the New York State Public Service Commission to investigate possible mismanagement and the disparity of rates of three private water companies that serve 70 per cent of the town.

title: First, shoot your deer
description: Very soon now, on Sunday nights, cars will be spotted rolling across the George Washington Bridge, into the city, with a buck tied across the bumper. The trouble is that most hunters won't know what to do with their kill. And there are so many things to do. A British food historian, Jane Grigson, in her book Good Things (Knopf, $8.95) suggests a simple soup, an allpurpose roast and a wine sauce developed for Queen Victoria.

title: But Blacks Contend Issue of Racism is Overriding
description: School finally is scheduled to begin on Tuesday for 29 black children in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn who have been at the center of an integration controversy that has roots going back 10 years.

title: F.B.I. Asked to Study Florida Smear Letter
description: TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 21. United States Attorney John Briggs said in Jacksonville today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had been asked to investigate an anonymous letter smearing Senator Henry M: Jackson and Hubert H. Humphrey. The letter, written on stationery of Senator Edmund S. Muskie, was mailed to prospective voters just before the Presidential primary in Florida last March 14.

title: Miss Ogden Has Nuptials
description: ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 21 Miss L. Marquis Ogden was married in the Cochran Chapel at Phillips Academy here this afternoon to Stephen Edward Devereux, a graduate of the academy. The Rev. James R. Whyle, the chaplain, performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: Two Arab towns that plumb Israel's conscience
description: JERUSALEM: This is no time for the doves Israel. Their voices, at least for the time being, have been silenced by the horrible murders at the Munich Olympic games. The new turn in Arab terrorism preoccupies a shocked and disgusted public and focuses debate on more urgent and immediate issues.

title: Raiders Rally Behind Sheehan's 2 Goals to Beat Aeros, 32
description: The New York Raiders, showing a tenacious ability to come back, beat the Houston Aeros, 32, yesterday afternoon in a World Hockey Association game at Madison Square Garden.

title: Julilly Waller Kohler Is Bride Of Charles Joseph Hausmann
description: KOHLER, Wis., Oct. 21Miss Julilly Waller Kohler, daughter of Mrs. John Michael Kohler and the late Mr. Kohler, was married this morning in the drawing room at Riverbend, the Kohler home here, to Charles Joseph Hausmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore L. Hausmann of Brookfield.

title: KNUDSON, ON 201, LEADS BY 5 SHOTS
description: NAPA, Calif., Oct. 21 (AP)Arnold Palmer lost a twoshot lead with a 75 today and George Knudson moved into a fivestroke lead in the $150,000 Kaiser International open golf tournment.

title: Child to Mrs. Hayes
description: A daughter was born to Mr, and Mrs, M. Vinson Hayes of New York Sept. 29 in the New York Infirmary. Mrs. Hayes is the former Miss Bettine J. Brown of Newton Centre, Mass.

title: NETS SNAP SLUMP IN 113104 VICTORY
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 21 Jimmy Chones, the New York Nets milliondollar rookie, scored 26 points in his finest pro performance to date and led a 113104 victory over the Indiana Pacers tonight. It snapped a Nets threegam losing streak.

title: Reds Win, 81, Tie Series; Deciding Game Set Today
description: The Cincinnati Reds evened the World. Series at three games apiece yesterday by routing the Oakland A's, 81, before 52,737 at Riverfront Stadium in Cincinnati. The deciding game will be played in Cincinnati today.

title: Karen D. Garvin Wed
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 21 Miss Karen Dagna Garvin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel F. Garvin of Glen Rock, N.J., was married here at noon today to Charles Anderson Stanifer, son of Mrs. Cecil Stanifer of Richmond and the late Mr. Stanifer. The Rev. Donald R.
