description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 22Sheriff's deputies ended a planned 20mile Walkathon by 3,000 young people for the March of Dimes this afternoon when several score of the marchers became unruly in the suburban community of Minoa, five miles east of here.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22  A noteworthy sideeffect of the socalled Environmental Revolution has been the increasing currency of the expression  foxes guarding the hen house

title: Article 5  No Title
description: QUEBEC CITY, Oct. 22 (UPI) The Quebec Nordiques lost their first home game of the season tonight before 6,394 fans as the Ottawa Nationals held on to a onegoal lead established in the second period by Bob Charlebois to post a 32 victory in the World Hockey Association.

title: Break Up I. B. M. ?
description: Two of the most significant business events of this century occurred in 1911; one was a corporate death, the other a corporate birth. For 1911 was the year the Supreme Court broke up the Standard Oil Company. And it was also the year that the ComputerTabulatingRecording Company was organizeda company that in 1924 changed its name to the International Business Machines Corporation. Is I.B.M., now the dominant force in the domestic and world computer market, to go the way of. Standard Oil?

title: ZUKERMAN SOLOIST FOR MUSICA AETERNA
description: The Musica Aeterna concerts at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium directed by Frederic Waldman are always pleasurable and instructive. One of the finest small ensembles in town, the orchestra invariably programs works that one rarely hears played by larger groups as well as more familiar pieces that always sound better with reduced forces.

title: 2 Ponies Are Found Dead In a Philadelphia Stable
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 (AP) Two ponies were found dead today, apparently the victims of a rockthrowing rampage by neighborhood youths.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The presence of the Horizon Corp. of Tucson, Ariz., which proposes to build 10,000 vacation homes in the town of Colton, N. Y., has already been felt within the state fotest of the Adirondack Park.

title: 4 Hold Turkish Plane With 69 In Bulgaria, Threatening Blast
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 22 (Reuters)Four guerrillas are holding a hijacked Turkish airliner with 69 persons aboard at the airport at Sofia, the Bulgarian capital, the Bulgarian radio said today.

title: 4 Die in Mine Blast in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 22 (AP) A coalmine explosion and cavein early today killed at least four miners, and 35 others were believed trapped. Official reports said rescue workers had recovered four bodies from the mine near Damghan, 205 miles northeast of Teheran.

title: McGovern Center Attacked
description: NEW ROCHELLE, Oct. 22Vandals threw eggs and a thick black muddy substance at the storefront headquarters of the United McGovern Democratic Committee on Main Street here tonight, soiling McGovern signs and breaking a plateglass window, according to the police.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Stained glass Is George W. Sell's medium, functional sculpture his message. The results are an extraordinary collection of objects, which include boxes that resemble shells and a medicine cabinet shaped like a woman's torso.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: The lion that mauled the Israeli tourist at Jungle Habitat in West Milford two weeks ago has been quarantined but will not be destroyed, a spokesman for the drivethrough game preserve said yesterday.

title: Track Goes for Daylight
description: LINCOLN, R. I., Oct. 22 (AP)  Lincoln Downs will switch from night to afternoon racing starting tomorrow.

title: Wilds of Asphalt Jungle Explored by Sierra Club
description: Most Sierra Club outings are strenuous hikes in places with names like Great Swamp and Breakneck Ridge. On Saturday night, however, the conservation  minded group sponsored a sevenhour trek through the flashing lights and sleeping streets of Manhattan Island.

title: JAMES H. WORTH, 54; OF THE LUMINUS CORP:
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 22 James H. Worth, a chemical company executive, died today at the age of 54. He lived at 18 Wynnwood Road.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Johnny Farrell no longer wears a derby hat. But years ago when he was applying for a job as coprofessional with his brother, Jim, at Scarsdale's Quaker Ridge Golf Club, he did.

title: LAOTIAN PREMIER HOPEFUL OF PEACE
description: PARIS, Oct. 22 (Agence FrancePresse) the Laotian Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma, flew into Paris today on his way to the United States and said he was optimistic about the chances of peace in Laos and throughout Indochina.

title: Italian Chief to Visit Soviet
description: ROME, Oct. 22Premier Giulio Andreotti will leave this Tuesday for a weeklong official visit to the Soviet Union. He will be accompanied by Italy's foreign minister, Giuseppe Medici, and by the Governor of the Bank of Italy, Dr. Guido Carli.

title: William Gant
description: William Gant, a former editor with The New York Herald Tribune News Service, died yesterday in Palnia on the Spanish island of Majorca, where he had been living in retirement. He was 68 years old.

title: Gusman Dedicates Hall in Miami
description: MIAMI, Oct. 22One day in 1899, when this city was just a small finishing village, Maurice Gusman, a 14yearold boy from a Ukrainian shtetl, stood nervously before an immigration inspector on Ellis Island and was admitted to the United States.

title: Aerial Is Tipped Into an 83Yard Scoring Play
description: An overthrown pass by Joe Namath caromed off the hand of Charlie Stukes, a Baltimore cornerback, and into the arms of Ed Bell, who ran 35 yards to complete an 83yard touchdown play and give the New York Jets a 2420 victory over the Colts yesterday before a crowd of 62,948 in Shea Stadium.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Among the practitioners of arrogance these days is the doubleparker, creating unnecessary congestion on city streets. He increases the possibility of accidents, promotes an indulgence in profanity and steals time and money from other people. One taxi driver blames doubleparkers for making his meter read $3.50 for a run that ordinarily costs $1.90.

title: Infant Slain During a Party Celebrating His Christening
description: A sixweekold baby boy was found murdered in his bassinet late Saturday night while a party, attended by 30 relatives and friends, was being held in an adjacent room to celebrate the infant's christening a few hours earlier.

title: 125,206 at Games Here
description: The Giants beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 2721, before 62,258 fans at Yankee Stadium and the Jets downed the Baltimore Colts, 2420, before 62,948 at Shea Stadium yesterday. (Page 43.)

title: LAWMAKER DISPUTES CENSORSHIP PLANS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UPI) Representative William S. Moorhead, Democrat of Pennsylvania, said today that secret government contingency plans would allow President Nixon to impose national censorship during a limited war such as the Vietnam conflict.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: DOVER TOWNSHIP, Oct, 22  Ocean County residents will learn next month the route of a controversial 35mile New Jersey Turnpike spur linking this municipality with South Brunswick.

title: Canadiens Play Rangers To 11 Tie
description: The Rangers and Montreal Canadiens got what they deserved last night, a 1all tie.

title: CONFLICT CHARGED TO MRS. MEYNER
description: State Senator Joseph J. Maraziti, Republican candidate in New Jersey's 13th Congressional District charged yesterday that his Democratic opponent, Mrs. Helen Meyner, supported the proposed Tocks Island project because she had a financial interest in utility companies that would benefit from the project.

title: Sol Gelb, 73, Criminal Lawyer, ExJudge, Aide to Dewey, Did
description: Sol Gelb, a leading criminal lawyer who formerly served as a judge of the old General Sessions Court and as a Chief Assistant District Attorney, died of pleurisyyesterday in the New York Infirmary. He was 73 years old and lived at 165 East 72d Street.

title: Exiles Draw Up a List By FLORA LEWIS
description: PARIS, Oct. 22A group of nonCommunist exiles from South Vietnam met here tonight to agree on a list of men who might compose the neutralist third segment of a. Saigon coalition government.

title: ISRAEL OUSTS MAYOR AND COUNCIL OF GAZA
description: GAZA, Oct. 22 (AP)  Israeli military authorities in the occupied Gaza Strip dismissed Mayor Rashad Shawa and the Gaza municipal council today for refusal to carry out an Israeli order to incorporate the nearby Shati refugee camp into the municipality.

title: LAWRENCE B. SIZER OF MARSHALL FIELD
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (UPI) Lawrence B. Sizer, a former official of Field Enterprises, Inc., died today of a heart attack at Mercy Hospital, Benton Harbor, Mich. He was 70 years old.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION UP BY 4.2% IN WEEK
description: Steel production for the week ended Oct. 21 rose by 4.2 per cent to 2.7 million net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This compared with 2,591,000 tons a year earlier. The industry's production index lose to 110.7 from 106.2 a year earlier.

title: 150,000 Cheer Their Victorious A's at Parade in Oakland
description: The baseball season finally left the sporting scene yesterday in a parade of antique cars through downtown Oakland, while a crowd of 150,000 lined the curbs and cheered the mustachioed young men driving past.of rewards, which may reach $20,000 apiece from the World Series purse alone, about $6,000 more than the Reds. Also on the agenda: trades, contract disputes, criticism of night baseball in late October and other problems left by the long season, including these:

title: Hanoi Calls for Accord
description: PARIS, Oct. 23The North Vietnamese delegation to the Vietnam talks here suggested today that if a peace agreement did riot come to fruition soon, it could mean that President Nixon has been mounting an elabdrate electoral charade.

title: Stolen Car Leads to Death
description: LOWELL, Mass., Oct. 23 (UPI)Harry Brewer happened to look out his window at 2 A.M. yesterday and saw someone driving off with his car. Mr. Brewer, 58 years old, did not have a telephone so he ran to a corner phone booth to call the police. Before he could make the call, Mr. Brewer collapsed. He was pronounced dead of a heart attack at St. John's Hospital.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Henry Kissinger has come home from Saigon amid thick rumors that a ceasefire in Vietnam is near, to be followed by a political settlement of the war. This has prompted George McGovern to say that he, for one, weuld rejoice if the war could be ended, no matter the political impact.

title: Chesss: Huebner Attracts Notice With Play and Temperament
description: Robert Huebner, West Germany's newest grandmaster, won the gold medal for the top result in the Olympics in Yugoslavia. The 23 yearold philology student, playing board one for his team, had seven victories and six draws in the finals, narrowly surpassing his leading rivals, Czechoslavakia's Vlastimil Hort and Hungary's Lajos Portisch.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: A memorial fund to pay funeral expenses for Rick Sanders, 27yearold Olympic wrestler killed in a carbus crash in Yugoslavia last Wednesday, has been started by Portland State University. School officials said expenses were expected to run about $2,500. Funeral arrangements are pending the arrival of Sanders's body from Yugoslavia.

title: Fortunoff Planning To Expand Store In Westbury, L.I.
description: Fortunoff Fine Jewelry and Silverware, Inc., helme furnishings, jewelry and gifts retailer, will more than double its space in Westbury, L. I., to 440,000 square feet, making it the largest store of its kind in the metropolitan area and one of the country's biggest suburban stores. On Long Island, its size will be exceeded only by the 560,000squarefoot Abraham & Straus department store in Hempstead.

title: Dee Jays Inspect the Stars At Country Music Festival
description: NASHVILLE, Oct. 21Harold Hendren stood in the doorway of the Decca freeload room, shaking hands with assorted disk jockeys and songwriters, pickers and promoters.

title: Clinton Crushes Monroe, 400. to Tie for Lead
description: Clinton tied Evander Childs for the ManhattanBronx Public Schools Athletic League lead yesterday by routing Monroe, 400, at Clinton Field. It was the fourth league triumph for the Governors, whose only loss was in nomeague play.

title: UTEP Names Hudspeth Interim Football Coach
description: EL PASO, Oct. 23 (AP)The University of Texas  El Paso today appointed its offensive coordinator, Tommy Hudspeth, to take over as interim head football coach for the remainder of the season.

title: Bears Top Vikings On Percival's Kick In 4th Period, 1310
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP)After Minnesota drove 69 yards to the Chicago 5yard line, only to be pushed back by a penalty, the Vikings Fred Cox missed a 27yard field goal in the closing seconds and the Bears upset the Vikings, 1310, tonight.

title: OLD GLORY SALES ATTRACT SPORTS
description: YONKERS, Oct. 23Baseball's Gene Michael and Whitey Ford, golf's Lew (Buck) Worsham, hockey's Gilles Villemure and horsemen from as far away as Australia, California and Florida were among the overflow crowd of 2,500 at the second matinee of the Old Glory Horse Standardbred Sale at Yonkers Raceway today.

title: JOHN BIRCH GROUPS URGE U.S. QUIT U.N.
description: Today, Oct. 24, should be proclaimed U.N. Day of Shame, and the United States should withdraw from the United Nations, a fullpage advertisement sponsored by ad hoc committees of the John Birch Society urges in today's editions of The New York Times.

title: Scribner Agrees to Shift Black Pupils in Canarsie
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner last night agreed to white parents demands and reassigned 31 black pupils whose enrollment at John Wilson Junior High School 211 in Brooklyn touched off a threeday sitin there last week.

title: GATT Links Inflation To Monetary Instability
description: GENEVA, Oct. 23International trade experts warned today that the world might first have to bring inflation under control if it was to achieve a stable monetary system.

title: Business Briefs
description: The inflow of new deposits into the nation's savings and loan associations continued at a record pace during September, the United States Savings and Loan League estimated yesterday. At the same time, the league said that associations closed $4.6billion in new mortgage loans last month, which was 25 per cent higher than the same month a year ago.

title: An I.T.T. Message System Is Purchased by the Soviet
description: The International Telephone & Telegraph Corporation said yesterday its French subsidiary, Compagnie Generale de Constructions Telephoniques, would deliver to the Soviet telegraph administration in 1973 an electronic messageswitching system valued at about $1.3million.

title: Scrawls Mark Hockey Drills
description: NEW HYDE PARK, LI., Oct. 23Skateland was a delight today for hockey fans and autograph seekers.

title: 7 SAW 11EIR NAY OUT OF THE TOMBS
description: Seven prisoners made a daring and wellplanned escape from the Manhattan House of Detention (the Tombs) early yesterday in the first jailbreak from the present building since it was opened in 1941.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I was quite surprised to see Senator McGovern quoted in the Sept. 26 Times to the effect that Mr. Nixon has loaded the Federal Power Commission with spokesmen for the big utilities and big oil companies. The article proceeds to quote a memorandum issued by McGovern aides stating that Pinckney (sic) Walker had been a consultant to natural gas companies before becoming a member of the power commission.

title: Case Takes Exception To Billboard on Busing
description: NEWARK, Oct. 23(UPI) Senator Clifford P. Case's campaign director said today that he had filed a complaint with the Fair Campaign Practices Committee objecting to billboards that said the Republican Senator favored forced busing in New Jersey.

title: GROUND FIGHTING WIDENS IN SOUTH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday. Oct. 24Extensive fighting was reported yesterday in the center of South Vietnam, with Communist forces concentrating their attacks around the city of Pleiku.

title: Kodes Wins Spanish Final From Orantes, 63, 62, 63
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 23 (AP)  Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia defeated Spain's Manuel Orantes, 6.3, 62, 63, to win the singles final in the Spanish international tennis tournament today.

title: Arson at Interracial Church in Queens Shocks Neighborhood
description: Flags flew from the neat homes in the southwest corner of Forest HMS yesterday, trioutes to veterans who fought for American traditions. But there were also clusters of stunned people talking on 70th Avenue and on Loubet and Kessel Streets.

title: Bulldozer Kills Man
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 23 (AP)A man was killed today by a runaway bulldozer that he was trying to stop. Theodore W. Brown, 22 years old, had been operating the bulldozer at a garbage dump and had left it to get in a truck when he noticed the dozer was moving, investigators said. Mr. Brown ran up to the moving machine, started to climb on but slipped and fell. The tread apparently ran over him.

title: Merger News
description: The Continental Telephone Corporation and the MidContinent Telephone Corporation announced yesterday an agreement in principle to merge and form what they claimed would be the nation's second largest telephone company outside the Bell system.

title: Theater: Musical Pippin at Imperial
description: An amiable and racy musical, Pippin, which arrived at the Imperial Theater last night, has three great things to commend it. It is one of the best musical stagings to be seen on Broadway in years, it is most beautifully designed and it might well do for the actor Ben Vereen what Cabaret did for Joel Grey.

title: FRANK J. TAYLOR, 78; WROTE ON GARDENING
description: LOS ALTOS HILLS, Calif., Oct. 23 (AP)Frank J. Taylor, who wrote hundreds of nonfiction articles for national magazines and was the author of nine books, died today at his home here of what the Santa Clara County coroner's office said were selfinflicted gunshot wounds. lie was 78 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: In addition to the memories of entrechats past that they left in Poland, the New York City Ballet, which carne home Sunday night, also left behind its favorite piece of gray linoleum. The linoleum had been used to cover the stage floor of the New York State Theater and almost every other stage the City Ballet danced on around the world. The gift was the largesse of George Balanchine, the company's director. Before he left Warsaw, Mr. Balanchine autographed the floorcovering for the Polish Ballet. Polish dance officials quickly cut the autograph from the linoleum and framed it for hanging in the studio of the Polish Ballet School.

title: Udall Forecasts Congress Will Vote Itself a Pay Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) Representative Morris K. Udall, Democrat of Arizona, architect of a plan to grant Congressmen automatic pay rises, believes the lawmakers will probably agree to increase their salaries to nearly $50,000 next year.

title: Seoul Cabinet Takes Legislative Role
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 23  The South Korean Cabinet issued three special laws today in preparation for a national referendum to be held next month to change the Constitution.

title: Inmate Group in Tombs Devising Own Reform Plan on Sentences
description: While judges experiment with sentencing panels and legislators call for mandatory prison terms for certain crimes, inmates in the Manhattan House of Detention for Men are devising sentencing reforms of their own.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Seven leaders of Orthodox and Hasidic Jewish groups have praised President Nixon for his noble efforts in inspiring our country toward a greater commitment of moral values.

title: Neumann's Sloop Takes Storm Trysail Club Race
description: HAMPTON, Va., Oct. 23Dr. Walter Neumann's 43foot sloop, Sitzmark, out of Pelham Manor, N. Y., was the winner yesterday of the Storm Trysail Club's fourth annual race to Chesapeake Bay.

title: Ferries in Boston Studied
description: BOSTON, Oct. 23 (AP)A special legislative committee on harbor pollution in Massachusetts has asked for a study to determine the possibility of using an extensive ferry network to relieve traffic congestion around the Boston area.

title: Small War, Big Stakes
description: Reports that Arab League mediators have achieved agreement on a plan for peace and ultimate unity between the two Yemens will be greeted with relief tinged with substantial skepticism.

title: Points of Difference Cited
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System reported last night that Mr. Kissinger and President Thieu were, in complete agreement in principle on a ceasefire plan, but that there were four areas of major difficulties.

title: Yomiuri Leads Series, 20
description: TOKYO; Oct. 23 (AP)The Yetniuri Giants defeated the Hankyu Braves, 64, today, taking a 20 lead in the Japan baseball championship series.

title: Safety in the Schools
description: The recent rash of robberies of elementary school teachers in their classrooms comes on top of a series of cowardly and despicable assaults, including the brutal mugging of a teacher during a field trip with her class in Prospect Park. These outrages emphasize the urgency of rethinking and revamping school security.

title: BRAZIL MISSION TO AFRICA IS SET
description: BRASILIA, Oct. 20In the name of common heritage and interests, Brazil plans a new push into Africa.

title: Alcoholism Unit's Head Named by Heart Group
description: William W. Moore, executive director of the National Council on Alcoholism, has been named executive director of the American Heart Association. The appointment is effective Dec. 1.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: These are Orwellian days when war is peace and a 5.5 per cent national unemployment is a rising economy. Yet despite this deranged logic, there is more to be concerned about on the national scene, and that is the casual acceptance by the populace of almost every conceivable immoral or unethical practice on the part of the Administration. Whether it be the I.T.T. scandal, the Watergate bugging, the wheat deal or the bombing of civilians, it all seems to be accepted with a shrug. All this is ample evidence that we have died spiritually, and we are ready for totalitarianism. I remember once a high administration official was fired for accepting an overcoat as a gift.

title: Kissinger to Report on Talks With Thieu
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23Henry Kissinger returned to the capital from Saigon tonight amid continuing speculation that a Vietnam or allIndochina ceasefire was near, but with no firm agreement to end the war apparently reached. We made some progress, Mr. Kissinger said, but he refused to elaborate.

title: Cordero Scores a Sweep Of Two Firenze Divisions
description: All that was necessary for bettor to capitalize on both ends of the Firenze Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday was to have a liking for Angel Cordero and for No. 5 on the program. The amiable jockey from Puerto Rico won both ends of the split race, making him truly the winner of the Firenze, and each of his mounts was No. 5.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Of all of the late William Fitts Ryan's stanchest advisers and supporters, nobody knew more or cared more about the causes for which he fought than his wife, Priscilla, now the Liberal party's candidate to succeed him in the Twentieth Congressional District.

title: About Pro Football
description: I keep saying anybody can win in this league. That was Coach Henry Strain speaking, a ruffled Henry Stram after the victoryless Philadelphia Eagles had upset his Kansas City Chiefs by 2120. Six of the Eagles' points had come when pass by their Pete Liske bounced off the foot of the Chiefs' Em mitt Thomas 8 yards into the hands of a startled Ben Hawkins, who then ran for a touchdown. Thomas was about to intercept when he collided with his teammate, Jim Marsalis. Blind luck, said Liske.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, Oct. 23 (AP)Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry was reported today to be planning to control Japan's exports of automobiles and steel in an effort to stave off increasing foreign pressure to revalue the yen. This followed a Saturday report that the ministry was considering invoking an ordinance control export trade to stem fastswelling exports of bearings to Britain and tape recorders to the European Economic Community.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Hearings Across U.S. Planned On Vietnam Veterans Troubles
description: Four Newark veterans of the Vietnam war period, two marines, an infantryman and a Wave, told yesterday of the frustrations they had had getting jobs, schooling and medical care in a nation they thought they had served.

title: THOMAS MAVITY, N.B.C. EXECUTIVE ExMead of TV Programing DiesStarted in Radio
description: Thomas A. McAvity, former vice president in charge of programing for the National Broadcasting Company's television network, died yesterday at his home, 430 East 57th Street. He was 65 years old.

title: Pennsylvania Report Sales Of Cars Damaged in Flood
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 23 (AP)  Motorists in states as far away as California and Georgia have unwittingly bought cars that were damaged in flooding in Pennsylvania last June and were spirited away by unethical dealers, a state official says.

title: Gains Are Shown In Net and Revenue For Two Utilities
description: The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation reported yesterday thirdquarter operating revenues of $117.9million against $107.5million a year ago.

title: METHADONE STIRS WORRY IN JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 23A small but steadily growing illicit market in methadone, the synthetic narcotic used as a substitute to treat harddrug addicts, has emerged in New Jersey and with rapidly increasing fatal results.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The statement that the difference between incumbent Representative Bella Abzug and her opponent, Priscilla Marbury Ryan, is simply one of style greatly underestimates Mrs. Abzug's achievements and exaggerates Mrs. Ryan's past political role. In her first two years in Congress, Bella Abzug has achieved the respect of her colleagues as an exceedingly hardworking and productive legislator. Her serious and responsible approach has won her the endorsement of the chairman of her Public Works Committee, John Blatnik, and House Speaker Carl Albert despite her political disagreements with them.

title: OneParty System
description: When Tammany Hall was in its heyday a halfcentury ago, its leaders and Samuel Koenig, then the city's Republican boss, would regularly make deals for the allocation of judgeships and other political patronage. The Democrats always got the lion's share because of their enormous edge in voting strength, but it suited their purpose to keep the G.O.P. as a contented vassal.

title: House Panel Plans Inquiry Into Xerox Hiring Practices
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 23 (AP)A House subcommittee, after hearing testimony alleging racial discrimination in Xerox Corporation hiring, decided today that it would mount a nationwide investigation of the company's practices.

title: Johnson Is Described As a Great Pet Lover
description: Former President Lyndon B. Johnson was so fond of his dog, Old Beagle, that when the animal died Mr. Johnson had it cremated and kept the ashes in a box over the refrigerator, Ladies Home Journal reported yesterday.

title: College Sports Notes
description: C. W. Post became the latest college in the metropolitan area to make drastic cuts in its intercollegiate athletic program as officialsat the Brookville, L.I., school last week ordered large budget cuts in all departments educational and extracurricular.

title: WILKENS RETURNS TO HAUNT KNICKS
description: Lenny Wilkens, starting his 13th season as a National Basketball Association backcourtman, will make his debut as a Cleveland Cavalier tonight at Madison Square Garden. The Cays will attempt to end a seasonopening, sixgame losing streak.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Oct. 6 editorial dealing with oil import quotas was both superficial and factually inaccurate. It misstated the recommendations of Secretary Shultz's group and also misrepresented the economic implications of oil import controls by focusing on the peripheral issue of costs to the consumer.

title: Study Discloses How Katydid Sings Complicated Courtship Song
description: Katydid, shedid sings out the tireless musician of the insect world. And now, highspeed movies, synchronized millisecond for millisecond with tape recordings of the melodious insect, disclose how the complicated courtship song is sung.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Senator George S. McGovern had trouble with electronic rings, fadeouts and bleeps on an hourlong telethon last night.

title: Four Powers Open Talks On Their German Rights
description: BERLIN, Oct. 23Representatives of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union opened talks today on a joint declaration to reassert fourpower rights and responsibilities for Berlin and Germany as a whole.

title: REDS FLOOD DUE IN SUBWAYS
description: The transit policemen's union said yesterday its men would cover the city's subways today with a blanket of summonses as part of their rulebook work slowdown against the Transit Authority.

title: ISLAND ISSUE STALLS SOVIETJAPAN TALKS
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23 (Reuters) apan and the Soviet Union today ended their first formal peace treaty talks deadlocked on the key issue of four Soviet held islands that the Japanese want returned.

title: Detectives Unable to Find Gross For Inquiry on Agency's Funds
description: Detectives have been looking for Ted Gross, the former Youth Services Commissioner, since Friday to serve him with a subpoena to testify in a city investigation of financial irregularities, reliable sources reported yesterday.

title: Art Works Valued at $500,000 Are Stolen at Center in Katonah
description: Twelve art works whose total worth is estimated at more than $500,000 were stolen last Thursday night from the Caramoor Center of Music and the Arts in Katonah, N. Y.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: SOUTH STRAFFORD, Vt.A hunter's moon washed the hills and valleys of Vermont the previous evening, and in the morning frosty leaves crunched underfoot and icicles gleamed on the rocks of trout streams.

title: SOCIALISTS DEPLORE HARRINGTON ACTION
description: The Socialist partyDemocratic Socialist Federation deplored yesterday the resignation of one of its three cochairmen, Michael Harrington, and reaffirmed its preference for George McGovern's Democratic candidacy against President Nixon.

title: 3 Kept Promises, 4 Giant Steps
description: The New York Giants began preparing yesterday for Sunday's game against the Washington Redskins at Yankee Stadium, a game that could put them in first place in the Eastern Division.

title: United Aircraft in Move
description: United Aircraft International, Inc., which has an agreement with Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., of Japan to build Pratt & Whitney aircraft jet engines and Sikorsgy helicopters under a license arrangement, has made a further agreement for Mitsubishi to make other products of the United Aircraft Corporation, particularly industrial and marine gas turbines, it was announced yesterday.

title: 4th Solidaiity Day Will Be Observed By Blacks on Nov. 6
description: Black families are being asked to refrain from going to work or school, and from shopping and trriveling on Monday, Nov. 6, it, observance of the fourth annual Black Solidarity Day.

title: STOCKS CONTINUE ON PEACE RALLY
description: While talks and speculation linked to a possible ceasefire in Indochina continued, Wall Street staged another peace rally yesterday. Glamour issues once again scored the best gains.

title: 1 Killed, 19 Hurt in PileUp
description: CORONA, Calif., Oct. 23 (UPI) One person was killed and at last 19 were injured in a 60car pileup on the fogshrouded Riverside Freeway today.

title: McAloon Loses Paris Bout
description: PARIS, Oct. 23 (Reuters) The European welterweight champion, Roger Menetrey of France, defeated Danny McAloon of New York tonight on a unanimous decision in a 10round welterweight match.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 23What began as a madcap political medicine show in Washingtonthe snake oil special, somebody Who saw it off remarkeddrew to a close today on a darker, deeply serious note.

title: MRS. ROBERT BENENSON
description: Mrs. Nettie Rachstein Benenson, widow of Robert Benenson, builder and philanthropist, died yesterday at her home in Atlantic Beach, L.I. She was 88 years old.

title: It's the Style That Counts Not How Exclusive It
description: It's very passe to mind if other women have the same &fess, said Adolfo in a very firm tone of voice.

title: Raiders Steal Arms From Ulster Military Base
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 23Fourteen armed men stole more than 100 weapons early today in a raid on a base of the parttime Ulster Defense Regiment in Lurgan, about 20 miles west of Belfast.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: WAYNE, N.J., Oct. 23At 5 o'clock one recent morning, Ken Boyle, Ken Nelson and Walter Jauch were in the parking lot of the Willow Brook Racquet Club doing calisthenics. They were not health freaks.

title: Gladys M. Park, ExDirector Of Health Unit Here, Dies
description: Gladys M. Park, who retired in 1965 as director of the health advisory service of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, died Sunday in University Hospital. She was 80 years old and lived at 2 East 12th Street.

title: VETERANS PARADE DIM ECHO OF PAST
description: About 200 veterans, most of whom had fought in longago wars and marched to the triumphant acclaim of longago crowds, put on their overseas caps, unfurled their flags and paraded before modest crowds on Fifth Avenue yesterday as proudly as if the armistice had just been proclaimed.

title: S.E.C. HEARING SET ON FUND CHARGES
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission will hold public hearings next month or early in December to determine whether, it will ask Congress to repeal legislation granting mutual funds exemption from pricefixing laws, William J. Casey, chairman of the commission, said here yesterday.

title: Larsens, Violinist, Is Poised in Debut; His Pianist Excels
description: A gifted violinist named Gunars Larsens made his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall late Sunday afternoon, and the countries in his background would almost make a United Nations quorum: of Latvian descent, he was born in Belgium, grew up in Australia and now lives in Switzerland. To complete the international picture, his remarkably expressive partner was a 25yearold Czechoslovak pianist, Peter Cizmarovic.

title: 2 Yemens Are Said To Agree on Steps Toward Unification
description: CAIRO, Oct. 23 (AP)Negotiators from feuding Yemen and Southern Yemen reached an agreement today that outlines steps toward unifying the two countries, the official Egyptian Middle East News Agency reported.

title: Theater
description: In black slit skirt, and wearing an expression of exhaustive experience, Geraldine Fitzgerald sings Pirate Jenny. For the first time within my memory, a singer who does not have a German accent is able to strike exactly the right quaver for this sorrowful and abrasive song.

title: SUNDAY'S HEROES NOT DINED MONDAY
description: Because hindsight is so much better than foresight, Eddie Bell and Earlie Thomas will be the featured players at next Monday's gathering of the New York Jets First and 10 luncheon at the Playboy Club. Yesterday's guests were Dave Herman, guard, and John Little, defensive tackle.

title: Winner of Piano Contest In Leeds Honored Here
description: Murray Perahia, 25yearold pianist who last month became the first American to win the Leeds International Piano Festival in Britain, was honored yesterday by Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx, who presented him with a Special Distinguished Citizen Scroll.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: STANFORD, Calif.Administration spokesmen have argued that the United States cannot unilaterally withdraw from Vietnam without inviting a vast bloodbath. In support of this thesis, they assert that following the Communist takeover in North Vietnam in 1954 a massacre occurred resulting in the killing of more than 50,000 people and the indirect deaths of hundreds of thousands more. Critics of the Administration have recently charged that no bloodbath took place in the Norththat President Nixon's apparent concern is founded on a myth.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Ecucci (Italian for Here we are) proclaims the marquee outside the little sportswear shop at 1162 Madison Avenue. Although much of the stock is from Italy, the owner, Georgina Brody, is Hungarian. A friend suggested the name, she explained, and I liked it because it had the same ring as Gucci and Pucci.

title: TeachIns for McGovern Mapped at 350 Campuses
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 (UPI)The National Teaching Committee for McGovernShniver announced today that more than 350 campuses would participate in its faculty and student events planned for next Wednesday.

title: Stage: Equity's The Maid's Tragedy
description: What the Equity Library Theater has done with Beaumont and Fletcher's The Maid's Tragedy is this: They have intelligently coiled inside the frame of the famous old Elizabethan classic an hoisted the play far enough above the boards to make it lifelike, if not alive. Only a miracle comparable to Jonah could make it soar.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Ronco Teleproducts. Inc., announced yesterday it had withdrawn its registration statement in connection with a proposed public offering of 500,000 common shares. The company had planned to sell 300,000 shares and certain selling shareholders 200,000 shares. The company said it acted due to unfavorable market conditions. The company's stock, traded on the American Stock Exchange, closed yesterday at 6, up .

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. to discuss report of Committee on Colonialism.

title: Advertising:
description: The Hush Puppies apparently fit, so Wolverine World Wide is going to let Wells, Rich, Greene wear em.

title: Lobbyists Powerful in Road Fund Battle
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 Richard J. Sullivan. Alfred E. Johnson. Joseph A. Bosco. Fred B. Burke. John Kramer.

title: A TENTATIVE ACCORD AT THE PLAIN DEALER
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 23 (AP)A tentative contract agreement was reached tonight between The Cleveland Plain Dealer and the striking Cleveland Newspaper Guild.

title: The Senate Races
description: Voters will decide 33 races for the United States Senate on Nov. 7. In a few states the outcome is a foregone conclusion. In others such as Georgia and Louisiana the contests are being fought out solely in terms of personalities.

title: SECURITY ACTION TAKEN IN SOCCER
description: The president of the GermanAmerican Soccer League, one of the strongest in the East, believes that he has found an antidote to the increase in rockthrowing at games in the metropolitan area.be appointed to supervise the games and that large fines and suspensions would be imposed on officials or players who became involved in such incidents.

title: Problems Found by Auditors Threaten an Activist Jobs Program in Birmingham
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 20  The Concentrated Employment Program in this grimy) steel town has had to fight hard for its survival. As a result, it has become one of the most activist and successful in the country.

title: JUDGE C. J. O'CONNOR
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 23 (AP)Retired Northampton District Court Judge Charles J. O'Connor died last night at Wesson Memorial Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived here.

title: STRIKERS AT REA ARE ORDERED BACK
description: Striking employes of REA Express were ordered back to work last night by a Federal judge after the union rejected the company's latest contract offer.

title: Youth Stabbed, 2d Beaten In Fracas in East Harlem
description: One teenager was stabbed and another was beaten by members of a youth gang in an East Harlem housing project last night, the police reported.

title: FRANCE, CHINA URGED TO JOIN ARMS TALKS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 23  Mexico initiated a campaign by nonnuclear countries today to induce France and China to join in United Nations disarmament negotiations.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Florynce Kennedy, a black attorney, TiGrace Atkinson, feminist author, and three other women militants were arrested yesterday for refusing to move during a Feminist party kissoff demonstration in front of a Nixon campaign office at 520 Madison Avenue.

title: Taiwan and Japan Continue Trading
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 23 Economic activity between Nationalist China and Japan has been continuing without major disruption since the two countries severed diplomatic relations three weeks ago.

title: NIXON VISITS AREA AND PLEDGES FIGEIT ON BIG SPENDERS
description: BOHEMIA, L.I., Oct. 23 President Nixon, telescoping virtually all of his New York metropolitan area campaigning into a single day's swing through Westchester County and Long Island, sounded familiar campaign themes and called for pluralities greater than those he received in the 1968 election.

title: First Pay TV on L.I. Offers Basketball and Hockey
description: Pay television on a regular basis will come to the metropolitan New York area for the first time Friday, When a subsoription television service of fering professional basketball and hockey games begins operating on Long Island.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: ITHACA, N.Y.President Nixon now justifies continued United States military involvement in Vietnam in large part by portraying Vietnamese Communist leaders as bloodthirsty fanatics who would order a massive bloodbath against their former foes if they were to gain power in South Vietnam one which would be even worse than the present daily bloodletting. In support of that argument, he has charged that the North Vietnamese Government carried out wholesale liquidations during the land reform from 1954 to 1956.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 23The designation of Nassau and Suffolk Counties as the Long Island Standard Metropolitan Area had been sought by municipal officials and the Long Island Association of Commerce and Industry for many years.

title: 22 MORE FOOD SPOTS LISTED AS UNCLEAN
description: The City Health Departmentl charged 22 more restaurants and other food establishments last week with serious Health Code violations and threatened to close them unless they were cleaned up in time for final inspections in three weeks.

title: Diamond Is Still Riding Bond Issue As His Bicycle Tour Across State Ends
description: When Henry L. Diamond, the state's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, neared the end yesterday of his bicycle ride across the state to promote the $1.15billion environmental bond issue, he issued a statement that said Based on the reception we have received I am convinced that the issue is going to carry the day on Nov. 7.

title: Italian Lawmakers for Nixon
description: ROME, Oct. 23 (AP)Eighteen members of the Italian Parliament announced today that they had formed a committee to support President Nixon's reelection.

title: KISSINGER FLIES HOME AMID SIGNS OF SOME SUCCESS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Oct. 24There were signs yesterday that Henry A. Kissinger had achieved some success in his fiveday effort here toward a settlement of the Vietnam war, but evidently without having reached a conclusive agreement with President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: FOUR SURRENDER JET IN BULGARIA
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 23 (AP) Turkish hijackers surrendered late today and freed more than 60 hostages whom they had held aboard a Turkish jetliner for 38 hours at the airport at Sofia, Bulgaria.

title: Hanoi Said to See Difficult Talks Ahead
description: PEKING, Oct. 23 (Agence FrancePresse)  Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the deposed head of state of Cambodia, said here today that Le Duc Tho had told him a week ago that the most difficult and delicate part of the Vietnam peace talks still remained to be held.

title: People and Business
description: When Thomas F. Willers was brought into the company now known as Champion International last February as president, the general impression on Wall Street was that he would be taking over the top post before too long. Yesterday, the big pulp and paper, building materials and homefurnishings company announced that the 53yearold executive would also become chairman and chief executive officer on Jan. 1.

title: Dance: Eglevsky Troupe
description: With few exceptions, outside of the major ballet companies, the classic ballets are subjected to illconceived performances. One of the notable exceptions is the Eglevsky Ballet Company, currently giving a series of six performances of Coppelia in the Greater New York area.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Magazine Cleared in Bias Complaint A complaint that the Reader's Digest magazine discriminates against women employes has been dismissed by the State Division of Human Rights.

title: Sierra Club Urges Controls on Energy To Avert Disaster
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23 (AP)The Sierra Club has appealed for national controls on the production and use of all types of energy including powerplants, transmission lines, dams, oil and gas pipeplines, strip mining, and storage of radioactive wastes.

title: Stolen Car Leads to Death
description: LOWELL, Mass., Oct. 23 (UPI)Harry Brewer happened to look out his window at 2 A.M. yesterday and saw someone driving off with his car. Mr. Brewer, 58 years old, did not have a telephone so he ran to a corner phone booth to call the police. Before he cotild make the call, Mr. Brewer collapsed. He was pronounced dead of a heart attack at St. John's Hospital.

title: GEORGIAPACIFIC SET TO REDEEM STOCK
description: The GeorgiaPacific Corporation said yesterday that it was calling its $1.40 convertible preferred stock for redemption.

title: REGIONAL EXCHANGES INVITED TO MEETING
description: James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that the heads of regional exchanges had been invited to attend a meeting of Big Board members tomorrow afternoon.

title: METHADONE ABUSE GROWS IN JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 23A small but steadily growing black market in methadone, the synthetic narcotic used as a substitute to treat harddrug addicts, has emerged in New Jersey, and with rapidly increasing fatal results.

title: Hopes for CeaseFire Progress Spur Amex Rise
description: Increased hopes that progress was being made toward a ceasefire in Indochina sent prices higher yesterday in the overthecounter market and on the American Stock Exchange.

title: MRS. REUTHER
description: WHEELING, W. Va., Oct. 23 Mrs. Anna Stocker Reuther, widow of Valentine Reuther, former president of the Ohio Valley Trades and Labor Assembly, and mother of Walter Reuther, who was president of the United Automobile Workers from 1946 to his death in 1970, died yesterday in a nursing home near Boston. She was 90 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: About 200 veterans, most of whom had fought in longago wars and marched trisumphantly to the acclaim of longago crowds, paraded down Fifth Avenue yesterday before modest crowds, to celebrate Veterans Day.

title: Rescue Specialist Arrives
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Oct. 23 (UPI)The Air Force's top specialist on search and rescue, Brig. Gen. Frank Everest, commander of the Aerospace Rescue and Recovery Service, arrived here today with two aides to observe the search operations, the Air Force said.

title: Market Place: Telephone: Is Giant Awake?
description: Investors who have been watching American Telephone in recent weeks may be wondering whether the sleeping giant is about to rise at last.

title: Study Discloses How Katydid Sings Complicated Courtship Song
description: Katydid, shedid sings out the tireless musician of the insect world. And now, highspeed movies, synchronized millisecond for millisecond with tape recordings of the melodious insect, disclose how the complicated courtship song is sung.

title: Philippines Evacuates 10,000
description: MANILA, Oct. 23 (Reuters)About 10,000 people were reported today to have been evacuated from the southern Philippine city of Marawi yesterday after an attack by 400 armed insurgents. Francisco S. Tatad, the Secretary of Information, said that some of the attackers were foreign  trained and that the Government was now trying to determine whether any, foreigners actually took part. The attack ended with 59 dead49 of them insurgents, the Government said.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: PICK UP a free colorful travel floater today during American'a Great Airfare Sale at American Airlines tinder the Kodak picture at Grand Central (Advt.)

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 23Sargent Shriver, wearing a new silver prisonerofwar bracelet on Veterans Day, charged the Nixon Administration today with suppressing job opportunities and educational benefits for G.I.'sprograms he said would have the highest priority in a new McGovernShriver G.I. Bill.

title: ESSO AFFILIATE OFFERED TO INDIA
description: BOMBAY, Oct. 23 (UPI)Esso Eastern, Inc., an affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) that has one of the largest private American investments in India, disclosed yesterday that it had offered to sell all its business or 74 per cent of its shares to the Government. A Government official said that India was seriously considering the proposal.

title: Eight Singers New In Hoffmann Roles At the City Opera
description: No fewer than eight singers were new to their roles at the City Opera performance of Les Contes d'Hoffmann Sunday night. Since the company lacks a second Beverly Sills to sing all three heroines, these parts were assigned to separate sopranos  inevitably destroying the onewomaninthree premise that Tito Capobianco's willfully pretentious production italicizes ad absurdum.

title: Senate Contest
description: ENID, Okla.  Representative Ed Edmondson smiled and pushed the newspaper clipping across the coffee shop table to an acquaintance.

title: FLORIDA CHECKS SCREWWORM FLY
description: MIAMI, Oct. 23The spread of the economically harmful screwworm fly in Florida has apparently been contained by prompt widescale Federal and state action.

title: Sudan Offered War College
description: CAIRO, Oct. 24 (Agence FrancePresse)President Anwar elSadat has offered the Egyptian military college near Khartoum, which closed a week ago, to Sudan's armed forces, it was announced here today.

title: Earnings Rise at Mobil Oil
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation increased its profits in the quarter and nine months ended Sept 30, the company reported yesterday.

title: Celtics Late Surge Sinks 76ers, 10585, For Seventh in Row
description: BOSTON, Oct. 23 (UPI)John Havlicek's 10 points in the final period helped the Boston Celtics pull away from the Philadelphia 76ers for a 10585 victory today to extend their winning streak to seven games.

title: ANTIQUES GALORE SHOWN AT ARMORY
description: America, Hurrah! is the theme of the National Arts & Antiques Festival, which opened last weekend at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 67th Street.

title: Her Abiding Affection for the Dahlia
description: FREEPORT, L.I.When Rori Gordon was 5 years old she began helping her parents, Richard and Ancil Gordon, in the family's fairly extensive flower gardens at 95 West Third Street. There was nothing unusual about this. A lot of children take a fling at planting bulbs or seeds and watching them grow. But then, after a few years, most of them lose interest.

title: Rutgers Chooses Armstead
description: NEW BRUSWICK, N. J., Oct. 23 (AP)The Rutgers University basketball team today elected Gene Armstead, a 6foot9inch center, as captain. He is a senior from Media, Pa.

title: Bridge: Mixed Pairs Play Provides Lesson in Rejecting Finesse
description: The final day's play in the Greater New York Bridge Association's metropolitan championships began at the New York Hilton yesterday afternoon with 70 teams competing in the Swiss team event.

title: Lobbyists Powerful in Road Fund Battle
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 Richard J. Sullivan. Alfred E. Johnson. Joseph A. Bosco. Fred B. Burke. John Kramer.

title: U.N. Group to Give $40,000 For Refugees From Malawi
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Oct. 23 (Agence FrancePresse)  The United Nations High Commission for Refugees is to supply $40,000 to help feed and care for Jehovah's Witnesses fleeing to Zambia from Malawi, it was announced here today.

title: Connecticut Legislators Are Assessed By CitizenAction Project in 149 Profiles
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 23  The Connecticut Citizen Action Group, an organization affiliated with Ralph Nader, today released profiles of Connecticut's 149 General Assembly members up for reelection. The profiles seek to kindle voters' lagging interest in their local legislature and in the major issues confronting their state senators and representatives.

title: Miller ReElected President Of U.S Zionist Federation
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 23Rabbi Israel Miller was reelected president of the American Zionist Federation today at the close of the federation's threeclay convention here.

title: MRS. FRANCIS PERRY
description: Mrs. Madeline Gartlan Perry of Forest Hills, Queens, an author of children's stories and poems, and a former teacher, here, died Oct. 11 at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Peter J. Hickey, in Atlanta. Her age was 92. She was the widow of Col. Francis William Perry, a municipal engineer here.

title: U.S. Force in Vietnam Cut By 600 in Week, to 34,000
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 23 (Reuters)United States troop strength in South Vietnam dropped by 600 men last week to 34,000, the United States command said today.

title: Sicrout Over Wage Cut Ends, But L.I.R.R. Runs Late Anyway
description: A few Long Island Rail Road trains were delayed yesterday, one as much as 29 minutes, but a spokesman attributed it to equipment failures rather than to the waning sickout of protesting trainmen.

title: Western United Approval Seen
description: The plan of the Great Western United Corporation to sell its beetsugar subsidiary and to retire its $1.88 preferred stock should meet with the approval of shareholders, according to Nathan K. Mendelsohn, owner of 37,200 preferred shares.

title: Laotian Expecting Truce
description: PARIS, Oct. 23 (UPI)  The Laotian Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma, said today that he expected an Indochina ceasefire to be announced before the end of the month, but that full peace settlement would come later.

title: JOHN O. STUBBS DIES; INVESTMENT BANKER
description: John O. Stubbs, former managing partner of F. S. Moseley & Co., Boston investment bankers, and a governor of the New York Stock Exchange from 1954 to 1957, died yesterday at his home in Dedham, Mass. He was 74 years old.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 23Oceanracing teams from Brazil and Argentina took an early lead yesterday over the United States after the first of four races in the Rio Circuit, a seventeam sailing series off the coast of Brazil.

title: Farm Food Dealers Urged To Warn Health Food Fans
description: ST. PAUL, Oct. 23 (AP)Minnesota's Agriculture Commissioner, Jon Wefald, has asked livestock and poultry feed dealers to post signs in their stores to head off health fond fans.

title: Trial Date Is Set for Suit By Control Data on I.B.M.
description: A trial date of Nov. 5, 1973, was set for the Control Data Corporation v. International Business Machine Corporation antitrust suit in Federal Court in Minnesota.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 23Some expected highlevel ticketsplitting and the margin by which President Nixon loses Essex County will determine the outcome of the election in this northern New Jersey county.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: SOUTH STRAFFORD, Vt.A hunter's moon washed the hills and valleys of Vermont the previous evening, and in the morning frosty leaves crunched underfoot and icicles gleamed on the rocks of trout streams.

title: Corporation President Is Profiled by Survey
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (UPI) The average president of a major American corporation according to Heidrick ang Struggles, a managementconsulting firm:

title: CAMBODIAN AIDES DENY HOLDING TALKS
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 23 (Reuters)Cambodian ministers denied a report today that Cambodia was negotiating with guerrilla leaders in the countryside.

title: KISSING ER FLIES HOME AMID SIGNS OF SOME SUCCESS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 23There were signs today that Henry A. Kissinger had achieved some success in his fiveday effort here toward a settlement of the Vietnam war, but evidently without having reached a conclusive agreement with President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: British Envoy Urges U. S. to Lead in Trade Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23Lord Cromer, the British Ambassador, called on the United States today to exercise leadership in the next major round of international trade negotiations, tentatively set to begin late in 1973.

title: Soccer List Unavailable
description: The British Soccer Standings usually printed in The Times on Tuesdays do not appear today. They are unavailable because of transmission problems.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Oct. 23 (Reuters)Increased optimism over the possibility of an early end to the Vietnam war led to a big dollarbuying wave in Europe today, raising value against the world's key nondollar currencies higher than at any time in seven months.

title: Scott Heads Tennis Field
description: Gene Scott heads the field for the first men's tennis tournament of the metropolitan indoor season starting Thursday in the armory at Fifth Avenue and 145th Street. Steve Turner, Art Carrington and Vitas Gerulaitis are also in the draw. The Jungle Tennis Club is putting up $2,000 in prize money.

title: Guard's Clanging Keys Open Jail Day for Reporter at 4 A.M.
description: Peter J. Bridge, who was sent to jail for refusing to answer a grand jury's questions about a news article that he wrote for the now defunct Evening News of Newark, describes his life in the Essex County Jail in the following article. The dispatch, the second he has written for The New York Times from inside the jail, was sent out through the regular mail.

title: Scribner Agrees to Shift 31 Black Pupils in Canarsie
description: School Chancellor Harvey B.1 Scribner said last night that the Board of Education had agreed not to enroll 31 black students in John Wilson Junior High School 211 in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: A search continued for three of five prisoners who broke out of the Camden County Jail annex in Gloucester Township Sunday night. Still at large were Frank J. Huryan, 19 years old, of Lindenwold; George Ennis, 19, of Collingswood, and John W. Humphrey, 18, of Gloucester City. Charles Mraz, 24, and Glenn Frampton, 20, both of Camden, were recaptured early Monday.

title: Disney World Sets Expansion Project To Cost $50Million
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 23 (AP)  A $50million expansion program for Walt Disney World, including a new hotel and 300 campsites, was announced on Saturday by Disney officials.

title: Soviet Again Denounces McGovern's View on Emigration Tax
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23  For the second time this month a masscirculation weekly has denounced Senator George McGovern for linking the Soviet emigration tax to the prospects of United StatesSoviet trade.

title: HANOI SAID TO SEE DIFFICULT TALKS
description: PEKING, Oct. 23 (Agence FrancePresse)  Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the deposed head of state of Cambodia, said here today that Le Duc Tho had told him a week ago that the most difficult and delicate part of the Vietnam peace talks still remained to be held.

title: Portugal Condemned at U.N. For Senegal Border Incident
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23The Security Council today condemned a violation by Portugal on the Senegalese border Oct. 12. Twelve countries voted for the resolution, with the United States, Britain and Belgium abstaining.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Oct. 23 (AP)  President Nixon, in a recorded message for Veterans Day ceremonies at Arlington National Cemetery, said today Hope is strong for a full generation of peace as American troops return home from a distant conflict.

title: Weyerhaeuser Profit Up
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company, the nation's largest maker of timber products and a major producer of pulp and paper, turned in the highest results of any forestproducts company in the three and nine months ended Sept. 24, a report yesterday from the company's Tacoma, Wash., headquarters indicated.

title: AMIN HOSPITALIZED, UGANDA RADIO SAYS
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Oct. 23 (AP)Maj. Gen. Idi Amin, the President of Uganda, was admitted to a hospital today, and his doctors ordered him to take a complete rest, the Uganda radio announced.

title: MAJOR PARTIES GAIN IN GERMAN ELECTION
description: FREIBURG, West Germany, Oct. 23The two major parties, the Social Democrats and the Christian Democrats, were the big gainers in communal elections yesterday in Hesse and Lower Saxony, where about 80 per cent of the eight million voters turned out.

title: Voters in Canadian West See Government as EasternOriented
description: VANCOUVER, B. C., Oct. 20 When Trudeau talks Canadian unity he's thinking one thing while we're thinking another, a passenger on a Vancouver bus complained.

title: LAOTIAN SEES TRUCE BY END OF OCTOBER
description: PARIS, Oct. 23 (UPI)  The Laotian Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma, said today that he expected an Indochina ceasefire to be announced before the end of the month, but that a full peace settlement would come later.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The League of Women Voters of New York State urges a no vote on Amendment 3, the Fifth Judicial Department, on Nov. 7. We oppose the creation of a costly and unnecessary new appellate and administrative structure for Nassau and Suffolk Counties. The ballot proposal would split the present Second Judicial Department into two parts, thereby dividing the existing appellate caseload and administrative responsibility between the two units.

title: Rumors on Truce Persist As Capital Awaits Report
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23Henry Kissinger returned to the capital from Saigon tonight amid continuing speculation that a Vietnam or allIndochina ceasefire was near, but with no firm agreement to end the war apparently reached. We made some progress, Mr. Kissinger said, but he refused to elaborate.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 23Peter J. Bridge will mark his 20th day in the Essex County Jail tomorrow when Superior Court Judge James R. Giuliano is scheduled to say whether he will dismiss the grand jury to which Mr. Bridge's fortunes are tied.

title: Gov. Moore of West Virginia Received Contributions From 6 Aliens He Helped While in Congress
description: Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. of West Virginia, who is currently seeking a second term, introduced immigration bills while in Congress for six alien physicians who later contributed to his 1968 campaign for Governor.

title: VARIETY MARKS SOLO BY CLAYTONTHOMAS
description: David ClaytonThomas, bestknown in this country as the torpier lead singer for Blood, Sweat and Tears, made a convincing solo debut at Alice Tully Hall Saturday night. Backed by a solidly swinging rhythm and bluesstyled group, he demonstrated a versatility in both style and substance that rarely had been apparent in his work with B, S & T.

title: Phelps Dodge in the Black
description: Two of the nation's major copper companies, the Anaconda Company and the Phelps Dodge Corporation, released thirdquarter reports yesterday showing turnarounds after losses in 1971.

title: Advertising:
description: Richard K. Manoff, who has the same name as his ad agency, is obviously displeased with the way broadcasters have been treating his favorite public service advertising project. So he's come up with a solution.

title: Inquiry Pressed in Brooklyn In Baby's Christening Death
description: The investigation into the murder of a sixweekold boy at his christening party in Brooklyn continued yesterday with the interviewing of many of the 50 people who were at the party and with forensic studies by the Medical Examiner's office.

title: SUMMONS FLOOD DUE IN SUBWAYS
description: The transit policemen's union said yesterday its men would cover the city's subway today with a blanket of summonses as part of their rulebook work slowdown against the Transit Authority.

title: McGovern Stresses Help for. Veterans In Visit to Hospital
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23Senator George McGovern visited patients in the United States Naval Hospital here today to dramatize his Veterans Day pledge to provide jobs, education and health care for veterans of the Vietnam war.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: PLAY IT AS IT LAYS AT THE BEEKMAN ON SUNDAY. ADVT.

title: AGNES M. CRAIG, 90, EXBRONX JUSTICE First Woman Elected to Municipal Bench Here Dies
description: Agnes M. Craig, the first woman to be elected to the Municipal Court bench here, died yesterday in the Josephine Baird Nursing Home, 340 West 55th Street, where she had lived for many years. She was 90 years old.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday that a new process to reduce sulphur dioxide emissions from sulphuric acid plants had been developed by Union Carbide and J. F. Pritchard & Co., a subsidiary of the International Systems and Controls Corporation.

title: Arts Abroad
description: PARISWe ought to die the death that pleases us, wrote Seneca. The remark is quoted by Henry de Montherlant in LaMaree du Soir (The Evening Tide), published a few months ago. It has turned out to be his last book, for last month Montherlant died the death of his liking, or at least of his choosing: He shot himself. His suicide is not his only kinship with Hemingway. He too, was wounded in World War I and tried his hand at bullfighting. In a way, Montherlant was a Hemingway raised by the Jesuits and fed on D'Annunzio.

title: MAINE ATOM PLANT IS PUT IN OPERATION
description: WISCASSET, Me., Oct. 23 (AP)The nuclear reactor at ((AP)The nuclear reactor at the Maine Yankee Atomic Power Company plant here was put into operation for the first time at 4:55 A.M. today.

title: Soccer List Unavailable
description: The British Soccer Standings usually printed in The Times on Tuesdays do not appear today. They are unavailable because of transmission problems.

title: Court to Rule on Jury Action Today
description: NEWARK, Oct. 23Peter J. Bridge will mark his 20th day in the Essex County Jail tomorrow when Superior Court Judge James R. Giuliano is scheduled to say whether he will dismiss the grand jury to which Mr. Bridge's fortunes are tied.

title: Romney Recommends Abolition Of Federally Subsidized Housing
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, suggested today that all the federally subsidized housing programs be abolished, a step that would do away with most of his department in the process.

title: Art Works Valued at $500,000 Are Stolen at Center in Katonah
description: Twelve art works whose total worth is estimated at more than $500,000 were stolen last Thursday night from the Caramoor Center of Music and the Arts in Katonah, N. Y.

title: Dealers Irked at Museum Over Coin Sale in Zurich
description: American art dealers are not alone in their unhappiness about the way the Metropolitan Museum of Art is selling some of its treasures. The coin trade here is miffed as well.

title: D.C. Race Bid to Belle Geste
description: LAUREL, Md., Oct. 23 (AP)Belle Geste, a 4yearold filly who finished second last weekend in Canada's richest turf race, was invited today to represent Canada in the $150,000 Washington D.C. International at Laurel Race Course Nov. II.

title: JOBS ARE INSECURE IN SPAIN'S SCHOOLS
description: MADRID, Oct. 23  A Gov ernment effort to exclude teachers who arc considered politically undesirable from the universities and high schools has helped spotlight serious economic problems in the schools and in Spanish society in general.

title: City Pushes Its Schools On Safety
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner has set Nov. 15 as the deadline for all city principals to submit plans for teacher and student safety in their schools.

title: Boy, 9, Found Slain On a Harlem Roof; Police Seek Killer
description: The mutilated body of a 9yearold  boy was found last night on the roof of a fourstory walkup apartment house in Harlem. The police were seeking the killer and investigating a possible link with similar slaying nearby several months ago.

title: Commuters Lib
description: For hundreds of chronically frustrated Penn Central commuters it was a heady though harrowing experience: braving rain and snow, they piled out of a stalled local near Pelham the other morning, slogged a halfmile down the tracks through mud to the Mount Vernon station, watched three express trains whisk by, and finally leaped back onto the tracks en masse to stop and commandeer a fourth express which grudgingly deposited them at Grand Central 71 minutes late.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: The patriotic aspects of the Veterans Day holiday, providing an opportunity for the muster of armed contingents, posed a security problem yesterday for President Nixon's motorcade tour of Westchester that clearly lacked a standard solution.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The modernization of Yankee Stadium will begin at the end of the 1973 baseball season, City Public Works Commissioner Alfred C. Maevis of the Municipal Service Administration announced yesterday. The proposed modernization plans are now being designed, and when the renovation is completed, we will have a ballpark as uptodate any other stadium in the country, Commissioner Maevis said.

title: POLICE CHIEFS SAY PUBLIC IS HOSTILE
description: SALT LAKE CITY  The nation's police continue to regard themselves as a scorned minority in a hostile society, judging by some of the speches at the annual convention of the International Association of Chiefs of Police here last week.

title: ALICE M. MURPHY
description: Alice M. Murphy, corporate secretary of American Standard, Inc., and a former president of the Young Women's Republican Club of New York, died Sunday of a brain tumor in St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 42 years old and lived at 1 Lexington Avenue.

title: City Pushes Its Schools On Safety
description: School Chancellor Harvey B, Scribner has set Nov. 15 as the deadline for all city principals to submit plans for teacher and student safety in their schools.

title: Wife Informed by Phone
description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 23 (AP)Judith Silver Shapiro of Cincinnati said today that the Soviet Union had granted her husband a visa. Her husband, whom she last saw June 8, informed her of it when she telephoned him.

title: New Hampshire U. Elects
description: DURHAM, N. H., Oct. 23 (AP)Mrs. Mildred Horton of Randolph has been elected chairman of the University of New Hampshire board of trustees. Mrs. Horton is a former president of Wellesley College and WAVES commander during World War II.

title: Books of The Times
description: In a peculiarly fascinating scene in The Odessa FileFrederick Forsyth's followup to The Day of the Jackalthe author describes with extreme technical clarity how a hired assassin sits down at a table in his hotel room in the south of Germany and constructs a makeshift bomb. The bomb and its triggering device are made of an odd assortment of common materialsan empty tea canister, a battery, five rubber erasers, a hacksaw blade, a light bulb, six condoms, some tape, and a pound of plastic explosive. And it is put together in the most obvious way. But it is clever, and it worksalthough not on the victim for whom it is intended, a young German freelance correspondent named Peter Miller, who has inadvertently stumbled on a ring of SS men operating inside postwar Germany and trying to help Egypt destroy Israel by means of rockets loaded with bubonic plague germs and radioactive cobalt.

title: NIXON VISITS AREA AND PLEDGES FIGHT ONTIG SPENDERS
description: BOHEMIA, L.I., Oct. 23 President Nixon, telescoping virtually all of his New York metropolitan area campaigning into a single day's swing through Westchester County and Long Island, sounded familiar campaign themes and called for pluralities greater than those he received in the 1968 election.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: YONKERS, Oct. 23Fresh Yankee, bought for $900 as a yearling in 1964 and winner since then of $1,294,252 on harness tracks round the world, was retired today by Duncan MacDonald of Sydney, Nova Scotia, the owner. She is the secondleading moneywinner among harness horses. Une de Mai of France, has won $1,604,463.

title: AFRICANS TACKLE BORDER DISPUTE
description: LIBREVILLE, Gabon, Oct. 14 In 1900 France and Spain signed a treaty that established what is now the border between Gabon and Equatorial Guinea. But because the treaty was not explicit enough, a dispute flared recently between the two West African neighbors, and a fournation commission was formed to settle it.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI)Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today that United States attorneys in Florida had taken seven months to act on the spurious campaign letter accusing him of illicit sexual affairs.

title: Fighting Saints Defeated By Whalers in W.H.A., 5.1
description: BOSTON, Oct. 23 (UPI)The New England Whalers took 51 victory from the Minnesota Fighting Saints in a World Hockey Association game tonight.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23Since Mr. Nixon has been President, rape is up 22 per cent, an announcer observes in a matteroffact tone. Since Mr. Nixon has been President, aggravated assault is up 25 per cent.

title: Thomas Lyon White Dies; Architecture Partner, 70
description: GENEVA, N. Y., Oct. 23Thomas Lyon White, senior (partner in the architectural firm of White & Harvey, died last night. He was 70 years old.

title: TV: Of Thee I Sing
description: Back in 1931, Of Thee I Sing hit the Broadway musical stage, and thousands cheered. Tonight, in a special adaptation, it hits television and millions may wonder what the cheering was all about.

title: Air Force Asserts It Will Not Abandon Search for Boggs
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Oct. 23 (AP)Despite bad weather, the Air Force refused today to give up hope as the search for a light plane carrying the House Democratic leader, Hale Boggs, and three other men entered its second week.

title: Pan American Net Off
description: Pan American World Airways Inc. reported thirdquarter net earnings of $20million, or 50 cents a share, yesterday, down more than 20 per cent from the $25.5million, or 64 cents, it earned in the third quarter of 1971.

title: 7 SAW THEIR WAY OUT OF ME TOES
description: Seven pris, bners made a dar ing and well'planned escape from the Manhattan House Of Detention (the Tombs) early yesterday in the first jailbreak from the present building since it was opened in 1941.

title: EN FIGHTING WIDENS IN SOUTH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday. Oct. 24Extensive fighting was reported yesterday in the center of South Vietnam, with Communist forces concentrating their attacks around the city of Pleiku.

title: Auto Maker's Net Surges
description: DETROIT, Oct. 23  The Chrysler Corporation reported today that its thirdquarter earnings jumped to $31.9million, or 61 cents a share, from the yearearlier $6.2million, or 12 cents a share. The profit was the highest for a third quarter since 1950.

title: PUERTO RICAN DUE ON CHARTER PANEL
description: The New York City Charter Revision Commission established by Governor Rockefeller will name a Puerto Rican lawyer in Brooklyn as a temporary paid member today to give representation to both Brooklyn and Puerto Ricans.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The indifference of the Metropolitan Museum to the plight of the turnofthecentury houses on Fifth Avenue across from the museum's plaza defeated our efforts to save the houses from demolition until such time as the Landmarks Preservation Commission could hold its authorized hearings.

title: UTILITIES BILLING SCORED BY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23A committee of state officials who regulate public utilities said today that the latepayment charges imposed by most gas and electric companies were too high.

title: Gambino Leaves Hospital; To Be Called Before Jury
description: Carlo Gambino, reputed to be the most powerful figure in organized crime, has been released from Columbus Hospital and will now be called for questioning before a Brooklyn grand jury, Brooklyn District Attorney Eugene Gold said last night.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Even if we win tomorrow, said Sparky Anderson on the eve of the seventh game showdown in the World Series, my opinion won't change. I'll still think that the best team in baseball is Pittsburgh.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Peter J. Bridge, who was sent to jail for refusing to answer a grand jury's questions about a news article that he wrote for the now defunct Evening News of Newark, describes his life in the Essex County Jail in the following article. The dispatch, the second he has written for The New York Times from inside the jail, was sent out through the regular mail.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23The man at the door said he was from the famous Spoilsport Poll. We were ecstatic. An American dream had come true.

title: WHEAT PRICE OFF; SOYBEANS ARE UP
description: The Department of Agriculture hinted over the weekend that China might be in the market for additional United States wheat. China, whose wheat production was hurt by drought earlier this year, has bought some 160 million bushels of wheat in the world market, including about 15 million bushels from the United States in October.

title: House Contest
description: In this district you never know, Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal said yesterday. I'd be afraid to call It.

title: Rocket Hits Pnompenh
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 23 (Arnce FrancePresse) Two civilians were reported to have been killed and 10 wounded today when a 107mm, rocket struck the city center near the Cambodian Army general staff headquarters.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
