description: TWIN FALLS, Idaho, Oct. 23  After declining for several days to talk about the war, Vice President Agnew lashed out today at North Vietnam, accusing its Government of open aggression, in Southeast Asia.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: PARAMUS, Oct. 23  Like Golden Glovers clamoring for a chance to step into the ring with Muhammad Ali, close to 100 chess players of widely varying abilities and experience, turned out at the Bergen Mall Shopping Center today for an opportunity to face a few of the world's topranked players.

title: Personalities: Tanner Honored
description: Chuck Tanner, who charmed the moody Dick Allen into a happy slugger and the lowly, Chicago White Sox into pennant contenders in two seasons, was named yesterday the American League manager of the year by the Associated Press. Tanner received 213 votes in a poll conducted by sports writers and broadcasters, Eddie Kaska of the Red Sox finished second with 140 votes. Tanner became the Chicago manager three weeks before the team finished the 1970 season with a 56106 wonlost record and drew 589,891 fans. In two seasons he brought the club to an 8767 record that helped push the Chicago attendance to 1,186,028.

title: Lindsay Supports Proposal to Convert Forest Hills Project to a Cooperative
description: Mayor Lindsay has agreed to support a plan to convert the controversial lowincome Forest Hills housing project into a lowincome cooperative.

title: Two Parks Closed to Cars
description: Central and Prospect Parks will be closed to cars for the convenience of bicycle riders from 7 to 10:30 o'clock tonight and tomorrow night. The Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration reported erroneously last week that the midweek closings had ended for the season. They actually end after tomorrow night's bicycle riding.

title: Construction in Connecticut Is Halted by a Strike
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 23  Construction work in most of Connecticut was halted today by a laborers strike.

title: AUSTRIANS HARD HIT BY DOCTORS STRIKE
description: VIENNA, Oct. 23 (Reuters)A nationwide strike of thousands of doctors and dentists has almost paralyzed the Austrian health service and has hurt the civic pride of the average Austrian, at the same time: Austria has one of the lowest strike rates in Western Europe.

title: Israel's Hopes for Stability in Gaza Wane
description: GAZA, Oct, 23The thing to remember about Gaza, an Israeli officer in the military government here said today, is that nothing very good or very bad ever lasts very long.

title: Neumann's Sloop Takes Storm Trysail Club Race
description: HAMPTON, Va., Oct. 23Dr. Walter Neumann's 43foot sloop, Sitzmark, out of Pelham Manor, N. Y., was the winner yesterday of the Storm Trysail Club's fourth annual race to Chesapeake Bay.

title: Harold Boeschenstein, Founder Of OwensCorning, Dead at 76
description: Harold Boeschenstein, founder of the OwensCorning Fiberglas Corporation of Toledo, Ohio, a pioneer in this industry in the United States, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in the Carlton House Hotel. He was 76 years Old and lived in Perrysburg, Ohio, near Toledo.

title: McGovern Stresses Help for Veterans In Visit to Hospital
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23Senator George McGovern visited patients in the United States Naval Hospital here today to dramatize his Veterans Day pledge to provide jobs, education and health care for veterans of the Vietnam war.

title: Dee jays Inspect the Stars At Country Music Festival
description: NASHVILLE, Oct. 21Harold Hendren stood in the doorway of the Decca freeload room, shaking hands with assorted disk jockeys and songwriters, pickers and protnoters.

title: Credit Markets
description: Bond prices bounded ahead yesterday amid mounting evidence of progress toward an end to the fighting in Indochina.

title: Mexican Soccer Fans Riot
description: PUEBLA, Mexico, Oct. 23 (UPI)A riot erupted during a Mexican professional soccer game yesterday when players of both teams and hundreds of fans battled on the field in Puebla, a site of matches during the 1970 World Cup Soccer tournament. At least three players and several fans required hospital treatment, authorities raported today.

title: MAINE ATOM PLANT IS PUT IN OPERATION
description: WISCASSET, Me., Oct. 23 (AP)The nuclear reactor at the Maine Yankee Atomic Power Company plant here was put into operation for the first time at 4:55 A.M. today.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23The editor of the Republican National Committee newsletter said today that he had sent various Democratic Presidential aspirants information about other contenders during the New Hampshire primary campaign because he had wanted to do what I could to help them attack each other.

title: Lawyer Heads Home for the Aged
description: The election of William I. Riegelman, a partner in the law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver and Jacobson, as president of the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged was announced yesterday.

title: Akron Lawyer Jailed for False Statement to Bank
description: CLEVELAND, Oct, 24Don Lowers, the 43yearold Akron lawyer who masterminded an $11million scheme promising a high return on investment, was given a twoyear prison sentence today for giving a false financial statement to a bank.

title: 3 Teachers and 3 Parents Held Up in Queens School
description: Three youths walked unchallenged into a quiet elementary school in Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday morning and robbed three teachers and three parents, saying that they were armed with guns.

title: Bill May Help to Safeguard Mayan Art Works From Theft
description: WASHINGTONIn its rush io adjourn, Congress took sufficient time last week to pass bilt, that may help preserve the remnants of Mayan and other preColumbian civilizations from the growing depredations of art thieves.

title: GUILD ENDS STRIKE ON CLEVELAND PAPER
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 24  A strike by 225 editorial department employes against The Plain Dealer that shut down the paper for three clays ended today with ratification of a 29month agreement.

title: U.S. Pushing Retraining Of Saigon's Entire Army
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 24United States Army instructors are putting the entire South Vietnamese Army through a brief but intensive retraining program in a tacit acknowledgment that Vietnamization has not worked as American officials had hoped.

title: Southern Railway Raises Earnings For Third Quarter
description: Net income of the Southern Railway, one of the nation's most profitable carriers, climbed to $18.6million, or $1.25 a share, in the third quarter from $15.1million, or $1 a share, in the 1971 period, W. Graham Claytor Jr., president, announced yesterday.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX MOVE DOWN A BIT
description: Trading overthecounter and on the American Stock Exchange reflected yesterday disappointment over the reported reluctance of President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam to allow Communists to participate in a coalition government.

title: HIGH COURT TAKES CASE ON RAIL TAX
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a railroad is entitled to a tax deduction for depreciation of Governmentfinanced facilities in case the Government says can sharply affect tax revenue.

title: She's Found That Career Can Be Hard on a Family
description: NASHVILLE, Oct. 24She was almost 14 years old when she was marriedLoretta Webb from Butcher Hollow marrying Mooney Lynn, a coal miner like her daddy. They moved across country and her only singing was lullabies to her babies, four within four years.

title: WORKER FOR G.O.P. RECALLS SABOTAGE
description: TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 24A 26yearold Tampa secretary has said that she was part of Republican scheme to sabotage the Presidential campaign of Senator Edmund. S. Muskie in Florida last winter.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 24  The United Automobile Workers union threatened today to reverse itself and oppose the transportation bond referendum if Transport of New Jersey, the state's largest bus company, goes ahead with its plans to purchase Belgianmade buses with its proceeds from the bond issue.

title: Man in the News
description: When he was young, President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam recalled one day last summer, he went to the underground to cooperate with the Communists in resisting the French. It was 1945.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I hope that many of your readers will join me in thanking you for having published Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's Nobel lecture [OpEd Sept. 30 and Oct. 7], which he was unable to deliver due to the very forces he decried in the lecture. Now, a Committee of American Intellectuals has been formed to protest the Soviet treatment of Solzhenitsyn.

title: Rhode Island Jobless Down
description: PROVIDENCE, Oct. 24 (AP)Rhode Island's unemployment rate fell to its lowest level in 10 months at midSeptember, with 24,200 workers off their jobs, state labor officials said today. Mary Hackett, director of the Department of Employment Security, estimated the jobless rate at 6 per cent last month, compared with 6.7 at midAugust when 27,200 workers were idle.

title: S.E.C. Sets Up Committee For Guidelines to Brokers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24An industry advisory committee whose job will be to work out guidelines that brokers should follow in dealing with customers and in supervising their own employes was appointed today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Umpires All but Cleared In Gambling Investigation
description: PIKESVILLE, Md., Oct. 24 (AP)  No formal disciplinary action is planned against any of the umpires whose names were found in a notebook seized last month during a Baltimore area gambling raid, major league officials said today.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 24 (UPI)The Federal Reserve Board said today its new regulations for altering bank reserve requirements and streamlining check collection procedures would take effect Nov. 9.

title: High Court Bars Doctor's Plea To See Kennedy Autopsy Data.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The Supreme Court declined today to hear a challenge to the authority of the United States Archives to keep secret some of the autopsy materials and other items relating to the assassination of President Kennedy.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: FREEHOLD, Oct. 24Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin vigorously denied today that he had attempted to win a $600,000 highway contract for a Matawan contractor in 1970 in return for a $10,000 contribution to the state Republican finance committee.

title: Security Tightened at the Tombs As 7 Escapees Remain at Large
description: Security was tightened yesterday at the Manhattan House of Detention, and the number of visitors was sharply reduced as correction officials sought to unravel the mystery of how seven inmates escaped at dawn on Monday.

title: Earnings Soar at Burlington
description: Burlington Industries, Inc., the nation's largest and most diversified textile producer, showed a sharp rise in earnings in its fiscal fourth quarter from the depressed yearearlier level, the company reported yesterday. Earnings in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 rose 23.6 per cent on a sales gain of 5.2 per cent.

title: Amin Still Hospitalized
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Oct. 24 (AP)The Government radio reported today that President Idi Amin, who was admitted to the hospital yesterday, spent a comfortable night and was suffering from a sore throat.

title: 2 Views in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Oct. 25The curtailment of bombing is seen here as both a gesture of goodwill to the North Vietnamese and as a form of pressure on President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam.

title: M'GOVERN LINKS NIXON TO HAWKS
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 24Senator George McGovern accused President Nixon today of having needlessly prolonged the war in Vietnam to satisfy rightwing war hawks.

title: Frelighuysen, Disputing a Times Article, Cites Federal Backing of His Immigration Bill
description: The director of the Newark office of the Immigration and Naturalization Service said yesterday that there was no evidence of a criminal record or criminal associations on the part of the beneficiary of a private immigration bill sponsored by Representative Peter H. B. Vrelinghuysen, New Jersey Republican.

title: PARENTS SCUFFLE Al SCHOOL DOORS BARRED TO BLACKS Canarsie Protesters Seek to Register 29 Pupils in Defiance of Edict SCRIBNER IS CRITICIZED His Reversal of Decision on Tilden House Youths Is Termed a Sellout
description: The parent of 29 black children unsuccesflly tried to push their way past policemen and barricades yesterday to register their children at Canarsie's John Wilson Junior High School 211 in defiance of an order by Chancellor Harvey B. Schribner, who reversed an earlier directive and barred the students from entry.

title: Echoes of 1968
description: President Thieu's grudging prediction that there may soon be a ceasefire in Indochina reinforces speculation that Washington and Hanoi are close to agreement on terms for a cessation of hostilities. But the South Vietnamese leader has made clear that he will do all in his power to block a political settlement, again sharply rejecting any coalition with the Communists and setting conditions for a ceasefire that may not be attainable.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: GENEVAIt is precisely ten years since Uganda became the 110th member of the U.N., bringing the socalled AfroAsian bloc to exactly half the total membership. Both the latter figure (now 128) and the proportion of states from Africa and Asia are today even larger, although the concept of a bloc is fading.

title: IRISH OFFICIAL, HERE, WARNS AGAINST I.R.A.
description: Desmond O'Malley, Ireland's Minister for Justice, yesterday asked Americans to stop contributing money to the Irish Republican Army.

title: Status of Soviet Exit Tax Unclear
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 24  The Soviet Union is perpetuating uncertainty about the status of its controversial emigration tax despite the fact that almost all of the some 190 Jewish families who have been authorized visas in the last week have been exempted from paying it.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP)Twentyfive black businessmen endorsed president Nixon today, saying that the Republicans had tripled aid to minority entrepreneurs over the last four years.

title: Man Smashes 45 Windows
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 29 (UPI) Douglas Vollrath, 21 years old, who crashed through 45 plate glass windows along a srteet here before he was restrained by the police yesterday, was reported in satisfactory condition today. The police said Mr. Vollrath had told a psychiatrist at the hospital that he had taken a drug, believed to be LSD, Sunday night.

title: TreePlanting Celebration Marks The Commercial Boom in Yorkville
description: The East MidManhattan Chamber of Commerce held ceremony yesterday to celebrate the planting of eight honey locust trees on a commercialized stretch of 86th Street.

title: Charter Review Panel Discovers Brooklyn Balance Is Missing
description: The City Charter Review Commission discovered yesterday that Raymond J. Suarez, a proposed new member who was recruited to give Brooklyn representation on the panel, was not a resident of that borough.

title: G.M. Inventory Lag Hampers Dealers
description: DETROIT, Oct. 24Sales of new cars fell behind last year's record pace in the middle third of October. A lag at the General Motors Corporation accounted for the decline, and G.M. complained that its dealers were short of cars.

title: Laotian Reiterates Hope of CeaseFire
description: PARIS, Oct. 24Prince Souvanna Phouma, the Premier of Laos, said today that despite the hardline speech delivered by President Nguyen Van Thieu in Saigon, he remained optimistic about an Indochina ceasefire in the near future.

title: MATTHEW SPINKA, 82, CHURCH PROFESSOR
description: CLAREMONT, Calif., Oct. 24 Dr. Matthew Spinka, professor emeritus of church history at Hartford (Conn.) Theological Foundation, died yesterday at nursing home here. He was 82 years old.

title: Austin Carr of the Cavaliers sliding into Walt Frazier in the first period last night. Carr was charged with a
description: Despite the addition to the opposition of Lennie Wilkens, who surprised himself by playing 30 minutes in his first National Basketball Association outing of the season, the Knicks had little trouble in bombing the Cleveland Cavaliers, 12390, last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Arts and Crafts With Vibrancy
description: The latest objects shown by decorative arts museums are generally of no more recent vintage than the early 19th century. More contemporary possessions are usually stashed away in a storage cellar. Thus the astonishment of many decorative arts experts when they learned that Prof. Robert Clark was mounting the current Princeton Art Museum exhibitionthe Arts and Crafts Movement in America from 1876 to 1916.

title: Excerpts From Thieu's Address to the Nation on the New Proposal for Peace
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 24 (Reuters)Following are excerpts from an unofficial translation of the address delivered by President Nguyen Van Thieu tonight on South Vietnamese radio and television:

title: 2 JOIN THE CAST OF MILLER'S PLAY
description: Zoe Caldwell and George Grizzard are the latest major replacements in the forthcoming production of Arthur Miller's play, The Creation of the World and Other Business, whose opening now has been set for Nov. 30 instead of Nov. 20 at the Shubert Theater.

title: Private Immigration Bills Found to Drop Sharply
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The number of private immigration bills introduced and passed by Congress dropped sharply in the 92d Congress after a House Judiciary subcommittee tightened its rules for handling the measures.

title: Nixon Honors Policeman
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP)  President Nixon, honoring the Policeman of the Year, said today, It's justice that we wantnot just law and order. Mr. Nixon received Patrolman Jake Miller of New Orleans and 10 honorablemention winners in the Oval Office.

title: MUVERN LINKS NIXON TO SINKS
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 24Senator George McGovern accused President Nixon today of having needlessly prolonged the war in Vietnam to satisfy rightwing war hawks,

title: CIVIL SERVICE UNION IN CITY BACKS NIXON
description: Solomon Bendet, president of the chapter representing nearly 10,000 employes of various state agencies in the city, said at a news conference that it was the first time the unit had ever endorsed a Presidential candidate. The decision, he said, was voted by a 2to1 majority of the 100 delegates on the union's executive committee.

title: In Bonn Campaign, the Stress Is on Imitsch
description: BONN, Oct. 24One of the words most used in West Germany's campaign for the federal election Nov. 19 is image, borrowed from English and pronounced imitsch, and the three chief candidates are struggling to live up to publicrelations projections drawn up for them.

title: Oil, Oil Everywhere
description: ANCHORAGEI do not agree that there is a world energy crisis. We are not running out of resources worldwide.

title: 8Seat People Mover Gets Trial in TrafficChoked Morgantown, W Va.
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va, Oct. 24Patricia Nixon Cox, the President's daughter, took flawless ride today on what is billed as the world's first personal rapid transit system. She said it was more fun than Disneyland.

title: CORONA'S LAWYER DISPUTES JUDGE
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., Oct. 24The trial of Juan V. Corona, who is accused of mass murder, resumed here today in a session marked by a sharp exchange between the presiding judge and the defense attorney, Richard Hawk.

title: Westinghouse: New Generator
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported here yesterday development of a superconducting alternating current generator that could provide a new standard of power generation.

title: Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: AllAmerican
description: No onenot even other blacks who soon followed him into the major leaguescould know what Jackie Robinson endured in that 1947 season when he broke baseball's color line as a Brooklyn regular. His burden was not primarily the taunts or the occasional physical abuse he absorbed from Dodger opponents; nor was it the early hostile attitude of some of his own teammates.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 24 (AP)Gaylord Perry, a pitcher for the Cleveland Indians, led the American League complete games, with 29, and was tied with Wilbur Wood of the Chicago White Sox with the most victories, 24, during the 1972 baseball season.

title: Long Prods Nixon on Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, called on President Nixon today to sign H.R. 1, the big Social Securitywelfare bill, as soon as it reached his desk. He issued his statement from his Washington office.

title: And Now the Esso Name Is History
description: The gavel came down. A low voice, speaking to the side and not directly into the microphone, said, 'This was the last stockholders meeting of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

title: Hemingway's Letters Tell of Fitzgerald
description: The strangely ambivalent relationship between two of this country's foremost novellistsErhest Hemingway and F. Scott Fitzgeraldis pitilessly traced in a series of letters that Hemingway wrote between 1949 and 1951 to Arthur Mizener, Fitzgerald's biographer, and that are due to be auctioned Tuesday at Sotheby Parke Bernet.

title: Summons Flood Doesn't Happen
description: The storm of summonsissuing that union policemen threatened to unleash yesterday on the subways in their contract dispute with the Transit Authority proved to be a zephyr.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: LAST CALL ANGERS GRANT OF VIKINGS
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (UPI)Bud Grant, the Minnesota Vikings coach, thought his team was beaten by an improper call last night and, up to a point, coach Abe Gibron of the Chicago Bears agreed with him. The Bears survived a frenzied finish to beat the Vikings, 1310.

title: Communists in Cambodia Attack Provincial Capital
description: PINIOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 24 (UPI)  Communist forces launched a ground attack at dawn today against the besieged provincial capital of Takeo but were driven back by allied jet fighters, the Cambodian military command reported.

title: Mortgage Rates Unchanged
description: Interest rates on home mortgages were essentially unchanged in September, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The peace terms for Indochina that are now under such active discussion have been variously defined by Hanoi and Saigon, but Washington remains silent, as if it were a mediator rather than a party to the war. Indeed, mediation may be. Henry A. Kissinger's essential role at this point as he seeks a ceasefire and exit for the United Slates, with or without a promising deal on the political future of South Vietnam.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Off at Monthly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Government's monthly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Nixon Outlay Tops McGovern by 2 to 1
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 President Nixon's main national campaign organization has outspent Senator George McGovern's by about 2 to 1 in the Presidential campaign, official campaign financial statements disclosed today.

title: ROBERT SPINNER, 48, LED DATA CONCERN
description: NORTH CALDWELL, N. Oct. 24Robert E. Spinner, president and chairman of the board of SDA Information Sciences, a market research and data communications concern in New York, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital, Montclair. He was 48 years old and lived here.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 24Governor Cahill announced today that he was creating a state task force that would attempt to help New Jersey's cities clean up their streets and cut down their crime.

title: Books of The Times
description: The ugliness of life in America today seems to provoke beautiful books. Our best writers are at their best in describing the sense of loss, the loneliness, the absurdity, the anxiety, the yearning many of us feel. The pathology of our society fills their pens with paradoxes, ironies, pathos, even poetry. Our failures are great enough to lend grandeur to theft diagnoses.

title: One Killed, 4 Hurt in Blast
description: CLOVIS, N.M., Oct. 24 (UPI) A welder's torch caused dust explosion in a grain elevator today, killing one man and injuring four other workers. The blast in El Rancho Milling Company killed Pedro Sandoval, 40 years old, of Clovis. The other men were hospitalized in fair condition.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The Supreme Court let stand today the New Jersey Supreme Court's decision upholding the constitutionality of a special law creating a race tracksports complex in the Hackensack Meadows.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: The New York Public Library, which normally keeps its rhetoric on the shelves, braced itself for a rash of investive last night as John Kenneth Galbraith squared off against. William F. Buckley Jr. in a $100aplate dinner debate.

title: EXHEALTH CHIEF HITS TOBACCO ADS
description: Dr. Luther L. Terry, the former surgeon general who released the first reports linking cigarette smoking and cancer, said yesterday that he would like to see all cigarette advertising banned.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Oct, 24 (AP)  A Nebraska football star, Johnny Rodgers, was found guilty in Lancaster County District Court today of operating a motor vehicle while his driver's license was revoked. The charge carries a mandatory sentence of 30 days in jail and a oneyear suspension of the driver's license, but Rodgers could be placed on probation if the adult probation office and Judge Herbert Ronin concur.

title: U. N. Gives Consortium the Job Of Clearing Key Bengali Port
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24A contract to clear sunken vessels from the approach channel of Chalna in Bangladesh was signed today by the United Nations and a group of international salvage concerns.

title: Guttmacher Honored By Parenthood Group
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 24 (AP)Dr. Alan F. Guttmacher of New York a birth control pioneer who advocates liberalized abortion laws, received today the Planned Parenthood Federation of America's highest award.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 24 (UPI)About 50 Roller Derby skaters wore street shoes as they began picketing the office of the International Roller Derby League yesterday. A spokesman said the skaters want the minimum salary of $2,500 increased to $6,000, job security, a 40week season and improved travel allowances.

title: Grand Jury Finds No Evidence In Its Inquiry on Newark Official
description: NEWARK, Oct. 24An Essex County grand jury found without substance today allegations that the appointment of Robert Notte as executive director of the Newark Housing Authority had been Supported by organized crime.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CHARLESTON, Ill., Oct. 24 (UPI)A campaign worker for Senator McGovern said yesterday that he was approached earlier this year by a man claiming to be a Republican party worker and was asked to participate in political spying:

title: Cancer Society Head Named
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 24 (AP)Dr. Arthur G. James of Columbus has been named president of the American Cancer Society, succeeding Dr. Hamblin Letton of Atlanta.

title: Personalities: Erving Injunction Upheld
description: Another round was completed yesterday in the Julius Erving case. A threejudge panel headed by Harold R. Medina, in answer to Erving's appeal of an injunction prohibiting him from playing with any other professional basketball team other than the Virginia Squires, affirmed the Federal. District Court's decision to continue the injunction until an arbitrator was named in the contract dispute.

title: LTV Offers a Refund Plan On Its 6% Debentures
description: The LTV Corporation announced yesterday a plan to refund through an exchange offer its 61/2 per cent debentures scheduled to mature June 1, 1973.

title: Pyongyang Asks Seoul to Alter Policies
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 24 North Korea said today that South Korea must discard its antiCommunist laws and policies if the NorthSouth Red Cross talks on reuniting families separated by the division of the country are to succeed.

title: People and Business
description: To celebrate the 75th anniversary of its London branch, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company gave a luncheon yesterday at Claridge's, the London hotel, for a group of British financiers and businessmen. After coffee was served, Ellmore C. Patterson, chairman and chief executive officer of the large American bank, stood up to caution his audience that London could lose its supremacy as a world capital of finance if it put heavy restrictions on the operations of foreign banks.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) The Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization, representing 7,500 Federal employees, has announced its endorsement of the reelection of President Nixon.

title: Stage: Lower Depths at City Center
description: Acting Company Gives Confident Production

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Regarding Mr. McGovern's idea of reducing corporation profits to pay for increased Social Security benefits: He doesn't realize that there are millions of frugal, small investors who are depending on the dividends from these profits.

title: Delaware Eleven Still No. 1
description: Unbeaten Delaware, which routed West Chester, 3114, last Saturday for its sixth football victory, remained No. 1 yesterday in the weekly Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference Division II voting for the Lambert Cup.

title: JUSTICES TO WEIGH PREGNANCY ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON; Oct. 24 The Supreme Court agreed today to decide if the military services discriminate unconstitutionally against female officers by discharging them when they get pregnant.

title: Heifetz in Rare Recital on Coast To Bolster Music School Fund
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24Some said it was his first recital in 17 years, some his first in only four years; it depends on what you mean by a recital, in any event, Jacha Heifetz gave his first big, formal, fulldress concert in a long time last night in the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion of the Los Angeles Music Center, and everyone was curious to know how he'd sound. The concert, with a $25 top, was given for the benefit of the scholarship funds at the School of Music of the University of Southern California, where Heifetz teaches. It was sold out and a great popular success.

title: RISE IN G.I. BENEFITS APPROVED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) President Nixon signed today legislation increasing GI Bill of Rights benefits to veterans of the Vietnam era and authorizing Federal aid to new state medical schools to operate in conjunction with the Veterans Administration. Some 200 veterans attended the White House ceremony.

title: New Low Is Set In Value of Pound
description: PARIS, Oct. 24The pound, which had been worth as much as $2.50 last June, fell to a record low of $2.3760 today, down more than a penny and a half from yesterday's close.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Columbus Hospital has filed a $1.15million damage suit against Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein, City Councilman Eldon R. Clingan and three others on charges that they conspired to deprive the hospital of its property, extort money and interfere with its management and operation.

title: SIGNAL TO ENEMY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The White House has ordered a temporary cessation of all bombing north of the 20th parallel in North Vietnam, Administration sources disclosed today.

title: BIG BOARD PRICES SHOW INCREASES
description: BIG BOARD PRICES

title: U.S. Assailed by Pathet Lao By MALCOLM W. BROWNE
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 24A delegation from the Pathet Lao told the Laotian Government here today that American influence in Laos must be eliminated before serious negotiations to end the decadeold civil war can bear fruit.

title: Nixon Help Sought For Last Veteran Of the Indian Wars
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (UPI) Lillian Fraske hopes President Nixon can do for her fatherthe nation's only surviving veteran of the 19th century Indian warswhat she said the Veterans Administration has not.

title: CLAIRE WINDSOR, ACTRESS, 74, DEAD
description: HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 24 (AP) Claire Windsor a star of the silent scren, died today at Good Samaritan Hospital, where she was rushed after collapsing in her apartment, apparently of a heart attack. She was 74 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Only with a keen sense of irony and bitter amusement can one read about the bold words used and the searching vision displayed by the wouldbe Vice President, R. Sargent Shriver, in his recent stirring speech before the student body of Notre Dame University.

title: REA Express Back After Judge Bars A Continued Strike
description: REA Express resumed surface shipments and normal Air Express service yesterday as a majority of striking workers went back to work following a fourday national strike.

title: Day of Silence Protest Is Held in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 24 (AP) Chileans stayed home today in observing a day of silence to protest the programs of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: Unwanted Merchandise
description: The central fact of the disgraceful school controversy in Canarsie is that 31 black children have been shuttled back and forth like so much unwanted merchandise. Whatever the overt and hidden objections to the pupils' assignment to Junior High School 211, those who stood in the schoolhouse door to deny them access must bear on their consciences responsibility for the indelible damage done to young minds and hearts.

title: PARENTS SCUFFLE AT SCHOOL DOORS BARRED TO BLACKS
description: The parents, of 29 black children unsuccessfully tried to push their way past policemen and barricades yesterday to register their children at Canarsie's John Wilson Junior High School 211 in defiance of an order by Chancellor Harvey B. Schribner, who reversed an earlier directive and barred the students from entry.

title: Utility Income Hits Record
description: The General Telephone & Electronics Corporation reported yesterday new highs, in net income, telephone revenues and manufacturing sales for the third quarter and first nine months. Net income rose to $74million, or 63 cents a share, from the $52.9million, or 57 cents a share, reported in the three months ended on Sept. 30, 1971. The report placed sales and revenues at $1.07billion for the quarter, against $953million a year ago.

title: EDWIN WILLIS, 68, EX CONGRESSMAN
description: ST. MARTINVILLE, La., Oct. 24 (AP)Former Representative Edwin E. Willis, who began an investigation of the Ku Klux Klan as chairman of the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities, died tonight. He was 68 years old.

title: DR. H. HOWARD GREEN
description: NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 24Dr. H. Howard Green of Shorefront Park, former chief of the orthopedic department at Norwalk Hospital, died there last night of cancer. His age was 65.

title: White House Optimistic and Cautious in Describing Results of Kissinger's Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The White House combined some optimism with a dose of caution today in describing the results so far of Henry A. Kissinger's efforts in Paris and Saigon to achieve a negotiated settlement of the Vietnam war.

title: HEARINGS ARE SET ON II.D.A.'S FUTURE
description: Hearings on a bill to abolish the city's Housing and Development Administration and replace it with two new departments will begin Nov. 14, Councilman Edward L. Sadowsky announced yesterday.

title: Wax and Lava Reactions Clues to Ocean Mystery
description: Experiments with candle wax and observations of churning lava in a Hawaiian crater have thrown light on one of the most puzzling aspects of ocean floors throughout the world.

title: Q's Rout Cougars, 123109
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 24 (AP)The San Diego Conquistadors won their fifth game in a row tonight as they beat the Carolina Cougars, 123109

title: 18 BROKERS PUT ON WARNING LIST
description: Eighteen Wall Street brokerage firms in financial difficulty have been placed on a special surveillance list by the New York Stock Exchange, James J. Needham, chairman of the exchange, disclosed here last night.

title: Charges Against Lavelle Dismissed by Air Force
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 The Air Force announced today the dismissal of courtmartial charges filed against Maj. Gen. John D. Lavelle by an Air Force lieutenant after what it called a thorough investigation and review of all facts and material. It said the charges had been dropped because the interests of discipline hal already been served.

title: A RECORD BUDGET VOTED BY SUFFOLK
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 24The Suffolk County Legislature approved a record $370million 1973 county budget today, up 24 per cent over last year's previous high.

title: Economic Analysis
description: In 1848 Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels put forth the thesis that world peace and a new world order would ultimately be founded upon the common economic interests of workingmen in all countries. Workers of the world, unite! proclaimed the Communist Manifesto.

title: Dance: Marathon Debuts
description: Yes, they are still dancing at the ANTA theater. Monday night, the Cliff Keuter Dance Company and the Elizabeth Keen Company made their first appearance in the continuing American Dance Marathon series there, sharing the bill with the Inner City Repertory Dance Company.

title: About Pro Football
description: The Washington Redskins will be in the local pro football scene the next three weeks because they play the Giants and Jets here on successive Sundays and then the Giants again in Washington. This is an awful lot of the Redskins. But it is an interesting outfit to watch, and, its record, five victories in six games, stands as second best in the league. The Redskins in many ways remind one of the Giants good teams in the 19581963 era. There is a handful of exceptional players, but only average talent at most positions. The team has a collective purpose about it, however, and its destiny is to win somehow, some way, most of its games.

title: Reporter Who Was Silent To Grand Jury Is Released
description: NEWARK, Oct. 24At 4:10 P.M. on the big wall clock in Room 602 of the New Jersey Superior Court here, Judge James R. Giuliano pronounced the six words that Peter J. Bridge had been waiting nearly three weeks to hear.

title: A $149 Winner Completes $448 Double at Aqueduct
description: Just before yesterday's running of the second race at Aqueduct, a septuagenarian in the crowd of 19,145, looked at the past performances of Philip M. Winchester's Sinamar and said:

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct, 24 United States Attorney John L. Briggs said today that there were some good suspects who might have helped distribute the bogus letter last winter defaming Senator Jackson and Senator Humphrey.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MAYS LANDING, N. J., Oct. 24  Atlantic City Race Course, which had its future cast in doubt last August by Gov. William Cahill, wound up its 60day meeting this year in a blaze of financial glory and hope.

title: Moody Blues Lifts Its Audiences To Instant Nirvana at Garden
description: What happens when the Moody Blues the ultimate apostles of cound as substance, of medium rather than message, appear at Madison Square Garden? For the jampacked audiences at Monday's two concerts, the answer was instant Nirvana. The revolution not only had come, it was already gone; the spirit of Hesse hovered in the air (somewhere in the area of the Knicks bench) and all the painful, bittersweet spirittraveling of late adolescence found its expression.

title: About Motor Sports
description: Remember the TransAm Championship  the Mustangs, Camaros, Javelins, Challengers, the factory teams and the name drivers? Say goodby to the TransAm as you've known it, because it is about to disappear. Its likely successor, a smallscale Le Manstype endurance race for mixed classes, is to be submitted for approval by the professional competition board and the board of governors of the Sports Car Club of America'If they really want a professional series next season, they do not have much choice.

title: Ivy League Roundup
description: Last weekend was notable for the collapse of The Big Red Machine in Cincinnati and the collapse of the Big Red Machine of Ithaca, N. Y. The latter, of course, refers to Cornell's dismal showing in a 3315 loss at Harvard Stadium Saturday. Jack Musick of Connell lamented: Harvard's team took charge at times when we thought we had them stopped. Crone [Eric] scrambled out of sure losses time and again, while our defense collapsed on thirddown situations. We did our worst job ever of tackling and of containing the quarterback.

title: 198 Sold at Yonkers
description: YONKERS, Oct. 24  The third afternoon of the Old Glory Horse Sale at Yonkers Raceway saw 198 head bring an aggregate of $431,400 today for an average of $2,179.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Senator Clifford P. Case's reelection campaign has raised almost five times as much money as that of his Democratic opponent, Paul J. Krebs, according to reports filed yesterday.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: NEW WILMINGTON, Pa., Oct. 24 (UPI)Westminster College, faced with possible dismissal after being placed on indefinite suspension by the National Collegiate Athletic Association last January, resigned from the organization today. The Titans were suspended for participating in the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics football playoffs last year.

title: Advertising:
description: Although J. Walter Thompson's billings for the third quarters of 1971 and 1972 were almost the same, its net income fell by 93 per cent. So while thirdquarter billings stood at $169.8million, net income was down to $70,000 from $959,000.

title: Tokyo Aide Reports Soviet Reluctance To Return 4 Isles
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 25 Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira of Japan returned to Tokyo this morning after having met in Moscow with Premier Alessei N. Kosygin and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union to begin negotiations for a peace treaty.

title: FASHION TALK
description: The unacknowledged banner under which Seventh Avenue is charging into spring could very well be less is more. Mies van der Rohe's architectural dictum is being applied to clothes and it's not a bad idea at all. Ralston provided the caftan, Chanel supplied the cardigan and Saint Laurent resuscitated the shirtdress. With these minimal ingredients, designers are turning out lowkeyed clothes, if you don't mind the sequins. The sequins are sprinkled over classic evening things, like liberal doses of salt on a basic steak.

title: Bar School Foils Burglars
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 (UPI) Burglars, apparently angered when they found that their loot was phony, threw it on the floor but escaped with $2,000 worth of office equipment. The robbery was reported yesterday by the International School of Bartending. The burglars got into one of the classrooms, only to find that the 60 liquor bottles they attempted to steal contained colored water and the cash they wanted to take was play money, both used to teach the students how to tend bar.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The main point now in this sensitive phase of the Vietnam peace talks is to get as secure a ceasefire as possible, guaranteed by the United States, the Soviet Union and China, and then a long pause to give time for really careful and private negotiations. It will not be easy but it is the first priority.

title: WHEAT FUTURES POST PRICE GAINS
description: Talk of the sale of 200,000 metric tons of hard winter wheat to China, equivalent to 7.4 million bushels, strengthened wheat futures prices on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

title: Raphael Soyer, Dean of Realists, Sees New York as My Country
description: At the age of 72he was born on Christmas Day, 1899, with his twin brother, Moses, in the dismal town of Borissoglebsk, RussiaRaphael Soyer has become the dean of American realist painters, a distinction that leaves him a little puzzled.

title: A Carolina Fugitive freed After Living 18 Years in Fear
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 24 (AP)John Henry Jones, who escaped from a North Carolina prison in 1954 and since then has lived in fear of discovery, is now a free man.

title: U.S. Pushing Retraining Of Saigon's Entire Army
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 24United States Army instructors are putting the entire South Vietnamese Army through a brief but intensive retraining program in a tacit acknowledgment that Vietnamization has not worked as American officials had hoped.

title: Chile WriteOff Cuts Results
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation reported yesterday gains in sales for the third quarter and first nine months of 1972. However, results fell sharply below 1971 levels, due entirely to the writeoff of its equity interest of $50.4million in El Teniente Mining Company of Chile, which Chile has nationalized, less a related incometax deduction of $24.2million. This produced an extraordinary deduction of $26.2million for both 1972 periods.

title: A.M.A. MAPS STEPS TO PARE OUTLAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Faced with declining membership and revenues, the American Medical Association has made a series of belttightening moves aimed at saving over $1million next year.

title: NORDIQUES SCORE OVER AFROS BY 53
description: QUEBEC CITY, Oct. 24 (UPI)  The Quebec Nordiques, sparked by two firstperiod goals by Reynald Leclerc, downed the Houston Aeros, 53, tonight in a World Hockey Association game.

title: 3 Linked to Pony Deaths
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 (UPI) Detectives said today that three youths questioned in connection with a rockthrowing attack on 27 ponies that led to the death of two of the animals had admitted their involvement. Lieut. Kenneth Schwartz said the boys told the police that they just wanted to see the horses run.

title: Two Injured in Derailment Of Freight Train Upstate
description: FORT MONTGOMERY, N. Y., Oct. 24 (AP)Five cars of Penn Central freight train derailed early today In southern Orange County, slightly injuring two trainmen. Railroad officials said faulty tracks were to blame.

title: EXPOLICE OFFICER HELD AS BAG MAN
description: A retired police lieutenant accused of being a bag man and connection between gamblers and the police was arrested in Brooklyn last night after he allegedly passed more than $5,000 to an undercover police agent.

title: Grand Jury Finds No Evidence In Its Inquiry on Newark Official
description: NEWARK, Oct. 24An Essex County grand jury found without substance today allegations that the appointment of Robert Notte as executive director of the Newark Housing Authority had been supported by organized crime.

title: Merger News
description: Pepsico Inc., which expanded recently into the wine business, is making a bid to gain control of the Rheingold Corporation, a leading Eastern brewer and the world's largest independent bottler of PepsiCola.

title: HOSPITAL AT CONEY IS SCENE OF PROTEST
description: A number of residents of the Coney Island and Brighton Beach sections of Brooklyn demonstrated at Coney Island Hospital last night, charging that poor and inept emergencyroom treatment had led to three recent deaths.

title: Business Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 24 (AP)Armand Hammer, an American oil magnate who just gave Russia a milliondollar Goya portrait, submitted proposals to the Soviet Government today on a deal he says could be worth billions.

title: Teachers in Indianapolis Arrested on Picket Line
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 24 (UPI)About 130 striking Indianapolis teachers were arrested as they picketed schools today. They were booked in the Marion County Jail while another 200. marched outside chanting, Let my people go.

title: American Express Lifts ThirdQuarter and NineMonth Net to Record
description: Increased income from insurance services and gains on sales of investment securities plus the higher income from travel and financial services lifted the American Express Company's thirdquarter and ninemonth results to new records, its report disclosed yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The fact that this country faces an energy crisis will not get a reaction from the public until one tries to turn on the airconditioner or lights and nothing happens. It will be too late then to build a refinery overnight, for they take at least three years to build.

title: Tow Truck Operators Vote For Work Stoppage Today
description: The Tow Truck Operators Organization voted last night to refuse to tow any cars in the city beginning at 7 A.M. today in a dispute over rates.

title: Bailing Out Big Business
description: Business talks about free enterprise but asks Government intervention in any financial crisis. The bailout of Lockheed Aircraft Corporation was a case in point. At about the same time, the White House almost intervened to save Penn Central but happily exercised restraint. The approach, as in the case of Lockheed, has been always exclusively political and always ad hoc, treating each situation individually. Now there is concern about the future of Grumman.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky, Oct. 24 (AP)  Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, assailed President Nixon today for his veto of a water quality bill passed by Congress, That hill was the product of two and a half years of nonpartisan work by both houses of Congress, V Senator Muskie said.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 24Volunteer physicians will enter state prisons here and at Rahway tomorrow morning to care for inmates diagnosed earlier by New Jersey National Guard medical units.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 24At 4:10 P.M. on the big wall clock in Room 602 of the New Jersey Superior Court here, Judge James R. Giuliano pronounced the six words that Peter J. Bridge had been waiting nearly three weeks to hear.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Forest Hills residents association ended more than 20 months of opposition to a controversial housing project by coming out in favor of a lowincome cooperative. However, the association wants three eightstory buildings instead of three 12story buildings, as proposed in the compromise plan endorsed by Mayor Lindsay, Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes and Simeon Golar, chairman of the city's Housing Authority.

title: SIGNAL TO ENEMY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The White House has ordered a temporary cessation of all bombing north of the 20th parallel in North Vietnam, Administration sources disclosed today.

title: CHARLES H. M'GLUE
description: BOSTON, Oct. 24 (AP)Charles H. McGlue, an authority on Massachusetts election laws and twice state campaign manager for Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, died last evening at his home. He was 83 years old.

title: Gold Cautioned by Suffolk On Immunity for Suspects
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Oct. 24The Suffolk County District Attorney, George J. Aspland, has told District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn to make certain that Brooklyn grand jury subpoenas of organizedcrime figures from Suffolk County do not inadvertently give immunity from prosecution to persons now on trial br under indictment or investigation here.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 24Vice President Agnew brought his confident campaign to upstate New York today and was confronted with the most effective harassment and least cooperative acoustics of his travels.

title: South Africa Shifts Value Of Rand and Fixes Parity
description: PRETORIA, South Africa Oct. 24, (Reuters)The South African rand was today devalued by 4.202 per cent, effective tomorrow, and returned to a fired parity from a floating rate.

title: 3 Die as English Bridge Falls
description: READING, England, Oct. 24 (AP)A bridge under construction near here collapsed today and sent 30 workmen plunging into a river. Officials reported that three of the men were killed and five injured. The survivors were dragged from pile of girders and concrete blocks.

title: ARIZONA FLOOD LOSS IS PUT AT $5MILLION
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 24 (AP) Federal and state emergency officials have tentatively estimated at $5million to $10million the damage from floods in southeastern Arizona that killed eight persons.

title: News Analysis
description: Last Thursday morning City School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner scored what seemed to be a major personal victory when he succeeded in getting, a group of angry white parents to abandon their threeday occupation of the John Wilson Junior High School 211 in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn. The white parents had been protesting Dr. Scribner's earlier order that the school had to admit a busload of black youngsters from Brownsville, and while his action did not resolve the lctngboiling controversy, it did defuse an immediate and potentially explosive situation.

title: SPEECH IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 24  President Nguyen Van Thieu said tonight that all the peace proposals discussed by Henry A. Kissinger and the North Vietnamese in Paris so far were unacceptable, and, in an ambiguous statement, he asserted that there were great difficulties in the way of ceasefire.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: IOWA CITY, Oct. 24 (UPI)A former University of Iowa basketball player filed a $5million suit against four university doctors today, charging them with negligence that made him go blind.

title: CANADIENS RALLY TO TOP ISLANDERS Al COLISEUM, 43
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Oct. 24Snmeclay it will turn for the Islanders.

title: Business Briefs
description: CORNING, N. Y., Oct. 24  Amory Houghton Jr., chairman of the Corning Glass Works, told security analysts here today that the company anticipates 1972 earnings to be significantly better than those of 1971, when Corning Glass earned $4.82 a share, or $5.27 before an extraordinary charge.

title: ExSecurity Chief of A.E.C. Indicted on Fraud Charges
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) The former security director of the Atomic Energy Commission was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges that he intended to defraud the A.E.C. credit union by inducing other employes to withdraw money for him.

title: Senate Contest
description: NASHVILLEWhen an antibusing move was narrowly defeated in the Senate recently, the Republican Senator from Tennessee, Howard H. Baker Jr., was a leader of the antibusing forces.

title: 3 DEAD AS HURRICANE BATTERS FIJI REGION
description: SUVA, Fiji, Oct. 25At least three persons were killed and nine injured by a hurricane that left a broad path of destruction in several South Pacific islands today. Roaring winds still hold this city of 80,000 people virtually immobilized, although the center of the storm passed this area early this morning headed southeast toward the Polynesian kingdom of Tonga.

title: SPEECH IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 24  President Nguyen Van Thieu said tonight that all the peace proposals discussed by Henry A. Kissinger and the North Vietnamese in Paris so far were unacceptable, and, in an ambiguous statement, he as serted that there were great difficulties in the way of a ceasefire.

title: STARS LATE TALLY TRIPS BLUES, 2 TO 1
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 24 (UPI)Bob Nevin scored with 8 minutes 16 seconds to play tonight to give the Minnesota North Stars a 21 victory over the St. Louis Blues in a National Hockey League game.

title: CELTICS WIN 8111, DOWNING BRAVES
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 24 (AP)Don Nelson and Jo Jo White contributed some clutch Shooting in the last 31/2 minutes, and the unbeaten Boston Celtics won their eighth National Basketball Association game tonight, beating the Buffalo Braves, 10597.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24 (AP)A former military attorney says that he was invited last fall to join a group planning to infiltrate Democratic campaigns to prevent any one candidate from dominating the primary elections.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The White House made its first move to investigate the Watergate bugging only two days after five men were caught in the headquarters of the Democratic party on June 17, according to papers filed at United States District Court here today.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CULVER CITY, Calif., Oct. 24 (AP)  The United States should withdraw from the United Nations because the international body is a center for organizing a world government, the American party Presidential candidate, John G. Schmitz, said today.

title: PLAY IT AS IT LAYS
description: AT THE BEEKMAN ON SUNDAY. ADVT.

title: More on Tap Tonight
description: There will be another nonbetting Sires Stakes event, this one for sophomore trotting colts and geldings, going for $40,625 Wednesday night. However, with only four entered, there will be a legitimate excuse for no betting on the outcome. All starters are assured of a piece of the purse. The victor will take down first and fifth money.

title: 2 in Heroin Case Sentenced
description: BOSTON, Oct. 24 (AP)Two French nationals convicted of importing $15million worth of heroin from France into the United States were sentenced in Federal District Court today to 19 years in prison. United States Attorney Joseph L. Tauro said Jean Claude Kella, 27 years old, of Paris, and Laurent Fiocconi, 32, of Toulon, pleaded guilty to a conspiracy indictment after five days of trial. The sentences were imposed by Federal District Judge William Murray.

title: Dance: Nijinsky, Clown of God Bows
description: NIJINSKY, CLOWN OF GOD (Aineriean errmlere), Ballet realed by Maurice Bejart; music, Pierre Henry with sequences from TchalkovskY's Palhe Nuge Symphony); set and costume design, Joelle Rouslan and Roger Bernard; lighting, Roger Bernard assisfed by Joe Calvin; hats, Marquerlle Gouilin; heads of the grotesques, Jacques Viersel. Presented by the Ballet of the Twentieth Century in association with the National Opera BelgulmTheatre Royal de la Monnale and Madison Square Garden prorductions, Inc. at the Felt Forum, Madison Square Garden Center.

title: Credit Markets
description: Reports that South Vietnam's President Nguyen Van Thieu would not accept a coalition government with Communists sent investors scurrying to the sidelines yesterday and a couple of key new bond issues thereby met a cool reception. The market opened broadly higher, continuing the peaceoriented advance that began late last week, but the Thieu statement dampened enthusiasm and the gains were diminished.

title: Scribner Is Sharply Criticized by Several Educators
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner was sharply criticized yesterday by educators, civil rights leaders and educational association for his handling of the Canarsie school situation.

title: HANOI ASSERTS THIEU IS OPPOSED TO PEACE
description: PARIS, Oct. 24The North Vietnamese spokesman here denounced President Nguyen Van Thieu's speech today as new proof that he is obstinately opposed to peace and national concord, that he is extremely belligerent.

title: Coffee, Labeled as Fertilizer, Reaches Town in Soviet, and Red Tape Ensues
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 24People the world over fall victim to the power of paper and the rigidity of bureaucracy. But rarely have the awe of documents and the iron hand of the Soviet bureaucracy been more simply captured than in the great fertilizer foulup.

title: Notes on People
description: After signing legislation to increase veterans educational benefits, President Nixon was greeting the veterans he had invited to the White House when one of them, Larry Kirk, caught the President's eye. Mr. Kirk, a 33yearold veteran who lost both legs below the knees and part of one arm in combat in Vietnam, told the President he wanted to become a White House fellow. About 20 of the prestigious fellowships are awarded each May to persons who are then assigned to assist White House officials.

title: Chinese Doctors See Computer for Doctor
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 24(UPI) Twelve Doctors from Communist China visited the headquarters of the 200,000member American Medical Association today and saw a computer that contains the names of every doctor in the United States. The Chinese gave the AMA a doll with which to study acupuncture.

title: Nixon Outlay Tops McGovern by 2 to 1
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 President Nixon's main national campaign organization has outspent Senator George McGovern's by about 2 to 1 in the Presidential campaign, official campaign financial statements disclosed today.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: About 300 politicians, many of whom served in the administration of Robert F. Wagner during his 12 years as Mayor, held a testimonial dinner for him last night.

title: Advertising:
description: Advertisers were clearly not happy with the editorial changes at Harper's Bazaar magazine under the leadership of James Brady. And they had an alternativeVogue.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP)President Nixon will make his fifth campaign radio broadcast tomorrow, the White House announced today. The topic will be Lhe Federal role in education.

title: 4 Die as Plane Crashes On Carrier Off Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Oct, 25An A6 FighterBomber crashlanded on the deck of the United States aircraft carrier Midway off Vietnam last night killing four men and injuring 22 others, a spokesman for the Navy said today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: In the scene that doesn't fade, the Brooklyn Dodgers are tied with the Phillies in the bottom of the 12th inning. It is 6 P.M. on an October Sunday, but the gloom in Philadelphia's Shibe Park is only partly due to oncoming evening. The Dodgers, championselect in August, have frittered away a lead of 131/2 games, and there is bitterness in the dusk of this last day of the 1951 baseball season. Two days ago, the New York Giants drew even with Brooklyn in the pennant race. Two hours ago, the numbers went up on the scoreboard: New York 3, Boston 2. The pennant belongs to the Giants unless the Dodgers can snatch it back.

title: Bridge:
description: The Metropolitan Championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association ended Monday night at the New York Hilton Hotel with a resounding triumph for youth. In the lastround match for the Swiss team title, eight of the 10 players were under 30 years old, and two were high school students.

title: Pasarell Defeats Froehling In German Tennis, 63, 62
description: ESSEN, Germany, Oct. 24 (AP) Charles Pasarell beat Frank, Froehling of Miami, 63, 62 today in the second round of an international tennis tournament.

title: By the Rules
description: The use of a rulebook work slowdown by the city's unionized transit policemen as a pressure tactic in contract negotiations extends a maneuver made familiar in the subways by the late Michael J. Quill. The fact that such slowdowns are also frequently an effective means of softening up the public toward acceptance of the particular union's demands raises a fundamental question beyond the current conflict.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 29Sargent Shriver struck angrily today at turncoat Democrats and liars who he said were conducting a smear campaign against his Presidential running mate, Senator George McGovern.

title: Ground Broken in East Harlem For $33Million Housing Project
description: At a groundbreaking ceremony yesterday for a $33million community development in East Harlem, people in the area expressed thanks to government agencies but saved the warmest praise for themselves.

title: GROSS SHOWS UP FOR QUESTIONING
description: Ted Gross, former Administrator of the City Youth Servlice Agency, was questioned for two and a half hours late yesterday by Commissioner of Inrestigation Robert K. Ruskin regarding fiscal irregularities in the agency.

title: Hotelevision Introduces Uncut Movies as Part of Room Service
description: Its called Hotelevision and the film industry is hoping it's here to stay.

title: Instructions Are Revised For PriceEarnings Table
description: In an article on Personal Finance Monday in The New York Times, incorrect instructions were given for using the accompanying table to compute the compound growth rates of a company's earnings.

title: Birbach Offers New Plan For Forest Hills Housing
description: Jerry Birbach, president of the Forest Hills Residents Association, announced yesterday that it favored a lowincome cooperative for Forest Hills, but one that would differ markedly from the idea to be considered tomorrow the Board of Estimate. This marked the first time in more than 20 months of bitter resistance that the Queens group had favored any kind of lowincome housing at the 8.46acre site, at 108th Street and 62d Drive.

title: The Price of Apathy
description: Is it really true that corruption is as American apple pie? Is it accurate to say that corruption is inherent in the American political system?

title: East Side Massage Parlor Raided 2d Time in a Week
description: For the second time in a week; a Romanstyle East Side massage parlor was raided early yesterday. The police arrested eight togaclad masscuses and the residentmanager on prostitution charges.

title: Frank L. Wiswall Is Dead at 77; Prominent in Saratoga Racing
description: Frank L. Wiswall, a former leader in Saratoga racing as chairman of the Saratoga Harness Racing Association and as president of the Saratoga Raceway, died yesterday at his home in Cantine, Me., after a long illness. He was 77 years cid.

title: Security Is Debated and Tightened at Schools Where Teachers Were Attacked
description: Some tightened security measures were put into effect and others were debated yesterday in a number of schools where teachers were assaulted in a rash of classroom robberies last week.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Political Committee10:30 A.M.

title: Smoky Midtown Fire Snarls Traffic
description: Smoke billowed over Fifth and Madison Avenues yesterday as a threealarm fire destroyed the Japan Kobe East Restaurant at 10 East 52d Street, drawing hundreds of spectators and tying up traffic in the area.

title: 3 Teachers and 3 Parents Held Up in Queens School
description: Three youths walked unchallenged into a quiet elementary school in Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday morning and robbed three teachers and three parents, saying that they were armed with guns.

title: LEADERS ACT TO END INDIAPAKISTAN RIFT
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 24Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India and President Zulfikar All Bhutto of Pakistan have exchanged letters in an effort to resolve a deadlock over the Kashmir ceasefire line, informed sources said tonight.

title: Nixon, in Tribute, Cites Robinson's Courage, Brilliance
description: Many tributes were paid yesterday to Jackie Robinson. They included:

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 24 (AP)Georgia's most successful professional sports team on the playing field, the Atlanta Chiefs of the North American Soccer League, has been retired because of a lack of fans.

title: WORKER FOR G.O.P. RECALLS SABOTAGE Secretary Asserts She Was Part of AntiMuskie Plot in Florida's Primary
description: TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 24A 26yearold Tampa secretary has said that she was part of a Republican scheme to sabotage the Presidential campaign of Senator Edmund S. Muskie in Florida last winter.

title: Work Slowdown Begun By Correction Guards
description: A rulehook work slowdown was started early today by guards in prisons run by the City's Department of Corrections to press demands for a new contract.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The neglected issue in the Presidential campaign might be called Richard M. Nixon vs. the Constitution.

title: COMMERCIAL BANKS CHARGED WITH BIAS
description: The Council on Economic Priorities, a nonprofit, publicinterest research group, charged yesterday that the commercial banking industry was guilty of broad racial and sexual discrimination in employment, and pervasive secrecy about its employment practices.

title: Market Place: Digital Is a Test Trading Halt
description: Investors may learn today whether an overnight trading halt can soften a selloff triggered by unexpected bad news.

title: CITY U. LETS ELDERLY TAKE FREE COURSES
description: The Board of Higher Education last night extended its openadmissions policy to people 65 years or older. Starting with the spring semester of 1973, they will be permitted to enroll tuitionfree in undergrad; uate courses in any college of the City University on a spaceavailable basis.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: M. R. Minto writes (letter Oct. 2) of the need for investigation and discussion of whether loans, instead of outright contributions, to the McGovern for President campaign were being made for possible baddebt tax deductions.

title: IDLE DICE CLEARS 7 FEET 2 INCHES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Harry Gill's Idle Dice, the most consistent performer on the circuit all season, captured the puissance (high jump) tonight at the Washington international horse show with an effort of 7 feet 2 inches.

title: BOGGS HUNT MISLED BY DEBRIS IN WATER
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Oct. 25 (AP)Debris was sighted today in the Gulf of Alaska near the flight path of a missing plane that carried the House Democratic leader, Hale Boggs of Louisiana, but it was identified as jetsam.

title: Sabra Rose Takes Trot In Sire Stakes, Pays $0
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 24Despite the preponderance of harness racing bettors who believe that any race worthwhile staging is worthwhile betting on, another nonwagering New York Sires Stakes event was presented at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. It had nine starters.

title: SQUIRES TRIUMPH OVERTAMS, 123111
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 24 (AP)Julius Erving scored 35 points and the Virginia Squires broke open the game in the last three minutes to defeat the Memphis Tams, 123111, tonight in American Basketball Association action.

title: Music: Kempe and 3 B's
description: The Royal Philharmonic, which is inaugurating the tenth season of Carnegie hall's International Festival a Visiting Orchestras, gave ils second concert in the anniversary series on Monday night. Rudolf Kempe, who bears the formidable title of Conductor for Life, put his ensemble through a program of three B'sBarber, Bruch and Berliozand left no one doubting that the R.P.O. can hold up its head in the company of the world's leading orchestras.

title: Jackie Robinson, First Black in Major Leagues, Dies
description: Jackie Robinson, who made history in 1947 by becoming the first black baseball player in the major leagues, suffered a heart attack in his home in Stamford, Conn., yesterday morning and died at Stamford Hospital at 7:10 A.M. He was 53 years old.

title: Chrysler Testing Wankel
description: BOSTON, Oct. 24 (UPI)The Chrysler Corporation, the last holdout among the major auto makers to consider using the Wankel, announced today it had started testing the rotary combustion engine.

title: 2 DETECTIVES HELD IN MAFIA INQUIRY Accused in Dismissal of Case Against 4 Suspects Linked to Junkyard Trailer
description: Two Brooklyn police detectives were arrested yesterday, accused of having arranged for the dismissal of a criminal case against four persons linked to a Canarsie junkyard trailer that has been named as a covert Mafia meeting place.

title: Orders for Durable Goods Up 1.8%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24New orders received by durablegoods producers increased by $640million, or 1.8 per cent, in September, largely because of an extraordinary increase in defense orders, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Having recently read that President Nixon has been enclosing election material with Social Security checks reflecting increased benefits, I feel that it is only fair, in this election year, that he enclose a message in all pay envelopes stating that next year the withholding tax to pay for this increase will be 35 per cent higher for those currently earning $10,800 or more. In addition, an increase of 11 per cent is scheduled for 1974.

title: CON EDISON TO TAP REMOTE SOURCES Plans to Test Method to Get Electric Power to City
description: An official of Consolidated Edison told a rateincrease hearing yesterday that the company was planning to test a method of transmitting electric power to the city from remote sources, such as Labrador, to fill power needs of the nineteen eighties.

title: SOLDIER IS KILLED BY ULSTER SNIPER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 24 (UPI)A sniper killed a British soldier with a single shot today in the Roman Catholic area of Lower Falls here, the army said.

title: Lakers Subdue Kings
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 24 (AP) Jerry West's 29 points paced the Los Angeles Lakers to 114.94 victory over the Kansas CityOmaha Kings tonight.

title: Missing Painting Blocks Franklin House Project
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24The National Park service announced today a worldwide search for a small 18th century watercolor.

title: Chinese Purchase U.S. Noodle Wheat With Japanese Aid
description: China has bought at least 300,000 metric tons of scarce American noodle wheat in deal arranged and financed by a big Japanese trading company in the last week.

title: Jackie Robinson, First Black in Major Leagues, Dies
description: Jackie Robinson, who made history in 1947 by becoming the first black baseball player in the major leagues, suffered a heart attack in his home in Stamford, Conn., yesterday morning and died at Stamford Hospital at 7:10 A.M. He was 53 years old.

title: Six Killed in Plane Crash
description: PEKIN, Ill., Oct. 24 (UPI)Six persons Were killed last night when an Aero Commander* 500 twinengine airplane crashed in a cornfield about four miles east of here. The victims, all from Morton, Ill., were identified as Joseph Jacobs; his wife, Flossie; their daughter, Susan, 17 years old, and their son, Thomas, 11, and another couple, Lee Shock and his wife, Eunice.

title: Art Institute and Symphony Share in Detroit Bequests
description: DETROIT, Oct. 24A woman practically unknown'in Detroit's cultural circles willed $500,000 to Detroit's Institute of Arts and another $500,000 to the Detroit Symphony and both bequests are without any restrictions.

title: Oil Group Lists Mixed Net
description: The oil industry turned in mixed financial reports yesterday for the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30.

title: PROF. JOHN D. WILD, YALE PHILOSOPHER
description: NEW HAVEN; Oct. 24John D. Wild, professor emeritus of philosophy at Yale University and a former president of the American Philosophical Association, died yesterday at the Yale New Haven Hospital. He was 70 years old and made his home in this city.

title: Outline of Understanding
description: CeasefireA ceasefire in place in South Vietnam. This would leave the Saigon Government, headed by President Thieu, in charge in most of the country, including main populated areas. The Vietcong, backed by 145,000 North Vietnamese troops who would remain in the country, would continue to control scattered areas. All American bombing and mining would stop and all American forces would be withdrawn, including advisers. There would be a prisoner exchange. Separate ceasefires would be negotiated in Laos and Cambodia. Rules on American and North Vietnamese military aid to South Vietnam would be set. Mr. Thieu has called for withdrawal of North Vietnamese troops but is expected to yield on that.

title: Moscow Paper Criticizes Abusers of Medical Aid
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 25The old babushka dialed 03, Moscow's special hot line for ambulance calls and emergency home medical care. Without conveying any sense of urgency she gave her name and address, and was urged to state her business.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Governor Cahill and Dr. Jerome H. Jaffee, director of the White House Special Action Office for Drug Abuse. Prevention, announced yesterday in Trenton that New Jersey had signed a $1million contract with the Federal Government for the expansion of statewide antidrug and rehabilitation programs.

title: Criminal Ambush
description: The despicable attack on two school buses carrying black and Puerto Rican youngsters to Elizabeth Blackwell Junior High School 210 in Ozone Park, Queens, has entered New York into active competition with the nation's most unreconstructed pockets of virulent bigotry.

title: UNION OFFICESEEKER REPORTS A SHOOTING
description: The police are investigating the report of a shooting Incident Tuesday night in Lower Manhattan involving John Smith, one of five candidates seeking the presidency of Local 1101 of the A.F.L.C.I.O. Communications Workers of America.

title: Judge Acquits Hanrahan of Plot In 69 Chicago Raid on Panthers
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 25State's Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan and 13 codefendants were acquitted today by a judge of conspiring to obstruct justice in connection with the police raid in which a Black Panther leader, Fred Hampton, was slain nearly three years ago.

title: An Appraisal
description: Sir John Hicks of Oxford and Kenneth Arrow of Harvard are essentially economists economists. Neither writes for the popular press or runs for political office. But their esotericappearing writings provide the new theoretical systems out of which legislation of the future will be shaped. Hicks's magnum opus, Value and Capital, was published back in 1939 when Arrow was still an earnest student at C.C.N.Y. The book bristles with mathematical equations. The equaLions are misleadingly penned info an appendix ghetto, but their spirit permeates the innocentlooking pages of text.

title: Business Briefs.
description: DETROIT. Oct. 25Ford Motor Company said today its dealers sold 91,711 cars in midOctober, down 2 per cent from the 93,238 the year before. This brought the industry Oct. 1120 total to 318,445 retail deliveries, down 4.7 per cent from 334,290 a year ago.

title: People and Business
description: It has to be an occasion when the Mayor of New York ventures forth to Wall Street, and yesterday was no exception. The Mayor was the guest of honor at the opening of an investment information center  a vastly expanded version of the one in Grand Central Stationat the new headquarters building of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 26 (UPI)  The Hanoi radio in an Englishlanguage broadcast heard here said:
