title: Towmen, in Rate Protest, Tie Up Roads for 3 Hours
description: A morninab nightmare of clogged roadways, snail's pace traffic, tension and temperigniting frustration assailed thousands of motorists yesterday when towtruck operators seeking increased rates refused to work and apparently staged a stallin.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It was saddening to an old admirer of James Reston to see him brand Senator McGovern's proposals for peace in Vietnam as virtually a formula for surrender [column Oct. 11].

title: Harvard and Oxford Professors Share Nobel Prize in Economics
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 25The Nobel Memorial Prize for economics, went today to an American and a Briton whose theories help to assess business risk and government economic and welfare policies.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Federal Government disclosed that it would build a 44story annex to the fiveyearold Federal office building in Foley Square. The structure, which will be the tallest Government building in the nation, will be started no later than January, according to the General Services Administration.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Scapegoat
description: A cartoon in the influential Indian Express recently showed Prime Minister Indira Gandhi receiving a report from her party president, S. D. Sharma, who tells her: This week's C.I.A. activities include four pricerise demonstrations, seven buses hijacked by students, plus one cyclone in Orissa.

title: Several Men Attack School Buses Here; 8 Students Treated
description: Several white men attacked two buses carrying black and Puerto Rican children to a Queens junior high school yesterday morning, smashing the windows with pipes and dumping oil on the students.

title: Denver Area Evacuated
description: GLENDALE, Colo., Oct. 25 (UPI)Police evacuated 3,000 persons from their hoMes in a sixblock area of this Denver suburb yesterday because construction crew accidentally cut into a natural gas main. The area was evacuated and blocked off for two hours until repairs could be made on 20inch main distribution line.

title: White House Aide Assails Criticism by Black Caucus
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) A White House aide charged today that criticism by the Congressional Black Caucus of Sammy Davis Jr. and other black entertainers for supporting President Nixon was insuiting, outrageous and posturing hot air.

title: Wildcat Strikes Hit Israeli Government and Industry
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 25Thousands of Israelis, from customs clerks to doctors, have been walking off their jobs in recent weeks.

title: Personalities: Anderson Is No. 1 in His League
description: George (Sparky) Anderson, whose Cincinnati Reds failed in the World Series, was honored yesterday as National League manager of the year. He said, I have nothing to complain about. How can you complain when you've got steak in your mouth? Anderson added, If I weren't here, I'd be painting houses, so I can't kick. Anderson, whose Reds have lost two of the last three World Series, beat out Bill Virdon of Pittsburgh for managerial honors in the Associated Press Poll. Anderson polled 271 votes to 179 for Virdon. Gene Mauch of Montreal was a distant third in the balloting.

title: IN THE NATION
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 25The newspapers here, as might seem to befit the heartland of America, are supporting Richard M. Nixon for reelection. So are hundreds of others across America, in one of the strangest paradoxes of a paradoxical election.

title: Charges Abuse of Power
description: DETROIT, Oct. 25Senator George McGovern, making his harshest attack on the President, declared tonight that the United States faced a moral and a constitutional crisis, of unprecedented dimensions because of widespread abuse of power by the Nixon Administration.

title: Coast and Hawaii Ships Struck By Masters, Mates and Pilots
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25 (UPI)Masters, mates and pilots of American flag ships on the West Coast and Hawaii went on strike today after talks with shippers over a new labor contract had broken down.

title: Styles That Look Lived In
description: PARIS, Oct. 25One hot day in Cairo a young Egyptian saw a Saint Laurent dress in the street. I'm going to Paris, he announced.

title: U.S. Aides Call Foe's Military Position Weak
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 25American officials said today that the Communists ha& offered significant new concessions in the Vietnam peace negotiations because they were in a badly weakened military position.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Hanoi Says U.S. Backs Off After an Accord in Paris
description: HONG KONG, Thursday, Oct. 26The Hanoi radio said today that the United States and North Vietnam agreed in Paris on a ceasefire agreement to be signed in Hanoi and Paris this month, but that the United States backed off, claiming that it was having difficulties in Saigon.

title: Business Briefs.
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Oct. 25 (UPI)Sheik Ahmad Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabian's Minister of Oil and Minerals, said today that other oil producing countries would like the same deal the Arabian gulf producers have negotiated with western oil companies.

title: Giants Aerial Balance Puts Tucker in Crowd
description: Until Bob Tucker caught six passes against St. Louis last Sunday, Giant fans must've thought the tight end had become lost in somebody's intricate zone defense.

title: Business Briefs.
description: GENEVA, Oct. 25The international agency that supervises world trade relations submitted today to a special panel a complaint by Israel that she was being unfairly discriminated against by British import restrictions on cotton textiles.

title: Suit Seeks to Block Mining In a West Virginia Forest
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 25The Forest Service was taken to Federal Court today to prevent deep mining in Monongahela National Forest in eastcentral West Virginia, a mountainous, semiwilderness area with sparse population that is promoted nationally for its tourist attraction.

title: Discolored Water Due
description: Residents of the Lower East Side could get harmless discolored water out of their taps today as a result, of repairs on a Third Avenue water main, the Department of Water Resources said yesterday. Crews working from 8 A.M. to 3 P.M. will shut dow na 30inch water main to replace pipe connecting the main to tydrants on the street. The discoloration would be the result of the increased velocity of the water in the pipes.

title: CYAMOME, $7.80, WINS BIG A DASH
description: A spirited closing rush by Cyamome enabled that filly to carry the silks of the PenYBryn Farm to success in the main event on the card at Aqueduct yesterday. The race was a 6furlong sprint for fillies and mares, with a field of seven participating.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none.)

title: WASHINGTON VIEW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 American officials now believe that there will be a ceasefire in Indochina in the next few weeks, perhaps even before election day, Nov. 7, barring a supreme act of folly in Saigon or Hanoi.

title: 20 CLINICS PLANNED FOR BREAST CANCER
description: Some 20 clinics for the early detection of breast cancer will he set up throughout the country, many by the end of next year, under a $6million program of the American Cancer Society and the National Cancer Institute, the Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: House Contest
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 25  From before daybreak most mornings for the last 10 weeks, Ronald A. Sarasin, the 37yearold assistant Republican leader in the Connecticut House of Representatives, has been campaigning hard in the state's Fifth Congressional District. He has been standing at factory gates to shake hands with workers and waiting on railroad platforms to chat with commuters.

title: New Account of Sabotage
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25A young California businessman said today that he had been recruited and paid by Donald H. Segretti to sabotage Democratic political rallies and gather intelligence from the party's campaign headquarters.

title: RAID HERE YIELDS 8 USURY ARRESTS
description: A team of detectives yesterday raided a plush midtown barbershop and a neighboring checkcashing service that were said to serve as a front for one of the country's largest loansharking banks.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25Two major television networks have offered President Nixon and Senator George McGovern prime time to present their opposing views in sequence on a series of separate videotapes next week. The offer has apparently been rejected by the Republicans.

title: Harvard and Oxford Professors Share Nobel Prize in Economics
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 25The Nobel Memorial Prize for economics went today to an American and a Briton whose theories help to assess business disk and government economic and welfare policies.

title: PATROLMAN HEARD AT EXTORTION TRIAL
description: CATSICILL, N. Y., Oct. 25 (AP)  Dominic Ausanio, a Kingston patrolman, testified before a Greene County Court jury yesterday that he saw Chris Rienzo, a grocer, immediately after he apparently had been roughed up by gamblingdebt collectors.

title: Sulzberger to Be Honored By West Side Association
description: The West Side Association of Commerce, Inc., announced yesterday that Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times and president of The New York Times Company, would receive the association's National 48th Annual Gold Medal Award at the annual dinner at the Statler Hilton Hotel on Nov. 16.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Pairings for the 21st annual Holiday Festival basketball tournament, which will be played Dec. 2630 at Madison Square Garden, were announced yesterday by the sponsoring Eastern College Athletic Conference.

title: Pound Hits Another Low in Hectic Trading
description: LONDON, Oct. 25 (AP)The British pound plunged to another new low today in hectic trading on foreign exchange markets that at times looked like a run on sterling.

title: STAY ASKED ON SALE BY PENN CENTRAL CO.
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 (AP)The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York asked United States District Court Judge John P. Fullam today to stay the $14million sale of four prime midManhattan properties by the Penn Cetral Transportation Company.

title: Lawyers Unit Changes Negative Stand on NoFault
description: The New York State Trial Lawyers Association  which successfully lobbied against a no fault automobile insurance bill in the Legislature this year said yesterday that it no longer opposed the nofault concept.

title: THIEU A QUESTION
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 25  President Nguyen Van Thieu's vaguely worded rejection last night of a ceasefire in place has left many political figures and diplomats here with the belief that he would still accept a ceasefire soon, but only if Henry A. Kissinger can negotiate further concessions from the North Vietnamese.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIN
description: When the four candidates the intense race in Manhattan's 20th Congressional District crossed paths yesterday, all her rivals ganged up on Representative Bella S. Abzug before an elderly audience a Young Men's Hebrew association branch.

title: A $150MILLION SUIT FILED ON SOVIET SALE
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 25 (UPI)  An Oklahoma wheat farmer filed a $150million law suit in Federal court yesterday Charging a former Agriculture Department official and five grain companies With conspiracy in the sale of wheat to the Soviet Union.

title: Beverly Smith, Writer of News For More Than 4 Decades, Dies
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 25 (AP)Beverly Smith, whose reports in major American newspapers and magazines spanned four decades, died at Union Memorial Hospital after suffering a stroke on Monday. He was 74 years old and made his home here.

title: Mrs. Shriver Visits Brother's Memorial in Dallas
description: DALLAS, Oct. 25  Eunice Kennedy Shriver placed pink and white roses at the John Fitzgerald Kennedy Memorial here today in what she said was the first visit by any member of the late President's family to the site of his assassination almost nine years ago.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: A series of violent explosions on an oil barge loading at a dock in Carteret, N. J early yesterday touched off a raging fire that sent flames hundreds of feet into the air and a burning oil slick almost a mile up the Arthur Kill to set off other fires on the Kill's New Jersey and Staten Island shores.

title: Kashmir Deadlock
description: A persisting deadlock in negotiations between Indian and Pakistani officials on a future dividing line in Kashmir dims hope for an urgently needed larger peace settlement on the Indian subcontinent.

title: PLAY IT AS IT LAYS
description: AT THE BEEKMAN ON SUNDAY. ADVT.

title: RALLY BY SABRES TIES BRUINS, 2 TO 2
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 25 (UPI)Rene Robert and Gerry Meehan each scored secondperiod goals tonight to give Buffalo a 22 tie with the Boston Bruins and move the Sabres into a tie for first place with Montreal in the National Hockey League's Eastern Division.

title: 12 Pupils Are Stricken by Polio At Private School in Greenwich
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 25 About 12 pupils at the Daycroft School, a private Christian Science preparating school here, have been stricken by polio, the State Health Department reported today.

title: Senate Contest
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 26 One of the most powerful men in the United States Senlate stood before a group of Jaycees the other day and looked positively coquettish when he told an anecdote that was revealing of his formidable influence in Washington.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by large stockholders, directors and officers of its listed companies.

title: EDWIN S. COLBURN
description: SOUTHBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 25 (AP)  Edwin S. Colburn, who left a New York publishing post six months ago to return to library work, died yesterday at Harrington Memorial Hospital after abrief illness. He was 57 years old.

title: Helmerich Brings in Well
description: DALLAS, Oct. 25 (UPI)Helmerich & Payne, Inc., has brought in a combination gas and oil well in Krebs Field in Stevens County, Oklahoma, that flowed on a test basis at 1,612 barrels of 41 degree gravity oil plus 1,764,000 cubic of gas daily from depths of around 7,400 feet.

title: P. & G. NET CLIMBS BY Vro IN QUARTER
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, a leading merchandiser of soaps, detergents, toiletries and related products, in its first fiscal quarter had the highest sales and earnings of any guarter in its 135year history, the company reported yesterday.Higher profits were also reported yesterday for the third quarter by the National Gypsum Company, the A. E. Staley Manufacturing Company, the USLife Corporation, the Cessna Aircraft Company, the Clark Oil and Refining Corporation, the Stanley Works, the CTS Corporation, the AlbertoCulver Company, the General Cable Corporation, the Freeport Minerals Company and the Vulcan Materials Company. The White Motor Corporation operated in the black after incurring a big loss in the third quarter last year.

title: Teacher Says Nixon Was Hard Worker
description: DINUBA, Calif., Oct. 25 (AP)  Blanche Burum, a fifthgrade, teacher credited by President Nixon today with stimulating his interest in world affairs, says she remembers the President as a deep little thinker and hard worker during his school days.

title: AUSTRALIS BEATS NIRVANA IN JUMP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25Australis, who won the green and open jumper high point championships of the United States more than five years ago, still hasn't lost her touch.The smartstepping little mare carried Mrs. Bambara Kerr, a member of the Canadian Equestrian Team who now resides in Kennett Square, Pa., to victory in the Ringmaster class for internationalopen jumper tonight at the Washington International horse show.

title: Men in the News
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 25When word carne this morning that Prof. Kenneth Joseph Arrow of Harvard had won a Nobel Prize in economics, the 51yearold scholar was on his way to Stanford University in California for a visit. It seemed fitting that he should celebrate with old friends at Stanford, for it was in nearly two decades of research and teaching there that he built the international reputation that led to today's award. Although some were surprised that recognition had come so soon, few of his, fellow economists doubted that Professor Arrow would some day win, the p&e. He established his reputation Very early with his. 1951 doctoral dissection at Columbia, Social Choice and IndiVidual Values.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: ITHACA, N. Y. 6 When I left Hanoi on Sept. 30, high Governtnezit officials with whom I had been talking lacked any hope that the wellpublicized talks' with Henry Kissinger would be fruitful.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL TRIPLES PROFITS
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported yesterday that thirdquarter earnings were more than triple the level of the similar period a year ago, but Stewart S. Cort, chairman, termed net income for the quarter and first nine months disappointing.

title: 7 SEEK TAXATION OF 2 JEWISH UNITS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 A financial consultant, two Protestant ministers, three professors and a Washington State legislator filed suit today in Federal District Court asking the Internal Revenue Service to end the taxexempt status of the United Jewish Appeal and the United Israel Appeal.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: OJAI, Calif., Oct. 25 (AP)A former stock car race driver, Johnny Mentz, 55 years old, died today after his pickup truck drifted off Highway 33 four miles south here and slammed into a utility pole, authorities said. Mantz, alone in the truck, apparently fell asleep at the wheel, the highway patrol said.

title: YARIO AND 4 HELD IN HIJACKING CASE
description: Paul Vario, the reputed Mafioso who is said to have run a number of illicit enterprises from a Brooklyn trailer while it was under surveillance, was indicted yesterday along with four alleged associates on charges of hijacking a truckload of women's slacks worth $44,000.

title: CAVALIERS WIN, END STREAK Kr 7
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 (AP)The Cleveland Cavaliers, led by Austin Carr's 35 points, defeated Philadelphia, 113108, tonight for their first victory of the National Basketball Association.

title: Lakers 112107 Victors
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 25 (UPI)A pair of free throws by Gail Goodrich gave Los Angeles a onepoint lead with 43 seconds left tonight and the Lakers, helped by a 33point performance from Jerry West, stopped Houston the rest of the game to take a 112107 decision from the Rockets.

title: At Zoo, It Wasn't All Real
description: Enthroned on a folding metal chair borrowed from the Central Park Zoo cafeteria, Muriel Lady Dowding beamed on zoo visitors who had wandered from the gorillas cage to see what the stir was all about.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A favorite media topic these days is the apparent indifference of the public to the accusations of corruption being made against the Nixon Administration. Almost to a man our pundits, commentators and editorial writers are busy analyzing the nature of this tolerance and prophesying dire things for our society as a result of such casual concern for integrity in government.

title: BLUE CROSS SEEKS 18.1% JERSEY RISE
description: TRENTON, Oct. 25  The New Jersey Blue Cross asked today for an average 18.1 per cent rate increase for a million subscribers who hold individual policies or who are included in groups of fewer than 100 members.

title: OilBarge Blasts Set Off Wave of Fires
description: A series of violent explosions on an oil barge loading at a dock in Carteret, N. J., early yesterday touched off a raging fire that sent flames hundreds oef feet into the air and a burning oil slick almost a mile up, the Arthur Kill to set off other fires on the Kill's New Jersey and Staten Island shores.

title: By Philip C. Clarke
description: Despite enormous physical losses, South Vietnam appears to be recovering from its latest ordealbyfire potentially in better shape than before. Its armed forces, though bloodied, are leaner and tougher, having passed their first real combat test since.Vietnamization was accelerated in 1969. More importantly, there are clear signs Of an awakening selfreliancelargely by necessity.

title: Pediatricians Cite Pollution
description: BOSTON, Oct. 25 (AP)Massachusetts pediatricians consider air pollution to be the biggest environmental hazard facing children, according to a survey conducted by the state chapter of the American Academy of Pediatrics.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MADISON, N. J., Oct. 25To encourage interest and participation in Little League baseball and other organized sports for young people in areas of limited opportunity, several businessmen in Union, Essex and Morris Counties last spring formed a corporation called Buddies of Young Sportsmen (BOYS).

title: Indianapolis Teacher Strike Continues Despite Arrests
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 25 Some 2,200 teachers continued their strike against the Indianapolis public school system today in defiance of a court order.

title: TV Review
description: Most movies made for TV let's face itldok it. By now, many home watchers, inured to a stagy, cornercutting format stretched to 90 minutes, methodically wait for the real McCoy on the late shows.

title: A Day for Harlem to Pay Its Respect
description: Later in the day, the body would be moved south to Riverside Church down to what a number of mourners referred to as the bourgeoisie.

title: Bridge:
description: Nobody was surprised when Alvin Roth of New York and Barbara Rappaport of East Orange, N. J., the national life master pair champions for the last two Years, won two events in the Metropolitan Championships at the New York Hilton Hotel last weekend. This is a feat they have achieved on several previous occasions.

title: MOZART INSPIRATION TO PERAHIA, PIANIST
description: This week and next, Murray Perahia is appearing in three guises at Hunter College Playhouse. On Tuesday night, the pianist played concertos with small orchestra led by Alexander Schneider. A solo recital is due. Oct. 31, an appearance with the Guarneri Quartet on Nov. 3.

title: Needham Opposes Fee Changes Now
description: James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday that he opposes further cuts in the level of negotiated rates during the current depressed cycle of the securities industry.

title: Woman Wins Reopening Of Court Settlement
description: A cleaning woman who fractured a leg in the hallway of a Bronx tenement nearly two years ago and sued the owner for $100,000, yesterday won an appeal of a $3,010 settlement that would have been spilt between her lawyer and the Department of Social Services, and left nothing for her.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 25, (AP)Rep, ublican leaders noted yesterday that Mr. Cleveland is state chairman of the Oklahoma Farmers and Ranchers for McGovern and they dismissed the suit as politically motivated.

title: Chinese to Visit Canada
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 25 (UPI)A group of Chinese physicians visiting the United States will go to Canada before returning home, Carol Rogers, press coordinator for the trip, announced today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: It was a historic ball game on several counts, even though it was only a spring training exhibition between the Dodgers and Yankees at Havana in 1947. What was to give it public impact was that it led to a brouhaha involving Branch Rickey and Leo Durocher of the Dodgers on one side and Larry MacPhail, the stormy petrel of the Yankees, on the other. From it emerged Durocher's unjust suspension from baseball by the then commissioner, Happy Chandler. What made that game even more memorable to me, however, was that it gave me my first awareness of Jackie Robinson and his place in the plans of Rickey for the breakthrough of the color line. Now that Jackie is dead, the recollections keep piling up. Yet I find myself treasuring the foreknowl edge of his soontobe date with destiny, even if I was unable to take advantage of it.

title: McGovern Slightly Narrows Nixon's Gallup Lead
description: Senator George McGovern has slightly narrowed President Nixon's massive lead as measured by the Gallup Poll.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In a dinner speech to the Conservative party in New York, Vice President Agnew enunciated the overriding issue of the present Presidential campaign, and, in doing so, made the most effectivd argument for the election of Senator George McGovern, the Democratic candidate. As reported in The Times of Oct. 14, Mr. Agnew set forth as the fundamental issues of the campaign a belief in the primacy of reason in public affairs, the acceptance of the need for a just order based on law, and the acknowledgement of a transcendent moral order.

title: REVERSAL SORT ON SCRIBNER EDICT
description: Four members of the District 18 Community School Board appealed yesterday to the City Board of Education to overrule Monday night's decision by Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner reassigning 32 black children to Isaac Bildersee Junior High School 68 in Canarsie.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct, 25 (UPI)Eddy Merckx of Belgium, the world's top cyclist, set a world onehour record for professionals by pedaling 49.408.68 kilometers (30.7 miles) in a solo run today. Merckx broke the mark set 1968 at the same track, the Olympic Velodrome, by Denmark's Ole Ritter, who cycled 48.653.92 kilometers in 1968.

title: MACHU'S OFFICE UNDER NEW STUDY
description: The state's new corruption investigator has questioned witnesses about the handling of murder case by the office of the Queens District Attorney, Thomas J. Mackell, according to lawenforcement sources.

title: HardPressed Cities To Get $4.3Million As a Tax Windfall
description: TRENTON, Oct. 25With virtually everyone around here warning gloomily of municipal financial crises, Governor Cahill could hardly wait to announce today that he had good newsa $4.3million tax windfall for financially pressed local governments.

title: Cooking the Way Restaurants DoFirst Make a Mother Sauce
description: Cooks at home who are weary of chaining themselves to the stove for 48 hours before every party in order to emerge, flushed and drained, with a complex bu triumphant meal cannot be blamed for yearning after shortcuts to culinary preeminence in their crowd.

title: Arrest at McGovern Hotel
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 25 (UPI) The police investigated today a complaint that fireworks were being set off in the Marc Plaza Hotel, where Senator George McGovern was staying. No arrests for fireworks violation were made, but a member of the rock group Grateful Dead was arrested in a hallway and accused of drunkenness.

title: News Of Dogs
description: Too many fanciers have moved into the sport in, a haphazard way. They see a pup, buy it and enter a show only to be told, You have, a, very nice pet, but no showdog.

title: Child Is Taken From Hospital to Bar Transfusion
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 25 (UPI)The doctor told William Bergeron, 25 years old, of Newport, Ky., that his newborn girl had an RH incompatibility and would have to undergo a blood transfusion.

title: Picture of a Canadian Aids Nixon's Campaign
description: OAKVILLE, Ont., Oct. 25 (AP)Mrs. Jeanette Corlett has become part of the campaign to reelect President Nixon, and she does not mind a bit, even though she knew nothing about it.

title: BEAME URGES CUT IN MAYOR'S POWER
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame urged the Charter Review Commission yesterday to curtail considerably the powers of the Mayor, the office many politicians feel Mr. Beame will seek next year.

title: Farm Workers Union Charges Markets Misuse Lettuce Label
description: The United Farm Workers Union charged yesterday that Sloan's Supermarkets, a 23store New York chain, had repeatedly misrepresented the union's black eagle label on nonunion lettuce.

title: THOMAS CARMICHAEL
description: Thomas N. Carmichael, who had been on the staff of Life magazine for 21 years before his retirement in 1966, died Tuesday of a heart attack in Labarca Mexico. He was 52 years old.

title: Klein Sees Nixon Taking The Metropolitan Area
description: Herbert G. Klein, President Nixon's director of communications, predicted yesterday that Mr. Nixon would carry New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Flushing Out the Woodcock
description: NORWICH, Vt.  Standing in the wet, pungent gloom of an alder swamp as a light snow sifted through the dark branches, we harkened to the fragile tinkling of bells. The bells, each with a slightly different tone, were on the collars of our three birddogs.

title: REYNOLDS RAISES PRICES OF METAL
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said yesterday that it planned to raise selling prices, on its painted coil sheet for mobile homes and recreational vehicles, while at the same time lowering its list prices for the product, effective Jan. 1.

title: Detroit Free Press Leans To McGovern's Candidacy
description: DETROIT, Oct, 25The Detroit Free Press, in its editions dated tomorrow, editorially leans to Senator George McGovern for the Presidency without quite endorsing him.

title: N.C. A.A. Puts California On Probation Until 1975
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct 25 (UPI)The National Collegiate Athletic 'ssociation's Council cited the University of California at Berkeley today for 21 rules infractions, including a scheme to get junior college credit for two prospective athletes through fraud, and put the school on probation until 1975.

title: The House Races
description: Congressional contests in the metropolitan area, including Connecticut and New Jersey, will be discussed in subsequent editorials. While it is not possible to comment here on all the House races elsewhere in the nation, there are members of both parties whose service during the past two years deserves special recognition.

title: Proceedings in the U.N.
description: Political Committee10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Listing of All Winners Of Nobel Prizes in 2
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 25 (AP) Following is a list of Nobel Prize winners for 1972:

title: Federal Building to Get a 44Story Annex
description: The Government disclosed yesterday that it would build a 44story annex to the fiveyearold Federal office building on Foley Square.

title: Lucille Ball to Play Mame in the Movie
description: Lucille Ball has been signed to play the title role in the movie Auntie Mame, it was confirmed by Warner Bros., producers of the projected adaptation of the Broadway musical Mame.

title: SOVIET AIDE HERE ROBBED IN PARK
description: Valentin Zorin, one of the Soviet Union's top political commentators, currently assigned to the Soviet mission to the United Nations, was robbed at gunpoint of $154 while walking at midday yesterday in Central Park.

title: Norman Norell, Designer, Dies; Made 7th Ave. the Rival of Paris
description: Norman Norell, the dean of American fashion designers, died yesterday at the age of 72 in Lenox Hill Hospital. He never regained consciousness after suffering a stroke Oct. 15, the day before he was honored by a retrospective showing of his designs for the last 50 years at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Russians Check Expo74
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Oct. 25 (UPI)Four Russians checked out facilities and plans today for their nation's participation in the Expo74 World Environmental Exposition. The Soviet Union is one of four foreign nations that has announced plans to participate. The others are Canada, Japan and Iran.

title: Bucks Rally to Win
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 25 (AP) The Milwaukee Bucks blew a 5743 halftime lead, then rallied tonight behind Kareem AbdulJabbar and Mickey Davis, a rookie, to defeat the Buffalo Braves, 10992.

title: City Traffic Deaths Down
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday that traffic deaths in the city in the first six months of this year decreased 16.7 per cent, compared with the first half of 1971. The Commissioner said a State Department of Motor Vehicles report showed that 423 persons were killed in the sixmonth period this year, compared with 508 persons in the same period of 1971.

title: OilBarge Blasts Set Off Wave of Fires
description: A series of violent explosions on an oil barge loading at a dock in Carteret, N. J., early yesterday touched off a raging fire that sent flames hundreds oef feet into the air and a burning oil slick almost a mile up, the Arthur Kill to set off other fires on the Kill's New Jersey and Staten Island shores.

title: Mr. Nixon on Debates
description: While President Nixon continues to spurn the facetoface national television debates that he once strongly advocated for Presidential rivals, the White House has come up with a new TV campaign tactic: trying to plant leading questions to be asked of Senator George McGovern and Sargent Shriver by television interviewers.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 25 (AP)The Cincinnati Reds asked waivers on an infielder, Julian Javier, today for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release. The Reds said the 36yearold Javier, a 12year player who played for the St. Louis Cardinals before joining Cincinnati at the beginning of this season; had indicated he was planning to retire.

title: WHOLESALE PRICE OF GAS STUDIED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 The Price Commission has under way an investigation to determine whether major oil companies and independent refiners have made disguised and illegal increases in the wholesale price of gasoline.

title: AM PA ION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 35 (UPI)Vice President Agnew has contributed to President Nixon's reelection campaign, but former Attorney General John N. Mitchell has not. Secretary of State William P. Rogers has donated, but Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird has not.

title: Theater: Next Time I'll Sing to You
description: When the Phoenix Theater first presented James Saunders's Next Time I'll Sing to You in 1963, it seemed Lobe an interesting but confused example of absurdist theater. But when the City Center Acting Company presented the play yesterday at the Good Shepherd  Faith Church, it was an antic disputation on the meaning of theater and of life.

title: 2 Serbian Party Leaders Quit in. Wide Purge by Tito
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 25An extensive purge under way in Yugoslavia's six republics struck the leadership of the Communist party in Serbia today as President Tito, who is 80 years old, pushed a campaign to rebuild a disciplined and obedient party as his successor.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two of the inmates who escaped from the Manhattan House of Detention for Men (the Tombs) on Monday were recaptured yesterday and a third inmate surrendered at the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan. Still at large are four others who fled the Tombs by sliding down a rope of bedsheets from the fourth floor.

title: Dude Closes at 16
description: Dude, the Gerome RagniGalt MacDermot musical'clbsed its local run at the Broadway Theater last Saturday after 16 performances, The production was budgeted at $700,000 and is reported to have sustained loss of $800,000. Adcla and Peter Holzer were the producers.

title: Hayden Stone Reports Sharp Drop in Earnings
description: Hayden Stone, Inc., the investment house, reported yesterday that it had net income of $24,968, or 1 cent a share, in the fiscal first quarter ended Sept. 29, down sharply from net of $893,110, or 31 cents a share, in the yearearlier quarter.

title: Nyquist Orders an Investigation of Fuentes Case
description: Ewald B. Nyquist, the State Commissioner of Education, yesterday ordered an investigation into charges that Luis Fuentes is unfit to serve as superintendent of Community School District 1 in Manhattan.

title: NIXON REAFFIRMS ANTIBUSING STAND
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25President Nixon, in his fifth radio campaign speech, restated today his support for Federal aid to nonpublic schools and his opposition to courtordered busing and promised to press for legislation to implement both policies.

title: Several Men Attack School Buses Here; 8 Students Treated
description: Several white men attacked two buses carrying black and Puerto Rican children to a Queens junior high school yes terday morning, smashing the windows with pipes and dumping oil on the students.

title: Charges Abuse of Power
description: DETROIT, Oct. 25Senator George McGovern, making his harshest attack on the President, declared tonight that the United States faced a moral and a constitutional crisis of unprecedented dimensions because of widespread abuse of power by the Nixon Administration.

title: BENJAMIN STRUMINSKI
description: Benjamin X. Struminski, an import specialist in chemicals for the Customs Bureau, died yesterday at BeekmanDowntown Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Glen Cove, L.

title: Leafs Beat North Stars
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 25 (AP)Third period goals by Pierre Jarry and Dave Keon powered the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 43 National Hockey League victory over the Minnesota North Stars tonight.

title: Servicemen Abroad, Uneasy Over Civilian JobHunting, Get Aid From Task Force
description: MILDENHALL, England, Oct. 16S. Sgt. William Rudolph sat in a United States Air Force service club this afternoon looking over brochures about civilian jobs at home. He seemed nervous.

title: GAIN REGISTERED FOR SOYBEAN OIL
description: Although some commodity futures prices dropped yesterday perhaps because of pessimism about peace talks, the price of soybean oil moved ahead.

title: Stage: Chelsea Players Tragedy of Billie Holiday
description: Brooklyn's Chelsea Theater the best thing the borough has had since the Dodgers lefthas for the first time come down from its attic in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Last night it made its debut, as it were, in one of the academy's regular theaters, giving the premiere of Lady DayA Musical Tragedy.

title: XRAY VALUE CITED BY PEDIATRICIANS
description: Three pediatric radiologists moved Xray viewing boxes from their hospitals to a hotel here yesterday to demonstrate how chest Xrays can help save the lives of many newborn infants as they sruggle to breathe during the first hours of life.

title: Peron Reported Set to Return To Buenos Aires Next Month
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 25 (UPI)  The former Argentine dictator, Juan D. Pern, will return Nov. 17 to try to make a political comeback, the newspaper Cronica said yesterday. It said he would bring the body of his wife Eva, the idol of millions of Peronists while he was in power.

title: A FRENCH REPORT
description: PARIS, Oct. 25  A wide measure of understanding on a ceasefire and a subsequent political settlement in Vietnam has been reached between Henry A. Kissinger and the North Vietnamese negotiator, Le Duc Tho, a highranking French source disclosed here today.

title: DELAWARE BANK QUITTING RESERVE
description: The Wilmington Trust Company, Delaware's largest bank, announced yesterday that its directors had voted to withdraw their bank from membership in the Federal Reserve System, of which it has been a part since 1917.

title: Housing Study: High Rise = High Crime
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25A threeyear study by a New York University research team has produced dramatic evidence of a major cause of the terror that afflicts public housing residents in many major cities: The higher the building, the higher the crime rate.

title: TODAY POSTPONES PROGRAM ON P.O.W.'S
description: A twohour program devoted to the prisoners of war in Vietnam, scheduled for this morning's Today show on the television network of the National Broadcasting Company, has been postponed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Why, oh why, when the subway has stopped between stations, can't the conductor briefly, courteously tell us why we've stopped and for how long the delay. And if he doesn't know, fine, but let him tell us. He is not riding alone.

title: Priests Urge Bombing Halt
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Oct. 25 (AP) A resolution calling on. President Nixon to halt immediately the massive bombings of North Vietnam was passed yesterday at the sixth annual New England Conference of Priests Senate. The vote was not unanimous and several of the 55. Roman Catholic priests in attendance abstained from voting.

title: Notes on People
description: Criminals at large in the areas of Omaha and St. Louis are advised that they may now be eligible for arrest by the Federal Bureau of Investigation's first women special agentsSusan Lynn Roley, 25 years old, and Joann Pierce, 31. Miss Roley, a former Marine officer, and Miss Pierce, a former Roman Cathblic nun; successfully completed the 14week training, course at Quantico, Va. The course included shooting guns and handtolfand combat, the kind of activity that was allegedly too difficult for woolen during he 48year F.B.I. tenure of the late J. Edgar Hoover. The nowomen policy was changed last spring and Miss Roley, whose first assignment is Omaha, and Miss Pierce, on her way to St. Louis, are the first of the 30 women to apply for agent's jobs to succeed Like the 45 men who passed the course kpith them, the two women were given, 38caliber revolvers and bronze badges and they will be paid a starting salary of about $15,000 a year.

title: MRS. ANTHONY B. RIVES
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Oct. 25Mrs. Gwendolen Ella Armstrong Rives, a leader in civic preservation here, died Tuesday night at the age of 61. She was the widow of Anthony B. Rives.

title: Screen: Clement's 'The Deadly Trap'
description: "The Deadly Trap," Rene Clement's 1971, English-language French film, is, I think, supposed to be a suspense melodrama about an American couple (Frank Langella and Faye Dunaway) who live in Paris and are menaced by the members of an industrial espionage ring.Although "The Deadly Trap" does contain a great deal of plot, all of its is so arbitrarily muddled you begin to believe the film means to demonstrate other things, say, the limits of human patience."If you shut me out with your silence," Faye says to Frank, "you shut yourself in." Ground for divorce? Not at all. Frank, who's trying to work, displays only a mild irritation with this sort of wisdom. It may be, of course, that he suspects that Faye is a bit nutty and should be humored.At least the audience is led to think that Faye is nutty, but then any mother with two children as noisy and willful as hers might well be ready for a straitjacket. Even when the kids jump around and block her vision while she's driving the car, the patient Faye just laughsand smashes into the rear end of a truck.Two writers, Sidney Buchman and Eleanor Perry, are given official credit for the screenplay, but I've been told that three other people also worked on it at one time or anotherRing Lardner Jr., Daniel Boulanger and Clement himself. Which may explain some of the screenplay's ludicrous inconsistencies (is the film being told from Faye's point of view, from Frank's, from Clement's?) and the way in which vital information is stitched into the dialogue, in patches, like desperate afterthoughts designed to make the story hold up.Nothing really works, though. Not the performances (including a walk-on by the usually fine Maurice Ronet), nor the direction by a man who once made interesting films ("Forbidden Games," "Purple Noon"). All that seems to remain of that talent are stylistic touchesphotographing people from the ankles down, through fishbowls, that sort of thing.

title: Japanese in Peruvian Deal
description: LIMA, Peru, Oct. 25 (UPI)Three Japanese concerns will install $19.6million worth of facilities in the Peruvian port city of Talara to refine petroleum into high octane gasoline Government announced today.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 25Embittered Vietnamera veterans and some of their counselors indicted the nation's veterans services yesterday for what they said was a lack of commitment and an abundance of red tape.

title: Welfare Cuts Barred If Mother Remarries
description: BOSTON, Oct. 25 (AP)A Federal judge has ruled that since a stepfather is not legally required to support his stepchildren, the state cannot cut welfare payments to mothers who remarry.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Untl Bob Tucker caught six passes against St. Louis last Sunday, Giant fans must've thought the tight end had become lost in somebody's intricate zone defense.

title: Books of The Times
description: CONTOUR IN TIME: The Plays of Eugene O'Neill. By Travis Bogard. 491 pages. Illustrated. Oxford, $15.

title: THIEU A QUESTION
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 25  President Nguyen Van Thieu's vaguely worded rejec tion last night of a ceasefire in place has left many political figures and diplomats here with the belief that he would still accept a ceasefire soon, but only if Henry A. Kissinger can negotiate further concessions from the North Vietnamese.

title: Enemy Presses 113 Attacks in Apparent Drive to Gain Territory Before Truce
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 26  Enemy troops launched 113 smallscale attacks thorughout South Vietnam in the last 24 hours, Saigon Government spokesman said this morning, in what American officers termed an apparent campaign to broaden claims to territory in the event of a ceasefire.

title: Honeywell Plants Picketed
description: BOSTON, Oct. 25 (AP)Demonstrators from Clergy and Laity Concerned picketed Honyewell, Inc., plants across Massachusetts today to protest the company's manufacturing of antipersonnel weapons.

title: Agreement in Chile Is Reported On Settlement of Truck Strike
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 25 (UPI)President Salvador Allende Gossens and striking truckowners reportedly reached agreement tonight on settling the truck strike, key to the national labor stoppages that have cost Chile an estimated 5100million in two weeks.

title: DALLAS CHIEF CURBS ARRESTS OF BLACKS
description: DALLAS, Oct. 25 (UPI)Police Chief Frank Dyson disclosed last night, that he had temporarily stopped sending the police into black neighborhoods with arrest warrants. Three Negroes have been shot by policemen in the past two weeks, and blacks have protested with demonstrations.

title: Turner Ordered by Court To Testify in Refund Case
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Oct. 25 (AP)Glenn W. Turner and two of his Florida businesses have been ordered to show cause Nov. 15 why they have not refunded $182,510 to Washington citizens and why they should not pay a $25,000 civil penalty.

title: Laird Says That Talks Are in a Significant Stage
description: LONDON, Oct. 25 (Reuters) Melvin R. Laird, United States Secretary of Defense, flew to London tonight and parried all questions about the progress of current Vietnam peace developments.

title: New Consumer Aide Here
description: Mayor Lindsay and Corporation Counsel Norman Redlich announced yesterday the appointment of Evan A. Davis to head the consumer protection division of the city's Law Department. Mr. Davis had served as general counsel to the Bureau of the Budget since 1971

title: For a New Theater, a Nostalgic Gala
description: The new Circle in the Square Theater, the first new major Broadway house to open in 44 years, will open its doors tonight in a splurge of nostalgia for its own OffBroadway past and With its Sights set on becoming something of an innovation in the history of the Great White Way.

title: RecordKeeping Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) The Treasury Department today proposed amendments to relax recordkeeping: requirements under the Bank Secrecy Law.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: DETROIT, Oct. 25 (UPI)Tom Haller, a catcher, and Don Leshnock, a lefthanded pitcher, were sold by the Detroit Tigers to the Philadelphia Phillies today for an undisclosed amount of money.

title: Panel Wants Policemen To Moonlight in Schools
description: A City Council committee demanded yesterday that the Police Department change its regulations to permit policemen to moonlight as security guards in city schools to curb the recent outbreak of robberies of teachers and parents.

title: Music: A Piano Master
description: A pianist who puts on one program Boulez's tightly organized Second Piano Sonata and a Dionysian improvisation of his own fertile invention knows where the outer limits of 20thcentury music lie. And when he plays both types of work as phenomenally well as Frederic Rzewski did at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night, enlightenment and pleasure can only result.

title: Jury on Staten Island to Study Police Corruption,
description: A new grand jury investigation of police corruption will begin today  this time on Staten Island.

title: Eisenhower Plaque Unveiled
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 (UPI) Mrs. Julie Nixon Eisenhower unveiled today a plaque displaying an excerpt from President Nixon's eulogy for Dwight D. Eisenhower at the state funeral in 1969.

title: Outline of Understanding
description: CeasefireA ceasefire in place in South Vietnam. This would leave the Saigon Government, headed by President Thieu, in charge in most of the country, including main populated areas. The Vietcong, backed by 145,000 North Vietnamese troops who would remain in the country, would continue to control scattered areas. All American bombing and mining would stop and all American forces would be withdrawn, including advisers. There would be a prisoner exchange. Separate ceasefires would be negotiated in Laos and Cambodia. Rules on American and North Vietnamese military aid to South Vietnam would be set. Mr. Thieu has called for withdrawal of North Vietnamese troops but is expected to yield on that.

title: SIRHAN ASKS REVIEW BY SUPREME COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) Lawyers for Sirhan B. Sirhan appealed today to the Supreme Court for review of his conviction of the murder of Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

title: LEROY C. BROWN
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 25LeRoy C. Brown, administrator of Phelps Memorial Hospital here since its inception in 1954, died Monday in New York Hospital where he was being treated for a heart condition. He was 60 years old and lived at 14 Kingsland Road.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In his Oct. 4 OpEd article, James Roosevelt said that Senator McGovern would give up [our] naval bases in Greece and thereby give the Russians complete control of the eastern Mediterranean and expose Israel to indefensible pressures from hostile naval forces.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., Oct. 25 Vice President Agnew brought the Republican campaign back to the South today, seeking the votes of disgruntled Democrats and trying to build what he called the new American majority on the remnants of oneparty system.

title: Lindsay Charges Gross Violated Trust
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday accused Ted Gross, the former Youth Services Agency Commissioner, of a reprehensible violation of public trust for alleged improper expenditures of $326,589.

title: THE 1972 CAMPIAGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25Senator George McGovern is continuing to rely heavily on a series of large loans to finance his Democratic Presidential campaign, his financial disclosure statements revealed today.

title: Bullets Down Pistons, 115105
description: DETROIT, Oct. 25 (AP)Wes Unseld, Dave Stallworth and Mike Davis led a fourthperiod surge tonight that carried the Baltimore Bullets to a 115105 victory over the Detroit Pistons.

title: Classes at Wilson School Held in Calm Atmosphere
description: While the parents and supporters of 32 black children clamored outside barricades manned by the police at John. Wilson Junior High School 211, in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn yesterday, classes resumed with no serious visible problems.

title: UNION SUES TO FORCE CITY TO DISMISS AIDE
description: The Allied Building Inspectors Union filed suit yesterday in State Supreme Court in an effort to force the city to dismiss Frank Padavan, a deputy buildings commissioner who is on leave of absence to run on the RepublicanConservative ticket for State Senator in Queens.

title: Boston Edison Asks Rise
description: BOSTON, Oct. 25 (AP)Edward B. Hanify, a lawyer for the Boston Edison Company, said at a hearing today that the utility's request for a rate increase of $42million was justified because the company had recently purchased new generators and transmission facilities. The hearing was held by the Department of Public Utilities.

title: PAPER SECTOR SEES FULL CAPACITY USE
description: A position of relative prosperity is opening in the paper industry as a result of full utilization of existing capacity, it was pointed out yesterday at the American Paper Institute.

title: Wyoming to Supply Tree
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI)The Forest Service an.: ounced today that the national Christmas tree would be a 65to70foot Englemann spruce from the Medicine Bow National Forest in southeastern Wyoming. The tree will be a central feature of the annual Pageant of Peace exhibit just south of the White House., Forest Service spokesmen said the tree would be selected and cut by Nov. 17 and shipped here by about Dec. I.

title: C.A.B. IS CHECKING AIR TRAVEL CLUB
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board said yesterday that it was investigating a Miamibased air travel club that is offering MiamiNew York roundtrip flights for $59almost 40 per cent less than the lowest fare on an airline.

title: 31 A Train Riders Injured
description: Thirtyone subway riders sustained minor injuries yesterday when an IND southbound A express train screeched to an emergency stop a block south of the 59th Street station, according to a spokesman for the Transit Authority. The spokesman said that someone apparently pulled the cord of the emergency brake in one of the cars as the crowded 10car train was leaving the 59th Street station at Columbus Circle at about 8:20 A.M.

title: HORSE SALE SETS $3.3MILLION MARK
description: YONKERS, Oct. 25  With H. T. Luca, a 4yearold pacer, bringing $100,000 and Latest Record, a 6yearold trotter, going for $75,000, the fourday Old Glory Horse Sale, which dates back to 1894, concluded today with record sales totals at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Personal Finance
description: With winter just around the corner; you may be one of the thousands of tourists heading for the sun somewhere around the world.

title: 2 Drivers for Newspapers Plead Guilty to Larceny
description: UNION CITY, N.J.  Two circulation truck drivers for New York City newspapers who were accused of stealing 405 copies of the Sunday issues of The New York Times here pleaded guilty to larceny Friday in Municipal Court.

title: WASHINGTON VIEW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25America officials now believe that there will be a ceasefire in Indochina in the next few weeks, perhaps even before election day, Nov. 7, barring a supreme act of folly in Saigon or Hanoi.

title: Norman Norell, Designer, Dies; Made 7th Ave. the Rival of Paris
description: Norman Norell, the dean of American fashion designers, died yesterday at the age of 72 in Lenox Hill Hospital. He never regained consciousness after suffering a stroke Oct. 15, the day before he was honored by a retrospective showing of his designs for the last 50 years at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Business Briefs.
description: The Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, announced yesterday that it would lead a 13bank consortium to finance a $68million contract that the Caterpillar Tractor Company signed last week to supply construction machinery to the Soviet Union. The borrower will be Tralttoroexport, the Soviet trade organization responsible for agricultural and machinery, with a guarantee from Bank for Foreign Trade of the U.S.S.R. The interest rate on the loan, which is to be repaid by 1981, was not disclosed.

title: Advertising: A New Talent Mix
description: Seven years ago two chaps one of them named Helfgottleft Smith/Greenland to set up their own thingHelfgott & Partners.

title: Housing Study: High Rise =High Crime
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25A threeyear study by a New York University research team has produced dramatic evidence of a major cause of the terror that afflicts public housing residents in many major cities: The higher the building, the higher the crime rate.

title: REVERSAL SOUGHT ON SCRIBNER EDICT
description: Four members of the District 18 Community School Board appealed yesterday to the City Board of Education to overrule Monday night's decision by Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner reassigning 32 black children to Isaac Bildersee Junior High School 68 in Canarsie.

title: Funds Sought for Church
description: The AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith called yesterday for the formation of a community committee to raise funds to repair a Forest Hills, Queens, interracial church damaged by an arsonist fire last Sunday midnight.

title: Clerics Wives to Nail Feminist Theses to Door
description: PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 25 (UPI)  Just as Martin Luther nailed his historic 95 theses to a church door in Germany, so a group of militant women plan to nail or tape a list of feminist theses to church doors this Sunday.

title: Lindsay Charges Gross Violated Trust
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday accused Ted Gross, the former Youth Services Agency Commissioner, of a reprehensible violation of public trust for alleged improper expenditures of $326,589.

title: Dow Fights Chilean Seizure
description: Lawyers representing the Dow Chemical Company yesterday filed appeals in Santiago against the Chilean government's seizure of Dow's interests in that country. Last week the Chilean Government took control of PetroquimicaDow S.A., a 70 per cent Dowowned company in Concepcion, and of Dow Quimica Chilena, S.A., a subsidiary in Santiago.

title: Maj. Gen. Charles Willoughby, Intelligence Aide in Pacific, Dies
description: NAPLES, Fla., Oct. 25 (AP) Maj. Gen. Charles A. Willoughby, retired assistant chief of staff for Army intelligence in the Pacific from 1941 to 1951, died today at his home here. He was 80 years old.

title: Men in the News
description: LONDON, Oct. 25  Sir John and Lady Hicks, both retired Oxford economists, were 7,000 miles from their books, their papers and their cottage garden today when it was announced that he and an American were the winners of the Nobel Prize for economic science. At their Tokyo hotelSir John and Lady Ursula are on a roundtheworld tripthe manager announced that the 68yearold professor wanted no calls, The human side of a man whose achievement was described in a Nobel citation as presenting a complete equilibrium model with aggregated markets for commodities, factors or production, credit and money, can be difficult to pinpoint, particularly if he is half a world away and not answering the telephone.

title: SEARCH FOR BOGGS IS NOW 10 DAYS OLD
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Oct. 25 (UPI)Airmen spent a 10th day today chasing a lot of ghosts over. 25,000 square miles of rugged Alaskan mountains and islands in the search for a missing plane carrying the House majority leader, Hale Boggs of Louisiana, and three companions.

title: Market Place: Digital Report: Spur for Panic
description: The spectacular slide in share value for the Digital Equipment Corporation yesterday suggests that many professional money managers lose their heads at the slightest hint of bad news.

title: Towmen, in Rate Protest, Tie Up Roads for 3 Hours
description: A morning nightmare of clogged roadways, snail's pace traffic, tension and temperigniting frustration assailed thousands of motorists yesterday when towtruck operators seeking increased rates refused to work and apparently staged a stallin.

title: Ashe Triumphs Over Stolle In German Tennis, 62, 76
description: ESSEN, West Germany, Oct. 25 (AP)Arthur Ashe of Gum Spring, Va., beat Fred Stolle of Australia, 62, 76, today in the third round of a professional tennis tournament.

title: Borrowing of $3Billion Is Scheduled by Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25The Treasury Department announced today that it planned to borrow $3billion next week through the auction of 6 per cent, fouryear notes.

title: Foster Leads Royal Philharmonic in Tippett's First
description: In recent years the veteran 67yearold British composer, Sir Michael Tippett, has been enjoying a suddent burst of fame m England. But little of his music is heard here; the younger generation of British postserialists, headed by Peter Maxwell Davies, has been getting the play.

title: Operation Efficiency
description: It would be an exaggeration to say that the first quarterly report on the city's effort to lift productivity in municipal agencies reflected an astonishing spurt toward greater efficiency. Yet the gains in the report by Deputy Mayor Hamilton do offer hope that a new attitude is beginning to take hold in the civic bureaucracy.

title: Eurodollar Borrowing Up
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (Rcuters)Gross liabilities of UnitedStates banks to their foreign, branches increased $370million in the week ended Oct. 18 from the previous week to $1,084,000,000, the Federal Reserve reported today. Eurodollar's borrowing since Oct 20, 1971, showed a decrease of $639million.

title: Chess: Hungary's SecondStringers Did Double Duty at Skopije
description: The secret of Hungary's smashing secondplace finish behind the Soviet Union in the Olympics in Skoplje, Yugoslavia, was a combination of the team's surprising depth plus a sensational winning streak by Lajos Portisch at first board.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND OTC DECLINE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market finished slightly lower yesterday for the second consecutive session in slower trading.

title: 2 Are Killed in a PileUp on Staten Island Expressway
description: Two men were killed and three others injured yesterday in a pileup of nine vehicles on the Staten Island Expressway that snarled traffic during the height of the morning rush hour, the police reported.

title: Equity Financing
description: A public offering of one million common shares of Portland (Oregon) General Electric Company at $20,875 per share was made yesterday by Blyth Eastman Dillon & Co. The company's stock closed unchanged at 20 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: HUGHES IS CRITICAL OF LAVELLE DECISION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 Senator Harold E. Hughes said in a statement today that the Air Force decision to dismiss all remaining charges against Maj. Gen. John D. Lavelle was in effect, a slap on the wrist for flagrant violations of orders.

title: THE IRISH WILL VOTE ON CHURCH POSITION
description: DUBLIN, Oct. 25About one and a half million people in the Irish Republic will be asked later this year whether the special position of the Roman Catholic Church in the nation should be scrapped.

title: A FRENCH REPORT
description: PARIS, Oct. 25  A wide measure of understanding on a ceasefire and a subsequent political settlement in Vietnam has been reached between Henry A. Kissinger and the North Vietnamese negotiator, Le Duc Tho, a highranking French source disclosed here today.

title: I. L G. W. U. POSTER OPPOSED AS RACIST
description: More than 100 people JapaneseAmericans, ChineseAmericans, blacks, Puerto Ricans and whites  held a demonstration on Broadway outside the International Ladies Garment Workers Union Building yesterday to protest against what they said was the union's racist advertising campaign.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Thanks to a little bit of luck last Sunday and a lot of running the week before, the New York Jets have put two victories together for the second time this season, have a 4.2 wonlost record and are once again playoff contenders.

title: LetterBombs Injure Arabs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 25Explosive devices sent by mail critically injured an Arab postman and a secretary here today, and other letterbombs exploded or were intercepted in Algeria, Libya and Egypt.

title: Klein Doesn't Expect A Truce by Election
description: Herbert G. Klein, President Nixon's director of communications, said yesterday he did not expect a ceasefire in Vietnam before the Nov. 7 election.

title: Mackell's Handling of Murder Case Reported Under Scrutiny by State's Corruption Investigator.
description: The state's new corruption investigator has questioned witnesses about the handling of a murder case by the office of the Queens District Attorney, Thomas J. Mackell, according to three separate lawenforcement sources.

title: NIXON REAFFIRMS ANTIBUSING STAND
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25President Nixon, in his fifth radio campaign speech, restated today his support for Federal aid to nonpublic schools and his opposition to courtordered bus, ing and promised to press for legislation to implement both policies.

title: Harlem Housing Official Accused of Rent Thefts
description: The city's Commissioner of Investigation, Robert K. Ruskin, announced yesterday the arrest of Robert T, Gaimes, 39yearold project director of the Eest Harlem North Special Improvements Arca, on charges of using his office to collect rents and security deposits illegally.

title: Exceptions Listed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25 (AP)  A union spokesman said, Military cargoes will be handled, perishables will be delivered, and passenger ships will be allowed to operate as normal,

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25The White House, appearing increasingly restive about the socalled corruption issue in the Presidential campaign, angrily denied today a news report linking President Nixon's chief of staff, H. R. Haldeman, with a secret fund allegedly used to underwrite a reported campaign of political espionage.

title: Massachusetts Eases Ban On Harvesting of Shellfish
description: BOSTON, Oct. 25 (AP)The Massachusetts ban on harvesting of softshell clams was furtther eased today in an announcement by Dr. William J. Bicknell, Commissioner of the Department of Public Health.

title: Merger News
description: RSR Corporation and St. Joe Minerals Corporation announced yesterday they had reached agreement in principle for RSR to acquire all of the capital stock of Quemetco, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of St. Joe. Under the agreement, RSR will acquire the subsidiary for about $20million in cash and $2million in notes and will assume St. Joe's obligations as guarantor of certain of Quemetco's longterm plant leases. Quemetco is primarily engaged in the manufacture and sale of various types of lead alloys and oxides. Last year it had sales lof about $32million.

title: Charlotte Gano Garrison; Taught at Teachers College
description: Charlotte Gano Garrison, who headed for many years the, kindergarten section at the Horace Mann School of Teachlers College, Columbia University, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 91 years old and lived at 39 Claremont Avenue.

title: STOCKS MEANDER IN TRENDLESS DAY
description: The stock market drifted aimlessly yesterday as investors awaited further developments in the negotiations for a truce in Vietnam.

title: 2 More Teachers Robbed In Front of Their Classes
description: Two elementary school teachers, one in the Bronx and one In Brooklyn, were held up in front of their classes yesterday. The Bronx teacher had her purse containing $2 stolen and the Brooklyn teacher was robbed of $4 in cash.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Brooklyn District Attorney Gold continues to titillate us with new disclosures from that trailer in the Canarsie junkyard, and the media continue to report it as if it has been factually proved.

title: May Deport 3 Americans
description: MANILA, Oct. 25 (UPI)The Government announced today that an American lawyer who worked with servicemen and two other Americans who were arrested last week in connection with possession of allegedly subversive documents faced possible summary deportation if they did not depart voluntarily. The authorities said they had enough information to charge the Americans Douglas Sorenson of Palo Alto, Calif., and Eugene Parker and Bart Lubow of New Yorkwith activities inimical to national security.

title: Registration in South Called a Curb on Minorities
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 25 (UN)Southern states use voter registration as a means of keeping minority citizens from voting, report of the Voter Education Project charges.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: OSAKA, Japan, Oct. 25 (UPI)Hideji Kato belted two homers for three runs today to pace the Hankyu Braves to a 53 victory over the Yomiuri Giants in the third game of the fourofseven Japan baseball series before 34,582 fans at the Nishinomiya Stadium.

title: Marketing Accord Is Set
description: The Union Carbide Corporation announced an agreement yesterday under which the New England Nuclear Corporation will market Union Carbide's line of radiopharmaceutical products.

title: Israelis Intercept LetterBombs Mailed to Nixon, Rogers and Laird
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 25Boobytrapped letters addressed to President Nixon and two members of his Cabinet have been intercepted by Israeli postal workers.

title: Jets Stale Pass Rush Using Fresh Approach
description: Thanks to a little bit of luck last Sunday and a lot of running the week before, the New York Jets have put two victories together for the second time this season, have a 42 wonlost record and are once again playoff contenders.

title: MANY ARMS YIELDED, PHILIPPINES REPORTS
description: MANILA, Oct. 25An intensive campaign to collect loose weapons, especially highpowered ones, brought impressive results as the grace period closed tonight, the Philippine Constabulary reported.

title: Rail Unions Rack Change Of Retirement Program
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP)  A major campaign in Congress, designed to bring about sweeping changes in the pension system for railroad workers, was announced today by representatives of 21 labor unions.

title: 11 Paintings From Metropolitan: And a Degas Highlight Auction
description: Foreign buyers, two of them from Tokyo, were among the successful bidders for 19th and 20thcentury works of art that included 11 paintings consigned by the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The museum pieces, appraised to bring about $314, 400, instead raced ahead of presale estimates for virtually each piece to reach a total of $547,500.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: President Nixon's hard line against legal relief for war objectorsexpressed at the Oct. 16 meeting of the League of Families of American Prisoners and Missing in Southeast Asia is distressing. It also shows remarkable inconsistency.

title: New Account of Sabotage
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25A young California businessman said today that he had been recruited and paid by Donald H. Segretti to sabotage Democratic political rallies and gather intelligence from the party's campaign headquarters.

title: Payrolls at Peak in Steel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) The steel industry paid out a record average $7.29 an hour to its employes in August, the American Iron and Steel Institute said today. The payroll costs, which included such fringe benefits as pensions, insurance and vacations, were up sharply from $7.08 in July as a result of an industrywide wage increase. The institute reported total steel employment dropped about 1,100 in July, to 489,949.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25Scene: The hearth of home. Two of America's most typical people are rocking, procrastinating and listening to their arteries harden.

title: Soviet Aide Held Up
description: Valentin Zorin, one of the Soviet Union's top political commentators, currently assigned to the Soviet mission to the United Nations, was robbed at gunpoint of $154 at midday yesterday in Central Park. Park Administrator August Heckscher apologized on behalf of the city. Page 7.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: RERUN It's a long time between showings of the 1938 Soviet film, Professor Mamlock, one of the first made about Nazi persecution of the Jews at a, time when the American film industry was still wary about international markets and backed away from the topic. The movie, directed by Adolph Minkin, will be shown tonight at 7:30 at the Jewish Museum, 11,09 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street (RI 93770). The musewn is sponsoring in its auditorium Thursday a series of;', films dealing with the Jewish experience. It will run through Dec. 28 and includes films from a number of nations and a long span of years, among them The Dybbuk (1970, Israeli), Nov. 9 The Golden Age of Second Avenue (1969, United States), Nov. 16; Border Street (1948, Poland), Dec. 14; Transport From Paradise (1963, Czechoslovakia), Dec. 28. Admission to the museum ($1; 50 cents for students and under 10's) covers the movies. Ask for ticket when entering museum.

title: CHAR TO OPPOSE MANES ON HOUSING
description: Simeon Golar, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, declared yesterday that if the Board of Estimate approved limiting the proposed federally financed Forest Hills Housing project to 65 per cent elderly persons and 35 per cent veterans, he might have to pro ceed with original plans for three 24story buildings.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: One of the more excruciating problems of the Vietnam war is the relationship between our P.O.W.'s and M.I.A.'s on the one hand and those who have refused induction and gone to jail or emigrated on the other. Often ignored in our thinking about this are those who supported the war and yet used the loopholes to avoid service. Their number is far greater than either those who served or those who refused. What are we to make of these fortunate people? And with so many of these hypocrites in our midst, how can we so passionately condemn those honest few who refused to fight and yet accepted the consequences of their acts?

title: Award Is Won by Retailer For Corporation Report
description: Lowe's Companies, Inc., a North Carolinabased retailer, was the recipient last night of the gold OscarofIndustry award for the best corporation report in 1971, Presented by Financial World magazine, the business Oscar is offered annually to encourage publication of more information and more readable annual statements for shareowners.

title: Judge Acquits Hanrahan of Plot In 69 Chicago Raid on Panthers
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 25State's Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan and 13 codefendants were acquitted today by a judge of conspiring to obstruct justice in connection with the police raid in which a Black Panther leader, Fred Hampton, was slain nearly three years ago.

title: 12Month Rise posted
description: The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for three and 12 months ended Sept. 30. The report placed revenues at $652.6million for the Septem ber quarter against $569.5mil lion a year earlier.

title: Big Bill on Social Security Finally Reaches President
description: WASHINGTON, Oct., 25 (AP) The huge Social Securitywelfare bill, passed by Congress Oct. 17, finally went to the White House today.

title: Film: Cockney Surprise
description: Robert Hartford-Davis's "Beware of the Brethren" is the story of a young Londoner, raised by a doting mother and influenced by a fire-and-brimstone evangelical preacher, who murders girls so as to free his mind of evil thoughts and to hurry his victims toward a better life than they have ever known in the muck and mire here below. The basic quirks and prerequisites of such a story are very familiar, and "Beware of the Brethren" offers no surprises beyond the surprise of how a young man (Tony Beckley) brought up in such a bath of standard stage diction from Ann Todd (his mother) and Patrick Magee (the preacher) could come out of it all speaking so much Cockney.Normally, I abhor superlatives, but at the very least "Beware of the Brethren" is the worst film I have seen all month. A failure even in promoting sex and violence, it is a veritable textbook example of how not to work for suspense, or terror, or titillation, or whatever unspeakable pleasure drives you to the movies.Several special-interest groups will have complaints against the film, all of them valid. Feminists will hate it because it demeans women. Believers will deplore it because it degrades religion. And movie lovers will despise it because the ineptitude of its technique pushes the art or cinema back a good 20 years before D. W. Griffith."Beware of the Brethren" opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters.

title: Crash in Malaysia Kills Two
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Oct. 25 (Reuters)  A retired United States Marine, Lieut. Col. Richard L. Robinson, and a Malaysian Prince, Mohammed Yusoff, died in a crash near here today, official sources said.

title: Pennzoil in an Advance
description: The Standard Oil Company of California and the Pennzoil Company reported yesterday higher earnings for the quarters and ninemonth periods, while the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company announced profit declines for both periods.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: On June 21 the Soviet secret police arrested Pyotr Yakir, a prominent Soviet historian, following the search of his apartment and the confiscation of his books and papers. Since that time he has been held in a Moscow jail, though no charges against him have been made public.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 25Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin heard himself described today as a liar and political fixer and also as a concerned public official looking out for the best interests of the state. The attack and defense came during four and a half hours of trial summations.

title: City Gains Stay in Correction Slowdown
description: The city obtained a temporarystay order yesterday against the Correction Officers Benevolent Association, after the association's 3,000 members staged a rulebook job action that slowed criminal courts here throughout the day.

title: CUTS BY CONGRESS PERIL RELIEF AID
description: The city served notice on the state yesterday that Congressional cutbacks would compel massive increases in both state and city funding to maintain existing daycare and other child welfare and social services.

title: WILLS IS PLACED ON WAIVERS AT
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct, 25 (API) Maury Wills, who stole morn bases than any other major league baseball player in his tory, was placed on waivers today by the Los Angeles Dodgers, who also offered him an instructor's job.

title: Credit Markets
description: Interest rates, except for a spectacular advance in Federal funds, displayed a narrowly mixed pattern yesterday, a session marked by lackluster trading activity.

title: 3 FOOD COMPANIES TO INCREASE PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) Prices are expected to rise soon for frozen and canned foods as a result of Price Commission approval of increases sought by three companies.
