title: HELLMUTH KOHN, LED GERMAN PAPER HERE
description: Hellmuth Kohn, chairman of the board of Aufbau, Germanlanguage weekly newspaper in this city, died in his sleep yesterday. He was 63 years old and lived at 161 West 54th Street.

title: Soviet Aide Held Up
description: Valentin Zorin, one of the Soviet Union's top political commentators, currently as signed to the Soviet mission to the United Nations, was robbed at gunpoint of $154 at midday yesterday in Central Park. Park Administrator August Heckscher apologized on behalf of the city. Page 7.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Shelli Lipton, a young art director for an advertising agency, was looking for sturdy old tables when she chanced to see three wire and cable reels in a dump truck. She thought that with some refinishing they might do. So, with the help of some friends, she rolled the reels about 15 blocks and then got them up three flights of stairs to her apartment.

title: Once Wealthy Widow Wins Delay of Eviction
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. Oct. 25 (UP1)A judge stayed an order today to evict Mrs. James A. Moffett, a 77yearold widow whose assets tumbled from RollsRoyces to food stamps, from her walkup apartment.

title: GILBERT, RANGERS TRIM FLYERS, 61
description: The hair was longer, and one player even sported a Buffalo Bill goatee, but the Philadelphia Flyers played no differently from last season as they collapsed before the Rangers in a 61 drubbing last night. New York won all six meetings last season.

title: PACIFIC GAS POSTS GAIN FOR EARNINGS
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company reported yesterday gains in revenue and net income for the September quarter.

title: POVERTY UNIT AGREES TO POLICY REVIEW
description: After hearing complaints of excessive secrecy, the new chairman of the city's Council Against Poverty promised last night to review the council policy limiting the public's attendance at meetings.

title: Music: Strauss Program
description: One of the complaints registered by habitual concertgoers is predictability of concert programs, which, on the whole, tend to revolve around a severely limited segment of the available repertory.

title: Ubell to Quit C.B.S. For Post at WNBC As News Director
description: Earl Ubell, a former newspaperman who has been science editor of television station WCBS for the last six years, has been hired by the rival station WNBC as director of television news.

title: Text of the North Vietnamese Statement on the Secret Negotiations With the U.S.
description: TOKYO, Oct. 26 (AP)Following is the text of a statement issued by the North Vietnamese Government today on the peace negotiations, as broadcast in English and monitored here:

title: L.I.R.R. Strike Is Averted As Wage Gain Is Explained
description: MASSAPEQUA, L.I. Oct. 26 A strike at 12:01 A.M. Friday by members of the United Transportation Union against the Long Island Rail Road was averted tonieht when the terms of a new contract were made public.

title: CITY EMPLOYE LIST BARRED TO PUBLIC
description: The only complete list of city employes and their home addresses available for public scrutiny has been quietly withdrawn at the request of the Manhattan District Attorney's office so that the names of certain policemen who reportedly have received death threats can be excised.

title: Baby Whale Dies After Month In Captivity at Aquarium Here
description: The baby pygmy sperm whale that washed ashore with its wounded mother a month ago died early yesterday in its pool at the New York Aquarium. It was the first whale of its kind to have survived more than a few days in captivity.

title: City Approves a LowIncome CoOp for Forest Hills
description: In a frequently turbulent setting, the Board of Estimate approved last night a compromise of a controversial lowincome nousing project in the middleincome Forest Hills section of Queens.

title: UAL Cancels Options for Concorde
description: Directors of UAL, Inc., the holding company parent of United Air Lines, voted here yesterday not to exercise the company's options to buy six BritishFrench Concorde supersonic jets at a potential cost of more than $250million.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Arriving home weary at the end of a day of fishing, many saltwater anglers put their rods and reels away with no further attention until they are brought forth for the next trip. This is a shoddy habit.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 26 (AP)The new chairman of the Greater Newark Chamber of Commerce said tonight that any solution of Newark's fiscal crisis undoubtedly will require continued Federal and state assistance.

title: FUTURES OF CORN HIGHER AT FINISH
description: Reports of approaching peace in Vietnam had little influence on the commodity futures markets yesterday. Traders were very much aware of the news, and it might have encouraged some buying, but only where there were underlying factors for strength.

title: Laos Offers Peace Plan
description: VIENTIANE, Oct. 26 (AP)The Laotian Government proposed a plan today to the Pathet Lao for ending the war in Laos.

title: Lincoln Center Forum Curtailing Season, and Jules Irving Resigns
description: Because of insufficient funds, the season of the Forum Theater at Lincoln Center will be canceled after the coming Samuel Beckett festival, according to Jules Irving, artistic director of the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center.

title: Municipals Are Target
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26The Securities and Exchange Commission filed lawsuits today against two groups of organizations and individuals charging fraud in the sale of municipal bonds.

title: NIXON OPTIMISTIC ABOUT CEASEFIRE
description: ASHLAND, Ky., Oct. 26President Nixon said tonight he was confident that difficulties blocking a Vietnam ceasefire and peace settlement can and will be worked out.

title: Bills of Two Congressmen Aided Alien Clients of Indicted Lawyer
description: Two Congressmen from New York introduced more than al dozen private immigration bills on behalf of beneficiaries represented by a Brooklyn lawyer who was under Federal indictment for immigration fraud.

title: Chronology of U.S.Hanoi Negotiations
description: Sept. 26 and 27For the 18th time since August, 1969, Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security, meets privately in Paris with Le Duc Tho, a Hanoi Politburo member, and Xuan Thuy, North Vietnam's chief delegate to the Paris peace talks.

title: Newcombe in Quarterfinal With StraightSet Victory
description: ESSEN, Wset Germany, Oct., 26 (AP)Topseeded John Newcombe of Australia moved into the quarterfinals of the World Championship Tennis tour event here today with a 63, 6.4 victory over Colin Dibley, also of Australia.

title: SudaneseSoviet Ties
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 26The Sudan and the Soviet Union will restore full diplomatic relations before the end of the year, according to an interview with President Gaafar alNimciry of the Sudan published today by An Nahar, the elading Lebanese newspaper.

title: Transcript of Kissinger's News Conference on the Status of the CeaseFire Talks
description: We have now heard from both Vietnams and it is obvious that the war that has been raging for 10 years is drawing to a conclusion, that this is a traumatic experience for all of the participants.

title: Strike Deadlines Eased
description: DETROIT, Oct. 26 (AP)United Automobile Workers officials eased strike threats at two General Motors plants today but said the extensions were only on a daytoday basis. The plants are the Fisher Body plant in Hamilton, Ohio, and the General Motors Assembly Division facility in St. Louis. Both plants were set to walk out this weekend.

title: Surge Tied to Vietnam Reports Lasts Less Than an Hoar
description: Public confirmation by Henry A. Kissinger, the President's national security adviser, of significant progress in the negotiations for peace in Vietnam produced a dramatic but shortlived rally in the stock market yesterday.

title: Bridge:
description: Many opportunities to punish the opponents in a lowlevel contract are missed because neither player appears to be in a position to double. The fear of doubling the opponents into game is deeply rooted and bidding judgment of a high order is required.

title: Stop School Muggings
description: Each day brings new incidents of muggings, robberies and invasions of classrooms inside the city's elementary schools. Teachers, parents and pupils have been the victims. This epidemic must be stopped.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: John Kerry of Massachusetts is one of three Vietnam veterans who are majorparty nominees for seats in the House of Representatives this year, according to researchers at Congressional Quarterly, the Washingtonbased publication.

title: Briefing at White House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) Journalists from ethnic groups will be briefed tomorrow by high Administration officials. Mrs. Richard M. Nixon will welcome them at a White House reception. The 125 persons invited to the briefings are editors, publishers and broadcasters from news outlets appealing to ethnic groups. The White House said that many national backgrounds would be represented.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26Teams of trade union presidents will fan out across the country next week in a lastditch effort to salvage the labor vote for George McGovern, the Democratic Presidential candidate.

title: NEW TALK NEEDED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26Henry A. Kissinger said today that peace is at hand in Indochina and that a final agreement on a ceasefire and political arrangement could be reached in one more negotiating session with the North Vietnamese lasting not more than three or four days.

title: Market Place:
description: The test of a highperformance mutual fund is not whether it can lead the pack in a given year but whether it can maintain its performance record in good markets and bad. That is, can it sustain its gains over an entire market cycle?

title: McGovern Says He Hopes Nixon View Is Confirmed
description: IOWA CITY, Oct. 26Senator George McGovern expressed hope here today that the, Nixon Administration's confidence of an imminent ceasefire in the Vietnam war was well founded. But he refused, in a carefully worded speech Id 15,000 people on the campus of the University of Iowa, to credit the Nixon Administration for the prospect of peace, saying that those who had opposed the war deserved much of the credit.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Arriving home weary at the end of a day of fishing, many saltwater anglers put their rods and reels away with no further attention until they are brought forth for the next trip. This is a shoddy habit.

title: Noncom Sought in 3 Deaths Said to Give Up in Lebanon
description: HANOVER, West Germany, Oct. 26 (AP)The West German police reported today that a United States Army sergeant sought in the deaths of two military guards and a German cleaning woman has surrendered to the American military attach in Beirut, Lebanon. A spokesman said that Sgt. Thomas DeGrogoric, 26, of Hialeah, Fla., would be handed over to West German authorities. He is accused of shooting the two guards and the cleaning woman and throwing their bodies from a train.

title: Soviet Criticism Noted
description: ROME, Oct. 26Generally enthusiastic press reactions here to the results of the talks in Moscow were slightly dampened by reports of Soviet criticism of a recent Italian decision to provide an island base for nuclearpowered American submarines.

title: Westchester, Upstate
description: 23d District: Former Representative Richard L. Ottinger (Dem.Lib.) is this newspaper's choice over incumbent Peter A. Peyser (Rep.Cons.). Throughout his three terms in office Mr. Ottinger enjoyed a wellearned reputation as a legislator particularly concerned with environmental matters. Mr. Peyser's record in this area is among the least admired by environmentalists. Similarly on other major issues, the two have been squarely opposedwith Mr. Ottinger consistently taking what we regard as the more acceptable view.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISHistorians may eventually decide the most significant aspect of the Indochina war was that it never produced a superpower confrontation resembling the nuclear showdown over Cuba just ten years ago.

title: Texaco Off, Shell Up
description: Oil industry earnings continued to be without a pattern as both advances and declines were reported yesterday by major companies.

title: Egypt's Arms Chief Quits After Leaders Back Sadat
description: CAIRO, Oct. 26President Anwar elSadat today accepted the resignation of Gen. Mohammed Sadek from all his posts as a Vice Premier, War Minister, commands;inchief of the armed forces and Minister of War Production, an official announcement said.

title: Peking Gives Journalists a Tour Of City's BombShelter Complex
description: PEKING, Oct. 26A responsible Chinese military official said today that China had an earlywarning system and that the bulk of the population of her larger cities could take shelter underground within minutes.

title: Plunkett Is Hoping Frustrations Ease In Jets Game Here
description: As the bus carried the New England Patriots to the airport in Pittsburgh last Sunday, Charlie Gogolak tried to push his seat back into a reclining position and the seat made a loud noise.

title: Igor Sikorsky, Helicopter. Pioneer, Dies
description: Igor I. Sikorsky, the legendary aviation pioneer who developed the world's first practical helicopter, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home in. Easton, Conn. He was 83 years of age, and until recently had visited his office several times a week in the Sikorsky plant in nearby Stratford.

title: President, on Political Trip to Appalachia, Says Goal Is Peace With Honor
description: ASHLAND, Ky., Oct 26 president Nixon said tonight he was confident that difficulties blocking a Vietnam ceasefire and peace settlement can and will be worked out.

title: Sherwin and 2 Are Guilty Of Conspiracy in Road Bid
description: FREEHOLD, Oct. 28 Paul J. Sherwin, New Jersey's Secretary of State, and two codefendants today were found guilty today of conspiring to influence the award of a $600,000 highway contract in return for a $10,000 contribution to the state Republican, finance committee.

title: No Flowers Around Jackie Robinson
description: The doors of the Riverside Church at 122d Street and Riverside Drive opened at noon yesterday and mourners for Jackie Robinson began a procession past his bier that continued into the night.

title: Boston's 3d Home Defeat
description: BOSTON, Oct. 26 (AP)Chico Maki touched off a Chicago scoring barrage with a goal 21 seconds after the opening faceoff and the Black Hawk went on to defeat the Boston Bruins, 63, tonight. It was their first National Hockey League victory in the Boston Garden in nearly two years.

title: NEW TALK NEEDED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26Henry A. Kissinger said today that peace is at hand in Indochina and that a final agreement on a ceasefire and political arrangement could be reached in one more negotiating session with the North Vietnamese lasting not more than three or four days.

title: Books of The Times
description: The compiler and editor of an antholbgy such as The New Oxford Book of English Verse, as near to an offical volume as the republic of letters allows, is not quite the free and unfettered spirit that his title indicates, Heor as in this case, sheis more a custodian of a national treasure than a freeenterprise entrepreneur on his

title: Polaroid Camera Unveiled To Approving Audience
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 26The Polaroid Corporation introduced its longanticipated SX70 camera tonight in the grand hallroom of the Fontainbleau Hotel to a generally approving audience of 1,200 camera dealers and others.

title: Oriental Beef Dish
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Batterdipped fried shrimp Beef and broccoli*

title: United Aircraft Engine Sale
description: The United Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday that it had sold $20million in spare jet engines to China. United said the engines, Pratt & Whitney JT3D turbofans, were for the 10 Boeing 707 transports the Chinese ordered in September. Delivery will start in mid. 1973, the company said.

title: U.S. Agents Checking Calls On Russian Grain Deals
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency are looking into a case involving telephone calls last summer by a Mr. Smith who told a Kansas City trade magazine details of United StatesSoviet grain transactions.

title: Business Briefs
description: Two decisions were lost Yesterday by a group of scheduled airlines seeking to block implementation of new Federal regulations that allow anyone to fly on the lowcost charter flights that previously have been limited to members of organized groups.

title: Correction Aides Defy Writ, Continue Slowdown
description: Correction officers at the city's 15 jails continued their rulebook slowdown yesterday despite a court order. But their job action, which was begun Wednesday to press their contract demands, had only a spot ty effect.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I wonder how many people have been able to see the beautiful new perspective of St. Patrick's Cathedral since the building (Best & Co.) to the north of it has been torn down. It is sad to think that this wonderful view is only temporary, as soon, no doubt, a new building will go up to block this panorama.

title: Huntington Hartford's Club Opens Up With a Throng
description: It was, to put it mildly, bedlam, and, according to one guest who was delicately removing an oily lettuce leaf that had been jostled into her somewhat remarkable cleavage, the scene at the club made sardines look like pikers.

title: Nixon Aide Discards Idea of Jobless Goal
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26Herbert Stein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, formally abandoned today the idea of a maximum unemployment rate of 4 percent as a national goal.

title: DOUBT IS VOICED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Oct. 27The South Vietnamese Foreign Ministry issued a statement this morning that said South Vietnam was ready to accept a ceasefire but would never accept a political settlement which goes against the interests and aspirations of the 17 million South Vietnamese people.

title: An Author Who Felt Lost in Paradise
description: Like Gauguin and millions of other people, he wanted to get away from it all. So he fled to Pago Pago, leaving behind a broken marriage, three sons, an editorship at Time magazine and a fancy home in Westchester County.

title: Souvanna Sees Laos Truce Later
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26  Prince Souvanna Phouma, Premier of Laos, said today that no ceasefire had been worked out yet for Cambodia or Laos.

title: Chapo Captures Open Jumper Title
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26Ask any rider in the international open jumper division of the Washington International horse show what Chapo's record is for the year and you'll get blank stare.

title: Canadiens Crush Blues, 70
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 26 (UPI)Jacques Lemaire scored two goals and added two assists and Ken Dryden registered his third shutout of the season tonight as the Montreal Canadiens extended their unbeaten streak to nine games by blanking the St. Louis Blues, 70.

title: Hospital Officials Are Held Hostage By Coney Residents
description: Dr. Joseph T. English, president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, went to Coney Island early this morning after other officials of the corporation and of Coney Island Hospital were held hostage by a group of community residents who demanded to speak to him about conditions at the hospital.

title: CURBS ON IMPORTS BACKED BY MEANY
description: George Meany, the president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., told leaders of the aluminum industry here last night that the labor organization was strongly supporting the controversial BurkeHartke bill. He described the measure as dealing with the causes of America's deteriorating position in international economic relationships.

title: Lockheed Sells 2 Tristars
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 (UPI) The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation said today that it had obtained an order for two Tristar airbuses from a West German airline, Lufttransport Unternehmen. Including spare parts, ground equipment and training services, the order will total $48million, the company said.

title: National League Lands 8 Of 10 Berths on AllStars
description: Dick Allen and Billy Williams, the baseball strongboys from Chicago, lead the 1972 Major League AllStar team anbounced yesterday by the Associated Press.

title: No Americans Died In the War Last Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam; Oct. 26 (Reuters)The United States command reported today that there were no American combat deaths, in Indochina last week.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama will return to this area this weekend for the first time since he was shot May 15. He will help raise funds for Holy Cross Hospital, where he spent 54 days after the assassination attempt while he was campaigning in nearby Laurel on the eve of Maryland's Presidential primary. The hospital's eighth annual fundraising ball will be held at the Sheraton Park Hotel here.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26How did happen? And what remains to be settled before a ceasefire in Vietnam? These are the questions now being discussed here at the end of the long dark tunnel.

title: Laotian Troops Drive to Retake a Key Southern Town Before a CeaseFire
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 26The war in Laos is apparently being fought as bitterly as ever as negotiations to end it continue.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 26  When hecklers tried to disrupt his downtown rally here today, Vice President Agnew responded with a long treatise on the role of courtesy in a democratic society.

title: POUND DECLINES ON PARITY RUMOR
description: LONDON, Oct. 26The British Treasury today took the unusual step of denying a rumor that the floating pound would be anchored to a new parity of only $2.25but the statement was ignored in the foreign  exchange markets, where sterling again lost ground and closed down 1.6 cents at $2.3445.

title: Paper Backs McGovern
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 26 (UPI)The Oregon Journal today endorsed Senator George McGovern for President, saying President Nixon doesn't deserve a landslide victory.

title: Igor Sikorsky, Helicopter Pioneer, Dies
description: Igor I. Sikorsky, the legendary aviation pioneer who developed the world's first practical helicopter, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home in Easton, Conn. He was 83 years of age, and until recently had visited his office several times a week in the Sikorsky plant in nearby Stratford.

title: U.S May Speed Shipments Of War Material to Saigon
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 Pentagon sources said today that the Defense Department was considering a significant acceleration of arms shipments to South Vietnam to insure that most of the jets, tanks and artillery previously scheduled for delivery arrive before any ceasefire closes off reinforcement.

title: About Pro Basketball
description: The National Basketball Association's college draft last May has presented some earlyseason surprises. LaRue Martin, 6foot10inch center from Loyola of Chicago, the first player chosen in the draft, has played only 64 minutes in the Portland Trail Blazers first six games and averaged 4.3 points a game. Henry Bibby, the University of California, Los Angeles, guard, the 58th player taken when the Knicks picked him on the fourth round, is playing like a No. 1 draft choice. The only player chosen after Bibby still on an N.B.A. roster is Mark Minor of Ohio State. Minor, a 6.6 guard, was the 11thround choice of the Boston Celtics. He has played in only one of Boston's first eight games.

title: COMMUNISTS INSIST U.S. SIGN ON OCT. 31
description: PARIS, Oct. 26North Vietnamese and Vietcong delegates here demanded today that the United States observe what they said was a firm agreement to sign a Vietnam ceasefire accord in Paris next Tuesday, Oct. 31.

title: TEACHER ASSAULTED IN BROOKLYN SCHOOL
description: A 29yearold teacher was assaulted in his classroom in a Brooklyn elementary school yesterday by the older brother of one of his pupils, the police said.

title: Stage: Wedding Band
description: It is the summer of 1918. There is a war in Europe. And there is a war in South Carolina  a hidden, submerged war between the races. Julie Augustine is a seamstress and is black Herman is a baker and is white. They are lovers. It is not only diifficult, it is actually illegal.

title: Museum Gets 250,000 Spiders
description: Roughly 250,000 dead spiders were carried into the American Museum of Natural History yesterday not because the public has a passion to see that many of them but to augment one of the great reference collections of the world.

title: /V.C.A.A. Quits U.S. Olympic Committee
description: A longstanding dispute in amateur sports broke into revolt yesterday when the National Collegiate Athletic Association withdrew from the United States Olympic Committee.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Oct. 26  Football rivals for 101 years, Rutgers and Columbia will have a new incentive when they meet Saturday: the Morris Goodkind Trophy, which will go annually to the winner of the game.

title: Equity Financing
description: The Otis Elevator Company said yesterday that the company's Japanese subsidiary, the Toyo Elevator Company, has purchased 7.2 million of its shares from Tokyo Shibaura Electric Company, Ltd. The purchase price was at about $3.6million. The shares will be retired by Toyo Otis Elevator and the subsidiary will then be 100 per cent owned by the Otis Elevator Company. Otis Elevator was up  at 40 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: ELDERLY MAN SLAIN, A 2D IS WOUNDED
description: Two elderly men were victims of stabbing attacks last night in the East Village, the police reported. One man died and the other was critically wounded.

title: BRITISH BYELECTION IS WON BY A LIBERAL
description: LONDON, Friday Oct. 27 The Liberal party, which has only six seats in the House of Commons, captured a seventh from the Labor party in a byelection yesterday.

title: Communists Step Up SmallScale Attacks in South
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Oct. 27 (AP)The South Vietnamese command reported that Communistled forces stepped up their attacks across South Vietnam yesterday and today in what allied officials said was an accelerated effort to establish their presence before a ceasefire.

title: Man in the News
description: When he was growing up in Miami in the nineteentwenties, the Rev. Wilbert Baniel Miller, spokesman for 32 black and Puerto Rican children trying to gain admittance to a Brooklyn junior high school, noted that he and his friends had a lake, a river, a bay and an ocean, and black kids couldn't swim in any one of them. Mr. Miller's mother, Ida, is 86 years old and still lives in Miami. But it was his father, he said, who always inspired us to believe we were as good as any white kids in town because he was what black folks used to call race man.

title: City Patrolman Charged With Rape and Robbery
description: A 29yearold New York City patrolman was arrested yesterday on three counts of rape and robbery.

title: NEW TUNE TAKES AQUEDUCT SPRINT
description: New Tune, a Canadianbred owned by Samuel Lehrman, won the $12,000 main event on the card at Aqueduct by a head yesterday.

title: Flyers Top Detroit, 21
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 (AP) Bill Flett's seventh goal of the season, at 14 minutes, 10 seconds of the final period, gave the Philadelphia Flyers a 21 victory over previously unbeaten Detroit in a National Hockey League game tonight.

title: McGovern Says He Hopes Nixon View Is Confirmed
description: IOWA CITY., Oct. 26Senetor George McGovern exptessed hope here today that the, Nixon Administration's confidence of an imminent ceasefire in the Vietnam war was well founded. But he refused, in a carefully worded speech to 15,000 people on the campus of the University of Iowa, to credit the Nixon Administration for the prospect of peace, saying that those who had opposed the war deserved much of the credit.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 26 (UPI)The Oregon Journal today endorsed Senator George McGovern for President, saying President Nixon doesn't deserve a landslide victory.

title: Tenace Given Sports Car For Role as Series Hero
description: Bud Harrelson of the New York Mets sat in Mamma Leone's restaurant yesterday, watched the mustachioed young man accept the keys to the sports car as the most valuable player in the World Series and said with wonder:

title: Miro Season Off to a Rollicking Start
description: The Mir season is upon us and a happy, wacky, rollicking season it is, full of comic high spirits, beguiling erotic fancy, and delicious flights of poetic extravagance. For Joan Mir, the 79yearold Catalan painter whose work is now on view all over town, is it seems, at once one of the most daring and most imaginative of the modern mastersand also one of the most amusing. He is one of those painters who have achieved the almost impossible feat of being both extremely literary  employing a full arsenal of literary puns, metaphors and poetic allusionsand profoundly pictorial.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 26Sargent Shriver introduced himself here today as the grandson of a Confederate officer from Maryland and said that an end of fat, waste and bureaucracy in the Pentagon and withdrawal from Vietnam are the steps to restoring the military traditions of Southerners like Wade Hampton, Robert E. Lee and George C. Marshall.

title: FASHION TALK
description: In this corner, the pants people. Across the ring, the skirt people. That's the way the battle lines are being drawn for spring on Seventh Avenue.

title: B52's Strike in the South
description: SAIGON, Friday, Oct. 27 (Reuters)The United States command reported yesterday that, to meet the increased Communist activity in South Vietnam, B52 bombers had been sent on 27 missions to attack suspected concentrations of troops and their supply dumps.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (UPI)President Nixon will come here next Tuesday for a tickertape parade in the Loop, the Illinois Committee for the Reelection of the President announced today.

title: Notes on People
description: The creation of a $25,000 annual award for helping to improve mankind was announced in New York by Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson. It is the Zale Award, funded by the Zale Foundation, an offspring of the Zale jewelry concern. Mrs. Johnson, cochairman of the awards committee, said the award would be made to an American who has made a significant contribution to the betterment of mankind in his or her field. At the announcement ceremony were several members of the committee that will select the award winners, including Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall; Dr. William McGill, president of Columbia University and Arthur B. Krim, chairman of United Artists Corporation.

title: Two Union Leaders Ask Nixon If He Plans Lower Wage Limit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26Two leaders of a publicemployes union challenged President Nixon today to disclose before the Nov. 7 election whether he intends to reduce the national payrise standard of 5.5 per cent.

title: Norell Rites Will Be Today
description: A funeral service for Norman Norell, the fashion designer, will be held today at 11 A.M. at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue at 80th Street. Mr. Norell died Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital at the age of 72. Burial wil be in Indianapolis where he lived and worked for many years.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 26A press release implying that Senator, George McGovern and his supporters are traitors was sent to New Jersey papers this week on the letterhead of the Committee for the Reelection of the President, bearing the names of Governor Cahill and Harry L. Sears, state chairman of the committee.

title: URIS HALL OF FAME NAMES FIRST GROUP
description: The first set of members elected to the Theater Hall of Fame and Museum, housed in the new Uris Theater, now nearing completion on the site of the old Capitol Theater at 51st Street and Broadway, has been announced.

title: People and Business
description: Monsanto, the chemical company, reached into Procter & Gamble, the soap company, yesterday and pulled out a president  John W. Hanley.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26Israel has given the Security Council a detailed account of the finding of arms and explosives in the luggage of a 33yearold Palestinian carrying an Algerian diplomatic passport. The man was detained at Schipol Airport in the Netherlands but then allowed to continue to Latin America.

title: Raiders Win, 76
description: In an intimate atmosphere created by only 3,000 fans sitting in an arena built for 17,500, Terrible Ted Green returned to Madison Square Garden last night and heard hardly a boo.

title: SOL MANGEL IS DEAD; LED CLOTHING CHAIN
description: Sol Mangel, a founder and former head of Mangel Stores Corporation, a national chain of women's and children's apparel shops and discount stores, died Wednesday in Doctors Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived at 875 Fifth Avenue.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today Oct. 27, 1972
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Political and Security Committee10:30 A.M.

title: House Contest
description: LOWELL, Mass.The Fifth Congressional District of Massachusetts is no stronghold of traditional Last Hurrah politics.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: On Sept. 25, The Times in a news story advanced the startling thesis that in state courts mafiosi are treated more leniently than the general run of criminals. Comparing sentences across offense categories is misleading exercise. But, mpre importantly, you strongly suggested that unjust dispositions are pervasive, resulting from widespread corruption and dereliction of duty. This grave conclusion is highly questionable, and the purported documentation provides dubious support.

title: From Soup to Nuts, the Meal Is Cheese
description: *  The Purple Foot, 717 First Avenue (below 42d Street), 6976799.

title: PALMER CARDS 65 IN LAS VEGAS GOLF
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 26 (AP)  Arnold Palmer shot sixunderpar 65 and tied four others for the liistround lead today in the $135,000 Sahara invitation golf tournament.

title: Sharp Climb in Quarter
description: The American Smelting and Refining Company reported yesterday gains in net income for the September quarter and first nine months.

title: Costanzo Background
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 26 Francis T. Purcell, the Presiding Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, said today that the towel cannot legally suspend Mr. Costanzo until further investigation.

title: BOGGS SEARCHERS CHECK WEAK SIGNAL
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Oct. 26 (UPI)Air Force planes searching for Hale Boggs, the House majority leader, and three companions sought today to check out a very weak, garbled emergency signal on Nabesna Glacier.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In your Oct. 16 editorial Fiscal Responsibility you quote me as saying that Mr. McGovern's proposed $22billion tax increase will fall far short of paying for the increased expenditure the opposition has espoused. The quotation is accurate. Your editorial finds my statement misleading because you think I have ignored Mr. McGovern's proposal to cut defense spending by $30 billion. In fact, I didn't ignore it. My statement is correct for the net expenditure increase proposed by the Senator, even assuming his recommended defense cuts were made. As your editorial says in the next paragraph:

title: Sports of The Times
description: Carl R. Gray, president of the Union Pacific. Railroad, was in the stands when his son, Howdy, scooped up a fumble and raced 43 yards for a Princeton touchdown. In an excess of jubilation, the elder Gray whacked the head in front of him with his rolled program. The head belonged to a woman whose escort whirled in sudden anger.

title: RADIO IN DAHOMEY REPORTS A COUP
description: COTONOU, Dahomey, Oct. 26 (Reuters)  The army took power in Dahomey today, according to an announcement broadcast over the national radio.

title: Nixon's Chances Seem Enhanced by Moves for Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26Official declarations that a peace settlement is now within President Nixon's reach brought joy today to his political strategists, who have spent a trying 10 days defending themselves against charges of political espionage and searching for a fresh burst of good news.

title: GiantRedskin Game Like Old Times
description: Football games mean different things to different people, and this Sunday's game with the Washington Redskins, for which the New York Giants installed their game plan in yesterday's practice, has all sorts of different connotations to various members of the Giant community.

title: 50 Policemen Call in Sick
description: JOPLIN, Mo., Oct. 26 (UPI) About 50 policemen called in sick today in a wage dispute with the Joplin City Council, leaving the city of 40,000 persons protected by only a halfdozen supervisory personnel. The Joplin Policemen's Association is seeking a $200amonth acrosstheboard wage increase.

title: Reform Needs Cited
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission called yesterday for legislation to regulate municipal bond dealers.

title: Con Ed Withdraws Application For Nuclear Plant at Verplanck
description: The Consolidated Edison Company has withdrawn its applications to the Atomic Energy Commission to build nuclear powergenerating plants at Verplanck, N.Y.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The City Council voted unanimously yesterday to amend the city's Administrative Code to prevent employers from interfering with the religious practices of their employes. The amendment says, in part:

title: Reporter Believes Others Will Face Jail for Contempt
description: Peter J. Bridge, the reporter who spent 20 days in jail this month for having refused to answer some questions by a grand jury, said last night that other reporters could expect to face contemptofcourt sentences if they refused to divulge information given to them in confidence.

title: COURT QUESTIONS NEW CAMPAIGN ACT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26  A special threejudge court ruled preliminarily here today that the new Federal Election Campaign Act, requiring candidates for President and Congress to disclose their finances, plainly presents substantial questions of constitutionality. The court said the law may substantially chill the First Amendment right of free speech.

title: Nixon Aide Discards Idea of Jobless Goal
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26Herbert Stein, chairman of the President's Council of Econumic Advisers, formally abandoned today the idea of a maximum unemployntent rate of 4 per cent as a national goal. In testimony before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, he said that the setting of any specific target for unemployment would be counterproductive.

title: Colleagues Still Mourn Slain Agent And Wonder: What Went Wrong?
description: I was informed by radio that these two guys had left the hotel. I went through the connecting door and saw one of the defendants off to my right. I looked very surprised at him, and he at me. He raised a longbarreled .38. I grabbed it with both hands and tried to point it down to the floor. He was able to let go a shot that hit me in the leg, a flesh wound but enough to weaken my grip, and went down to my knees. He yanked the gun from my hands. He shot me again in the back of my neck. I started to say a very last act of contrition, and tried to reach for my gun at the same time, and found myself completely paralyzed.

title: Bay State Relief Cases Up
description: BOSTON, Oct. 26 (AP)The caseload in the general relief category of welfare assistance in Massachusetts increased 280 per cent from 1961 to 1971, the Massachusetts Taxpayers Foundation said yesterday, and payments during the decade increased 647 per cent.

title: BUCKS BEAT KINGS FOR 5TH STRAIGHT
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 26 (AP)  Bob Dandridge and Oscar Robertson led a thirdperiod surge that carried the Milwaukee Bucks to a 114107 National Basketball Association victory over the Kansas CityOmaha Kings tonight.

title: Panel Finds Half of Poor Still Hungry
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26Despite massive gains during the Nixon Administration, half the nation's poor are still going hungry, according to the findings of a leading citizens' organization on malnutrition.

title: Afghan Historian Slain
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Oct. 26 (AP)An eminent Afghan historian Prof. Mohammud Ali 78 years old, was strangled by thieves in his home early today.

title: U.S. May Speed Shipments Of War Material to Saigon
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 Pentagon sources said today that the Defense Department was considering a significant acceleration of arms shipments to South Vietnam to insure that most of the jets, tanks and artillery previously scheduled for delivery arrive before any ceasefire closes off reinforcement.

title: Lenox Cuts Sales Charges
description: The Lenox Fund, which is managed by a subsidiary of L. M. Rosenthal & Co., Inc., the brokerage firm, said yesterday that it had eliminated sales charges and become a noload fund, a move designed to increase sales.

title: Connecticut
description: Second District: This slice of eastern Connecticut has a chance to send a distinguished man to Congress in the person of Roger Hilsman (Dem.). An Assistant Secretary of State under President Kennedy, Mr. Hilsman resigned over the Vietnam war policy of the Johnson Administration. He faces tough opposition from Representative Robert Steele (Rep.), who has been a reasonably good Congressman with a flair for publicity. Our preference is for Mr. Hilsman.

title: WILLIE KNAPP, 84; ONCE STAR JOCKEY
description: Willie Knapp, the Hall of Fame jockey who rode Upset in the Sanford Stakes at Saratoga in 1919 to hand Man o' War the only defeat in his career, died yesterday at Lbng Island Jewish Hospital, New Hyde Park. Mr. Knapp had been struck by an automobile on Wednesday night. He was 84 years old.

title: BOARD REVERSES SCRIBNER, ORDERS 32 INTO M.S. 211
description: The City Board of Education yesterday overruled Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner and directed that 32 black and Puerto Rican children be admitted to John Wilson Junior High School 211 in Canarsie  the school they had been barred from entering last week when protesting white parents took over the building and shut it down.

title: Krebs for Senate? 95% in Poll Never Heard of Him in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Oct. 26The director of the New Jersey Poll reported today that Paul J. Krebs, the Democratic candidate for United States Senator, had a publicrecognition level that was so low that it defied computer analysis.

title: Text of the South Vietnamese Declaration at the Paris Peace Talks
description: PARIS, Oct. 26 (AP)Following, as made public in English, is the text of the statement delivered at the Paris peace talks today by the South Vietnamese delegate, Nguyen Xuan Phong:

title: Credit Markets
description: Bond prices staged a brief rally early yesterday on reports of a Vietnam peace agreement between the United States and North Vietnam, but the market failed to hold much of its phis.

title: Week's Store Sales Up 11%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The Department of Commerce reported today that departmentstore sales last week were an estimated $911million, up 11 per cent from the yearearlier $822million. Total retailstore sales were an estimated $8.9billion, up 11 per cent from the yearearlier $8billion.

title: House Contest
description: SMITHTOWN, L. I.  Perhaps the greatest help for the candidacy of Joseph H. Boyd Jr., Republican nominee in Suffolk County's First Congressional District, came when the Democrats nominated Senator George McGovern for the Presidency.

title: Term Paper Sales Barred By Massachusetts Judge
description: BOSTON, Oct. 26 (Reuters)A Suffolk County Superior Court judge, Harry Calus, ordered term paper companies in Massachusetts today to stop selling their prepared papers to college students.

title: Ivy League Roundup
description: Triskaidekaphobia? One does not expect to find such words in a sports publicity release, but in this case the Dartmouth etymologist's usage is eminently valid.

title: Power of the Purse
description: Despite the refusal of Congress to grant the President power to make whatever cuts he wanted in spending programs to hold the Federal budget under a $250billion ceiling, Mr. Nixon's aides say that he still intends to impound funds on his own to reach the same objective.

title: Bates Talks About Acting and the Butley Character
description: In recent years Alan Bates has carved out a solid reputation as an international film star, while still retaining his rank as a stage actor of the first magnitude. With Butley, already a hit on the London stage, he returns to Broadway for the first time since Poor Richard in 1964.

title: Doyle E. Carlton Sr. Dies; A Former Florida Governor
description: TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 26 (UPI)Former Gov. Doyle E. Carlton Sr., who cut his own pay to help save the state public school system during the depression years, died yesterday in a nursing home. He was 85 years old.

title: TOWMEN CONTINUE PROTEST ON RATES
description: Towtruck operators jammed streets around City Hall yesterday in a hornblowing, lightflashing demonstration to dramatize their insistence on an increase in the rates they are permitted to charge for hauling disabled vehicles.

title: The Dance: Creativity for a Marathon
description: If it is creativity in the theater that you are looking for then the American Dance Marathon's newest program, shared by the Erick Hawkins Dance Company and Twyla Tharp and Dancers, should top the list.

title: GREENWICH PUPILS GET IMMUNIZATION
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 28 Students, teachers and workers at the Daycroft School, a private institution whose pupils for the most part are Christian Scientists, were immunized today after what health officials described as the most serious outbreak of paralytic polio in the United States in seven years.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: The Appellate Division of Superior Court refused overturn an administrative decision that had cost a bowler first place in a tournament.

title: Thelma Votipka, Soprano, Dies; Sang With the Met for 28 Years
description: Thelma Votiplca, a soprano with the Metropolitan Opera for 28 years, died Tuesday in her apartment at the Ansonia Hotel, Broadway and 73d Street. She was 74 years old.

title: and New Jersey
description: Third District: Representative James J. Howard (Dem.) has been an independent and generally liberal Congressman. His opponent, William F. Dowd (Rep.), a former aide to President Nixon, is strictly proAdministration on all issues. We emphatically endorse Mr. Howard.

title: U.S Indicts 6 in a Conspiracy To Sell 86 Stolen Cars Abroad
description: Four Americans and two Lebanese citizens were charged yesterday with conspiracy and the transportation of 86 stolen cars.

title: Congress: Long Island
description: In offering our recommendations for election to the House of Representatives from Long Island, upstate and nearby Connecticut and New Jersey, we concentrate on those districts in which the contests have particular significanceand where at least one of the candidates seems to us to be qualified, effective and experienced enough to warrant endorsement.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) Senator Robert J. Dole of Kansas, the Republican National Chairman, accused The Washington Post today of engaging in a desperate lastditch effort to prevent the polotical humiliation of their radical friend, Senator George McGovern.

title: NEW PROCESS ADDS PROTEIN TO BREAD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) The Agriculture Department has issued a public patent for a new breadmaking process that its supporters say will put more protein into bread.

title: CITY'S YOUTH BIT TIGHTENING RULES
description: The new head of the city's Youth Services Agency said yesterday that she was reorganizing and tightening up the agency's fiscal procedures as a result of charges against her predecessor, Ted Gross, whom Mayor Lindsay has accused of reprehensible conduct in fiscal transactions.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Oct. 26 (UPI)Llle Nastase of Rumania downed Jurgen Fassbender of West Germany today to gain the semifinals of a Dewar, Cup tennis tournament, 6.4, 26, 64. In the women's quarterfinals Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia beat Wendy Gilchrist of New York, 60, 6.1, and Brenda Kirk of South Africa toppled Julie Heldman of Houston, 64, 16, 64.

title: LAW PROFESSORS ENDORSE MEYER
description: A committee of 102 law pro, fessors from all of the states 11 law schools and including three deans endorsed State Supreme Court Justice Bernard S. Meyer yesterday for election to the Court of Appeals Nov. 7.

title: Truck Volume Increases
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported today that intercity truck tonnage last week was 1.8 per cent above the preceding week. Truck tonnage was 8.8 per cent above the 1971 level. The rail carloadings report will not be available until tomorrow because of the Veterans Day holiday Monday.

title: 9, Including L.I. Official, Seized in TaxBribery Case
description: Nine persons, including a Long ISland municipal official and the president and two other officers of the ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League, were arrested yesterday on charges of conspiracy and bribing Internal Revenue Service agents to fix incometax cases.

title: Numbers Ring Broken Up
description: DETROIT, Oct. 26 (UPI)Federal, state and local authorities have broken up an $11millionayear mutuel numbers combine that the authorities said today represented the largest volume of daily business of any illegal gambling setup in recent times. Nine persons were arrested. One of the prime headquarters raided was the TwentyGrand Hotel.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Two bands of schoolaged youths vandalized two West Side IRT subway trains during yesterday morning's rush hour, frightening passengers and forcing the trains to be taken out of service, the Transit Authority reported. No injuries were reported and no arrests were made, a spokesman said.

title: Texts of Statements Made by Board of Education and by Scribner
description: Following are the texts of the statements by the Board of Education and Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner in the District 18 controversy:

title: U.S. Official Sees No Plan For Revival of the SST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) The controversial supersonic transport project will not be revived in the next Congress, Transportation Under Secretary James M. Beggs said today. He said there was no movement now in the department to revive the 1,800mileanhour plane that was killed by the last Congress, mostly because of opposition from environmentalists who charged the giant jetliner would be too noisy and would pollute the atmosphere.

title: A M'DOWELL SONATA PLAYED BY WINEROCK
description: The four piano sonatas of Edward MacDowell have never found a steady place in the repertory. When one turns up it is something of an event.

title: Recital: Nerine Barrett
description: Nerine Barrett's recital at Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night suggested that the Jamaican pianist has reached a plateau in her career from which she could leap ahead to big things. Miss Barrett's gifts and accomplishments, displayed in abundance at this recital, already have carried her quite far and high. Next must come increased freedom and individuality in interpretation if her climb is to continue. The attractive young artist, now 28, chose a program that steered clear of largescale masterpieces: Chopin's 24 Preludes (Op. 2S) offer all the lyrical and pyrotechnical opportunities one could ask, certainly, but Bartk's Suite (Op. 14) and Schubert's Sonata in B (D.575) are among those composers lesser scores and so Miss Barrett's work was cut out for her. She played the Bartok with admirable absence of clang and bang, and a sensitivity to tonal beauty that made the Sostenuto finale engrossing.

title: Books of The Times
description: When is absurdity Absurd, and when is it simply free association? This was one of the questions that nagged at me as I picked my way through Donald Barthelme's latest volume of short stories, Sadness. I use the word picked advisedly, because that, it seems, is what one has to do with this book. A felicitous sentence here, a good but only partly realized idea there, a few apt, antic word choices now and then: it's rather like going to a Chinese restaurant and eating nothing but appetizers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It is ironic that the Eagleton affaira political decision based on knowledge of prior treatment for mental reasonshas stimulated some persons to regard Senator McGovern as an unsympathetic and indecisive human being, while the more important concerns on attitudes toward mental illnes have been overshadowed. The real mental health needs of this country have not been made an election year issue.

title: DOUBT IS VOICED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Oct. 27The South Vietnamese Foreign Ministry issued a statement this morning that said South Vietnam is ready to accept a ceasefire but would never accept a political settlement which goes against the interests and aspirations of the 17 million South Vietnamese people.

title: Peace at Last?
description: Henry A. Kissinger's firm assurance that peace at hand in Vietnam and his confirmation of the agreement announced by North Vietnam should go far to relieve doubts about the Administration's determination to end the long United States involvement in Indochina. Nevertheless, an apparent delay in the signing of the pact and Saigon's resistance to provisions that require South Vietnamese cooperation indicate that peace remains elusive.

title: Exports Off in September As Imports Set a Record
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 United States merchandise exports declined in September while imports rose to another high, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: 11 Citizens Given City Awards For Efforts in Cleaning Streets
description: Awards were given to 11 New Yorkers yesterday as part of what Administrator Jerome Kretchmer described as the most successful program his Environmental Protection Administration had undertaken to clean up the city's streets.

title: William J. Williamson Is Dead; ExPublisher of The Villager
description: William J. Williamson, publisher of The Villager, Greenwich Village community weekly newspaper, from 1959 to 1969, died of cancer yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 15 West 121h Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Another Veterans Day! I would have missed it but my kids have the day off from schoolwhile I have to work. Next year  all of us veterans should go AWOL on our day. Would our employers grant us amnesty? No way. Well, if Veterans Day cannot be celebrated by veterans, then let's abolish it. Let the nonveteran join with us veterans, both working.

title: Wells Sidelined by Court
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 26 (UPI)  An Alameda County court today prohibited Warren Wells from joining the Houston Oilers in time for their game this weekend, pending clarification of his probationary status, Wells, a wide receiver waived by the Oakland Raiders and claimed by the Oilers, is under care of the court because of a 1969 rape charge.

title: Evolving Peace Terms Resemble 69 Kissinger Plan
description: The formula that Henry A. Kissinger says may be bringing peace in Vietnam nearer is basically the same outline for peace he envisioned in an article he wrote almost four years ago.

title: AGRONOMICS AGREES TO MAKE DISCLOSURES
description: The American Agronomics Corporation, accused in a suit by the Securities and Exchange Commission of failure to make full disclosure in the sale of orangegrove tax shelters in Florida, disclosed last night that it had offered to give investors their money back.

title: Wry Observations From Peter Allen Enliven His Songs
description: Peter Allen, a young Australian singer turned songwriter, has settled into the downstairs room at Tuesday's (appropriately called Tuesday's Bottom), on Third Avenue at 18th Street, with a bag of songs and a lively singing style that could be the start of something big, both for Mr. Allen and for the room.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 26Strict new sanitation regulations for mobile hotdog stands went into effect here today and, as a result, many of the city's 441 hotdog venders may be forced out of business.

title: Horse Crash Kills Car Rider
description: LEWISTOWN, Pa., Oct. 26 (UPI)An automobile passenger was killed yesterday when the vehicle collided with a runaway horse, Tile victim was Jack Mitchell, 51 years old, of Baltimore.

title: FED SAYS GROWTH OF MONEY SLOWS
description: Monetary expansion has slowed markedly in recent weeks, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

title: British Study Finds No Birth Pill Peril, But Issues Caution
description: LONDON, Oct. 26 (AP)A British Government report said today that six years of study had failed to substantiate American warnings that contraceptive pills might contribute to cancer in women.

title: Cambodian Victory Reported
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 26 (AP)The Cambodian command said today that a Cambodian infantry brigade had occupied a large enemy training and staging camp 40 miles west of the capital.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 26 (AP)The Public Service Commission approved today a $3.5million rate increase requested by the Iroquois Gas Corporation of Buffalo, which serves nearly 500,000 customers in Western New York. The increase will add about 75 cents to the average homeowner's heating bill, the company said.

title: Soviet and Italy Agree to Hold HighLevel Consultations Regularly
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 26Italy and the Soviet Union agreed today to hold regular consultations on relations and on the world situation. The talks are to be conducted twice a yeari at the level of Foreign Ministers or their deputies.

title: MacGregor Identifies Four Who Guided Special Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26Clark MacGregor, chairman of the Committee for the Reelection of the President, acknowledged today that selected members of the reelection effort had held control of a special cash fund but he insisted that it had not been used to underwrite sabotage against the Democrats.

title: Ellis Stops Carter in 7th
description: BECKLEY, W. Va., Oct. 26 (AP)Jimmy Ellis knocked down Harold Carter three times and then stopped him at 37 seconds of the seventh round tonight in a scheduled 10round heavyweight bout. Ellis floored Carter for a fivecount in the fifth round and put him down twice in the sixth. The fight was attended by about 1.700.

title: PROFITS ADVANCE AT UNION PACIFIC
description: The Union Pacific Corporation announced yesterday that its profits in the third quarter climbed to $27.7million, or $1.22 a share, from $19.3million, or 86 cents a share, in the yearearlier period.

title: Business Briefs
description: The New York Stock Exchange has begun a routine investigation into trading activity in the shares of the Rheingold Corporaion for the four trading sessions immediately prior to an announcement by Pepsico that it was making a tender offer for 51 per cent of the beer producer's stock.

title: School Buses to Ozone Park Get a Police Escort
description: Once again the police were out in force yesterday to es cort the school buses carrying black and Puerto Rican pupils to Elizabeth Blackwell Junior High School in Ozone Park, Queens.

title: Maj. B. H. Natelson Weds Alice Gordon
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 26 Miss Alice Gordon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Gordon of New York, was married here this noon to Maj. Benjamin H. Natelson, U. S. A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben Natelson, Rabbis Pinellas Teitz and Joseph Preil performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.1 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 124.7 from 124.8 last week.

title: 2 LEADERS NAMED BY SERBIAN PARTY
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 26  A scholar and a skilled worker were named today to take over the posts of chairman and secretary of the central committee of the Serbian Communist party, whose former leaders resigned under criticism from President Tito for ideological liberalism.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 26The director of the New Jersey Poll reported today that Paul J. Krebs, the Democratic candidate for United States Senator, had a publicrecognition level that was so low that it defied computer analysis.

title: Dear Constituent: I Support Nixon
description: WASHINGTONI share certain of the criticisms you and others have raised concerning the Nixon Administration dealing with the war in Vietnam. Yet I can support Richard Nixon for the Presidency despite the fact that I disagree with him on how to extricate us from the quagmire in Vietnam.

title: Laird Briefs NATO Group In London on Strategic Arms
description: LONDON, Oct. 28 (Reuters) Melvin R. Laird, the United States Secretary of Defense, today briefed North Atlantic Treaty Organization officials on the strategic nuclear balance between the superpowers and on the SovietUnited States negotiations on limiting stratecnc arms.

title: Sherwin and 2 Are Guilty Of Conspiracy in Road Bid
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Oct. 28Paul J. Sherwin, New Jersey's Secretary of State, and two codefendants today were found guilty today of conspiring to influence the award of a $600,000 highway contract in return for a $10,000 contribution to the state Republican finance committee.

title: Jewish Weekly Backs Nixon
description: President Nixon was endorsed for reelection yesterday by The Jewish Press, a weekly newspaper with a circulation of 18,000. The endorsement, made in a frontpage editorial in this week's issue, was announced by the New York Committee to Reelect the President. The editorial said that President Nixon would be a better friend for Israel to have in the White House than Senator George McGovern.

title: Eastern Airlines to Seek C.A.B. Aid in TakeOver Bid
description: Eastern Airlines, which has spent two years and. $5million in its bid to take over Caribair, a financially ailing Puerto Rican airline, disclosed yesterday that it would ask the Civil Aeronautics Board to reach an immediate decision.

title: Business Briefs
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Oct. 26 (UPI)Oil ministers from five Persian Gulf oilproducing states met today to continue their search for a common position on how they will participate in the Western oil companies operating in their territories.

title: RECORDS ARE SET FOR POSTWAR ART
description: It was a big night last night at auction for abstract expressionism, pop art and op art, color field minimal painting, kinetics and a variety of sculptures that may still be without classifications.

title: Bangkok Officials Hail The Possibility of Peace
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 27 (Agence FrancePresse)High Thai officials here today welcomed the Indochina peace agreement that Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's national security adviser, said was at hand.

title: About Pro Football
description: Both local, teams play at home again on Sunday with the Jets favored by two touchdowns over New England and the Giants underdogs by one against Washington. Games on television here will be San Francisco at Atlanta, Channel 2, 1 P.M.; Miami at Baltimore, Channel 4, 4 P.M., and on Monday night, Dallas at Detroit, Channel 7, 9 o'clock. Thu halfway mark of the season approaches with eight teams of the 26 in first place in their divisions and 11 more behind by two games or less. Here is a preview of all games with wonlosttied records in parentheses.

title: Orr, With Injured Knee, Is Sidelined Indefinitely
description: BOSTON. Oct. 26 (UPI)Bobby Orr, the Boston Bruins' star defenseman, will be sidelined indefinitely because of his injured left knee.

title: ISRAEL BIDS NATIONS ACT ON ARAB TERROR
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 20Israel has asked governments to take firm action against Arab nations that give diplomatic cover to Arab terrorists and gunrunners, an official disclosed today.

title: ISSUES 1972
description: WASHINGTONIt is not easy to identify George McGovern with any of the categories of traditional politics. One cannot really say he is leftwing or rightwing, or a conservative or liberal because he is a complex mixture and does not lend himself to our usual labels.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26At a time of suspicions, fear and resentment on the path to truce In Vietnam, the White House today pronounced a veiled threat to Saigon and an unmistakable commitment to Hanoi that seal the bargain even before it is signed.

title: MacGregor Identifies Four Who Guided Special Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26Clark MacGregor, chairman of the Committee for the Reelection of the President, acknowledged today that selected members of the reelection efsort had held control of a specail cash fund but he insisted that it had not been used to underwrite sabotage against the Democrats.

title: 400 PROTEST OUSTERS IN FUENTES DISTRICT
description: About 400 principals, assistant principals and supervisors gathered yesterday in front of the offices of the Board of Education at 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, afternoon to protest the dismissal of two principals in the Lower East Side's District 1 by its community school board on the recommendation of its superintendent, Luis Fuentes.

title: A Teaser of Bureaucracy Will Pit Ponies Against the U.S. Mail
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26A man whose motto is when in doubt, mumble, and whose perfect gift for bureaucrats is a pencil with erasers at both ends, is confident of beating the United States mail next week on a pony express between Philadelphia and Washington.

title: UFFA FOX IS DEAD; YACHT DESIGNER
description: LONDON, Oct. 26Uffa Fox, the yacht designer and sailing, companion of the Duke of Edinburgh, died today at the home of a friend near Worcester, His age was 74.

title: REDMAN PLANNING VINTAGE PURCHASE
description: Directors of Redman Industries, Inc., and Vintage Enterprises, Inc., agreed in principle yesterday for Redman to acquire Vintage through an exchange of stock valued at about $40million.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 26  The conviction today of Paul J. Sherwin, New Jersey's Secretary of State, %yds viewed here by a number of officials, both Republican and Democratic, as potentially harmful to Governor Cahill's chances for reelection should be run for second term next year.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Board of Estimate in New York held a stormy hearing on the proposed compromise plan for the Forest Hills lowincome housing project. Board members and witnesses predicted the compromise plan of three 12story buildings would be approved. The main remaining issue is whether to limit the tenants to elderly people and veterans.

title: Writer Sentenced in Turkey Dispatch at The Times, Landon
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 26A martiallaw tribunal here today sentenced Nasill Nuri a writer, to seven and onehalf years in prison for translating a book on the life and works of Lenin. He was also banished under police supervision for two years to a remote district on charges of disseminating Communist propaganda.

title: BODY OF EXECUTIVE FOUND IN FLORIDA
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Oct. 26 (UPI)The body of a man found beneath a pile of palm fronds on Key Biscayne was identified today as that of a missing Alcoa executive, James W. Lindsay, 63 years old, of Pittsburgh.

title: GUARD IS GUILTY OF TAKING BRIBES
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 26Glenn Oldham, one of the 24 correction officers at the Nassau County Jail indicted last June along with two alleged crime figures on a variety of charges, pleaded guilty today to three counts of a 27count indictment.

title: EXTRADITION SOUGHT IN NEWSMAN DISPUTE
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., Oct. 26 (UPI)Gov. Wendell Ford has asked Gov. William O. Milliken of Michigan to extradite a former Louisville CourierJournal reporter, Paul Branzburg, to Kentucky, where Mr. Branzburg faces a contempt of court sentence in Jefferson County.

title: Park Gives Plan to Extend Seoul Rule
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Oct. 27President Park Chung Hee of South Korea formally proposed today sweeping constitutional changes that would pave the way for him to remain in power for life.

title: Busing Fades as Issue in Most Races
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26The busing of children to desegregate schools, which emerged as a heated national issue during the Nixon Administration, has faded into the background in most of the current election campaigns.

title: A.E.C. OFFERS PLAN ON RADIATION LOSS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26The Atomic Energy Commission staff outlined today measures to diminish the possibility of accidental, dangerous radiation losses at nuclear power plants.

title: C.B.S. Wins Network Race on Kissinger Briefing
description: In the inevitable television race to cover yesterday's briefing by Henry A. Kissinger, national security adviser to President Nixon, the Columbia Broadcasting System came in first with the help of an electronic partner called the minicam.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The current antitrust suit against I.B.M. is a classic example of the Government working against its own avowed objectives.

title: Lee Heads Turf Writers
description: Mike Lee, sports editor of The Long Island Press, was elected president of the New York Turf Writers last night at Les Champs Restaurant. He succeeds Jim McCulley of The Daily News. Herb Goldstein will continue as secretary.

title: Chou Is Said to Praise Hanoi's Stand in Talks
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 26 (Agence France  Presse)Premier Chou Enlai said in Peking this evening that China supported North Vietnam's position in the present stage of the peace negotiations with the United States.

title: DC10 Sales Climb
description: Bolstered by heavy DC10 airbus sales, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation reported yesterday sharply higher earnings in the third quarter and first nine months of 1972.

title: Kraftco Hit by Charge
description: Several food companies yesterday reported increased sales and earnings for the latest quarter.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The views concerning the position of Jews in the Presidential election expressed by two former students of mine (OpEd Oct. 9) depressed me deeply by the absence of any reference to the war in Vietnam, by the highly exaggerated claim of pressure the Israelis have put on U.S. Jewry, and above all, by the lack of any reference to the fundamental commitments that characterize Jewishness.

title: Amex and OTC Prices Score Gains
description: Buoyed somewhat by reports that a Vietnam peace settlement is near prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market registered gains in steppedup trading yesterday.

title: Advertising: Penney's Big Bet
description: J. C. Penney, which started to become a really serious national advertiser in August, will cap its efforts with full or partial ElectionDay coverage on all three television networks.

title: S.D.S. to Picket G.O.P. Rally
description: BOSTON, Oct. 26 (AP)Students for a Democratic Society say they will picket an Oct. 31 fundraising rally sponsored here by the Committee for the Reelection of the President. Mrs. Richard M. Nixon is scheduled to address the rally at the Commonwealth Armory.

title: F.B.I. Chief Pledges Fight On the Nation's Extremists
description: L. Patrick Gray 3d, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said yesterday that law enforcement officials were determined to root out what he called the nation's extremists bent on social change through violence.

title: McGovern Aide Received Briefing on Peace Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI)  Gen. Alexander M. Haig, deputy to Henry A. Kissinger, said today that he met Friday with Paul Warnke, Senator George McGovern's representative, on the peace talks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Owner of 3 Companies Is Leading in Cheers
description: DALLAS, Oct. 27Those leggy cheerleaders waving snappy multicolored pompons at the football game tomorrow are more than just a happy contrast to the roughandtumble on the field. They are also the foundation of an extraordinary and profitable business  the cheerleader business.

title: Court of Appeals
description: This is the year of healthy exposure of the shortcomings of the judiciary and the administration of justice. Fortunately the highest court of the State of New York the Court of Appealshas a long and great tradition of legal distinction. Benjamin Cardozo, Samuel Seabury, Irving Lehman and other respected jurists including the present chief judge, Stanley Fuld, have graced this court in Albany. It must remain a sanctuary of law.

title: Allende Breaks Off Talks With Strikers
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 27 (AP)President Salvador Allende Gossens said tonight that he had cut off talks with leaders of unions involved in a twoweekold nationwide strike because they want political concessions that would limit his constitutional powers.

title: Picasso and Poets Ranges Widely
description: The exhibition Picasso and His Poets at the Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street, is one of the liveliest shows in town at the moment. It is devoted to Picasso's book illustrationsand a good deal of literary historyranging from his superb 1911 and 1914 Cubist etchings for two books by his poetfriend Max Jacob, Saint Matorel, and Le Siege de Jerusalem, to his racy etchings for Fernand Crommelynck'se Le Cocu Magnifique, published 1968.

title: 121 OF 352 REGISTER FOR BONUS LOTTERY
description: ALBANY, Oct. 27 (AP)Vendors have sold 352 state lottery tickets that qualify their holders for the state's final bonus lottery drawing Nov. 2, but the whereabouts of 231 of them remains unknown.

title: Jets Philbin, Out of Favor, Sees Redskins as His Hope
description: Gerry Philbin, the New York Jets defensive end, has always been one to speak frankly, laugh at himself and answer questions.

title: Laird Confident on Arms for Saigon
description: LONDON, Oct. 27Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said todar that the limits on military aid to South Vietnam under the proposed peace settlement would permit shipment of sufficient weapons to keep the Saigon Government militarily strong.

title: Dickinson Motifs Keep Tradition Alive
description: The career of the American painter Edwin Dickinson has been a long and distinguished one, and yet his art is without a fixed, secure position in either our minds or our museums. His painting seems to belong to the pastthe dead pasQ as we sayuntil we place it alongside what is really dead in that past, and then it reveals a strikingly personal sensitivity and even boldness. It seems very much alive, whatever its eccentricities or digressions. And yet how distant it seems from the present, how deeply rooted in a personal but remote mode of vision.

title: A Veto in Saigon?
description: North Vietnam has put the Nixon Administration in a difficult position with its insistence that before the end of the month the United States sign the agreement that has been made public by Hanoi and essentially confirmed by Washington.

title: Delta Air Quarterly Net Up 75%
description: Reflecting record revenues, Delta Air Lines, Inc., lifted earnings 75 per cent, in the first fiscal qu'arter ended Sept. 30, according to yesterday's unaudited report from the line's headquarters in Atlanta.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 27The restructuring of the state's Department of Institutions and Agencies is under renewed scrutiny here.

title: Peking's Year at the U.N. Enlightens China Watchers
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27In the year that Peking has been a member of the United Nations, diplomats have come to know a great deal about its foreign policy.

title: NETS TOP ROCKETS AS ROCHE EXCELS
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 27A hotshooting first half and John Roche's clutch baskets gave the Nets a 117112 victory tonight over the Denver Rockets at the Nassau Coliseum. It was the third straight American Basketball Association triumph for the Nets, who played well in spurts, and the third loss in three nights for Denver, winner of four of its first five games.

title: Trumpet Taken Off Statue
description: HOLLYWOOD (UPI)A thief, stole the $450 trumpet held to the lips of a wax figure of the late jazz great, Louis Armstrong, at the Hollywood wax museum, the police said.

title: F.B.I. Ends Compilation of Data On Those in Congressional Races
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27L. Patrick Gray 3d, the acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, disclosed today that for 22 years the bureau had been compiling biographical data on major Congressional candidates. He said he was ending the practice immediately.

title: KOSYGIN SUPPORTS MORE NEGOTIATION
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 27  Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin expressed hope today that further Vietnam negotiations would be held and that they would soon lead to an agreement ending the war.

title: Manila Ousts Americans Linked to Communists
description: MANILA, Oct. 27 (AP) Four Americans, including three working for the National Lawyers Guild in a counseling project for American servicemen, were deported from the Philippines today, the Government reported.

title: PRICES ARE LOWER ON AMEX AND OTC A Late Rally on Exchange Erases Earlier Loss
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market finished slightly lower yesterday as the trading pace slowed.

title: Opera: Well Sung Zauberflote at Met
description: Mozart's Die Zauberflote, absent from the repertory of the Metropolitan Opera for two seasons, was restored on Thursday night, along with the nowfamous colorsplashed settings and costumes by Marc Chagall. There were a number of singers new to their roles and a conductor who had not led the work here before. The result: a performance extremely well sung but not very well conducted.

title: Tulsa Coach Replaced
description: TULSA, Okla., Oct. 27 (AP)Claude Gibson was replaced today as football coach at the University of Tulsa. F. A. Fry, athletic director, assumed the coaching duties. Tulsa })as won one game and lost five.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAGIN
