The remark was already current fifteen years before the Queen's birth, as may be seen from Rousseau's Confessions, book vi. It is attributed there to a great princess and it was probably an old chestnut when Rousseau first heard it, as a tutor in the Mably household around 1740.

title: MonmouthOcean
description: Central Ocean pulled off the biggest upset of the Jersey shore area season yesterday when it defeated Ocean Township, 160, at Ocean Township's field. Ocean Twp, had entered the game as a heavy favoriteuntied and unscoredupon in five previous decisions.

title: McGovern Bars Unity Drive If Beaten
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28 (AP) Senator George McGovern contends that he will win the Presidential election despite the pollsters odds against him, but he adds that if he loses he could not in good conscience ask the American people to rally behind a victorious President Nixon.

title: One good Lessing and twelve lesser
description: Twelve of the thirteen stories in Doris Lessing's new collection add little to one's sense of her development as a writer. The old subjects are there (the hazards of sex and politics; the terrors of poverty; the imminence of a sciencefiction apocalypse); but the forms are so slight (anecdotes, sketches, monologues masquerading as tales) that little drama is generated and not much illumination comes through. The title piece, though, is firstrate: a powerful, suggestive novella about the religious temptation of a rational man.

title: Capitalism Is Alive but Not So Well in Yugoslavia
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia Slobodan Ristic, one of Marxist Yugoslavia's most successful private enterpreneurs, has an office at his rubbergoods factory only large enough for a desk, a few chairs and his master craftsman's diploma on the wall. But he owns a Volvo station wagon and a tastefully furnished villa.

title: The Screen: Farewell Uncle Tom
description: The events dramatized in Farewell Uncle Torn are anything but coincidental, says the solemnforeword to this latest safari by the welltraveled Italian moviemakers, Gualtiero Jacopetti and Franco Prosperi. But despite this introduction and the gently nostalgic title, their color feature, which opened yesterday at the Cinerama and other theaters, is more a voyeur's view of not a sad good by to, some lurid aspects of American Slavery.

title: Jim Duncan, 19461972: The Case is Closed, but the Mystery Remains
description: LANCASTER, S. C., Oct. 28 Jim Duncan, a cornerback with the Baltimore Colts when they won Super Bowl V, has been dead for more than a week, an apparent suicide with a policeman's revolver. But many elements surrounding his life and his death remain a mystery.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Three women, all Democrats, are among the majorparty candidates for the State Senate, which has had only three women members in its history and none since 1965.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: The first results yesterday of the straw poll conducted by The Daily News showed President Nixon leading Senator George McGovern by 65 per cent to 35 per cent in New York State and 56 per cent to 44 per cent in New York City.

title: Everything Is Relatives
description: WHAT the world needs now is a monster movie for the whole family. At least that's what hubbyandwife team Don Quine and Judy Balaban seem to feel, Some time next month in California, shooting will get under way on their coproduction, Trick or Treat, which is all about a gang of ingratiating adolescents who save their hometown from a horde of horrible monsters, Quine, working from his own story and a script by Peter S. Beagle, will handle the directorial chores.

title: Melvin Luebke, Headmaster Of School for Deaf on L. I.
description: MILL NECK, L. I., Oct. 28Melvin W. Luebke, headmaster of the Mill Neck Manor School for the Deaf since its founding 22 years ago, died yesterday in the Glen Cove Community Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived on Frost Mill Road.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 28 (AP)The Seattle PostIntelligencer, citing the President's sound fiscal and social practices, has endorsed Mr. Nixon's bid for reelection.

title: 2 EAST GERMANS TELL OF FLEEING
description: BERLIN, Oct. 28The two young men had coma to West Germany on a clandestine trip via Prague. They were East German students seeking asylum in the West.

title: The price is very high; the price of delay is vastly higher:
description: America's national psyche is troubled today, although we hide it in multiple ways. We namecall, hide behind code words, pass the buck. Some even say that all goes well, that there are no real problems. But there are. The New York Times editorial endorsing McGovern for President spoke of the need for a perception of the things that are wrong with America politically, socially, economically, morallyas well as the things that are right; and a sense of priorities that gives precedence to human needs and pubiic integrity over the panoply of wealth and the arrogance of power.

title: Cambodians Are Facing a Bleak Future
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 28  In this country, where most of the seven million people are believers in mystical signs and spirits, there has been a spate of omens this month. These manifestations, unfortunately, are the only things that have given any hope to the disillusioned Khmer people that peace might return to them after two and a half years of a hopeless war that they did not want or seek.

title: The World
description: CAIROEgypt's, relations with the Soviet Union have long been domestic issue of burning importance here. This was brought home last week in a number of ways.

title: The Nation
description: In the novels of Horatio Alger, so shrewdly shaped to a national daydream, a poor but honest boy won approbation, respect and wealth through the performance of some act of courage, charity or general worthiness under the right eyes.

title: Music
description: IT'S a success story, sort of. Last May, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center (hereafter referred to as CMSLC), finishing its third full season, was gathered to the bosom of Lincoln Center and made a full constituent, along with the Metropolitan Opera, the City Center, the New York Philharmonic and the library and drama groups. Now CMSLC sits on the Lincoln Center hoard and council, with all the pleasures and headaches thereof. And last Friday it opened its fourth season at Tully Hall, happy in the realization that its 24 concerts are sold out in advance. A limited number of rush seats are offered for each concert, to take care of students and public.

title: Angus Green Weds Gretchen E. Beck
description: Miss Gretchen Elizabeth Beck, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Beck of Ithaca. N.Y. was married yesterday morning to Angus MacDonald Green, son of Mrs. Edith Shaw Green of Ocean City, Md., and the late Angus MacDonald Green.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: RICHMOND, Oct. 28 (AP)William and Mary stood off a late passing barrage and beat Virginia Tech, 1716, in the Tobacco Festival football game today.

title: Where the Wasteland Ends
description: To the Editor: A society that refuses to accept science for what it isa marvelously efficient way to get things done, and no moredeserves a Theodore Roszak. Especially Roszak's latest book, Where the Wasteland Ends. Politics and Transcendence in Postindustrial Society. In my opinion, it deserves better than George Stade's brilliantlyconstructed albeit uneasy defense of rationality in his essayreview  a dead horse if ever there was one.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: I am the playwright referred to in Helen Epstein's  And the Mexico of Violence in the Night (Travel section, Aug. 27). [The article chronicled the events which took place after Sally Thomasson, an American resident of San Miguel de Allende, had been shot by a wouldbe rapist who entered her apartment; the article also described the lifestyle of Americans living in San Miguel.] I am writing to comment on Sally's letter to the editor (Travel section, Oct. 8) and give my version of exactly what happened from the time Sally was shot until she was, finally, placed in competent doctors hands.

title: Cooke Leads Dedication Of New Fordham Building
description: Cardinal Cooke presided yesterday at a special mass dedicating the new $5.5million Fordham Preparatory School building on the Bronx campus of Fordham University.

title: MUSLIMS PURGE POLICE MEMBERS
description: The Black Muslims in New York have expelled dozens of their members who work as policemen. The action apparently came as the result of fears that some of the policemen might be undercover agents.

title: Music: Charles Aznavour Concerts
description: Charles Aznavour Seems such a lonely figure On., the huge Carnegie Hall Stage, Where he opened a series of concerts Thursday evening that will continue through today, small, thin as a straw, with huge, vulnerable eyes in a forlorn, angular face.

title: F. and M. Clinches Title
description: ANNVILLE, Pa., Oct. 28 (AP)  Franklin and Marshall clinched its second straight Middle Atlantic Conference Southern Division championship today by thrashing Lebanon Valley, 276. The victory was the ninth straight for F. and M.

title: HOUSING SCANDAL IN DETROIT GROWS
description: DETROIT, Oct. 28  Federal housing officials said today that home repair companies had been cheating the Government, collecting for work they were not doing on Governmentowned houses here.

title: The World
description: LONDONAt 6:30 Friday night, Prime Minister Heath, looking weary from days and nights of battling with Britain's latest economic troubles, climbed into his car outside 10 Downing Street and drove off Into tbo darkness, accompanied only by one policeman and a chauffeur. He headed for Chequers, his country home, to rest and to contemplate his moves as the crisis approaches a climax this week.

title: Play after play to find the answer
description: That our most distinguished playwright is at the same time perhaps the most relentlessly depressing writer in our entire literary history, and that most of his work constitutes a compulsive selfanalysis in terms of what the past has made of him, tell us important and sobering things about ourselves. According to Travis Bogard in this exhaustive, convincing study, Eugene O'Neill wrote play after play in a compulsive need to establish his identity, to search out the roots of his psychological painall of his work evolving into A Long Day's Journey into Night. Literally, Bogard states, it is this play he lived to write  and this play is the highest achievement of the American realistic theater.

title: HOLY CROSS TOPS VILLANOVA, 269
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 28 (AP)John Provost ran 55 yards to score with an interception early in the fourth quarter today and 19 seconds later Pete Vaas threw a 33yard touchdown pass to Rich Pelletier as Holy Cross went on to defeat Villanova, 269.

title: New &Novel
description: Walter Kempley's THE PROBABILITY FACTOR (Saturday Review, $5.95) could just L as well have been named Murder by Computer, for that is what it is all about. And a more farcical, madder crime book will be hard to find.

title: Catholics Ease Pastorate Qualification
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn recently filled two open pastorates under a revived system of selection that reduced the number of years a priest must serve before becoming eligible.

title: Visitors Jam Wildlife Area
description: Naturewatchers have been flooding New Jersey's sprawling, 5,500acre Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge in Morris County.

title: Lloyd Graf Jr. Weds Joan P. Stephenson
description: DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 28In the chapel at Duke University here at noon today Miss Joan Priscilla Stephenson, who received a bachelor's degree from the university in May, was married to Lloyd Herbert Graf, Jr., a candidate for a Ph.D. degree in microbiology there. The Protestant ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. James T. Cleland, dean of the chapel.

title: Anthony Burgess meets New York
description: I have previously known New York from the safe and venerable comfort of the Algonquin. Now I am renting an apartment at Broadway and 93d, and this, I think, makes me a sort of New Yorker. New Yorkers are defined existentially. The most notable ones weren't born here, and who, especially nowadays, can put a term to the number of days he thinks he may live here? Being a New Yorker seems to mean knowing one's way round the subway system, being recognized as neighbor, being greeted by name (even if the wrong name) in particular supermarkets, bars and Chinese restaurants. It means being able to show visitors from Salt Lake City, Minneapolis and Macon (Georgia) around, no matter how echt American these visitors are. In New York one hardly dare ask what an American is. If you define it in terms of language. I seem to be more American than most of the people who live round here.

title: New York
description: On a network television movie last week a group of passengers was trapped by an earthquake in the labyrinthian bowels of the New York subway system. The hero: A policeman who led them to safety past collapsing tunnels, torrents of water and a predatory junkie.

title: Campaign
description: WASHINGTONRichard Nixon did an extraordinary thing last weekhe actually appeared, in public no less, with Republican candidates running for office.

title: FIREBOATS ON JOB IN CITY A CENTURY
description: The city's fireboats, which were instrumental in putting out the spectacular fire in the Arthur Kill on Wednesday that followed an, oilbarge explosion, go back more than a century in the city's history.

title: 89th National Horse Show Gets Under Way Tuesday at Garden
description: It was an eventful year, 1883.

title: Pilgrimage for Black Americans: The Slave Castles of West Africa
description: FOR good reason, Plymouth Rock is a universal symbol for the American experience. Most Americans shared with the Pilgrims their flight to a promising new land to start a new life. Most Americans, but riot all.

title: ROLAND W. DUMAIS
description: HOLLYWOOD; Fla., Oct. 28 (AP)Poland W. Duinaii; vhb piloted the passenger airplane Caroline during John F. Kennedy's 1960 Presidential campaign, died Thursday at the age of 53.

title: HERBERT THOMS, BIRTH CURB AIDE
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 28 (AP) Dr. Herbert Thorns, an obstetrician and gynecologist who pioneered in natural childbirth and birth control, died yesterday at YaleNew Haven Hospital after a long illness. He was 87 years old.

title: Ulrich von Ziegesar Marries Mary Wright in Ruxton, Md.
description: RUXTON, Md., Oct. 28Miss Mary Adele Wright, a granddaughter of the late Floyd L. Carlisle, who was chairman of the boards of Consolidated Edison Company, of New York, Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, St. Regis Paper Company and of the Eastern States Corporation, was married here at noon today to Ulrich von Ziegesar.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Dr. Henry Kissinger's confident assertion that peace is at hand in Indochina is the most welcome statement from a public official or from any Administration since the resolution of the Cuban missile crisis. At long last, after so many illusory lights at the end of the tunnel, and beyond the natural sense of relief that this announcement did not bring news of invasion, bombing, mining or deadlock, Dr. Kissinger managed to be convincing that the longest war in our history is about over.

title: Mt. Holly Fighting to Move Jail
description: MOUNT HOLLY  The Board of Freeholders has agreed to consider a demand by Mayor Joseph D. Weber Jr. to move the Burlington County jail from the central business district here to less populous site.

title: Music
description: THE Symphony of the New World opens another season this afternoon at Philharmonic Hall. This statement has more significance than appears on the surface, because the organization went through an internal upheaval last spring that threatened its existence. It survived that ordeal, with Benjamin Steinberg, the original conductor, stepping down in favor of an administrative group of founderplayers. (It will be interesting to see if another New York City enseinble, the American Symphony Orchestra, survives the loss of its founderconductor, Leopold Stokowski, who is retired and ill in England. As yet, it has been unable to schedule any regular concerts this season, although it has played a couple for private organizations.)

title: Albatross Beats Nansemond by 2 3/4 Lengths in Pace Derby
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 28A final quarter in 28 2/5 seconds failed to give Albatross, haress racing's big bird, the world record for 11/4 miles, but it led to a 23/4length victory over Nansemond in the $50,000 National Pacing Derby at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

title: Dr. Geerat Vermeij Weds Edith Zipser
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 28Miss Edith Zipser, a candidate for a doctorate in biology at Yale University, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Geerat J. Vermeij, who received his Ph.D. in biology from Yale last year. Justice of the Peace Harriet Seligson performed the ceremony in the chapel of Yale's Branford College.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security affairs, had a bigger impact on the stock market last week than any other force. In fact, many brokers were calling it the Kissinger market.

title: Connecticut Co. Bus Line Agrees to Keep Operating
description: The Connecticut Company agreed yesterday to obey court order barring a planned shutdown of bus service at midnight in Hartford, New Haven and Stamford.

title: Notre Dame Downs Tex. Christian, 210, With Ground Attack
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 28 Art Best, a freshman halfback, ran 57 yards for a touchdown today, his second long scoring dash in two games for Notre Dame, to spark the Irish to a 210 victory over Texas Christian.

title: New &Novel
description: Pippa Rowantree, an English girl motorbiking in Italy, is sideswiped by the limousine of the enigmatic Count D'Anza. Instead of seeking a good negligence lawyer, Pippa agrees (or seems to agree) to convalesce from a nasty head wound on the count's peculiar island, Isola Malcontenta. (Symbolism!) D'Anza, it turns out, is not entirely an old dear, but a sickie whose hobbies are infrared photography and fetishism.

title: Maryland Court Calls Death For Rape Unconstitutional
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 28 (AP)  The Maryland Court of Special Appeals has ruled that a Maryland law imposing the death sentence for rape convictions was unconstitutional.

title: Arabian Horse to Co To Winner of a Raffle
description: A purebred Arabian horse will be raffled off by the National Horse Show at the closing session on Nov. 7.

title: Horse Show News
description: Barney Ward, a chunky 29yearold professional rider, has been aiming at the National Horse Show all summer.

title: TOP SOVIET CRITIC ATTACKS 3 NAYS
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 26  As part of this year's broadening campaign of ideological vigilance in the arts, three new plays have just come under fire for ideological failings, including one on the relations between Pushkin and Czar Nicholas I.

title: Music
description: WATCHUNG  Good jazz is not in such great supply in this area for one to quibble about the reasons for bringing such jazzmen as Bobby Hackett, Vic Dickenson, Doc Cheatham, Kenny Davern, Herb Hall and Joe Thomas out here. All of them have appeared in recent weeks at O'Connor's Beef n Ale house, a big, rambling place out in the country north of Plainfield.

title: FORDHAMBOWS, 150; DREXEL WINS FIRST
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 Drexel posted its first victory of the football season, defeating Fordham, 150, in a driving rain at Drexel Field today.

title: Jane Blackburn Wed
description: WESTON, Conn., Oct. 28  Miss Jane Walker Blackburn, daughter of Mrs. Brevoort Walden, was married here this afternoon to F. Stephen West, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wellington West Jr. of Westpoint, Shelly Bay, Bermuda. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George R. Laedlein in the Emmanuel Episcopal Church. The bride was formerly employed by the Bermuda Department of Tourism and Princess Hotels International, both in New York. Mr. West, whose family arrived in Bermuda in 1618, owns his own architectural services company.

title: HAROLD P. GOLDMAN
description: Harold P. Goldman, a lawyer and senior partner of Goldman, Charney & Mordlinger, 420 Lexington Avenue, died Friday, apparently of a cardiac arrest, at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at 95 Christopher Street.

title: Travel Notes: A European Hotel on Wheels
description: T HE travel industry seems to be courting young people these days more ardently than a gigolo going after a pretty heiress. The latest wrinkle is an extremely economical travelcumcamping venture in Europe organized by Exprinter International (500 Fifth Avenue) and patterned on Europeanoperated program that has already had great success. The heart of Exprinter's tours on wheels is the Hotelbus, a vehicle that serves as a mobile home for tour members, complete with bunks, bedding, kitchen units, closet and locker space and baggage and sanitary facilities.

title: Miss Schaberg Becomes Bride
description: NEWTON, N. J., Oct. 28Miss Nancy C. Schaberg and John L. Beringer were married here this morning in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Thomas H. Murphy.

title: Louisville Ace Scores His 66th Touchdown
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 27 (AP)Howard Stevens, Louisville's cannonball tailback, shattereu the collegiate records for career touchdowns and rushing yardage today as he led the unbeaten Cardinals to a 3813 victory over Cincinnati.

title: ExAddicts Train For the Job World
description: JERSEY CITY  Two former heroin addicts will soon move out of the drug world as they become the first graduates of the Vocational Adjustment Center in the Meadowlands.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Ron Hollander's article was excellent. But quite apart from the African panorama that the great snake slithers through, the East African Railway is a show unto itself.

title: Mary Strong Tewksbury Is Bride
description: RYE, N.Y., Oct. 28Miss Mary Strong Tewksbury, employment manager with Brown Brothers Harriman & Co., bankers, was married here this afternoon to Richard Charles Newnham, vice president for marketing with the Simera Corporation, an advertising and marketing company in New York. The Rev. Calhoun Wick performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Presto change! Giorgio di Sant Angelo!
description: Giorgio di Sant'Angelo is a rara avis of a designer. He lights on a fashion and does it to the ultimate, often before it's even recognized as such by the most fashioneducated eyes. By then Giorgio's soaring into other projects that touch on every aspect of fashion  jewelry, clothes, even underwear. (Sant'Angelo usually builds it right into his clothes). And he always leaves his mark. (Remember gypsies? And Indians?) Now Sant Angelo thinks seriously about today's woman. He believes in clothes that do something, preferably lots of thingsespecially if they are expensive, as his are. His fall collection was a series of clothes that are capable of miraculous aboutchanges. Giorgio's model, Anjelica Huston, here transforms three of these chameloncostumes: one, a long dress with a train thatwell, the top row shows what can be done; another long dress with a capeskirtheaddress and a pants costume with Giorgio himself doing the presto chango! The clothes shown here range from $250 for the pants suit to a big $615 for the dress and cape. To order from Elizabeth Arden.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: According to your New Jersey Sunday edition, the bowandarrow hunting season began Oct. 7 and will run through Nov. 9. In that period, in this state alone, 30,000 hunters, 3,000 of them novices, will be beating the woods in the hope of bringing down some luckless animal, preferably a deer. Whatever they hit, they will maim far mote often than they will kill.

title: Dean of University Takes His Baby Son To Work With Him
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 28 (AP)Dr. Hendrik Gideonse, a dean at the University of Cincinnati, takes his 10weekold son to work with him, and his wife drops in at the office regularly to breastfeed the baby.

title: GROWTH DECRIED FOR COAST COUNTY
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., Oct 28At the borders of this county seat on the San Francisco peninsula are wooden signs that proclaim: Weather Best by Government Test.

title: NIXON APPROVES PLAN TO ASSURE PRODUCT SAFETY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28President Nixon has signed legislation creating an independent commission with authority to set and enforce safety standards on thousands of consumer products.

title: Lucretia McCalmont Of Fortune Is a Bride
description: Miss Lucretia Anne McCalmont, an associate editor of Fortune magazine, was married in the Unitarian Church in Richmond, S. I., yesterday afternoon to William Fain Marmon Jr., a staff correspondent with Time magazine. The Rev. Horace Colpitts performed the ceremony.

title: News of Dogs
description: Little dogs are the big attraction at two sites here today.

title: DR. HARRY A. ALTNER
description: Dr. Harry A. Altner, director of anesthesiology at the Peninsula Hospital Center, Far Rockaway, Queens, from 1942 to 1961, died yesterday at the center. He was 71 years old and lived at 11916 Rockaway Beach Boulevard, Rockaway Park, Queens.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: As a small investor I wish to reply to James J. Needham's article Institutions as Brokers (Oct. 22).

title: World News Briefs
description: PARIS, Oct. 28  President Nixon's senior narcotics adviser told today of a series arrests that, he said, incapacitated a Latin drug connection to the United States. This might be a blow from which the underworld could not recover, said Nelson Gross, Senior Adviser to the Secretary of State and Coordinator for International Narcotics Matters.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The rail journey from Kampala lo Nairobi is one of the slowest, most scenic in the world, and Ron Hollander's article On the East African Railway: Going to the Nile's Source, (Travel section, Oct. 1) brought back vivid memories for meof hugging my blanket at dawn as we reached Timbotoa, not far from the Equator but 9,000 feet up, and of how each little station became a trading post as our train whistled in.

title: F.M. TOLD TO AID NIXON, TIME SAYS
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in 14 states were ordered to help the Nixon reelection effort by identifying local campaign issues related to criminal justice, according to Time magazine. It said the request for F.B.I. help had originated with John D. Ehrlichman, President Nixon's chief domestic adviser.

title: Dragon by the Tail
description: In 1931 John Paton Davies Jr, started out on a Foreign Service career that was to immerse him in the Chinese Revolution for two decades and to end in his being fired by John Foster Dulles. In 1946 Seymour Topping began a newspaper reporting career that spanned the fall of Chiang Kaishek, the triumph of Mao Tsestung, two decades of American intervention in Asiaand, in May, 1971, his joyous return to China in the aftermath of PingPong. Both men have now written a China and me traveloguememoir; and each, in its is a good book.

title: PRICE RISES HERE LED U.S. IN 196671
description: Consumer prices increased more sharply in the New York metropolitan area over the last five years than in any other area of the country, according to a report by the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Coast Antique Dealer Meets an Old Friend
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28 (UPI)John T. Shiels owned an antique shop in the West Hollywood area in the ninetenfifties. In 1958, someone stole an 18th century painting, Lady with Satyr, valued at $1,100. That and four other burglaries drove him out of the antique trade.

title: Cardinal Cooke Asking Prayer for Asian Peace
description: Cardinal Cooke asked all Roman Catholics yesterday to join in prayers for peace in Southeast Asia. Specifically, he requested that the pastors of the 408 churcnes In the Archdiocese of New York lead their congregations in special prayer today.

title: Riders Learn What Police Do
description: PLAINFIELD  A Ride Along Program, developed here last year, allows resident 16 years of age or older to join the police on their regular tours of duty in patrol cars.

title: Miss Susan Demlein Is Married Upstate
description: DE WITT, N. Y., Oct. 28Miss Susan Margaret Demlein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Demlein of Syracuse, was married here this morning to Vincent A. Powell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Powell of the Bronx.

title: Tiens! Now they're making vegetable pie!
description: The cauliflower crop is big and beautiful this year, enough to spur a cook's imagination. And fresh spinach, zucchini and Swiss chard are bountiful. Here are two unusual vegetable appetizers starring the season's harvest. Both were adapted by Bert Greene, proprietor of The Store in Amagansett, L. I., from dishes that caught his fancy in France. The pie, which he calls Tiens! (he translates it as Look here!) is doubly unusual in that it has no crust. In France, it is usually served chilled with a dry white wine as an appetizer, but it is equally appealing served warm either as an appetizer or as a vegetable to accompany cold meats.

title: Movies
description: SHE bounces down the Waldorf Towers hallway. Her body, from the waist up, precedes the rest of her by thirty seconds. The fourinch platform wedgies do it. They build up her 5footlinch tinyness, but weigh down her legs so that the bottom half lags behind. The first thought is a cuddle doll on a pulltoy wagon, all blonde and golden and a trifle wobbly.

title: Preps
description: EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Oct. 28Fordham Prep's powerrunning duo of Orest Kozicky and Larry Bellone combined for three touchdowns and a conversion today as the Little Rams trounced Wheatley, 287. Kozicky, a senior halfback, was unstoppable. He racked up 272 yards rushing in 17 carries, and scored on runs of 97 and 46 yards.

title: the traveler's world
description: FACILITATION is a five syllable word government officials and travel executives use when they must talk publicly about how they make life tough for the business and pleasure traveler, especially when neither wants to take the responsibility. The Secretary of Transportation of the United States, John A. Volpe, recently sponsored in Washington a twoday Transportation Facilitation Forum with a program titled Improvement of Services for People Who Travel. The banner across the front of the meeting hall bore this slogan: Doing More for People Who Travel.

title: Some Social Events in the Weeks Ahead
description: Oct. 31, Nov. 1The annual Christmas Boutique of the New York Botanical Garden Shop will offer plants for house and garden and equipment to nurse them, plus unusual gifts for adults and nonadults from 10 to o'clock at the St. RegisSheraton. Mrs. Harding F. Bancroft is chairman.

title: Coins
description: ANOTHER of the East's colorful coin shows moves into the spotlight here Thursday when the Eighth annual Grand Central convention gets under way at the Americana Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 52d Street. The fourday event is sponsored by the Long Island Coin Club.

title: The auto crash as sexual stimulation
description: One of the strippers whom nightclubbers in Singapore found especially bewitching was a big Australian girl who crouched on a stationary motorcycle and flung her clothes off. But the music and lights created the illusion of the motorcycle speeding along, and after a sequence of antipodean gymnastics there was a terrific crash, the motorcycle tipped over and the strippernow completely nakedsprawled in a grotesque simulation of an accident victim, her arms tangled in the steering gear, her legs scissored open and all askew. The Chinese, not noted for extravagant displays of appreciation, applauded this wildly. The act ran for months and just about put the Korean kicklines out of business.

title: Oilers Whip Whalers 41
description: BOSTON, Oct. 28 (AP)Jack Norris turned in an outstanding performance in the nets of kicking out 43 shots, to help the Alberta Oilers score a 41 victory over the New England Whalers tonight.

title: Ches: Spassky's Problem Is Solved (But Too Late) by Gligoric
description: One of the most dramatic points of last summer's world championship match between Boris Spassky and Bobby Fischer came in round three. Fischer had lost the first game on blunders and the second by forfeit  he failed to show up in a protest over television cameras and, with the score 20 against him, no one would bet he would continue.

title: Analysts Have to Eat, Too
description: The New York Society of Security Analysts daily luncheon spotlighting corporations is (A) an elevated forum where the giants of industry hold forth before the most sophisticated observers of business, (B) a nice opportunity to have, a $4.75 nonalcoholic lunch, (C) the only game in town for harddigging but timepressed stock analysts, (D) largely a vacuous ritual that insults both the mind and the stomach.

title: The Truth About Lie Detectors in Business
description: The lie detector, once used almost entirely for government security applications and criminal investigations, is being appropriated by more and more businesses as a routine tool for screening employes and job applicants.

title: TRIBAL LAND CASE PUT UP TO COURT
description: SANTA FE, N. M., Oct. 28Jurisdiction over activities by Indians on their own lands has long been left to the Federal authorities by the State of New Mexico, but the leasing of section of the Tesuque Pueblo, 10 miles north of this city, to nonIndian development company has raised a complicated legal question for the state.

title: Preps
description: SOUTHBORO, Mass., Oct. 28 John Griffin, a swift junich halfback from Pittsburgh, rep turned punts 70 and 73 yards for touch downs to lead Milton to its fifth straight victory, 32 14, against St. Mark's today. 1 Giandomenico, the Milton captain, added touchdowns on runs of 53, 6 and 2 yards.

title: Timely Favors
description: New York

title: Agriculture Agency Studies Price Rises For Milk Products
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28The Nixon Administration is considering a change in the wholesale, price structure for milk products that would increase consumer costs.

title: Brooklyn Before The Bridge
description: From The Great Bridge by David McCullough. Copyright 1972 by David McCullough. Reprinted by permission of Simon & Schuster, Inc.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28Senator George McGoverns farewell day, in California had solid impact in the local media but was considerably less effective elsewhere in the country.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 28 (AP)SThe Houston Chronicle editorially endorsed President Nixon for reelection in its Sunday editions. We believe President Nixon has demonstrated his ability to perform, the editorial said.

title: Connecticut
description: Greenwich moved into sole possession of first place in the Fairfield County west division yesterday with a 15.6 victory over Trumbull. Both teams had been tied for the division lead with Danbury.

title: Hobart Beats Union, 28.21, As Kowalski Gets 3 Scores
description: GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 28 Rich Kowalski scored three touchdowns, two of them in the second half, to lead Hobart College to a 2821 victory over Union College today.

title: Television
description: THERE they are, America's sweethearts, relaxing not in a cutebutcramped apartment above a Lower East Side deli but in a plush cornflowerblue suite in the St. Regis Hotel. Bridget (Meredith Baxter) is stretched out on a flowery sofa, looking like a college coed in a blue and white argyle sweater and a blue wool skirt. Her cherubic face is scrubbed free of makeup. Bernie (David Birney) sits in a nearby chair, puffing on a pipe in a brown Vneck sweater and tweedy pants as strains of Mozart play softly from a tape recorder.

title: Artist Redefines BlackTie Dinner for a Princess
description: Robert Rauschenberg's formal dinner for Her Royal Highness Princess Christina of Sweden was perhaps the most unusual interpretation of a blacktie party since somebody dressed a monkey in a dinner jacket and seated it next the hostess.

title: Harrier Meets Put Off
description: Heavy rains forced the postponement yesterday of crosscountry competition for the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association and the Public Schools Athletic League at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. The C.H.S.A.A. sectional meet was rescheduled for next Saturday at 1:30 P.M. The P.S.A.L. threeborough meet will be staged Tuesday, beginning at 3:15 P.M.

title: dames Edge Canueks, 21
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Oct. 28 (UPI)Jacques Richard and Bill MacMillan scored tonight to lead the Atlanta Flames to a 21 victory over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: U.S. Women Visiting Hanoi
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 28 (Agencel FrancePresse)  A group of American women arrived in Hanoi today for a visit at the invitation of the Vietnam Committee for Solidarity with the American People and the Vietnam Women's Union, the North Vietnamese press agency reported. The visitors included Jane Hart, wife of Senator Philip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, and the poets Denise Leverlov and Muriel Ruykcyscr.

title: One by One
description: The significance of the title is borne home by the outcome of this unusually subtle courtroom novel. Until he reaches the point where the title becomes a revelation, the author sifts the ambiguities of race relations in America. His instrument for evaluating social justice is Ben Waddell, a black assistant D.A. in an American metropolis, and a seeming pillar of law and order. Waddell has been a jazz musician, fighter pilot and Korean P.O.W. (as was the author) before entering the law. The sum of his experience has left him with a degree of moral confusion, especially as regards his role in the blackEstablishment relationship. Waddell does not subscribe to what he calls the Grand Illusionthe belief in full enfranchisement in the larger culture. Nonetheless, he has opted for total personal success in that culture.

title: About Motor Sports
description: If the top echelon of the Sports Car Club of America seems to be a band of badgewearing lotus eaters, is there a reason for it? An almost universal criticism in the racing community is that the club can seldom move quickly because of its membersgovernorsstaff structure, overlaid with a heavy smog of politics. Such democracy is fine for club racing and rallies, the argument goes, but In pro fessional racing it is quite unbusinesslike. Another observation is that sponsors investing hundreds of thousands of dollars in racing are unhappy about entrusting their stake to the caprice of hobbyists, who may not be around next season.

title: Phyllis K. Toohey Is Bride in Jersey
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Oct. 28Miss Phyllis Karen Toohey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Joseph Toohey, was married here this afternoon to Jefferson Earl Hughes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hughes of West Caldwell.

title: Niagara Defeats St. John's On FirstHalf Drive, 3226
description: Niagara University's club football team took advantage of St. John's fumbles, built up a big lead and then herd off the Redmen in the second half to win, 32 to 26, at St. John's Jamaica campus yesterday.

title: Headliners
description: Twas two months before Christmas, and all through Peru last week the creatures of the Ministry of Education were stirring. They had a message for Santa Claus: Get lost. The Peruvian GOVernment has taken a hard line against foreign themes general, and Santa, Christmas frees and reindeer particular. Radio and television advertisers will be sticking to completely Peruvian symbols, such as the national version of the Christ Child, El Nino Manuelito. A Government aide added that Santa and company were fine for, northern climes, but: We don't have reindeer or snowcovered pine trees at Christmas time. We're in the middle of summer.

title: Kathleen Gardiner to Marry in England
description: Miss Kathleen Mona Gardiner, First Secretary of the United Kingdom Mission to the United Nations in Geneva and a former British vice consul here, plans to be married next month to Dr. William Gilbert Fogland, an ophthalmologist, of Massena, N.Y.

title: Dismissals Disputed as College Starts Reorganizing
description: The College for Human Servicesa widely praised, federally financed school in Manhattan that trains slum residents as socialservice, paraprofessionals has entered a period of upheaval that is expected to change its nature dramatically.

title: MIAMI 287 VICTOR OVER ARMY IN RAIN
description: WEST POINT, Oct. 28Miami didn't need a first down, let alone a fifth down, to score enough early points to beat Army in a rainstorm today. Then, after two quick touchdowns in the first quarter, the Hurricanes went on to a 287 victory over the cadets before a crowd that varied from 33,000 at the start to less than 5,000 at the end in Michie Stadium.

title: EssexHudson
description: Marvin Mack and Kevin Jackson specialize in interceptions  and Barringer remains unbeaten because of their larceny.

title: Like a Who's Who of the avantgarde
description: The legend of Black Mountain College has grown in glamour and stature since 1956 when, after 23 hazardous years, it closed its doors and disbanded. Born in controversy and sequestered from the outside world, this lethal little community, as Fielding Dawson called it, jumped its geographical limits to become prominent throughout America for artistic innovation and flamboyant life style. Black Mountain attracted congregation of uncommon talents and it fostered dazzling events, like John Cage's first evening of mixed media theater; it gave its name to a group of poets, though many of them had no connection with the school; and it published the Black Mountain Review whose impact on the literary scene has been almost scriptural.

title: Stanford Victor, 1711
description: STANFORD, Calif., Oct. 28 (AP)Stanford rallied quickly from a 30 halftime deficit and held on to defeat Oregon State, 1711, today in a game highlighted by 20 punts.

title: Elis Fumble Eight Times
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 28Maybe it was the rain. Maybe it was the artificial turf. Or was it the fact that favored Yale was playing its first outoftown football game this season?

title: J. H. Minton 3d Weds Ann S. McAllister
description: FREEVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 28 Miss Ann Sanxay McAllister, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ferdinand Ficker McAllister of Upper NyaCk, was married here this afternoon to John Henry Minton 3d, son of Mr. Minton Jr. of Miami and Mrs. Robert Frederick Olson of Englewood, Fla.

title: New &Novel
description: If you liked the folks you met in Last Exit to Brooklyn, you should love the crowd in Turkey Hash. Subterranean Los Angeles is the scene. Mental defectives, maimed drifters who think with their appetites, geek material, random assassins and their victimsthese float in and out of Craig Nova's harsh spotlight. The center of attention is Niles Cabro, an L.A. youth whom the publisher bills as borderline psychotic. Tut. Anyone whose idea of fun is to be beaten nearly senseless in an offal orgy is hardly borderline.

title: The Tough Road Ahead
description: This Is how Washington and Hanoi envisage the coming of peace to Indochina, as indicated by the agreements outlined by Hanoi radio and Henry Kissinger last week and by official clarification of the peace terms:

title: Preps
description: WALLINGFORD, Conn., Oct. 28  Mount Hermon spoiled Father's Day for Choate when it registered its first victory of the year today, 2612. Choate is still without victory after five games.

title: Tito's Foreign Minister Quits
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct, 28 (AP)  Foreign Minister Mirko Tepavac has resigned, foreign diplomatic sources here reported today. The resignation reportedly was for personal reasons. Foreign diplomats, however, speculated that it might be connected with the purge by President Tito of liberalminded Communist leaders.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: SAN FRANCISO, Oct. 27The River Queen I, a sleek houseboat that once belonged to Erie Stanley Gardner the writer, chugged out into San Francisco Bay to help solve a mystery that even Perry Mason would have found interesting: flow does all that smog plaguing our cities come into being?

title: The Pacific Rivals
description: A high official in the Kennedy Administration, stopping off in Tokyo on his way back to Washington after a visit to Taiwan, asked for a meeting with Kenzo Matsumura, a senior statesman in the ruling conservative party and one of Japan's unofficial links with Chinese leaders in Peking. He hoped to sell his ideas on containing mainland China and to see what he could learn from Matsumura, who was convinced that American policy was wrong.

title: Roberts Rites Wednesday
description: A memorial service for Dr. Henry L. Roberts, who was professor of history at Dartmouth College and had earlier headed the Russian Institute at Columbia University, will be held Wednesday at 2:30 P.M. in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia. Dr. Roberts died Oct. 17 in Randolph, Vt., at the age of 56.

title: The greatest voice in the world
description: By Stanley Jackson. Illustrated. 302 pp. New York: Stein & Day. $7.95.

title: Preps
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 28 Rich Ruttkamp scored two touchdowns on passes thrown by Chris Kristoff in the second half as St. Mary's of Greenwich edged Horace Mann, 1514, today.

title: Music
description: IT is a clich that the theater must reflect life. In a sense, it is therefore as good as lifeour life. Often what it reveals must disturb and question rather than celebrate. I doubt if the theater can exist, or has ever existed, without disturbing. The audience leaves the performance with their preoccupations changed or challenged. The disturbance is profound because it is emotional, not rational. And it can be as strong at farce as at tragedy.

title: TV Mailbag
description: ARECENT episode of Marcus Welby, M.D., dealt with the problem of abortion in California, a state which allows women to have legal abortions under certain circumstances. When Dr. Welby's patient came to him 11 weeks pregnant and, at 19, a minor, he advised her to see a psychiatristeven though the time was running out for her to have the safest and easiest type of abortion.

title: A night environment
description: There are thousands of New Yorkers who don't see their apartments from morning until night. Designer Melvin Dwork, who is one of them, decided to capitalize on this fact when he redecorated his onebedroom apartment. He switched from an allwhite plan, which was really a daytime ambiance, to a night environment that comes alive after the sun goes down. The walls, carpeting and ceiling, which appear inky black in these photographs, are a rich forest green. Even the vertical blinds on the window wall are painted green. This dramatic dark background demanded contrast which he provided with the white sofa and lounge chairs he had used in his previous scheme. Lighting was possibly the most important element in the change. He installed a track system around the perimeter of the room and painted it the same dark green as the ceiling. The effect is of light emanating from a hidden source. Downlights focus on his collection of African art and spots highlight the paintings turning them into glowing islands of color.

title: Stamps
description: ADDITIONAL 1973 stamp catalogues have appeared, a number from overseas, that have been popular compendiums with American stamp collectors. (Scott Vol. I and Minkus World Wide were discussed in this column Oct. 1.)

title: CHARTER REFORM PRESSED UPSTATE
description: ALBANY, Oct. 28  Three upstate counties, Rensselaer, Niagara and Chemung, will vote on Election Day to determine if they will have new charters providing for strong county executives with wide powers to supervise the administration of their governments.

title: Teachers at Meeting Taught by Students
description: GREENVALE, L. I.More than a hundred educators from Nassau and Suffolk Counties pondered last week the future of public schools on Long Island at a symposium monitoredand sometimes directedby their students.

title: Linda Kramer Fiancee of Murray Evans
description: WOODMERE, L. I., Oct. 28  Mr. and Mrs. Horace Z. Kramer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Marie Kramer, to Murray S. Evans of Manhattan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Evans of the Bronx. The couple plan to be married Jan. 7 in Temple Sinai in Lawrence.

title: Kathy Kusner Clinches jumping Title at Washington Show
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 28Kathy Kusner of the United States Equestrian Team scored her second victory in two nights in the Ladies International invitation jumping competition at the Washington International horse show tonight and clinched the championship.

title: Kings Trim Braves, 113102
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 28 (AP)Nate Archibald scored 34 points tonight as the Kansas CityOmaha Kings beat the Buffalo Braves, 113102.

title: Social Announcements
description: Weddings

title: Electrified Spaghetti on Avant Garde Fete Menu
description: All the way from the wheelhouse, which Shirley Clarke, the film maker, had transformed into a fortunetelling booth, to the galley, where Elizabeth Phillips of Bennington College served platters of electrified spaghetti that squeaked and hummed as it was eaten, the old Hudson River Dayliner Alexander Hamilton was transformed into a gallery of anarchic imaginings yesterday.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISThe approach of Indochina peace brings with it inevitable discard of shibboleths that have dominated political thinking on Asia during the past two decades. Two assumptions that now seem wholly outmoded are the socalled domino theory, Washington's bask precept of the nineteensixties, and the socalled Brezhnev Doctrine tentatively presented as a fundament of Moscow's Eastern policy.

title: U.C.L.A. OUTSCORES WASH. ST., 35 TO 20
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28 (UPI) James McAlister scored two touchdowns and Mark Harmon passed for another pair today as the ninthranked U.C.L.A. Bruins defeated Washington State, 35.20, to remain undefeated in the Pacific8 conference and 71 over all.

title: Michael M. Lent And Canta Pian Are Married
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 28  Miss Canta Chaopo Pian was married here Itoday to Michael Max Lent, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Lent of Great Neck, L. I. City Clerk Andrew DiMarco performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Prof. and Mrs. Theodore H. H. Pian.

title: Rockland
description: North Rockland waited until the fourth period, then exploded with two touchdowns and a field goal yesterday to beat Pearl River, 15.0, and win its 23d straight in Public Schools Athletic League play.

title: Preps
description: EAST HAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 25Williston spotted Suffield a 140 firstquarter lead and nen rallied for a 2714 victory, its first of the year. Mark Palombo scored twice on short runs. Suffield dropped to 23.

title: New York
description: New York

title: Brigham Young Victor hi FightFilled Game
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., Oct. 28 (AP)Brigham Young scored three quick touchdowns today and coasted to a 448 Western Athletic Conference victory over Colorado State, which has yet to win a game in eight starts.

title: To be herself
description: Carol Prince, heroine of Rona Jaffe's sixth novel, loses her virginity on her 21st birthday. She had hated her childhood and hungered to be free, and now she was on her way. Her mother told her that boys don't marry girls who are too independent, and because everyone she met at parties talked about their analysis, Carol treated herself to a year of analysis to find out why she had never married. The doctor asked her immediately if she wanted a penis. She told him that all she wanted was to be herself, which meant she wanted to avoid all the selflimiting roles society had picked out for her.

title: Tennessee Routs Hawaii
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 28 (AP)  Conrad Graham intercepted a pass and returned it 25 yards for a touchdown on the first play from scrimmage and 14th  ranked Tennessee went on to rout previously unbeaten Hawaii, 342: today.

title: Social Announcements
description: Anniversaries

title: NASSAU REPORTS WELFARE DECLINE
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 28 The decline in the number of people on welfare in Nassau County that began this year is continuing, County Executive Ralph G. Caso reports.

title: In Support Of Nixonomics
description: For about a year now we have been telling our clients that the United States may be on the verge of one of the most dynamic expansion periods in our postwar history. We say maybe. The position is hedged because we believe that the election of Senator George McGovern would materially damage the longterm growth prospects of the American economy. Given the reelection of President Nixon, we believe that our growth from 1972 to: 1976 will be dynamic, vigorous and different from what has gone before.

title: East Carolina Triumphs
description: GREENVILLE, S. C., Oct. 28 (UPI)Carl Summerell fired a seven yard touchdown pass to Vic Wilfore with 32 seconds remaining to give East Carolina a 2721 victory over Furman today. The triumph left East Carolina undefeated in the southern conference with a 50 wonlost record while the Pirates are 61 over all. Furman, which lost its fourth straight game, has a 14 conference mark and a 2.6 over all record.

title: STUDY UNIT SCORES NIXON ON CONSUMER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UPI) A study group working for Senator George McGovern accused the Nixon Administration today of yielding to industry pressure by ignoring consumer needs for quality and safety in everything from cars to drugs.

title: Two Kinds Of People
description: To the Editor: The man who said the world could be divided into two kinds of peoplei.e., those who do and those who do not think there are two kinds of people was not, as Nora Ephron asserts, Anonymous.

title: W. M. G. A. PLANS A NOV. 9 MEETING
description: The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association will hold its annual meeting at the Pringeton Club Nov. 9. Mrs. Jean Ashley Crawford of Apawamis, captain of the 1972 Curtis Cup team, and Patty Berg, world star, will be speakers.

title: Art
description: HUMOR, Satire and Irony, which opened last week at the New School Art Center at 65 Fifth Avenue, is an oddball exhibition that plays over a vast field in spotty fashion, wisely avoids trying to prove anything about a subject (What is humor?) that has already seduced philosophers and critics into some of their most blushmaking analyses, and ends up as a pleasant experience with disturbing undercurrents.

title: A Mouthful From Martha
description: BALTIMORE LADIES and Gents! blares the loudspeaker in the suburban appliance store on a recent Saturday. Making her way to the front of Luskin's is the star of stage, screen and TV, soon to be seen on Broadway in No, No, Nanette, and now appearing locally in Minsky's Burlesque  MISS MARTHA RAYE!

title: Music: L. I. Youths React to Old Sound
description: GREAT NECK, L. I.  It Might have been one of those college movies that Hollywood ground out in the nineteen thirties with Jack Oakie and Toby Wing and the rest of the perpetual undergraduatesboys constantly playing musical instruments, everybpdy singing and girls dancing tirelessly in their sweaters, pleated skirts, bobby socks and saddle shoes.

title: 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 28John S. Knight, editorial chairman of Knight Newspapers, announced in his weekly column today that he would not vote for President this year.

title: SHOP TALK
description: WEST ORANGEA dozen or so new clothing and antiques shops have brought a fresh life to the Valley section of this city, and many other shop owners in the area feel that it may one day be transformed into a Greenwich Village.

title: Miss Deborah Beinecke Affianced
description: Miss Deborah Beinecke and William Archibald Kinsella 3d, son of Mrs. Kinsella Jr. of Southport, Conn., and the late Mr. Kinsella, will be married here Feb. 17 in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: Mrs. J. Robert Oppenheimer, 62, Nuclear Physicist's Widow, Dies
description: ANCON, C. Z., Oct. 28 (Reuters) Mrs. Katherine Puening Oppenheimer, widow of the nuclear physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer, died in Gorgas Hospital here last night. She was 62 years old and lived in Princeton, N. J.

title: Fish are jumpin and the cotton is high
description: Shooting, as he often does, from the Hip, Norman Mailer once called Calder Willingham a clown with the bite of a ferret, but faulted him for lacking ideas and being too indulgent to his shortcomings. Mailer is seldom wrong about other writers (meaning: his perceptions jibe with mine, or else mine eventually grow up to his). Here is Willingham's eighth novel, and the clowning is, still as waggishly pervasive as in Geraldine Bradshaw or Providence Island. Fish are jumpin and the cotton is high. Ideamongering is not even attempted. Shortcomings  prolixity, playful digressions, overinsistence on minor points, attentionnumbing redundancy, cutenessare admittedly indulged. But where is the ferretbite?

title: Shriver Assails Nixon on Social Justice
description: YONKERS, Oct. 28Sargent Shriver charged here today that if President Nixon was reelected, his aim over the next four years would be to wreck the socialjustice advances made under the Democrats.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 28 (UPI)The Baltimore News American endorsed President Nixon for reelection in Sunday's editions.

title: Carl Sandbarg Estate Named Historic Site
description: HENDERSONVILLE, N. C., Oct. 28The woodland estate of the poet Carl Sandburg, Connemara in suburban Flat Rock, was formally pronounced a national historic site at a National Park Service ceremony there yesterday. But it still is not open to the public.

title: Twelfth District
description: People today are primarily concerned with their quality of life.

title: Social Announcements
description: Births

title: Integrity in Washington
description: Once asked what he regarded as the most important virtue, Winston Churchill replied, Couragebecause is the guarantor of all other virtues.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Three months ago most textile fibers throughout the world were a glut on the market. They were plentiful and low in price.

title: CeaseFire Pitfalls
description: WASHINGTONOutlining the prospective peace settlement to reporters last Thursday, Henry Kissinger alluded to the danger of extensive bloodletting if both sides make a lastditch effort to expand the areas under their control as the ceasefire goes into effect. Actually, many Washington analysts predict that a standstill ceasefire will produce not an end to hostilities but a change in the character of the war. The shift they foresee is from setpiece battles between major units of the North and. South Vietnamese armies to a shadow war between small units of guerrillas and counterguerrillas, terrorists and police, assassination teams and psychologicalwarfare squads on both sides, all vying for control of the countryside.

title: EUROPEAN COUNCIL HAS LITTLE IMPACT
description: STRASBOURG, France, Oct. 28Armand Jehle, a 21yearold biology student at Strasbourg University, says that the only thing he knows about the European Parliament and the Council of Europe is that there seem to be a lot of policemen around their joint assembly building when the meetings are on.

title: One of 12 Who Escaped From Albany Jail Is Seized
description: The Albany police captured without resistance last night one of 12 prisoners who had escaped Friday night from the Albany County Jail at Colonie, N. Y., six miles from Albany.

title: New York
description: Classroom holdups. Attacks on school buses. The fear of violence spread through New York City's schools last week.

title: Television
description: ACOUPLE of weeks ago a network executive, when asked to comment on television's new permissiveness, agreed that certain subjects have been taboo on the tube, but added that many of these taboos have been of our own making, we the broadcasters. Pressured by younger audiences in search of more adult fare, the networks are beginning to broaden their subject matter. If we do it right, the executive said, 'if we don't put neon quotation marks around it, it will be acceptable.

title: On Many Issues, Tilden Residents Fight System That Ignores Us
description: The eight 16story buildings of brown and beige brick that make up the Tilden Houses in Brooklyn's Brownsville community sit on a 10acre site, undistinguished from each other except for their address numhers.

title: G.O.P. Smiling Over Nixon Gains in Brooklyn and Queens
description: Nine days before Election Day, President Nixon is apparently running so strongly in Brooklyn and Queens that he has a good chance of capturing one or both counties.

title: It's a Lovely Way to Do a Show
description: THE kingdom of musical comedy has left the back gate open and the wandering minstrels are all streaming through again. Thus, Pippin, the new eighthcentury musical at the Imperial, awash in jesters caps, Pulcinella noses, illuminated manuscripts, and a lot of the old soft shoe. The Chansons de Roland have been reorchestrated to Swanee rhythms, twoaday pitterpat, electricorgan doodleswith a sizable indebtedness to Joan Littlewcod's Oh, What a Lovely War!and when the Visigoths are slain in blood red as sunset, warmer than wine there is a fine black court fool to daggerdance the mayhem in spats and silk shirt, his walkingstick carving the air with Ted Lewis lese majestd. It's a lovely way to do a show, whatever one may ultimately wish to say about the material.

title: Laird Visits Spain
description: SOTOGRANDE, Spain, Oct. 28 (AP)Melvin R. Laird, United States Secretary of Defense, arrived here today for a weekend of golf on Spain's Costa del Sol near Gibraltar. Mr. Laird flew into the United States Navy base at Rota on Cadiz Bay after meetings in London with the sevenmember Nuclear Planning group of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Stamps
description: BRITAIN'S silver wedding stamps commemorating the marriage of Princess Elizabeth (now Queen Elizabeth II) and Prince Phillip of Greece (Duke of Edinburgh), which are due Nov. 20, will have an added attraction, according to George Downs, British postal director, a recent visitor to New York, and currently on a tour of American stamp centers.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN TRIBE REJECTS U.N.'S HELP
description: RUNDU, SouthWest Africa, Oct. 28 (Agence FrancePresse) Leaders of the SouthWest African Kavango tribe have asked the United Nations not to interfere with their internal problems.

title: OHIO STATE TOPS WISCONSIN, 2820
description: MADISON, Wis., Oct. 28 (AP)  Greg Hare, a quarterback, amassed 238 yards in total offense and Harold Henson, a sophomore fullback, ran for 122 yards and two touchdowns today to power fourthranked Ohio State to a 2820 Big Ten football victory over Wisconsin.

title: L. I. YOUTH, BURNED, FOUND DEAD ON ROOF
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Oct. 28  A 16yearold with burns over the lower half of his body was found dead last night on the roof of his family's home here, the Nassau County police reported today.

title: Article 16  No Title
description: ESSEN, West Germany, Oct. 28 (Reuters)  Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia produced his best tennis to beat Cliff Richey of Sarasota, Fla.; in the semifitials of a World Championship Tennis tour event tonight. The scores were 46,63,64.

title: The World
description: BELGRADEAfter two decades of an experiment in that freewheeling form of Marxism that has become known as Titoism, Yugoslavia today is in a fever of reappraisal centering on the question: What is the role of the Communist party in a selfmanaging, decentralized, semimarket economy?

title: L.I. Woman Is Named Teacher Of the Year
description: WOODMERE, L. I. School is to prepare you for life and life is many, many things besides reading and writing, and these things must also be taught in the classroom, said Thelma G. Patel, a fourthgrade teacher at Woodmere Elementary School who was selected by the New York State Department or Education as its Teacher of the Year.

title: Giants Seek Fifth Victory in Row Today
description: The longest winning streak in the National Football Conference will run into the best record in that conference today when the New York Giants try to tie the Washington Redskins for first place in the Eastern Division in a 1 P.M. game at Yankee Stadium.

title: Governorship Race
description: WELCH, W. Va., Oct. 27The tall young man pranced from one side of the platform to the other, shouting into the hand microphone that he clutched in the manner of a pop singer. Handsome, nattily dressed in a windowpane check sports coat, he looked out of place in the drab courthouse of this remote mining town.

title: Asia's Population Seen At 3.8 Billion by 2000
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct., 28 (Reuters).By the year 2000 Asia's population will increase to more than the 1970 total world population, a study released here yesterday predicted.

title: Paula Margaret Metcalf Wed To Richard Johnston in Jersey
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., Oct. 28 Miss Paula Margaret Metcalf, a trainee in the investment division of the United States Trust Company of New York, was married here this afternoon to Richard Johnston, a portfolio manager in the investment advisory department of F. Eberstadt & Co. in New York.

title: Fund to Save Tiger Started
description: GENEVA, Oct. 28The World Wildlife Fund has begun a campaign to raise $1million to have the tiger from extinction. The private conservation agency, with headquarters in the small Swiss town of Morges on Lake Geneva, reported that only about 5,000 tigers remain in the world today.

title: Railroad Museum Opening
description: GLEN RIDGEThe Erie Lackawanna Railway Museum, which recalls the days when the railroad was king, opens its doors to the public here today.

title: Anne Poekel Bride of Richard McCauley
description: ESSEX FELLS, N. J., Oct. 28Miss Anne Lester Poekel and Richard Lee McCauley were married here this morning in St. Peter's Episcopal Church by the Rev. David St. George.

title: The Atomic Establishment
description: Awesome and terrifying though it was, the nuclear coup de main that ended World War II heralded a hopeful new age. The specter of atomic war would keep world peace, while civilian scientists converted mankind's newest sword into its most miraculous plowshare. Hardly anything seemed beyond the atom's capability: cheap electricity, nuclear ships and planes, mining and tunneling, food preservation, even nuclearheated long johns for deepsea divers. To manage this Promethean wonder, Congress created the Atomic Energy Commission, endowing it with broad powers and responsibilities. The A.E.C. was at once an arm of the Pentagon, big brother to the budding nuclear industry, and defender of the public interest in all matters nuclear.

title: Watchung's Quiet Is About at an End
description: SUMMITThere's a lush solitude at the base of the ravine where the small Blue Brook flows through the center of the Watchung Reservation, the largest park in the Union County park system. Looking up from the creek through the heavy woods, it is almost impossible to visualize the county's population of more than a halfmillion crushed up against the park border.

title: The Top 70 Intellectuals
description: You could cut the gloom with an alpenstock last week down at The Lukewarm Cavity, a watering spa a little to the left of Esquire's Red Hot Center and a little to the right of Ted Solotaroff's Red Hot Vacuum. The intellectual ratings had come out, and quite a few Lukewarmers were afraid that their credibility was about to get cancelled. They hadn't made the Top 70.

title: Editorial Cartoon 4  No Title
description: Editorial Cartoon 4  No Title

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: ALBANY, Oct. 28  Test borings have begun for a new bridge alongside the NewburghBeacon Bridge, which carries Interstate Route 84 across the Hudson River. The cost is estimated at $55million, with the Federal Government paying $50million.

title: Auburn Steals Four Huff Passes, Defeats Florida State
description: AUBURN, Ala., Oct. 28 (AP)  Terry Henley scored three touchdowns. Randy Walls put on an exhibition of his passing skill, and Auburn's defense intercepted four of Gary Huff's passes today as the 12thranked Tigers walloped Florida State, 2714.

title: Iowa State Triumphs
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 28 (AP)George Amundson and Mike Strachan gained 452 yards between them as Iowa State routed Kansas, 348, in a Big Eight football game today.

title: State Control of Power Sites Sought
description: TRENTON Legislation is being drafted that would mandate a decisive new role by the state in the preservation, planning and selection of electrical generating power plants in New Jersey.

title: Prepaid Health Groups Are Held Up by Tardy Legislation
description: TRENTONEfforts to establish Health Maintenance Organizations in seven New Jersey counties have been serimsly retarded by lack of legislation on both the Federal and state levels.

title: Nazareth Well Is Fouled; Holy Site for Christians
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 28 (UPI)A well in Nazareth that Christians consider one of the holiest sites of the Holy Land is being polluted.

title: The World
description: BUENOS AIRESPolitical commentators here invariably fall back on the same simile to describe the transactions between President Alejandro Agustin Lanusse and the exiled dictator, Juan Domingo Peron. The complex battle between the two for supremacy, the pundits say, is like a chess game.

title: Issues Viewed By Candidates
description: NEWARKMany politicians say the shifting boundaries caused by the recent reapportionment of Congressional district are as important as the issues in seven of the races in northern New Jersey.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: We're asking our people this question: What moves you more: your prejudices or your pocketbook?' said a labor leader active in the McGovernforPresident campaign. And we're telling them: If you maintain your prejudices, it will cost you money.;

title: Jolly Petite Triumphs
description: BOSTON, Oct. 27 (AP)Jolly Petite, the 1310 favorite in a field of six, took a sevenlength lead at the top of the stretch and breezed to victory today in a $7,500 handicap at SSuffolk Downs. The winner paid $4.60.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Geoffrey Wolff, in his appraisal of Paul West's Bela Lugosi's White Christmas (the concluding novel in the Alley Jaggers trilogy), complains of West's determination to make his work inaccessible. After fainting with damned praise, Wolff pays homage to West by awarding the author those inabilities he himself has demonstrated through his review: Wolff does not understand West's book. He blames West, as if West had decided not to let Geoffrey Wolff comprehend his novel.

title: Edward Gorey, a retrospective
description: I planned to begin this review by saying that Edward Gorey, like Donald Barthelme, is a master of the problematic. Then I looked problematic up in two dictionaries which agreed that, in logic, the term applies to a proposition that is possibly, but not necessarily, true  as, for example, the existence of unicorns. This is clearly not a description of the work of Edward Gorey. What his fey and elegant books of humor communicate to his readers is entirely, absolutely true. Problematic is only the method which produces such astonishing wrinkles and quirks in deep grammar. Or do I mean metasyntax?

title: Trinity Downs Rochester
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 28 (AP)Trinity College rallied behind the running of Dave Kuncio and tim Balesano today to defeat Rodiester, 286.

title: Preps
description: BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 281 Rich Smith returned the opening kickoff 85 yards for a touchdown today and Blair went on to rout The Hill, 267. Smith, a cornerback, also intercepted a pass by Dave Del Bello, The Hill's quarterback, one of three interceptions by Blair.

title: Miss Gleason Fiancee Of Harcld Cuddy 3d
description: WINTER GARDEN, Fla., Oct. 28Miss Mary Frances Gleason and Harold J. Cuddy 3d, both on the faculty of the Pasco Junior High School in Dade City, will be married Dec. 16.

title: The World
description: The World

title: An American who once picked the targets tells
description: Jerome J. Brown could easily be mistaken for typical American businessman living abroad. He's 30 years old, slightly beefy, profane and constantly wears oversized sunglasses. He's now a partner in a management consulting firm headquartered in Malaysia, where he lives with his Indonesian wife and their young son.

title: Foe Occupies 13 Hamlets, Cuts 3 Roads Near Saigop
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Oct. 29Communist troops occupied 13 hamlets and cut three major highways within 40 miles of Saigon yesterday in an apparent lastminute effort to seize territory before an expected ceasefire, allied military officers reported.

title: TURCOTTE RIDES 8LENGTH WINNER
description: LAUREL, Md., Oct. 28Secretariat and La Prevoyante went trickortreating today at Laurel race course, and both 2yearolds wound up with the expected goodies.

title: Katherine E. Putnam Is Fiancee Of Preston Witherspoon Farr
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 28Miss Katherine Elizabeth Putnam, a descendant of Charles Carroll, a signer of the Declaration of Independence, and Preston Witherspoon Farr, whose ancestor, John Witherspoon, was also a signer of the document and president of the College of New. Jersey at Princeton, plan to be married in June.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  One of the guiding principles of American politics is that it takes months, perhaps a year, for an issue to be effective. The theory is that voters dismiss charges made in the heat of the campaign as lastminute mudslinging.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 28  A British soldier was shot to death in Londonderry today and a 10yearold boy nearby was wounded by the same sniper.

title: University of Pennsylvania Honors 4 at New Building
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 1 The University of Pennsylvania granted four honorary degrees today as it marked the 50th anniversary of the Wharton School's graduate division and the dedication of Vance Hall, the new headquarters for the division.

title: Campaign
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Walt Disney built an empire out of fantasy and in it, at a campaign rally in the Disneyland Hotel here yesterday, Senator George McGovern declared that he would win the Presidency on Nov. 7.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: I read with interest Barnard Law Collier's Chileans Follow the Dollar, Ignoring the Flag (Travel section, Oct. 15). I was in Chile as a tourist the year before the 1970 election of Salvador Allende Gossens. Even then the bellboy at the hotel where I stayed grunted confidentially, You got any dollars? give you best price. During a brief conversation with some passengers on my arrival at the Chilean airport, learned that the street escudodollar exchange was higher than the official rate in banks and hotels and that some Chileans were eager to buy and hoard American dollars. At that time no receipt of sale was required to prove that one bought his escudos at the official price. After being in Santiago few days I heard that there was some kind of law against trading dollars and escudos other than at authorized locations. It would have taken a strong man to resist those constant temptations, Hey, sefior, you got any dollars? I give you best price.

title: SENATORS ARE RATED BY CONSUMER GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UPI) The Consumer Federation of America gave 100 per cent ratings this week to 18 Senators for voting right on 11 key issues. It said Senator George McGovern acted correctly on the five issues on which he voted.

title: The Money Maker
description: This is the success story of Jason Steele, a Yankee fisherman's son who rises from modest circumstances to heights at which he loses $138million in eight weeks. Jason starts poor, marries rich, works hard and makes the most of his opportunities. Mr. MacNamara, an expert in the oil business, and the investment business (and the sport of yacht racing) sets forth in crisp detail the maneuvers through which his hero parlays an oil distribution company into a corporate monster. Steele's crowning acquisition is to be World Equities, Ltd., an international money management behemoth in the Bernie Cornfeld mode. Here the entrepreneur finally meets a pair of sharks who are even sharper than he.

title: U.S. Reports Wage Rises Averaged 6.6% in 9 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP)  Nearly 1.5 million workers received wage increases averaging 6,6 per cent a year under major collective bargaining contracts negotiated in the first nine months of the year and approved by Federal wage controllers, the Government has announced Thursday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Plans to modernize traffic lights at 975 intersections in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens were announced by the city yesterday, subject to approval of $13.2million Federal and state funds.

title: HOLDUP MAN SLAYS MAN AT CARD GAME
description: A 27yearold man was shot to death yesterday afternoon when he sought to object to holdup at a card game in a Bronx apartment.

title: DOCTORS PROTEST IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: The Pennsylvania Medical Society called last night for the ouster of the state's insurance commissioner, Herbert S. Denenberg, because of what it called his irresponsible activities.

title: Football In Stands Surpasses Field Play
description: When you have two sons who are rock fans and a 10yearold daughter who is a sports nut, the least you can do is take her to a football game. It sure beats going to a rock concert, even if you were invited.

title: Suffolk
description: East Islip, the county's only untied and unscoredupon team, turned back Commack North, 220, yesterday for its sixth triumph of the campaign. Brentwood defeated previously unbeaten West Islip, 147, to extend its undefeated string to 23 games over a threeseason span.

title: House Contest
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 28 Whatever happens in the 24th Congressional District on Nov. 7, the impact is certain to be felt far beyond the borders of the 15 Westchester County cities and town's that the district includes.

title: Ninth District
description: The single most important issue facing the voters of the Ninth Congressional District is the ability of the Federal Government to come to grips with the pressing economic and social problems affecting them as American citizens.

title: Autumn Canoeing, Amid Wild Beauty
description: JACKSON TOWNSHIPThe sun was almost warm enough to make people shed woolen jackets, yet scarlet oak and golden birch leaves fell to the water each time the wind whispered.
