This was the setting as six canoes from the Murray Hill Canoe Club and the American Canoe Association started out on a weekend cruise on the Toms River.

title: Clinics for Sex Therapy Proliferate Over Nation
description: For many people, including at least half the married couples in the country, sex is not the most natural thing in the world.

title: Religion
description: Selling belief in God is an ad man's dream. You start off with a good image and wide recognition. There is no Number 2. And, as Charles Harrison, head of LiebermanHarrison, Inc., observed last week, You don't have the problem of product breakdown.

title: 37 Accused of Voting Fraud In Illinois Primary Election
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (AP)Thirtyseven more persons have been indicted on charges of voting fraud in the Illinois primary election.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTON  Pregnancy, the United States Solicitor General reminded the Supreme Court the other day, is a physical condition which happens to be peculiar to women.

title: FRANCIS A. RAFFAELE
description: Francis A. Raffaele, a proofreader for the last five years for The New York Times and earlier for more than 30 years with The New York Herald Tribune, died Friday in University Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 2 Fairfield Place, Yonkers.

title: Hyndman Tops Person To Take Title in Golf
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 28 (UPI)William Hyndman 3d of Huntingdon, Pa., scored a 3and2 victory today over threetime champion, Curtis Person of Memphis, to win the North and South senior men's golf title.

title: WALL STREEt
description: Wall Street's enchantment with pollutioncontrol stocks started several years ago, and the courtship has had its share of ups and downs on the charts.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Oct. 16 OpEd article by Molly Ivins about the schizophrenic nature of the Texas Democratic party in this Presidential election year was both humorous and incisive.

title: UnionMiddlesex
description: Willie Wilson is only a junior, but the Summit back is proving one of the most versatile backs in New Jersey.

title: Colleges in Nassau To Share Facilities
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I,Faced with fiscal problems because of competition from public institutions of learning, six Nassau County colleges and universities have created the Nassau Higher Educcation Consortium.

title: Mrs, ngulo Has Son
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Oct. 28 A son was born on Monday to Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Angulo in the Washidgton Hospital Center in Georgetown. The child has been named John Ralph. His mother is the former Miss Harriet Whitman, daughter of Alden Whitman. Mr. Angulo is a lawyer with the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Dance
description: ONE specially interesting aspect of the City Center Dance Marathonwhich is still happily at the ANTA Theateris the presence of a number of companies that are not based in New York. We are growing accustomed to excellent classic ballet companies all across the country. Only last weekend, for example, I saw the National Ballet of Washington open its Kennedy Center season in particularly exuberant form. Yet today professional modern  dance companies are developing outside of New York. Already this season New York has been visited by the Utah Repertory Dance Company, and now in the Dance Marathon we have had the Bella Lewitzky Dance Company and the Inner City Repertory Dance Company, both from the Coast.

title: 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) Richard M. Nixon and George McGovern may agree that they offer the clearest choice of this century, but there are nine other Presidential candidates who insist that the choice is wider.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Twice a year, in May and October, the principal economic officers of the United States Government and 100 or more chiefs of the country's biggest corporations and banks converge on a Hot Springs, Va., resort, the Homestead.

title: GROSHAWK RALLIES, WINS COAST STAKES
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Oct. 28 (AP)Groshawk, a 25 choice ridden by Bill Shoemaker, rallied from last place in the field of five 2yearolds and won a stretch battle with Autry to capture the $98,375 Norfolk Stakes today at Santa Anita's Oak Tree meeting.

title: State School Chief Rules Today On Appeal in Canarsie Dispute
description: State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist plans to rule today on the Canarsie local school hoard's appeal of a Board of Education order last week admitting 32 black and, Puerto Rican Brownsville youths to John Wilson Junior High School 211.

title: Moscow Plans to Assist In Rebuilding Program
description: PARIS, Oct. 28The Soviet Ambassador to France, Pyotr A. Abrasimov, a member of the Soviet Communist Party's Central Committee, spent an hour with the French Foreign Minister, Maurice Schumann, today discussing the Vietnam situation.

title: Canadiens and Sabres Continue Unbeaten by Battling to a 33 Stalemate
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 28 (UPI)The Dryden brothers, Ken and Dave, battled each other to a standoff in the nets tonight as the Montreal Canadiens and the Buffalo Sabresthe only unbeaten teams in the National Hockey League this seasonbattled to a 33 deadlock.

title: Preps
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 28, Doug Buonanno, a twoway guard, tackled Mike Leonard, who was punting for St. George's, in the end zone for safety that gave Moses Brown a 1514 lead and set it on the way to a 2814 victory today. Buonanno's key play came early in the fourth period.

title: Iowa, Michigan State Tie
description: IOWA CITY, Iowa, Oct. 28 (UPI)Harry Kokolus kicked two field goals today to salvage a 6.6 tie for Iowa with Michigan State. Both teams suffered from fumbles and interceptions and failed to capitalize on scoring opportunities after the Spartans jumped out to a 6.0 lead in the first quarter.

title: Long Prison Terms Called SelfDefeating in a Report
description: BOSTON, Oct. 28 (AP)  A study by the RoscoePound Trial Lawyers Association says that long prison terms should be outlawed because they are selfdefeating.

title: Haiphong Devastated by Bombing but Still Bustling
description: TORONTO, Oct. 28If any explanation is needed as to why the Vietnam war is drawing to a close, the devastated but still dynamic port city of Haiphong provides it.

title: BergenPassaic
description: Clifton continued to cut a swath through the Northern New Jersey Interscholastic League yesterday with 280 victory over Bergenfield in Clifton.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Obituary 2  No Title

title: BUCKS HOD 76ERS 8TH LOSS IN A ROW
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 (AP) Kareem AbdulJabbar's gamehigh 23 points carried the Milwaukee Bucks to their sixth straight National Basketball Association victory tonight and handed the victoryless Philadelphia 76ers their eighth loss in a row, 9692.

title: WEATHER HARMS STOCKING OF TROUT
description: CHARLEVOIX, Mich., Oct. 28  Michigan fish trappers are battling time and gale weather in a strenuous effort to save a program that since 1960 has been seeking to restore lake trout to the Great Lakes by means of stocking.

title: An Unwed Mother With a Son 4, Opts to Stay Single and Raise Him Alone
description: Mary Hanes has deepset eyes and a kind of melancholy expression that isn't erased even when she smiles. She has a little boy, James. But she doesn't have a husband, never has had, and says she doesn't want one.

title: MRS. JACQUES FISCHL
description: Mrs. Theodora Boettger Fisch director of volunteers at the SloanKettering Cancer Care Center, died Friday at her home, 200 East 74th Street. She was 58 years old.

title: Experts Offer Ideas on Drugs at Seminar.
description: MAHWAHPerched casually on a desktop at Ramapo College, Dr. Leo Gold, a psychologist, could have been conducting a group therapy session with the 25 students crowded into the small classroom.

title: The Nation
description: LOWELL, Mass.  The Democratic party, which has been running against Herbert Hoover and the specter of jobless apple venders for 40 years, cannot seem to frighten voters with the unemployment issue in 1972.

title: MRS. MINNA CASSARD
description: Mrs. Minna Dessez Cassard, an author of devotional books, lecturer on religious subjects and former librarian at the Episcopal Library of St. Bede, died Friday at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 66 years old and lived at 1700 York Avenue.

title: MICHIGAN ROUTS MINNESOTA, 420
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 28 (AP)  A junior fullback, Ed Shuttlesworth, bulled his way for four touchdowns today as he led fifthranked Michigan to a 420 rout over Minnesota in the battle for the Little Brown Jug.

title: DUKE'S DEFENSE HALTS NAVY, 1716
description: NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 28 (AP) Al Glenny of Navy threw his second touchdown pass to Jack Forde in the last minute of play, but defense crushed a 2point conversion try as the Blue Devils edged the Middies, 1716, today in the Oyster Bowl game.

title: Shira Nadich Plans Bridal
description: Rabbi Judah Nadich of the Park Avenue Synagogue and Mrs. Nadich have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Shim. Adina Nadich, to James Loren Levin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Levin of Poughkeepsie. N.Y. The wedding is planned for June at the synagogue here.

title: Staaten Eylandt Gets Tulips
description: RICHMONDTOWN, S.I. Hans Van Zelst is transplanting a bit of the old country to the land his ancestors called Staaten Eylandt.

title: Fifteenth District
description: High unemployment is the most serious problem facing the people of the 15th District. Official figures show that since January, 1969, when the Nixon Administration took office, unemployment in the Perth AmboyNew Brunswick Labor Area has increased by a shocking 77 per dent! Converted in human terms, this means that more than 10,000 persons in this Area alone have lost their jobs since President Nixon was inaugurated, bringing the total unemployed to an almost incredible 23,400 (seasonally adjusted as of September, 1972).

title: REARGUMENT APPEAL LOST BY FERDINANDO
description: Joseph Perdinando has lost his appeal to have his forthcoming trial on 35 counts of grand larceny removed from prosecution by Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell to prosecution by. Maurice H. Nadlad, the new special deputy attorney general.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: BIBLICAL ANIMALS FLOWN TO ISRAEL
description: Species of oncecommon wild and domestic animals found in the Middle East in Biblical times are being renewed with the help of a group of prominent Americans headed by Edwin L. Weisl Jr., former Assistant United States Attorney General for Parks and Natural Resources.

title: POTATOES LINKED TO BIRTH DEFECTS
description: LONDON, Oct. 28The possibility that blighted potatoes may cause, defects in newborn children is being studied by Britain's Department of Health and Social Security.

title: Agnew is the common man made exceptional
description: WASHINGTON: I knew I had come to the right place when I saw a Secret Service agent searching an expensive bag of golf clubs. There was a holiday atmosphere on the tarmac. Tennis rackets were also in evidence. Welldressed men were rushing about handling baggage and being helpfully bossy. Mr. Joe Alsop arrived and was treated with great deference. I imagined Calais in the old days when the English set out on the grand tour. We studied the schedule over coffee and doughnuts set out on a white cloth on a trestle table. It looked more like a vacation than an election sweep. Two hours in Detroit and then wheels up for Frank Sinatra's place in Palm Springs, Calif. This was Saturday morning and nothing would again interfere with pleasure until Monday night when the candidate would address an Orange County rally. Welcome, said a traveling reporter, to the Spiro T. Agnew Country Club Campaign.

title: The World
description: Life in Dahomey is hard. The average per capita income is $60. Life expectancy for the Kentuckysized West African nation's 2.5 million people is just 37 years. But Dahomey apparently has one thing in abundance: governmental coups.

title: Preps
description: Locust Valley Friends won the Metropolitan Athletic Association of Private Schools title yesterday by defeating Fieldston, 12.0, at Fieidston. Vinnie Mazzeo led Locust Valley with his running and passing. The quarterback connected on five passes in six attempts, with one touchdown, and carried 13 times for 69 yards and a 47yard score. Gene Knoll shared rushing honors with 104 yards.

title: Mothers on L. I. Say Boo to Halloween
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I.  Aroused over what they feel is a growing incidence of holiday violence and vandalism, a group of mothers here are using a decidedly inhospitable emblem  a frowning pumpkinin their campaign to keep village youngsters off the streets this Hdlloween night.

title: Article 17  No Title
description: MANILA, Oct. 28 (Reuters)Marcelo Lara of Mexico downed Mike Estep of Dallas, 26, 76, 61, and Dick Dell of Bethesda, Md., defeated Australia's Syd Ball, 67, 6.3, 64, in the semifinals of the Philippines international tennis touarnment today.

title: Record Growth in Population Is Forecast for Ocean County
description: Ocean County, the fastestgrowing county in New Jersey, expects to set a new record in population expansion during the seventies.

title: Medical Professionals Back State Union in Pennsylvania
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 28 (AP)  Doctors, dentists and other medical professionals employed by the state have voted to join a union.

title: Jane A. Beaton Plans Wedding
description: DETROIT, Oct. 28  Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Beaton have announced the engageanent of their daughter, Miss Jane Ann Beaton, to Thomas Costain Steinmetz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry D, Steinmetz of Morristown, N.J., and Naples, Fla.

title: Cambodia Raids Reported
description: TAKHMAU, Cambodia, Oct. 28 (Reuters)Cambodian guerrilla forces today raided an area just south of this town outside Pnompenh, Government officers said.

title: Driving Arrests on Increase in Nassau
description: MINEOLA, L. I.The Nassau County Police Commissioner, Louis J. Frank, reported this week that county police have arrested 2,633 persons charged with driving under the influence of alcohol in the first nine months of 1972. an increase of 60 per cent over the corresponding period in 1971.

title: Dentists Oppose Health Aid For Those Who Can Pay
description: LAS VEGAS, Oct. 28 (UPI)  The dental profession will continue to oppose the use of public money to provide health care for those who can afford to pay, according to the presidentelect of the American Dental Association.

title: DOLE LINKS O'BRIEN TO FIGURE IN INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UPI) Senator Robert J. Dole, the Republican national chairman, charged today that Lawrence F. O'Brien, Senator George McGovern's campaign chairman, met secretly with the president of a company allegedly linked to organized crime shortly before a Congressional hearing on the company was halted.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Japan has once again managed to outmaneuver both the Governments of Nationalist China and Communist China and attain considerable political and economic advantages at minimal cost. By the astute pawning of one China for the other Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan has accomplished the feat of making the Chinese people pay a second time for Japanese war crimes.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28for the next few days or weeks, President Nixon is obviously going to have trouble getting the South Vietnamese and the North Vietnamese to agree to his terms for a ceasefire. For the now, lie seems to be caught in the middle, but actually lie holds most of the trump cards to get through the election and arrange a truce. The outlook for an enduring peace, however, is not so good.

title: REFORMS OFFERED BY MARTUSCELLO
description: State Supreme Court Justice M. Henry Martuscello, who is running n the Liberal line for the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, is campaigning on a prisonreform program.

title: Article 18  No Title
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 28 (UPI)Roosevelt Leaks ran 39 and 27 yards for touchdowns to lead 11thranked Texas to a 459 victory over errorprone Rice tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article Strains at Westbeth Threaten a Noble Vision [Sept. 24] gave the mistaken impression that no prospective commercial tenant at Westbeth had been turned away.

title: UNBEATEN UMASS ROUTS CONNECTICUT
description: AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 28 (AP)Piel Pennington took undefeated Massachusetts on another easy victory swing today as he passed for four touchdowns and scored once in a 4916 Yankee Conference romp over Connecticut.

title: AIR FORCE CONTINUES SEARCH FOR BOGGS
description: ANCHORAGE, Oct. 28 (AP) Air Force officials put another maximum search effort into the air today in the nearly twoweek search for Hale Boggs, the House Democratic Leader, Representative Nick Begich of Alaska and two other men.

title: 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28The Under Secretary of Labor, Laurence H. Silberman, issued today a second rebuttal to charges by Senator George McGovern that the Nixon Administration planned to reduce minimumwage enforcement and make other policy changes unwelcome to labor.

title: Preps
description: SHEFFIELD, Mass., Oct. 28Berkshire used a strong running game to take its first vietory today, 40.7, over Canterbury. John Romboli ran for three scores, including a 45yarde.r. Berkshire is 14 and Canterbury is 121.

title: RELIGION LIBRARY DEDICATED ON L.I.
description: STONY BROOK, L. I,A $2million research institute and library specializing in the religions of the East has been dedicated on the Stony Brook campus of the State University of New York.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: TRANSPORTATION

title: Dreams of a way out in a closed world
description: We have been here, almost, before, though then it was a room, a box, a circle. Now it is a flattened cylinder 50 meters around and 18 high, or would be if this system were not a hypothetical notion in some sense equal to the enclosing prose in which this myth in the form of a defining explanation is framed. The writer is Samuel Beckett, that grim gray Nobel eminence, and the story (as he classes it) is called The Lost Ones.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: When William Rehnquist was nominated for the Supreme Court many felt that he had demonstrated a narrow partisanship at odds with willingness to make conclusive judgment only after the parties have had their opportunity to argue the merits. We consoled ourselves that at least he was smarter than Carswell and perhaps amenable to argumentation.

title: The Nation
description: GREENWICH, Conn.;,It you had to choose a perfect setup for a polio outbreak, it would be a place like this, noted a public health official during a mass immunization program at the Daycroft School last week.

title: U.S. JUDICIAL GROUP URGES MORE JUDGES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) The Judicial Conference of the United States has announced that it has voted to recommend the creation of 62 more federal judgeships.

title: Turning City Squares Back to PedestriansBrussels Mini Victory
description: BRUSSELSTo park or not to park in Grand'Place? The question has disturbed and divided the inhabitants of the Belgian capital for more than a year, and the question has still not been resolved. In an experiment this summer, privatecar parking was prohibited. Now owners of private automobiles are again being allowed to park in Grand'Place, but the city's councilmen have said they will restore the parking ban in April, and they may even make It permanent.

title: Edith Schneider Plans Marriage To J. L. Rogues
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 23  Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Schneider have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Emily Schneider, to Jean Louis Rogues, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rogues of Toulouse, France. A December wedding is planned.

title: Preps
description: MERCERSBURG, Pa., Oct. 25 Unbeaten Lawrenceville won its fifth game today, 240, from Mercersburg. Scott Coolidge again sparked the Larries with his passing. He threw to Dave Lecher for one score and a conversion and added a touchdown: on a short run. Lawrenceville is 501.

title: MOORE, MRS. COURT WIN TENNIS FINALS
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Oct. 23 (Reuters)Ray Moore defeated a fellow South African, PatCramer, 64, 46, 64, today in the final of a Dewar Cup indoor tennis tournament.

title: Anne Guestier Manice, Is Bride
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct, 28 St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Chapel was the setting here at noon today for the marriage of Miss Anne Guestier Manice, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hayward Ferry Manice of New York and Old BrookVille, to Ens. Edmond de Haye Jousselin of the Freneh Naval Reserve. He is the son of Mayor and Mrs. Bertrand de La Haye Jousselin of St. Aubin d'Escrosville, France. The Rev. James E. Collins performed the ceremony, which was followed by a small reception at the Manice home in Old Brookville.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: For Thomas Maremaa to say that Robert Crumb is the most important social satirist today is to allow himself to be rippedoff by the fraudulent merchants of the youth culture. First, the writer forgets that there are other underground cartoonists who have a wider audience (Gilbert Shelton), who have better technique (Skip Williamson or Jay Lynch), or who are simply more ingenious (The Mad Peck). Second, the writer discounts tradition too much, for to say that in the fifties experimentation and social commentary ceased is to ignore Flook or T i'l Abner. To suggest that Crumb appeared in 1968 with Zap in hand to save us all is to say that Crumb is our own personal Mr. Natural. Which he isn't.

title: Julie Meck Wed To C. B. Hamlin At Dartmouth
description: HANOVER, N. H., Oct. 28 The Rollins Chapel at Dartmouth College was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Julie Hazlett Meek; daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Foster Meck of Hanover arid Prouts, Neck, Me., to Charles Borden Hamlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Clark Hamlin of Chaumont, N. Y.

title: MAYOR RESISTING A CANARSIE STAND
description: Mayor Lindsay is resisting strong pressures that he intervene in the Canarsie school conflict because he is fearful that his entry at this point would make the problem more severe and perhaps ignite similar outbursts elsewhere in the city.

title: Eleventh District
description: The single mostcrucial issue facing my district is the one facing every district in the nation  the erosion of trust and confidence in our political system.

title: Queens Playhouse Opening
description: The myriad hues of autumn are overtaking the leaves in, Flushing Meadow Park these days, and the paths once trod by millions of visitors to the New York world's fairs now play host to strollers, joggers and bicyclists.

title: Milo Miloradovich, Soprano And Investment Adviser, 71
description: Milo Miloradovich, a former operatic soprano, died Friday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 71 years and lived at 235 East 73d Street.

title: SCHOOL FOOTBALL
description: BROCKTON, Mass., Oct. 28 Pete Colombo tossed three touchdown passes and Tony Hruzd crashed over for three more today as Brockton spoiled White Plains unbeaten season with a 40.8 victory before 8,000 fans at Marciano Stadium.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Mao and China
description: I am alone with the masses, Chairman Mao told Andre Malraux shortly before the Cultural Revolution. Waiting.

title: Debate on Outside Directors
description: More than three dozen suits have been filed by disgruntled shareholders of the Penn Central Transportation Company against the members of its board of directors who served prior to its receivership. These suits are based on the rule of law imposing the ultimate legal responsibility for the management of a corporate enterprise upon its board of directors.

title: Fairleigh Dickinson. Downs American Univ. Eleven, 240
description: TEANECK, N. J., Oct. 28 Tom DiMaggio ran 61 yards for a touchdown and passed 13 yards to Jim White for another today as Fairleigh Dickinson University defeated American University, 240, in a club football game.

title: STUDENTS SEEKING MORE PROTECTION
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 28College students, who are being mugged, raped and robbed with alarming frequency, are now demanding more protection from the campus security officers they once called pigs.

title: Mary Cameron Armstrong Bride
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 28Miss Mary Cameron Armstrong, daughter of Mrs. Frances H. Armstrong and Henry B. Armstrong 3d, both of Farmington, was married here this afternoon to Laurence Rumsey Goodyear Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Goodyear of Buffalo.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28Sexton is depressed about the Vietnam war ending. He is only forty years old and, therefore, cannot remember what it was like to live in a world without a Vietnam war. He has doubts about his ability to survive in such a world.

title: Air Force Scores A 3931 Triumph Over Ariz. State
description: TEMPE, Ariz., Oct. 28 (AP) The Air Force Academy won a fiercely fought aerial battle today, defeating 16thranked Arizona State University, 3931.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: When our forefathers wrote the First Amendment with its guarantee of a free press, they could not have anticipated the aura of romantic nonsense that long has shielded journalists and their media, print and electronic, from deserved criticism and prosecution.

title: Hearing to Open Tomorrow In OilBarge Explosion
description: A Coast Guard board with subpoene powers will convene here tomorrow to seek the cause of the oilbarge explosion and fire at Carteret, N. J., last Wednesday. The board will meet at 10 A.M. in Room 503 of the Customs House near Battery Park.

title: Preps
description: DEERFIELD, Mass., Oct. 28 Deerfield, smarting from 270 loss to Andover that dropped it from the undefeated ranks last season, intercepted five passes and recovered fumble to gain revenge, 200, at Andover's expense today.

title: Bare Ruined Choirs
description: Though here and there a little wild and wrongheaded, Bare Ruined Choirs is one of the most interesting hooks of the year, a brand new stickwaving Old Testament prophet's careful analysis of the crisis of the Roman Catholic Churcha crisis linked to that of American civilization as a whole. What happened? asks the prophet of the Lord, Garry Wills (political columnist and author of the highly praised Nixon Agonistes). One moment the two Johns are reigning serenelyKennedy in the White House, making Americans proud of their country; Pope John in the Vatican, convincing not only Catholics but all men of good will that Mother Church is the noblest of firstladies. The next moment America is a network of official and unofficial bombfactories, and the Jesuit schools, intellectual frontline of Catholicism, are closing down, wrecked by mere human marriages. Soon the only zealous faithful (though they hate the Mass in English) are F.B.I. men tracking Berrigans. What power could so easily smash the majestic ageold church?

title: Pacific Tops Idaho, 227
description: MOSCOW, Idaho, Oct. 28 (AP) Clutch secondhalf defensive plays and a twotouchdown effort by Mike Mangrum gave the University of Pacific a 227 nonconference victory over Idaho on a snowy afternoon today.

title: Vietnam
description: WASHINGTONExcitement was in the air. Hanoi had just broadcast the secret terms of a United StatesNorth Vietnam peace agreement, claiming that Washington was stalling on putting it into effect. The Administration, which had said almost nothing for a month about the peace talks, was forced td respond. By the time of the daily 11 A.M. White House news conference last Thursday, some 500 newsmen were crammed into the briefing room.

title: ADVERTISING POINT OF VIEW
description: I'm writing this column to put in a good word for fun. I know the business of Spending a lot of somebody else's money is not supposed to be funpresumably because if we aren't grim about it the clients will take all that dough back.

title: Peter Gerard to Marry Sophie C. May
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 28Mr. and Mrs. Irene du Pont May have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sophie Christine May, to Peter Charles Rupert Gerard, son of Mrs. H. ReissBrian Gerard of Bernardsville, N. J., and Rupert Charles Frederick Gerard of London and Glynde, England. A summer wedding is planned.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Robert Tomasson's article Oct. 15 concerning payments of rents by welfare clients failed to mention one suggestion that would solve what appears to be an insoluble problem.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: State legislatures, which last year enacted more than $5billion in tax increases, have generally taken a breather on the tax front this year.

title: Time Changes in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sunday, Oct. 29 (AP)Daylight saving time was officially introduced in four Australian states today, advancing clocks one hour.

title: SQUATTERS APPEAL TOCKS AREA CURB
description: SHAWNEE, Pa., Oct. 25With winter approaching, about 40 squatters on land acquired for the controversial Tocks Island Dam near here are seeking reversal of an order that cut off fuel and electrical service to the houses they live in.

title: Japanese Sought on Lubang
description: MANILA, Oct, 28 (Reuters)A search team looking for former Japanese soldier said to be hiding on the island of Lubang today searched his old hiding place and recovered rifle and other equipment. No sign of any recent activity in the hideout was reported.

title: PRISONS ASSAILED IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct, 28Gov. Milton J. Shapp has appointed seven officials to look into ways to improve health care for the 5,500 inmates in the slate's eight prisons.

title: Turnpike ParkRide A Commuter Boon
description: EAST BRUNSWICKIn an effort to alleviate the problem of where to park when taking a bus to New York, East Brunswick and the New Jersey Authority have joined forces to create a parkandride facility adjacent to Exit 9 of the Turnpike.

title: Sara Dailey Married to Allen G. Smith
description: Miss Sara Gibson Dailey was married here last evening to Allen Graves Smith at a SelfRealization Fellowship service at the Biltmore. Brother Anandamoy performed the ceremony after the annual meeting of the fellowship, whose members follow the philosophy of an Indian guru for action and meditation.

title: Vietnam
description: SAIGONSome 1,000 of President Thieu's supporters marched on the Presidential Palace here last Friday. Mr. Thieu, who had arranged the audience, spoke to them of the tentative peace agreements reached between Washington and Hanoi. Any ceasefire without our signature will not be valid, he said, to applause, [and] so far we have not agreed to anything.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 28 (AP)The Baltimore Sun endorsed President Nixon for reelection in its Sunday editions, saying the President is a better choice because he is a surer choice than. Senator George McGovern.

title: Nixon Signs a Bill To Give Diplomats Federal Protection
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28President Nixon signed a bill yesterday making it a federal offense to murder, kidnap, harass or threaten foreign diplomats, senior visiting foreign officials or other designated guests in this country. The law also applies to members of their families.

title: A Chinese Province Catches Record Number of Centipedes by Using the Correct Doctrine
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 12 Peasants in 10 districts of Hupeh Province have established a record in centipede catching this year because they followed the correct political line, China's official newspaper, Jenmin Jih Pao, reports.

title: Fotimer, Piloting Porsche, Triumphs In CanAm Finale
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Oct. 29 (AP)George Follmer, a Californian, napped his triunmphant CanadianAmerican Challenge Cup series for sports cars today by winning the Los Angeles Times Grand Prix at the International Raceway, the series finale.

title: Canadiens Nip Wings, 2.1
description: DETROIT, Oct. 29 (UPI)Secondperiod goals by Murray Wilson, a rookiehis first in the N.H.L.and. Pete Mahovlich gave the unbeaten Montreal Canadiens a 21 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight.

title: Jets Steal 3 Passes in 3410 Victory; Boozer Scores 3 Touchdowns. Again
description: Although Emerson Boozer gained 91 yards on 19 carries and scored three touchdowns in the New York Jets 3410 victory over the New England Patriots yesterday, all of the game balls went to the Jets' defensive line.

title: WARMS IS VICTOR IN SAHARA BY SHOT Rookie's 69 for 273 Beats Palmer, the RunnerUpNicklaus Ties for 5th
description: LAS VEGAS, Ned., Oct. 29 (AP)  Lanny Wadkins, a rookie, undaunted by the challenge of Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus, posted a twounderpar 69 today and won the $135,000 Sahara invitation golf tournament by one stroke with a total of 273. Palmer finished second.

title: Man and Son, Suspects on Jet, Sought in Murder of 2 at Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Charles A. Tuller Jr., charged today as one of four men who hijacked an Eastern Airlines jet to Cuba after killing a ticket clerk, left his job as a Commerce Department official here 10 days ago.

title: Oceanography in Soviet Union Praised by Navy Official After Tour
description: Soviet oceanography is hampered somewhat by problems in getting the materials and electronic components for experiments, but the research effort is clearly very large and guided by first  class ideas.

title: S. I., Manhattan
description: Seventeenth District: In spite of occasional votes of an overly cautious and conservative sort, we endorse the candidacy of Representative John M. Murphy (Dem.). He should be reelected basically because of his accomplishments, but also because his opponent, Mario Balardino (Rep.Cons.) is a flamboyantly poor candidate.

title: NEW JERSY
description: A technical advisory group has been formed to find and publicize recycling alternatives to a projected giant incinerator in the Hackensack Meadowland. The group under the aegis of the Committee for Resource Recovery.

title: MTS. BLITZER DIES; SCHOOL INNOVATOR
description: Mrs. Clara Fish Blitzer, a longtime leader in the Public Education Association who started the school volunteer program in the city's schools, died yesterday at the Lenox Hill Hospital, She was the widow of Moses D. Blitzer, founder and chairman of Lightolier, Inc., makers of lighting fixtures. Her age was 74, and she lived at 88 Central Park West.

title: UPSTAIRS IS BACK IN REVUE BUSINESS
description: The Upstairs at the Downstairs, where Julius Monk's satirical revues once held forth, is back in the revue businessand most happily.

title: Redskins Beat Giants, 2316, As Brown Runs for 191 Yards
description: Larry Brown was the difference yesterday as the National Football League's leading runner led the Washington Redskins to a 2316 victory over the New York Giants at Yankee Stadium.

title: U.S. LOSES IN VOTE AT UNESCO PARLEY
description: PARIS, Oct. 29  A strong trend among what appears to be a majority of the world's countries against the free international flow of information has emerged at the current meeting here of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, known as UNESCO.

title: Greek Orthodox Church Consecrated in Suburb
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Oct. 29  The Greek Orthodox Church of Our Saviour was consecrated here today in a fourhour service rich in the ancient symbolism of the Old and New Testaments.

title: LAWRENCE J.. FAGAN'
description: PITTSBURGH, Oot. 29Lawrence J. Fagan, who retired in 1960 as city editor of The Pittsburgh Press, died here yesterday at the home of a daughter, Mrs, Charles W. Herald. He was 79 years old and had been living in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Personal Finance
description: For veterans who are in school, college, graduate school or taking vocational training, and for those who are planning to do so, there is good news. By a law enacted last week, monthly educational allowances have been increased.

title: Senate Contest
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I. Oct. 29There are two fine men running for the Senate in Rhode Island, begins a campaign radio spot urging the reelection of Senator Claiborne Pell.

title: Houston Wins Golf Tourney
description: BATON ROUGE, Oct. 29 (AP)  The Houston Cougars captured team and individual honors in the 13th annual Louisiana State University invitation golf tournament today. The Cougars Bill Rogers overtook L.S.U.'s Dick Clark with a twounderpar 69 in the final round of the 54hole tourney. The Cougars had a team total of 1,073.

title: Outcry Holds Up California Bid To Deal With Illegitimate Births
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 29Mounting statewide controversy has persuaded a welfare advisory panel set up by Gov. Ronald Reagan to revise a drastic plan that it had proposed for dealing with California's growing number of illegitimate children.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: This report is based on the fourth of a series electoral vote surveys conducted for The New York Times by Daniel Yankelovich, Inc., of New York, major social and marketing research company.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Oct. 30, 1972 SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. to elect five members of the International Court of Justice.

title: Sidney I. Cole
description: Sidney I. Cole, chairman of the board of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, 710member Reform synagogue association in North America, died Saturday of a heart ailment in Chicago, where he lived. His age was 65.

title: Dolphins Stay Unbeaten By Thrashing Colts, 230
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 29Because the teams of the National Football League are so evenly matched, the law of averages is supposed to catch up with the undefeated Miami Dolphins any Sunday now.

title: CHAMBER CONCERT SPICED BY VARIETY
description: In its variety, yesterday afternoon's concert at Carnegie Recital Hall by the Long Island Chamber Ensemble of New York could hardly have been more spicy. How often do you hear on one program works as various as Mozart's Trio for Clarinet, Piano and Viola (K.498), Michael Colgrass's Variations for Four Drums and Viola, Louis Cheslock's Descant for Unaccompanied Clarinet, Nathan Ivan Kaplan's Quartet for Clarinet, Viola, Piano and Percussion (1972), and Bach's Suite No. 2 in D minor for Solo Viola?

title: Cavaliers Win, 11597
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 29 (AP)Lenny Wilkens and Austin Carr spurred the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 11597 victory over the Kansas CityOmaha. Kings in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

title: HORSE SHOW CUP TO SCOTCH VALLEY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 Scotch Valley, who Spent the week far down among the alsoram, suddenly found a course to his liking and won the President's Cup for international open jumpers tonight at the closing session of the Washington International horse show.

title: Hanoi Aides Say Both Sides Made Concessions on Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The North Vietnamese diplomats in Paris say that both sides made concessions in arriving at the current proposed settlement of the war.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: QUEBEC, Oct. 29 (Canadian Press)The Quebec Nordiques and the Cleveland Crusaders battled to a 22 tie in the first overtime game in Quebec Coliseum before 7,020 fans tonight.

title: J. Culbert Palmer, 76, Dies; Partner in Law Firm Here
description: J. Culbert Palmer, a partner in the law firm of Kelley, Drye, Warren, Clark, Carr & Ellis, Idled Saturday in ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 76 years old and lived at 1170 Fifth Avenue and in Stonington, Cenn.

title: PRINCESS ROSPIGLIOSI
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Oct. 29Princess Laura Rospigliosi, the former Laura MacDonald Stallo of Cincinnati and a granddaughter of Alexander MacDonald, an oil magnate, died here yesterday. She was 82 years old and lived in Palm Beach.

title: NEW JERSY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 29New JerIsey's Department of Environmental Protection has developed la map identifying for the first time the state's claims to lands that were formerly overflowed by tidal waters in now builtup areas from Elizabeth to Newark.

title: SCOTT IS NAMED TO HEAD PISTONS
description: One of the most precarious jobs in the National Basketball Associatien is coaching the Detroit pistons. The latest coach to find, that out was Earl Lloyd, dismisse Saturday night and replaced by Ray Scott, his assistant.

title: Angry Namath Scares Mates
description: Joe Namath's teammates said they never.had seen him so angry.

title: Mansfield Asserts Senate Must Investigate Watergate
description: HELENA, Mont., Oct. 29 (AP)Senator Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, said today that a thorough Senate investigation into the Watergate affair and all its ramifications is mandatory.

title: MobStyle Slaying Reported Near Police Headquarters
description: A 47yearold Brooklyn man whom the police described as a smalltime hoodlum was shot and killed yesterday morning two blocks west of Police Headquarters in an apparent hit by an unknown gunman, the police reported.

title: Raffish Police Gazette Still Lives
description: RAID IN THE TENDERLOIN, the headline read, Clark's Notorious Sixth Avenue Dive Closed by the PoliceA Night at the StationThe Girls Smoke Cigarettes and Have High Jinks in Their Cells.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Oct. 29 (Reuters)The United States yacht Aorcery was first across the finish line late last night in the Rio de Janeiro to Santos sailing regatta after a stunning run home. Skippered by J. B. Baldwin, Sorcery crossed in darkness shortly before midnight with a time of 23 hours 15.8 minutes. She had sailed out to sea in a gamble to catch the wind and was declared missing Friday' afternoon.

title: Bridge: Grand National, a New Kind Tourney, Is Coming Soon
description: The Grand National, a new type of event, has been scheduled by the American Contract Bridge League for the coming season. Each of the league's 25 districts will produce a district champion team, all of which will then compete for eight zonal titles. The eight survivors will play a final at the summer national championships in Washington in July, and the winning team will compete in the playoffs to determine the 1974 international team.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I intend no apology for the New York Stock Exchange. But in my view you neglected to consider a very important policy question in your editorial Oct. 10, Antitrust on Wall Street. In excoriating Needham and the Exchange for their position on the minimum commission and narrowing your objectives to the antitrust ideal of unregulated price competition, you lose sight of the equally important and countervailing ideal in the securities law of customer suitability.

title: McGovern Fears U.S. Faces New Depression if Nixon Wins
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The United States could experience another depression if President Nixon were to win a second term in the White House, Senator George McGovern suggested here today.

title: U.S.Japanese Deal Is Set on Soviet Gas
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 29An ambitious United StatesJapanese deal for the development of Siberian natural resources appeared to be shaping up here last week as executives from the two countries met separately with Soviet officials.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) Vice President Agnew said today that a calculated attempt to prove corruption on the part of the Administration  has fallen flat as a pancake in the eyes of the American people. The American people are tired of having all these insinuations made about the Nixon Administration, the Vice President said.

title: Filipinos Support Marcos Take.Over In Hope of Reform
description: MANILA, Oct. 23  In the waning days of his second and constitutionally last term as president of the Philippines, Ferdinand E. Marcos has conferred on himself absolute power.

title: 2 SHOT IN FLATBUSH; SUSPECT IS WOUNDED
description: A 40yearold man shot two men, one seriously, as he ran through the streets of the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn last night, according to tht police, who wounded and captured the man on the roof of tenement at 1555 Nostrand Avenue.

title: Music: Flawless Magic of de Larrocha
description: Alicia de Larrocha has always been one of the most popular artists to appear in the Hunter College series, and Saturday night the overflow extended to the stage. Her reception was overwhelming. To the huge audience, the tiny lady from Spain could do no wrong. That is because, among other reasons, she can do no wrong.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: MANILA, Oct. 29 (UPI)Dick Dell of the United States beat Mexico's Marcelo Lara, 61, 64, today to win the first Philippine Tennis Championships, the second in a threeleg Asian circuit. Dell, 23rdranked American, beat Lara in the opening leg in Tokyo, 64, 75.

title: General Host In Offer
description: The General Host Corporation has announced it will make an offer to purchase up to $50million principal amount of its outstanding 7 per cent subordinated debentures due Feb. 1, 1994, at a cash price of $70 per $100 principal amount. The offer, to be made to all holders of the debentures, will involve a cash payment by General Host of about $35.7million.

title: 15,514 See Flyers Win
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 (AP) Rick MacLeish scored two goals tonightits the Philadelphia Flyers pounded the listless Toronto Maple Leafs, 52. The crowd of 15,514 was the largest in history to see a National Hockey League game in Pennsylvania.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE MOUNTAIN PEOPLE. By Colin Al. Turnhull. 309 pages Illustrated Simon & Schuster. $7.95.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: RENSSELAERVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 29Three experts in publicopinion polling  two of them pollstersagreed, at conference here this weekend, that political polls did not have a bandwagon effect.

title: Wallace Recovery: Battling SelfDoubt As W ell as Wounds
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 29After more than five months of pain and selfdoubt, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama is beginning to emerge from the shock of an assassin's bullets that had crippled his ambitions as well as his body.

title: M'GOVERN AIDES ASK REFORMS IN DEFENSE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 29 (AP) A panel of national security advisers to Senator George McGovern called today for sweeping reform of the armed services, saying the military is one of our greatest casualties of the Indochina war.

title: Ruling by Nyquist
description: The State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist upheld yesterday the city Board of Education's decision to assign 32 black and Puerto Rican pupils from Brownsville to predominantly white John Wilson Junior High School 211 in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn.

title: MRS. WHITLOCK DIES; WROTE FOR CHILDREN
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 29 Mrs. Virginia. Bennett Whitlock; author of books of games for children and wife of F. Beaatarri Whitlock, retired vice, president of the Hanover Bank, died Friday at their home, 39 EMI Rock Road. Her age was over 70.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Captain Willenbucher's indisputable facts concerning the Panama Canal Zone (letter Oct. 6) are so disputable that one wonders how history is taught at the Naval Academy.

title: Major Expansion Of U.S. Economy Seen Through 73
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The Commerce Department predicted today that major expansion of the economy would continue at least through 1973.

title: DEFENSE BALANCE STRESSEDBY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29President Nixon, in the latest of his series of nationwide radio campaign speeches, denounced his opponent's defense policies today and came out strongly against any possibility of amnesty for draft dodgers and deserters.

title: High Blood Pressure Is Found to Be Inadequately Detected and Treated
description: A study conducted among nearly 23,000 employed adults in the Chicago area has shown that most people who have high blood pressure do not know of their condition and that few of those who do are being adequately treated for it.

title: CITY MAY REQUIRE LANDLORD DEPOSIT
description: The city, is drafting legislation that would require residential landlords to post a security deposit of one month's rent for each apartment to guarantee that repairs would be made when necessary.

title: The Scent of Repression
description: The nation's freedom is rooted in the law and nurtured by mutual trust between the Government and the people. The Nixon Administration has consistently undermined liberty's legal roots and poisoned the air with the scent of repression. It has done so not by any single measure but by persuading the selfish interests of a divided country that the cause of law and order justifies governmental inroads on even the most sacred personal rights.

title: SPANISH GROUP BUYS CONTROL OF I.O.S.
description: Control oF I.O.S., Ltd., the oncepowerful mutualfund organization, has been sold to a Spanish group, Milton F. Meissner, president, disclosed over the weekend.

title: Folimer, Driving Porsche, Triumphs in CanAm Finale
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Oct. 29 (AP)George Follmer, a Californian, capped his triunmphant CanadianAmerican Challenge Cup series for sports cars day by winning the Los Angeles Times Grand Prix at the International Raceway, the series finale.

title: JOHN S. SINCLAIR, LAWYER
description: WILTON, Conn., Oct. 29John S. Sinclair, former lawyer, banker, insurance executive and Red Cross leader, who retired in 1963 as president of the National Industrial Conference Board, died today at his home, 51 Shadow Lane. He was 75 years old.

title: Advertising:
description: If you show it in America. If you sell it in America. Make it in America was the message carried up Madison Avenue Friday by unionists protesting television commercial production outside the United States.

title: PRESIDENT ENDORSED BY WASHINGTON STAR
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (Reuters)President Nixon today received the editorial backing of The Washington Star for reelection on Nov. 7.

title: Excerpts From the Nyquist Statement
description: ALBANY, Oct. 29Following are excerpts from State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist's ruling in the Canarsie school dispute:

title: COUGARS CAPTURE 4TH IN ROW, 110105
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 29 (UPI)The Carolina Cougars, led by Billy Cunningham's 30 points, won their fourth straight game tonight, a 110105 victory over the Memphis Tams. It was the Tams fifth loss in a row.

title: At a Witchcraft Museum, Halloween Is More Than Trick or Treat
description: BRENTWOOD, L.I.For Raymond Buckland, Halloween means more than trick or treat. That's because he's high priest of a local coven of witches.

title: Search for Boggs Is Halted By Snow and Low Visibility
description: ANCHORAGE, Oct. 29 (AP)The Air Force said today that heavy snow and bad visibility had forced the temporary cancellation of its twoweekold search for the light plane missing with the House Democratic leader, Representative Hale Boggs, and three other persons.

title: CITY IS RENEWING BID FOR BIG BOARD SEAT
description: New York Citywhich has been trying to buy a seat on the New York Stock Exchange in an effort to save money on securities transactions  said yesterday it was renewing its bid for a seat.

title: Evander and Clinton to Play For ManhattanBronx Title
description: Evander and Clinton won yesterday and set up a meeting next Saturday that will decide the football championship of the ManhattanBronx Public Schools Athletic League. The winner of that game, which Will be played at Evander in the Bronx, will qualify for the semifinal round of the city playoffs.

title: Text of Interviews With Monserrat, Scribner and Local Leaders on Canarsie Issue
description: Following are excerpts from transcribed interviews on the Canarsie school controversy with Joseph Monserrat, president of the Board of Education; Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, Chancellor of the New York City schools; Jack Zimmer, president of the District 18 community school board; and the Rev. Wilbert B. Miller and Mrs. Joan Boatright, leaders of the parents of the black and Puerto Rican children involved in the dispute.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Cahill of New Jersey asked Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe last night to find a way to consolidate the services of three bankrupt railroads, the Central of New Jersey, the Lehigh Valley and the Reading.

title: KUWAIT IS TRYING TO END ARAB RIFT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 29Kuwait has begun diplomatic approaches to Egypt and Jordan in an effort to heal the breach between them before the meeting of Arab foreign ministers in Kuwait nest month, according to Arab diplomatic sources.

title: Salute to Nixon Planned
description: BOSTON, Oct. 29 (AP)Bob Hope, Ethel Merman and Lionel Hampton's orchestra will perform Tuesday night at a Salute to President Nixon's Reelection at Commonwealth Armory. Mrs. Nixon will attend.

title: ' Play It as It Lays' Comes to the Screen
description: At the age of 30, Maria (pronounced Mar-EYE-ah) Wyeth is driving her Camaro toward disaster on that great Southern California freeway called Life. Her daughter is retarded. Her mother and father, not seen for years, have died in the desert, searching for rainbows that now end in missile ranges. Her marriage to Carter Lang, one of Hollywood's most promising young directors, is on the rocks. Carter won fame directing Maria in "Angel Beach," but now he's less interested in Maria's moods than in his career, and in giving interviews about the geography of the human heart.Maria's only friend is B. Z., Carter's producer, a man who has found incontrovertible evidence that life means zero. When B. Z. decides to take an overdose of Seconals, Maria refuses to fetch him the necessary glass of water, but, with understanding and sorrow, she holds him as he drifts into death. Why does Maria go on? Why not? she says.Joan Didion's highly regarded novel, "Play It as It Lays," is so full of accurately observed details, and it's so relentlessly single-minded and tough as it charts the breakdown of its heroine, that I, for one, am not particularly bothered by this maraschino cherry of wisdom that one finally finds at the bottom. Getting to it has been more than half of the fun.This is not quite true with Frank Perry's film version, based on a screenplay by Miss Didion and John Gregory Dunne (Miss Didion's husband). The film is beautifully performed by Tuesday Weld as Maria and Anthony Perkins as B.Z., but the whole thing has turned soft, for reasons that I should have thought Miss Didion might have considered when she was working on the screenplay.The novel is nothing if not leanChapter 78 is 28 words long. Physical things and people are seldom described except in terms of feelings and effects. Which is the kind of novel it is. Even the layout of the book reflects the state of Maria's mindthere is something shocking about all of that white space on pages that otherwise contain only two or three lines of type.Movies, however, are different from novels, and Mr. Perry and his screenwriters have found no visual equivalent to Miss Didion's prose. There are no blank spaces in the film, and the images we see on the screen are not the banal images of Miss Didion's prose. They are banal images that have been transformed by the camera eye into terribly fancy art.The eye is dazzled in all the wrong ways. The dreadful Los Angeles freeway becomes, on screen, when seen from a helicopter, a magnificent op art design  graceful gray loops on which tiny spots of red, yellow and aquamarine zoom in mindless motion.We never have much time to get inside Maria's mind because we're so busy reacting in our own ways to everything Maria pays no attention to  to the meals uneaten, to the heated swimming pool unswum in, to the magnificent desert sunsets and sunrises unnoticed, to the glamorous parties that are supposed to be boring, to the expensive cars that are driven so badly I wonder how they last a week.Going to pieces this way doesn't seem all that terrifying, just extravagant. "Play It as It Lays" is so chic and elegant looking (Roy Lichtenstein was a visual consultant) that it reminds me of a charity ball for mental health. The cause is a good one, but it seems to be the last thing on anybody's mind at the moment. Unlike the novel, which evokes pity, the film is more likely to evoke pure, unadulterated envy.In addition to Miss Weld and Mr. Perkins, the cast includes Tammy Grimes, Adam Roarke and Ruth Ford. The film opened yesterday at the Beekman.

title: RANGERS TROUNCE BLACK HAWKS,71
description: A remarkably vicious assault by Curt Bennett, one of two Ivy Leaguers in the National Hockey League, against the Chicago Black Hawks' Cliff Koroll punctuated last, night's commanding 71 Ranger victory at Madison Square Garden.

title: NEW JERSY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 29Governor Cahill met with United States Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe tonight to seek a way to bring order out of what is now chic with commuter and freight railroads in New Jersey.

title: ExBackers of Mrs. Gandhi Launch Drive Against Her
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 29Former colleagues of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi decided today to lunch a nonviolent mass movement against her Government which they said had brought India to the brink of economic disaster.

title: Rabbi Leopold Friedman Dies; Leader of Hasidic Movement
description: Rabbi Leopold Friedman, who revitalized the movement of Hasidic Jews in the United States, died Saturday of a heart attack in his home at 71 Lee Avenue, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. He was 68 years old.

title: NIXON HOLDS LEAD AS M'GOVERN GAINS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Despite further gradual gains by Senator George McGovern, President Nixon held a massive lead in potential electoral votes as the Presidential campaign entered its last two weeks, according to the fourth New York Times/Yankelovich survey.

title: PILIC RALLIES TO TOP LUTZ IN ESSEN FINAL
description: ESSEN, West Germany, Oct. 29 (AP)Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia rallied for a 46, 64, 36, 64, 76, victory over Bob Lutz of Los Angeles today and won his first title in the World Tennis Championship series.

title: Saigon Increasing Vigilance in Cities
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam,) Oct. 29Government policemen have been combing the streets and neighborhoods of Saigon and other large cities for the last two weeks, checking identification cards and enforcing new regulations that South Vietnamese citizens must possess a national flag and produce it on demand.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In addition to the evidence cited in your endorsement of Senator McGovern I hope that the readers of your influential newspaper wilt be impressed with the significantand perhaps sufficientfact that two of the states which are giving Senator McGovern his strongest support are South Dakota, where they know George McGovern best, and California, where we know Richard Nixon best.

title: Dagbury Beats 326 Rivals for Best in Show
description: An English import, Ch. Dagbury of Calartha, coowned by Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords Jr. of New York and Michael Wolf of North Babylon, was bestinshow at the 40th alltoy fixture of the Progressive Dog Club, which drew a field of 327 to the Hotel McAlpin yesterday.

title: Pressures Mount for Yen Revaluation
description: TOKYO, Oct. 29The pressures on Japan for another revaluation of the yen have become so strong that the question asked in Tokyo today is not whether it will happen, but when, how much, and under what circumstances.

title: Israeli Planes Raid 4 Targets in Syria
description: TEL AVIV, Monday, Oct. 30  Israeli planes raided four Arab guerrilla bases in the suburbs of Damascus today and returned home safely, the Israeli Government said.

title: WADKINS VICTOR IN SAHARA GOLF
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 29 (AP)Lanny Wadkins, a rookie, undaunted by the challenge of Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus, posted a twounderpar 69 today and won the $135,000. Sahara invitation golf tournament by one stroke with a total of 273. Palmer finished second.

title: Homosexual Church Moves
description: Nearly 100 members of the Church of the Beloved Disciple, the first homosexual congregation in New York City, marched across town yesterday from the Episcopal Church of the Holy Apostles at Ninth Avenue and 28th Street to a new home in the First Moravian Church at Lexington Avenue and 30th Street.

title: POPE BEATIFIES SALESIAN PRIEST
description: ROME, Oct. 29Pope Paul VI today beatified the late Rev. Michele Rua, the successor of St. John Bosco, who founded the Salesian order in the 19th century. A blessed or beautified person is a candidate for sainthood.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: The bitter rivalry between the Liberal and Conservative parties for the favor of the voters and for power in this state will take a new turn in the Nov. election when for the first time they will compete on the Presidential line.

title: BRITON BEGINS VISIT TO CHINA FOR 5 DAYS
description: PEKING, Oct. 29 (Agence FrancePresse)Foreign Minister Chi Pengfei received his first report today on the European summit meeting held in Paris Oct. 19 and 20 from Britain's Foreign Secretary, Sit Alec DouglasHome. Sir Alec arrived here this morning on fiveday official visit.

title: Madrid Is Moving To Combat Inflation As Unrest Mounts
description: MADRID, Oct. 29The Spanish Government has taken emergency steps to stabilize the Cost of living after large price increases caused wide discontent.

title: NEW JERSY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Oct. 29 (AP)The Center for Transportation Studies of the Eagleton Institute of Politics is being disbanded because of a lack of funds to continue adequately researching problems of transportation, according to Donald Herzberg, Eagleton director.

title: Bulls Edge Sonics
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 29 (AP) Bob Love's basket and Jerry Sloan's two foul shots in the final 40 seconds shut off a Seattle rally and enabled the Chicago Bulls to score a 9594 victory tonight.

title: U.S. SAYS ACCORD WILL NOTBE SIGNED BY HANOIDEADLINE Agnew and Others Rule Out a Pact Tomorrow but Are Optimistic on One Soon INTELLIGENCE IS CITED Signals From Foe Said to Indicate North Vietnamese Would Not End Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 Administration officials said without qualification today that the Indochina peace accord would not be signed by Tuesday, the deadline set by North Vietnam, but at the same time, they continued to express optimism about an early settlement of remaining details. Moreover, Vice President Agnew, appearing in a television interview, sought to assure North Vietnam that the United States was not seeking to renege on the ninepoint agreement reached by Henry A. Kissinger and Le Due Tho in Paris earlier this month.

title: DEFENSE BALANCE STRESSED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29President Nixon, in the latest of his series of nationwide radio campaign speeches, denounced his opponent's defense policies today and came out strongly against any possibility of amnesty for draft dodgers and deserters.

title: Mrs. Nixon to Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI)  Mrs. Richard Nixon will campaign in Chicago with her Ihusband on Tuesday.

title: Engagements
description: TROTTERMILLSMr. 8. Mrs, Hells of Upton Grey House, Hampshire, England announce the engagement of their daughter Jemlma to Edward, son of the late Lt. Col. George and Lady Moryoth Hay of Forbes Lodge, Gifford, England.

title: Dance: Emery Hermans
description: Dancers who have come out of the Alwin NikolaisMurray Louis sctool or Mr. Nikolais's company tend naturally to conserve their teachers movement style when they turn to choreography, but they often have their own ideas about where to go next. In Emery Hermans's Nexus, a concert that was the equivalent of his first oneman show, at the LouisNikolais Theater Lab Friday night, Mr. Hermans created a surprisingly emotional aura in the precincts of the nonpsychological approach.

title: 15 Precincts Lose 20% of Policemen While 8 Others Gain
description: The New York Police Department has carried out a major redistribution of manpower during the last year in which 15 of the city's 73 precincts Jost more than 20 per cent of their policemen while eight precincts gained strength.

title: Enemy Steps Up Infiltration Near Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Oct. 30Communist troops intensified their infiltration 0 campaign around Saigon again yesterday in preparation for an expected ceasefire occupying 17 hamlets within a 45mile radius of the capital, allied officers said.

title: Raiders Early Spree Routs Rams, 4517 in First Meeting
description: In the first National Football League meeting between the Oakland Raiders and the Los Angeles Rams, the Raiders literally  got off to a fast start on their neighbors from southern California.

title: Leonhardt Gives a Harpsichord Recital
description: When Gustav Leonhardt gave a recital at the Hunter College Playhouse a few years ago, his playing impressed me as being correct, dignified and somewhat uneventful. At Tully Hall Saturday night, the impression made by the Dutch harpsichordist was different. His playing was still correct and dignified, but uneventful it was not.

title: Pope Hopes CeaseFire Will Bring True Peace
description: ROME, Oct. 29Pope Paul VI today expressed hope that the expected ceasefire in Indochina would represent a true peace that would satisfy the present eagerness for peace that pervades the world.

title: Any Shutdown Opposed
description: Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, the City School Chancellor, has vowed as his first responsibility in the Canarsie dispute to keep open Junior High School 211, where embittered parents have been demonstrating against the admission of 32 black and Puerto Rican youngsters from outside the district.

title: Aqueduct's Post Time Shifted to 12:30 P.M.
description: Because of the return to Eastern Standard Time, starting today the, post time for the first race at Aqueduct will be 12:30 P.M., one hour earlier than before.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In the Oct. 23 news article Cambodia: A Fear of Forces Beyond Control Craig R. Whitney reported among other things that increasingly, President Lon Nol is governing through a smaller and smaller circle of intimates. In addition, the correspondent alleged the lack of government presence in the countryside.

title: Enemy Steps Up Infiltration Near Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Oct. 30Communist troops intensified their infiltration campaign around Saigon again yesterday in preparation for an expected ceasefire, occupying 17 hamlets within a 45mile radius of the capital, allied officers said.

title: State's Relief Chief Asks City Penalties In Failure on Tax
description: State Welfare Inspector General George F. Berlinger has called for state penalties against the city because he said it was failing to recover tax refunds from welfare recipients.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Now that we have been treated to another commission report on the state of education in New York, it is little wonder that many of its suggestions are the outgrowth of Dr. Silberman's critique, which in turn aped Mr. Holt's opinion, and so on ad nauseum, ever moving forward by stepping backward in time.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New York Police Department has carried out major redistribution of policemen during the last year in which 15 of the city's 73 precincts have lost more than 20 per cent of their men while eight precincts have gained strength, according to study of police records.

title: MOORE SONG CYCLE HEARD IN PREMIERE
description: A composer's lot is hard enough these days, but if you happen to be a woman composer and black, the obstacles must seem well nigh insuperable. Dorothy Rudd Moore, however has been gallantly carving a niche for herself. Her newest work is From the Dark Tower, a cycle of four songs for mezzo and orchestras, which had its premiere yesterday afternoon at Philharmonic Hall by Hilda Harris and the Symphony of the New World under George Byrd's baton.

title: Advertising:
description: Jim Jordan and John Bergin, the creative biggies at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborne, which includes the Gillette company among its many accounts, were having lunch together the day the World Series stood at three games to one in favor of the Oakland Athletics.

title: NIXON HOLDS LEAD AS M'GOVERN GAINS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Despite further gradual gains by Senator George McGovern, President Nixon held a massive lead in potential electoral votes as the Presidential campaign entered its last two weeks, according to the fourth New York Times/Yankelovich survey.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Slowly, three blue jerseys arose, revealing Larry Brown stretched out, his face mask in the grass, as if he had been squashed. When the National Football League's leading running back continued to lie there, a small cheer began to circulate Yankee Stadium from the wishful thinkers, who knew that if Larry Brown were out of the game, the New York Giants might win. But suddenly, he hopped to his feet mid the wishful thinkers were stilled, as if a waterfall had been turned off. I wasn't hurt, I was resting, he would say later. But when that cheer started, that's when I got up.

title: Pistons 119111 Victors
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 29 (AP)The Detroit Pistons rallied behind Bob Lanier in the fourth quarter tonight and gave their new coach, Ray Scott, his first victory, a 119111 triumph over the struggling Portland Trail Blazers. Lanier got 33 points.

title: John F. Roy, ExPresident Of Two Troy Newspapers
description: GUILDERLAND, N. Y., Oct, 29 (AP)John F. Roy, former president of the Troy Record Company, publisher of The Troy Record and The Times Record, died Friday, at a nursing home.

title: Nostalgic Michigan Students Join in OldFashioned Homecoming
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 29Remember ths days before relevance and politics became concerns on the nation's campuses; that distant past when the simple pursuit of happiness was the prime aim of every redblooded college student and the most violent collegiate activity was the Saturday football game?

title: MRS. MAX GROSSMAN, FAMILY EXPERT, 78
description: Mrs. Jean Schick Grossman, former director of parent education for the Play School Association and author of numerous books, pamphlets and articles on family themes, died yesterday in Montefiore Hospital in the BronX. She, was 78 years old and lived at 70 East 10th Street. Her husband, Max Grossman, is a lawyer and past president of the New York Society for Ethical Culture;

title: Lemon to Head N.B.C. Radio
description: Robert W. Lemon will become president of the radio division of the National Broadcasting Company on Wednesday. Mr. Lemon, who has been with N.B.C. for 15 years, will succeed Robert L. Stone, who resigned to head the Hertz Corporation. Mr. Lemon, who became vice president for special projects, N. B. C. television stations division last month, had been vice president and general manager of WMAQTV, the N. B. C.owned station in Chicago.

title: Martin Sparks Sabres
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 29 (AP)Rick Martin'scored the Buffalo goals, his 12th and 13th of the season, as the undefeated Sabres defeated the Minnesota North Stars, 21, tonight. The victory extended Buffalo's streak to 10 games.

title: When Essex Hunt Meets to Race, The Faithful Turnout, Even in Rain
description: FAR HILLS, N. J., Oct. 29 There are some outdoor events that are simply canceled when the odds are weighted against them. The Essex Fox Hounds Hunt race meeting isn't one of them.

title: College Enrollment Is Up by 2%; Cost Trouble Forecast for 1980's
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 29  A national authority on college enrollment says that approximately 9,215,500 students were enrolled this fall, a 2 per cent increase over last year's total.

title: Merger News
description: The board of directors of the Rheingold Corporation said over the weekend it would seek to enjoin the tender offer made last Tuesday by Pepsico Inc, to purchase a controlling interest in Rheingold.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: There is a special New York irony in the fact that the rulebook slowdown being suffered upon us by the Transit Police is nothing less than the Transit Police doing part of what they are supposed to be doing and obviously have not been doing at all. In a city where every minor flouting of law is dismissed as an inconvenience by those hired to enforce it, we have nothing left but to look upon this rulebook idiocy as a curious blessing. Now if we could only inspire somebody to punish us further by actually enforcing the new antinoise law, [Editorial Oct. 25.]

title: Hercules Expanding Plant
description: Hercules, Inc., said over the weekend that it had started a major expansion of its plant at Wilmington, N. C., to make dimethyl terephthalate, the principal raw material used in making polyesters for synthetic fiber and film. The expansion will increase the plant's capacity from 600 million to 900 million pounds a year. Industry sources put the cost of the program at more than $25million.

title: French Designers. Favor the Casual Look
description: PARIS, Oct. 29Coco Chanel made a name for herself o't of a man's polo sweater that she tossed over her shoulders during the chilly season in Deauville.

title: Dublin Hotels Bombed
description: DUBLIN, Oct. 29As Sinn Fein, the political arm of the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army, met here in a conference this weekend, terrorists set off bombs in four hotels and one more in a railroad station.

title: BUSES FACE HALT IN WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 30Officials of three major Westchester County bus lines that carry about 90,000 riders daily said today they feared that service might be halted by a strike at midnight Tuesday when labor contracts expire.

title: Pride Evident in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 29Palestinian refugees indicated excitement and evident pride today over the hijacking of the Lufthansa airliner to obtain the release of three guerrillas in West Germany. But the major Palestinian guerrilla organizations with headquarters here refused to comment on the operation.

title: Congress: Queens, Bronx
description: The Times recommendations in Congressional races in the five boroughs of New York City follow:

title: 2 New City Firehouses Kept Idle by Job Freeze
description: For almost a year now, two new firehouses have stood vacant while Fire Department officials tried to figure out a way of manning them within the limitations of the city's job freeze.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The United States could experience another depression if President Nixon were to win a second term in the White House, Senator George McGovern suggested here today.

title: 3 to Receive Journalism Awards
description: The Maria Moors Cabot Prizes for interAmerican journalism will be awarded tomorrow at Columbia University to Tom Streithorst, former LatinAmerican correspondent for N.B.C. News, Dr. Arturo Uslar Pietri, editor in chief of the Caracas Venezuela, newspaper El Nacional, and Dr. Pedro G. Beltran, former editor and publisher of the newspaper La Prensa, of Lima, Peru.

title: Fruit and Light
description: The greatest of modern economists, Alfred Marshall, who died half a century before there was a Nobel Prize in economics, used to like to cite Francis Bacon's distinction between scientific works that bear fruit and those that shed light.

title: MISS SNYDER, PIANIST, BACK AFTER 7 YEARS
description: In the seven years since her New York piano debut, Mary Richter Snyder has apparently built an active performing career in the Middle West, with radio and television appearances in her home state of Ohio, and various other regional appearances in solo and chamber repertoire.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Dwight L. Chapin, a deputy assistant to President Nixon has acknowledged to Federal investigators that he hired Donald H. Segretti, a young lawyer who is reported to have been a Republican sabotage agent, according to Time magazine.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Mayor Lindsay's observations about slobs (Oct. 16) certainly tries valiantly to fight a growing and powerful trend. Slobism and slobology are big these days. Some of the best people are slobs.

title: Boy Mauled by a Tiger In Florida Animal Parade
description: MIAMI, Oct. 29 (AP)A boy was mauled by a pet tiger today during a parade in which animals were blessed.

title: Belfast Youth,16, Killed by Gunmen; 4 Blasts in Dublin
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 29 (UPI)Gunmen firing from a passing automobile killed one Belfast youth and wounded another today, police officials said.

title: RAIDERS TRIUMPH OVER OILERS, 72
description: The New York Raiders beat Alberta yesterday with a thumping so solid, 72, that it raised the question of how the Oilers had ever reached second place in the Western Division of the World Hockey Asiociation.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 29 (AP)The Indiana Pacers moved into a secondplace tie with San Diego in the Western Division with a 11298 victory over the young Conquistadors tonight.

title: Credit Markets
description: Interest rates are expected to remain stable, several bond traders and credit market analysts suggested late last week as they tried to discern the nearterm outlook. These are the factors cited to support the view that fixedincome security prices will not change much dur ing the week ahead:

title: U.S. SAYS ACCORD WILL NOT BE SIGNED BYFIANO1 DEADLINE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 Administration officials said without qualification today that the Indochina peace accord would not be signed by Tuesday, the deadline set by North Vietnam, but at the same time they continued to express optimism about an early settlement of remaining details.

title: and Brooklyn
description: Twelfth District: Something of a disappointment in her second term, in which much of her attention went to an abrasive campaign for the Presidency rather than the business of the House, Shirley Chisholm (Dem.Lib.) is nevertheless a useful Congresswoman.

title: M'GOVERN FEARS ANEW DEPRESSION IF PRESIDENT WINS
description: The Candidates

title: Article 6  No Title
description: TOKYO, Oct. 29 (AgenceFrance Press)Negotiations for the socalled memorandum trade agreement began in Peking last Wednesday.

title: NEW JERSY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 29The 325,000 Puerto Ricans in New Jersey were urged today not to lock themselves into one political party and to exert positive influence upon all levels of government to respond to their social needs.

title: 3 Sailors Killed, 12 Hurt in Fire on the Saratoga
