description: SINGAPORE, Oct. 29 (UPI)Fire broke out aboard the aircraft carrier Saratoga at her berth here, killing three sailors and injuring 12 others.

title: Any Shutdown Opposed By GENE 1. MAEROFF
description: Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, the City School Chancellor, has vowed as his first responsibility in the Canarsie dispute to keep open Junior High School 211, where embittered parents have been demonstrating against the admission of 32 black and Puerto Rican youngsters from outside the district.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: FLORISSANT, Mo., Oct. 29Sargent Shriver accused President Nixon today of wanting to turn the Supreme Court back 40 years, to emasculate Congress with spending ceilings, and to end the executive branch's role in aiding the helpless and stimulating the economy.

title: MISS MARSEE'S ELAN FITS COSI FAN TUTTE
description: The charming New York City Opera production of Mozart's Cosi Fan Tutte is peopled with some of the finest singing actors in the companyPatricia Brooks, Ruth Welting, Kenneth Riegel, Richard Stilwell and Michael Devlinso any newcomer to the cast had better be cut from that same high quality musical cloth. Susanne Marsee is, and the mezzo was an adorable Dorabella in her first appearance in the role Saturday night, the touch of duskiness in her bright voice serving as an ideal counterweight to the patrician elegance of Miss Brooks's Fiordiligi and the frothy girlishness of Miss Welting's Despina.

title: Martha Huddlleston Dies; Former Book Executive
description: Mrs. Martha Hawley Buddieston, who was wellknown in the educational record industry here and earlier, in the book field; died Friday in Rochester (Minn.) Methodist Hospital. She was 66 years old and lived at 20 East Eighth Street.

title: 2 Art Treasures Cross the Channel
description: PARISTo celebrate England's entry into the European Economic Community, she and France are lending each other two major treasures from their grandest museums.

title: Bruins Trounce Islari ers, 91, as Bucyk Collects 400th Career Goal
description: BOSTON, Oct. 29 (AP)Johnny Bucyk became the eighth player in National Hockey League history to score 400 goals and Greg Sheppard connected for the first three goals of his brief career tonight as, the Boston Bruins breezed to a 91victory over the New York Islanders.

title: Arabs Hijack German Airliner and Gain Release of 3 Seized in Munich Killings
description: Palestinian guerrillas hijacked a West German jetliner yesterday over Turkey and won the release of three Arab commandos accused of taking part in the slaying of 11 Israelis at the Olympic Games in Munich on Sept. 5.

title: 4 Kill Texas Airline Aide And Hijack a. Jet to Cuba
description: Four hijackers armed with pistols and a shotgun killed an Eastern Airlines gate agent and wounded another employe at Houston Intercontinental Airport early yesterday before diverting a jet and its 29 passengers to Cuba.

title: M'GOVERN FEARS ANEW DEPRESSION IF PRESIDENT WINS
description: The Candidates Senator George McGovern said that if President Nixon was reelected, he's going to try to veto us right back to where we were in 1932.

title: VISITOR TO CITY HELD IN BRIBERY ATTEMPT
description: A Massachusetts man was charged with attempted bribery yesterday after he allegedly offered a policeman $10,000 to falsify a drug report, according to police.

title: Israel to Protest
description: A Foreign Ministry spokesman said Israel would raise the capitulation to the hijackers immediately with Bonn.

title: Canadian Polls Give Trudeau Party Slight Edge in Vote Today
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 29  The voters of Canada decide tomorrow whether they want to keep Pierre Elliott Trudeau as Prime Minister.

title: Wallace Recovery: Battling SelfDoubt As W ell as Wounds
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 29After more than five months of pain and selfdoubt, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama is beginning to emerge from the shock of an assassin's bullets that had crippled his ambitions as well as his body.

title: Sudan Seizes 3 Communists
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Oct. 29 (AP)Sudanese security authorities announced today that they had captured three Communist leaders who disappeared after an unsuccessful coup d'etat attempt in July, 1971. They said that they also seized important documents that disclosed Communist planning and activities over the preceding months.

title: Why Market Snubbed Peace
description: Peace in Vietnamit will do wonders for the stock market. That is what some of the smart people in Wall Street have been saying off and on for several years.

title: Two Tie for Jumper Crown At The Hill's Horse Show
description: NORTH SALEM, N. Y., Oct. 29Imperial Wizard, owned by the Mountain Valley Equestrian Center of South Britain, Conn., and Nilesway Farm's Jesse James tied for the open jumper championship today at the closing session of The Hill horse show.

title: NEW JERSY
description: TOMS RIVER, Oct. 29The proposed twin offshore nuclear generating plants, which would be moored within a huge manmade breakwater southeast of Little Egg Inlet, have attracted their first formal government opposition.

title: Peking, Backing, Hanoi, Bids U.S. Sign Accord
description: HONG KONG, Monday, Oct. 30 (Agence FrancePresse)Peking today threw its weight behind Hanoi and demanded that the United States sign a Vietnam peace agreement as scheduled.

title: A French Sex Survey Damages the Reputation
description: PARIS, Oct. 29 (AP)A new survey on sex life in France, described as a Gallic Kinsey report, damages the reputation of Frenchmen as expert lovers.

title: Johnson & Johnson Employes Give $67,000 to Office Seekers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Oct, 29 (AP)Johnson & Johnson, the harmaceutical concern, has collected more than $67,000 to give to Congressional candidates with a sympathetic ear to business problems.

title: Ruling by Nyquist
description: The State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist upheld yesterday the city Board of Education's decision to assign 32 black and Puerto Rican pupils from Brownsville to predominantly white John Wilson Junior High School 211 in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Oct. 29 (AP)Two Australians, David Graham and Peter Thomson, with 72hole totals of 281, tied in the Qantas Australian golf tournament today and will compete in an 18hole playoff tomorrow.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally, in a recent television speech, repeated Vice President Spiro Agnew's observation that the flow of Vietnamese refugees to Saigon rather than to Hanoi is an ideological reflection. The observation is warped. If B52's were dumping their bombs over Saigon instead of Hanoi, the refugees would be northward bound. Survival is still the name of the game.

title: DONALD MACAULAY, A PAPER SPECIALIST
description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Oct. 29 Donald Macaulay, a pioneer in the development of qualitycontrol systems in the graphic arts industry, died yesterday at the Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco. He was 70 years old and had lived here for the last 32 years.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 29 (AP)Johnny Neumann, the sophomore scoring star signed into pro basketball off the University of Mississippi campus last year, has been placed on waivers by the Memphis Tams of the American Basketball Association.

title: NEW JERSY
description: CARTERET, Oct. 29  One can hardly round a corner of this industrial town 10 miles southwest of Manhattan without seeing a tank farm of petroleum or chemical products. Consequently, it was no surprise to find many of the residents of this workingclass community on the Arthur Kill, just west of Staten Island, expressing some apprehension for their safety shortly after the series of explosions and fires last week.

title: The Lessons of Eagleton
description: The tragic episode of Thomas F. Eagleton last July, of first winning the Democratic VicePresidential nomination and then losing it on grounds of three psychiatric hospitalizations, has opened up an intense debate about the question of mental stability of our political leaders. Generated by deep anxiety, the debate continues, at least in medical circles.

title: The Unemployment Issue
description: On Election Day the latest unemployment rate that voters will have seen will be September's 5.5 per cent. The number of jobless workers is now 4.8 milliontwo million higher than when President Nixon took office. But, with the polls showing Mr. Nixon far ahead of Senator McGovern, the Administration's economists have formally abandoned the goal of 4 per cent unemployment that economists accepted as an approximate measure of full employment through the postwar period. The Nixon Administration's own economists have used 4 per cent unemployment as the basis for their calculation of fullemployment budgetsthe cornerstone of the Administration's fiscal policy.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Sudden Death Fails To End Deadlock In Women's Golf
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Oct. 29 (UPI)Three women tour members tied in regulation play today in the $20,000 Corpus Christi Civitan open golf tourney and went into a suddendeath playoff: Kathy Whit7 worth was eliminated, but darkness left Joann Prentice and Sandra Palmer still tied for first place.

title: Scribner Weighed Resignation After Reversal by School Board
description: For three days last week, Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner seriously considered resigning if the Board of Education reversed him, as it ultimately did, in the Canarsie school dispute.

title: NEW JERSY
description: MORRISTOWN, Oct. 29A thoroughly modern, $600,000 Salvation Army Center, a far cry from the drab and gloomy surroundings many people associate with the organization, Opened here today.

title: WILLIAM GILMAN, 53, BLIND LEGISLATOR
description: OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., Oct. 29 William P. Gilman, an Army veteran blinded in World War II who became twoterm member of the Maine Legislature in the 1950's, died at his home here Friday. He was 53 years old.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: LOS ANGELESThe White House announcement that peace is at hand in Vietnam should by all ordinary logic have destroyed whatever hopes George McGovern had in this election, So most commentators thoughtand so evidently did some of the McGovern staff.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: A State Court of Appeals candidate disclosed yesterday that he had scrapped one of his television commercials because of criticism that I sound like a district attorney.

title: JAPAN AND CHINA SET TRADE AGREEMENT
description: TOKYO, Oct. 29 (AP)Japan and China signed a private trade agreement in Peking today calling for $120million in twoway trade for 1973, up 30 per cent from the expected trade volume for this year.

title: SHOP TALK
description: There's something cozily comforting about Aida Grey's nononsense motherknowsbest approach to the business of skin care. It has made her Wilshire Boulevard salon in Los Angeles a Mecca for old movie stars (Irene Dunne, Betty Grable, Alice Faye) and young ones (Jane Fonda, Marlo Thomas, Nancy Thomas) who drop in as often as once a week for her brand of admonishment and encouragement.

title: One Bettor. Wins $32,967 On Green Mountain Perfecta
description: POWNAL, Vt., Oct. 29 (AP) One unidentified ticketholder in a crowd of 6,822 collected $32,967 on the big perfecta today as Green Mountain Park wound up 20'0 days of racing.

title: House Contests
description: NORTH TONAWANDA, N.Y., Oct. 29In 1964, Richard D. (Max) McCarthy, an energetic publicrelations man and a liberal Democrat, won a surprising election to the House of Representatives, thanks in part to President Lyndon B. Johnson's Democratic landslide.

title: Filipinos Support Marcos TakeOver In Hope of Reform
description: MANILA, Oct. 23In the waning days of his second and constitutionally last term as president of the Philippines, Ferdinand E. Marcos has conferred on himself absolute power.

title: John McAllister 2d, Managed RCA's Aerospace Division
description: John R. McAllister 2d, vice president and general manager of the aerospacesystems division of the RCA Corporation, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Saturday, in Sugar Bush, Vt. He was 53 years old and lived in Concord, Mass.

title: MRS. JULIUS TANTLEFF
description: Mrs. Shirley baimita Tentleff, president of the East End chapter of the City of Hope, a hospital and research center in Duarte, Calif. died Saturday night at a dinner at the Plaza. She was, 47 years old and the wife of Julius Tantleff, owner of the Black Angus restaurant in the San Carlos Hotel, 150 East 50th Street, where the couple resided.

title: Student Animal Dealer Finds City Is Fair Game
description: Stuart Salenger, who graduated from Columbia University's School of General Studies last week, put himself through school by selling anteaters. And elephants and lion cubs and pythons an pet food and tropical plants and Turkish bird cageseven custommade aquariums and terrariums.

title: Canarsie Parents Press Their Boycott of Schools
description: More than 2,200 white Canarsie parents, anticipating that the assignment of 32 black and Puerto Rican Brownsville youths to John Wilson Junior High School 211 would be upheld, vowed at a rally yesterday to continue their boycott of eight area schools and to turn out in front of J.H.S. 211 today to protest the assignments.

title: Temporary Homes For Pets: Locating One That's Suitable
description: The latest thing in matchmaking is matching dogs to foster homes. No crowding, no cages, no lonesome hours while you're away, the brochure for BoardaPet Placement Service, Inc., says. The matching is done scientifically, the brochure also says, and it can be done for cats and birds as well as dogs.

title: WILLIAM PLUNKERT
description: William J. Plunkert, who had directed alchoholism programs for the Community Council of Greater New York and had served as an associate director of National Council on Alcoholism, died Saturday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 601 East 20th Street.

title: N.Y.A.C. Wins Team Title In A.A.U. 3,000Meter Run
description: The New York Athletic Club won the National Amateur Athletic Union 3,000meter run team championship yesterday.

title: 2 Women Shot, 1 Fatally, In Brooklyn Incidents
description: Two shooting incidents in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn last night left one woman dead and another with gunshot wounds in both legs.

title: 2 Escape Prison in Cyprus
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 29 (AP)The police announced today that two men serving 14year jail terms for trying to assassinate President Makarios in March, 1970, escaped from Nicosia's central prison yesterday. A police statement said that three staff members of the prison had been detained in the escape.

title: In Laos, Few Illusions Now About Peace
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 29Ten years ago the word reached Vientiane that the great powers had signed an agreement ending the war in Laos for the second time.

title: Paultz's Shot Gives Nets Uphill Triumph Over Chaps, 10098
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 29Billy Paultz connected with an 18foot jumper with 18 seconds to go to give the New York Nets a 10098 victory over the Dallas Chaparrals in an American Basketball Association game in Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: Photographer Is Freed
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 29 (AP)Gaston Boudelet, a French freelance photographer seized by Communist forces near the Angkor temple complex in July, 1971, has been released and arrived today in Pnompenh, the Cambodian military command reported. Mr. Boudelet, 20 years old, had set out to photograph the temples, carrying a press card issued by the Cambodian Government.

title: Israel Gives Lansky a Stayl
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 29 (AP)Meyer Lansky, the United States underworld figure who lost a legal battle for Israeli citizenship, has been given two weeks more to leave Israel be1fore being expelled, a Government spokesman said today,. Lansky appealed to the Interior Ministry for more time to arrange an entry visa to a country other than the United States, where he is under indictment by two grand juries on gambling charges.

title: Feminist Service Puts Eve in New Light
description: Serving each other a communion of bread and apple juice, feminists held a religious service yesterday to liberate the apple from the curse of the fall and to confess guilt in falling for a traditional male interpretation of the Eve and Adam story.

title: Pravda Dismisses the Idea Thieu Could Block Peace
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 29 (Reuters) Pravda today dismissed the idea that South Vietnam's president, Nguyen Van Thieu, could block a Vietnam peace settlement and appealed to Washington not to let the chance of ending the war slip by.

title: MachineTool Orders Up
description: The nation's machine tool industry chalked up a 1972 high for new orders in September, according to statistics released over the weekend by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

title: 4 Kill Texas Airline Aide And Hijack a Jet to Cuba
description: Four hijackers armed with pistols and a shotgun killed an Eastern Airlines gate agent and wounded another employe at Houston Intercontinental Airport early yesterday before diverting a jet and its 29 passengers to Cuba.

title: Winnipeg Beats Edmonton
description: WINNIPEG, Oct. 29 (AP)Don Jonas passed for four touchdowns and added 8 points by kicking today as the Winnipeg Blue Bombers beat the Edmonton Eskimos, 3824, in a Canadian Football League game.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 29Golfers who play private or public courses in the United States will be surprised learn that daily green fees in Japan are as high as $40, says Robert Trent Jones of Montclair, the noted golfcourse architect.

title: Major Candidates Agree On United Canada as Goal
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 29Canada's national election tomorrow is an occasion for pulling together a diverse population that lives in what sometimes seem like isolated countries scattered across a huge land.

title: Saigon to Get Longbinh Base
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 29 (UPI)Longbinh, the 15,000acre United States Army camp that once was the largest American military installation outside the continental United States, will be turned over to the Vietnamese Government by Dec. 1, military spokesmen announced today.

title: Stage: Debut in Queens
description: The more diverse the theater we have in New York, the better. Not all theatergoers live in Manhattan, and throughout the five boroughs indigenous theatrical activity could advantageously grow. If Staten Island had a theater as goodor, give or take a bit, almost as goodas Joseph Papp's Shakespeare Festival Theater, most Staten Island residents in their sanity would take their theatrical pleasures on their home grounds.

title: Missouri's 2d Effort Is Upsetting
description: If at first you don't succeed, try another field goal. Missouri's Greg Hill did so Saturday, scoring on his second fieldgoal attempt in the final 98 seconds for a 2017 Big Eight upset over Colorado and the Tigers second successive surprise triumph.

title: People of a jersey Town Full of Oil Accept Blast Danger as a Way of Life
description: CARTERET, N. J., Oct. 29One can hardly round a corner of this industrial town 10 miles southwest of Manhattan withcut seeing a tank farm of petroleum or chemical ??? Consequently, It was no surprise to find many of the residents of this workingclass community on the Arthur Kill, just west of Staten Wand, expressing some apprehension for their safety shortly after the series of explosions and fires last week.

title: Land Achieves His Dream With New Polaroid SX70
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29 It has been nearly three decades since Edwin H. Land, the physicist who reigns over the Polaroid empire, first dreamed of producing a totally automatic camera that would instantly print vivid color pictures.

title: Miss Simons Wed in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Miss Marjorie Simons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Simons of Louisville, Ky., was married here this afternoon to Alexander Philip Federbush, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max W. Federbush of New York and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: JETS 4GOAL RALLY DEFEATS AEROS, 53
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba( Oct. 29 (UPI)The Winnipeg Jets rallied for four consectitivee goals in the third period tonight to defeat the Houston Aeros, 53, in a World Hockey Association game. The, triumph, Winnipeg's fourth in a row, moved the Jets into first place in the Western Division.

title: Drama and ComedyVariety to Join Cavett and Paar
description: The American Broadcasting Company has completed its package of rotating programs to replace the nightly Dick Cavett Show after the first of the year, and it will present the series under the umbrella title, A.B.C. Wide World of Entertainment.

title: LAKERS CONQUER SUNS, 133 TO 123
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct, 29 (AP) Gail Goodrich pumped in 32 points and the Los Angeles Lakers went on a 2914 spree at the end of the third period to emerge with a 133123 National Basketball Association victory over the Phoenix Suns tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The undersigned, all economists, wish to express our full agreement with The Times editorial support for the Presidential candidacy of George McGovern.

title: RUMSFELD DISPUTES GRAYSON PRICE VIEW
description: Donald Rumsfeld, counselor to President Nixon and director of the Cost of Living Council, repudiated yesterday a weekend statement by C. Jackson Grayson Jr., the chairman of the Price Commission, that wage and price controls should not be extended beyond their scheduled expiration next April.

title: Miranda's Father Killed
description: MESA, Ariz., Oct. 30 (UPI)The father of Ernesto A. Miranda, whose rape conviction was overturned in a United States Supreme Court decision that resulted in rules on the use of confessions, was killed last night in a traffic accident, sheriff's deputies said. Manuel Abril Miranda, 64 years old, of Mesa, died when the car he was driving ran a stop sign southeast of here and was hit by a truck, said Deputy Alan Weiss.

title: Critics Accuse A.B.C. of Suppressing Safety Test Data on Nuclear Plants
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The Union of Concerned Scientists has renewed its attack on tests done for the Atomic Energy Commission, which underly the safety of nuclear electric power plants.

title: U.S. Buys Record Amount Of Gold From Soviet Union
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (Reuters)The United States bought a record total of 245,000 ounces of gold from the Soviet Union during the first nine months of this year, Treasury sources said today.

title: China Open to Parley Role
description: PEKING, Oct. 30 (AP)China advised Britain today that she was ready to consider taking part in an international peace conference on Vietnam but could decide only when full details were known.

title: Metropolitan P.G.A. Picks Borek as Pro of the Year
description: CEDARHURST, L. I., Oct. 30Gene Borek of the Pine Hollow Country Club, East Norwich, L. I., was named Pro of the Year by the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association at its annual meeting today at the Rockaway Hunt Club.

title: INDIANS TO BEGIN CAPITAL PROTESTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 Groups of American Indians will be in the nation's capital this week in an effort to gain through peaceful demonstrations the economic and social benefits that they believe are due them as first citizens of the land.

title: Britain Proposes New Ulster Rale
description: LONDON, Oct. 30Britain offered proposals today for a sweeping overhaul of the Northern Ireland government that would broaden the powers of the Roman Catholic minority.

title: Actors Equity Lends Voice To Times Sq. Cleanup Drive
description: Actors Equity Association has joined the drive to improve the Times Square area by voicing opposition to massage parlors and other undesirable elements in the theatrical district.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP)President Nixon's campaignfinance apparatus asked Chief Justice Warren E. Burger today to put off trial of suit to force disclosure of campaign contributions made before Federal regulations were tightened this spring.

title: The State Senate
description: We make the following endorsements among candidates, for the New York State Senate from the metropolitan area. Incumbents are designated by an asterisk:

title: Poll Shows Nixon Tops 68 Among 2 Groups Here
description: President Nixon has been found in a survey to be receiving twice as much support of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut Catholics and Jews as he did in the 1968 election returns.

title: Decision Reserved On I.B.M. Motion In Antitrust Suit
description: Chief Judge Davis N. Edelstein reserved decision yesterday on a motion by the International Business Machines Corporation for an immediate trial on the question of definition of the computer market and separation of this issue from the overall antitrust action brought by the Justice Department.

title: Fans Organization Protesting Renovation of Yankee Stadium
description: A group of seasonticket holdels in various sports, led by the president of the New York Giants fan club, has called on Governor Rockefeller to stop the Yankee Stadium project approved by the city. The group also advocates the creation of a bistate sports authority to be appointed by the governors of New York and New Jersey.

title: M'GOVERN ASSAILS NIXON AS ELUSIVE
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30Senator George McGovern charged here tonight that for the first time in the history of this country, we have had a Presidential campaign with only one candidate.

title: Lindsay Exempts Queens Judges From Criticism
description: Mayor Lindsay, who last month accused the State Supreme Court of being instinctively unproductive, has exempted the judges of Queens county from that accusation.

title: TRUDEAU LOSES MAJORITY AS TORIES SCORE BIG GAINS IN CANADIAN VOTING UPSET
description: OTTAWA, Tuesday, Oct. 31 Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau lost his majority in Parliament and possibly control of the Liberal government in the general election last night. Unofficial tabulations indicated that the Liberals lost 38 of the 147 seats they held in the last Parliament, while the Opposition Progressive Conservative party gained 34. The unofficial returns gave the Liberals 109 seats in the next Parliament to 107 for the Conservatives. With third and fourth parties holding a balance of power, it remains unclear whether Prime Minister Trudeau can keep the Liberals in power.

title: City Takes Measures to Smooth Voting
description: Battered by criticism over the way it had administered the primary election here last June, the City Board of Elections is taking unusual steps to make sure that citizens will be able to vote without disruption on Election Day.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) In a paid political broadcast on radio tonight, Vice President Agnew criticized Senator George McGovern's statement that if elected he would reserve the right to renegotiate some portions of any Vietnam peace agreement.

title: Chase Manhattan and Citibank Seek to Open Offices in Soviet
description: The rapid expansion of trade between the United States and the Soviet Union may soon lead to the establishment of the first Soviet offices of American banks since 1922.

title: Sports of The Times
description: To some bemused adherents of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, the organization has most of the manly attributes of the Boy Scouts. The N.C.A.A. is trustworthy, loyal, helpful, friendly, courteous, kind, obedient, cheerful, thrifty, brave, clean and reverent. Don't you believe it. It also is filthy rich from television loot and greedy for power.

title: MRS. CHARLES T. RICE
description: Mrs. Dorothy Donohue Rice, wife of Charles T. Rice, a lawyer and past president general of the Irish American Historical Society, died Saturday at their home, 210 East 68th Street. She was 67 years old and a daughter of the late Representative Michael Donohue of Philadelphia.

title: 5 ARE KILLED IN BLAST IN MINNESOTA STORE
description: LAKE CITY, Minn., Oct. 30 (AP)Five persons were killed and several were believed missing in a pile of rubble today after an explosion rocked variety store in this small Southeastern Minnesota community.

title: Dembitz, Democrat, Backed By G.O.P. Women's Group
description: A Republican women's organization announced yesterday its support of a Democrat for the first timeJudge Nanette Dembitz, who is running for the New York Court of Appeals.

title: FrenchLed Group Wins Greek Contract
description: ATHENS, Oct. 30A Frenchled international consortium has beaten California's giant Automation Industries in a contract for a multimilliondollar aircraftrepair and maintenance plant in Greece.

title: Auto Strike Vote Set in Ohio
description: LORDSTOWN, Ohio, Oct. 30 (AP)Members of Local 1112, United Auto Workers, have authorized a strike vote for next Sunday at the General Motors Vega and Chevrolet plant here, a union spokesman said today. The spokesman, noting that balloting to authorize a strike vote was taken last week, said the results was 69 per cent in favor of the authorization.

title: 44 Die, 320 Hurt as Chicago Commuter Trains Crash
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 30At least 44 persons were killed and more than 320 injured this morning in the nation's worst railroad accident in 14 years when one Illinois Central commuter train was crushed from behind by another.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The success of President Nixon's first Administration is the result of his brilliant and daring decision to dump Dick Nixon.

title: A Pediatrician at Stanford Says the Diet Given Infant Helps Shape the Adult
description: STANFORD, Calif., Oct. 30How a mother feeds her infant during the first year of his life may be crucial in determining how healthy an adult he will be when he grows up, a pediatrics expert said last week.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES SET NEW HIGHS
description: Soybean futures set new lifeofcontract highs for every month yesterday as prices rose sharply in active trading on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: 27 Are Killed in Crash Of Plane in Italy's South
description: BARI, Italy, Oct. 30 (Reuters)  Twentyfour passengers and three crew members were killed when an airliner crashed near Bari in southern Italy tonight, the police said.

title: People and Business
description: Muriel F. Siebert, who in 16 years rose from a $65aweek research trainee to become the first woman member of the New York Stock Exchange, is selling her seat and buying another.

title: Metropolitan P.G.A. Picks Borek as Pro of the Year
description: CEDARHURST, L. I., Oct. 30Gene Borek of the Pine Hollow Country Club, East Norwich, L. I., was named Pro of the Year by the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association at its annual meeting today at the Rockaway Hunt Club.

title: Books of The Times
description: I read William Trevor's The Ballroom of Romance after having just reviewed books of short stories by John Updike and Donald Barthelme, and this made me feel the traditional nature of Mr. Trevor's work more strongly than I might ordinarily have. Though I thought that only Mr. Updike had succeeded in his latest collection, both he and Mr. Barthelme had the effect of making today's volume of stories seem terribly oldfashioned, even anachronistic. They remind me of a very wellmade suit of clothes, painstakingly sewn together of the sort of fabric that seems to endure forever, but awkwardly out of style. The sort of suit a woman wonders what to do with after her husband has died. Surely someone can still use it.

title: U.S. Samoa, Scene of Rain Basks in Economic Sun
description: PAGOPAGO, American SamoaTill recently, if Sadie Thompson had returned here, she would have readily recognized Pagopago as the seedy, watersoaked setting of Rain, the 1922 play based on the Somerset Maugham story of a tempestuous woman who upset the staid society of American Samoa more than half a century ago.

title: Mayor Urges Caution For TrickorTreat Day
description: Mayor Lindsay urged parents and children yesterday to take a number of safety measures to insure that the youngsters Halloween trickortreating today will result in fun and not tragedy.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30Senator George McGovern's Task Force on Latin America has charged in a special report that under the Nixon Administration a friendly region is being converted to an adversary, leading to the unhappy and even dangerous situation of a powerful United States losing friends at its own borders.

title: Environmental Bond Issue Opposed by Conservatives
description: The Conservative party yesterday urged voters to reject the proposed $1.15billion New York State environmental bond issue, contending that the recommended outlays are too imprecise and amount to blank check for state expenditure of taxpayers money.

title: COWBOYS VICTORS OVER LIONS, 2824
description: Continued From Page 57 with 81 yards in 20 carries. Landry led Detroit's ground game with 46 yards on nine rushes.

title: DELAY PENALTIES URGED BY TREVINO
description: Lee Trevino believes there is too much slow play on the pro golf tour. One reason for his sudden and unexpected withdrawal midway through the third round of the $135,000 Sahara tournament at Las Vegas, Nev., last Saturday was because of the slow pace, he explained yesterday.

title: Safety Precautions Defended
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 30 (AP)Airline and city officials defended Houston Intercontinental Airport security precautions today.

title: Ford Fund, in a Shift, Awards Grants to More Black Colleges
description: The Ford Foundation, modifying a yearold policy under which its program of aid to traditionally black private colleges was to be narrowly focused on 10 institutions, yesterday named 25 such colleges as recipients of grants totaling about $50 million over the next five years.

title: Merger News
description: The Rockwell Manufacturing Company announced after the close of the stock market yesterday that it had received an offer from the North American Rockwell Corporation to merge Rockwell Manufacturing into North American Rockwell.

title: Sports. News Briefs
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, Oct. 30 (AP)Jeff Borowiak of Berkeley, Calif., upset secondseeded Arthur Ashe of New York, 61, 36, 76, tonight in the first round of the World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Nothing that happened on Seventh Avenue yesterday, as the spring fashion openings keep chugging along, was likely to make truck drivers snicker or husbands sneer. Designers are still doing penance for the excesses of the last few years. They're crying classics and proving it by sticking with cardigans, caftans (tents are often called caftans) and shirtdresses.

title: PEKING SUPPORTS HANOI ON SIGNING
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 30China today supported North Vietnam's demand that the United States sign the ceasefire agreement worked out in Paris and strongly condemned President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam.

title: Philip Hubert Frohman Dies; Designed National Cathedral
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30Philip Hubert Frohman, architect of Washington Cathedral, died today in Sibley Memorial Hospital, after having been struck by an auto on Aug. 7 near the cathedral. His age was 84.

title: 30 Minutes of Shelling
description: BEIRUT Lebanon, Oct. 30A Syrian military spokesman said today that Syrian artillery had shelled the Israelioccupied Golan heights for 30 minutes after Israeli jets had raided near Damascus.

title: 21 Are Killed and 70 Hurt In East German Train Crash
description: BERLIN, Oct. 30  Two express trains collided in heavy fog this morning near KarlMarxStadt in southern East Germany, killing 21 persons. About 70 other passengers were injured, some critically, the East German press agency, A.D.N., said.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 30 (UPI)The American Telephone & Telegraph Company requested approval today establish digital data links among five cities in order minimize noise and distortion in voice and data transmissions.

title: Davits Rated 100% by Consumer Unit
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits voted 100 per cent right on key consumer, bills in the 1972 Congress while Senator James L. Buckley voted virtually 100 per cent wrong, according to ratings released by the Consumer Federation of America.

title: CHLOE OWEN WRAPS LIEDER IN TALENTS
description: Seven Schumann Heeler, 10 by Hugo Wolf and Dvorak's 6 Ciganske Melodie made up Chloe Owen's Town Hall pro gram Sunday afternoon, and while greater stylistic variety would not have been unappreciated, the soprano's uncommon artistry and unfailing taste gave the recital a special glow.

title: NEW UNIT TO SCAN MARKET MAKERS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30A joint task force of Government and securities industry officials was created today to monitor more closely the activities of brokers who spectalize in making markets in lowpriced, speculative securities.

title: Heath Fails to Break Deadlock In Talks on Pay and Price Curb
description: LONDON, Oct. 30Prime Minister Heath, struggling to curb inflation and restore confidence in the pound, failed tonight to win agreement from labor and industry for a voluntary program of restraint on wages and prices.

title: WILLIAM PLUNKERT, AIDED ALCOHOLICS
description: William J. Plunkert, a social worker who founded the Alcoholism Recovery Institute, the New York City affiliate of the National Council on Alcoholism, after having discovered in 1955 that he suffered from the disease, died of cancer on Saturday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 601 East 20th Street.

title: Advertising:
description: The Polaroid Corporation, which last week unveiled its new SX70 camera in Florida, yesterday outlined its advertising and marketing plans for a New York audience.

title: Sewer Pipe of Recycled Glass Is Installed in System on L.I.
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Oct. 30  The first sewer pipe made of recycled, crushed glass was installed in the Town of Huntington's sewer system today.

title: Man Surrenders to Police In Killing in Spring Valley
description: SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Oct. 30 (AP)Andrew Grisby, 31 years old, walked into the police station here today and surrendered in the fatal shooting of another Spring Valley man last Friday, the police reported.

title: Sea Attacks Reported Halted
description: SAIGON, Tuesday, Oct. 31 (AP)  United States naval bombardment of the North Vietnamese coast north of the 20th parallel has been halted in a further move to improve the climate for ceasefire negotiations, informed sources said yesterday.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company received a $47.8million addition to a previously awarded Air Force contract for Maverick airtoground guided missiles, it was announced yesterday.

title: Students Roll to Record
description: NORTH WINDHAM, Me., Oct.1 30 (UPI)After three days and 230 miles, thirty students at St. Joseph's College have claimed the world's beer barrel rolling record. In a stunt to benefit the Greater Portland United Fund, six teams of five students rolled the barrel from Portland to Merrimack, N.H., and back to Portland again.

title: U.S.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 30 (AP)  The United States cOMmand announced today that American troop strength in Vietnam dropped by 300 men last week, to 33,700. All those Withdrawn were from the Army. The present target is 27,000 by Dec. 1.

title: News Analysis
description: PARIS, Oct. 30After a few frantic days, it is now clear that there will be no Vietnam peace ceremony here tomorrowand perhaps none before the United States election a week from tomorrow.

title: Sailor Dies in Fire
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 30 (Reuters)A tire in the forward cargo hold of the Navy submarine rescue ship Florikan this morning killed one seaman and injured another. A Navy spokesman said the cause of the fire had not yet been determined.

title: An AntiU.S. Play Is a Hit in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 30With peace in Vietnam seemingly within grasp, there is an element of anachronism in Moscow's latest stage hit, Under the Skin of the Statue of Liberty, which portrays United States war protesters pitted against helmeted police. Full houses are viewing it, at the avantgarde Taganka Theater.

title: Irving Meeting Put Off By Repertory Theater
description: The meeting of the board of the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center to discuss the resignation of Jules Irving, artistic director of the Repertory Theater, was postponed yesterday to later this week. The day has not been determined.

title: 34 Hurt as Bus Overturns
description: JOHNSTON, Pa., Oct. 30 (UPI) A school bus carrying a junior varsity high school football team overturned today about eight miles south of this western Pennsylvania community. Thirtyfive persons were injured, at least one critically. The police said the bus was carrying members and coaches of the junior varsity football team, of Ligonier Valley High School to a makeup game against Conemaugh Township in Davidsville.

title: E.E.C. Agrees on Inflation
description: LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 30 (UPI) The Common Market countries agreed tonight to fight inflation with monetary and budgetary policies aimed at keeping price rises down to 4 per cent a year.

title: About Pro Hockey
description: Toin Miller, jabbed in the spleen by Phil Esposito, was in Massachusetts General Hospital yesterday and will pot: know until tomorrow Whether he will undergo surgerY, Miller, a center for the New York Islanders, suffered the Injury in the first period against the Bruins in Boston Sunday night.

title: Scientist Fears Equable Climate Around World Could Be Ending
description: The current 12,000yearold era of comfortable climates around the world may he coming to an end, closing another chapter in what a University of Miami scientist believes has been a history of frequent and relatively shortlived ice ages and warm ages.

title: Survey of Farmers Finds Nixon Ahead by 48 Points
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI)A poll of Middle Western farmers shows President Nixon with a 48.4point lead over Senator George McGovern, the Doane Agricultural Service said today.

title: Big 4 Meet Again in Berlin
description: BERLIN, Oct. 30 (UPI)Representatives of the Big Four met for two hours today in their fourth session here in week to discuss the rights of the World War II Allies in Germany after the two German states join the United Nations.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: The German captain of Liberian tanker testified yesterday that he had given the order to abandon ship at a spectacular fire in Carteret, N.J., last week and that all had left the vessel except himself.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, Oct. 30 (UPI)Japanese Government officials will begin negotiating with industrial leaders here this week to put into effect measures designed to reduce Japan's trade surplus by at least $1billion a year.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Inevitably at this time of year in northern New England and other areas with substantial numbers of ruffed grouse, country editors will get phone calls from householders who have had a sudden and catastrophic visit from one of these birds.

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS BILL THAT WIDENS SOCIAL SECURITY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 President Nixon signed a $5billion Social Security bill today, along with 59 other measures, but vetoed two bills that would have aided the elderly.

title: 4 National Union Chiefs Urge Blitz Campaign for McGovern
description: Leaders of four national unions yesterday urged a rally of labor volunteers for Senator George McGovern to carry out a sevenday blitz to get out the vote for the McGovernShriver ticket.

title: Undermining the Court
description: President Nixon made of the Supreme Court a major plank in his 1968 campaign platform. He played irresponsible political games with the Court then, and he has since persisted on that dangerous course. Instead of strengthening the people's faith in what Winston Churchill called the most esteemed judicial tribunal in the world, Mr. Nixon has repeatedly raised public doubts concerning its capacity to act as arbiter of such emotioncharged issues as school desegregation.

title: Yale Professor Predicts Computerized Reader
description: NEW HAVEN, Act. 30 (AP) In a halfdecade or so a device may be available that can scan printed material and translate it into spoken words, according to a Yale University researcher.

title: MRS. PAULINE PANZER
description: Mrs. Pauline Richman Panzer, a writer and the wife of Martin Panzer, assistant to the field director of the Israel Bond Organization, died Sunday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 61 years old and lived at 501 East 79th Street.

title: Miss Prentice Wins On 10th Extra Hole With a Birdie Putt
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Oct. 30 (UPI)JoAnn Prentice sank a birdie putt on the 10th extra hole today to capture the Civitan open golf tournament. It was the longest suddendeath playoff in the history of the, women's tour.

title: News Analysis
description: It was in another part of Brooklyn and in another decade, but the angry shouts now being heard in Canarsie are similar to those that rang through the air in Ocean HillBrownsville five years ago.

title: SOVIET SCRATCHES ENTRY AT LAUREL
description: LAUREL, Md., Oct. 30 (AP)The Soviet Union, denied a request to run a second horse in the $150,000 Washington, D.C., International, has withdrawn the 3yearold colt Herold from the Nov. 11 race.

title: Sports. News Briefs
description: With prize money in men's singles raised from $35,000 to $75,000 and the addition of a women's singles tournament, the third annual Clean Air Tennis Classic will held from Dec. 4 to Dec. 10 at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 66th Street.

title: El Paso Natural Gas Raised Net Income For Third Quarter!
description: The El Paso Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday thirdquarter operating revenues of $267.7million, up from $251.4million a year earlier. Net income rose to $17.3million, or 55 cents a share, from $14.4million, or 48 cents a share, on fewer shares, in the three months ended Sept. 30, 1971.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 30 (UP1) Hialeah race track appealed to the Florida Supreme Court today for the choice Jan. 17March 3 racing dates that state authorities awarded to Gulfstream for the second straight year. The Board of Business Regulation ordered Hialeah to race March 5April 19 next year, after many of the big bettors have left the state. The court promised an early decision.

title: SUIT IS FILED HERE AGAINST LENS MAKER
description: The National Patent Develop ment Corporation, owner of exclusive patent rights for manufacturing and marketing of soft plastic contact lenses, has filed suit against Bausch & Lomb, Inc., for an accounting of profits.

title: City U. and Union Are Still in Deadlock
description: The mediation attempt to break a deadlock in contract negotiations between the City University and its faculty and staff union ended yesterday without an agreement. The dispute will now be taken to a nonbinding factfinding panel of the State Public Employe Relations Board.

title: An Accountant Will Direct Community Service Drive
description: Samuel J. Duboff, a partner in the accounting firm of S. D. Leidesdorf & Co., has been named chairman of the 197273 fundraising campaign of the Community Service Society of New York.

title: Guyana, Building Cooperative Socialism, Wants Foreign Capital
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Oct. 22At age six, this nation of 800,000 people frustrates outsiders who would try to define it.

title: Reactions in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 30Reaction to the British Government document has been guarded but generally favorable.

title: Hijacking Followed Warning by F. A. A.
description: The Government warned the airlines last Friday of a possible hijacking attempt by the fatherson team that is accused of participating in the hijacking of an Eastern Airlines jet to Cuba.

title: Pioneer Sots Name Change
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) Pioneer Airlines has changed the company's name to Pioneer Industries, Inc., in accordance with a majority vote of stockholders, president A. L. Wheeler said today.

title: U.S. Aides Investigating Housing Deal in Detroit
description: DETROIT, Oct. 30 (UPI) Federal officials are investigating a nonprofit agency and a building contractor who allegedly parlayed the purchase of 174 homes repossessed by the Government into a $2.5million profit.

title: To a Visiting Mayor, City Streets Are Clean
description: The Mayor of Jersey City, Paul T. Jordan, carne to New York City yesterday to meet with Mayor Lindsay in City Hall and present an unusual request: guidance in setting up a program for better street cleaning.

title: FRANK A. BADOLATO
description: SAYVILLE, L. Oct. 30Frank A. Badolato, a retired realtor long active in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn and former owner of the Hamilton House restaurant on Sheepshead Bay, died yesterday in a Central Islip hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 44 Colton Avenue.

title: Communists Seize Camp in Highlands
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Oct. 31  A South Vietnamese border camp in the Central Highlands was lost Sunday night to a heavy Communist shelling and infantry attack, the Saigon command said yesterday.

title: Driver Repeats Mistake
description: SAN MATEO, Calif. (AP) A 29yearold San Mateo man went to court recently on charge of driving with a revoked license. And he got there by drivingwith a revoked license. The police said he would now be tried on two charges, rather than one.

title: Movies for Kids Series to Play At Tully and Two Other Halls
description: A series of feature films for children that sold out one hall repeatedly last season will be seen in three halls this fall. It is Movies for Kids, the junior division of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, which also sponsors the annual New York Film Festival.

title: PARENTS BOYCOTT SHUTS 6 SCHOOLS IN CANARSIE AREA
description: A communitywide parents' boycott kept more than 9,000 Canarsie pupils out of classes and forced six schools to close yesterday as 29 black and Puerto Rican children from Brownsville, guarded by 200 riotequipped policemen, again attended John Wilson Junior High School 211 in Brooklyn.

title: Firemen Save 2 Children From 2d Fire in Month
description: Two small children were pulled unconscious from fireswept room at the Concourse Plaza Hotel in the Bronx last night in what the Fire Department said was the second fire undergone by the family in a month.

title: District 18's School Board Appears Divided on Racial issues
description: On Monday night last week, Charles Fazio, a former police detective with 23 years on the force and now a member of the District 18 Community School Board, brought cheers from the tumultuous audience of white Canarsie parents when he declared that the central Board of Education has been the most destructive single force in New York City.

title: Cowboys Triumph Over Lions, 2824
description: IRVING, Tex., Oct. 30 (AP)The Super Bowl champion Dallas Cowboys, struggling to stay alive in the race to the 1972 National Football League playoffs, rode the passing arm of their quarterback, Craig Morton, to a 28.24 victory over the Detroit Lions tonight.

title: Personalities: Barry's Perfect
description: Rick Barry of the Golden State Warriors has yet to miss a foul shot in the first three, weeks of the National Basketball Association season. Barry has hit on all 30 attempts. Pro basketball's only underhand foul shooter explains his accuracy as a kind of a lost art of foul shooting. It's just practice in a certain fieldpractice feel and concentration. Wilt Chamberlain of the Los Angeles Lakers, who used to shoot fouls underhand and was not very good at it, has a 79.7 fieldgoal percentage In his first 10 games. Barry and Chamberlain missed training camp, which might indicate that no practice makes perfect. The regularseason record of 55 fouls in a row was set by Bill Sharman in 195657.

title: Saigon Sets 2 Requirements for Accord
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct., 30Foreign Minister Tran Van Lam of South Vietnam emphasized again today that North Vietnam must agree to withdraw all of its troops from the South and recognize the demilitarized zone before his country will sign a peace accord.

title: WATERGATE SUSPECT LOSES FLORIDA PLEA
description: MIAMI, Oct. 30 (UPI)A criminal court judge refused today to dismiss state notary fraud charges against Bernard L. Barker, one of the five persons accused of political spying on Democratic party national headquarters in the Watergate complex in Washington last June.

title: Advertising:
description: The ad agency in charge of the directmail fundraising effort for Senator George McGovern says it will raise a record of $15million before the campaign ends.

title: Palornares Lives With Memory of HBomb
description: PALOMARES, Spain, Oct. 25 The tomato crop here is doing well this year and as tomatoes go so goes Palomares. Almost seven years after this obscure and unkempt Andalusian town became unwillingly famous when four American hydrogen bombs were dropped on or around it, almost everyone agrees that everything is normalmore or less.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The attention of voters this coming election will understandably be, focused on the Presidential contest. However, also of exceptional importance will be the selection of three associate judges of the Court of Appeals.

title: Mineral Sales Up 27%
description: The St. Joe Minerals Corporation reported yesterday that its thirdquarter net income, rose to $4.8million, or 57 cents a share, from $3.8million, or 45 cents, in the three months ended Sept. 30, 1971.

title: U.S. EXPECTS HANOI TO DROP DEADLINE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30Administration officials said today that they remained confident that North Vietnam would not allow the passing of its deadline tomorrow for the signing of the Vietnam accord to set back the chances to reach a settlement within the next few weeks.

title: F. A. A. Cautioned Airlines About 2 In Cuba Hijacking
description: The Government warned the airlines last Friday of a possible hijacking attempt by the fatherson team that is accused of participating in the hijacking of an Eastern. Airlines jet to Cuba on Sunday.

title: Miss Edith G. Gibson Is Bride Of Michael Bacon in Suburbs
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 30Miss Edith Gay Gibson and Michael Bacon were married here yesterday afternoon in St, Mark's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Grant Morrill.

title: Welch to Take New Post
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 30  Mayor Louie Welch announced here today that he would not seek reelection when his term expires in January, 1974. Instead, he said, he will become president of the Houston Chamber of Commerce. Mr. Welch is president of the United States Conference of Mayors. This fall he endorsed President Nixon's reelection campaign.

title: LI. TEACHERS SEE A BREAK IN STRIKE
description: ROOSEVELT, L. I., Oct. 30A spokesman for the striking Roosevelt Teachers Association reported today that some progress had been made in the continuing negotiations with the Board of Education and that important new developments would be announced tomorrow.

title: TEEN'S PARTY LOSES MAJORITY IN CLOSE VOTING
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 30An upsurge in Conservative strength in Englishspeaking central and western Canada threw the Canadian federal election tonight into a finish too close to permit any party a clear majority in the next Parliament.

title: Flat Tires Close School
description: PINE LAINTS, N.Y., Oct. 30 (AP)Classes for today were canceled in this northern Dutchess County community because vandals over the weekend let the air out of the rear tires on 10 of the school's buses, authorities said.

title: XRAYS CLEAR UP GIANTS INJURIES
description: The New York Giants found it hard to start looking ahead yesterday, still suffering from their disappointment at Sunday's 2316 loss to the Washington Redskins. But how they respond, in facing a Denver team they will be expected to beat, will provide a good measure of how much maturity they are developing, and how quickly.

title: New York Post Endorses McGovern and Scores Nixon
description: The New York Post gave its endorsement yesterday to Senator George McGovern, the Democratic Presidential candidate.

title: Synod of Bishops Suggests That It Meet Every 3 Years
description: ROME, Oct. 30The advisory council of the Roman Catholic Church's Synod of Bishops has recommended to the Pope that the synod meet every three years, rather than every two years, as it has been doing. The recommendation, announced here today, means that the next meeting will probably be in the fall of 1974.

title: Two U.S. Banks Seeking Offices in Soviet
description: The rapid expansion of trade between the United States and the Soviet Union may soon lead to the establishment of the first Soviet offices of American banks since 1922.

title: Sheldon Reynolds Weds Countess
description: Countess Andrea Milos of Paris was married here last evening to Sheldon Reynolds, a television and movie writer, director and producer. About 20 close friends attended the ceremony performed at the Four Seasons by State Supreme Court Justice Isidore Dollinger.

title: TWO PATROLMEN CLEARED IN BRIBE
description: Two suspended Queens patrolmen accused of having accepted a $200 bribe to release two burglary suspects nearly three years ago have been acquitted by a Queens State Supreme Court jury.

title: 2 PUERTO RICANS SEE HOPE IN G.O.P.
description: In past elections when Puerto Ricans ran for office on the Republican ticket they usually knew they had no chance to win. This year, two Puerto Ricans running for the Assembly with Republican designation and considered to stand a good chance of being elected.

title: Monticello Official on Trial On Tax Evasion Charges
description: Jerome Ehrlich, accused of a fraudulent tax scheme to have others cash his winning tickets at Monticello Raceway, where Ehrlich was a director and vice president, went on trial in Manhattan Federal Court yesterday.

title: President Marcos: Another Pacific Dictator
description: On Aug. 28 of this year, during a visit to the barrio in the Philippines where I had lived as a Peace Corps volunteer from 1961 to 1963, I wrote in my diary: Talk of revolution is all around usand perhaps even revolution itself. It is coming, and it will be bad, bloody, a lost cause. There will be a military dictator. Is there a large enough segment of the population to maintain a modicum of sanity? Last month President Marcos set the wheels of civil warfare irrevocably in motion by establishing his military dictatorship.

title: Practice for Emergency On Plane Is Well Timed
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 30 (AP) An airplane flight to practice emergencies ended in a real emergency.

title: MRS. MAX GILBERT
description: Mrs. Bertha Fausty Gilbert, former elementary schol teacher here, who had been an operator of Camp Winona, Lake Como, Pa., died yesterday in Pensacola, Fla. She was 82 years old and lived in Gulf Breeze, Fla.

title: Monticello Official on Trial On Tax Evasion Charges
description: Jerome Ehrlich, accused of a fraudulent tax scheme to have others cash his winning tickets at Monticello Raceway, where Ehrlich was a director and vice president, went on trial in Manhattan Federal Court yesterday.

title: Teacher Hurt, Another Robbed Outside Their Brooklyn School
description: A teacher in the East New York section of Brooklyn suffered a broken nose yesterday when he and a fellow teacher were set upon by a gang of teenagers outside Public School 213, the police reported.

title: All Major Units Gain
description: Tenneco Inc., a Houstonbased conglomerate, benefited frciiii higher operating revenues in oil ()Orations, machinery and automotiveparts production in the third quarter, giving the company record results in both that period and the nine months.

title: New Soviet Priorities
description: Repercussions from this year's unsatisfactory harvest are apparently beginning to be felt widely in the Soviet union. These repercussions stir fears of food shortage this winter, with consequent attempts to hoard potatoes and vegetables in some areas. They also give rise to insistent reports that the Soviet Government is changing its economic priorities for the year ahead. Soviet budget managers have reportedly allocated an additional $24 billion to the needs of agriculture, resources obtained by depriving other fields of Soviet activity.

title: Theater: Lincoln Mask at Plymouth
description: There have been many plays about Abraham Lincoln, and it seems that this season we are to have one or two more. The first contender in these stakes arrived at the Plymouth Theater last night. It is a play by V. J. Longhi, it is called The Lincoln Mask and it is most worthily inconsequential.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: PRINCETON, Oct. 30A coalition of 23 environmental and antinuclear power groups said here today that it planned mass protests in the next two months at Tocks Island on the Delaware River and at Long Beach Island to protest proposed construction of nuclear power plants in New Jersey.

title: Angela Davis Urges Change
description: BOSTON, Oct. 30 (AP)Angela Davis, the black activist; endorsed Edward S. Teixeira, Communist party candidate for State Representative, here today.

title: Two Held in a Death Threat Admit Passing Heroin
description: Two young men accused of threatening to kill a prospective Government witness in their narcotics case pleaded guilty yesterday to having distributed an ounce of heroin.

title: Neutralist Criticizes Accord
description: PARIS, Oct. 30A prominent South Vietnamese neutralist said today that the published version of the agreement to end the Vietnam conflict failed to provide sufficient guarantees of political democracy.

title: U.S. EXPECTS HANOI TO DROP DEADLINE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30Administration officials said today that they remained confident that North Vietnam would not allow the passing of its deadllne tomorrow for the signing of the Vietnam accord to set back the chances to reach a settlement within the next few weeks.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two Long Island public figures appeared briefly yesterday before a Brooklyn rackets grand jury that is considering information accumulated during six months of electronic surveillance of a reputed Mafia meeting place in the Canarsie section.

title: Notes on People
description: In an appeal for a reducCon of his twoandonehalfyear prison sentence, Clifford Irving, author of an ersatz autobiography of the billionaire Howard R. Hughes, said his rehabilitation activities included teaching fellow inmates a course in creative writing. Irving, sentenced for his role in the Hughesbook hoax, is serving his time at a minimum security prison at Allenwood, Pa.

title: BREWSTER TRIAL BEGINS IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The bribery trial of former Senator Daniel B. Brewster opened today in Federal district court with the selection of an allwoman, allblack jury.

title: Miss Prentice Wins On 10th Extra Hole With a Birdie Putt
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Oct. 30 (UPI)JoAnn Prentice sank a birdie putt on the 10th extra hole today to capture the Civitan open golf tournament. It was the longest suddendeath playoff in the history of the women's tour.

title: C.B.S. Agrees to Accept an Unusual Vote for Peace Program
description: A halfhour political telecast turned down by two networks was aired last night on the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

title: Brain Development Cited
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 (AP)Underfed or poorly nourished pregnant women risk having retarded children, says the head of a Columbia University research team studying brain development.

title: F.P.C. to Widen Requirements On Projects Environment Role
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The Federal Power Commission, responding to a court order in a New York State case, said today that it planned to require that its staff write an environmentalimpact statement for proposed naturalgas pipeline and hydroelectric projects.

title: 89th National Horse Show To Open Today at Garden
description: A blast of the horn, at 10 o'clock this morning, will echo through Madison Square Garden, and for the 89th year the National Horse Show will get under way. The show runs for eight days and evenings, closing on election night.

title: FREIGHT TRAIN FIRE DELAYS NEW HAVEN
description: Six New Haven Division commuter trains were delayed 20 to 93 minutes during the morning rush yesterday after fire broke out in a freight train near Westport, Conn.

title: Below Central Park: Drivers Obstacle Course
description: From the Battery to Central Park, the streets of Manhattan are proving a frustrating obstacle course for motorists.

title: Nixon Workers Partake Of the Convivial Life
description: Several hundred volunteer campaign workers for President Nixon threw a cocktail party for themselves last night at the exclusive Raffle's Club in the SherryNetherland Hotel, because, as one of them put it, We wanted to take a look at where the limousine liberals live and play.

title: Personalities: Barry's Perfect
description: Rick Barry of the Golden State Warriors has yet to miss a foul shot in the first three weeks of the National Basketball Association season. Barry has hit on all 30 attempts. Pro basketball's only underhand foul shooter explains his accuracy as a kind of a lost art of foul shooting. It's just practice in a certain fieldpractice feel and concentration. Wilt Chamberlain of the Los Angeles Lakers, who used to shoot fouls underhand and was not very good at it, has a 79.7 fieldgoal percentage in his first 10 games. Barry and Chamberlain missed training camp, which might indicate that no practice makes perfect. The regularseason record of 55 fouls in a row was set by Bill Sharman in 195657.

title: Amex Announces Election Of New Board of Governors
description: The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its membership had elected a new 20member board of governors to replace the former board. The names of the candidates for the new board had been disclosed previously and their election was not in doubt, since there were no opposition candidates.

title: Canarsie Blacks Join Battle Over Schools
description: The controversy over the admission of 32 black and Puerto Rican students to John Wilson Junior High School 211 is now affecting Canarsie, blacks directly. Many yesterday angrily stormed past boycotting white parents who were trying to, block the entrances to the district's schools.

title: Unfair Labor Practice Laid to Moving
description: The National Labor Relations Board yesterday charged the Metropolitan Museum of Art with unfair labor practices against its employes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Regardless of details for a temporary or quasipermanent accommodation in South Vietnam, the innate pluralism of that nation must be cons sidered. The fractionated nature of its diverse interest groups requires establishment of a complex, even burdensome system of governing if any imaginable peace is to be more than a farce. Unitary government simply will never work. Some format for federalism is requisite for anything approximating political equilibrium.

title: Hall Finds Communist Gain
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 30 (UPI)Gus Hall, the Communist party Presidential candidate, said yesterday that there had been an unbelievable response to Communism on college campuses he has visited. The students have not yet accepted Communism, but their questioning shows they are beginning to regard it as a thinkable alternative, Mr. Hall said.

title: Wallace Associate Cleared In Campaign Donation Case
description: SELMA, Ala., Oct. 30 (AP)Earl Goodwin, an industrialist, was cleared today of charges that he fraudulently used phony advertising invoice to get an income tax deduction on a $3,000 contribution to the late Gov. Lurleen Wallace's 1966 election campaign.

title: Sanders Funeral on Coast
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 30 (UPI)  Funeral services were held today for Rick Sanders, the Olympic wrestler who died Oct. 19 in an auto accident in Yugoslavia Sanders, 27yearold former Portland State University star, was honored Saturday night in a ceremony before the Portland StatePuget Sound football game here.

title: IN THE NATION
description: In a depressing example of the moral and legal insensitivity that pervades the Nixon Administration, Vice President Agnew said Sunday on the program Issues and Answers that whether a person steals Larry O'Brien's secret papers or steals the Pentagon Papers he should be punished. I didn't see any of these cries of moral indignation against the person accused of stealing the Pentagon Papers.

title: J. Edward Slavin, 76, Dies; Long New Haven's Sheriff
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 30 (UPI) J. Edward Slavin, longtime New Haven County sheriff, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Cranston, R.I., while preparing to attend a wedding. He was 76 years old.

title: Construction Set a Record in September
description: The construction industry set its second consecutive high in September, according to the monthly report yesterday of the F. W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company.

title: Britain Offers Ulster Plans With Wider Catholic Role
description: LONDON, Oct. 30Britain offered proposals today for a sweeping overhaul of the Northern Ireland government that would broaden the powers of the Roman Catholic minority.

title: Protest at M.I.T. on Soviet
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 30 (AP)About 100 persons dernonstrated today outside the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to protest imposition of head taxes on Jews who wish to leave the Soviet Union for Israel. Earlier, a letter and petition signed by 150 faculty members was presented to Dr. Mstislav V. Keldysh, president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, in the office of president, Dr. Jerome B. Weisner.

title: Daniel Berrigan Is Denied A Visit to North Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) The Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan, the antiwar priest, was denied permission by the United States Parole Board today to go to North Vietnam.

title: JOHN B. RIX
description: PORT JERVIS, N. Y., act. 30John B. Rix, a director and secretary of Kolmar Laboratories, Inc., cosmetics manufacturers, died yesterday in St. Francis Hospital. He was 58 years old.

title: Price Changes
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's secondlargest steel producer, said yesterday that it was advising customers it would not increase current prices for any sheet products until at least April 1, 1973.

title: Port Notes
description: Action on creating a single nationwide union of dock workers, with a combined membership of more than 100,000, was forecast yesterday by Thomas W. Gleason, president of the International Longshoremen's Association.

title: Market Place; No One Even Said, I'm Sorry
description: The investment climate changes from hot to cold very rapidly these daystoo rapidly for some small investors, it seems.

title: TEACHERS AT 211 IGNORING BOYCOTT
description: The feeling I had this morning was a grown man wanting to cry, said one of the teachers at Junior High School 211 in Canarsie.

title: 3 Injured and 300 Detained On Chile's 13th Curfew Night
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 30 (Reuters)  Three men were seriously wounded by military patrols and 300 people detained for a time during the Chilean capital's 13th night of curfew last night, the police said today.

title: Nassau Approves Purchase Of County's 10 Bus Lines
description: MINEOLA. L. I., Oct. 30The Nassau County Board of Supervisors voted along party lines today to acquire ownership of the county's 10 financially distressed bus lines.

title: Service for Eleanor Glueck
description: A memorial service will be held at 4:30 P.M. tomorrow in Memorial Church, Harvard Yard, Cambridge, Mass., for Eleanor Touroff Glueck, who died Sept. 25. She was a research associate at Harvard Law School, where her husband, Sheldon Glueck, is Roscoe Pound Professor Emeritus.

title: Warning by Hanoi
description: Tuesday Oct. 31 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Nguyen Duy Trinh of North Vietnam warned last night that if the United States continued to delay signing the draft accord to end the war, it would never reach an agtieernent.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: The Mayor of Jersey City, Paul T. Jordan, came to New York City yesterday to meet with Mayor Lindsay in City Hall and present an unusual request guidance in setting up a program for better street cleaning.

title: Soviet Crop Woes to Aid U.S. Farmer
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.These are ordinarily the days of growing silence on the nation's wheat farms. The graip sown last spring has been harvested and the winter wheat is planted.

title: Stars Turn Back Colonels With Late Rally. 117106
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 30 (AP)Ron Boone came off the bench to spark a fourthquarter rally as the Utah Stars defeated the Kentucky Colonels, 117106, in an American Basketball Association game tonight.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J. Oct. 30Al Forman remembers how he became an umpire: It was the spring of 53 and the Korean War was winding down. I was a recreation specialist at the. Oceana Naval Bak in Virginia Beach. The umpires didn't show up and the lieutenant commander came into the room and asked for a volunteer. Since I was the only guy in the room, I became the volunteer, The lieutenant commander even gave me $5 and the next day off,

title: Stars Turn Back Colonels With Late Rally, 117106
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 30 (AP)Ron Boone came off the bench to spark a fourthquarter rally as the Utah Stars defeated the Kentucky Colonels, 117106, in an American Basketball Association game tonight.

title: SYRIANS HIT TWICE BY ISRAELI PLANES
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 30Israeli planes raided Syria twice today, striking at commando bases near Damascus in the morning and returning later to attack a Syrian Army camp. In between, Syrian forces shelled the Israeliheld Golan heights.

title: Lockheed and Boeing Sell Japan Jets
description: The Boeing Company sold the first models of a new, shortrange, 498passenger version of its 747 jumbo jet, and the Locks heed Aircraft Company made a major breakthrough in efforts to sell its oncetroubled L1011 trijet yesterday  both involving Japan.

title: Credit Markets
description: Bond prices edged lower on a broad front yesterday, apparently reflecting a general letdown now that an end to the Vietnam fighting appears at hand.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 Sargent Shriver, believing that fear if not affection might rebuild the Democratic majority, has warned that racial segregation could be made legal again and that the American commitment to Israel might be compromised in a second Nixon. Administration.

title: SOVIET SCRATCHES ENTRY AT LAUREL
description: LAUREL, Md., Oct. 30 (AP)The Soviet Union, denied a request to run a second horse in the $150,000 Washington, D.C., International, has withdrawn the 3yearold colt Herold from the Nov. 11 race.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30President Nixon, in a special campaign appeal to elderly voters, reaffirmed today his pledge to ask Congress next year for property tax relief for older Americans.

title: Nixon Signs $5Billion Bill Expanding Social Security
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30President Nixon signed a $5billion Social Security bill today, along with 59 other measures, but vetoed two bills that would have aided the elderly.

title: Senate Contest
description: BOISE, Idaho, Oct. 28 Big Eastern money has always been a hated phrase west of the Great Divide. Now itand, of all things, potatoes have become an issue in what is shaping up as a tight Senate race in Idaho, where a Nixon landslide is taken as a certainty.

title: Shift in Golf Tourney Site
description: LIGONIER, Pa., Oct. 30 (UPI)  The National Professional Golfers Association team championship will not be held at the Laurel Valley Golf Club next year, sponsors of the tournament said today. A spokesman explained that satisfactory television coverage could not be arranged because the national Open was to be held at Oakmont next June.

title: Sports. News Briefs
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Oct. 30 (UPI)Peter Thomson shot a 4underpar 68 to beat David Graham by six strokes in the 18hole playoff today for his third Australian Open golf championship. The two Australians were tied at 281 after the final round yesterday.

title: Bias in the News
description: Suddenly there is a rash of news about news, fierce debate over the campaign coverage, dueling between President and press, questions about the objectivity and credibility of the media, all sorts of news about news, newsmakers and newsgatherers.

title: N.Y. Court Is Awarded Lean Suit Jurisdiction
description: The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that a New York Federal Court has jurisdiction in a $22million suit brought by a United States company against a British corporation.

title: Business Briefs
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 30 (Reuters)Theunis de Jongh, governor of the South African Reserve bank, said today that the bank was abolishing the existing ceilings on bank credit from Nov. 1 and would prescribe liquid assets and cashreserve requirements.

title: FRANK BROOKS, 85, REALTY FINANCIER
description: R. Frank Brooks, a leader in Teal estate financing from 1912 to his retirement in 1972 as senior vice president of Brooks, Harvey & Co., died Sunday in New York Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 610 Park Avenue.

title: DECLINES PREVAIL ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock

title: SYRIANS HIT TWICE BY ISRAELI PLANES
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 30Israeli planes raided Syria twice today, striking at commando bases near Damascus in the morning and returning later to attack a Syrian Army camp, In between, Syrian forces shelled the Israeliheld Golan heights.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The advertisement in The Times of Oct. 16 by a group of scholars supporting the reelection of President Nixon was not a deviation from the trend. Many of us dopolls estimate about half the academic community. Various supporters will have various reasons for support, but a few of those reasons may be of interest to your readers.

title: Luigi Felici Is Dead at 65; Photographer for Vatican
description: ROME, Oct. 30Luigi Felici, official photographer of the Vatican since 1929, died here Saturday, it was reported today. He was 65 years old.

title: TRAFFIC COP GETS RUNAWAY VICTORY
